fields.headline: Royle defies cock-up gene
fields.trailText: Royle delighted; Francis unconcerned
fields.body:
Joe Royle, the Manchester City manager, hit the nail on the head when he claimed that his side never do anything the easy way. Three-nil up at half-time against a First Division side would usually allow supporters to sit back and enjoy the second-half procession. Not at Manchester City.

Francis Lee, the former City player and chairman, once joked that the club would be the most successful in the land if they awarded cups for cock-ups. Here, the Maine Road side would have deserved one if they had managed to lose this tie. Royle said: 'Just when you thought it was safe to go back on to the pitch ... there must be a gene running through this club because nothing is ever done easily.

'The players and faces may change over the years, but it's always the same old story.'

Judging by the first-half display, this was set to be a vintage Manchester City performance. Birmingham, flying high in the First Division, pressed their hosts early on but Royle's men survived those scares to take the lead through Andy Morrison.

Morrison, the former captain, was starting only his third game in 15 months for the club after a lengthy battle with a knee injury. He rose to head his first goal since scoring in a 6-0 win at Burnley 18 months ago.

It was a textbook header, but new buy Darren Huckerby's solo goal on the half-hour surpassed Morrison's effort. Huckerby waltzed past two defenders before scoring past goalkeeper Ian Bennett. Unfortunately, an ankle injury forced Huckerby out of the game shortly afterwards, but then a Shaun Goater penalty suggested City would survive without their pacy acquisition from Leeds United.

They did, but only just.

A classic curled strike by Martin Grainger and a close- range header from Dele Adebola before the hour was up left the home fans on the edge of their seats. But for a fine save by Nicky Weaver in the closing stages from Marcelo, the tie could have finished all square.

Birmingham manager Trevor Francis seemed remarkably unconcerned about the defeat. With a Worthington Cup semi-final against Ipswich on Tuesday, Francis pointed out his team's priorities.

Francis said: 'The semi-final was obviously in the back of the players' minds. That's more important to us, simply because we are in the semi-finals. It's the biggest game of some of my players' careers.'

So much for the romance of the FA Cup!

fields.headline: Spurs indebted to Doherty
fields.trailText: Tottenham win away - just.
fields.body:
Here was a turn-up for the books: Tottenham won an away game for the first time this season. The home DJ's idea to play the theme tune from It's a Knockout as the teams ran out thus backfired on Leyton Orient, though it took until added time for them to fall from the greasy pole.

Spurs seemed relieved to be heading for home comforts, Orient content with a pay night at White Hart Lane, as the fourth official signalled three minutes to play. Then Gary Doherty popped up to head his second goal in the week to settle a mundane tie between two teams lacking a cutting edge and Spurs had negotiated the mysteries of the Orient.

The Third Division side were well organised in defence, tigerish in midfield but rarely looked like pinching the goal that would surely have seen off Tottenham, who enjoyed the greater possession and chances but who were short of the wit and invention even to undo such humble opponents.

It was telling that the goal came from a set-piece, Doherty powering through a penalty-box crowd to head down past the unluckiest man of all, the Orient goalkeeper Ashley Bayes. Doherty had done similarly against Newcastle last Tuesday. Bought for £1 million from Luton Town last summer, the 20-year-old Irishman has become a more than useful weapon attacking from deep.

'No question - he'll be a defender instead of a striker,' said the Spurs manager George Graham afterwards, responding to discussion about Doherty's best position. 'Hopefully we can build on this and improve our away form in the league,' he added.

Don't bank on it; though spirited in time-honoured cup fashion, Orient were hardly the most potent of third-round opponents.

Even though it was only a few miles down through east London, Spurs' body language betrayed a team lacking confidence away from White Hart Lane, after just two points from 11 Premiership games on the road. By contrast, Orient were immediately, appropriately perky having won nine of 12 games at Brisbane Road and they quickly tested how much the aristocrats fancied slumming it, with Scott Houghton particularly eager to impress against his former club. Inside him, in the centre of midfield, Andy Harris and the Belgian Wim Walschaerts tackled to good effect.

Neil Sullivan had to be alert to hold Matthew Lockwood's fierce shot but, largely through Darren Anderton's ability to retain possession and see openings, Spurs managed to tentatively create a few decent chances. Sol Campbell bundled the ball into the net, only to be ruled offside. Ledley King several times troubled Bayes when arriving late in the penalty area, hitting the post with a header from Oyvind Leonharden's cross. Stephen Clemence then scooped the rebound on to the bar.

When Sergei Rebrov lifted a good chance over the bar with the outside of his right foot, and Orient made it to the interval level, the fear for Spurs was that a breakaway could yet undo them. After a further warning early in the second half, though, when Doherty had to be brave to block Houghton's shot from Walschaerts's cross, Spurs composed themselves once again.

Some Orient pressure failed to yield a real chance and Rebrov looked the likeliest match winner at the other end, brave Bayes twice spectacularly turning aside headers. The second yielded the corner, curled in menacingly by Anderton, from which Doherty delivered the last-ditch decider; maybe the home defence was still pre-occupied with the spritely Ukrainian.

And perhaps it really is lucky for Spurs, FA Cup winners in 1981 and 1991, when the year ends in one.

fields.headline: Viduka offers home comfort
fields.trailText: Viduka makes the difference.
fields.body:
Leeds moved into the fourth round of the FA Cup, but a Mark Viduka goal was all that separated David O'Leary's stuttering side from another embarrassing result at home.

O'Leary had demanded a command performance from his talented side, but also a hatful of goals to boost confidence and spirits in the Elland Road camp. Ultimately, though, Leeds again failed to convince.

'We are looking a team that is burdened by expectancy' a relieved O'Leary said afterwards. 'We are a good side, but one which is under-performing after setting ourselves such high standards.

'For two-and-a-half years its all been one-way, but now we're in a dip and people are questioning this team.'

And yet they had started brightly, threatening to demolish their Yorkshire neighbours before the first half had expired. Viduka grabbed his 14th goal of the season as Leeds ran riot - O'Leary had started with the attacking trio of Viduka, Alan Smith and Robbie Keane, and it was no surprise when they took a ninth-minute lead.

Danny Mills started the move with a long ball down the right wing. Matt Appleby failed to intercept, allowing Eirik Bakke to feed a wide-open Viduka from eight yards.

Leeds continued to pour forward in search of a second, killer goal. Smith set Keane free in the 27th minute with a flick-on header after winning a challenge with Steve Chettle. Keane was clean through, although in pausing to look behind him with only Miller to beat, it gave Chris Barker the opportunity to make a tackle and brilliantly deny the Republic of Ireland forward.

The second half was a dour affair, though, in which Leeds fans were left roaring their disapproval at their team's inability to kill the tie off - the Tykes could not muster a shot on target until the 61st minute, when substitute Bruce Dyer demanded a smart save from Paul Robinson.

The young Leeds goalkeeper was also forced to thwart Alex Neil and Neil Shipperley in the closing moments, only for Barnsley's problems in front of goal to haunt them again - they've scored just four times in the last two months.

Caretaker manager Eric Winstanley was satisfied with his side's showing, if disappointed with the result: 'The players are disappointed they have not got something out of this game because I thought we outplayed Leeds in the second half.

'We came here and defended properly in the first half before taking the game to them in the second and I don't think anyone can argue we deserved better things.'

fields.headline: Wiltord ends Atkins's dream
fields.trailText: The presence of Jimmy Glass was a reminder that miracles can happen in football, but - despite the solitary goal separating them - Carlisle were simply not equipped to bridge the gap between the bottom of the Third Division and second place in the Premiership.
fields.body:
The presence of Jimmy Glass was a reminder that miracles can happen in football, but - despite the solitary goal separating them - Carlisle were simply not equipped to bridge the gap between the bottom of the Third Division and second place in the Premiership.

Glass, the keeper whose last-gasp goal famously kept United in the League two years ago, returned here to a rapturous reception from fans with little else to warm them yesterday apart from the impressive resolve of their bit-part players. Arsenal smoothly negotiated this third-round tie without spicing their controlled performance with further goals following Sylvain Wiltord's sweetly struck winner in the 22nd minute.

Manager Arsène Wenger was satisfied by the professionalism of his players, notably Patrick Vieira, who refused to be riled when Ricard Prokas's determination to make a name for himself spilled over midway through the first-half. Vieira was injured by a two-footed lunge from Prokas, who escaped punishment.

'A player's career can be ended by that kind of tackle,' said Wenger. 'Vieira is so important in our midfield that I'm scared that some people go out to try and do him. It happened last week at Charlton when Graham Stuart was not punished and it happened again today.

'I can show you Patrick's shin protector. It's broken and full of blood. He didn't react, but it wasn't easy. He controlled himself well, but I was always a little bit nervous. Players can expect to be kicked, but they also expect to be protected. Maybe the referee didn't see it, but you tend to get fed up when it happens two or three times.'

Carlisle manager Ian Atkins saw the incident differently. 'You saw two very committed players going for the ball,' he said. 'When that happens, somebody - sometimes - gets hurt.'

Atkins was not entirely surprised by the London side's victory. He admitted before the tie that Arsenal would dispose of his team nine times out of ten. Presumably the tenth meeting would be postponed.

This is a manager who, with the start of the season only days away, didn't possess enough players to make up a team, never mind one capable of winning mundane Third Division matches.

Since then, he has assembled a collection of free transfers and loan signings who all earn less in a year than most Arsenal players pick up in a week. The gulf in salaries was cruelly reflected yesterday in the quality of the teams. Carlisle were honest and industrious, but so, so limited and would have been punished further if keeper Matty Glennon had not saved well from Wiltord, Fredrik Ljungberg and Dennis Bergkamp in a one-sided second half.

United's interest in the FA Cup is over for another season and perhaps for ever if they pursue a plan to enter the Scottish League next season should they fail to escape relegation to the Conference.

Their fate may be decided without Atkins, believed to be on his way out after his new bosses declined to give him their backing. But if this does prove to be Atkins' last game in charge, he can at least leave with the knowledge that the side he threw together shortly before the start of the season gave him a decent send-off.

fields.headline: Relief for Redknapp
fields.trailText: Kanouté the killer.
fields.body:
West Ham fans who had not made the trip to the Midlands could probably have heard a sigh of claret-and-blue relief back in east London. The name of Walsall could easily have been added to their list of recent knock-out nightmares. A side who cost £200,000 to assemble ran them mighty close. Ultimately, Premiership class told; the adventure of Joe Cole, the breathtaking finishing of Frédéric Kanouté, and the commitment of Stuart Pearce made the difference.

'In the end we're going down with honours,' said Ray Graydon. 'It was a bit of a disappointment because on a slightly better day we could have taken them to a replay.' Absolutely. Given West Ham's habit of self-destructing in the face of potential cup humiliations, the Bescot side was not an easy nut to crack.

Nothing like an early breakaway goal to soothe the nerves, and four minutes in Cole fed Kanouté, whose backheel was nudged home coolly by Frank Lampard. If it felt like the overture to a comfortable cruise for West Ham, Graydon's men had other ideas. Reward came just after the half-hour, when Ian Brightwell's free-kick was knocked on by Jorge Leitao, and Darren Wrack arrived to side-foot a deserved equaliser.

No self-respecting FA Cup third round intrigue would be the same without a dose of goalkeeping heroics: step forward James Walker. He produced a spectacular double save, beating away from Kanouté and Cole. Moments later he deflected Michael Carrick's powerful drive.

Walsall couldn't be faulted for application and ambition, and pumped the ball into the West Ham box. Their endeavour edged them closer - until they were exposed by a devastating counter attack. From a Walsall throw deep in West Ham territory, Titi Camara's surging run put the home defence on the back foot. Cole took up the baton, accelerating down the right before picking out Kanouté with a teasing, millimetre-perfect cross. The Frenchman nodded past Walker with ease.

West Ham tightened their grip and ought to have scored their way into the comfort zone. Walker was again inspired. One particular reflex save to repel Lampard was outstanding. He was helpless, though, when the marvellous Kanouté's scorcher of a strike - his seventh in five games - curled past. Unstoppable.

Walsall scrapped their way back into it when Wrack's misdirected shot bobbled to Angell, who injected hope for a grandstand finish. West Ham held on though. 'The attitude had to be right. Walsall are a very, very good football team and they'll be a credit to the First Division if they go up - and I hope they do,' concluded Hammers boss Harry Redknapp. He could afford to be magnanimous, having avoided the worst-case scenario. 'It's been the story of our life over the years, unfortunately. I'm well pleased to come through.' West Ham breathe again.

webTitle: Reid on parade at Palace again

fields.headline: Reid on parade at Palace again
fields.trailText: Palace put Sunderland on back foot again.
fields.byline: Peter Keeling at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Lightning almost struck twice here. Palace, conquerors last month of Sunderland in the Worthington Cup, valiantly held their Premiership rivals in this FA Cup rematch and fancy their chances of successfully taking on the Wearsiders in a replay.

Sunderland manager Peter Reid said: 'I thought they might have had a late penalty when our goalkeeper Thomas Sorensen dropped the ball. But we have the chance to go back there and end a run of abysmal performances against Palace.'

Alex Kolinko was the hero for Palace with some astounding second-half saves, especially in the opening minutes after the interval. Palace got their replay despite the handicap of playing with 10 men after Hayden Mullins was sent off in the 56th minute for wrestling Gavin McCann to the floor. Parity was reached only in the last four minutes when defender Stanislav Varga was dismissed by referee Mike Riley for a last-man foul on Dougie Freedman.

Palace manager Alan Smith thought they could have won despite enormous pressure from Sunderland: 'Despite long spells of defending, we had the best three chances of the game and could have had two penalties in the second half with a different referee. We can win the replay and complete the double; but we would never underestimate a team as good as Sunderland.'

When Sorensen was worried into dropping the ball by Mikael Forssell, he appeared to catch the Palace substitute's ankle in trying to recover the situation only for referee Riley to wave appeals away.

The game plan of Smith, who admitted he finds it easier to control a side like Sunderland, despite their quality, than a First Division side, ensured that record-breaking striker Kevin Phillips hardly had a clear chance.

The first break in the game came in the opening seconds when a cross from Andrejs Rubins ran across the six-yard line with nobody quick enough to get on the end of the opportunity. A sliding tackle by Kolinko kept out Danny Dichio in the 11th minute. The Latvian keeper made several excellent saves in the first half, but even he would have had no chance if Dichio had not mis-kicked from six yards.

The pressure after the restart was intense, but three fine saves by Kolinko from Alex Rae, Hutchison and Phillips were followed by a header from Varga that rattled the bar but bounced to safety.

There were other outstanding saves from Kolinko as Sunderland pressed. But the tempo oddly changed when Sunderland enjoyed their one-man advantage, and Palace finished the stronger side.

fields.headline: Millers' time fails to come
fields.trailText: Heskey double thwarts Millers.
fields.body:
With typical Scouse humour, Rotherham's manager, Ronnie Moore, shrugged his shoulders and accepted that his side's FA Cup final suits will have to be put back in mothballs for another year.

Former Tranmere striker Moore watched Liverpool stick three second-half goals past his Second Division outfit but, until the Premiership side eventually found another gear after an hour, this intriguing tie was beginning to look too close to call.

Emile Heskey struck with a double to take his season's tally to 15 while Dietmar Hamann also pounced with a fine finish. In the end, it was all too much for the Millers. But things might have been so different.

'We'll have to put the suits away for another year,' Moore quipped. 'But I was proud to come here in charge of a team. I'm just disappointed that we couldn't do more for our fans. If you come to Anfield and play with three strikers, you are either brave or silly. It may look like I was silly, but I think the scoreline flattered Liverpool a little bit.'

Heskey's diving header from Michael Owen's right-wing cross put Liverpool in control a couple of minutes after the break. Yet it was only when they lost defender Igor Biscan for a second bookable offence that Gèrard Houllier's side finally found their feet. Two goals in the space of as many minutes killed off Rotherham. Hamann smacked home from 16 yards on 72 minutes before Heskey thundered in another from just outside the box.

Rotherham, who boast the best away record in Division Two, clearly shocked Liverpool with their enterprising first-half display. Moore, however, remained pragmatic. 'We didn't get enough balls in to our front three,' he said. 'But it's still been a good day for us.'

fields.headline: Elementary, Watson
fields.trailText: It was worth waiting 17 years for this rip-roaring tie that saw Watford and Everton meeting in the FA Cup for the first time since the 1984 final - with the Merseysiders prevailing again.
fields.body:
It was worth waiting 17 years for this rip-roaring tie that saw Watford and Everton meeting in the FA Cup for the first time since the 1984 final - with the Merseysiders prevailing again.

This time around, it was much harder work for Everton - and a lot more entertaining. After Watford had gone ahead in the 21st minute through Tommy Mooney's 15th goal of the season, Everton had looked to be dead and buried.

But after half-time they suddenly discovered some self-belief. After Stephen Hughes had equalised in the 83rd minute, Steve Watson's valiant diving header two minutes into injury-time put the visitors into the fourth- round draw. That each side had a player sent off only added to the raucous excitement.

'I'm pleased that we got up enough steam to push Watford back,' said the Everton manager, Walter Smith. 'Although we didn't create many chances, we thought something might eventually happen and it did.' His opposite number, Graham Taylor felt, quite rightly, that his side had done enough to deserve a draw, and he took a swipe at referee Rob Styles for his over-fussy approach. 'Some referees do all they can to keep players on the pitch and some don't. But I'm not in any way criticising the ref,' he said disingenuously.

Everton had looked alarmingly short of confidence, which is hardly surprising considering their run of five defeats and one draw in the Premiership. Watford took the game to the visitors from the start, raiding aggressively down the right flank where Everton's left-back, Gary Naysmith, looked ill at ease.

After a series of scares in the Everton defence, Watford went ahead. Gifton Noel-Williams won an aerial tussle and Mooney, who had drifted behind the defence, shot deftly across the face of the goal and saw it strike the foot of the post and roll across the line.

Everton were showing little attacking threat, but at half-time they replaced Danny Cadamarteri with the American Joe-Max Moore. After the break, they were reinvigorated. Duncan Ferguson should have scored in the 54th minute when he hesitated before firing a left-foot shot wide. Watford were being pinned back and something had to give. In the 82nd minute, it did.

The Watford captain, Robert Page, fouled substitute Idan Tal and was shown the red card for his second bookable offence, and from the short free-kick that followed Hughes unleashed a thunderbolt into the roof of the net.

Moore was then also shown a second yellow for stupidly kicking the ball away - and with 10 men on each side it seemed all was set for a replay. Then Watson inexplicably appeared in the penalty area to torpedo himself towards Niclas Alexandersson's cross and deflect the ball past the Watford goalkeeper, Alec Chamberlain who, in a twist befitting all good Cup ties, was once on Everton's books.

fields.headline: Daggers drawn at Valley
fields.trailText: Solako rescues a second chance for Charlton.
fields.body:
Ah, the magic of the Cup.

How else can you explain why Dagenham and Redbridge, seventh in the Conference, could come within minutes of beating Charlton, similarly placed in the Premiership and conquerors of Arsenal just five days earlier?

Not only were the part-timers from Essex on the brink of writing another chapter in the long and illustrious history of FA Cup giant-killing, but they justifiably felt hard done by not to have beaten Charlton.

Barely five minutes of normal time remained when John Salako, who played in the 1990 final for Crystal Palace, scored a spectacular goal to salvage a draw for Charlton and spare their blushes. Up to that point it looked as though Junior McDougald, Texas-born and Tottenham-taught, was going to follow the likes of Ronnie Radford et al by scoring a goal to give David a mighty victory over Goliath.

McDougald has been round the houses since leaving Spurs as a teenager - Brighton, Chesterfield, Rotherham, Millwall, Chesterfield, Orient and even a spell with Toulon in France - but when he headed home Mark Janney's cross to put Dagenham ahead three minutes before half-time, he was set to become a household name.

Good work from his strike partner Danny Shipp, who held off the challenge of Richard Rufus, set up Janney to cross from the right, and the ball sailed over goalkeeper Dean Kiely for McDougald to thump home a header from close range. Few would deny Dagenham their lead. They took the game to Charlton from the start, and what they lacked in that extra yard of pace, they more than made up for in determination and effort.

'That is what the cup is all about,' admitted Alan Curbishley, the Charlton manager. 'Dagenham were the better team in the way they went about it, and we were minutes away from getting scalped. It's a fantastic achievement and they thoroughly deserved it.'

Garry Hill, his opposite number, said: 'I'm a very proud manager tonight, especially when you consider Charlton beat Arsenal here and scored three against Manchester United.

'You come to a Premiership club frightened you are going to get a trouncing, but within ten minutes we felt confident. I couldn't see Charlton scoring.'

Quite. Martin Pringle, replacing the injured Jonatan Johansson in attack, missed two good chances to give Charlton the lead, but Dagenham always looked more likely to open the scoring.

Steve Heffer and Lee Goodwin both missed with close-range headers before McDougald scored to set the large and noisy visiting contingent into raptures.

Charlton almost equalised two minutes into the second-half when Pringle headed against the inside of the far post, but that was a rare foray past an otherwise solid Dagenham defence.

Indeed, the visitors should have increased their lead before Charlton equalised. At one stage they had a three-to-one numerical advantage on the break, and then substitute Rob Haworth hammered a volley high over the bar when he had the goal at his mercy. At the other end, former QPR goalkeeper Tony Roberts did not have too much to do apart from deal with the varying accuracy of Charlton's long-range shooting.

Substitute Salako finally equalised, his swerving left-footed volley from 30 yards taking a deflection that wrong-footed Roberts.

That was in the 85th minute, and Dagenham had to face a furious finale that went into six minutes of stoppage time. But they hung on for the draw that means a replay at either Victoria Road or possibly West Ham's Upton Park on Wednesday week.

Hill, meanwhile, may or may not turn out for Woodham Town, his Sunday league side, this morning depending on the size of his hangover. 'I've been milking the situation for the last few days but it will be lager tonight,' he said with a laugh. 'I'll have to see how the manager feels before seeing if I play.'

fields.headline: Coventry in control
fields.trailText: Sky Blues step over the banana skin.
fields.body:
For Coventry the prospect of a decent cup run to supplement their improving Premiership form. For Swindon, the chance to strengthen their side for the Second Division survival battle ahead from record receipts of £175,000. In short, no hint of an upset here despite manager Andy King's somewhat bizarre post-match assessment that the Sky Blues had been there for the taking.

From the moment that Sol Davis dwelt too long on the ball inside his own box and paid the penalty, there was only one result. The only surprise was that Coventry needed nearly an hour more to score a second, clinching goal.

'In all a good performance,' said Coventry manager Gordon Strachan. 'You only had to look at the allocation of press tickets to see that something might have been on here. In fact the game could have been over a lot sooner, we have now lost only one of the last seven and that tells its own story.'

Craig Bellamy punished Davis's blunder after four minutes, dispossessing the defender and coolly angling his shot beyond Bart Griemink. Coventry's second came following a poor clearance by Chris Kirkland. Gary Breen blocked substitute Keith O'Halloran's shot and at the end of a sharp counter-attack Chippo laid his cross on a plate for fellow Moroccan Mustapha Hadji.

fields.headline: Canned Shrimps and dashed dreams
fields.trailText: Dreams dashed by an unfair margin.
fields.body:
The scoreline was a little cruel. Morecambe gave a good account of themselves for at least an hour and made Ipswich work hard for their place in the fourth round. Although there was no shock result there was certainly a shocking miss by Ipswich's Martijn Reuser, and the Conference side's few minutes of fame may be extended by endless replays and its inclusion on nightmare video compilations.

Morecambe's nickname is the Shrimps, and it was their spectators who were packed in like sardines, paying over the odds and more than the Ipswich fans as the club tried to squeeze maximum revenue from their honourable decision to keep the game at Christie Park. Some even crammed into the press box. 'I'm sitting next to the reporter from the News of the World,' one shouted into his mobile.

That's the third round of the FA Cup for you. Glamour all the way. Ipswich did their best to kill the romance of the occasion by scoring an early goal, but Morecambe responded with some of the best football of the afternoon.

Morecambe's best chance to take an early lead came when Steve Walters set John Quayle free on the right, but the scorer in the second-round victory over Cambridge was unable to keep his cross down with the stretched Ipswich rearguard backpedalling furiously.

George Burley praised the pitch for allowing Ipswich to play a passing game, though their opening goal was thoroughly route one. Alun Armstrong fastened on to Richard Wright's long clearance and his shot on the turn was well blocked by Dave McKearney, but, with the goalkeeper already committed, Marcus Stewart rolled the rebound past two defenders on the line for his fourteenth goal of the season.

For a few minutes, Morecambe were rocked, with Jermaine Wright forcing a save from Smith and Mattie Holland going close. But they steadied and caused Ipswich some anxious moments before half time.

Herman Hreidarsson was certainly sweating a bit when he let Quayle get goalside and had to resort to a none-too-subtle push in the penalty box in the 24th minute. With Richard Wright having to race out to whip the ball from Ryan Zico Black's toes, cover a shot from Walters and punch clear from Quayle's head after Stewart Drummond's near-post flick had wrongfooted the Ipswich defence, it was not difficult to see why Morecambe have acquired a reputation as the best footballing side in the Conference. 'Morecambe are a smashing side, as good as everyone told us,' Burley said. 'I had to ask the lads to step it up at half time and create more movement.'

They did so to such good effect that they could have made the game safe 10 minutes into the second half. Instead it turned into what already looks a strong contender for the worst miss of 2001.

Armstrong broke clear before squaring to the better- placed Reuser. All the Dutchman had to do was tap into an empty net, but he did not just miss an open goal, he nearly cleared the roof of the Umbro stand. The Tractor Boys were horrified while the Shrimps in the press box fell about laughing.

Ipswich finally killed the game when Armstrong headed his fourth goal since moving from Middlesbrough from Fabian Wilnis's cross. Jermaine Wright added a third as Morecambe succumbed to fatigue - 'We were dizzy chasing them by the end,' Jim Harvey admitted - but with the possible exception of a certain Dutch international, everybody enjoyed their day out by the Lancashire seaside.

fields.headline: Blues show their pedigree
fields.trailText: After half an hour of this match, with Chelsea somehow still to score, Barry Fry allowed himself to wonder if maybe, just maybe, this could be his day. The 3,500 visiting fans must have allowed their minds to wander down a similar path, but Chelsea did enough in the opening 20 minutes to open a chasm of class that, eventually, the scoreline reflected.
fields.body:
After half an hour of this match, with Chelsea somehow still to score, Barry Fry allowed himself to wonder if maybe, just maybe, this could be his day. The 3,500 visiting fans must have allowed their minds to wander down a similar path, but Chelsea did enough in the opening 20 minutes to open a chasm of class that, eventually, the scoreline reflected.

Two minutes before Chelsea's breakthrough Leon McKenzie had missed Peterborough's best chance, hitting high when played through by Andy Clarke, but in the end his profligacy proved inconsequential.

'I think we had to score six to make a game of it,' said Fry. 'They were just too good for us but I can't complain about any of my lads. We got a hammering but Chelsea are a great side.'

A great side, furthermore, with a great cup pedigree, and a manager who has already won knockout competitions in Italy and Spain. Chelsea's cup crown has slipped of late, with early defeats this season in Worthington and Uefa cups, but the holders' grasp on this trophy remains firm.

Gianfranco Zola put Chelsea on their way, running onto Gustavo Poyet's through-ball and chipping over the advancing Mark Tyler. Fry rates his young keeper as the best in the Nationwide League, and but for him the scoreline could have been much more embarrassing. A first-half save from Dennis Wise and another in the 71st minute from Zola's free-kick caught the eye, but this was not the best day to be the Peterborough goalkeeper.

In first-half stoppage time Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink extended the home side's lead, deftly controlling Wise's chipped pass before beating the keeper from five yards. With the game already out of their reach, Fry rearranged his side and instructed them to go in search of a goal. Instead, they conceded three more but it was less a case of the floodgates opening than their never quite being closed in the first place.

Twice in as many second-half minutes Chelsea attacked down the right and were rewarded with a goal. First, Poyet's centre allowed substitute Eidur Gudjohnsen to stab home, then Poyet himself reached Albert Ferrer's cross to score the fourth. Zola slotted home the fifth after Tyler was unable to hold Poyet's stinging 25-yard shot in an ultimately comfortable win for Claudio Ranieri's side.

'We have to honour them,' said Zola. 'They fought, they did whatever they could to cause us problems, but our better quality was enough to give us the game.'

fields.headline: A Ricketts reprieve
fields.trailText: Michael Ricketts' unerring scent for goal off the bench finally ended Yeovil Town's courageous FA Cup run 45 seconds into stoppage time of an absorbing third-round tie.
fields.byline: Ian Whittell at The Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
Michael Ricketts' unerring scent for goal off the bench finally ended Yeovil Town's courageous FA Cup run 45 seconds into stoppage time of an absorbing third-round tie.

Bolton narrowly avoided their first FA Cup loss to non-league opposition for 90 years, a defeat that would have made them the twenty-first League victims in Yeovil's illustrious cup fighting history, when Ricketts claimed his 16th goal of the season, his eleventh as a substitute.

Kevin Nolan chested a long free-kick into his path and, after a kind bounce, Ricketts lashed in an unstoppable right-foot shot. But Yeovil, who will surely end this season as a League side themselves, thoroughly deserved the standing ovation they received from both sets of supporters on the final whistle.

Sam Allardyce's calculated gamble of fielding a shadow team was always likely to be severely questioned by a Yeovil side currently heading the Conference with Manchester United-like domination. So it proved as the first division side, FA Cup semi-finalists last season, fell behind to a controversial opening goal from the visitors after 24 minutes.

Warren Patmore, an extrovert character who once retired from non-League football to try and become a professional golfer, was the scorer, collecting a Ben Smith through ball in a borderline offside position.

The pass looped over defender Mike Whitlow and presented Patmore with the chance to finish confidently from 15 yards, a goal that infuriated the home team although replays suggested Patmore may have been marginally on.

Italian youngster Emanuelle Morini forced Tony Pennock into a fine one-handed save with a curling left-foot shot from 20 yards and, two minutes before the interval midfielder John O'Kane levelled with an untidy goal.

Bolton opened the second half with increased urgency and an obvious sense of relief. O'Kane came close to his, and Bolton's, second as he rose at the far post to meet a Simon Charlton left-wing cross with a header that flew just wide.

By that stage Bolton had lost Holdsworth, leaving the home side down to 10 men for the game's concluding 23 minutes. The disadvantage did not prevent Bolton's continued domination. Frandsen's superb 20-yard free-kick again found Pennock inspired, this time the keeper producing a diving one-handed save.

fields.headline: York deflated
fields.trailText: FA Cup review
fields.body:
Generally a reasonable FA Cup day for Premiership teams, but some needed more luck than others.

Take Leicester in the 3-0 win at home to York. Ten minutes before half-time, with the score 0-0 and the Foxes struggling to get their act together, York's striker, Chris Iwelumo, was clean through with only the keeper to beat. But Iwelumo, who is on loan to the Third Division club from Stoke, dragged his shot wide, and Leicester went on to take command with two goals in seven minutes from Gary Rowett and Muzzy Izzett.

The scorer of their third was their substitute, Richard Cresswell, a former York player. His old team were so deflated by the time he came on that he could easily have had a hat-trick.

Manchester City and Derby also established 3-0 leads, against Birmingham and West Bromwich Albion respectively, but then subjected their fans to nail-biting finales by allowing the opposition to score twice.

City ultimately owed much to a brilliant Nicky Weaver save from Marcelo. Even Birmingham's manager, Trevor Francis, was raving about it. Birmingham have the consolation of a Worthington Cup semi-final clash with Ipswich on Tuesday, and Francis said: 'I think for most of my players, this will be the biggest moment of their careers, so we are not too disappointed at having been beaten today.'

West Brom's manager, Gary Megson, sang a different tune. 'It's too easy to start congratulating ourselves as gallant losers,' he explained. 'We should not have played in the manner we did. If it was going to come down to a nice, pretty game with good passing then there was only going to be one winner. We needed to make it the complete opposite to what Derby are used to but we didn't do that.'

Southampton also had to settle for a one-goal win against Sheffield United, through a disputed late penalty by Jason Dodd. It was awarded when United's keeper, Simon Tracey, appeared to bring down James Beattie.

It prompted a bitter verbal attack on the referee, David Elleray, and Southampton, by United's manager, Neil Warnock. 'From where the referee was standing I think he would have needed binoculars to see it,' he said.

'Our trouble is we haven't got enough con men. The higher the division you go the better the con men get. You have to be able to con well and they have done it very well this afternoon.'

No match produced greater excitement than Luton's 3-3 draw against QPR. The latter, who fought back from 2-0 and then 3-2 down, eventually forced a replay through a last-minute Gavin Peacock penalty conceded by Kurt Nogan with an unnecessary handball.

Luton's manager, Lil Fuccillo, said: 'Kurt did not know why he did it. It is annoying that one of our most experienced players should make a mistake that cost us the win. He was in tears in the dressing room.'

The most notable performances by lower division clubs included those of Bristol City who won 2-0 at Huddersfield, Scunthorpe who drew 2-2 at Burnley, and Notts County who twice came from behind to draw 2-2 at Wimbledon (attendnce: 4,931).

Bristol City's manager, Danny Wilson, seemed put out when it was suggested that his team had pulled off a 'shock'. He said: 'It might have seemed that way to some people, but not to me.

'Luck was smiling on us when they hit the post, but I thought we did enough to earn the win.' His opposite number, Lou Macari, agreed. 'We've got to give credit to Bristol City who played exceptionally well. They rose to the occasion and we didn't.'

Rising to the occasion was something that Gillingham were noted for when they emerged as one of the surprise teams in last season's competition. They shone again with a 3-2 win at Bournemouth. Their decisive goal stemmed from a mistake by Bournemouth's outstanding on-loan striker, Jermaine Defoe.

fields.headline: Chapple works magic
fields.trailText: Another league scalp for a Geoff Chapple side.
fields.body:
Alison Moyet, Southend's celebrity supporter, once had a hit with a song called 'That Old Devil Called Love'. As the Shrimpers fans streamed away yesterday they could have been forgiven for changing the words to 'That Old Devil Called Geoff Chapple' after the FA Cup had again sprinkled its magic over the Kingstonian manager.

Southend were his seventh League scalp of a 20-year career, which has taken him round a tour of the game's less glamorous outposts, such as Windsor, Woking and now Kingstonian.

Chapple first came to the public's attention 10 years ago this week when he led Woking to an unlikely victory at West Bromwich Albion in the third round, but he rated this performance even higher after his Conference strugglers withstood intense pressure once Eddie Akuamoah had put them in front with only eight minutes on the clock.

'This was probably tougher as we knew they'd throw the sink at us,' he said after watching Kingstonian reach the fourth round for the first time in their 116-year history. 'It was a rearguard action, a magnificent performance because it was pretty much one-way traffic in the second half.'

David Webb, himself an FA Cup legend having scored Chelsea's winning goal in the 1970 final against Leeds, was left with a sour taste in the mouth after watching his Third Division Southend side he manages outfought and outthought by the well-drilled visitors.

But one look at the non-League side's FA Cup pedigree showed that an upset was always on the cards here for not only did they have Chapple guiding them but their chief executive is Chris Kelly, better remembered as 'The Leatherhead Lip'. Kelly earnt a brief period in the spotlight 25 years ago when he led Leatherhead to the third round.

Akuamoah took the opportunity to put his own indelible stamp on FA Cup folklore when he picked up a Geoff Pitcher throw-in and was given the freedom of the Southend penalty area to drill a left-foot shot beyond Darryl Flahavan. 'It was a magnificent strike, all the hallmarks of the FA Cup,' said a rueful Webb.

With Kingstonian defending so doggedly and Southend struggling to find a way through, it was no surprise there was a combustible atmosphere that ignited seconds before half-time. Kingstonian's Gary Patterson appeared to elbow Ben Abbey and it sparked a brawl involving every player on the pitch except the two goalkeepers.

Once the referee had sorted out the mess he decided to send off Patterson and Southend's Leroy Roget.

Tempers were kept largely in check in the second-half but perhaps Southend could have done with some fire in their bellies. For all their possession, they resorted for most of the game to humping high balls which keeper Gavin Kelly, on loan from Tottenham, dealt with comfortably.

The one scary moment for the visitors came in the 76th minute when Daniel Webb came close to saving his dad's blushes with a shot from an acute angle that hit the post.

Otherwise, Chapple was pretty much able to enjoy the last few minutes, certainly much more than he was able to when Kingstonian beat Kettering 3-2 in the FA Trophy final at Wembley last May. That was the fifth time he had triumphed in the non-League's premier competition.

'What's it like to lead a team out at Wembley?' Sir Alex Ferguson was asked recently at the draw for this year's FA Trophy held at Old Trafford. 'Don't ask me,' he replied. 'Ask Geoff Chapple.'

Now Chapple would like to pit his wits against Sir Alex in the next round.

webTitle: Chasers fall away by falling away

fields.headline: Chasers fall away by falling away
fields.standfirst: While Manchester United continue to accumulate points on the road their main rivals are all suffering from travel sickness. Paul Wilson reports
fields.trailText: While Manchester United continue to accumulate points on the road their main rivals are all suffering from travel sickness.
fields.body:
How bad are Tottenham Hotspur? Listening to Richard Littlejohn and his gloomy mates on the radio every Saturday evening one could easily conclude Spurs are the dullest team in the Premiership and that visits to White Hart Lane are about as uplifting as the Christmas omnibus edition of EastEnders. Yet George Graham's team have won eight of 11 home matches this season and drawn the other three.

Arsenal and Manchester United have won nine at home and Spurs, unlike United, have yet to be beaten in front of their own crowd. Even allowing for the fact that Graham's sides will never win awards for cavalier football, this is not the sort of form that usually has supporters commiserating with each other and questioning the aptitude of their manager. But then again, look where Spurs' impressive home form has got them. They start the new year as the lowest-placed London club in the Premiership.

The reason is not difficult to spot. Spurs have a big fat zero in their away wins column, and a meagre two points to show from 11 games on their travels this season. This is a pathetic return by any standards, and the worst away record in the Premiership, though Spurs are not alone in setting wildly different standards at home and away. Chelsea, the season's next worst travellers, have won eight at home and none away. The expected challengers to Manchester United have all fallen away because... they have fallen away.

Arsenal and Liverpool both boast the same nine from 11 home wins as United, but whereas the defending champions have managed six away wins, Arsène Wenger and Gérard Houllier are both fretting about a string of away defeats.

United's away tally is healthily in the black, with 20 for to 10 against, Ipswich's is level, and everyone else is in the red. Leeds United, those other expected Champions League contenders, have scored just seven times to Ipswich's 16 in losing four away games. Although the Champions League has undoubtedly been a distraction, Leeds simply appear to be having an old-fashioned bad run on the domestic front. But what has been going on everywhere else? Why has the division between home and away suddenly become so pronounced? Why is the malaise affecting the bigger, more ambitious clubs, and not the smaller ones?

Graham says he is baffled by Spurs' away form: 'It's the puzzle of the season and I can't quite put my finger on where we are going wrong.' Hmm. Spurs' defeat at Manchester United last month was not too much of a puzzle. Graham's players appeared to have worked out in advance they were not going to take anything from the game and decided to get it over as quickly as possible. At Old Trafford that is perhaps understandable. What baffles Spurs fans is why the team take the same attitude to places like Southampton and Ipswich.

Darren Anderton is refreshingly honest on the subject: 'We haven't played well away from home this season; we've been awful really.' Steffen Freund pointed out that the United game was all too typical: 'Away from home we stay too deep and don't get forward enough to create pressure.' Yes but why? The more critical of Spurs fans blame Graham, for being old-school enough to try to stifle games and play for a point away from home. If so, the strategy is not working. For all the away points they have picked up this season Spurs might as well have started every game with three strikers and a devil-may-care attitude.

On the whole, however, Chelsea are not a great argument for such a policy. Like Graham, Claudio Ranieri is at a loss to explain dismal away results, but he professes not to be too worried about them. 'I can't criticise my players. We have been playing well but not getting much luck,' he said. 'We should have won at Middlesbrough, when we had several chances to score but lost to a deflection. We were two-nil up at Ipswich and missed two more excellent chances to kill the game before Ipswich came back. Obviously I wish we had taken those chances, but you don't get everything you wish for. I have to be happy that we are playing well enough to create chances. The time to worry is when you are not.'

Between the opposite extremes of carefree Chelsea and cautious Spurs, Arsenal and Liverpool have more prosaic explanations. Wenger has admitted his side need to be 'more audacious' away from home, but there is another problem specific to Arsenal. The Gunners used to have a defence that built a platform for results away from home, and at the moment they don't. For the first time in years, Arsenal are having to chase games. 'It is a problem I've never had before,' Wenger said. 'I've hardly ever had to put out a side lacking David Seaman, Tony Adams and Martin Keown.'

And Liverpool? Well, apart from not being as ruthlessly professional in shutting out opponents and holding on to an advantage as their predecessors from Anfield's glory years, Liverpool might just have been unlucky. They were winning 2-0 at Elland Road in November, hardly a sign of a hesitant away side, when a mistake by Christian Ziege triggered a barely credible 4-3 defeat. Neutral observers reckon the defeat at Middlesbrough two weeks ago was one of the most one-sided games in Premiership history, with Boro pinching a result that Houllier was at a loss to explain, following as it did the first away win at Old Trafford for two years.

'Our away form is quite good,' Houllier said, 'but our results need to improve.' Perhaps it is true, as Chelsea's Ranieri says, that this sort of thing is quite normal in football. Perhaps what needs explaining is the abnormality of Manchester United, who chase games better than anyone else in the country when they have to, but mostly don't have to. Travelling United fans regularly goad rival supporters with chants about providing their 'Cup final', but it is possible that is not happening any longer. Smaller clubs do not seem to be raising their game for United as they once did, but opting for damage limitation instead. Meanwhile it is Arsenal, Chelsea, Liverpool and Spurs who are playing cup finals every other week.

webTitle: It's all over bar the quoting

fields.headline: It's all over bar the quoting
fields.trailText: If there's one group less interesting on the subject of their work than thespians it is professional footballers.
fields.body:
'Now over to Garth Crooks at the Theatre of Dreams.'

'Thanks, Ray.' (Assumes most serious expression) 'Sir Peter: a full house, a flawless performance, a standing ovation. Does it get any better?'

'Well, obviously, we're all happy with the result. But at the end of the day it's too early to get carried away. We'll be taking each performance as it comes.'

'Well, absolutely, Sir Peter. (Pause) What about the boy Othello? Magic?'

'Well, obviously. He gives us a lot of options up front. He's a big lad. Not afraid to put himself about. Gels well. Natural finisher. Lovely lad.'

'Tremendous. And little Desdemona?'

'Yeah, well, Dessie's come in and done a phenomenal job of work. There were a lot of people who questioned her stamina, her commitment, her... how can I put this... balls. But we don't hear so much from them now. (Chuckles) Do we?'

'Well, absolutely.' (Fiddles with earpiece) 'Sir Peter, I'm afraid that's all we've got time for. Thank you so much. Back to the studio.'

'Thanks, Garth. And Sir Peter Hall. Great to see him back on the programme. Less happy news from the West End of London - Gerald Sinstadt.'

'Jeffrey, a sad day for everyone here at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, with the news that mathematically it's all over. Three weeks and your run in the top flight, plying your trade among the big boys, will be at an end.'

'Yeah, at the end of the day it's the lads I feel gutted for. They've given everything. The lot. You should see the scenes in the changing room now. Grown men crying in the showers. They're... they're...'(Chokes up)

'Upset?'

'Beyond upset. Utterly gutted. Words fail me.'

(Long pause)

'Well, thank you very much, Jeffrey Archer. Back to the studio.'

What a bunch of baloney. Very nearly unreadable. And imagine if every director and every actor was given his or her say. If after every episode of EastE nders the cameras would wait outside Albert Square for Ian Beale to appear and tell the world: 'At the end of the day, Carts came in from the right and delivered the perfect line and all I had to do was put a finish on it.'

Horrible to contemplate. Yet if there is one group less interesting on the subject of their work than thespians it is professional footballers, and every day similar nonsense is parroted incessantly on our various TV channels and reported verbatim in multifarious national newspapers.

It is very rare for this column, in any of its guises, to agree with the Daily Mail, but it's hard not to concur with Ian Wooldridge's comment on Wednesday that 'it would now appear that no report is complete without some participant stating the imbecilically obvious'.

A fine sentiment although somewhat at odds with the rest of the Mail that day, which included:

Walter Smith: 'There's no point trying to hide behind excuses but... '(page 73)

Glenn Hoddle: 'But what I really like is the way that he plays with his head up.' (page 74)

Mart Poom: 'I just can't wait for each game to come along at the moment. The main thing for this club is to make sure we stay in the Premiership. Everything else is just a bonus.' (page75)

Lucas Radebe: 'On paper no one can beat us but, unfortunately... '(page 76)

Graham Taylor: 'Things seem less of a mess now than they did on Boxing Day, sitting around looking at cold turkey.' (page 77)

Alex Ferguson: 'Having taken maximum points from our first two European games, we are in an excellent position.' (page 78)

Dean Kiely: 'In this League, you have to fight to earn the right to play.' (page 79)

Bobby Robson: 'I don't condone what Kieron Dyer did. He's apologised and was silly. He has to learn to control himself but... ' (page 80)

Beyond padding. Beyond blotting-paper. A goo of unfinished papier-mché that seeps into the brain and rots it senseless. There's no escaping it and no stopping it.

Only last week, the High Priest of Babble, the Sun's Brian 'Wooly' Woolnough (random quotes: 'Kevin Keegan has the energy of a horse and the mental capacity of a scientist'; 'take away David Beckham and Paul Scholes and our technique cupboard is bare'; 'Group A in Euro 2000 was pressure like never before on the man known as the Messiah') was, according to the UK Press Gazette , 'wooed to the Daily Star by a fabulous salary hike and promise of club-class travel around the world'. You sense it was the club-class travel that swung the deal.

Wooly is the leader of the pack. When football writers gather to receive their post-match quotes, it is always Wooly who gives the sign to David Davies, or whoever, that the Sundays have had their fill and it is time for the Mondays to gather in a corner and receive exactly the same but sufficiently different quotes. Thus it is that Saturday matches generate sufficient 'quotage' to fill not one report but two.

Double bubble for the merchants of babble. Before long Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays will be in on the act. The 'quotage' will be overflowing. Like the magic porridge pot, it will generate enough stuff to drown us all.

The Woolster is also the eminence grise of Hold the Back Page , a programme that, depending on your mood, is either the funniest or the most depressing on television. It can be deeply funny to watch grown men ponder, furrow their brows and generally behave like someone who has been raised 20 grand he doesn't have, before finally saying, with a grimace, something like: 'I don't think the Man United back four can accommodate both the Nevilles.'

There are other times when it's not. When it leaves you feeling dispirited and not a little worried. Bereft of hope that romance and humour and fun will ever return to football and football writing. For while there is nothing funnier than people taking something essentially trivial achingly seriously, even the best jokes can go on too long.

Mercifully, there may be an escape. One ex-sports editor once asked me rhetorically, 'Do you want to know the four most important sports in this country, son?' And, before I could stop him, answered: 'Football, Football, Football and Football.' But those days may be about to end.

It is the first week in Janu ary, but what has football to offer for the rest of the year? United winning the Premiership for the seventh time in nine years? Yippee-skippee. A tense relegation battle involving Bradford City? Can't wait. A non-Premiership team winning the FA Cup? Won't happen.

Up against this motley crew there is a tranche of events that may interest even the non sports fan: the Six Nations, Istabraq at Cheltenham, the Lions tour of Australia, an Ashes series we might win, Lewis v Tyson, Henman at Wimbledon, Tiger Woods and the Ryder Cup. Make the most of it while you can. In 2002, it's the World Cup against the Commonwealth Games.

webTitle: Fear of losing that fosters United's winning habit

fields.headline: Fear of losing that fosters United's winning habit
fields.trailText: The champions are under pressure too, says Paul Wilson.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson claims he personally shed few tears over missing last season's FA Cup. 'The third round being so early put me off,' he said. 'For some clubs the Cup represents a last chance of glory, so how can you start it in December?'

The Manchester United manager admits his players took the enforced withdrawal rather harder, however, and Gary Neville would be among the first to agree.

'We have never treated the FA Cup as anything other than a big competition,' the England defender said. 'There was nothing we could do last season because it was taken out of our hands, but we all missed it. Nothing surpasses the FA Cup final as a one-off occasion in my opinion. It is the greatest fixture in the English calendar and always will be - that's how highly I rate it. I have been lucky enough to win a few Wembleys, but even when we lost it was still a memorable day.'

The surest way to annoy Ferguson at the moment - apart from reporting job offers from Aberdeen, which gets you ejected from the interview room - is to mention a possible Treble. If United are back in the FA Cup, the theory goes, they are bound to win it, and with the title a formality they can afford to concentrate on the Champions League. 'It's much too early for that sort of talk,' Ferguson said. 'A lot of stuff has got to conspire in your favour first. Injuries, cup results and so on. The FA Cup means just one thing to me - sudden death. One penalty decision against you, an own goal or a bad deflection off a kneecap, and you can be out. Then that's it for another year. We'll be happy just to get through this round.'

Neville will second that. 'You are not successful until you have won something, no one knows that better than us,' he said. 'People say Manchester United win everything, but just in my short time here we have been knocked out of two Champions League quarter-finals and a semi, we have lost two championships and been beaten in an FA Cup final. We lost a Double within a week at the end of my first season. Those were all massive disappointments, but because we have kept essentially the same players and the same manager, we have grown stronger because of them.

There is a new maturity about the team this season, I don't think we have ever been as confident going into matches. That's because we all believe in each other because we have been through so much together, the downs as well as the ups. It is simply not true to say Manchester United don't know what it's like to lose, or have never experienced disappointment. OK, we don't get relegated, but successes at this club tend to be brushed aside quite quickly. It's often the defeats that stay with you longest.'

If these words make ominous reading for Fulham, they are meant to. 'We appreciate this could be a tricky tie for us, away from home,' Neville said. 'There's no doubt Fulham are a good side. I saw them at Anfield and they dictated the pace of the game in the first half. I don't think we'll be letting them do that.'

fields.headline: Delivering Fayed's  Fulham dream
fields.standfirst: Christian Damiano might not be as well-known as Jean Tigana but his contribution is vital as Craven   Cottage - and its wealthy owner - welcomes Manchester United for today's big game
fields.trailText: Christian Damiano might not be as well-known as Jean Tigana but his contribution at Craven Cottage is vital.
fields.body:
Even the most sophisticated of people receive naff Christmas presents, it seems. As Christian Damiano sits at the Fulham training ground in unaccustomed suit and tie, trying patiently to explain in his developing English how the club's French renaissance has been shaped, your eye is drawn to his socks. They have the club crest on them.

Christian who? The same was asked of Gross at Tottenham, who came, saw and confounded. This one, though, sounds as if he knows what he is doing. If Jean Tigana is the architect of Fulham's Premiership plan, Damiano is the draughtsman - one of those unsung, brilliant, career coaches, who abound in French football and one who contributed significantly to their becoming world champions.

Today offers the ultimate test for Tigana and Damiano to see how their construction is taking shape, with the visit of Manchester United to Craven Cottage for an FA Cup third-round tie to relish - a meeting of runaway leaders of Premiership and First Division. Damiano smiles a toothy grin at the prospect.'They are an example, the best team perhaps in the world,' he says. 'It is modern football. They can score from every player. They have big movement. They take risks. They have great passion.'

Can Fulham play this football? 'We need to play 140 per cent,' he says, with that French footballing fondness for expressing everything in percentages (Arsène Wenger often talks of players being at 80 per cent of their capacity, the team at 90 per cent of their efficiency). 'We are progressing but we don't play every game at the same level as them.'

Even if you take that as a no, the fascination of watching them try should be, ooh, 150 per cent. Damiano accepts that the absence of the captain, Chris Coleman, who broke his right leg in a car accident last week, is a huge blow but believes that any replacement should be familiar with the all-important system - 'and then it comes to the quality of the player'.

As Fulham slipped out of contention for the First Division play-offs last season, the then manager, Paul Bracewell, gradually realised, apparently, that the club's colourful owner Mohamed al-Fayed was looking for a 'name' to replace him. Indeed, Fayed phoned Eric Cantona, but he was too busy with beach soccer and other acting roles and recommended Tigana.

But Tigana is proving that he is more than a name. Shrewdly, he spent the last weeks of last season observing and analysing the club and their needs. Then he placed a call to Nice, to Christian Damiano, to offer him the job as his assistant. The man from near Monte Carlo said yes and the revolution began.

'He has brought a good team of coaches around him,' said Wenger last week as his first response to a question about Tigana's success. Gérard Houllier believes Damiano to be a top man. 'I like him. He's very important to them,' says the Crystal Palace boss Alan Smith, formerly Fulham's academy director. 'But I also have the utmost respect for Tigana. The vision, the system is his. I also like his lack of ego.'

Damiano knew Tigana as a player from the great French team of the Eighties when the elegant midfielder was Michel Platini's lieutenant. They first met in 1993 when Tigana was a student on a coaching course at Clairefontaine run by Damiano. 'He was in my group for four years,' says Damiano. 'He arrived and he wanted to learn. Every big player understands it is different work being a coach. You learn the physical, the tactical, the psychological. You need a big knowledge for everything. Jean wanted to learn to be a big coach. Always he was very interested in everything.' Lessons there for every English player - and chairman - who believes you just have to have had a playing career.

Tigana became manager of Monaco and remained in touch with Damiano, by now Houllier's trusted assistant with the under-18 team that included Thierry Henry and which won the European Championship in 1996, Henry being a Monaco player at the time. Damiano then joined Aime Jacquet's staff, monitoring the French national team players in Italy ahead of the '98 World Cup. 'I would spend seven or eight days observing sessions with Marcello Lippi and Arrigo Sacchi,' Damiano recalls.

After a year as assistant to Jacquet's successor, Roger Lemerre, Damiano answered a call from struggling Nice but soon jumped at Tigana's offer. 'There was big politics in Nice,' he says. 'It was not possible to build there like here in Fulham.'

The work began in earnest in pre-season, the third musketeer, fitness coach Roger Propos, coming into his own. Fulham went to Clairefontaine, where the players were introduced to a regime of three sessions a day, at 7am, 10am and 2.30pm. 'A few of the old pros found it a bit of a shock,' says the defender Andy Melville, 'They were used to half past 10. But we got on with it and enjoyed it in the end. It makes sense.'

Methods de rigueur in France but still unusual in England, such as dental check-ups, to gauge posture and balance, were introduced. Body fat is measured every month. 'Paul Bracewell also talked to us about diet and nutrition and our fat was down to 13, 12, 11 per cent,' says Melville. 'This year it's 10, nine and eight.' Tigana has also imposed an alcohol ban.

'The players understand why the food you eat is important for the effect on the blood,' says Damiano. 'They have it explained to them very well. The fantastic attitude has been the passion of the players for the work. They are always ready, always interested. It is easy to build on this.'

Indeed, it must seem simple at times to Tigana and Damiano. They have honed with their methods an already competent group of home-grown players, not yet adding significantly, even if the purchase of the Henryesque - though left-footed - striker Louis Saha from Metz for £2.5 million has gilded the lily. The training regime is based on 'many, many repetitions', according to Damiano, likening it to a golfer grooving his swing. 'If you learn very well the basic skills, it is possible to add things,' he says. 'It is easy to train players. When things are automatic, it is not then a problem to take a risk.'

'He is very quiet, very efficient, pays great attention to detail,' says Alan Smith. 'They practise one thing at a time until they have mastered it.'

Tedious? 'No, it's fun,' says the striker Barry Hayles. 'It changes day in, day out. There's a lot of ball work, one- and two-touch. Tigana is always cracking jokes and Christian has new ideas and techniques. Like, we will have a heading day. You think "boring", but the way he does it, it is competitive and enjoyable, with new games where you head the ball throughout.'

It has combined to produce an enlightened brand of build-from-the-back passing football, with players such as the right-back Steve Finnan and Sean Davis in midfield emerging as more rounded performers.All are encouraged to be adventurous most likely to be seen today in the gifted little left-winger on loan from Rennes, Fabrice Fernandes. 'You accept mistakes as long as players work hard to get the ball back,' says Damiano. 'If you want players to take risks and have success, you must do this.'

An hour-and-a-half before kick-off on match days, Tigana will show them video clips of the opposition - though he might be tempted to forego that today so as not to frighten them - giving pointers about how to counter them. Then he will deliver his main team talk. 'All he says really is go out there and play,' says Hayles. It mirrors Wenger at Arsenal; the real work long complete. 'The time for reflection is not when you step on the pitch,' Tigana himself has said. 'It comes weeks before.'

Not that Tigana is some serene purist. 'He can lose it,' says Melville, once subjected to Peter Reid at Sunderland. 'He'll let you know if he's not happy. He raises his voice. But he'll also think about what he's going to tell the players as well. Sometimes in this game, things can be said at half-time that are out of order.'

'At Sheffield Wednesday, he came in at half-time very irate,' Hayles recalls. 'It was the first time I saw him say a lot at half-time. He dragged the paper off the wall, got his pen out and started scribbling things. A lot of managers would bawl you out, but he tends to show you how things are going wrong and how to change it. He pulls people out and has a word with them individually. He's done it with me and I appreciate that. It's helped my confidence.'

Tigana, like Wenger and Houllier, also accepts that this is a contact sport. Against Portsmouth, Fulham were in danger of being bullied. Tigana stressed the need for physical competition in the second half. 'Everyone says we can't handle that,' says Melville. 'But I think we thrive on it, if anything. He says, "Keep your discipline but don't pull out of the tackles. Show them what you are about."'

Tigana is bucking the current trend, that the greatest of players do not make the best coaches. 'I've often had this discussion with Michel Platini,' Tigana has said. 'He thought things were very simple and he couldn't understand why someone couldn't do this or that.

'I looked at things the other way round. I have spent entire nights thinking about those things I did naturally, about how I could find training which would allow my players to do those things. If you have a team or players who don't understand, you have to find training exercises which will make them understand. I love communicating and passing on knowledge.'

'He has personality,' says Wenger. 'He has pushed through his vision of football and sticks to it. He already had a good team and now he has added Saha. This and his coaches, explains his success.' It adds up to a microcosm of the English game. Tigana's predecessor Kevin Keegan was a talkative motivator for both club and country; overseas expertise is adding to the passion for the game.

'You have spirit, you have fantastic spectators, you have TV, you have money. The game here is a church,' says Damiano. 'Now you need to play the international game.' And you notice that those Fulham socks of his are pulled up.
