The fantastic attitude has been the passion of the players for the work. They are always ready, always interested. It is easy to build on this.' Indeed, it must seem simple at times to Tigana and Damiano. They have honed with their methods an already competent group of home-grown players, not yet adding significantly, even if the purchase of the Henryesque - though left-footed - striker Louis Saha from Metz for £2.5 million has gilded the lily. The training regime is based on 'many, many repetitions', according to Damiano, likening it to a golfer grooving his swing. 'If you learn very well the basic skills, it is possible to add things,' he says. 'It is easy to train players. When things are automatic, it is not then a problem to take a risk.' 'He is very quiet, very efficient, pays great attention to detail,' says Alan Smith. 'They practise one thing at a time until they have mastered it.' Tedious? 'No, it's fun,' says the striker Barry Hayles. 'It changes day in, day out. There's a lot of ball work, one- and two-touch. Tigana is always cracking jokes and Christian has new ideas and techniques. Like, we will have a heading day. You think "boring", but the way he does it, it is competitive and enjoyable, with new games where you head the ball throughout.' It has combined to produce an enlightened brand of build-from-the-back passing football, with players such as the right-back Steve Finnan and Sean Davis in midfield emerging as more rounded performers.All are encouraged to be adventurous most likely to be seen today in the gifted little left-winger on loan from Rennes, Fabrice Fernandes. 'You accept mistakes as long as players work hard to get the ball back,' says Damiano. 'If you want players to take risks and have success, you must do this.' An hour-and-a-half before kick-off on match days, Tigana will show them video clips of the opposition - though he might be tempted to forego that today so as not to frighten them - giving pointers about how to counter them. Then he will deliver his main team talk. 'All he says really is go out there and play,' says Hayles. It mirrors Wenger at Arsenal; the real work long complete. 'The time for reflection is not when you step on the pitch,' Tigana himself has said. 'It comes weeks before.' Not that Tigana is some serene purist. 'He can lose it,' says Melville, once subjected to Peter Reid at Sunderland. 'He'll let you know if he's not happy. He raises his voice. But he'll also think about what he's going to tell the players as well. Sometimes in this game, things can be said at half-time that are out of order.' 'At Sheffield Wednesday, he came in at half-time very irate,' Hayles recalls. 'It was the first time I saw him say a lot at half-time. He dragged the paper off the wall, got his pen out and started scribbling things. A lot of managers would bawl you out, but he tends to show you how things are going wrong and how to change it. He pulls people out and has a word with them individually. He's done it with me and I appreciate that. It's helped my confidence.' Tigana, like Wenger and Houllier, also accepts that this is a contact sport. Against Portsmouth, Fulham were in danger of being bullied. Tigana stressed the need for physical competition in the second half. 'Everyone says we can't handle that,' says Melville. 'But I think we thrive on it, if anything. He says, "Keep your discipline but don't pull out of the tackles. Show them what you are about."' Tigana is bucking the current trend, that the greatest of players do not make the best coaches. 'I've often had this discussion with Michel Platini,' Tigana has said. 'He thought things were very simple and he couldn't understand why someone couldn't do this or that. 'I looked at things the other way round. I have spent entire nights thinking about those things I did naturally, about how I could find training which would allow my players to do those things. If you have a team or players who don't understand, you have to find training exercises which will make them understand. I love communicating and passing on knowledge.' 'He has personality,' says Wenger. 'He has pushed through his vision of football and sticks to it. He already had a good team and now he has added Saha. This and his coaches, explains his success.' It adds up to a microcosm of the English game. Tigana's predecessor Kevin Keegan was a talkative motivator for both club and country; overseas expertise is adding to the passion for the game. 'You have spirit, you have fantastic spectators, you have TV, you have money. The game here is a church,' says Damiano. 'Now you need to play the international game.' And you notice that those Fulham socks of his are pulled up.

webTitle: Coleman's stark lesson for my Palace pups

fields.headline: Coleman's stark lesson for my Palace pups
fields.trailText: Alan Smith on how Chris Coleman's car crash brought back some unhappy memories.
fields.body:
Seeing Chris Coleman in hospital recovering from his serious car crash last week reminded me how quickly the fame and glory of a footballer's career can be snatched away - as I know from painful experience.

Thirty years ago I was in almost the same position - pulled from the mangled wreckage of a car, with both legs and one arm broken and my playing career on the line.

I was 22, a young professional at Brentford, and was looking forward with hope to a long and successful playing career. That dream came to an end when I hit three trees as I skidded out of control and off the road, although it was to be another year before I realised I would never play again.

I spent six months at the RAF's rehabilitation unit at Headley Court, learning to walk again just as Douglas Bader had done a generation earlier. It gave me plenty of time to consider my future and the world outside football, and certainly my life took a different direction. I was lucky enough to be taken on by Sidney Black, who was Wimbledon's chairman at the time and ran a property company. I learnt all about the property world and am now a Fellow of the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors.

Coaching came some time later - what was foremost in my mind was having a full-time job and studying for a career. Fortunately it does not seem so serious for Chris, who hopes to be playing again by the start of next season despite breaking his right leg in three places. When I visited him last week, he was sitting up in bed and chatting to Jean Tigana, who joked that he would let me have Chris on loan for the rest of the season!

But more seriously, Chris is lucky to be alive and I'm sure he will spend much of the next few months reflecting on what might have been and where his life is heading.

He has been a good friend as well as a colleague since he signed for Palace from Swansea almost 10 years ago. He has progressed to become one of the best central defenders in the League, captain of his club and country, and a well-respected professional. He has a beautiful wife and four lovely kids, a nice house in the country, and a lifestyle to envy.

Yet everything could have been snatched away in seconds on a cold, wet road. One minute you are preparing for the most glamorous FA Cup tie imaginable, against Manchester United, and the next minute the rescue services are debating whether they need to amputate your foot. That is why I always try to drum into young players the need to appreciate how lucky they are. We flew up to the North-East on Thursday to prepare for yesterday's FA Cup tie against Sunderland by staying in a magnificent hotel, yet still some of my players were complaining about being away from home for an extra day. It tends to be the smarter ones who respond by thinking, 'I like this life so I'll work harder to attain it.'

They have a chance to push themselves a step closer to the big time this week when we play Liverpool in the first leg of our Worthington Cup semi-final. Chris Coleman was in the Palace side when we lost to them at this stage five years ago, during my first spell in charge. We had a very good team then, with players such as Nigel Martyn, Gareth Southgate, Chris and John Salako. Unfortunately our leading striker, Chris Armstrong, was serving a suspension for smoking cannabis and unable to play in the semi-finals, in which we lost both games 1-0. We also lost to Manchester United in the FA Cup semi-final that season.

I had been Steve Coppell's assistant when we lost to United in the FA Cup final five years earlier, and I can confirm the old cliché that it is more painful to lose in a semi-final than a final.

Both teams are very different now. One survivor on our side is Simon Rodger, whom I signed from non-league Bognor and is set for a testimonial after 10 years at the club. We rarely get that sort of loyalty any more and I wonder if 'Jolly' - as the fans call him - will be the last of his kind.

Liverpool no longer have their old air of invincibility and are more likely to concede silly goals, although I've noticed a big improvement in recent games I have watched. Gérard Houllier has brought with him a different style to the Liverpool of old, which is more athletic, and he has a fairly young side. Because the tie is over two legs, it is important for us not to be too gung-ho at home, and I think the first leg at Selhurst Park may be more like a European game than an old-fashioned English cup-tie. The best we can hope for is to take a one- or two-goal lead to Anfield, while I have to admit that a home defeat would make it very, very difficult for us to get to the final.

We also have a young side - younger than our class of '95 - but potentially better, and I am working hard to do everything I can to improve the players I have and the squad. This may be the club's biggest week for the last five years, but I will be flying out to Italy on Tuesday to watch three players in action for China against Lazio.

Sun Jihai, Li Ming and Zhang Enhua are all players I would like to sign as we build on what we have here, and I am planning six months ahead rather than from week to week.

I have already worked out our pre-season programme for next summer and arranged our friendlies - frightening isn't it?

webTitle: The biggest test yet for the new regime

fields.headline: The biggest test yet for the new regime
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al-Fayed has a dream... an unlikely dream. It has nothing to do with his decades-long quest to secure a British passport and does not involve re-erecting the Royal warrants outside his Harrods store in London's Knightsbridge.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al-Fayed has a dream... an unlikely dream. It has nothing to do with his decades-long quest to secure a British passport and does not involve re-erecting the Royal warrants outside his Harrods store in London's Knightsbridge.

This dream is to make Fulham Football Club one of the greatest names in world football. Today Fayed, the Fulham owner-chairman, will savour the opportunity to gauge how close his dream is to reality when his team play Manchester United in the FA Cup. Only five years ago it was Scarborough, Rochdale and Hartlepool in Division Three as Fulham threatened to slip out of the League.

These days, Fulham are directed from Fayed's Knightsbridge HQ as much as Craven Cottage. Since he took over in 1997, he has had Kevin Keegan - initially with another former England captain, Ray Wilkins, alongside - Paul Bracewell and now Jean Tigana guiding the team up the Football League. All those managers have had Fayed's money to spend on top-quality players. They are runaway First Division leaders and promotion looks assured.

And so to Manchester United. What better yardstick could the Egyptian millionaire have? He will not miss the chance to compare and contrast in the round's most glamorous tie.

'Manchester United are recognised everywhere football is played as being one of the outstanding names in in the world game and that is what I want for Fulham,' says Fayed. 'That is my dream.

'We don't want just to reach the Premier League but to establish ourselves right up with the best... Manchester United, Arsenal and Liverpool. When you think that we were in danger of going out of the League, we've come a long way.'

It has been suggested - by the former Fulham coach and Observer columnist Alan Smith, for one - that the club is run as just another Harrods department and that managing the side is not much different in the Fayed scheme of things from overseeing the famous store's food hall. Fayed slaps down the suggestion - Fulham is now the real passion in his life - and, once again, he invokes his dream

'No, that is not true. The success of Harrods is, of course, important to me. I want it to be recognised as the world's finest store, but Fulham and football is my dream. It's my passion. I know what Alan Smith said but I don't think he is right - and I don't think he knows me as well as he thinks. Having said that, he's doing a fine job for Crystal Palace.'

Fayed has constantly been in the news for several years - for his controversial claims that the crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales and his son Dodi was not an accident; his libel battle with disgraced MP Neil Hamilton; his quest for a passport. Yet his stewardship of Fulham, following the initial surge of interest in his plans to invest more than £30 million in transforming the club, has been much less strident. Only his determination to succeed has produced the odd ripple in the club's smooth rise through the divisions.

Paul Bracewell was one such ripple. He was signed as a player by Keegan and then eventually stepped up to manage the club when England called for Keegan in 1999. Less than a year later, in Fulham's first season back in the First Division, he was sacked. At the time, last March, Bracewell had guided Fulham to tenth place - having been in the top three during October - and had bought Premiership players such as Lee Clark, Bjarne Goldbaek and Andy Melville.

'But I was under no illusions,' Bracewell says from the manager's office at his new employers, Halifax Town. He has no complaints about his treatment by Fayed. 'The fact that I didn't get long or that a manager such as Tigana was chosen to replace me was no shock.

'The speculation started from day one and all sorts of people were linked with my job; Terry Venables, Glenn Hoddle and Eric Cantona, for example.

'I remember the press conference when I was appointed and, in answer to a question, I said I thought I needed two years to get us into the Premiership. The chairman interrupted me and said I had one. That showed me what was expected.

'Looking at Fulham now, they have not changed the personnel too much since last year and my timetable looks about right, doesn't it?'

So is Fayed ruthless? 'Ruthless? No, but I think you do have to be single-minded if you are to be successful in any area,' he says. 'Paul Bracewell knew he was inexperienced but we gave him a try. I'm sure he will become a top manager. Kevin Keegan was let go because of the England job but he did a great job for us and I'm on very good terms with him. I regard him as a friend.'

And so to Tigana, who grants even fewer interviews than his chairman. He lets his footballers - and their football - do the talking. There is informed gossip that Fayed sounded out Cantona for Bracewell's job only, ultimately, for Cantona to recommend that Fayed turn to Tigana. Fayed's version of events confirms this.

He explains: 'There are several people I know in world football whose opinions I highly respect and Eric [Cantona] is one of those. He is one of several people who recommended Jean Tigana to me. All of those people have the highest regard for the vision, ability and perception of Jean Tigana and I think everyone at Craven Cottage can now see why. He has the potential to play a vital role in Fulham becoming a great club.

'Just a few weeks ago I was talking to Michel Platini who told me he believes that Tigana could emerge as one of game's greatest managers.'

And he insists he is not an interfering chairman - something Bracewell confirmed. 'I get in the best people and then let them do their jobs. I did not interfere in the past and I don't interfere now with Jean Tigana,' he says.

'I am always there for Jean and he knows that - but you leave an outstanding manager to manage. We share the same vision. That much was apparent when we first sat down and discussed his coming to Fulham. We both had the vision of building Fulham into a great club.'

Visions, dreams. Plans for a 30,000-seat stadium to supplant the terraces where Fayed claims he used to stand; a magnificent training complex in Surrey under development. Those dreams, for 90 minutes, will all be laid out vividly at Craven Cottage today.

Only Manchester United threaten to turn them into a grimmer, wide-awake reality.

webTitle: Lifelong Morecambe fan David Jones on their big day

fields.headline: Lifelong Morecambe fan David Jones on their big day
fields.trailText: Where the hell is Morecambe? Before 4.40pm yesterday a few daytrippers might have been able to tell you, but to many the name was just an excuse to trot out tired old end-of-pier jokes. Went there on holiday once, but it was closed. Ho-ho.
fields.body:
Where the hell is Morecambe? Before 4.40pm yesterday a few daytrippers might have been able to tell you, but to many the name was just an excuse to trot out tired old end-of-pier jokes. Went there on holiday once, but it was closed. Ho-ho.

Those of us born and raised in the North Lancashire resort - Sand Grown 'Uns, we call ourselves proudly - are on a mission to convince the outside world they don't know what they're missing. We've got the bonniest bay in Britain, we gave you potted shrimps and Miss Great Britain; Eric Morecambe and Thora Hird. And there's a cracking little football team, too. I don't know why, but the team always seem to get the biggest laugh. At least until yesterday, when the indomitable Shrimps, and their incredible North Stand choir, put Morecambe (population 40,000) on the map.

I'd longed for this day since I was six and attended my first match with Dorothy, who worked in our corner shop during the week and sold the pies at Christie Park on Saturdays. Match of the Day cameras! If only the late, great poacher Arnie Timmins had been up front - I saw him bag eight in the 14-0 rout of Rossendale in the vintage 68-69 season - we might have embarrassed mighty Ispwich. A pipe dream, perhaps. But those of us who spend our Saturdays trekking from home in London to join the diehard band of 20 or 30 loyal Shrimps fans at Forest Green or Boston are entitled to fantasise.

And reminisce. About those glory days in the Lancashire Combination, when Rossendale and their ilk were our weekly cannon-fodder, and even Burnley and Blackburn knew better than to field a team of kids and reserves when they drew us in the Senior Cup. Or the time we got ticked off over the loudspeaker for scaling the new £4,000 floodlights; the Cup run of 66-67, when we took York City to a second reply at Maine Road; and the FA Trophy final win over Dartford in 1974 - a game I tragically missed because I wrote off my mum's Mini on Westgate, 600 yards down the 250-mile route to Wembley. The chants might not have been as deafening then as yesterday but they were equally witty and inventive.

Puzzlingly, Morecambe's demise began the season after that Wembley triumph, continuing through a procession of big-name managers - Leighton James and Wolves new boss David Jones among them - for almost 20 barren years. During that period, when gates plunged from 2-3,000 to less than 400, I lost the faith. Day trips to watch us thrashed at Gainsborough became too much to stomach. That I returned to the fold and witnessed yesterday's skilful and spirited display is largely down to one man: Morecambe's own Messiah, the genial, Hamlet-smoking manager Jim Harvey. When he arrived seven years ago we were among the also-rans in the HFS Loans League. Today we not only have a team to ruffle Ipswich, but Jim has set up a productive youth academy. There's a fine new North Stand; a playing surface that suits the team's slick passing game; terracing in place of the old black 'slagheap' where I stood as a boy. I doubt I'll ever see the Shrimps swimming among the prawns and lobsters in the Football League. So 'll treasure days like yesterday. Where the hell is Morecambe? In Ipswich and beyond they know the answer now.

A pipe dream, perhaps. But those of us who spend our Saturdays trekking from home in London to join the diehard band of 20 or 30 loyal Shrimps fans at Forest Green or Boston are entitled to fantasise. And reminisce. About those glory days in the Lancashire Combination, when Rossendale and their ilk were our weekly cannon-fodder, and even Burnley and Blackburn knew better than to field a team of kids and reserves when they drew us in the Senior Cup. Or the time we got ticked off over the loudspeaker for scaling the new £4,000 floodlights; the Cup run of 66-67, when we took York City to a second reply at Maine Road; and the FA Trophy final win over Dartford in 1974 - a game I tragically missed because I wrote off my mum's Mini on Westgate, 600 yards down the 250-mile route to Wembley. The chants might not have been as deafening then as yesterday but they were equally witty and inventive. Puzzlingly, Morecambe's demise began the season after that Wembley triumph, continuing through a procession of big-name managers - Leighton James and Wolves new boss David Jones among them - for almost 20 barren years. During that period, when gates plunged from 2-3,000 to less than 400, I lost the faith. Day trips to watch us thrashed at Gainsborough became too much to stomach. That I returned to the fold and witnessed yesterday's skilful and spirited display is largely down to one man: Morecambe's own Messiah, the genial, Hamlet-smoking manager Jim Harvey. When he arrived seven years ago we were among the also-rans in the HFS Loans League. Today we not only have a team to ruffle Ipswich, but Jim has set up a productive youth academy. There's a fine new North Stand; a playing surface that suits the team's slick passing game; terracing in place of the old black 'slagheap' where I stood as a boy. I doubt I'll ever see the Shrimps swimming among the prawns and lobsters in the Football League. So 'll treasure days like yesterday. Where the hell is Morecambe? In Ipswich and beyond they know the answer now.

fields.headline: Said & Done: 2000 awards
fields.trailText: Part two: best of the rest
fields.body:
Part two: best of the rest

Best commentary of the year came from Belgian channel RTBF. As Belgium keeper Filip De Wilde trod on the ball to gift Sweden the opening goal in Euro 2000, RTBF's commentator lost it. 'What a c**t!' he screamed - then added for emphasis 'what a c**t!' RTBF later toned down the commentary for replays - replacing it with the much more balanced 'Quel idiot! Quel idiot!'

Best denial

There's dire - Lazio's Sinisa Mohajlovic claimed his reference to Patrick Viera as 'a shitty black monkey' was 'not racism'; there's sublime - Jesus Gil denied blowing $800,000 of Atletico Madrid's money on women's underwear ('No one told me there was a prohibition on panties and bras'); and there's simple. Simple wins. In June, a furious MARTIN KEOWN laid into journalists who had quoted him criticising Kevin Keegan. 'I was disturbed to read in a number of newspapers comments attributed to me suggesting that I was critical of both the England team and the manager, Kevin Keegan. Nothing could be further from the truth.' Nothing? Here's Keown writing in the Daily Telegraph 24 hours earlier: 'The bottom line is that we were inept tactically, we were exposed against teams we should have beaten, we lacked a pattern in our play at times and,' he added, 'individual and collective tactical mistakes cost us.'

Best punditry

OFFICIAL AC MILAN WEBSITE, reacting to the departure of George Weah to Chelsea in January: 'San Siro fans are left to ponder on the transient nature of all things football. But in this soccer culture that raises ephemera to a level of importance that falsely attests to their true worth, here is a player deserving of elegiac treatise.'

Best moment

In March, the month when coach Ladislas Lozano celebrated his Calais side beating Racing Strasbourg 2-1 ('This is the most beautiful day of my life') and Cambridge United refused to say why they sacked striker Steve Guinan (an insider told us of vomit and genitals), our adopted team Anguilla won their first match ever. After a better-than-usual 14-1 defeat to Grenada, the team pulled off a stunning coup against the British Virgin Islands despite three key players not arriving until half-time. Taking a four-goal lead, they held out for a 4-3 win - the first in Anguilla's footballing history. Their triumph just beats Airdrie striker Paul Jack to the award: Jack issued a public apology to Livingston groundsman Andy Forrest for mistaking him for a bin and kicking him ferociously after being sent-off. Fifa also came close - in April they apologised for appointing a dead referee to officiate a World Cup qualifier.

Best interview

RYAN GIGGS, asked by Sky Sports whether winning last season's title 'felt different' to all the others. 'It's different,' said Ryan. And how was it different? 'It's not the same.'

Most moving moment

Saddest news of the year came from Belgian referee AMAND ANCION, who was sacked in tears after disallowing a valid goal in a First Division game between Mouscron and Charleroi. The 45-year-old told Belgian TV immediately after the game that he was 'distraught'. It was the final straw - previous career highlights included being throttled by Manchester United's Ronnie Wallwork during a game at Royal Antwerp (Wallwork was given a life ban, later overturned), and, in August 1999, issuing 12 yellow cards, four reds and five penalties in a 6-6 draw between Westerlo and Genk. He beats Norwegian goalkeeper Olav Fiske to the 'most moving moment' title. Fiske, who was seen drinking several pints of water before his side's cup-tie, couldn't hold on when the game went into extra time. With the ball upfield he rushed to the touchline to relieve himself, only to watch in horror - midstream - as opposition striker Tor Oddvar Torve lobbed the ball 40 yards into the net. The match finished 1-0.

Best campaign

The Crystal Palace Supporters Trust were forced to print a new batch of 'Kick (David) Mellor out of football' T-shirts after they sold out in their hundreds including, we discovered, several to his BBC Five Live colleagues. A campaign website remains, and the most admirable fight in football goes on.

Other news: the longest journey

The longest British away trip ever takes place on the 20th - Falmouth Town travel to play Bedlington Terriers in the FA Vase 4th round. That's 485.2 miles - a conservative journey time of 9 hours. 'We'll be taking 30 or 40 fans up there,' says club secretary John Thompson. 'Gone on Friday morning, back on Sunday night.' Is there any longer away trip in domestic football? Let us know.

Rough Guide: the winners

The Sturm Graz stadium is named after Arnold Schwarzenegger, not Brigitte Bardot or Macaulay Culkin. Copies of the new Rough Guide to European Football go to Jill Tardivel, Canterbury; Virendra Mistry, Sheffield; Laurie Middleton, Swindon; Dawn Quadling, Norfolk; Elaine Lewis, Lincolnshire; Jon Robinson, Swansea; John Bailey, Cardiff; Damien Duggan, Belfast; Michael Bennett, Vale of Glamorgan; Steven Caine, Surrey.

webTitle: Italy's answer to Ipswich makes Milan derby a sideshow

fields.headline: Italy's answer to Ipswich makes Milan derby a sideshow
fields.standfirst: Atalanta's model is a tractor, not a Ferrari, says Simon Evans
fields.trailText: Atalanta's model is a tractor, not a Ferrari, says Simon Evans.
fields.body:
Today is derby day in Milan, but if local pride and media hype are stripped away the reality is that the San Siro is hosting a mid-table Serie A match. There will, as always, be 80,000 at the stadium but they will be watching an inconsistent seventh-placed Milan face a shambles of an Inter side stranded in eleventh. There is a real sense that this Milan derby is little more than a diversion.

The important points are being played for a few miles down the road, in Bergamo, where third-placed Atalanta, the Ipswich of Serie A , take on leaders AS Roma, who are looking real championship material after losing just one game this season. But their opponents Atalanta are the surprise of the season.

Today may determine whether Giovanni Vavassori's young side really have the quality to maintain a challenge for a Champions League place, but Atalanta have already provided Italy with a refreshing reminder of how the old way of doing things can still work.

A sound youth policy and a series of wise buys from the lower divisions have proved more effective than the big-spending of clubs such as Inter and Parma and have exposed struggling Napoli's ludicrous policy of replacing their entire team and coach upon promotion.

The journeyman former Inter and Milan striker Maurizio Ganz is forging a promising partnership in the Atalanta attack with young Nicola Ventola, also off-loaded from Inter, and behind them are a midfield oozing with young homegrown Italian talent - the playmaker Cristiano Doni, the effervescent winger Luciano Zauri and the all-purpose Zenoni brothers, Damiano and Cristiano. The mix of youth and bargain buys has the stamp of Ipswich's 'Tractor Boys'.

Everyone is cooing about the Bergamo boys. Italy coach Giovanni Trapattoni is a frequent spectator at the Stadio Atleti Azzurri di Italia and called up Damiano Zenoni for his debut in November's friendly against England - it would be no surprise to see other players, who last term were playing in Serie B, pulling on the Azzurri shirt in the near future.

It is not lost on the Italian footballing public that while Atalanta are prospering, Inter, the biggest-spending club in Italian football history, are having another nightmare season, but show no signs of ending their free-spending import-led transfer policy nor, despite the example from Bergamo, their negligent attitude to youth.

Inter replaced coach Marcello Lippi with Marco Tardelli, appointed after winning the European Under-21 Championships for Italy last May. Hopes of a change in direction, then, but he is not proving to be an Italian Peter Taylor.

Inter are not the only big club ignoring youth. Lazio's Roberto Baronio, one of Tardelli's under-21 stars, has been largely cold-shouldered by club coach Sven-Göran Eriksson. England's next coach has given Baronio just a handful of chances in minor fixtures, even turning to the ageing Attilio Lombardo and signing the fading Dino Baggio rather than give Baronio an extended run.

But there are signs that the miracle of Atalanta is having an effect on the big clubs. Milan already have three young Italian internationals in their midfield in Francesco Coco, Gennaro Gattuso and Massimo Ambrosini, and club vice-president Adriano Galliani recently stated their policy should be followed by other clubs. 'We need to protect our national identity and to hold to account those clubs who are basing themselves on foreign players. Our policy for the past three years has been crystal clear and we will continue to focus on young Italian talent,' said Galliani.

Sadly for Atalanta, the price of changing attitudes to young Italian players will be probably come at the end of this season, when the likes of Doni, Zauri and the Zenoni brothers are tempted away. There is only so far you can go with the old ways of doing things.

Cup shocks abound in Spain where they adopted English, single-ties for early rounds. Now only Barcelona of the major clubs remain. European champions Real Madrid, runners-up Valencia and league champions Deportivo have all crashed out. A total of 12 First Division teams have lost to minnows. Spanish TV, anxious about their ratings, hope that Barca, at least, manage to go all the way.

 Catch theTurner Exhibition at the National Gallery of Scotland (0131 624 6200) Edinburgh. Noon - 5pm. Free.

fields.headline: Unmissable Hong Kong
fields.standfirst: Shopping, sightseeing, eating out - you want to fit it all in. But where to start? Here are Joanne O'Connor's five must-dos
fields.trailText: Shopping, sightseeing, eating out - you want to fit it all in. But where to start? Here are Joanne O'Connor's five must-dos.
fields.body:
The Peak

The lights were just coming on across Victoria harbour when Jackie Chan, dressed in a cream linen suit and suspended from a crane, flew in a graceful arc over my head, landing as lightly as a cat in front of the television cameras. The crowd that had gathered on the viewing terrace of the Peak to watch the martial arts film star being interviewed for a local TV show gasped and clapped their approval. As entrances go, it was a pretty good one.

The Peak is the number one tourist attraction in Hong Kong. Take the tram to the top of this impossibly steep hill and fight your way through the crowds in the shopping mall, past the Ripley's Believe it or Not! odditorium and the new Madame Tussaud's, to the viewing deck.

You probably won't see Jackie Chan but you will get to gaze god-like down on Hong Kong Island, the frantic activity of the harbour and the distant skyscrapers of Kowloon. The tranquil gardens of the Peak Café are the perfect spot for a coffee or ice-cream in the shade of a bamboo tree.

Shopping

Hong Kong is not the bargain basement it used to be for electronic goods and garments but few places can offer such a variety of shopping experiences. Try swish shopping malls such as the Landmark and Pacific Place for designer goods (the real thing, with real prices to match), Hollywood Road for antiques and giant malls such as Harbour City for everything else.

The huge night market on Temple Street with its dodgy designer rip-offs and bootleg CDs, palm readers and sidestalls selling murky bowls of turtle soup has a certain tacky charm while the flea market on Cat Street has a hotchpotch of stalls selling kitsch communist paraphernalia such as Chairman Mao side plates and lighters that play the communist anthem.

Traditional Chinese department stores such as Chinese Arts and Crafts and CRC may look unpromising from the outside but are the best place to find reasonably priced Chinese crafts, jewellery and clothing. If time allows, pick your way past the fruit and veg stalls and buckets of writhing eels on Graham Street and stock up on ginseng and Chinese herbs from one of the many wholesalers on Bonham Strand West.

The Star Ferry

The Star Ferry is Hong Kong's answer to the San Francisco cable car or the London double decker - an institution, a mode of transport and a tourist attraction rolled into one. For less than 20 pence the distinctive green and white ferries take passengers between Hong Kong Island and the Kowloon peninsula. The seven-minute journey gives stunning views of the skyline on both sides, particularly beautiful at night when the skyscrapers are lit up.

There are also regular and cheap ferry services connecting the largest of Hong Kong's 200-plus Outlying Islands.

Lamma Island has some beautiful beaches and good seafood restaurants while sleepy Cheung Chau offers fishing junks, rugged coastal views and a welcome respite from the frenzied activity and traffic of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon. Green and rolling Lantau Island is undeveloped, although the arrival of a large mouse and his entourage in 2005 will change all that. Land reclamation work has already begun to make way for Hong Kong Disneyland although local environment groups are making valiant, if futile, attempts to minimise the impact. For the time being, the main attractions of Lantau are its good hiking terrain and the Po Lin Monastery with its huge bronze Buddha statue.

Body, mind, soul

Though it may not seem this way to an expat or a weekend visitor, there is more to Hong Kong than making money and spending it. Even the most futuristic skyscrapers are built along feng shui lines and the small and smoky temples are full at lunchtime with office workers and students lighting incense and shaking fortune sticks before gold-plated gods and their cluttered shrines piled high with fruit and flowers.

The Hong Kong Tourist Association can help you fix up an English-speaking tai chi class, feng shui workshop, horoscope reading or a Chinese medical checkup. Full of good health I skipped into the Happy Valley medical centre for my reflexology and pulsology session. One hour later I shuffled out with a weak heart, lungs and liver, poor circulation, malfunctioning digestive system, respiratory problems and a scribbled prescription in Chinese. Deflated, I paid a palm reader in Kansu Street two dollars to tell me that I would live to a ripe old age. He also told me that I had no luck for gambling and that I would only be happy if I married a 'little successful man'. His limited English prevented me from establishing whether the little referred to my future husband's success or his stature.

Dine in style

Hong Kong offers several culinary experiences which should not be missed and many that should. A close shave with a bowl of turtle soup in Temple Street convinced me that menus with pictures or dim sum restaurants where you point at food as it is wheeled round on a trolley were the safest options.

The Super Star Seafood Restaurant on Nathan Road offers a quite alarming range of dim sum options at lunchtime. Deep fried chicken feet and a wobbling, luminous orange blancmange goldfish were offered - and turned down - several times before something vaguely recognisable rolled by.

Make sure you leave room for afternoon tea - a British tradition which the five-star hotels here have turned into an art form. Try The Peninsula in Kowloon or the Mandarin Oriental on Hong Kong Island for the daintiest cucumber sandwiches and pastries.

In the evening, catch a ferry to Lamma Island to dine at one of the many seafood restaurants where the food is so fresh it's still alive. And, at some point in the evening, take the lift to the top floor of the Peninsula Hotel.

Philippe Starck designed the bar here: the drinks are pricey, the decor bizarre and it's full of very large, very successful expats, but the views across the harbour to the bright lights of Hong Kong Island will make the bar bill seem almost reasonable.

Fact file

A five-night stay with British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 243) at the five-star Ritz-Carlton Hotel costs £885 per person for departures between 1 February and 31 March. The price includes return scheduled flights, transfers, accommodation and UK taxes. The supplement to travel in Club World, BA's business class cabin, is £689 one way and £1,378 return, but it buys you the comfort of a seat which reclines fully to make a six-foot flat bed, now available on all BA's Hong Kong flights.

In addition the airline has installed its new World Traveller Plus cabin - an upgraded product for long haul economy travellers - on flights to Hong Kong. The new cabin features wider seats with greater legroom (38 inch pitch compared to 31 inches for World Traveller), extra handluggage allowance and seat back entertainment. World Traveller Plus fares start from £1,153.50 return including taxes. (0845 77 333 77).

The Star Ferry The Star Ferry is Hong Kong's answer to the San Francisco cable car or the London double decker - an institution, a mode of transport and a tourist attraction rolled into one. For less than 20 pence the distinctive green and white ferries take passengers between Hong Kong Island and the Kowloon peninsula. The seven-minute journey gives stunning views of the skyline on both sides, particularly beautiful at night when the skyscrapers are lit up. There are also regular and cheap ferry services connecting the largest of Hong Kong's 200-plus Outlying Islands. Lamma Island has some beautiful beaches and good seafood restaurants while sleepy Cheung Chau offers fishing junks, rugged coastal views and a welcome respite from the frenzied activity and traffic of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon. Green and rolling Lantau Island is undeveloped, although the arrival of a large mouse and his entourage in 2005 will change all that. Land reclamation work has already begun to make way for Hong Kong Disneyland although local environment groups are making valiant, if futile, attempts to minimise the impact. For the time being, the main attractions of Lantau are its good hiking terrain and the Po Lin Monastery with its huge bronze Buddha statue. Body, mind, soul Though it may not seem this way to an expat or a weekend visitor, there is more to Hong Kong than making money and spending it. Even the most futuristic skyscrapers are built along feng shui lines and the small and smoky temples are full at lunchtime with office workers and students lighting incense and shaking fortune sticks before gold-plated gods and their cluttered shrines piled high with fruit and flowers. The Hong Kong Tourist Association can help you fix up an English-speaking tai chi class, feng shui workshop, horoscope reading or a Chinese medical checkup. Full of good health I skipped into the Happy Valley medical centre for my reflexology and pulsology session. One hour later I shuffled out with a weak heart, lungs and liver, poor circulation, malfunctioning digestive system, respiratory problems and a scribbled prescription in Chinese. Deflated, I paid a palm reader in Kansu Street two dollars to tell me that I would live to a ripe old age. He also told me that I had no luck for gambling and that I would only be happy if I married a 'little successful man'. His limited English prevented me from establishing whether the little referred to my future husband's success or his stature. Dine in style Hong Kong offers several culinary experiences which should not be missed and many that should. A close shave with a bowl of turtle soup in Temple Street convinced me that menus with pictures or dim sum restaurants where you point at food as it is wheeled round on a trolley were the safest options. The Super Star Seafood Restaurant on Nathan Road offers a quite alarming range of dim sum options at lunchtime. Deep fried chicken feet and a wobbling, luminous orange blancmange goldfish were offered - and turned down - several times before something vaguely recognisable rolled by. Make sure you leave room for afternoon tea - a British tradition which the five-star hotels here have turned into an art form. Try The Peninsula in Kowloon or the Mandarin Oriental on Hong Kong Island for the daintiest cucumber sandwiches and pastries. In the evening, catch a ferry to Lamma Island to dine at one of the many seafood restaurants where the food is so fresh it's still alive. And, at some point in the evening, take the lift to the top floor of the Peninsula Hotel. Philippe Starck designed the bar here: the drinks are pricey, the decor bizarre and it's full of very large, very successful expats, but the views across the harbour to the bright lights of Hong Kong Island will make the bar bill seem almost reasonable. Fact file A five-night stay with British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 243) at the five-star Ritz-Carlton Hotel costs £885 per person for departures between 1 February and 31 March. The price includes return scheduled flights, transfers, accommodation and UK taxes. The supplement to travel in Club World, BA's business class cabin, is £689 one way and £1,378 return, but it buys you the comfort of a seat which reclines fully to make a six-foot flat bed, now available on all BA's Hong Kong flights. In addition the airline has installed its new World Traveller Plus cabin - an upgraded product for long haul economy travellers - on flights to Hong Kong. The new cabin features wider seats with greater legroom (38 inch pitch compared to 31 inches for World Traveller), extra handluggage allowance and seat back entertainment. World Traveller Plus fares start from £1,153.50 return including taxes. (0845 77 333 77).

fields.headline: Check in and chill out
fields.standfirst: Caroline Raphael, editor of the Good Hotel Guide, selects 50 favourites to mark the launch of the guide's Continental Europe edition
fields.trailText: Caroline Raphael, editor of the Good Hotel Guide, selects 50 favourites to mark the launch of the guide's Continental Europe edition.
fields.body:
City hotels

The growth of low-cost airlines - Ryanair, Easyjet, Go and Buzz - has encouraged travellers to take advantage of a cheap fare and find their own accommodation. Here are 10 ideas for the more popular cities:

1 Vienna
König von Ungarn
Schulerstrasse 10, 1010 Vienna, Austria.
Tel 0043 1 515 840, fax 515 848
hotel@kvu.at, www.kvu.at
Near St Stephan's cathedral and very good shopping; said to be the oldest hotel in Vienna. Pleasant atrium with greenery; vaulted restaurant. 32 bedrooms. B&B Sch1,195-1,690 (£55-£77). Set dinner Sch490 (£22). Airline: Buzz.

2 Carcassonne
Domaine d'Auriac
Route de St-Hilaire, BP 554, Carcassonne 11009 Aude, France.
Tel 00 33 4 6825 7222, fax 6847 3554
auriac@relaischateaux.fr, www.relaischateaux.fr
In park close to hilltop fortress: nineteenth-century classical mansion, elegant, luxurious but unostentatious. Michelin-starred restaurant; 18-hole golf course, swimming pool, tennis. 26 bedrooms. D, B&B Fr600-1,500 (£58-£145). Airline: Ryanair.

3 Lyon
Cour des Loges
6 rue du Boeuf, 69005 Lyon Rhône.
Tel 00 33 4 7277 4444, fax 7240 9361
contact@courdesloges.com, www.courdesloges.com
In lively area of Vieux Lyon, an unusual luxury hotel: four old buildings with dramatic art deco interior, large atrium, modern paintings, roof garden, wine cellar, garage. 62 bedrooms. B&B 770-1,420 frs (£75-£135). Meal 350 frs (£33). Airlines: Buzz, Ryanair and Go.

4 Paris
Hôtel de l'Abbaye St-Germain
10 rue Cassette, 75006 Paris, France.
Tel 0033 1 4544 3811, fax 4548 0786
hotel.abbaye@wanadoo.fr, www.hotel-abbaye.com
Near St-Sulpice: former monastery, now elegant B&B hotel. Courtyard (with greenery and pond) for drinks and breakfast; conservatory. 46 bedrooms. B&B Fr610-1,220 (£59-£117). Airlines: Buzz and Ryanair (from Prestwick).

5 Berlin
Hecker's Hotel
Grolmanstrasse 35 10623 Berlin, Germany.
Tel 00 49 30 88900, fax 30 8890260
info@heckers-hotel.com, www.heckers-hotel.com
Good value for its central location in Charlottenburg area: stylish hotel with glossy modern decor, roof terrace, Mediterranean-style restaurant. 71 bedrooms. D, B&B Dm233-358 (£75-£115.) Airline: Buzz.

6 Nice
Le Grimaldi
15 rue Grimaldi, 06000 Nice, Alpes-Maritimes, France.
Tel 00 33 4 93 16 00 24, fax 87 00 24
jlz@le-grimaldi.com, www.le-grimaldi.com
Yann and Joanna Zedde's B&B in belle époque town house with bright Provençal decor. On quiet street near old town, 10 minutes walk from beach. 23 bedrooms. Fr410-870 (£40-£85). Airline: EasyJet.

7 Bologna
Hotel Orologio
Via IV Novembre 10, 40123 Bologna, Italy.
Tel 00 39 051 231 253, fax 260 552
hotoro@tin.it, www.cnc.it/bologna
Central but quiet B&B hotel in tall building in pedestrianised zone near main square: good bedrooms; excellent buffet breakfast. 34 bedrooms. B&B Lr157,000-350,000 (£51-£114). Airline: Go.

8 Milan
Hotel Spadari al Duomo
Via Spadari 11, 20123 Milan, Italy.
Tel 00 39 02 7200 2371, fax 861 184
reservation@spadarihotel.com, www.spadarihotel.com
Stylish little B&B hotel in side street near duomo; modern-romantic decor; works of art, extravagant flower arrangements. Good breakfast and snacks, in bright bar. 39 bedrooms. B&B Lr130,000-368,000 (£42-£120). Airlines: Buzz and Go.

9 Venice
Agli Alboretti
Accademia 884, Dorsoduro, 30123 Venice, Italy.
Tel 00 39 041 5230 058, fax 5210 158
alborett@gpnet.it, www.logis.it
Unassuming little hotel, good value, near Gallerie dell'Accademia; simple decor; good food in ochre-walled courtyard, under a canopy of leaves and vines. 19 bedrooms. D, B&B L205,000-245,000 (£67-£80). Airlines: Buzz and Ryanair.

10 Lisbon
Lapa Palace
Rua do Pau de Bandeira 4, 1240-021 Lisbon, Portugal.
Tel 00 351 21 394 9494, fax 395 0665
info@hotelapa.com, www.orient-expresshotels.com
On hillside (fine views) in residential area; big, opulent hotel in beautiful gardens. Large outdoor swimming pool; health club; very good restaurant. 108 bedrooms. D, B&B 35,300-55,300 esc (£111-£174). Airline: Go.

Lakes and mountains

1 Tirol
Parkhotel am Tristachersee
Lienz, 9900 Tirol, Austria.
Tel 00 43 4852 67666, fax 4852 67699
tristachersee@osttirol.com, www.tophotels.com/tristachersee
On small lake beside wooded hills, with Dolomites in background: Kreuzer family's chalet-style hotel with simple, modern decor; large dining terrace above lake; indoor pool and spa; garden. 43 bedrooms. D, B&B Sch700-1,370 (£32-£63).

2 French Alps
Le Cordonant
Cordon, 74700 Haute-Savoie, France.
Tel 00 33 4 5058 3456, fax 5047 9557
Pretty chalet hotel in resort village west of Chamonix: views of Mt Blanc and ski slopes; rustic decor; very good food; terrace for summer meals; pleasant garden. 16 bedrooms. D, B&B Fr 260-410 (£25-£40).

3 Lake Constance
Seehotel Siber
Seestrasse 25, Konstanz, 78464 Baden-Württemberg, Germany.
Tel 00 49 07531 63044, fax 07531 64813
seehotel.siber@t-online, www.integra.fr/relaischateaux/siber
Handsome white Jugendstil villa on shores of Lake Constance, with wide views to Swiss Alps: much panelling, stained glass, modern art; Michelin-starred restaurant; terrace for summer meals, Mediterranean-style gardens, lakeside footpath. 12 bedrooms. D, B&B Dm375-465 (£120-£150).

4 Lake Garda
Villa del Sogno
Via Zanardelli 107, Fasano del Garda, 25083 Brescia, Italy.
Tel 00 39 0365 290181, fax 0365 290230
villadelsogno@gardalake.it, www.gardalake.it/villadelsogno
Elegant hotel on Lake Garda. Lake views from flower-filled terrace where meals are served, and from large bedrooms. Large public rooms, elaborately decorated; garden with swimming pool, tennis. 31 bedrooms. D, B&B Lr230,000-305,000 (£75-£99).

5 Norang
Hotel Union Øye
Norangsfjorden, 6196 Norway.
Tel 00 47 7006 2100, fax 7006 2116.
post@unionoye.no, www.unionoye.no
Set in remote mountains in Norang valley: Swiss Gothic-style hotel (regularly visited by Kaiser Wilhelm and Conan Doyle); immaculately restored; efficient service; good dinners, huge breakfasts.26 bedrooms. D, B&B 1,005-1,205 Nkr (£77-£92).

6 Portugal
Quinta do Barranco da Estrada
Santa Clara-a-Velha, 7665-880 Beja, Portugal.
Tel/fax 00 351 283 93 39 01
paradiseinportugal@mail.telepac.pt, www.paradise-in-portugal.com
In the Alentejo: Frank and Lulu McClintock's family home, set amid orange and lemon trees and flowers, above huge, unpolluted lake. Lots of wildlife and bird-watching. Communal meals. Eight simple bedrooms. B&B 11,500-27,000 esc (£36-£85).

7 Lake Bled
Vila Bled
Cesta Svobode 26 , Bled, 4260 Gorenjska, Slovenia.
Tel 00386 04 5791 500, fax 5741 320
vilabled@robas.si, www.vilabled.robas.si
On low hill, former royal palace remodelled by Tito, now Slovenia's most sumptuous hotel; good restaurant; 13-acre park with private lido. 30 bedrooms. D, B&B (£64-£92).

8 Sweden
Toftaholm Herrgård
Lagan, 340 14 Småland, Sweden.
Tel 00 46 370 440 55, fax 370 440 45
frontoffice@toftaholmherrgard.com, www.toftaholmherrgard.com
Fourteenth-century manor house on shores of Lake Vidöstern: private beach, fishing, swimming. 45 bedrooms. D, B&B Skr952-1,425 (£69-£103).

9 Lake Maggiore
Casa Berno
Ascona 6612 Ticino, Switzerland.
Tel 00 41 91 791 3232, fax 792 1114
hotel@casaberno.ch, www.casaberno.ch
Well-run modern hotel above Lake Maggiore: great views from bedrooms and public rooms; swimming pool and lovely roof terrace (summer meal service).61 bedrooms. D, B&B SFr205-285 (£86-£119).

10 Swiss Alps
Relais du Belvédère
Champex-Lac, 1938 Valais, Switzerland.
Tel 0041 27 783 1114 fax 783 2576
belvedere@dransnet.ch
The Favre-Holsacker family's country inn sits amid pine-covered, snow-capped mountains in a charming family resort; spectacular views; Alpine decor, good food; near lake with boating, fishing, winter skating. Nine bedrooms. D, B&B SFr90-110 (£37-£46).

Child-friendly hotels

The following hotels are particularly good for a family holiday:

1 Austria
Hoteldorf Grüner Baum
Kötschachtal, Bad Gastein, 5640 Salzburger Land, Austria
Tel 00 43 6434 25160, fax 6434 251625
info@grunerbaum.com, www.grunerbaum.com
Set in the Hohe Tauern national park, a hunting lodge and surrounding chalets form the Blumschein family's village-style hotel: good family accommodation; family-friendly weeks (young children stay free); indoor and outdoor pools; adventure playground; 'cure centre' with thermal bath. 83 bedrooms. D, B&B Sch1,240-2,220 (£56-£100)

2 Austria
Hotel Madrisa
Gargellan, 6787 Vorarlberg, Austria.
Tel 00 43 5557 6331 fax 5557 633182
gast@madrisahotel.com, www.madrisahotel.com
Rhomberg family's informal hotel, near lifts and ski school in highest resort in Montafon valley: children's playroom; large indoor pool; free mountain bikes; good organic meals. 59 bedrooms. D, B&B Sch620-2,020 (£28.50-£93).

3 France
Auberge sur la Montagne
La Thuile, Ste-Foy-Tarantaise, France.
Tel 00 33 4 7906 9583, fax 4 7906 9596
lauberge@wanadoo.fr
Suzanne and Andy Mac's small hotel in a hamlet near Bourg-St-Maurice: relaxed style; sensational views; family suites, children's games; Savoyard specialities in restaurant; small garden; terrace; plunge pool. Seven bedrooms. D, B&B Fr275-675 frs (£26-£65).

4 Germany
Hotel Spielweg
Spielweg 61, Obermünstertal, Münstertal, 79244 Baden-Württemberg, Germany.
Tel 00 49 7636 7090, fax 07636 70966
spielweg@romantik.de
Fuchs family's old hostelry, folksy but elegant, set in hilly meadows south of Freiburg; indoor and outdoor pools; children's play area. 42 bedrooms. D, B&B Dm170-340 (£55-£109).

5 Greece
Hotel Minoa
56 Actis, 210 56 Toló, Peloponnese, Greece.
Tel 00 30 752 59207, fax 752 59707
kingmino@otonet.gr, www.geocities.com/familygeorgidakis
Georgidakis family's hotel, on beach of popular resort with clean, shallow sea; water sports; boat trips; access to pool. 42 bedrooms. D, B&B 11,750-18,250 drs (£21-£34). Open 15 Mar-5 Nov.

6 Italy
Relais Torre Pratesi
Via Cavina 11, Brisighella, 48015 Ravenna, Italy.
Tel 00 39 0546 84545, fax 84558
torrep@tin.it
Pink-washed farmhouse, west of charming town (best rooms are in sixteenth-century fortified tower); music room, library; garden with pool, play area, mini-gym, goats and chickens. Good no-choice meals. Seven bedrooms. D, B&B (including wine) Lr200,000-230,000 (£65-£75).

7 Italy
Hotel Bad Ratzes
Via Ratzes 29, Siusi allo Sciliar, 39040 Bolzano, Italy.
Tel 00 39 0471 706131, fax 0471 707199
info@badratzes.it, www.badratzes.it
Cheerful chalet-style hotel has beautiful skiing in winter and is also a summer resort. Children of all ages welcomed: special menus, games, baby-sitters, entertainments, cookery classes. Large pool; huge garden; rich and delicious meals. 48 bedrooms (most are big, with balcony). D, B&B Lr 120,000-200,000 (£39-£65).

8 Portugal
Quinta do Pintor
Estrada dos Canaviais, Évora, 7000-804 Portugal.
Tel 00 351 266 706 915.
Antonio and Maria Rosado's simple, peaceful, farmhouse outside the superb old city; garden with pets, organic fruit and veg; set meals (by arrangement, minimum eight people) 3,500 esc (£11) per head. Five bedrooms. B&B 5,000-11,000 esc (£15-£35).

9 Majorca
Hotel Mar i Vent
Carrer Major 49, Bañalbufar, 07191 Majorca.
Tel 00 34 971 61 8000, fax 61 8201
marivent@bitel.es, www.fehm.es
Run for many years by the Vives family: modest hotel on north side of island, above steeply terraced, cultivated slopes and sea cove; good, straightforward cooking; tennis court, pool. 29 simple, bright bedrooms, with balcony. D, B&B Pts 10,750-16,000 (£41-£61). Closed Dec-Jan.

10 Switzerland
Hotel Beau-Site
Saas-Fee, 3906 Valais, Switzerland.
Tel 00 41 27 958 1560, fax 958 1565
hotel.beau-site@saas-fee.ch, www.romantikhotels.com/rhsaas
In a resort surrounded by some of the highest peaks of the Alps, this chalet has family suites (some with cooking area); children's menus; games room; indoor pool. 32 bedrooms. D, B&B SFr128-238 (£54-£100). Romantic hotels

Ten ideas just for the two of you.

1 Belgium
Hostellerie du Prieuré de Conques
2 rue de Conques, Herbeumont, 6820 Luxembourg Belge, Belgium.
Tel 00 32 6141 1417, fax 6141 2703
www.conques.be
In a wooded valley by River Semois: former Cistercian priory, tastefully converted; very peaceful; good Ardennes cooking. 18 bedrooms. D, B&B BFr3,200-5,100 (£50-£80).

2 Prague
Hotel U raka
Cernínská 10/93, Prague 1, 118 00 Czech Republic.
Tel 00 420 2 205 111 00, fax 105 11
uraka@login.cz, www.romantikhotels.com/prag
Stylish guest house up hill near castle. Elegant conversion of old buildings around courtyards: tiled floors, beamed ceilings, open hearths, modern furniture, paintings by local artists; kitchen/bar/ breakfast room with open fire; small Japanese-style garden; meals by arrangement. Six bedrooms. B&B 3,100-6,200 koruna (£55-£100).

3 Denmark
Steensgaard Herregårdspension
Millinge, 5642 Denmark.
Tel 00 45 62 61 9490, fax 6361 7861
steensgaard@herregardspension.dk, www.herregaardspension.dk
On island of Funen, in park with lake and reserve for deer and wild boar: perfectly preserved fourteenth-century moated manor house. Beautiful public rooms; good food; lovely garden. 14 bedrooms. D, B&B DKr850-1,210 (£70-£102).

4 France
Le Moulin de la Gorce
La Roche-l'Abeille, St-Yrieix-la-Perche, 87800 Haute-Vienne, France
Tel 00 33 5 5500 7066, fax 7657
moulingorce@relaischateaux.fr, www.relaischateaux.fr/moulingorce
In remote hilly country south of Limoges: elegant hotel composed of sixteenth-century mills and a millhouse. Michelin two-star restaurant. breakfast by pond with ducks. 10 bedrooms. D, B&B Fr 775-850 (£75-£82)

5 Italy
Luna Convento
Via Pantaleone Comite 33, Amalfi, 84011 Salerno, Italy.
00 39 089 871002, fax 089 871333
luna@amalficoast.it
High above gulf of Salerno: medieval convent founded by St Francis of Assisi, now a beautiful hotel. Quiet cloister with lemon and kumquat trees; panoramic dining room; restaurant in old Saracen fortress jutting into sea; swimming pool carved into rocks. 45 bedrooms. D, B&B Lr200,000-230,000 (£65-£75).

6 Italy
Villa San Michele
Via della Chiesa N.462, Massa Pisana, 55050 Lucca, Italy.
Tel 00 39 0583 370276 fax 0583 370277
htlvillasmichele@tin.it
4km from this wonderful walled city of Lucca: Giuseppe Santarelli's thirteenth-century villa in large grounds amid olive cork, oak and bay trees, old urns and moss-covered walls. Buffet breakfast in an old brick-floored kitchen. 30 bedrooms. B&B Lr150,000-315,000 (£48-£100).

7 Netherlands
Kaatje bij de Sluis
Brouwerstraat 20, Blokzijl, Overissjel, 8356 DV, The Netherlands.
Tel 00 31 527 291 833, fax 291 836
kaatje@planet.nl, www.kaatje.nl
By canal in small, lovely, old harbour town, Fons and Anneke von Groeningen's Michelin two-star restaurant, with eight bedrooms across a bridge. Al fresco meals on terrace; seven-course breakfast in garden room. D, B&B 282-405 gld (£80-£116).

8 Portugal
Convento de São Paulo
Aldeia de la Serra, Redondo, 7170 Évora, Portugal.
Tel 00 351 266 98 91 60, fax 99 91 04
hotelconvspaulo@mail.telepac.pt
Twelfth-century monastery on a hillside, in vast estate of olives and cork. Cloistered courtyard; wide corridors; public areas lined by huge collection of azulejos. Garden; pool, art gallery in former chapel. 23 bedrooms. D, B&B 22,100 esc (£70).

9 Portugal
Quinta das Sequóias
Casa da Tapada, Ap. 1004, 2710-500 Sintra, Portugal.
Tel 00 351 21 924 38 21, fax 923 03 42
candigonzalez@hotmail.com
Finely renovated manor house on wooded hill outside Sintra: superb views. Peaceful courtyard; public rooms full of art works; luxurious bedrooms. Buffet breakfast enhanced by live music. Arbour, flowery terraces, fountains, pool. Five bedrooms. B&B: 11,000-25,000 esc (£35-£80).

10 Spain
Casa de Carmona
Plaza de Lasso 1, Carmona, 41410 Sevilla, Spain.
Tel 00 34 95 419 1000, fax 419 0189
reserve@casadecarmona.com, www.casadecarmona.com
Renaissance palace, now a luxury hotel, sumptuously decorated yet intimate. Beautiful bedrooms and bathrooms. Courtyards with potted plants and fountain, ornamental Arab garden with orange trees, small swimming pool. 32 bedrooms. D, B&B Pts 18,000-43,000 (£68-£160).

Castle hotels

France and Spain have some particularly fine examples.

1 Belgium
Château d'Hassonville
Route d'Hassonville 105, Marche-en-Famenne, 6900 Luxembourg Belge, Belgium.
Tel 00 32 84 31 10 25, fax 84 31 60 27.
Seventeenth-century pepper-potted château in huge park with lake, gardens designed by Lenôtre; peacocks, geese, putting green. Seven-course dinner. 20 bedrooms. D, B&B BFr 5,450-8,450 (£85-£130).

2 France
Hostellerie du Château de Bellecroix
RN 6, Chagny, 71150 Saône-et-Loire, France.
Tel 00 33 3 8587 1386, fax 8591 2862.
Medieval castle, turreted and creeper-covered, near Beaune. In lovely park with swimming pool. Good dinners; breakfast alfresco, under trees. 20 bedrooms. D, B&B 610-1,140 (£60-£110).

3 France
Château de Madières
Madières, Ganges, 34190 Gard, France.
Tel 00 33 4 6773 8403, fax 6773 5571
madieres@wanadoo.fr, www.madieres.fr.st
In southern Cévennes, above gorge of river Vis: Mme Brucy's fourteenth-century château. Homely feel; beautiful bedrooms, pool, fitness room. 12 bedrooms. D, B&B Fr750-1,115 frs(£72-£107).

4 France
Château de Nieuil
Nieuil, 16270 Charente, France.
Tel 0033 5 4571 3638, fax 4571 4645
nieuil@relaischateaux.fr, www.relaischateaux.fr/nieuil
Moated former hunting lodge of François I, now M Bodinaud's luxurious hotel, in wooded park near Angoulème. Fine antiques; Michelin-starred restaurant; lovely gardens. 14 bedrooms. D, B&B Fr 870-1,700 (£83-£163).

5 Germany
Burghotel Auf Schönburg
Oberwesel, 55430 Rheinland-Pfalz, Germany.
Tel 00 49 6744 93 930
huettl@hotel-schoenburg.com, www.hotel-schoenburg.com
Hüttl family's stylish conversion of medieval castle, high above the Rhine's west bank: superb views. Outwardly severe, intimate inside. 22 bedrooms. D, B&B Dm260-275 (£83-£88).

6 Italy
Castello di Ripa d'Orcia
San Quirico d'Orcia, 53023 Siena, Italy.
Tel 00 39 0577 897376, fax 898038
info@castelloripadorcia.com, www.castelloripadorcia.com
Magnificent medieval castle on steep hill above Orcia valley. Run by Aluffi Pentini family in house party style. Tranquil, simple, inexpensive, with good Tuscan cooking. Six bedrooms. D, B&B Lr135,000-163,000 (£44-£54).

7 Italy
Castel Pergine
Via al Castello 10, Pergine Valsugana, 38057 Trento, Italy.
Tel 00 39 0461 531158, fax 0461 531329
verena@castelpergine.it, www.castelpergine.it
Verena and Theo Scheider-Neff's medieval castle, in large grounds on hilltop. Marvellous views; good food. 21 bedrooms. D, B&B Lr 110,000-135,000 (£35-£44).

8 Slovenia
Golf Grad Mokrice
Rajec 4, Mokrice, 8261 Dolenjska, Slovenia.
Tel 00 386 7 457 4240, fax 495 7007
terme.catez@terme-catez.si, www.terme-catez.si
Wonderful old castle, sympathetically restored, now a resort hotel. Huge tower bedrooms with circular beds. 18-hole golf course, English-style gardens, lake (fishing, swimming). 28 bedrooms. D, B&B Dm118-209(£38-£68).

9 Spain
Parador de Jarandilla de la Vera
10450 Cáceres, Spain.
Tel 00 34 927 56 01 17, fax 56 00 88
jarandilla@parador.es
Fifteenth-century fortress in chestnut and oak woods. Round stone towers, drawbridge, galleried courtyard; garden with swimming pool amid olive trees. 53 bedrooms. D, B&B Pts 12,000-13,750 (£46-£52).

10 Spain
Parador Castillo de Sigüenza
Plaza del Castillo, Sigüenza, Spain.
Tel 00 34 949 39 01 00, fax 39 13 64
paradorsiguenza@parador.es
Twelfth-century castle (many uses, from Arab citadel to bishop's palace) dominating historic hilltop town. Vaulted restaurant, courtyard, small garden. 81 bedrooms. D, B&B Pts 10,450-15,700 (£40-£60).

fields.body:
Holidays

Marrakesh

Catch the excitement of the Djemaa El Fna, the square with jugglers, magicians and snake-charmers, on a three-night break for £350 with Direct Line Holidays (020 8239 3399). This includes BA flights from Heathrow on 6 February and half-board at the three-star hotel Oudaya.

Far East

A three-centre holiday with three nights in Singapore, four in Bangkok and seven in Pattaya costs £649 with Tradewinds (0870 751 0004). This includes outward flights between 22 and 31 January from Heathrow, Gatwick, Edinburgh, Birmingham or Manchester via Frankfurt or Paris and room-only accommodation. Direct flights from Heathrow for a £39 supplement.

Red Sea

Fly from Gatwick on 26 January and spend seven nights half-board at the four-star Heinan Hotel in Hurghada, Egypt, for £295 with Longwood Holidays (020 8551 4494).

Havana

Seven nights B&B at the three-star Hotel Inglaterra costs £589 with British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 245) for departures from Heathrow until 4 April. This includes return BA flights.

Caribbean

The Cruise Line (01273 835252) is offering an eight-night Cruise on the four-star Mistral for £599 (saving £556) for departures to Guadeloupe this Friday or 19 January. The itinerary includes St Maarten, Trinidad, Barbados, Grenada, St Lucia and Mayreau.

Cyprus

Fly from Gatwick or Manchester on Saturday for seven nights self-catering at the Land of the Kings Apartments in Paphos for £149 with Olympic Holidays (020 8343 9090). Departures on 20 and 27 January start at £169.

Flights

Sydney

Book by 31 January with Austravel (0870 055 0223) for a £559 fare from Heathrow to Sydney, Brisbane or Cairns including a one-night stopover in Tokyo with free hotel and a flight between Brisbane and Sydney. Valid from 1 February to 30 April.

Mexico

Fly from Gatwick to Puerto Vallarta on 22 January (returning 5 February) for £212. Book with Eclipse (08705 010203).

New York

Trailfinders (020 7937 5400) has three-day advance purchase fares with British Airways for £186 until 28 February. Must book by 29 January with a minimum Saturday night stay.

webTitle: Feeling hungry? Just follow your nose

fields.headline: Feeling hungry? Just follow your nose
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Cook hunts for truffles in the Apennine mountains where you're as likely to see wolves and boars as the prized delicacy
fields.trailText: Jonathan Cook hunts for truffles in the Apennine mountains where you're as likely to see wolves and boars as the prized delicacy.
fields.body:
'Va', va'!' Valissi Corinto shouts. It is unclear whether the order is addressed to his dogs or to us as we splash through a bath of mud recently vacated by wild boars. Presumably us: the dogs are in little need of encouragement. We, on the other hand, lag behind, grumbling as we become snared in branches and slip down banks of earth.

Valissi is a tartufaio, and for the past 37 years he and his dogs have been snuffling through the forests of the Apennine mountains of the Emilia-Romagna, in north-east Italy, searching for the much-prized subterranean golf balls of fungus known as truffles. It is a mysterious art and one he spent 30 years learning before taking up the job full-time. Our group had hoped to gain a little insight into his work, but he has the mischievous gleam in his eye of a man who knows a secret or two and isn't telling.

Not that he has put his faith solely in nature - a few years back, he planted his own saplings of chestnut and oak impregnated with truffle spores. In another decade, they should produce a regular crop of truffles, and one he'll be able to harvest with ease. But the location is a secret. As is the way he trains his dogs - his seven-year-old bitch Juve (short, of course, for Juventus) and her two offspring Cip and Ciop (pronounced 'chip' and 'chop' and apparently the Italian names of Disney's cartoon chipmunks).

Pigs, though better suited to this line of work (and easier for an unfit observer to keep track of), are apparently harder to train. Worse still, they are only enthusiastic about truffle hunting because they are even more enthusiastic about truffle eating. A tartufaio runs the risk of seeing his treasured fungus devoured before he can lay claim to it.

Valissi's excitement as Juve starts to dig makes sense given the small fortune he earns for every truffle. The white variety found among tree roots here are particularly prized by gourmets for their taste and pungency. But it is a false alarm. Soon, after more fruitless searching, Valissi admits defeat. This is a bad wood for truffles, he says, and he knows a better spot nearby. Tired and messy, we're starting to cotton on. Knowledge is money, and Valissi wants to keep us as much in the dark as possible.

In the next wood (lots of truffles but small and of poor quality, Valissi warns), Juve snouts around for a few minutes before digging frantically. Valissi pulls her back, using his vanghetto (truffling stick) to ease out the fungus ball from between the roots. Even before he has a chance to pass it to us, an offensive, slightly putrid, smell has filled the air. Maybe, I can't help feeling, it was better left buried.

Valissi is one of a vanishing breed of woodlander. The populations of the local villages have been slowly dying out, as the old forest arts have become redundant and youngsters have been attracted to nearby cities such as Bologna and Modena. In the past few decades the village of Pianaccio has dwindled from more than 800 inhabitants to barely 30, a figure only topped up during the skiing season. The region is trying to reverse the trend by reviving some of the area's traditional industries and lifestyles. In this spirit, the mountains were declared a national park in the late Eighties. It all sounds a little worthy, but for visitors attracted here by the opportunities for walks in the mountain forests it means an unexpected bonus - the chance to be transported into the world of a Thomas Hardy novel, where foraging, scavenging and hunting are the essentials of life. It's a high-altitude slice of Wessex.

As we walked the well-signed mountain paths, along carpets of ochre leaves and rotting chestnut cases, we regularly stumbled across crumbling casones. Once these rustic stone cottages were the key to the local economy - either as drying rooms for chestnuts, furnaces for making charcoal or as storerooms for woodland implements. There is now a drive to restore them and educate locals and visitors alike about the skills of this traditional culture.

At the Hotel Everest in La Ca we were offered a meal of several courses, all of them made from chestnut. If it sounds a little repetitive, think again. Presumably, before the advent of supermarkets, necessity was the mother - and grandmother - of invention: we had delicious chestnut polenta, ciacci (crepe), a sweet soup and frittelle (doughy flat bread). Add a dollop of ricotta or the local stracchino cheese, and it's a tasty feast.

Surprisingly, considering that it borders Tuscany, this region of the Apennines is little known to British visitors. In fact, it's not well-known to Italians either, unless they come for the skiing. But that's to miss out on pleasures the region has to offer at other times of the year, particularly its woodland trails. The network of paths, both high and low level, connect one village to the next, and mean it's easy to explore a new area each day. The hotel owners even lightened the load for us, in a reciprocal arrangement that ensured our bags were transported to the next destination.

In the autumn, the mountains are ablaze with colour as the oaks, chestnuts, birches and beeches begin to turn. At the top of the 5,000ft Monte Grande, we briefly surfaced from among the foliage to get a dizzying view of the surrounding countryside. But most of the time we were in winding, chaotic corridors of bark and leaves. When mist closed in, the darkening canopy overhead added a frisson of fairytale menace to the proceedings.

The more so because here be wolves. Seven, in fact. The pack roams the mountains but park wardens reassured us that they posed no danger. There are plenty of other non-humans sharing the woods. It is quite possible, if you tread lightly, to see red squirrels, deer, wild boars and muflones (a sort of cross between a goat and ibex).

I definitely saw the first two, and bored everyone with a disputed boar sighting too ('There was a black shape that moved very fast into the undergrowth. No, I didn't actually get a proper view but'). Equally hard to spot were the porcine mushrooms the woods are famous for. Irritatingly, most are well camouflaged to inexperienced eyes. As with truffles, it helps if you have a guide to show you where to look. But at least the most visible are also the most spectacular, like the huge tamburo (drum) mushroom.

Walking among all this flora and fauna gave us a hearty appetite. Fortunately, in the autumn, there is no shortage of local ingredients to go in the cooking pot - whether it be truffles, mushrooms, mirtillo (blueberries), endless varieties of cheese, chestnuts, boar, deer or trout. In Lizzano, the hub of the network of mountain villages, we arrived in time for the annual festa d'autunno, a cosy affair that revolves around a handful of stalls selling the many varieties of woodland booty. Restaurants and hotels host huge banquets. At the Tibidi Ristorante we started picking over the long menu before realising we were supposed to eat all 17 courses, most with liberal shavings of truffles. It was a fitting celebration of nature's bounty.

Getting there

Jonathan Cook travelled to Italy with Inntravel (01653 629010). A week's walking in the Apennines costs from £530 per person in a shared double room including seven nights' dinner, bed and breakfast and four picnic lunches, return BA flights from Heathrow to Bologna, and rail and private transfers, luggage transferred on from one hotel to another, walking maps and notes.

Inntravel also has 10-night autumn walking holidays which include a guided activity on alternate days such as hunting for mushrooms and truffles, a visit to a woodcarving studio and a cheese producer and cookery lessons. The price for autumn 2001 should be around £750.
fields.bodyText: 'Va', va'!' Valissi Corinto shouts. It is unclear whether the order is addressed to his dogs or to us as we splash through a bath of mud recently vacated by wild boars. Presumably us: the dogs are in little need of encouragement. We, on the other hand, lag behind, grumbling as we become snared in branches and slip down banks of earth. Valissi is a tartufaio, and for the past 37 years he and his dogs have been snuffling through the forests of the Apennine mountains of the Emilia-Romagna, in north-east Italy, searching for the much-prized subterranean golf balls of fungus known as truffles. It is a mysterious art and one he spent 30 years learning before taking up the job full-time. Our group had hoped to gain a little insight into his work, but he has the mischievous gleam in his eye of a man who knows a secret or two and isn't telling. Not that he has put his faith solely in nature - a few years back, he planted his own saplings of chestnut and oak impregnated with truffle spores. In another decade, they should produce a regular crop of truffles, and one he'll be able to harvest with ease. But the location is a secret. As is the way he trains his dogs - his seven-year-old bitch Juve (short, of course, for Juventus) and her two offspring Cip and Ciop (pronounced 'chip' and 'chop' and apparently the Italian names of Disney's cartoon chipmunks). Pigs, though better suited to this line of work (and easier for an unfit observer to keep track of), are apparently harder to train. Worse still, they are only enthusiastic about truffle hunting because they are even more enthusiastic about truffle eating. A tartufaio runs the risk of seeing his treasured fungus devoured before he can lay claim to it.
