webTitle: Winging it: Come fly with me

fields.headline: Come fly with me
fields.standfirst: To launch a regular column on his journey around the world in small planes, Martin Buckley describes his early fascination with flight and how he got his pilot's licence
fields.trailText: To launch a regular column on his journey around the world in small planes, Martin Buckley describes his early fascination with flight and how he got his pilot's licence.
fields.body:
A few years ago, a friend asked me which single invention separated modern man from our ancestors.

'Penicillin,' I suggested. 'Photography?

Sellotape?'

'No,' he said, 'It's flight! For centuries they dreamed about it, from Icarus to Leonardo. But we can actually do it - and we should! We owe it to their memory to learn to fly!'

It's an extreme position, but then Peter is an extreme pilot - he owns three aeroplanes. And he's always looking for potential converts. A few weeks after that conversation, he took me flying.

It was a brilliant summer day in the Cotswolds, the flying club a broad acreage of cracked, grass-tufted concrete that once witnessed the rumbling of a hundred Lancaster bombers. As soon as we were airborne, Peter showed me how the pedals and joystick worked, and gave me the controls of the two-seater. We climbed away from the bosomy hills, levelling at 5,000 feet where we scampered among clouds of teased candyfloss. One was the shape of a doughnut, and I couldn't resist flying straight through the hole. It was a delirious sensation, and I began to laugh. I felt, I told him giggling, like an angel.

Peter looked at me askance. 'I've had some weird reactions taking people flying, but this is the first time anyone thought they were an angel!'

I have dreamt of flying since childhood - but who hasn't? Didn't most of us spend childhood nights flying, reliving the weightless suspension of the womb? My dreams were so vivid and familiar - they would always begin with me gliding, chest-down like Superman but mesmerically slowly, out of my room, along the landing and down the Burgundy-red stair carpet - that I was convinced of their literal reality: at night, while others slept, I flew.

I grew up in the countryside a few miles from Farnborough, and during the annual airshow I could look up from our back lawn to see the Battle of Britain Memorial Flight pass overhead. It was rare on any summer day for five minutes to go by without the sound of an aeroplane, and we would shade our eyes and wait to capture the silver flash like a fish as it passed, straight and fast, between the chimney and the woods, and we'd try to read its shape against the sky. Now, perversely, I am reassured when the summer silence of the British countryside - the hum of bees, the distant lowing of cows - is disturbed by the faint rumble of an aero engine. This, the rumble says, is how it should be.

A few years back I started work on a book about the world's deserts. Early one chilly desert morning on my two-year journey I was standing at the small aerodrome of Nazca, in Peru. The rising sun was staining the jagged Andes red. I climbed into a four-seat Cessna and the pilot, Carlos, fired up the engine.

Some things only make sense from the air. Dawn is the best moment to appreciate the Nazca lines, when the shallow ridges are shadowed by the low sun, and the air is clear and vapourless. Climbing over the pampas we soon saw them: hundreds of straight lines scoring the desert, and animal shapes, including the iconic hummingbird with its wings outstretched. They seemed smaller than I expected.

'It's because of our height,' yelled Carlos. 'They're a long way down.'

'Well, can't we go a bit lower?'

We dropped out of the dawn-pink sky to buzz the drawings. As we banked tightly they whirled around us - monkey, dog, 'owlman', spider.

No one knows why, 1,500 years ago, Nazcans engraved these lines into the desert crust. Erich von Daniken's Chariots of the Gods claimed that they were landing-strips for alien spacecraft; a more plausible theory suggests they played a role in hallucinogenic rituals. Andean museum collections groan with the paraphernalia of shamanistic drug-use, and it was - is - common for shamans in these psychedelic trances to identify with some symbolic creature. Frequently they believe their spirits take to the sky, and soar. Each of the creatures on the Nazcan crust is etched in a single line. Perhaps they were paths, walked by the shamans during their possession by the animal - spiritual, not alien, runways from which the shaman's soul took flight.

A few months after that flight, I found myself in the Peruvian Amazon, sitting in a wooden cabin with the velvet night sky overhead and the jungle raucous with insects. A shaman and I had been into the jungle and found the ayahuasca vine, and back at his village had boiled it into a thick, bilious stew. There were four of us on the oil lamp-lit porch, two of them women smoking tobacco pipes. The shaman passed the potion, and while we sipped he hummed a tune, an invocation to the spirits of ayahuasca. Soon the visions began: I was airborne, flying over endless fantastic cityscapes, their gothic towers and frothing parks delirious shades of crimson, lime-green and turquoise.

My friend Peter was surely right that as long as man has had an imagination he has dreamt of flight. Fortifications have been constructed at the highest elevations for strategic purposes, but we are also drawn to mountaintops for reasons of the soul. Hilary's conquest of Everest had for the British, in the year of Queen Elizabeth II's coronation, some profounder meaning than a mere sporting record. Close to Everest is the fabulous Mount Meru, navel of the earth, abode of the Hindu gods. The gods of the Greeks and Romans also inhabited the heavens - as do the Trinity and angels, and all the virtuous souls, of Christianity.

The centenary of man's first powered flight occurs in two years' time. Orville and Wilbur Wright's Flyer III was a cumbersome machine, its kite-like forward rudder and complex controls in many ways an aeronautical cul-de-sac (it was Blériot's Channel-crossing monoplane that standardised the aeroplane form we know today); but the Flyer changed the world for ever, possibly for the worse. In Baden-Powell's words: 'Wilbur Wright is in possession of a power which controls the fate of nations.'

When did humans first fly? The 1965 movie Those Magnificent Men In Their Flying Machines began with a slapstick montage of fur-clad cavemen futilely flapping their arms, and early aviators on primitive hang-gliders dropping like stones. The Chinese had constructed kites of tremendous sophistication and scale by the third century AD, and it's at least possible that people - clinging on or strapped on - took to the air. Everyone knows about the 'balloonist' craze that swept Europe in the eighteenth century in the wake of the Montgolfier brothers' hot-air ascents. But what about Sir George Cayley, MP for Scarborough, who launched a manned glider in 1848? If even a French aviation authority can call Cayley 'the true inventor of the aeroplane and one of the most powerful geniuses in the history of aviation', then it must be true - yet he languishes in obscurity.

As for me, I continued to experience livid, full-colour flying dreams into my late teens. If they stopped, perhaps it is because, as the shrinks tell us, flying dreams are associated with sexual longing. I suspect that the improvement in my sex life grounded my dreams. But I seized every opportunity that came my way to fly small aircraft.

I was in Kenya when I realised that the subject of my next book would be flight. A contact at Unesco's Nairobi desertification programme had introduced me to his son, a keen amateur pilot, who invited me to go flying with him over the Rift Valley. The problem was, neither of us had enough money to rent a plane. The following afternoon we went out to the airport, and hung around the pilot's clubroom until someone offered to take us up. It was a stunning flight, swooping around the emerald craters of the valley's extinct volcanoes. I discovered something valuable that day: that the owner of a pilot's licence can walk into an aerodrome, get chatting to fellow pilots, and stand a good chance of being offered a ride. Suddenly I had an image of myself 'hitch-hiking' by small plane from one aerodrome to the next - and the idea of Winging It was born, a journey around the planet celebrating the many facets of manned flight - a journey I'll be describing in The Observer over the next few months.

So it was that on a glittering late summer afternoon four months ago I found myself at an Ontario airfield, with six weeks in which to gain a flying licence. It was my first day at the school, and I was eager to be up in the air. Who knew how long the weather would hold? Within four hours of climbing off the Airbus, I was at the controls of a Cessna 152.

Tim Coombs, my instructor, had shown me the Walk Around: like pioneer aviators, pilots still begin every flight with a physical inspection of the plane, waggling ailerons and rudder, poking a stick in the fuel tank to check the fuel level (gauges can be unreliable), and carefully monitoring the engine's performance. To the uninitiated this behaviour implies severe doubts about the plane's airworthiness, but this is the aviator's Highway Code: when cars break down, you coast onto the hard shoulder, but aeroplanes are less forgiving, so they simply aren't allowed to go wrong. Instructors like to build your confidence fast, and they usually have you take off first time (it's landing that requires the skill). With a delicate shudder the fragile three-wheeled machine takes off, a winged Reliant Robin improbably airborne.

Within a fortnight I was learning how to enter and recover from the spins and spiral dives we've all seen in war movies, manoeuvres which place the pilot within seconds of death. I began by dreading these nauseating exercises, but ended up taking a grim pleasure in being able to pull them off (that is, pull out of them); maybe one day I'll even start to like them. Certainly, they give you confidence in your ability to handle a plane. The British have removed these perilous techniques from the flying syllabus - making us, according to one Canadian pilot, 'a bunch of woossies'.

Over the next six weeks I flew tiny trainers, a bulbous, leather-seated vintage Cessna (the 1954 equivalent of business jet) and a floatplane that scudded over the placid, pea-green lakes of northern Ontario. Cruising at 95 knots, I learned that unlike cars, planes can crash from being flown too slowly: the air passing over the wings is suddenly insufficient to generate lift, and the plane 'stalls'.

This usually occurs when a pilot is so intent on giving passengers a bird's-eye-view of, say, his new swimming pool, that he takes his eye off the speedo. A plane stalling at 3,000 feet picks up speed as it drops, quickly generates lift, and can resume flight; stall it at 500 feet, however, and before you know it your propeller is ploughing its way across a field, which in the mordant words of my instructor Tim, 'exceeds its design specification'.

I was learning to fly with half-dozen trainee commercial pilots, and conversation often revolved around aviation's unspoken freemasonic secret: the fact that it's dangerous. (Q: 'What's the definition of a good landing? A: One that you can walk away from.') Pilots naturally tend to a gallows humour: they know theirs is a job where failure can wipe the smiles off 300 holidaymakers. I've never forgotten the visual gag in Airplane, where the in-flight movie contentedly watched by passive, post-prandial passengers is a montage of aircraft crashes and great balls of fire. When I first saw the film the audience's laughter was edged with hysteria - this was a taboo flamboyantly transgressed, a joke that stirred our most assiduously buried fears.

The airliner is an aseptic high technology, close for most of us to brain surgery and rocket science. We all made paper aeroplanes at school, but the spectacle of a 365-ton jumbo jet ponderously mounting the air fills us with a superstitious sense of nature violated.

Consider the morbid press ecstasies whenever one of the slender aluminium tubes plunges into ocean, mountain or municipal housing unit. We are happy to drive along a wet motorway at 90 with spouse and new-born sleeping beside us - that's acceptable risk (it's a statistical fact that planes are safer than family cars); but when Concorde, with its hitherto 100 per cent safety record, experiences a freak accident, we are irrationally disturbed.

In flight, we behave as though we're not. The cabin staff's professional grins, the videos and Muzak all conspire to distract us from the terrifying miracle of flight. Magic seeks to appease the Gods, and flight is unquestionably magic; passengers know they have propitiated no one, signed no Faustian pact - they are exposed. Just two trembling wings and a clutch of fallible engines keep them airborne. And what about Human Error? The technology depends on two gold-braided fly-boys (they're usually male) up front, and recent events (the Russian pilot who let his knee-dandled son plough a plane into the ground, those heavy-drinking BA pilots) have taught us they're not angels. Taxiing up to take-off one morning, my plane skewed to the left. I shut the engine down and went to look for Paul, the mechanic. I found him with his head inside a deconstructed Cessna.

'Paul, I have a Situation.'

'Whassat?'

'Left brake locked on taxi.'

He pulled himself out of the fuselage, wiped his hands on his overalls and picked up a hammer.

'Is that what you need?' I asked.

'It fixes most things.'

He beat the brake pads and, achieving no result, grunted and stuck his head under the dashboard. I went to find a coat against the Canadian autumn winds. When I returned, Paul was smiling. 'You're lucky it didn't lock a couple of minutes later, when you were landing. Woulda spun you right off the runway.'

'Oh. Is it safe now?'

'Safe is a relative term, my friend. I keep both my feet on the ground.'

In the mid-1960s, my father took a job with the UN, and we as a family were en route to Turkey via Rome. The era of flight as mass transit had arrived with the plane we were flying - a Boeing 707 - but flight was still romantic then, and Pan American had yet to become a victim of deregulated airways and go bust. Our Boeing was curvaceous, and the miniskirted hostesses who wore crisp, virtually seamless dresses like those in Kubrick's 2001 gave us children crayons and colouring books. The outline drawings all showed airliners and airports, and trilbied, suited emissaries of capitalism grinning as they passed through sleek and streamlined terminals, utopian symbols of Modernity. What happened to it all? When did the giddy romance of flight implode into the banality of mass tourism, where every grey terminal resembles every other, with the numbing inevitabilities of the X-ray machine and the stuttering Baggage Claim carousel?

Yet there are still thousands of courageous, wary figures who wrestle small planes over deserts and choppy seas and fog-covered mountains - planes that have changed little technically in 50 years. There are pilots who live in hangars, sleeping beside their planes, and others who have devoted their lives and chequebooks to the preservation of ancient, impossibly exotic aircraft. Then there are the half-mad aerobatics junkies, the air racers, the exhibition pilots who risk everything to thrill a jaded crowd, and meet their deaths at airshows with sickening regularity. It was to encounter these pilots, all over the world, that I decided to set off on the journey I'll be describing in The Observer.

My most memorable flight as a pilot so far came after six weeks in the Canadian skies, soon after I gained my licence. It stirred me (it still does) to wake up and see the leather wallet with Pilot Licence printed on it in gold sitting on the bedside table. That day I woke up early to a bright, cloudless winter sky. Perfect. At the aerodrome I tugged my plane round into the sun's first copper rays, and as they melted the fine layer of iced dew on the wings I completed the flyer's ritual, checking ailerons and rudder and poking a length of dowling into the fuel tanks to be sure that the cockpit gauges didn't lie.

Climb in, headphones on, fire her up, taxi onto the runway. Add full power, and the engine is almost brutally alive, the prop jerking the fuselage forward as you accelerate to 10,000 rpm. At around 55 knots you ease back the stick, and there it is - weightlessness, gravity-defiance, the instant miracle of flight, the landscape falling away from you, emerald streaked with early-morning gold.

Winging it

Martin Buckley sets off this week on his global journey by small aircraft. He begins with a pilgrimage to the workshop in Scarborough where Sir George Cayley built the first manned glider. But soon he will be flying to Paris, Marseilles and on to North Africa. Observer readers can share Buckley's experiences as he files a fortnightly column from 21 January in Escape based on his research for Winging It, a travel book celebrating manned flight around the world. If you have information to share, you can also contact him en route by emailing mbwingingit@hotmail.com. Buckley's first book Grains of Sand is published in paperback on 29 March (Vintage, £7.99).

As we banked tightly they whirled around us - monkey, dog, 'owlman', spider. No one knows why, 1,500 years ago, Nazcans engraved these lines into the desert crust. Erich von Daniken's Chariots of the Gods claimed that they were landing-strips for alien spacecraft; a more plausible theory suggests they played a role in hallucinogenic rituals. Andean museum collections groan with the paraphernalia of shamanistic drug-use, and it was - is - common for shamans in these psychedelic trances to identify with some symbolic creature. Frequently they believe their spirits take to the sky, and soar. Each of the creatures on the Nazcan crust is etched in a single line. Perhaps they were paths, walked by the shamans during their possession by the animal - spiritual, not alien, runways from which the shaman's soul took flight. A few months after that flight, I found myself in the Peruvian Amazon, sitting in a wooden cabin with the velvet night sky overhead and the jungle raucous with insects. A shaman and I had been into the jungle and found the ayahuasca vine, and back at his village had boiled it into a thick, bilious stew. There were four of us on the oil lamp-lit porch, two of them women smoking tobacco pipes. The shaman passed the potion, and while we sipped he hummed a tune, an invocation to the spirits of ayahuasca. Soon the visions began: I was airborne, flying over endless fantastic cityscapes, their gothic towers and frothing parks delirious shades of crimson, lime-green and turquoise. My friend Peter was surely right that as long as man has had an imagination he has dreamt of flight. Fortifications have been constructed at the highest elevations for strategic purposes, but we are also drawn to mountaintops for reasons of the soul. Hilary's conquest of Everest had for the British, in the year of Queen Elizabeth II's coronation, some profounder meaning than a mere sporting record. Close to Everest is the fabulous Mount Meru, navel of the earth, abode of the Hindu gods. The gods of the Greeks and Romans also inhabited the heavens - as do the Trinity and angels, and all the virtuous souls, of Christianity. The centenary of man's first powered flight occurs in two years' time. Orville and Wilbur Wright's Flyer III was a cumbersome machine, its kite-like forward rudder and complex controls in many ways an aeronautical cul-de-sac (it was Blériot's Channel-crossing monoplane that standardised the aeroplane form we know today); but the Flyer changed the world for ever, possibly for the worse. In Baden-Powell's words: 'Wilbur Wright is in possession of a power which controls the fate of nations.' When did humans first fly? The 1965 movie Those Magnificent Men In Their Flying Machines began with a slapstick montage of fur-clad cavemen futilely flapping their arms, and early aviators on primitive hang-gliders dropping like stones. The Chinese had constructed kites of tremendous sophistication and scale by the third century AD, and it's at least possible that people - clinging on or strapped on - took to the air. Everyone knows about the 'balloonist' craze that swept Europe in the eighteenth century in the wake of the Montgolfier brothers' hot-air ascents. But what about Sir George Cayley, MP for Scarborough, who launched a manned glider in 1848? If even a French aviation authority can call Cayley 'the true inventor of the aeroplane and one of the most powerful geniuses in the history of aviation', then it must be true - yet he languishes in obscurity. As for me, I continued to experience livid, full-colour flying dreams into my late teens. If they stopped, perhaps it is because, as the shrinks tell us, flying dreams are associated with sexual longing. I suspect that the improvement in my sex life grounded my dreams. But I seized every opportunity that came my way to fly small aircraft. I was in Kenya when I realised that the subject of my next book would be flight. A contact at Unesco's Nairobi desertification programme had introduced me to his son, a keen amateur pilot, who invited me to go flying with him over the Rift Valley. The problem was, neither of us had enough money to rent a plane. The following afternoon we went out to the airport, and hung around the pilot's clubroom until someone offered to take us up. It was a stunning flight, swooping around the emerald craters of the valley's extinct volcanoes. I discovered something valuable that day: that the owner of a pilot's licence can walk into an aerodrome, get chatting to fellow pilots, and stand a good chance of being offered a ride. Suddenly I had an image of myself 'hitch-hiking' by small plane from one aerodrome to the next - and the idea of Winging It was born, a journey around the planet celebrating the many facets of manned flight - a journey I'll be describing in The Observer over the next few months. So it was that on a glittering late summer afternoon four months ago I found myself at an Ontario airfield, with six weeks in which to gain a flying licence. It was my first day at the school, and I was eager to be up in the air. Who knew how long the weather would hold? Within four hours of climbing off the Airbus, I was at the controls of a Cessna 152. Tim Coombs, my instructor, had shown me the Walk Around: like pioneer aviators, pilots still begin every flight with a physical inspection of the plane, waggling ailerons and rudder, poking a stick in the fuel tank to check the fuel level (gauges can be unreliable), and carefully monitoring the engine's performance. To the uninitiated this behaviour implies severe doubts about the plane's airworthiness, but this is the aviator's Highway Code: when cars break down, you coast onto the hard shoulder, but aeroplanes are less forgiving, so they simply aren't allowed to go wrong. Instructors like to build your confidence fast, and they usually have you take off first time (it's landing that requires the skill). With a delicate shudder the fragile three-wheeled machine takes off, a winged Reliant Robin improbably airborne. Within a fortnight I was learning how to enter and recover from the spins and spiral dives we've all seen in war movies, manoeuvres which place the pilot within seconds of death. I began by dreading these nauseating exercises, but ended up taking a grim pleasure in being able to pull them off (that is, pull out of them); maybe one day I'll even start to like them. Certainly, they give you confidence in your ability to handle a plane. The British have removed these perilous techniques from the flying syllabus - making us, according to one Canadian pilot, 'a bunch of woossies'. Over the next six weeks I flew tiny trainers, a bulbous, leather-seated vintage Cessna (the 1954 equivalent of business jet) and a floatplane that scudded over the placid, pea-green lakes of northern Ontario. Cruising at 95 knots, I learned that unlike cars, planes can crash from being flown too slowly: the air passing over the wings is suddenly insufficient to generate lift, and the plane 'stalls'. This usually occurs when a pilot is so intent on giving passengers a bird's-eye-view of, say, his new swimming pool, that he takes his eye off the speedo. A plane stalling at 3,000 feet picks up speed as it drops, quickly generates lift, and can resume flight; stall it at 500 feet, however, and before you know it your propeller is ploughing its way across a field, which in the mordant words of my instructor Tim, 'exceeds its design specification'. I was learning to fly with half-dozen trainee commercial pilots, and conversation often revolved around aviation's unspoken freemasonic secret: the fact that it's dangerous. (Q: 'What's the definition of a good landing? A: One that you can walk away from.') Pilots naturally tend to a gallows humour: they know theirs is a job where failure can wipe the smiles off 300 holidaymakers. I've never forgotten the visual gag in Airplane, where the in-flight movie contentedly watched by passive, post-prandial passengers is a montage of aircraft crashes and great balls of fire. When I first saw the film the audience's laughter was edged with hysteria - this was a taboo flamboyantly transgressed, a joke that stirred our most assiduously buried fears. The airliner is an aseptic high technology, close for most of us to brain surgery and rocket science. We all made paper aeroplanes at school, but the spectacle of a 365-ton jumbo jet ponderously mounting the air fills us with a superstitious sense of nature violated. Consider the morbid press ecstasies whenever one of the slender aluminium tubes plunges into ocean, mountain or municipal housing unit. We are happy to drive along a wet motorway at 90 with spouse and new-born sleeping beside us - that's acceptable risk (it's a statistical fact that planes are safer than family cars); but when Concorde, with its hitherto 100 per cent safety record, experiences a freak accident, we are irrationally disturbed. In flight, we behave as though we're not. The cabin staff's professional grins, the videos and Muzak all conspire to distract us from the terrifying miracle of flight. Magic seeks to appease the Gods, and flight is unquestionably magic; passengers know they have propitiated no one, signed no Faustian pact - they are exposed. Just two trembling wings and a clutch of fallible engines keep them airborne. And what about Human Error? The technology depends on two gold-braided fly-boys (they're usually male) up front, and recent events (the Russian pilot who let his knee-dandled son plough a plane into the ground, those heavy-drinking BA pilots) have taught us they're not angels. Taxiing up to take-off one morning, my plane skewed to the left. I shut the engine down and went to look for Paul, the mechanic. I found him with his head inside a deconstructed Cessna. 'Paul, I have a Situation.' 'Whassat?' 'Left brake locked on taxi.' He pulled himself out of the fuselage, wiped his hands on his overalls and picked up a hammer. 'Is that what you need?' I asked. 'It fixes most things.' He beat the brake pads and, achieving no result, grunted and stuck his head under the dashboard. I went to find a coat against the Canadian autumn winds. When I returned, Paul was smiling. 'You're lucky it didn't lock a couple of minutes later, when you were landing. Woulda spun you right off the runway.' 'Oh. Is it safe now?' 'Safe is a relative term, my friend. I keep both my feet on the ground.' In the mid-1960s, my father took a job with the UN, and we as a family were en route to Turkey via Rome. The era of flight as mass transit had arrived with the plane we were flying - a Boeing 707 - but flight was still romantic then, and Pan American had yet to become a victim of deregulated airways and go bust. Our Boeing was curvaceous, and the miniskirted hostesses who wore crisp, virtually seamless dresses like those in Kubrick's 2001 gave us children crayons and colouring books. The outline drawings all showed airliners and airports, and trilbied, suited emissaries of capitalism grinning as they passed through sleek and streamlined terminals, utopian symbols of Modernity. What happened to it all? When did the giddy romance of flight implode into the banality of mass tourism, where every grey terminal resembles every other, with the numbing inevitabilities of the X-ray machine and the stuttering Baggage Claim carousel? Yet there are still thousands of courageous, wary figures who wrestle small planes over deserts and choppy seas and fog-covered mountains - planes that have changed little technically in 50 years. There are pilots who live in hangars, sleeping beside their planes, and others who have devoted their lives and chequebooks to the preservation of ancient, impossibly exotic aircraft. Then there are the half-mad aerobatics junkies, the air racers, the exhibition pilots who risk everything to thrill a jaded crowd, and meet their deaths at airshows with sickening regularity. It was to encounter these pilots, all over the world, that I decided to set off on the journey I'll be describing in The Observer. My most memorable flight as a pilot so far came after six weeks in the Canadian skies, soon after I gained my licence. It stirred me (it still does) to wake up and see the leather wallet with Pilot Licence printed on it in gold sitting on the bedside table. That day I woke up early to a bright, cloudless winter sky. Perfect. At the aerodrome I tugged my plane round into the sun's first copper rays, and as they melted the fine layer of iced dew on the wings I completed the flyer's ritual, checking ailerons and rudder and poking a length of dowling into the fuel tanks to be sure that the cockpit gauges didn't lie. Climb in, headphones on, fire her up, taxi onto the runway. Add full power, and the engine is almost brutally alive, the prop jerking the fuselage forward as you accelerate to 10,000 rpm. At around 55 knots you ease back the stick, and there it is - weightlessness, gravity-defiance, the instant miracle of flight, the landscape falling away from you, emerald streaked with early-morning gold. Winging it Martin Buckley sets off this week on his global journey by small aircraft. He begins with a pilgrimage to the workshop in Scarborough where Sir George Cayley built the first manned glider. But soon he will be flying to Paris, Marseilles and on to North Africa. Observer readers can share Buckley's experiences as he files a fortnightly column from 21 January in Escape based on his research for Winging It, a travel book celebrating manned flight around the world. If you have information to share, you can also contact him en route by emailing mbwingingit@hotmail.com. Buckley's first book Grains of Sand is published in paperback on 29 March (Vintage, £7.99).

fields.headline: Discount or disgrace?
fields.trailText: Are there any real savings to be made by booking now or should those in search of some cheap summer sunshine hold tight for last-minute deals?
fields.body:
The big holiday companies have flooded the high street with offers of half-price holidays, free child places and cut-price insurance in their annual bid to kickstart bookings for the summer. First Choice's current 'Buy One Get One Free' campaign is just one example, with prices starting from £128 for a week's holiday in Corfu. But for every discount poster there is a story in the media warning that these deals really are too good to be true. So are there any real savings to be made by booking now or should those in search of some cheap summer sunshine hold tight for last-minute deals?

Trading standards officer Bruce Treloar said the main pitfall to watch out for when shopping for new year bargains is prices which have been inflated just before Christmas to make the January discounts seem juicier. For example, a seven-night Tenerife holiday advertised in Airtours' second edition summer sun brochure quotes an adult price of £619, a child price of £159 and a flight supplement of £42 to fly from Manchester. By the time the third edition came out in November, prices for the same holiday had jumped to £719, £299 and £64 respectively. The current offer of £50 off adult prices does not seem so generous when seen in this light.

Airtours is not the only tour operator to employ this practice and the Institute of Trading Standards will be keeping a close eye on discount strategies over the next few weeks to ensure operators do not breach trading regulations.

Club Travel 2000 marketing director Andy Loynes said: 'Operators use a variety of tricks to confuse people. Many of these 50 per cent discounts apply to the adult price but the child price and the flight supplement may have doubled.'

Operators and travel agents defend their discounting policy by explaining that the travel industry is ruled by the laws of supply and demand and prices must fluctuate accordingly. Thomas Cook commercial director Mike Beaumont said that many holidays were in fact being sold at lower prices than last year. A two-week holiday in Majorca which cost £350 last January is this year being sold for £217.50, he claimed.

His advice for families who want to take advantage of free child places or who know where they want to stay is to book now. Operators have cut back on capacity this year so there is unlikely to be a glut of late availability or bargains in peak summer months. The poor winter weather has also generated a surge of early bookings for summer holidays, with Cyprus, Greece, Cancun and Florida emerging as hotspots.

Avoiding the discount pitfalls

 Shop around. Many of the big tour operators are selling identical holidays. If you can't get the discount being advertised, go somewhere else.

 Don't take discounts at face value. Ignore the percentages, look at the price. Is there a brochure showing the holiday at its original price? Legally tour operators can only discount a price that has been held for a period of 28 days in the previous six months. In practice, this is difficult to check as agents will remove old brochures from the shelves but if you have doubts contact your local trading standards officer.

 Watch out for hidden extras such as under-occupancy surcharges, or supplements for regional departures.

 Read the small print: most deals come with date and departure restrictions.

 Remember it is illegal for a holiday company to insist you purchase insurance in order to receive a holiday discount.

webTitle: Skiing resorts: Tignes takes on Val D'Isere

fields.headline: A rough and ready grandeur
fields.standfirst: Tignes is now giving its glamorous neighbour Val D'Isère a run for its money, writes Peter Beaumont
fields.trailText: Tignes is now giving its glamorous neighbour Val D'Isère a run for its money, writes Peter Beaumont.
fields.body:
Tignes has never been the prettiest of French resorts - the high-rise hotel blocks of Val Claret at the head of the valley take some beating for ugliness - and two years ago I found it particularly disappointing. Bulldozers were heaving through the centre as substantial building work dragged on. But last week I renewed my love affair with the resort.

The new ski centre is up and running, the road improvements are complete and a heavy early season dump of snow had dressed the prettier village of Tignes Le Lac in its best winter clothes.

The truth is, you don't go to Tignes for the ambience, you go for the skiing: the vast open fields of snow. And, after years of travelling the world to ski, Tignes remains one of my favourite resorts - up there with Chamonix and Banff-Lake Louise in the Canadian Rockies. They share one thing in common: a certain rough and ready charm with the kind of challenging skiing that won't have you rushing off the mountain for the bars before it is dark.

And despite lacking the breathtaking scenery of the Chamonix Aiguilles or the Rockies' Mount Rundle, Tignes has a certain grandeur all of its own, from its higher alpine slopes through the tight dark woods lower down. There is something, too, about creeping up the 20 kilometres of switchbacks above the neighbouring resorts of Les Arcs and Val Thorens that always cranks up the anticipation, spotting familiar landmarks along the way until, finally, the dam is crossed, and you have arrived.

What I like about Tignes too is that it is a resort where the skiing caters for all abilities: long swooping, gentle greens and blues, steep enough to challenge the most ambitious beginners, leading to reds and blacks and off-piste steep shots that will keep even the most ambitious of experts happy.

And here we were, driving into town after a pleasant two-hour pootle from Geneva along Lac Annecy to Albertville. I must admit I hate skiing in poor light. My sense of depth in these conditions is particularly poor. It also doesn't help skiing on telemark skis when you are following someone a decade younger, whose idea of fun is trying to ski backwards at speed on high performance skis or jumping down steep off-piste slopes. Which is, I guess, how we found ourselves after three hours skiing down an icy black, through murky mist, as the last light faded from the day.

After a night of snow, day two dawned to pristine blue skies, fresh powder on a firm base, and temperatures, for December, that were almost mild enough to allow skiing without a Gore-Tex windproof jacket.

So after a quick breakfast, we were off eating up blues, reds and then blacks until the inevitable happened, the egging-on-thing got silly. (And how is it that no matter how tightly you have done up your jacket, when you land in a snowdrift head first snow always shoots right down to the small of your back?)

Tooling round the slopes, one notices that Tignes and neighbouring Val D'Isère have really picked up their game. In the decade and a half in which I have been going to Tignes the quality of everything has been raised from mountain restaurants to the ski lifts which are going through a process of gradually being upgraded - although the high speed funicular from Val D'Isère has been closed for safety checks in the wake of the Kaprun disaster.

And if you like skiing with your countrymen then Tignes is also the place for you, particularly early in the season when prices are at their most appealing for bargain-hunting Brits.

Where Tignes falls down if anywhere, however, is in the quality of the nightlife. There are some pleasant enough bars, including the British run Censored, but resort restaurants and watering holes are pretty much the same unless you go to Val D'Isère. But this doesn't matter, for the skiing will call you back again and again.

Tignes factfile

Linked with Val D'Isère as L'Espace Killy.

Number of lifts: 96, leading to 200 miles of piste (60 per cent green/blue; 30 per cent red; 10 per cent black).

Six-day L'Espace Killy lift pass bought at resort costs 1,070 francs (£103). Check your tour operator's pre-bookable price.

Limited summer skiing on the Grande Motte glacier.

Tignes features in the brochures of all the leading tour operators. Sample price: £259 with Crystal (0870 848 7000), based on four people sharing a self-catering apartment. Chalet board starts at £445. Both with flights from Gatwick.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Gail
fields.trailText: A good place to stay in Mumbai is The Salvation Army behind the Taj Mahal Hotel. It feels a little institutionalised, but the rooms are large and you also get a breakfast and tea (of sorts).
fields.body:
Sorry to hear about the troubles in Kathmandu - I was luckier, and loved it - even the power cuts!

The Guardian asked for tips on places to stay in Mumbai. A good place is The Salvation Army behind the Taj Mahal Hotel. It feels a little institutionalised, but the rooms are large and you also get a breakfast and tea (of sorts). It's a lot better then the the other dodgy hotels on the same road, and the location is good; it's near the cinemas and cosmopolitan bars, but the best thing is that you can nip across the road and escape the heat in the air conditioned Taj. In the hotel there's a great bookshop with daily English papers,and a wonderful bakery. Just the thing when you begin to find India hard work....

And you get a chance to become a Bollywood star as every morning a man (Leo?) will come to the Sally and ask you to be an extra in a Bollywood film...

Look out for the rain at about 3pm in Singapore.
Best wishes.

fields.headline: India's keeper of the flame
fields.standfirst: Allan Jenkins makes a pilgrimage to savour dishes that are the essence of Avadhi cooking
fields.trailText: Allan Jenkins makes a pilgrimage to savour dishes that are the essence of Avadhi cooking.
fields.body:
'A cook has to be master of four elements: fire, water, salt and pepper.' Gulam Rasool and his assistant cook/interpreter laugh as he picks up the glowing coal with his bare hand and places it carefully in the centre of his bowl of Galawat Ke Kebab, the famed Mughlai dish of spiced and ground mutton. The use of charcoal smoking in this manner and the mixing of meats with fruits and ground nuts and spices is central to the Avadhi cuisine of Lucknow, capital of Uttar Pradesh. And Chef Rasool is Avadhi's greatest guru.

Ask Rasool who makes the best Galawat Ke Kebab in Lucknow and he will tell you that it is Grandson Tunday, proprietor of the kebab café in the labyrinthine Aminabad Bazaar and descendant of the legendary one-armed Tunday who established Lucknow's most atmospheric street-food restaurant.

It is a less fierily authentic version of Tunday's Galawat Ke recipe which is used at the smart Kebab Factory at Delhi's Radisson Hotel where the capital's demi-monde listen to Indianised versions of western crooners while eating a westernised take on their own culture's cooking. Ask any other top Indian chef, though, who is keeper of the roaring flame, the master of authentic Avadhi cooking, and they will respectfully tell you there is only Rasool.

Rasool has been cooking this sophisticated amalgamation of Mughlai and Hindi dishes perfected by the Lucknowi nawabs for nearly 60 years (there is some question about his age, he owns up to being maybe 70 or 76). But five years ago, at an age when most chefs working 12 hours a day surrounded by blasting tandoors would rather retire, he returned to the city of his birth to the palatial Taj Residency hotel. Not to be missed are the ramala roti, better known as the Lucknowi handkerchief naan, because of their size and light, lacy thinness - perfect for mopping up dhal, rhogan josh and biryanis.

Eating habits and the nawabs have played an extraordinary role in India's history. It was the British annexing of Avadh, and its exiling of Wajid Ali Shah, Lucknow's last nawab to Calcutta in 1856 which was chiefly responsible for the 1857 Mutiny. The other main contributing factor was the Bengal army order for the sepoys to bite cartridges, whose grease was rumoured to contain pig and cow fat, before putting them into their rifles. This was insulting to both Muslim and Hindu soldiers and triggered the uprising. The British and their supporters in the city held out at the Residency for 87 days before being besieged for a further two months during which time more than 2,000 died.

Tennyson's 'Defence of Lucknow' was until recently probably responsible for most of the British visitors to the city, though at only 2,000 tourists a year in a city with a population of two million, these are still rare enough to excite good-humoured interest when visiting the ruined Residency or the magnificent Bara Imababara Shia tomb. In recent years Lucknow has also become popular with Western followers of the guru Poonjaji, who died here in 1997.

But the newest group to visit is the authentic curry hunter - those British foodies who pass up on the shopping opportunities in the bazaars and instead make their pilgrimage to the Taj Residency and the cooking of Rasool. These, at least, have already feasted on Indian food at London's Chutney Mary. They have read proprietor Namita Panjabi's sister Camellia's definitive 50 Great Curries and know that chikankari is Lucknow's fine embroidered cloth and not just another take on tikka masala.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Graham Hamill, concierge at  42, The Calls, Leeds
fields.trailText: Graham Hamill, concierge at 42, The Calls, Leeds.
fields.body:
Have there been any famous guests?
Yes, we have had pop stars such as Martine McCutcheon and Louise here recently. We get lots of Yorkshire TV people because the station is based just up the road and we have even had filming at the hotel. During the summer the TV cricket commentators stayed during the Test match at Headingley against the West Indies. They were very friendly and were quite disappointed it finished in two days instead of five.

What sort of guests usually stay?
During the week it is mainly business guests, but at the weekends it can be anyone. A lot of people come up to Leeds just to do some shopping at Harvey Nichols, even Londoners who just want to compare shops. We are very popular with wedding guests and honeymooners, who often request room 307 which is spacious and has a black and white striped decor. We have 41 rooms and all are decorated differently so regulars always ask to try a new room. Visiting football fans often stay when their team is playing Leeds United. I have been a Leeds fan since I was in nappies. It's always a friendly atmosphere.

Any unusual requests?
Nothing too strange but I have had to go and buy chocolate for a lady at 3am.

What about a day out?
I recommend the Tetley Brewery Wharf, which takes you through the ages of beer brewing and the Royal Armouries across the river from us. Shoppers should go to Victoria Quarter. I have lived in Leeds my whole life and my family often go out to Bolton Abbey which is about half an hour away. It is in the countryside, by a river, and is one of our favourite places for a picnic: there is still a small church. Harewood House has tons of things for children to do.

What about a night out?
The top Indian restaurant in Leeds is probably the Dar Bar. The Brasserie next door, which does a smashing steak, and The Calls Grill nearby are good. But whenever I go out for dinner myself I like to have a load to eat and I find that the portions in designer restaurants are a bit small!

 42, The Calls: 0113 244 0099. Rooms from £95 per night.

webTitle: Imagine is your No 1 (closely followed by Beelzebub)

fields.headline: Imagine is your No 1 (closely followed by Beelzebub)
fields.standfirst: In a fight that went to the wire, Lennon's anthem topped the Channel 4/Observer poll. Here Neil Spencer distils the truth from the myths that surround the song
fields.trailText: In a fight that went to the wire, Lennon's anthem topped the Channel 4/Observer poll. Here Neil Spencer distils the truth from the myths that surround the song
fields.body:
Imagine no John Lennon, I wonder if you can. Of course you can't. No other pop star has stained our era quite so indelibly, inspired love, admiration and anger on such a scale. As Beatle one, two, three or four (let's not haggle over that fruitless pecking order) he bequeathed what remains, arguably, pop's greatest and most influential canon of work. And alone among all the early, pointless, squalid deaths that litter pop history, his alone was the result of an assassination.

That 20 years after his murder, John Lennon continues to exercise a powerful grip on the imagination of a worldwide public, is underscored by the election of 'Imagine' as the No 1 of UK number ones in Channel 4's current poll.

Hardly a surprise perhaps. With its utopian sentiments, solemn piano coda and wistful vocals, 'Imagine' has become the premier item in pop's slim hymnal, edging McCartney's 'Let It Be' into second place, with Simon and Garfunkel's 'Bridge Over Troubled Water' among the lighter-waving also-rans. The song may exhort us to 'imagine no religion' and 'no hell or heaven', but its celestial imagery ('above us only sky') and tone are clearly spiritual and aspirational. Surprisingly, 'Imagine' was not a British single until 1975, perhaps because Imagine the album soared to the top of the charts on its release in October 1971, two days before Lennon's 31st birthday, becoming the most successful record of Lennon's post-Beatles career. In the States, the song climbed to number two on the Cashbox charts, but 'Imagine' did not become a UK No 1 until Lennon's murder in December 1980 sent it there, borne aloft on a tide of sorrow.

Since then it's never been absent for long, reappearing in 1988 and 1999, when it was short-listed for the already forgotten 'Song of The Millennium' (a Westlife Abba cover, supposedly). 'Imagine' is simply in the ether; for example, in an initiative sponsored by the United Nations on Lennon's 50th birthday in October 1990, the song was broadcast by more than 1,000 radio stations in over 50 countries.

Exactly what the world is celebrating through 'Imagine' is less easily nailed down. Chiefly, one suspects, it's the memory of Lennon himself, the fallen hero and rock martyr, who thanks in no small part to Yoko Ono's solicitous guarding of her husband's legend, has long acceded to saint-like status.

'Imagine' has been the major theme tune to Lennon's canonisation. The accompanying proto-video, shot at the Lennons' Ascot mansion as part of Gimme Some Truth, a documentary film on the making of Imagine, has played a vital role. In an all-white drawing room, furnished only with an acre of white carpet, a Perspex table, and an all-white chess set, an unusually well-scrubbed John Lennon plays a white baby grand (a present to Yoko from him). As he gazes earnestly ahead, Yoko, in white dress and Cleopatra headband, floats from window to window, opening shutters, spilling light into the room.

The scene remains one of the most resonant images of John and Yoko's life together, presenting them as a pair of pure hearts wrapped in their idyll, yearning for a better world. The reality was somewhat different. The Ascot mansion was abandoned for New York City shortly afterwards, and within two years John and Yoko broke up for Lennon's notorious 18-month 'lost weekend'.

The real Lennon was certainly no enlightened saint sequestered in a pristine sitting room, but an artist with a volatile temper and an acid wit, a man who wrestled privately and publicly with a host of inner demons, and who was by turns charming, funny, brilliant and scary.

That all too human Lennon, recently described by Paul McCartney as 'a delicious broth of a boy', can be glimpsed easily enough on Gimme Some Truth (re-released on DVD last year), and stands naked on Plastic Ono Band, the 'primal' album he made just 10 months before Imagine. It is the mawkish idealist of 'Imagine' who is most often held up for admiration and ridicule, however.

For Albert Goldman, most scabrous (and revealing) of Lennon's critics, 'Imagine' is 'a hippie wishing well full of pennyweight dreams for a better world'. The song certainly glides on the airiest of utopian notions, while Lennon's urging us to 'imagine no possessions' is, at best, ironic coming from a millionaire rock star, gazing over seventy private acres of rolling Surrey woodland.

Charges of hypocrisy are wide of the mark, though. Lennon believed in a better world and fought for it in his way. To him, 'Imagine' was 'Working Class Hero' with chocolate on 'anti-religious, anti-nationalistic, anti-conventional, anti-capitalistic - but because it is sugar coated it is accepted'.

The song's inspiration was two-fold. Part of it came from Yoko's 1964 book, Grapefruit, which had been republished in 1970, and whose poetic aphorisms ran along the lines of 'Imagine the clouds dripping. Dig a hole in your garden to put them in'. Later, Lennon rued that he hadn't granted his wife a co-writing credit.

Then there was the idea of 'positive thinking' that Lennon had picked up from a book of 'positive prayer' that was handed to him by US comedian Dick Gregory.

This was the same concept which had inspired his and Yoko's campaign that 'War Is Over If You Want It', and in which John maintained a belief for the rest of his life.

He observed in 1980 that visualisation and affirmation had become commonplace among sports champions and corporate strategists. 'I believe in the power of mantra,' he said. The global anthem that is 'Imagination' some 30 years on surely proves him right.

Imagine: anatomy of the best No 1 single ever

Producers: John Lennon, Yoko Ono, Phil Spector

Musicians: Lennon, (vocals, piano), Klaus Voormann (bass), Alan White (drums)

Recorded: May 1971 at Lennon's house in Ascot.

Release #1: Although the album Imagine was released in October 1971, 'Imagine' the single wasn't out in the UK until 24 October 1975. It reached No 6 and spent 11 weeks in the charts.

Release #2: After Lennon's death in 1980, people were eager to buy 'Imagine'. Even before its re-release, 300,000 copies had been been ordered, and when it was finally available on 27 December, it spent 4 weeks at No 1 and remained in the charts for 13 weeks.

Release #3: 10 December 1988. 'Imagine' was in the charts for 5 weeks, reaching only No 45.

Release #4 'Imagine' was the favourite to be the 'Millennium Single'. After being released on 25 December 1999, it reached No 3 and spent 5 weeks in the charts, beaten to the top spot by Irish boyband Westlife.

John on Imagine

'It's the one I like best.'

The co-producer: Yoko Ono

Some songs you just know were recorded in the evening or late at night, but this was a day song. It was recorded during the morning, actually. Because the world has been so influenced by the message, it doesn't sound radical any more. It's a kind of message that people want to believe in. We both felt that it was an important song. I'm sure he felt, OK, it'll go to No 1 or whatever; he had a feeling about that. But for him it was still a new feeling - being independent from the band, on his own, so the song was more like a prayer than a prediction: a prayer in the sense of 'let's hope that this will circulate'.

We hoped the act of songwriting could help better the world. That's what we believed. We felt our songs were honest, whatever came out of us, would definitely help because truth has its own power. It doesn't have to be a lecture or a sermon.

The Bass Player: Klaus Voormann

All the people who played on the album were friends, we hung out, but it was not a particularly relaxed atmosphere recording the album. There were cameras recording everything we did, and John didn't get on with the engineer; he regularly had screaming sessions with him and told him to fuck off. But while we recorded the track 'Imagine' there were no ego trips, and it was surprisingly drug-free recording. John wanted to use the white piano. We lugged it from his living room but the piano doesn't actually sound that good. In the end, we replaced it with a simple brown upright piano.

After each song John would look at us with a question in his eyes, but with 'Imagine' it was different. The song works because it is so simple. Anybody can understand it. It's so hard to put your finger on, but John had a special gift for simple words and melody that go straight through into people. It was obvious it would be a classic. All of us knew he didn't have to use us on the track: it would have worked just as well if it had been just John and a piano. I feel honoured to be on the track, but completely unimportant.

The Drummer: Alan White

I had been John's drummer since he played in Toronto, which was the first solo piece after leaving the Beatles. I was only 21 and John was a kind of role model for me.

When John first played us the song it was a strange moment: we all knew that we had heard something special. We did just three takes, and with one of them everyone just knew that it was the best one. It very rarely happens that way. John recorded the vocals separately. The session only took a week and there were lots of people popping in and out. We were continually getting in the way of the builders who were making John a spiral staircase. Eric Clapton was around; so were George Harrison and Miles Davis. It was a communal thing. I have a really vivid memory of John insisting on watching some TV programme one night. I was wedged between John, Eric and Yoko on their king-size bed. We weren't having a wild time, but it was certainly fun.

webTitle: Your country needs you, retired teachers told

fields.headline: Your country needs you, retired teachers told
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Thousands of teachers are being brought out of retirement as the Government tries to solve the crisis in the classrooms and stop many schools being forced into politically damaging four-day weeks.
fields.body:
Thousands of teachers are being brought out of retirement as the Government tries to solve the crisis in the classrooms and stop many schools being forced into politically damaging four-day weeks.

David Blunkett, Education Secretary, has ordered local authorities to offer posts to retired teachers to plug gaps, as schools return from the Christmas break this week.

He blames the unions for 'scaremongering' a few weeks before their annual pay deal is announced. The Government is worried parents will become disillusioned with Labour's schools policy.

Schools in London and Essex have reported widespread problems with teacher shortages and 880-pupil Headlands school in Swindon is planning to send 11- to 14-year-olds home because of lack of teaching staff.

'We have to be seen to act,' said one Education Department official. 'Retired teachers offer experience and are a ready-made resource. We have to allow any schools facing difficulties to have access to that.'

Meanwhile teachers in hard-to-recruit areas could be offered 'golden handcuffs' payments of up to £4,000 a year just to stay in their jobs. The sweetener will come on top of a payrise expected to be only just above inflation.

For retired teachers, pension arrangements could be relaxed so they would not lose out by returning.

A report from the Nuffield Foundation revealed nearly half of all teaching posts in primary and secondary schools in England and Wales were 'difficult to fill' because there were 'too few applicants', or applicants of 'poor quality'.

Figures released last week showed applications for teacher training positions were down 16 per cent on last year. The Government insists that it is a short-term problem and that inquiries about joining courses are at record levels.

The trawl for retired teachers was swiftly attacked by the leading teachers' union. 'The desire on retired teachers' part is going to be limited. Why should they want to come back into a profession they have left for good reason?' said Doug McAvoy, the leader of the National Union of Teachers. 'This is a measure of the panic that is leading Government reactions to teacher shortages rather than taking the sensible approach and looking at the fundamental problem of why we are not recruiting enough young people.'

The leading headteachers' union welcomed the plans as a 'step in the right direction' but said Ministers needed a comprehensive package to tackle the situation.

We have to allow any schools facing difficulties to have access to that.' fields.headline: Teachers need long-term rises
fields.standfirst:
Salaries must enhance career status

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Salaries must enhance career status.
fields.body:
Weary of his notoriously dexterous footwork when making funding announcements, we are understandably sceptical when Education Secretary David Blunkett attempts to explain away the crisis in teacher recruitment. However, this problem does not have its provenance only in the last four years. It is the product of an all too typical poverty of long-term planning by governments for more than a quarter of a century.

It was under Labour in the Seventies that teacher training rolls were first slashed, a response to earlier over-estimations of the birth rate. At that time, there were 80,000 applications for 50,000 training places. Mr Chips and Miss Jean Brodie were on O-level reading lists. Now schools are warning of a recruitment meltdown, and the only cultural role model young people see for teachers is Lenny Henry playing headmaster Ian George in BBC1's Hope & Glory. (Beleaguered Mr George recently dropped dead of a heart attack.)

The replacement of specific teacher training with graduate courses made it easier for aspiring teachers to be diverted into other careers. But the current crisis goes far deeper. Teachers have been demoralised for years through funding cuts to schools and sneering treatment from politicians and the former head of the Office for Standards in Education as if they were professional babysitters rather than the custodians of our most prized social and economic assets, young people.

Some sensible remedial steps have been taken. Training salaries for graduates and incentives to join struggling, and not just successful, schools are both welcome. But it remains deeply disturbing that there are as many ex-teachers in Britain as there are teachers. Starting salaries are not necessarily the key to solving professional shortages; pupil barristers, after all, are prepared to work for modest amounts. Enduring long-term rewards for good teachers are more important. The Government should now commit itself, on all our behalfs, to very significant pay rises for long-serving teaching staff. The imminent pay announcement by the School Teachers Review Body for England and Wales provides an appropriate opportunity to make such a gesture.

fields.headline: Llanwern steel plant to close
fields.trailText: Unions have been told to prepare for the closure of the massive Llanwern steelworks in South Wales, with the loss of 3,000 jobs, as metals giant Corus finalises a savage package of cutbacks and redundancies.
fields.body:
Unions have been told to prepare for the closure of the massive Llanwern steelworks in South Wales, with the loss of 3,000 jobs, as metals giant Corus finalises a savage package of cutbacks and redundancies.

Corus directors informed union officials last week that Llanwern, which produces strip steel, would almost certainly be shut when the results of the company's internal review are announced early in February. It also emerged that plans announced in the autumn for the £35 million relining of a blast furnace at the plant have not proceeded.

The closure will come as a bitter disappointment to unions and MPs who have lobbied hard against the plant's closure ever since Corus head Sir Brian Moffat announced fresh restructuring in December. Welsh Labour MPs have asked that the decision be delayed until after the general election.

One union official said: 'We were informed on Wednesday by the company that the closure of Llanwern will be announced within the next few weeks.'

The closure comes as part of a wider review of Corus's operations which is likely to see further job losses at plants in Scunthorpe, Teesside and Rotherham as well as other plants in South Wales.

Corus has not yet decided whether it will close Llanwern immediately or in phases. It is due to brief unions this week on its plans.

The latest round of cutbacks comes on top of 4,500 job losses announced last summer. Corus has faced the strike threats from the ISTC steel union over plans to achieve this number through compulsory redundancies - a course avoided in the past.

Corus has already given notice of compulsory redundancies at Scunthorpe and Teesside. However, it has worked to cut the number of compulsory losses, and is likely to have averted a strike ballot at Scunthorpe by ensuring there will be none there. It has reduced the cut at Teesside to about 75. However, it added that there would probably be further compulsory losses elsewhere.

ISTC head Michael Leahy said compulsory redundancies would result in strike ballots, but welcomed efforts to reduce the number.

webTitle: New powers unveiled to track down deadly GPs

fields.headline: New powers unveiled to track down deadly GPs
fields.trailText: A crackdown on dangerous doctors, to be unveiled this week in the wake of the Harold Shipman case, will introduce stringent new measures on GPs who work alone.
fields.body:
A crackdown on dangerous doctors, to be unveiled this week in the wake of the Harold Shipman case, will introduce stringent new measures on GPs who work alone.

Single-handed family doctors will be forced through their contracts to undergo regular audits, to identify warning signs of incompetence or more sinister traits, amid fears that Shipman's solo practice enabled him to cover his tracks at the peak of his killing spree.

Meanwhile, health authorities will get new powers to suspend family doctors at any time if patients appear to be at risk. Complaints over clinical skills or professional behaviour will be fast-tracked to a new expert body to sidestep the existing disciplinary body, the General Medical Council.

Shipman went solo for the last six years of his career. He may have killed as many as 345 people. His killing rate soared once he was alone in his surgery.

In an interview today, Tony Blair is expected to highlight the package to be unveiled by health minister John Denham.

"We are determined to do our utmost to protect patients with a system of checks which will be faster and more effective for patients and fairer to doctors," said a Downing Street source.

Tomorrow, Mr Denham will outline the plans to root out "dangerous doctors" at all levels. Health secretary Alan Milburn has already announced that all doctors will face annual "MOTs". GPs will be obliged to report deaths in surgeries. And the banding together of GPs into several practices co-operating to provide services should also provide safeguards.

Ministers have been angry with the GMC over its slowness in responding to cases. Shipman provoked two complaints in 10 years, but he was only struck off after he had been convicted.

fields.headline: HSBC Performance Plus Isa
fields.trailText: Contact: 0800 299299
fields.body:
Contact: 0800 299299

Aim: To provide a tax free, equity-based home for capital released from maturing Tessas.

Bells & whistles: HSBC claims the Isa offers higher potential returns than are available on deposit-based accounts and capital protection if the investment is held for five years.

How it works: Savers who have deposited their money in a Tessa have up to six months from the Tessa's fifth anniversary to roll over their capital (but not interest) into a Tessa-only Isa. The HSBC Performance Plus Isa uses part of the fund to buy into an interest-rate swap to ensure the return of all original capital invested after five years, even if the FTSE 100 has fallen during this period. The residue is used to buy FTSE 100 options, which provide the potential for growth of up to 60 per cent over the five years - equivalent to 12% a year.

Minimum: £3,000, maximum £9,000.

Charges: Built into product.

Tax: Tax-free.

Risk: Low.

Should you invest? Michael Aaron of Milton Keynes independent financial adviser David Aaron Partnership says that most Tessa-only Isas are offering uninteresting levels of interest, so HSBC's offering makes a welcome change. 'We are quite confident about prospects for the stock market over the next five years. We would rather there wasn't a 60% cap on growth of course, but this is still a lot more than you could expect to earn on any other Tessa-only Isa.'

Dan Kemp of London firm Holden Meehan also likes the scheme. 'Over five years we expect the stock market to do better than cash deposits, but savers should be aware that they are moving from a safe environment to the stock market. A good return is not guaranteed.'

Points out of 10: Aaron - 8, Kemp - 7.
