webTitle: 99 ways to change your life (part two)

fields.headline: 99 ways to change your life (part two)
fields.trailText: Advice on play, health, wellbeing, nutrition and fitness.
fields.body:
Play
Pat Kane

45 Do a play audit of your life - start by taking yourself into a pleasant café in the middle of a working afternoon and asking yourself some simple questions. When I am at my happiest? What am I actually doing? Who am I doing it with? What resources of time, space and money am I deploying to achieve it? When you write your list, don't be embarrassed by anything you put down - whether it's grandiose (saving the world), banal (riding your techno-scooter) or very momentary and private (one night of the best sex ever). Look at it - and there's the beginnings of your play ethic.

46 Savour the ineffability of the urban moment. You know, when the winter sun hits the old stone wall over the motorway bypass, and you get the longest-possible look at a troubled but gorgeous passer-by, while all the crap in your life is slowly washed away inside you. Recognise that moment? Well, treasure it. That's when the universe is playing with you.

47 Try some spontaneity. If, for example, you're a long-time fan of someone, write the email now. Is there a bit of tech that would enhance your life? Fill in another credit-card form, now. When you see the loved one, does your heart burst? Let it out, now. Is time ticking on that outrageously simple business idea? Start phoning for money, now. Will that melody never leave your head? Start lustily singing, now. Spontaneity is to play as routine is to work. You need to stretch the muscles. Generate the consequences. See what happens.

48 Become a lifestyle militant in the workplace. Take all holidays, agitate for more, support parental leave, try to get a sabbatical, take a time-raise instead of a pay-raise, get ready to walk if the management turns inhumane, try to take the best of them with you to do something new and better. Sometimes you gotta play rough.

49 Make something beautiful. A complicated meal, a birthday card for a lover, a personal website, a prose poem, one perfect room - it doesn't matter. We all start off playing by pouring passions into materials. We all need constantly to remind ourselves of what that feels like.

50 Pull a tenner out of the wall, hit your local cyber café and surf like a mutha. Cyberspace is the player's kingdom: uncontrollable, mostly free, endlessly cut-and-pasteable. And, most importantly, sign up with www.blink.com, which enables you keep all your bookmarks on the web, so you can get to them at any time, home or work. That'll be your net-brain - every player needs one.

51 Kidult out. If you're a parent of a young child, no matter how wound up you are, just make sure you unravel with the toys, join in the minor fantasies, share the raptures with Barbie/Teksta. You're in a moment of great privilege, helping form a soul: don't blow it by thinking about project management. A child is a professor, a minor guru, of play. Sit there and learn from them just where the core energies of being human come from.

52 Make the ultimate soundtrack by tearing into the CD collection, extracting the absolutely best and life-enhancing records, isolating the indisputably major tracks and carefully compose your ultimate playlist. Do it over a few weeks; take your time; get it right. Then make sure that wherever you are, you can stick the earphones in, and disappear into perfection. Players need their portable inspirations: when the tech gets up to speed, we'll be able to do the same for books, movies, TV shows. But right now, only sound can really rock your world.

53 Find people with whom you can publicly share your passions. If you're doing five-a-side with several daft mates every week, or painting your corner of a wall mosaic for a local school, or sharing origami tips in a web-user group, or if you're moving through your t'ai chi in a room full of devotees_ Congrats, you're already playing. Just do more of it. If you're not dipping into any collective passions at all, then find one, quick. Or you'll just dry up and flake away.

54 Become a disciplined psychonaut, meaning that if you're going to alter the brain-chemistry, one way or another, make sure you're in the best of company, using the best of stuff, and intend to have the best of times. Anything less is less than truly playful: no point in largin' it, if the experience crushes you flat.

55 Send a tub of Play-Doh to Gordon Brown, MP. Boy, does that Presbyterian, work-obsessed patriarch need to knead.

Health
Wendy Moore

56 Remember to laugh. Laughing not only reduces your stress levels, it may even protect against heart attack. Researchers in the US have found that people who are more likely to laugh in difficult or embarrassing situations suffer less heart disease.

57 Get touchy-feely. Testicular cancer is the commonest cancer among men aged 20 to 39 and cases are rising. Although the disease is more than 90 per cent curable, men still die because it is not detected early enough. Now women are being urged to do their bit by checking their partner's testicles for abnormalities. Find out how on www.NetDoctor.co.uk.

58 Carry an aspirin. The humble aspirin will not only cure a headache, it may save your life. One soluble aspirin given to someone having a heart attack - experienc ing sudden severe chest pain - reduces the risk of dying, according to the British Heart Foundation. Call medical aid first.

59 Get web-wise. Health information on the internet can be invaluable, useless or downright dangerous. For basic stuff, save yourself time and harm by using a reputable gateway site, such as www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk or the US National Library of Medicine's consumer health site www.medlineplus.gov, both of which have good links. For rarer problems, it is worth a wider search. Sharing information with fellow sufferers can be hugely important.

60 Have a plan for the accidents that do happen. It is not only teenagers who end up with unplanned pregnancies. If you are happy at the prospect, fine. If not, emergency contraception - the morning-after pill - is 99 per cent effective if taken within 61 hours (ideally 24). It's free on prescription or you can buy it over the counter for £19.99 from the end of this month.

61 Get talking. A problem shared really can be a problem halved. Stress is the number one reason for work absence. Talking about it - to colleagues, family or friends - can alleviate the worst pressures, stress-management experts argue. For anonymous conversation, the Samaritans (08457 909 090) are always willing to listen.

62 Quit smoking. (You must have known you wouldn't get through health tips without being told to stop smoking.) Smoking is still the biggest preventable cause of death and disease. Seven out of 10 smokers want to stop. Here's how: nicotine-replacement therapy - patches, gum or inhalers - can double your chances of quitting and Zyban, the anti-smoking aid now on prescription, is less widely tested but shows promising results. For more information, call Quitline (0800 002 200).

63 Be discerning. There are now more alternative therapists in the UK than GPs and we spend more than £500m annually on complementary remedies. Some are proven to work, such as St John's Wort for depression. Others work better than conventional medicine, such as chiropractic for back pain. Much, however, is unproven and unregulated. Ask for evidence of effectiveness before you pay up.

64 Get fresh. Up to a quarter of us suffer from bad breath regularly. If you suffer - ask a friend for an honest answer - the problem is usually easily cured. Your dentist can advise. Drinking lots of liquids - but not coffee - and chewing carrots can help.

65 Ditch the diet. Almost 60 per cent of us are overweight, increasing health risks significantly, but crash diets are useless - the weight piles back on when the diet ends. The only effective way to lose weight permanently is to change your lifestyle - by eating less fat and exercising more.

66 Get protected. Sexually transmitted diseases are soaring. Cases seen at sexual health clinics - including gonorrhoea, chlamydia and genital warts - have doubled in the last decade. Most are easily prevented and treated. Condoms offer effective protection. If you think you have had risky sex, have a test and get treatment if necessary.

Wellbeing
Barefoot Doctor

67 Make it your New Year's resolution to use the power of positive thinking. Every day, decide what's bothering you most and use it to form an affirmation. For example, if other people are irritating you, affirm, 'I am amazed by my level of tolerance for others.'

68 Take a good look at what you're wearing - what are you saying to the world? The lighter the colour, the more you deflect the energy of others. That's why doctors wear white. The darker the colour, the more energy you attract and so the more authority you exude - that's why police wear navy. Pick according to the function you'll be performing and add colour that lifts your spirit.

69 Next time you're hurrying down the street oblivious to anything but the 20 messages on your mobile phone, decide to look around instead and focus on the reality of being on a planet that's currently orbiting the nearest star at 66,000mph while simultaneously rotating on its own axis at 1,000mph. It might help to face east in the direction of the spin. This will instantly put life in perspective.

70 Take up a martial art - it's not as difficult as you think - and work on your spirituality by harnessing mind, breath and energy through posture and movement (the merits of yoga and t'ai chi in this respect cannot be extolled enough).

71 Teach yourself to see how all the people in the world are connected by the light of consciousness that imbues all things, events and people (including you) with meaning. With practice, you will learn to see past the surface appearance of people and things to the inner light that animates, envelopes and informs them. This sense of connectedness will help cut down your monthly call charges.

72 Take more time to become aware of your body on a daily basis. Focus on your skeleton and contemplate being only that. Next, be aware of all the soft tissue in your body, including your flesh and organs and contemplate being only that. Now concentrate on all the fluids coursing through your system and contemplate being only fluid. Next, be aware of your nervous system, including your brain and contemplate being only that. This will help you to unhook yourself from the stress of managing the myriad details of daily life and bring you back to the central core of your being.

73 Exercise your heart - keep it open - and strive to love everyone equally (even though it feels impossible right now). Visualise an aperture in the centre of your chest through which you're breathing in and out, then while inhaling imagine you are drawing in the unconditional love of everyone in the world. While exhaling, imagine you're sending your love back out there.

74 Concentrate all your awareness into the centre of your brain, between and behind your eyes, into the 'original cavity of spirit'. Start by doing it with closed eyes then progress to going about your daily business observing and interacting with the world from this vantage point. This will open your 'third eye', which according to yogis is the key not only to enlightenment but to spiritual immortality, too.

75 Train yourself to be aware of all the synchronistic or serendipitous occurrences in your life. The more you focus on them, the more they will occur. This will reaffirm the existence of the underlying pattern which connects us all.

76 Learn the power of prayer. The simplest, most profound prayer is simply 'Thank you!' (Thank you for the magnificence of life.)

77 Pray or wish for the healing of others. Think of someone who can use it and visualise them enveloped in a bright healing light. Sending positivity to others will attract positivity to you threefold (at least).

Nutrition
Jane Clarke

78 Throw away the scales and pour yourself a glass of wine to celebrate the liberation. If you feel your weight spiralling upwards, make a note of everything you eat for a few days and set about tweaking your weak points immediately. It's much easier to lose a centimetre than an inch.

79 Treat yourself to a couple of quality cups of tea or coffee in the morning - think tea leaves and fresh coffee beans - and take the time to enjoy them. The memory should prevent you from settling for second best later on in the day.

80 Buy a juicer and use it, three times a week (see Nigel Slater, page 48, for some delicious recipes).

81 Nominate your favourite part of your body and flaunt it - focus on the positive attributes, not your blemishes - we all have them.

82 Aim to drink a glass of water every hour, plus one every time you go to the loo - you may feel awash, but remember that every extra pint of water can provide you with an extra 20 per cent of energy.

83 Ditch the habit of eating at your desk - even if you grab just 15 minutes away, you'll get far more enjoyment from your food and feel much more replenished for a change of scenery.

84 Bring three pieces of fruit to work with you in the morning and don't go home with them - hiding them in the desk doesn't count.

85 If you have a special dinner party and want to squeeze into your favourite little number, forget the crash diet and do as the French do - invest in some sexy, supportive underwear (not a contradiction in terms).

86 Take some of the angst out of food shopping and consider setting up a regular organic-box scheme or supermarket delivery to cover the basics.

87 Vow to make this year the year of better sleep - caffeine after midday, excess alcohol, staying up past the point where your body is winding down are all factors that aggravate good sleeping habits. Remember also that an hour before midnight is worth two after and focus on the fact that far from robbing yourself of valuable time today, sleep will energise you for tomorrow.

88 Give your body a couple of days a week off alcohol - obviously not on the day you throw away the scales.

Fitness
Helen Foster

89 Know how hard to work. There is a perfect effort level for exercise. You'll get maximum results lifting weights that leave you exhausted after 8-12 reps (and you should do three sets of these). For cardiovascular work, aim to reach 70-80 per cent of your maximum heart rate - you'll judge this as 7-8 on an effort scale and it'll mean you'll be able to speak in sentences but not paragraphs!

90 Give your trainers an audit. Worn-out trainers make your workout harder and put you at risk of injury. You should replace your trainers every 500 miles of running; every 100 hours of other exercise - or when they no longer pass the 'table test' which involves putting the shoes on the table and bending down to look at the heels. If there's more than a 3mm gap between them and the tabletop at the back or sides, your shoes are worn and you need new ones.

91 Get an aroma-workout. It may sound like nonsense but work by the Nicholas Institute of Sports Medicine and Athletic Trauma in New York has shown that a whiff of peppermint (or a citrusy scent such as orange) can increase energy and make workouts feel easier.

92 Take up fencing. One of the fastest- growing sports in the UK, fencing firms thighs, flattens stomachs, boosts reflexes and burns around 350 calories an hour. To find out more about the sport, visit www.fencingacademy.com.

93 Don't break the 48-hour rule. Working out every day is bad for your body, but if you leave more than 48 hours between gym sessions your workout will be harder. fields.bodyText: Play Pat Kane 45 Do a play audit of your life - start by taking yourself into a pleasant café in the middle of a working afternoon and asking yourself some simple questions. When I am at my happiest? What am I actually doing? Who am I doing it with? What resources of time, space and money am I deploying to achieve it? When you write your list, don't be embarrassed by anything you put down - whether it's grandiose (saving the world), banal (riding your techno-scooter) or very momentary and private (one night of the best sex ever). Look at it - and there's the beginnings of your play ethic. 46 Savour the ineffability of the urban moment. You know, when the winter sun hits the old stone wall over the motorway bypass, and you get the longest-possible look at a troubled but gorgeous passer-by, while all the crap in your life is slowly washed away inside you. Recognise that moment? Well, treasure it. That's when the universe is playing with you. 47 Try some spontaneity. If, for example, you're a long-time fan of someone, write the email now. Is there a bit of tech that would enhance your life? Fill in another credit-card form, now. When you see the loved one, does your heart burst? Let it out, now. Is time ticking on that outrageously simple business idea? Start phoning for money, now. Will that melody never leave your head? Start lustily singing, now. Spontaneity is to play as routine is to work. You need to stretch the muscles. Generate the consequences. See what happens. 48 Become a lifestyle militant in the workplace. Take all holidays, agitate for more, support parental leave, try to get a sabbatical, take a time-raise instead of a pay-raise, get ready to walk if the management turns inhumane, try to take the best of them with you to do something new and better. Sometimes you gotta play rough. 49 Make something beautiful. A complicated meal, a birthday card for a lover, a personal website, a prose poem, one perfect room - it doesn't matter. We all start off playing by pouring passions into materials. We all need constantly to remind ourselves of what that feels like. 50 Pull a tenner out of the wall, hit your local cyber café and surf like a mutha. Cyberspace is the player's kingdom: uncontrollable, mostly free, endlessly cut-and-pasteable. And, most importantly, sign up with www.blink.com, which enables you keep all your bookmarks on the web, so you can get to them at any time, home or work. That'll be your net-brain - every player needs one. 51 Kidult out. If you're a parent of a young child, no matter how wound up you are, just make sure you unravel with the toys, join in the minor fantasies, share the raptures with Barbie/Teksta. You're in a moment of great privilege, helping form a soul: don't blow it by thinking about project management. A child is a professor, a minor guru, of play. Sit there and learn from them just where the core energies of being human come from. 52 Make the ultimate soundtrack by tearing into the CD collection, extracting the absolutely best and life-enhancing records, isolating the indisputably major tracks and carefully compose your ultimate playlist. Do it over a few weeks; take your time; get it right. Then make sure that wherever you are, you can stick the earphones in, and disappear into perfection. Players need their portable inspirations: when the tech gets up to speed, we'll be able to do the same for books, movies, TV shows. But right now, only sound can really rock your world. 53 Find people with whom you can publicly share your passions. If you're doing five-a-side with several daft mates every week, or painting your corner of a wall mosaic for a local school, or sharing origami tips in a web-user group, or if you're moving through your t'ai chi in a room full of devotees_ Congrats, you're already playing. Just do more of it. If you're not dipping into any collective passions at all, then find one, quick. Anything less is less than truly playful: no point in largin' it, if the experience crushes you flat. 55 Send a tub of Play-Doh to Gordon Brown, MP. Boy, does that Presbyterian, work-obsessed patriarch need to knead. Health Wendy Moore 56 Remember to laugh. Laughing not only reduces your stress levels, it may even protect against heart attack. Researchers in the US have found that people who are more likely to laugh in difficult or embarrassing situations suffer less heart disease. 57 Get touchy-feely. Testicular cancer is the commonest cancer among men aged 20 to 39 and cases are rising. Although the disease is more than 90 per cent curable, men still die because it is not detected early enough. Now women are being urged to do their bit by checking their partner's testicles for abnormalities. Find out how on www.NetDoctor.co.uk. 58 Carry an aspirin. The humble aspirin will not only cure a headache, it may save your life. One soluble aspirin given to someone having a heart attack - experienc ing sudden severe chest pain - reduces the risk of dying, according to the British Heart Foundation. Call medical aid first. 59 Get web-wise. Health information on the internet can be invaluable, useless or downright dangerous. For basic stuff, save yourself time and harm by using a reputable gateway site, such as www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk or the US National Library of Medicine's consumer health site www.medlineplus.gov, both of which have good links. For rarer problems, it is worth a wider search. Sharing information with fellow sufferers can be hugely important. 60 Have a plan for the accidents that do happen. It is not only teenagers who end up with unplanned pregnancies. If you are happy at the prospect, fine. If not, emergency contraception - the morning-after pill - is 99 per cent effective if taken within 61 hours (ideally 24). It's free on prescription or you can buy it over the counter for £19.99 from the end of this month. 61 Get talking. A problem shared really can be a problem halved. This will instantly put life in perspective. 70 Take up a martial art - it's not as difficult as you think - and work on your spirituality by harnessing mind, breath and energy through posture and movement (the merits of yoga and t'ai chi in this respect cannot be extolled enough). 71 Teach yourself to see how all the people in the world are connected by the light of consciousness that imbues all things, events and people (including you) with meaning. With practice, you will learn to see past the surface appearance of people and things to the inner light that animates, envelopes and informs them. This sense of connectedness will help cut down your monthly call charges. 72 Take more time to become aware of your body on a daily basis. Focus on your skeleton and contemplate being only that. Next, be aware of all the soft tissue in your body, including your flesh and organs and contemplate being only that. Now concentrate on all the fluids coursing through your system and contemplate being only fluid. Next, be aware of your nervous system, including your brain and contemplate being only that. This will help you to unhook yourself from the stress of managing the myriad details of daily life and bring you back to the central core of your being. 73 Exercise your heart - keep it open - and strive to love everyone equally (even though it feels impossible right now). Visualise an aperture in the centre of your chest through which you're breathing in and out, then while inhaling imagine you are drawing in the unconditional love of everyone in the world. While exhaling, imagine you're sending your love back out there. 74 Concentrate all your awareness into the centre of your brain, between and behind your eyes, into the 'original cavity of spirit'. Start by doing it with closed eyes then progress to going about your daily business observing and interacting with the world from this vantage point. This will open your 'third eye', which according to yogis is the key not only to enlightenment but to spiritual immortality, too. 75 Train yourself to be aware of all the synchronistic or serendipitous occurrences in your life. The more you focus on them, the more they will occur. This will reaffirm the existence of the underlying pattern which connects us all. 76 Learn the power of prayer. The simplest, most profound prayer is simply 'Thank you!' (Thank you for the magnificence of life.) 77 Pray or wish for the healing of others. Think of someone who can use it and visualise them enveloped in a bright healing light. Sending positivity to others will attract positivity to you threefold (at least). If you feel your weight spiralling upwards, make a note of everything you eat for a few days and set about tweaking your weak points immediately. It's much easier to lose a centimetre than an inch. 79 Treat yourself to a couple of quality cups of tea or coffee in the morning - think tea leaves and fresh coffee beans - and take the time to enjoy them. The memory should prevent you from settling for second best later on in the day. 80 Buy a juicer and use it, three times a week (see Nigel Slater, page 48, for some delicious recipes). 81 Nominate your favourite part of your body and flaunt it - focus on the positive attributes, not your blemishes - we all have them. 82 Aim to drink a glass of water every hour, plus one every time you go to the loo - you may feel awash, but remember that every extra pint of water can provide you with an extra 20 per cent of energy. 83 Ditch the habit of eating at your desk - even if you grab just 15 minutes away, you'll get far more enjoyment from your food and feel much more replenished for a change of scenery. 84 Bring three pieces of fruit to work with you in the morning and don't go home with them - hiding them in the desk doesn't count. 85 If you have a special dinner party and want to squeeze into your favourite little number, forget the crash diet and do as the French do - invest in some sexy, supportive underwear (not a contradiction in terms). 86 Take some of the angst out of food shopping and consider setting up a regular organic-box scheme or supermarket delivery to cover the basics. 87 Vow to make this year the year of better sleep - caffeine after midday, excess alcohol, staying up past the point where your body is winding down are all factors that aggravate good sleeping habits. fields.headline: Dyke: BBC is hideously white
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the director-general of the BBC, has condemned the corporation as 'hideously white' and said its race relations are as bad as those in some police forces.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the director-general of the BBC, has condemned the corporation as 'hideously white' and said its race relations are as bad as those in some police forces.

In a radio interview to be broadcast tonight that echoes criticism of institutional racism in the Metropolitan Police, Dyke reveals that the management of the BBC is almost entirely white and that the organisation has failed to tackle the problem.

Although he will not go as far as to say that the corporation was racist, the director-general will admit that the corporation is unable to retain staff from ethnic minorities and questioned whether they were made to feel welcome in the organisation.

'I think the BBC is hideously white,' said Dyke on BBC Radio Scotland's The Mix . 'I think the BBC is a predominantly white organisation. The figures we have at the moment suggest that quite a lot of people from different ethnic backgrounds that we do attract to the BBC, leave. Maybe they don't feel at home, maybe they don't feel welcome.'

Dyke appointed Linda Mitchell as head of diversity at the BBC last March and his admission that the corporation has nevertheless failed to meet his expectations, is expected to be seen as an implicit criticism of her work.

He said that the BBC's failure to implement its equal opportunities policies was most noticeable at the highest levels. 'Our biggest problem is at management level,' he admitted. 'I had a management Christmas lunch and as I looked around I thought, "We've got a real problem here". There were 80-odd people there and only one person who wasn't white.'

It is not the first time that the director-general has voiced his concern over the ethnic make-up of the corporation: last year, at a Race in the Media conference, he claimed that the task of enlarging the ethnic representation of the BBC was the 'acid test' of his tenure and said that the corporation had a 'moral duty' to reflect the diversity of 21st century Britain.

In tonight's interview, he will pledge to increase the number of BBC employees from ethnic minorities from 8 to 10 per cent of his workforce by 2003. But broadcaster Trevor Philips, chair of the London Assembly and a close friend and unofficial adviser to Dyke on race issues, called the target 'absurdly low' for a London-based organisation.

'The commitment of Greg Dyke and Mark Thompson to diversity is genuine and heartfelt but if both, after a whole year, can't see any prospect of making a difference in the BBC, it completely bears out what McPherson said in his report: that discrimination in corporations is not to do with the individual intent of those involved but the nature of the organisation itself.'

A spokeswoman for the Commission for Racial Equality said that high-profile admissions of problems with race relations were vital in overcoming racism. 'I welcome his acknowledgement that there's a problem and that he's trying to do something about it,' he said. 'I think the key is getting the senior management to reflect the society we live in. Once that situation is sorted then that will obviously have a beneficial knock-effect on the rest of the corporation.'

fields.headline: I will return
fields.standfirst: After a year blighted by family illness, loss of form and injury,  the  comeback king is ready to do it all again.  As he prepares for what could be his last season, Andre Agassi  talks to   Tim Adams about why he's still 'doing the thing I was born to do'
fields.trailText: After a year blighted by family illness, loss of form and injury, the comeback king is ready to do it all again. As he prepares for what could be his last season, Andre Agassi talks to Tim Adams about why he's still 'doing the thing I was born to do'
fields.body:
Sitting opposite Andre Agassi you notice first something about his eyes. His father saw it, too, when his son was only a few days old. It looked to him then like a special kind of alertness, and Mike Agassi, the tennis coach at the Tropicana Casino in Las Vegas, encouraged that apparent quickness in his baby's attention, hung a tennis ball above his crib and let him bat it back and forth all day with his hand. In the 30 years since, those eyes have studied intently the flight of several million tennis balls, and they now seem to possess an almost supernatural acuity; while Andre Agassi talks, his eyes constantly interrogate you, intensely curious for stress and nuance. They are, as a result, all you really see.

In a penthouse hotel bar in Lyon, where he is playing in an end-of season satellite tournament, otherwise slight and unremarkable in a neat grey T-shirt and washed-out jeans, he is looking back unblinking on a year that has been made all the more difficult by the extraordinary triumphant one which preceded it. For a variety of reasons, he says, he has 'lost his focus' over the summer, and the literal implication of that cliché seems to trouble him; he has taken his eye off the ball, and for Agassi, these days, that inattention has an almost sacrilegious quality. 'It's been a year that has been physically impairing, and draining, really, and that takes you down a level; its been a difficult year, emotionally and mentally and physically and as a result I feel very far off where I was,' he says, a little wearily. 'Your experience helps speed up the process [of recovery] a lot but you have always to analyse, you know: where is my game? Do I have the ability to still do it?'

This time last year, a couple of months before his 30th birthday, Andre Agassi was doing it better than ever, at the peak of an extraordinary resurgence, a comeback unprecedented in modern tennis. Having slipped at one time to 141st in the world, and having been on the verge of quitting, he had rebuilt his game and his life to reach the final of the previous three Grand Slams, winning two, including his emotional triumph in Paris where he completed his full set of the major tournaments, a unique achievement among his generation. He had finished the season as world No 1 and he was preparing for the Australian Open where he would again eclipse his nemesis, Pete Sampras, with faultless, instinctive tennis.

By the time Agassi got to Zimbabwe in early February, John McEnroe, his Davis Cup captain, watching him practise (shirtless, of course) was awed by how hard he was hitting the ball; no one, he observed, had ever struck it earlier, or more sweetly. Such perfection, as Agassi knows better than most, can only ever be fleeting, however, and a couple of days later, after he had won his second match in Harare's dry heat and thin air, still jetlagged after a 30-hour flight from Melbourne, he was doubled over and washed up, vomiting into a flowerpot at courtside. He went home under medical supervision, and his confidence and his fitness and his game, he insists, have still not quite recovered. 'That's not an opinion,' he says. 'All you have to do is look at the results. I've had a couple of semis since, and that's it.'

Throughout his career, Andre Agassi has dealt only in extremes. 'When I'm in the zone,' he says, 'I go hard,' but that intensity extracts a toll. As a baseliner, and moreover one who, at 5ft 11in, lacks the imposing physical stature of most of the players on the tour, Agassi puts his body under absolute strain to compete (Bjorn Borg, the only baseline player in recent decades to achieve his level of success, retired from competitive tennis at 26). And the vulnerability of his highly strung frame is more than matched by his apparent emotional rawness: his heart constantly competes for space with the indentured Nike swoosh on his sleeve. Agassi's dip in form this time around has been exacerbated not only by a succession of injuries but also by the devastating news in the summer that both his mother, and his sister, Tammee, were suffering from breast cancer. It has, he says, ever since, been far too easy to separate tennis from the rest of his life: 'because you have no question where you want to put your energies.'

Although he has been trying to spend as much time as he can with his family - he withdrew in September from the defence of his Olympic title - he has not, at this stage in his career, felt able to take a substantial break from the game: 'I can't afford to take months off,' he says. 'If I did that I could never come back. I try instead to balance it. But it is hard to compete while you are still consumed with thoughts of "where am I?"' Still, he says, philosophically, 'I've taken some time away, and all things considered, my family is doing well'

There are few sports that so relentlessly expose the individual to psychological scrutiny as tennis, and Andre Agassi's personal rites of passage over the 15 years since he turned professional have been the most vivid of its spectacles. He refers to the game, more often than not, in abstract, metaphysical terms, presumably because it has always meant so much more to him than simply hitting the balls. 'You don't know anything else when you start playing before you can remember,' he explains, with a kind of sadness, of his growing up on court. 'I did not know life away from it. It's kind of like a tortured soul, you know, you have a choice but you don't have a choice. There are times when you look forward to quitting and times when you don't imagine ever possibly doing anything different.'

It is the presentation of this internal drama, that has, in the past decade or so, made Agassi among the most compelling of all sports stars, an archetypal figure for our neurotic and solipsistic times. No tennis player in that period has seemed so at odds with his gifts, or so questioning of his purpose. Even now, having achieved much of what he set out to achieve, when he talks about tennis it is as if, at times, you are listening to Hamlet quibble with mortality. 'At the end of the day I need to do it or not do it,' Agassi tells me at one point, 'that has always been the question for me. The question of not doing this thing I was kind of born to do has been with me for 15 years It's been hard to ignore it at times. But I've had to think about it and answer it, get on the plane and do it again'

That is the kind of moment that makes sport great: it had so much more to it for me than the game of tennis.'

If in that moment, Agassi had proved to himself he could 'just do it' - as his sponsor had long been expensively proclaiming - it took a good deal more soul-searching to enable him to repeat the process with any degree of certainty. In the years since Agassi has made himself something of an icon for the self-help industry, a case study for our times. At around the time of his Wimbledon triumph he put himself into therapy, and spent some time with Californian motivational speakers like Anthony Robbins (author of Unlimited Power, creator of 'the new science of personal achievement') . He also immersed himself in a customised new age Christianity. When he was first on the circuit he would study the Bible with Michael Chang on rest days during tournaments. He would talk about his faith, too, with reporters, explain how it had changed his life, but for a while now, he has not felt the need 'to pick up God's slack' in this way. (When I ask him about his religion, he replies only with a caveat: 'I'm not religious, but I have my faith. Religion to me is one guy telling some other guy how and what and when and why. But faith certainly is very important to me.')

His friend Barbra Streisand, the high priestess of self-fulfilment, who sometimes jetted in to see his tournaments, once famously called him 'a Zen master'; and certainly, when you ask him, he talks about his tennis as a kind of spiritual journey. In response to an innocuous question about the goals he sets himself in the game these days, for example, he speaks, typically, as if of a pilgrim's progress:'You discover more each day about who it is you want to be,' he suggests, 'and how you want to be, and once you discover it you are only half way there, after that it is about living up to it over and over again and failing at it a number of times'

Agassi's failings tended to increase, it seemed, at around the time of his brief, ill-fated marriage to Brooke Shields. He had first got together with Shields in 1993; though initially their relationship, suggested by a mutual friend Lyndie Benson, the wife of saxophonist Kenny G, was conducted through daily faxes - Shields was away on location in Africa - in which each slowly bared their soul. Shields's grandfather had been a US Open finalist, but they shared therapyspeak rather than on-court chemistry; when she returned they talked on the phone every day for six weeks, before they finally met each other at the end of the year.

At the time, Agassi told Esquire magazine that he and Shields were made for each other, a pair of damaged souls who could put each other back together: 'We've both gone through the same things,' he said, ever earnest. 'We were both celebrities young. We were both thrown into a strange lifestyle young, and we both got bad raps when we were young, so we have a similar history together. And I think both of us haven't maximised our abilities. But that's changing.' These hopes for his relationship with Shields - that it would resurrect his game - slowly proved unfounded, however; they were married in 1997, by which time Agassi was at his lowest point in tennis terms, rarely playing, and mostly losing when he did. He won't talk in public about that period now, except to say, smiling that, 'with my game, it was not easy for me to drop that far down, to be ranked at 140. I had to put in a great deal of hard work at the buffet table to achieve that, a great deal of work'

Oddly, soon after he was married and with his career virtually on hold, Agassi apparently made the decision to finally commit himself to his first love. At 27, when some of his contemporaries were giving up on the game, he set himself the target of fulfilling his dim and distant potential, but this time for himself rather than for anyone else. 'I'm very challenged by it, by this starting over,' he said. 'Sometimes it makes me happy with myself in a calm way, sometimes in a sick, demented way I've played this game for a lot of reasons, and none of them have ever quite been my own, but this time my desire is to get out there and enjoy it'

Many sportsmen dream of comebacks, but only the greatest ever achieve them. The defining factor in this rehabilitation perhaps came from another, more straightforward relationship, one that also began in 1993. Brad Gilbert had through the Eighties been the player on tour who had done most to maximise a limited talent. His high school coach had noted of him that he had 'No forehand. No backhand. No volley. Weak serve,' but also that he 'wins matches'. Gilbert delighted in proving that even the best could be beaten by application and mental toughness (at one changeover in the Masters tournament in 1986, John McEnroe told Gilbert: 'You don't deserve to be on the same court as me! You are the worst, the fucking worst!' he went on to lose, and afterwards talked for the first time about retirement.)

Gilbert wrote a book about his approach called Winning Ugly; intrigued, and after having been dumped by his long-time coach Bolletieri (who took up with Boris Becker), Agassi asked Gilbert if he could help him out. Gilbert's great strength was that he could not bear to see Agassi (who looked to him 'like a poster boy for the caffeine industry') waste his talent, but he also knew all too well that talent alone did not make a champion. For Brad, that was unacceptable because he was the kind of player who would think about where he was going to hit the serve two weeks before the toss'

Above all, Gilbert forced Agassi to believe that he could become what he has become. Watching Agassi train with his coach in Lyon, you can see how Gilbert has helped him to focus on every ball. Agassi was hitting for an hour or so with the Czech Karel Kucera, and after every rally he was leaving the court to discuss with his coach exactly how he was hitting the ball. Agassi has taken this thoughtfulness into tournaments, too. One of the great pleasures of watching Agassi since his return to form has been to see him slowly unpick an opponent's game, impose himself on a match. A case in point was his defeat of Mark Philipoussis at Wimbledon. The big Australian had brushed aside Tim Henman in the previous round and was one of the tournament favourites, but against Agassi his power was not only neutralised, it was made to look vaguely ridiculous. Agassi threw Philipoussis off his stride to begin with in that match by standing 10 feet behind the baseline to receive the famous scud serve, giving himself time to clip the ball past the Australian as he moved predictably to the net; by the end of the game, though, he was standing right up near the service line, picking up 135 mph serves virtually on the half-volley, as Philipoussis, rattled, tried unsuccessfully to blast the ball through him.

It is perhaps no coincidence that having fallen back in love with the game, Agassi has also found love within it. He is not a man who gives up his secrets lightly, though, and when you ask him about Steffi Graf, the eyes immediately warn you off. (To one reporter at the recent Masters tournament ,who asked only if he had talked to Steffi on the phone about his semi-final victory over Marat Safin, he responded by inquiring: 'Are you being serious right now? Do you actually have, like, a journalist license? Are you actually able to write?').

Asked whether it has been easier for him to have a relationship with someone who understands as well as he does the pressures, he says curtly: 'I don't think it's necessary for a relationship to have that kind of professional understanding, but I think if you do, it's an incredible asset.' In response to a question as to whether Steffi helps him in preparation for games he observes only that 'I find myself very interested in what she thinks about a lot of things, and that includes tennis'

I wonder, finally, if Steffi's decision to quit while still at the peak of the profession will have any influence on his own decision to eventually call it a day? 'No,' he says carefully. 'Every athlete is different. To compare it is to try to write the script before it is written, my career has not been normal, and I'm sure my retirement won't be normal either.'

As he prepares for the defence of his Australian Open title later this month, the question of whether he should try to make this his last golden season seems to loom large for Agassi, though he won't acknowledge it directly. His longevity as a tennis player has been brought into sharper focus by a number of things recently; first, there was the retirement last year of Jim Courier. Agassi has been playing Sampras and Chang and Courier for most of his life, and between them for the best part of a decade, Becker apart, they have dominated men's tennis. Courier's going, he says, 'did send signals, though more from an emotional standpoint. You know it gets tougher as you get older, emotionally growing up with a player, and having the same dreams and the same goals and just the same schedules, for that to be over for him, it leaves you feeling somewhat nostalgic, somewhat sad. And it does make me critically aware of my own situation.'

That critical awareness has perhaps been further heightened by a promotional campaign from the ATP which has depicted himself and Pete Sampras, surveying the younger talent, and posing the question of succession. 'New balls please', runs the strapline. I wonder if there is any extra motivation, as there always seemed to be for say, Connors, to prove himself against the new kids on the block?

Agassi laughs a little. 'I would probably consider it a great success never to be like Jimmy Connors in any respect whatsoever,' he says. 'For me, its nothing to do with younger, for me it's always only about the game inside the lines; when a young guy comes around and he does something differently and you haven't seen it before, you want to adjust and live up to the standard'

His generation, as he points out, has set a very difficult standard to follow, but he points to the fact that Gustavo Kuerten and Marat Safin in particular have come through this year, and he 'likes Hewitt's game' and suggests that, despite some anxiety among the powers that be about the absence, in particular, of a young American challenger, there is not a lot to worry about. 'You are talking about a sport that transcends the lines of life. One on one, man to man, you are talking about how what I do affects what you do and how you deal with that. There's something fundamental there. And you are talking about something that people can play for a lifetime. So I'm not worried about tennis though certain things have a look of panic, which is not justified or necessary. The game speaks for itself in a very authentic way.'

Is Agassi versus Sampras still, though, the biggest match. 'If we are both playing our best, yes.' Are those the games he most looks forward to? 'Not at the moment,' he says. 'Pete and I have great memories. But when we are not right on our game, then we don't really want to be out there, the matches don't live up to what we are capable of'

Great tennis players have always needed great rivals to extend them, and in this sense both Agassi and Sampras seem grateful for the fact that the other has been around at the same time. When Agassi was thinking of quitting the game, Sampras expressed his hope that he would come back to challenge him; when he won the French Open in 1999, he received a telegram from Sampras welcoming him back into the fray. They have, over the years, in many ways moulded each other's character, at least on the court, Agassi believes: 'I think both of us have shaped each other's games a little and frustrated the other. He's been a thorn in my side, certainly, but that's what makes it special'

Do they talk much away from the game? Agassi laughs at the idea. 'No, he's a way different cat than I am,' he says. 'I think each of our worst nightmares would certainly be to wake up and be the other one.'

When I saw him, Agassi believed that he would be ready again to resume that special relationship at the Australian Open, a belief that was reinforced by his invigorated showing at December's Masters tournament in Lisbon, where he reached the final: 'It's been a while since my mind was in a place where I could take in and use the expectations of the public,' he said. 'It hasn't been about winning and losing over the years as about my desire to keep getting better. There have been times recently on the practice court when I have been very, very happy with my game, but between the practice court and the tournament, it hasn't happened but I know it is only a matter of time.'

And when, later, the time comes for him to step away from the game, the only thing he has known, does he think he will know the right moment for that, too? 'I hope so,' he says. 'Certainly I'm more afraid about how it is at the end right now, than what happens after But as soon as I think about how its going to end then I guess it's over. In thinking about the end, the end is already there.' His eyes are flashing at the complexity of this prospect. 'What I hope,' he says, finally, 'is that the fight happens in a way that I am proud of.' In the meantime, you guess, all Andre Agassi really wants to focus his circuitous, exhilarating attention on, is the next ball, and then the one after that.

'It's been a year that has been physically impairing, and draining, really, and that takes you down a level; its been a difficult year, emotionally and mentally and physically and as a result I feel very far off where I was,' he says, a little wearily. 'Your experience helps speed up the process [of recovery] a lot but you have always to analyse, you know: where is my game? Do I have the ability to still do it?' But faith certainly is very important to me.') His friend Barbra Streisand, the high priestess of self-fulfilment, who sometimes jetted in to see his tournaments, once famously called him 'a Zen master'; and certainly, when you ask him, he talks about his tennis as a kind of spiritual journey. In response to an innocuous question about the goals he sets himself in the game these days, for example, he speaks, typically, as if of a pilgrim's progress:'You discover more each day about who it is you want to be,' he suggests, 'and how you want to be, and once you discover it you are only half way there, after that it is about living up to it over and over again and failing at it a number of times' Agassi's failings tended to increase, it seemed, at around the time of his brief, ill-fated marriage to Brooke Shields. He had first got together with Shields in 1993; though initially their relationship, suggested by a mutual friend Lyndie Benson, the wife of saxophonist Kenny G, was conducted through daily faxes - Shields was away on location in Africa - in which each slowly bared their soul. Shields's grandfather had been a US Open finalist, but they shared therapyspeak rather than on-court chemistry; when she returned they talked on the phone every day for six weeks, before they finally met each other at the end of the year. At the time, Agassi told Esquire magazine that he and Shields were made for each other, a pair of damaged souls who could put each other back together: 'We've both gone through the same things,' he said, ever earnest. 'We were both celebrities young. We were both thrown into a strange lifestyle young, and we both got bad raps when we were young, so we have a similar history together. And I think both of us haven't maximised our abilities. But that's changing.' These hopes for his relationship with Shields - that it would resurrect his game - slowly proved unfounded, however; they were married in 1997, by which time Agassi was at his lowest point in tennis terms, rarely playing, and mostly losing when he did. He won't talk in public about that period now, except to say, smiling that, 'with my game, it was not easy for me to drop that far down, to be ranked at 140. I had to put in a great deal of hard work at the buffet table to achieve that, a great deal of work' Oddly, soon after he was married and with his career virtually on hold, Agassi apparently made the decision to finally commit himself to his first love. At 27, when some of his contemporaries were giving up on the game, he set himself the target of fulfilling his dim and distant potential, but this time for himself rather than for anyone else. 'I'm very challenged by it, by this starting over,' he said. 'Sometimes it makes me happy with myself in a calm way, sometimes in a sick, demented way I've played this game for a lot of reasons, and none of them have ever quite been my own, but this time my desire is to get out there and enjoy it' Many sportsmen dream of comebacks, but only the greatest ever achieve them. The defining factor in this rehabilitation perhaps came from another, more straightforward relationship, one that also began in 1993. Brad Gilbert had through the Eighties been the player on tour who had done most to maximise a limited talent. His high school coach had noted of him that he had 'No forehand. No backhand. No volley. Weak serve,' but also that he 'wins matches'. Gilbert delighted in proving that even the best could be beaten by application and mental toughness (at one changeover in the Masters tournament in 1986, John McEnroe told Gilbert: 'You don't deserve to be on the same court as me! You are the worst, the fucking worst!' he went on to lose, and afterwards talked for the first time about retirement.) Gilbert wrote a book about his approach called Winning Ugly; intrigued, and after having been dumped by his long-time coach Bolletieri (who took up with Boris Becker), Agassi asked Gilbert if he could help him out. Gilbert's great strength was that he could not bear to see Agassi (who looked to him 'like a poster boy for the caffeine industry') waste his talent, but he also knew all too well that talent alone did not make a champion. 'Brad could not believe it,' Agassi observes of their differing approaches, 'when I told him that sometimes I'd decide where I was going to hit my serve during the ball toss. For Brad, that was unacceptable because he was the kind of player who would think about where he was going to hit the serve two weeks before the toss' Above all, Gilbert forced Agassi to believe that he could become what he has become. Watching Agassi train with his coach in Lyon, you can see how Gilbert has helped him to focus on every ball. Agassi was hitting for an hour or so with the Czech Karel Kucera, and after every rally he was leaving the court to discuss with his coach exactly how he was hitting the ball. Agassi has taken this thoughtfulness into tournaments, too. One of the great pleasures of watching Agassi since his return to form has been to see him slowly unpick an opponent's game, impose himself on a match. A case in point was his defeat of Mark Philipoussis at Wimbledon. The big Australian had brushed aside Tim Henman in the previous round and was one of the tournament favourites, but against Agassi his power was not only neutralised, it was made to look vaguely ridiculous. Agassi threw Philipoussis off his stride to begin with in that match by standing 10 feet behind the baseline to receive the famous scud serve, giving himself time to clip the ball past the Australian as he moved predictably to the net; by the end of the game, though, he was standing right up near the service line, picking up 135 mph serves virtually on the half-volley, as Philipoussis, rattled, tried unsuccessfully to blast the ball through him. It is perhaps no coincidence that having fallen back in love with the game, Agassi has also found love within it. He is not a man who gives up his secrets lightly, though, and when you ask him about Steffi Graf, the eyes immediately warn you off. (To one reporter at the recent Masters tournament ,who asked only if he had talked to Steffi on the phone about his semi-final victory over Marat Safin, he responded by inquiring: 'Are you being serious right now? Do you actually have, like, a journalist license? Are you actually able to write?'). Asked whether it has been easier for him to have a relationship with someone who understands as well as he does the pressures, he says curtly: 'I don't think it's necessary for a relationship to have that kind of professional understanding, but I think if you do, it's an incredible asset.' In response to a question as to whether Steffi helps him in preparation for games he observes only that 'I find myself very interested in what she thinks about a lot of things, and that includes tennis' I wonder, finally, if Steffi's decision to quit while still at the peak of the profession will have any influence on his own decision to eventually call it a day? 'No,' he says carefully. 'Every athlete is different. To compare it is to try to write the script before it is written, my career has not been normal, and I'm sure my retirement won't be normal either.' As he prepares for the defence of his Australian Open title later this month, the question of whether he should try to make this his last golden season seems to loom large for Agassi, though he won't acknowledge it directly. His longevity as a tennis player has been brought into sharper focus by a number of things recently; first, there was the retirement last year of Jim Courier. Agassi has been playing Sampras and Chang and Courier for most of his life, and between them for the best part of a decade, Becker apart, they have dominated men's tennis. Courier's going, he says, 'did send signals, though more from an emotional standpoint. You know it gets tougher as you get older, emotionally growing up with a player, and having the same dreams and the same goals and just the same schedules, for that to be over for him, it leaves you feeling somewhat nostalgic, somewhat sad. And it does make me critically aware of my own situation.' That critical awareness has perhaps been further heightened by a promotional campaign from the ATP which has depicted himself and Pete Sampras, surveying the younger talent, and posing the question of succession. 'New balls please', runs the strapline. I wonder if there is any extra motivation, as there always seemed to be for say, Connors, to prove himself against the new kids on the block? Agassi laughs a little. 'I would probably consider it a great success never to be like Jimmy Connors in any respect whatsoever,' he says. 'For me, its nothing to do with younger, for me it's always only about the game inside the lines; when a young guy comes around and he does something differently and you haven't seen it before, you want to adjust and live up to the standard' His generation, as he points out, has set a very difficult standard to follow, but he points to the fact that Gustavo Kuerten and Marat Safin in particular have come through this year, and he 'likes Hewitt's game' and suggests that, despite some anxiety among the powers that be about the absence, in particular, of a young American challenger, there is not a lot to worry about. 'You are talking about a sport that transcends the lines of life. One on one, man to man, you are talking about how what I do affects what you do and how you deal with that. There's something fundamental there. And you are talking about something that people can play for a lifetime. So I'm not worried about tennis though certain things have a look of panic, which is not justified or necessary. The game speaks for itself in a very authentic way.' Is Agassi versus Sampras still, though, the biggest match. 'If we are both playing our best, yes.' Are those the games he most looks forward to? 'Not at the moment,' he says. 'Pete and I have great memories. But when we are not right on our game, then we don't really want to be out there, the matches don't live up to what we are capable of' Great tennis players have always needed great rivals to extend them, and in this sense both Agassi and Sampras seem grateful for the fact that the other has been around at the same time. When Agassi was thinking of quitting the game, Sampras expressed his hope that he would come back to challenge him; when he won the French Open in 1999, he received a telegram from Sampras welcoming him back into the fray. They have, over the years, in many ways moulded each other's character, at least on the court, Agassi believes: 'I think both of us have shaped each other's games a little and frustrated the other. He's been a thorn in my side, certainly, but that's what makes it special' Do they talk much away from the game? Agassi laughs at the idea. 'No, he's a way different cat than I am,' he says. 'I think each of our worst nightmares would certainly be to wake up and be the other one.' When I saw him, Agassi believed that he would be ready again to resume that special relationship at the Australian Open, a belief that was reinforced by his invigorated showing at December's Masters tournament in Lisbon, where he reached the final: 'It's been a while since my mind was in a place where I could take in and use the expectations of the public,' he said. 'It hasn't been about winning and losing over the years as about my desire to keep getting better. There have been times recently on the practice court when I have been very, very happy with my game, but between the practice court and the tournament, it hasn't happened but I know it is only a matter of time.' And when, later, the time comes for him to step away from the game, the only thing he has known, does he think he will know the right moment for that, too? 'I hope so,' he says. 'Certainly I'm more afraid about how it is at the end right now, than what happens after But as soon as I think about how its going to end then I guess it's over. In thinking about the end, the end is already there.' His eyes are flashing at the complexity of this prospect. 'What I hope,' he says, finally, 'is that the fight happens in a way that I am proud of.' In the meantime, you guess, all Andre Agassi really wants to focus his circuitous, exhilarating attention on, is the next ball, and then the one after that.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Patriot | It's the Rage | Scarface | Duck Soup
fields.trailText: The Patriot | It's the Rage | Scarface | Duck Soup
fields.body:
The Patriot
(2000, 15, Columbia Tristar, VHS/Rental, DVD/Rental, Retail)

This visually handsome epic movie of the American Revolutionary War (scripted by Robert Rodat who wrote Saving Private Ryan, directed by Roland Emmerich, the man responsible for Independence Day) stars Mel Gibson as a moderate Southerner provoked into confronting the repressive Brits. This stirring, simplistic film became the centre last summer of an absurd debate about Hollywood's representation of English imperialism. The DVD is accompanied by numerous extra features including a scene-by-scene commentary.

It's the Rage
(1999, 15, Columbia Tristar, VHS/Rental, DVD/Rental)

James Stern's black comedy, a low-budget production with a formidable cast, goes straight to video in Britain. Set in Chicago and based on an elaborately patterned play, it explores the everyday madness of American life and indicts the laws that enable its characters to give lethal expression via handguns to their passing fantasies. Joan Allen leaves homicidal businessman Jeff Daniels to work for loony computer tycoon Gary Sinise, whose ex-assistant Josh Brolin becomes involved with a variety of pistol-toting types including whore Anna Paquin, disturbed gay David Schwimmer, bisexual black lawyer Andre Braugher, and psycho-crook, Giovanni Ribisi. Only retired cop Robert Forster is slow on the draw.

Scarface
(1932, PG, 4Front, VHS/Retail)
The best, most modern of the first cycle of gangster movies from the sound era is a dazzling amorality play closely based on the career of Chicago boss Al Capone, scripted by Ben Hecht and WR Burnett, who'd observed him at close hand. Howard Hawks's direction is harshly non-judgmental, and there's a stunning central performance from Paul Muni, and an iconic one from the mob-friendly George Raft as a coin-tossing associate.

Duck Soup
(1933, U, 4Front Video, VHS/Retail)
This was the last of the five anarchic comedies the Marx Brothers made for Paramount before they were subjected to the MGM straightjacket and its high production values. The others - all masterpieces - are Animal Crackers, Horse Feathers, Monkey Business and The Cocoanuts, and you can buy the lot for under £30 on this low-price label.
