fields.headline: Local hero
fields.standfirst: He tried to kill his father at 14 and had his first breakdown in his twenties. But at 41, Peter Mullan, award-winning star of My Name Is Joe, has found peace. Here he talks about hypothermia, Hollywood and why he'll never leave Glasgow
fields.trailText: He tried to kill his father at 14 and had his first breakdown in his twenties. But at 41, Peter Mullan, award-winning star of My Name Is Joe, has found peace. Here he talks about hypothermia, Hollywood and why he'll never leave Glasgow.
fields.body:
W e are in the middle of Canada's Rocky Mountains, the middle of nowhere in the middle of winter. A tiny film crew is shooting a decisive scene for a Gold Rush western, The Claim, surrounded by snow-covered mountains whose fading imprints in the dusk emphasise our isolation. It is freezing cold. Despite this, Scottish actor Peter Mullan has been gamely 'playing dead' in the snow for six hours. And the gap between acting and reality is getting a wee bit close for comfort.

Suddenly Mullan, who is wearing no more than thermals under his costume, his beard flecked with snow, starts to reel about as though drunk. The crew realises something is wrong and helps him to the back of a snowmobile. The actor promptly falls off it, struggling to keep his eyes open. Wes Bentley, the young star of American Beauty, and the Canadian actress Sarah Polley look on, concerned, until the paramedics come to Mullan's aid and whisk him off the mountain to hospital.

He is suffering from hypothermia. But Mullan is such a tough customer, and such a 'pro', that no one had the foggiest idea until it was almost too late.

It is just two years since Peter Mullan's annus mirabilis, when he scooped the actor's prize in Cannes for his performance as recovering alcoholic Joe Kavanagh in Ken Loach's My Name Is Joe; then in Venice won a clutch of prizes for his directorial debut, Orphans, a night of the soul for a working-class Glasgow family, heart-rending and humorous, and one of the few genuinely original films to come out of Britain for years. Approaching 40, and with a long career in theatre and film, the Glaswegian found himself an overnight sensation, a commendation he still meets with wry amusement. But the acclaim (it doesn't hurt when Martin Scorsese raves about your performance - and signs your Celtic strip) has considerably increased the actor's profile.

Between this breakthrough and the shoot of The Claim, Mullan made Ordinary Decent Criminal alongside Kevin Spacey, and gave a blisteringly intense performance as Jean, the faux class-warrior-cum-self-serving-shite of Strindberg's Miss Julie, in the lauded version by Mike Figgis. For the role of The Claim 's prospector, who sells his wife and child for a gold mine, builds a town, then suffers his tragic comeuppance (shades of The Mayor of Casterbridge are no accident), director Michael Winterbottom plucked Mullan from a list that included Robert De Niro and Harvey Keitel - an indication of the regard in which he is now held.

'To live in that time, that environment you had to be tough; and to run a town you obviously had to have charisma and power, and a certain sort of ruthlessness,' Winterbottom tells me. 'What's great about Peter is that he is tough. At the same time you feel that, inside, there's a huge amount of emotion.'

Indeed, in Glaswegian parlance, Mullan is very much the 'big man': loyal, committed, idealistic; and, yes, tough. The morning after his battle with the elements, I walk into the frontier town that Winterbottom has built in the milky lap of Fortress Mountain, near Calgary, to find the actor back on set without fuss or recrimination; greeting me with a familiar, face-creasing smile inside the comparative warmth of what he calls 'the horsebox', the most that actors can expect of a trailer at 7,000ft.

'It was minus seven or eight yesterday, which up here isn't that cold,' he recalls in his gruff, unadulterated Glasgow accent. 'But I didnae realise that I was soaking wet. The dampness, that's what did it. I've experienced that before, on another shoot - you feel drunk, then euphoric, then it's dangerous. Apparently another half an hour and I could have fallen into a coma.'

It clearly hasn't dented his enthusiasm. But then, two years ago he was unknown outside Scotland; now he has the pivotal role amid an international cast which includes Nastassja Kinski, Milla Jovovich, Polley and Bentley. 'To ride a horse and get to dance with Nastassja Kinski - man, you couldn't ask for anything fucking better,' laughs Mullan with an endearingly bone-dry cackle, before reflecting on the accident. 'This place is beautiful, but there's a cold up here that's deadly. It makes you think about the people who conquered these mountains, from all over Europe. And in terms of pure human achievement you go, "Wow." By the same token, you realise how that frontier mentality can become so incredibly violent. If you've travelled 25,000-odd miles, and it's been life and death all the way, and anyone is between you and a crust of bread, you'll kill them.'

Peter Mullan understands something about harsh environments, about hardship, even about violence bred by circumstance. Six months after The Claim has wrapped, we're sitting in Jinty McGinty's, a friendly, brown-panelled Irish pub in Glasgow's fashionable West End. The beard has gone, and with his T-shirt, casual jacket and trousers, and closely cut, greying hair, he could again be the clean-cut Joe Kavanagh of Loach's film.

McGinty's happens to be near Mullan's 'wee office', where he writes; but it's a long way from Glasgow's predominantly working-class south side, where he was raised in some poverty, and still lives. 'This isn't my local,' he points out. But it's near enough; he's near enough, to what makes him tick. And before we've even supped from the first of many pints, lit up the first of an inordinate number of cigarettes, Mullan is giving me a history of the Glasgow working class, of the Govan shipyards and the 'napalming' of the Thatcher years; while musing that, 'So many guys I was at school with have now killed themselves. Off the top of my head, I can think of four in the past five years. That's my generation. What happened, I really don't know. Poverty, alcoholism...'

He was born in Peterhead, the third-youngest of eight children, but grew up in Cardonald, near the shipyards. His father was a toolmaker and later a lab technician, whose income could hardly cope with such a large clan. Yet one of the most puzzling distinctions of the Mullans was that they lived in a grand house on the opulently named Moss Park Boulevard.

'Moss Park Boulevard. It sounds really posh,' he smiles. 'And it was, in a way. I've no idea how my old man got it. The irony was that at school we were always considered well-off, not least because we had too big Grecian pillars outside the door. And two gardens. And a garage. It just so happened we didnae have a car, we didnae have any carpets, we didnae have a television, we didnae have a telephone, we didnae have a washing machine. We had what looked like an upper-middle-class home, but we were dirt poor. As the old phrase goes, it was a coat and no knickers.'

His mother told the children to maintain the ruse that they owned rather than rented the house 'as a kind of saving face'. His father, who created the pretence in the first place, was simply a snob. 'I'll give you one classic example of where he was coming from. My eldest brother's name was originally Winston Spencer Churchill Mullan, which my mother, when she went to get the birth certificate, changed to Anthony. And thank the Lord. Let's say my dad wasn't a Marxist.'

Sadly, Mullan senior wasn't much of a father, either. 'To be fair to him, I believe that his whole generation were completely screwed. They were war casualties; they came back from the Second World War to no counselling, they were all running around barking mad. I'm convinced they had no clue how to relate to their wives, their kids or themselves. I know virtually no one of my age who can remember a hug, or a smile from their father, or a "Let's go play football."'

More than that, Mullan describes a household almost under siege from his alcoholic father's dark personality. 'There are some people who walk into a room and they oxygenate it, by their very being there's fresh air,' he says. 'Then there are those who come in with the smell of death and they suck the life out. He was one of those. I remember the undiluted, black-as-coal bile that used to come out of his mouth.'

As Charles Mullan's lung cancer worsened, so the abuse strayed from the psychological to the physical. 'In the later years, when he got drunk on whisky, you didnae wanna know. Eventually our household went completely nuts, because the boys became teenagers and physically strong, and violence became a way of life.' Mullan and his brothers hit back. 'We had no choice. I think it's fair to say that if you walk in from school and he's got your mother over the table with a knife at her throat, one's going to get physical.'

When he was 14, Mullan recalls, 'I completely lost it. It was a ludicrous thing to do. I made him a cup of tea and I filled it with all these sleeping pills that I found. And I went in - I'd never made him a cup of tea - and I gave him it, and he just looked up and smiled. Obviously he didnae drink it. That's how sick the sickness had grown. The fact that not only did he know what I was trying to do, but he found it dryly amusing, is heartbreaking - both on his part and mine. If my son ever thought of trying to kill me, I don't know how I could cope with it, the fact that I'd alienated him to that degree. But I'd had enough of what I was seeing around me.'

In the same period as this incident, Mullan was a member of knife-carrying Glasgow street gang the Young Car-Ds; hanging around, fighting with other gangs, chasing girls, getting drunk. Despite being a bright, bookwormy boy, he was truant from school for the entire year of his gang career. He recognises this now as a crossroads in his life, from which his fellow Car-Ds inadvertently helped him find the right path. 'They eventually asked me to leave, for two reasons: one, they always felt I was slumming it - because I would use words like "flabbergasted".' He grins, remembering the embarrassment. 'And also because I wanted to up the ante, I wanted us to do really crazy things.' For a change, he won't elaborate. 'Quite rightly they said no. They saved my life, no doubt about it.'

Mullan drags the last remnant of his cigarette and goes to the bar for another round. I'm already feeling drunk, as much on the talk as the beer. I remember that in Canada Wes Bentley, a sensitive, Juilliard-trained American half Mullan's age, but deeply impressed by him, observed how 'Peter is a storyteller. Whether we're sitting in a pub or on set, he's always got an amazing story; and if it's not a story, he's telling you how he feels in a story-like manner. It's very intriguing, you have no choice but to listen.'

There's more to it than that, of course, implied when Mullan says he forgives his father, but has 'a duty not to forget'. These are cautionary tales he tells.

The same disarming frankness exists in his acting. Ken Loach, whom the actor reveres, once told me: 'We saw lots of other people for Joe Kavanagh, but nobody had what Peter had. I think he's very true, he doesn't hide, he doesn't have those actors' tricks. There's a sense of danger about him which Joe needed. I mean, Joe knows he has been violent and he's sort of carrying that fear in his head, that he will be violent again. And I think you have a sense - not that Peter's violent at all - that there is, when he's working, a kind of coiled spring.'

His father died the day Mullan started at university. 'I was ironing a shirt. He was on the settee, been in a coma for two days. Then he stopped breathing and the sun came through the window, literally. I went over, checked, kissed him, was amazed that he got cold so quick, and called my mother. Then I put on my shirt and went to university. Never told a soul. Knew if I told anybody they would wannae go "Ahhh," and I didnae feel "Ahhh." I went out for a dance that night. It was like, 'Life begins now.'

Armed with five grade As in his highers and a place studying economic history and drama at Glasgow University, Mullan was the first in his family ever to go on to higher education. Not that it was going to be plain sailing into the middle-class sunset. The very fact of Mullan's success at university - in his second year he won both his class prizes - started, he says, to 'destabilise' him. He hadn't been programmed, either by his background or his father, for achievement. And in the middle of his finals - working a regime of 15-hour days, seven days a week - he suffered a nervous breakdown.

Mullan has spoken before of how he was working at home when suddenly he lost all concentration, started crying and couldn't stop. He was in hospital for a week. He talks now, shouting to be heard above the hen party standing beside our table, of becoming phobic, having panic attacks. 'I just put a ridiculous pressure on myself,' he recalls. 'I was terrified of failure, and paralysed by the idea of success. It had a lot to do with class, I think, with deep-rooted class insecurity. Everyone I met at university was middle class. I thought, "Who am I to be here?"'

He eventually re-sat and passed his exams. And in between the breakdown and graduation, he started acting at university. He doesn't remember why, other than being attracted to the company of thespians. Mullan refers often to actors, writers, directors as 'bohemians' and it's evident that to him such people offered a significant nonconformist escape route from the environment he knew. 'There's a part of bohemia I love,' he says. 'The lack of prejudice, the lack of aggression, I love the lack, for the most part, of competitiveness. It's more peaceful.'

For seven years after he left university Mullan combined teaching drama in the community - in borstals, prisons, community centres and, for two years, at the university itself - with performing. This was the heyday of left-wing theatre companies such as 7:84 and Wildcat. And Mullan helped set up guerrilla troupes with names like First Offence and Redheads, touring western Scotland with overtly political plays influenced by the likes of Brecht, Howard Barker and Dario Fo. Thatcherism, the miners' strike, the National Front, were typical subjects - 'anything that related to what I felt to be true about the working class'.

He knew he was a Marxist by the time he was 15, despite his Catholic background. 'Truth is I don't think God on a daily basis,' he shrugs. 'I think politics, science.' In the 80s he regarded himself as being further to the left than Militant, refusing to join either those rebels or the Labour Party itself. 'The irony was that Labour very mistakenly sent me a letter throwing me out - when I wasn't actually a fucking member.'

As often with Mullan, the anecdotal chuckle is not designed to hide his feelings, in this case a deep-rooted sense of betrayal. 'The people who we [the working class] trusted - the TUC and the Labour Party - sold us out big style, unashamedly so. Everything that the so-called New Labour stands for is beyond contempt - particularly from a Scottish context. They don't understand us, they never will understand us, they don't wannae understand us. These people, these spin doctors, these careerists... I despise them.'

While becoming immersed in political drama, in his mid-twenties, Mullan had two further breakdowns. 'I call them my breakdown years. I would needlessly punish myself - angst, angst, angst. Sometimes over a broken relationship, sometimes because I was 25 and hadn't changed the world. If we've all got pilot lights,' he tries to explain, 'mine has always been a bit high, I don't know how to turn it off, or to bring it down - although,' he smiles, 'I don't think by any means that makes me fucking unique.' But then, one day in 1986, 'I was just sitting on a bus and I had this realisation, quite literally, that I would never have another breakdown. I don't know why, but that permanent feeling of dread, that something terrible was going to happen to me, just went.'

But if I said to them, "They want me to be the next Batman ," which I'd absoloootely hate, they'd go, "Oh man, you've gotta do it, you've gotta do it." fields.bodyText: W e are in the middle of Canada's Rocky Mountains, the middle of nowhere in the middle of winter. A tiny film crew is shooting a decisive scene for a Gold Rush western, The Claim, surrounded by snow-covered mountains whose fading imprints in the dusk emphasise our isolation. It is freezing cold. Despite this, Scottish actor Peter Mullan has been gamely 'playing dead' in the snow for six hours. And the gap between acting and reality is getting a wee bit close for comfort. Suddenly Mullan, who is wearing no more than thermals under his costume, his beard flecked with snow, starts to reel about as though drunk. The crew realises something is wrong and helps him to the back of a snowmobile. The actor promptly falls off it, struggling to keep his eyes open. Wes Bentley, the young star of American Beauty, and the Canadian actress Sarah Polley look on, concerned, until the paramedics come to Mullan's aid and whisk him off the mountain to hospital. He is suffering from hypothermia. But Mullan is such a tough customer, and such a 'pro', that no one had the foggiest idea until it was almost too late. It is just two years since Peter Mullan's annus mirabilis, when he scooped the actor's prize in Cannes for his performance as recovering alcoholic Joe Kavanagh in Ken Loach's My Name Is Joe; then in Venice won a clutch of prizes for his directorial debut, Orphans, a night of the soul for a working-class Glasgow family, heart-rending and humorous, and one of the few genuinely original films to come out of Britain for years. Approaching 40, and with a long career in theatre and film, the Glaswegian found himself an overnight sensation, a commendation he still meets with wry amusement. But the acclaim (it doesn't hurt when Martin Scorsese raves about your performance - and signs your Celtic strip) has considerably increased the actor's profile. Between this breakthrough and the shoot of The Claim, Mullan made Ordinary Decent Criminal alongside Kevin Spacey, and gave a blisteringly intense performance as Jean, the faux class-warrior-cum-self-serving-shite of Strindberg's Miss Julie, in the lauded version by Mike Figgis. For the role of The Claim 's prospector, who sells his wife and child for a gold mine, builds a town, then suffers his tragic comeuppance (shades of The Mayor of Casterbridge are no accident), director Michael Winterbottom plucked Mullan from a list that included Robert De Niro and Harvey Keitel - an indication of the regard in which he is now held. 'To live in that time, that environment you had to be tough; and to run a town you obviously had to have charisma and power, and a certain sort of ruthlessness,' Winterbottom tells me. 'What's great about Peter is that he is tough. At the same time you feel that, inside, there's a huge amount of emotion.' Indeed, in Glaswegian parlance, Mullan is very much the 'big man': loyal, committed, idealistic; and, yes, tough. The morning after his battle with the elements, I walk into the frontier town that Winterbottom has built in the milky lap of Fortress Mountain, near Calgary, to find the actor back on set without fuss or recrimination; greeting me with a familiar, face-creasing smile inside the comparative warmth of what he calls 'the horsebox', the most that actors can expect of a trailer at 7,000ft. 'It was minus seven or eight yesterday, which up here isn't that cold,' he recalls in his gruff, unadulterated Glasgow accent. 'But I didnae realise that I was soaking wet. The dampness, that's what did it. I've experienced that before, on another shoot - you feel drunk, then euphoric, then it's dangerous. Apparently another half an hour and I could have fallen into a coma.' It clearly hasn't dented his enthusiasm. But then, two years ago he was unknown outside Scotland; now he has the pivotal role amid an international cast which includes Nastassja Kinski, Milla Jovovich, Polley and Bentley. 'To ride a horse and get to dance with Nastassja Kinski - man, you couldn't ask for anything fucking better,' laughs Mullan with an endearingly bone-dry cackle, before reflecting on the accident. 'This place is beautiful, but there's a cold up here that's deadly. It makes you think about the people who conquered these mountains, from all over Europe. And in terms of pure human achievement you go, "Wow." By the same token, you realise how that frontier mentality can become so incredibly violent. If you've travelled 25,000-odd miles, and it's been life and death all the way, and anyone is between you and a crust of bread, you'll kill them.' Peter Mullan understands something about harsh environments, about hardship, even about violence bred by circumstance. Six months after The Claim has wrapped, we're sitting in Jinty McGinty's, a friendly, brown-panelled Irish pub in Glasgow's fashionable West End. The beard has gone, and with his T-shirt, casual jacket and trousers, and closely cut, greying hair, he could again be the clean-cut Joe Kavanagh of Loach's film. McGinty's happens to be near Mullan's 'wee office', where he writes; but it's a long way from Glasgow's predominantly working-class south side, where he was raised in some poverty, and still lives. 'This isn't my local,' he points out. But it's near enough; he's near enough, to what makes him tick. And before we've even supped from the first of many pints, lit up the first of an inordinate number of cigarettes, Mullan is giving me a history of the Glasgow working class, of the Govan shipyards and the 'napalming' of the Thatcher years; while musing that, 'So many guys I was at school with have now killed themselves. Off the top of my head, I can think of four in the past five years. That's my generation. What happened, I really don't know. Poverty, alcoholism...' He was born in Peterhead, the third-youngest of eight children, but grew up in Cardonald, near the shipyards. His father was a toolmaker and later a lab technician, whose income could hardly cope with such a large clan. Yet one of the most puzzling distinctions of the Mullans was that they lived in a grand house on the opulently named Moss Park Boulevard. 'Moss Park Boulevard. It sounds really posh,' he smiles. 'And it was, in a way. I've no idea how my old man got it. The irony was that at school we were always considered well-off, not least because we had too big Grecian pillars outside the door. And two gardens. And a garage. It just so happened we didnae have a car, we didnae have any carpets, we didnae have a television, we didnae have a telephone, we didnae have a washing machine. We had what looked like an upper-middle-class home, but we were dirt poor. As the old phrase goes, it was a coat and no knickers.' His mother told the children to maintain the ruse that they owned rather than rented the house 'as a kind of saving face'. His father, who created the pretence in the first place, was simply a snob. 'I'll give you one classic example of where he was coming from. My eldest brother's name was originally Winston Spencer Churchill Mullan, which my mother, when she went to get the birth certificate, changed to Anthony. And thank the Lord. Let's say my dad wasn't a Marxist.' Sadly, Mullan senior wasn't much of a father, either. 'To be fair to him, I believe that his whole generation were completely screwed. They were war casualties; they came back from the Second World War to no counselling, they were all running around barking mad. I'm convinced they had no clue how to relate to their wives, their kids or themselves. I know virtually no one of my age who can remember a hug, or a smile from their father, or a "Let's go play football."' More than that, Mullan describes a household almost under siege from his alcoholic father's dark personality. 'There are some people who walk into a room and they oxygenate it, by their very being there's fresh air,' he says. 'Then there are those who come in with the smell of death and they suck the life out. He was one of those. I remember the undiluted, black-as-coal bile that used to come out of his mouth.' As Charles Mullan's lung cancer worsened, so the abuse strayed from the psychological to the physical. 'In the later years, when he got drunk on whisky, you didnae wanna know. Eventually our household went completely nuts, because the boys became teenagers and physically strong, and violence became a way of life.' Mullan and his brothers hit back. 'We had no choice. I think it's fair to say that if you walk in from school and he's got your mother over the table with a knife at her throat, one's going to get physical.' When he was 14, Mullan recalls, 'I completely lost it. It was a ludicrous thing to do. I made him a cup of tea and I filled it with all these sleeping pills that I found. And I went in - I'd never made him a cup of tea - and I gave him it, and he just looked up and smiled. Obviously he didnae drink it. That's how sick the sickness had grown. The fact that not only did he know what I was trying to do, but he found it dryly amusing, is heartbreaking - both on his part and mine. If my son ever thought of trying to kill me, I don't know how I could cope with it, the fact that I'd alienated him to that degree. But I'd had enough of what I was seeing around me.' In the same period as this incident, Mullan was a member of knife-carrying Glasgow street gang the Young Car-Ds; hanging around, fighting with other gangs, chasing girls, getting drunk. Despite being a bright, bookwormy boy, he was truant from school for the entire year of his gang career. He recognises this now as a crossroads in his life, from which his fellow Car-Ds inadvertently helped him find the right path. 'They eventually asked me to leave, for two reasons: one, they always felt I was slumming it - because I would use words like "flabbergasted".' He grins, remembering the embarrassment. 'And also because I wanted to up the ante, I wanted us to do really crazy things.' For a change, he won't elaborate. 'Quite rightly they said no. They saved my life, no doubt about it.' Mullan drags the last remnant of his cigarette and goes to the bar for another round. I'm already feeling drunk, as much on the talk as the beer. I remember that in Canada Wes Bentley, a sensitive, Juilliard-trained American half Mullan's age, but deeply impressed by him, observed how 'Peter is a storyteller. Whether we're sitting in a pub or on set, he's always got an amazing story; and if it's not a story, he's telling you how he feels in a story-like manner. It's very intriguing, you have no choice but to listen.' There's more to it than that, of course, implied when Mullan says he forgives his father, but has 'a duty not to forget'. These are cautionary tales he tells. The same disarming frankness exists in his acting. Ken Loach, whom the actor reveres, once told me: 'We saw lots of other people for Joe Kavanagh, but nobody had what Peter had. I think he's very true, he doesn't hide, he doesn't have those actors' tricks. There's a sense of danger about him which Joe needed. I mean, Joe knows he has been violent and he's sort of carrying that fear in his head, that he will be violent again. And I think you have a sense - not that Peter's violent at all - that there is, when he's working, a kind of coiled spring.' His father died the day Mullan started at university. 'I was ironing a shirt. He was on the settee, been in a coma for two days. Then he stopped breathing and the sun came through the window, literally. I went over, checked, kissed him, was amazed that he got cold so quick, and called my mother. Then I put on my shirt and went to university. Never told a soul. Knew if I told anybody they would wannae go "Ahhh," and I didnae feel "Ahhh." I went out for a dance that night. It was like, 'Life begins now.' Armed with five grade As in his highers and a place studying economic history and drama at Glasgow University, Mullan was the first in his family ever to go on to higher education. Not that it was going to be plain sailing into the middle-class sunset. The very fact of Mullan's success at university - in his second year he won both his class prizes - started, he says, to 'destabilise' him. He hadn't been programmed, either by his background or his father, for achievement. And in the middle of his finals - working a regime of 15-hour days, seven days a week - he suffered a nervous breakdown. Mullan has spoken before of how he was working at home when suddenly he lost all concentration, started crying and couldn't stop. He was in hospital for a week. He talks now, shouting to be heard above the hen party standing beside our table, of becoming phobic, having panic attacks. 'I just put a ridiculous pressure on myself,' he recalls. 'I was terrified of failure, and paralysed by the idea of success. It had a lot to do with class, I think, with deep-rooted class insecurity. Everyone I met at university was middle class. I thought, "Who am I to be here?"' He eventually re-sat and passed his exams. And in between the breakdown and graduation, he started acting at university. He doesn't remember why, other than being attracted to the company of thespians. Mullan refers often to actors, writers, directors as 'bohemians' and it's evident that to him such people offered a significant nonconformist escape route from the environment he knew. 'There's a part of bohemia I love,' he says. 'The lack of prejudice, the lack of aggression, I love the lack, for the most part, of competitiveness. It's more peaceful.' For seven years after he left university Mullan combined teaching drama in the community - in borstals, prisons, community centres and, for two years, at the university itself - with performing. This was the heyday of left-wing theatre companies such as 7:84 and Wildcat. And Mullan helped set up guerrilla troupes with names like First Offence and Redheads, touring western Scotland with overtly political plays influenced by the likes of Brecht, Howard Barker and Dario Fo. Thatcherism, the miners' strike, the National Front, were typical subjects - 'anything that related to what I felt to be true about the working class'. He knew he was a Marxist by the time he was 15, despite his Catholic background. 'Truth is I don't think God on a daily basis,' he shrugs. 'I think politics, science.' In the 80s he regarded himself as being further to the left than Militant, refusing to join either those rebels or the Labour Party itself. 'The irony was that Labour very mistakenly sent me a letter throwing me out - when I wasn't actually a fucking member.' As often with Mullan, the anecdotal chuckle is not designed to hide his feelings, in this case a deep-rooted sense of betrayal. 'The people who we [the working class] trusted - the TUC and the Labour Party - sold us out big style, unashamedly so. They don't understand us, they never will understand us, they don't wannae understand us. These people, these spin doctors, these careerists... I despise them.' While becoming immersed in political drama, in his mid-twenties, Mullan had two further breakdowns. 'I call them my breakdown years. I would needlessly punish myself - angst, angst, angst. Sometimes over a broken relationship, sometimes because I was 25 and hadn't changed the world. webTitle: Your rights: Happy returns in the sales

fields.headline: Happy returns in the sales
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles on what to do if that pink top now seems less of a bargain
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles on what to do if that pink top now seems less of a bargain.
fields.body:
Are you easily persuaded? Are you weakwilled in the face of a cut-price offer? This could be a dangerous time of year for you.

The January sales can prove a minefield for those unable to resist. It only takes a few seconds to snap up your 'bargain', but returning it can be a much more complicated process.

The important thing to remember when returning unsatisfactory sales merchandise is that you have exactly the same rights as if you had bought the items at their full price before Christmas. When you buy goods or services you have certain basic legal rights. These apply to goods bought or hired from a shop, street market, mail order catalogue or doorstep seller.

The law says goods must be of satisfactory quality, which means they must be free from defects, even minor ones. The only exception is when the flaws have been brought to your attention by the seller. If the goods are said to be shopsoiled, for example, you cannot complain about them being dirty.

Goods must also be fit for their purpose. If you ask for waterproof boots for walking in slush and snow, you should not end up with wet socks. Purchases must also be as described on the packaging, labels, display signs or by a shop assistant. A shirt described as 100 per cent cotton should not turn out to be made of polyester.

Many traders operate goodwill policies, which will allow you to exchange goods which are not faulty, such as clothes which are the wrong size or purchases you do not like in the cold light of day. But unless there is something actually wrong with the item, retailers are under no legal obligation to exchange it or give you its value in money or vouchers.

But a refund is your right when you are returning goods that do not meet your statutory rights; you do not have to accept the offer of a replacement, credit note or free repair instead. If you do accept a credit note and then can't find anything else you want to spend it on, you are unlikely to be able to exchange it for cash later on.

Shops cannot use their sales to wriggle out of their obligations under consumer law. Notices displayed in shops or on sales receipts saying 'no refunds on sales goods' are illegal: the shop should be reported to your local trading standards department.

Be warned, however, that if you fail to return an item within a 'reasonable' time - and this is not exactly defined - legally you are seen to have accepted it. So if you are after a full refund, it is best to get yourself down to the seller as quickly as possible.

Surprisingly, perhaps, while it is best to have some proof of purchase when you return goods, your statutory rights are not affected if you have lost your receipt. A credit card voucher, cheque stub or price tag should serve just as well.

You get extra protection if you pay for more expensive goods by credit card. Under the Consumer Credit Act, if a retailer refuses to pay up when you return faulty goods, you can claim a refund from the credit card company, provided they cost more than £100. But this is only the case if you use a credit card, rather than a debit or charge card.

However, if you attempt to return goods but fail to get satisfaction from the retailer, put your complaint in writing to the shop's head office, address it to customer services or to the chairman, and enclose a photocopy of your proof of purchase. Always keep copies of correspondence and any relevant documents.

If you get no joy from the company, your final recourse is to take them to your local small claims court.

If you are returning unwanted Christmas presents, only the person who originally bought the goods is legally entitled to a refund if they are defective. In practice, some stores will agree to deal with a complaint about a present. If genuinely faulty goods are returned to Marks & Spencer with or without a receipt, for example, the store will give a full refund regardless of who takes them back.

webTitle: The fall and fall of fast Eddie

fields.headline: The fall and fall of fast Eddie
fields.trailText: Eddie Newton scored in the FA Cup Final in 1997, and won a pocketful of medals. Now he's just been released by Hayes. Will Buckley meets him
fields.body:
Three-and-a-half years ago Eddie Newton was scoring the FA Cup Final winner at Wembley. 'Every man with any interest in football has dreamt about scoring in the Cup Final,' he says. 'Imagine how it felt in that dream and that's how it felt. Everything slows down and it's just quality.' Two-and-a-half years ago he was winning a European Cup Winners Cup medal in Stockholm. This season he has played six games for Barnet (W1, D2, L3) and five for Hayes (W0, D2, L3). 'It's easier to destroy something than to build it up,' he says. 'It took years to build my career at Chelsea, a matter of weeks to end it.'

We meet at the somewhat bleak Jarvis International Hotel in west London. Sky Sports 2 is on, muted, in the corner. It is not crowded. There is a man behind the bar. A woman cleans the floor, mopping skilfully around the 'Caution: Slippery When Wet' sign. Given the surroundings and Newton's tale, things could become depressing. It is to his credit that they do not. There is some bafflement but very little bitterness.

Let's start with the good times. 'From the age of eight there was never any doubt I'd be a professional footballer unless there was a catastrophic injury or something. My manager [of his school team] knew I was a cut above and took me to Fulham. And then I played schoolboy, district, five-a-side, Sunday, Inner London and Greater London football. There was a time when I was playing 10 games a fortnight. Which was ridiculous. Silly. And I'd always won things all through my life. Then I got to Chelsea and all of a sudden I stopped winning.' It was the era of Ian Porterfield and David Webb and Newton lined up alongside Andy Townsend in a Chelsea side who didn't concern themselves too much with passing.

'We were playing back-to-front football, and Andy and I would take it in turns to rush forward and get back again.'

Enter Glenn Hoddle. 'Glenn said: "You've got a bit of everything: you can tackle, win the ball in the air, you've the skill to get yourself out of trouble and you can pass the ball. The perfect position for you is to sit in midfield." ' Hoddle turned the club around, Ruud Gullit - 'a very relaxed man' - continued his work and Eddie started winning again. During his career at Chelsea he won four cup medals. As many, if you include the Full Members and the Zenith Data, as the club had won in their history before Newton joined.

Then came Vialli. 'Sometimes your face doesn't fit. Whatever you do, it doesn't matter. I'd been through a lot of managers so I suppose it was inevitable that one of them would not like my face. From day one I knew I wouldn't be in his side.' He played for the team only fitfully. 'The 98-99 season I couldn't find my feet. There was a game at Blackburn and Graeme Le Saux was injured in the first five minutes. I played really, really well and I thought: "Yeah, I'm back. Surely he can't drop me for the next two or three games." Next game - straight back on the subs' bench.'

Didier Deschamps was signed and Newton knew for certain he wouldn't be playing. He, as the saying goes, issued a come-and-get-me plea and it was eventually answered by Birmingham. 'That was a mistake. When I heard that Trevor Francis was the manager, I thought they would play football because of his background with Nottingham Forest. They wanted someone to play like the old days and I didn't play like that any more. I'd be going back to get the ball off the back four and they would bypass me. It's hard when the ball's going over your head and you just think "bloody hell". I struggled for seven months and that was it.'

A spell at Oxford United followed, then one at Barnet, and one at Hayes. 'It helped me stay involved. It was a good thing for both Hayes and me. They needed a senior player to bolster the middle of midfield and I needed match fitness. One minute you're an integral part of a cup-winning team and Gullit is telling everybody you should be in the England squad, the next you're travelling with Hayes to play at Dover. And lose 4-1. It's not been easy at all. First of all coming to terms with the fact that you're not at the top any more. You think you can slip into a little bit of a lower club but it just doesn't happen like that. It's been a very big test of my patience and I've gone through all the little character things.

'You start off thinking you can sit back and wait for things to happen. Then you go out and try to make things happen. Then that doesn't work and you think what else can I do and you fall down and then you have to pick yourself up. There's a lot of hoping - hoping that something will come along - and worrying will I be disappointed again. I'm getting to the point where I'm not frightened of being disappointed.'

His career plans are hampered by three factors, all based on false perception rather than reality. First, he has been stereotyped as a player who can play only the holding role in midfield, but before Hoddle came along he proved to be perfectly adept at playing a more harried, less patient game. Second: 'A lot of people think I'm 33, 34, but I'm 28, turned 29 just the other day. Hello. Wake Up. Because I played for Chelsea since I was 18 and was a fixture for a long while, people think I'm a lot older than I am. David Rocastle had the same scenario when he joined Chelsea and was only 29. Everyone thought he was in his mid-thirties.' And Tony Cascarino? 'Yeah we used to hammer him all the time about his hair dye.' Third, and the example of Rocastle is apposite here, there is a suspicion that injuries may have taken their toll. Eddie says not. 'I'm fit mentally and physically, so that when the phone call comes I'm ready to snap at that opportunity. At Chelsea I was always thrown back into things at the first opportunity and, with hindsight, I was coming back way too soon. But these last two seasons my body has had more than enough time to recover.'

So there you have it. A Premiership-standard player is languishing in west London, training on his own, waiting for that call to come. At the start of the interview he doesn't want to discuss his options: 'There's maybes out there but I don't want to say anything in case it goes wrong.' At the end, he says there may be offers from China or America. He would go anywhere to kick-start his career. Yesterday afternoon, however, as Chelsea fans made their way to Stamford Bridge to watch their team defend their trophy, Eddie Newton was going home to play with his son.

webTitle: The true evil of this killer doctor

fields.headline: The true evil of this killer doctor
fields.standfirst: His victims were old, the silent others, which is why we find such difficulty in dealing with the enormity of his crimes, argues  Nicci Gerrard, who covered the arrest and trial of Harold Shipman.
fields.trailText: His victims were old, the silent others, which is why we find such difficulty in dealing with the enormity of his crimes, argues Nicci Gerrard, who covered the arrest and trial of Harold Shipman.
fields.body:
When a trial finishes and a verdict is given, it is meant to be like the fifth act in a play: an ending which, if not happy, is at least authoritative and certain, providing a meaning, offering answers, and drawing a firm line under the mess and tragedy of what has gone before. So the curtain falls and the lights go up once more and we turn, blinking, back to the daylight where no ghosts lurk.

The trial of Harold Shipman was never like that. A year ago, he was convicted of murdering 15 women, but it was always thought that the actual number was higher; perhaps as high as 100, it was said, although that seemed far-fetched at the time. So when he was found guilty, there was none of the dramatic relief that is found in other such murder cases.

The trial had been long, wretched and baffling, his presence in the dock tetchy and pedantic, and the ending left us with no sense of redemption or of understanding. We did not know how many of his patients he had killed in his 24 years as a GP. We did not know if we would ever know. And we did not know why he had killed any of his mostly elderly victims. It was an ungraspable horror, like a sheer cliff face with no finger holds. Last Friday, a government dossier - product of a year's meticulous research - revealed that Harold Shipman may have killed as many as 265 of his patients. This figure has been arrived at through a clinical audit, comparing the medical records of Shipman with those of his fellow doctors in Manchester and Todmorden, West Yorkshire. His massacre was quiet and methodical. Most of the deaths occurred between noon and three in the afternoon. Assuming that the victims were all injected with diamorphine, they would not even have realised that they were dying.

The possibility of a retrial has been pretty much ruled out - it would be impossible to get an objective jury, and many of the relevant documents have been destroyed or lost and many of the witnesses are now dead. Shipman himself, held in solitude at Frankland Prison, near Durham, for his own safety, has not spoken, despite appeals for help. The relatives of the potential victims are left suspended in brutal doubt and agony. For them, the Shipman trial will never be over. They will never know how their loved ones died.

This shattering new figure makes Shipman Britain's worst serial killer by far - and perhaps the world's, too (only a Colombian, Pedro Alonso Lopez, may have killed more than him). He left a trail of death behind him. He cut a swathe through the community in which he lived as a revered family doctor. Yet he remains a weirdly unresonant figure, who baffles rather than horrifies us. On Friday morning, some of the newspapers led on the ghastly news; others placed it at the bottom of the page; still others put it in the middle of the paper, under a modestly-sized headline. Big Brother, delayed trains, flooded living-rooms, Madonna's private wedding: these things made as much or more impact than 265 people killed by one respectable man. By Saturday, the enormity of the new evidence had begun to sink in and several newspapers put Shipman on the front page.

Nevertheless, his face - clerkish and bespectacled, with a scratchy beard and aggrieved stare - doesn't send a frisson of terror through us, the way that Myra Hindley's obscenely painted face does. He has not become one of our demons, not an icon of evil, and that's because he doesn't hold an evident meaning for us.

Why is this? First, and most shamingly, the majority of Harold Shipman's victims and assumed victims were elderly and they were female, which gave them a double invisibility. Everyone's assumption, when Shipman was first arrested, was that he was a mercy-killer, easing sick patients out of a life they'd grown weary of.

But even after we knew that this was not the case - that many of them were healthy and happy, liked their life, went out gardening and dancing and courting and visiting, were loved and loving and full of pluck and gaiety and quite unready to die - we were still not gripped by pity for the women he'd killed. They weren't children, sweet innocents slaughtered, nor were they beautiful young women. They weren't the stuff of tragedy for us. We think of life as a line, and the elderly at the end of it, with not much time left and so it didn't matter so very much that time was taken away. The old - even if we are old ourselves - are "them", the silent others. We don't care enough.

Then, Shipman was like a ghastly bureaucrat, a statistician at work. He injected his patients with a lethal dose of diamorphine as they sat docilely in their chairs, sleeves rolled up, trusting the good doctor. He didn't seem to have any reason at all - the trawl back through his life shows a diligent schoolboy who loved his mother and saw her die of cancer; the fact that he used to watch her being injected with the same pain-killing drugs that he later used to kill his patients is both riveting and unrevealing.

His murders were not Gothic and tormented, the stuff of horror stories and dark fairy tales, but mute and with a ghastly decorum. He didn't kidnap them, torture them, sexually abuse them, mutilate them or cut them up. He didn't boil them or bury them vertically in his garden or basement. He never listened to them scream. He simply killed them, one by one, down the years.

This means that we cannot identify either with the victims or with the killer. When James Bulger was lured away and killed, there was a mass empathy with the parents. We watched, over and over on the grainy loop of the security video, the toddler being led away, and we put ourselves in their shoes. We imagined it happening to us. We started being over-protective of our own children, gripping them firmly in supermarkets, not letting them out of our sight. The same happened with Sarah Payne.

Conversely, when the details emerged of the murders committed by Fred and Rosemary West, there was another - and far more disturbing - imaginative engagement that we had to grapple with. The Wests were murderous sexual sadists, performing unimaginable acts of torture on their young victims. But while there has never been a case quite like it, most of us have some understanding of sex as potentially dark and perverse and scarily powerful.

The couple gave us a collective wince of terror, as if their monstrous actions offered a glimpse into a hidden side of our psyche. We called them evil and unnatural to comfort ourselves, because we feared they were human, like us - though it was a humanity taken to extremes and unravelled before our eyes.

Harold Shipman does not do this. He offers us no glimpse into ourselves. He will not become a symbol of anything; his story spreads few ripples. His voice is dry, neutral. His face is blank. His eyes are polite and empty. His lips are closed. His heart is a mystery. What does it mean, to be human?

webTitle: Hollywood stars stage a takeover of the West End

fields.headline: Hollywood stars stage a takeover of the West End
fields.trailText: The wave of Anglophilia sweeping Hollywood has reached tidal proportions with Robert de Niro now poised to move to London and take a West End stage role.
fields.body:
The wave of Anglophilia sweeping Hollywood has reached tidal proportions with Robert de Niro now poised to move to London and take a West End stage role.

The Oscar winner will be following a well-trodden path. Kathleen Turner, Daryl Hannah, Nicole Kidman, Jessica Lange, Macaulay Culkin, Kevin Spacey and Donald Sutherland are among those to have recently lived and worked this side of the pond.

De Niro, the star of Taxi Driver and the current hit comedy Meet the Parents, is reported to have bought a penthouse in an exclusive new development in Docklands - London's burgeoning 'Little Hollywood'. He is thought to be taking a part in Yasmina Reza's extraordinarily successful play, Art .

Staff at the sales office of the exclusive Canary Riverside development refused to comment on reports that De Niro has looked over a $4.73 million apartment formerly owned by boxer Lennox Lewis and close to the home of Sir Ian McKellen.

Calista Flockhart is also secretly preparing a London stage debut. The Ally McBeal star is looking over the script of The Philadelphia Story. The play, by Philip Barry, tells of the wealthy and beautiful socialite Tracy Lord, and has twice been filmed, first with Katharine Hepburn, Cary Grant and James Stewart in 1940, and then as the musical High Society, starring Grace Kelly, Frank Sinatra and Bing Crosby.

Flockhart, 36, already has a distinguished record in the theatre. She has played Laura in The Glass Menagerie and Natasha in Three Sisters on Broadway.

De Niro's interest in Art dates from an approach by his friend Sir Sean Connery, who co-produced the play after his wife, Micheline, saw it in Paris. A tragi-comedy about three friends who fall out following the purchase of an expensive piece of modern art, the play came to London five years ago and starred Tom Courtenay, Albert Finney and Ken Stott. Since then the cast has been replaced many times and included Sean Hughes, Jack Dee and George Wendt, the American star of Cheers. A new touring production starring Nigel Havers has just been announced.

Last summer Macaulay Culkin, the former child star, debuted in the critically rated Madame Melville and Daryl Hannah took the role Marilyn Monroe made famous on screen in The Seven Year Itch .

Earlier in the year Kathleen Turner made headlines with her nude scene as Mrs Robinson in The Graduate . Jessica Lange returned to the West End stage last year in Eugene O'Neill's play A Long Day's Journey into Night, and Kevin Spacey took a part in O'Neill's The Iceman Cometh at the tiny Almeida Theatre in Islington. Nicole Kidman took a £250-a-week role in the Donmar Warehouse production of The Blue Room .

It is estimated that Turner probably made no more than £200,000 for her 19-week run in London but the stint here helped revive her career.

But it all depends on the play. The strategy did not work for Canadian star Donald Sutherland in Enigmatic Variations at the Savoy Theatre or Greta Scacchi in The Guardsman . Both plays were panned and The Guardsman closed after only two weeks.

Both plays were panned and The Guardsman closed after only two weeks. vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Riviera Hotel, Bournemouth
fields.trailText: The hotel reopened recently after a £4 million refurbishment to take it up to three-star rating for the ever-growing short-breaks market.
fields.body:
Brilliant. A stay by the sea. So is it easy to find?
Not if you rely on the map provided by the hotel. Or indeed on any map. Bournemouth has a strange road system that involves two separate streets having the same name. This can lead to the kind of conversation that goes: 'LOOK. Maybe I should navigate and you should drive.' We eventually called the hotel and were talked in on our mobile. (They probably don't have to do this with all their guests.)

Was it worth it?
Yes. The hotel reopened recently after a £4 million refurbishment to take it up to three-star rating for the ever-growing short-breaks market. So it's pristine and comfortable with excellent disabled facilities. The new design is Art Deco.

Is the clientele mostly people who like wearing paper hats at their seven o'clock dinner?
Well, there are lots of guests who would prefer Perry Como to Eminem. But then don't we all?

Bournemouth isn't just for, well, the more mature then?
Do keep up. Bournemouth has always been praised for its seven miles of beach and it is now one of the busiest, most vibrant towns on the south coast. Lots of pubs, bars and clubs, plus the fantastic Borders bookshop.

All that sea air must give you an appetite?
Too true. And Harry Ramsden's is the perfect place for a fish and chip lunch after a brisk walk along the prom.

Website: Hotel Riviera

· Two nights (Friday and Saturday) at the Riviera (01202 763653) cost £79.50 per person (£69.50 in January). Rate includes dinner, bed, breakfast and VAT. Extend break with Sunday night special which includes free bed and breakfast and dinner at £14.

fields.headline: How lucky can Labour get?
fields.standfirst: The Health Secretary's had a good winter so far. His long-term prospects, though, are less healthy
fields.trailText: The Health Secretary's had a good winter so far. His long-term prospects, though, are less healthy
fields.body:
This is the season when all who overdid the Quality Street and Bailey's Irish Cream must traditionally pay the price and hit the detox diet. Depending on your choice of newspaper guru, you can do it the Carol Vorderman way (millet and water) or take the Vanessa Feltz route (porridge and water).

As January wears on, it should, according to established ritual, swiftly dawn on us that not all physical blight is amenable to budgie food and an outlay of £12.99 for a Carol or Vanessa video. This is also the season of the health crisis. A year has passed since the NHS reached meltdown. Wards overflowed, cancer patients languished, Lord Winston lambasted a service "not as good as Poland's", and Tony Blair, the Grinch who stole Gordon's budget, was forced to proffer billions and the pledge of eventual parity with Europe.

The NHS Plan - Beveridge embroidered for a new century - promised the way to a modern, tax-funded system. Would it be enough to stave off a winter disaster likely to pose the biggest threat to the government in the run-up to an election? Not in the view of Mr Blair or Alan Milburn, who last month told us to brace ourselves for the worst.

An extra 343 critical care beds were laid on, plans were made to cancel non-emergency operations and the elderly were exhorted to get their flu jabs. Even so, Mr Milburn expected problems. The crisis never happened. Flu is running at an all-time low, and, in the absence of grans on trolleys, the only pensioners whose maladies make headlines are Princess Margaret and the Pope. Such is the dearth of health scare stories that the BBC allegedly had to confect its own, by suggesting - apparently misleadingly - that farmed salmon, fed on sun-tan pills to achieve the peachy bloom reminiscent of Michael Winner on a Barbados beach, may be the aquatic equivalent of the mad cow.

Of course, there is the threat of a measles outbreak, but it is hardly the government's fault if reckless parents refuse to have their children inoculated. There is the grim tally of Dr Shipman's casebook, now running at an estimated 265 murders. But nowhere, give or take a report on filthy hospitals, is there any residual evidence of a health service in freefall. Mr Milburn must hardly believe his luck. There cannot have been such an intoxicating whiff of euphoria in the air since the days when he used to work in Days of Hope, a left-wing bookshop nicknamed Haze of Dope.

The message now is progress. The Department of Health, which is prone to issue a press release every time the secretary of state puts the kettle on for a cup of his preferred Earl Grey tea, last week had genuinely good news to impart. The allocation of £87.5m to cancer services coincided with the announcement that waiting times have been slashed in nine pilot areas.

In addition, a £20m vaccination campaign has virtually eradicated meningitis C in Britain, a breakthrough hailed by an immunisation expert as 'a miracle'. Though Frank Dobson, Mr Milburn's beleaguered predecessor, was quick to remind Daily Telegraph readers that the programme was his idea and, by implication, his miracle, the lustre attaches to the current health team, for whom more breakthroughs beckon. The human genome project presages the defeat of inherited disease. A vaccine against Alzheimer's is to go on trial.

Science and sound planning conspire to support Mr Milburn's view that "a corner is being turned" on health. Up to a point, he is right. But track back a few weeks to the descant of woe from health professionals unconvinced by the government's mood music. The BMA warned that doctors were falling into collective "clinical depression". The Royal College of General Practitioners claimed more than 10,000 new GPs were essential, and the Royal College of Nursing reported a likely 90,000 exodus by 2004.

Barry Jackson, president of the Royal College of Surgeons and a key Mr Milburn adviser, told The Observer that change was so slow that patients would not be pleased with the NHS for another 10 years. Underlying this unease is the awareness that professional bodies, locked in by Mr Blair to support his reforms, may also take the rap if it all goes wrong. There are other caveats. The new-look NHS is an over-centralised monolith in which local initiative counts for too little.

Cancer and heart treatment, though vastly improved in some areas, is still a lottery. Rationing remains a taboo word, and the hard decisions politicians should take on who gets what are conveniently shifted to the National Institute for Clinical Excellence. Ageism prevails, and so does the harsh edict that elderly people in nursing homes must pay for a cup of tea or a change of bandage. Then there is the health gap, a problem that has failed to resonate with a government that craves instant, measurable results and forgets that its obsession with saving the NHS does not always square with saving those it is designed to serve. Successive reports (Black in the 1980s, Acheson in the 1990s) underlined that the poorer you are, the iller you get and the sooner you die.

The authors of the most recent study, in the current British Medical Journal, updated a survey of Dickensian London and discovered that 100 years of policy initiatives had made almost no impact on health inequalities. Tony Blair has, as yet, failed to become as devout a convert to redistribution as Ebenezer Scrooge. Though his targets are ambitious (the abolition of child poverty in 20 years), the reality, according to the latest figures, is 14.5m people living below the breadline. We know that they face bad health, more mental illness and premature death and, assuming one buys the neo-Darwinian theory, we know why.

In his book, Mind the Gap, published this week, Richard Wilkinson argues that the caveman-meets-mastodon response of instant stress has translated into a chronic anxiety leading to increased blood pressure, heart disease and cortisol levels. If that is a simplistic synopsis of his argument, then the health department's remedies are hardly less sketchy. If only the poor would eat their broccoli and lay off the cigarettes and fried pies, then all would be well.

Such initiatives seem designed to feed middle-class views on responsible behaviour, just as a jumble of targets and initiatives are bait to middle-class voters most preoccupied by the state of the health service. That is not to say that the government has ducked the issue of poverty. Gordon Brown has ruled out across-the-board tax cuts and signalled special payments for families with small children beyond the £10-a-week children's tax credit to be introduced in April. Even so, an acknowledgment that bad health is inextricably linked with social division should, logically, come from the Department of Health.

So far, Mr Milburn has kept quiet. One can see his problem. The initiatives and partnerships needed to improve matters are complex. You cannot advance the not-very-good NHS Direct as an instant solution. You cannot vaunt the nation's 36 drop-in nursing centres (also of questionable quality, according to Which?) as a fresh dawn. As for the news bulletins now regularly dispensed, in morphine-pump drips of comfort, they are both testament to the health secretary's success and a warning that a remodelled NHS pledging equal shares for all needs a vision much broader than vote-catching in May.

fields.headline: Deng's Tiananmen paranoia revealed
fields.trailText: China's ageing rulers sent in the troops to suppress the 1989 democracy movement after their leader had expressed fears of being placed under house arrest.
fields.body:
China's ageing rulers sent in the troops to suppress the 1989 democracy movement after their leader had expressed fears of being placed under house arrest.

They were also told 'CIA agents' were active in Tiananmen Square, according to secret Chinese documents to be published in the US.

The documents, said to have been smuggled out by a disaffected civil servant, show how the leadership's paranoia prevailed over more moderate voices.

The revolutionary veterans were convinced by hardliners that the students were being incited by 'reactionary elements and CIA agents' to seize power. The post-Mao Supreme Leader Deng Xiaoping said: 'Anarchy gets worse every day. If this continues, we could even end up under house arrest.' The documents show how Jiang Zemin - now China's President - was chosen to lead the Communist Party days before the massacre, after a fierce power struggle.

On the eve of the massacre, Premier Li Peng accused US diplomats, including CIA agents, of 'collecting intelligence aggressively'.

'Almost every day, and especially at night,' he told the elders, 'they would go and loiter at Tiananmen or at schools such as Beijing University and Beijing Normal.' Li, who still ranks number two in the Chinese leadership, called overseas Chinese dissidents 'the scum of the nation' who were financed by the CIA.

'A major scheme of the organisers and plotters of turmoil,' he warned, 'has been to occupy Tiananmen Square to serve as a command centre for a showdown with the party and government.'

'Those goddamn bastards,' elderly general Wang Zhen then exploded, referring to the students. 'Who do they think they are, trampling on sacred ground like Tiananmen so long? They're really asking for it. We should send the troops right now to grab those counter-revolutionaries. Anyone who tries to overthrow the Communist Party deserves death and no burial,' he concluded.

The hardliners played on the fears of the leaders by saying the aim of the alleged plotters was to 'overthrow the Communist Party and subvert the socialist system'.

Deng summed up by saying 'the martial law troops [should] begin tonight to carry out the clearing plan [of Tiananmen Square] and finish it within two days.' The army finally reached the square after shooting indiscriminately in the streets of Beijing on the night of 3-4 June.

Extracts from the documents are published in the latest issue of the US journal Foreign Affairs, which says they have been smuggled out of China by 'a representative of reform elements within the Communist hierarchy'.

The documents have been vetted by three US specialists who are convinced of their authenticity. They include two writers on China, Orville Schell and Perry Link, and political scientist Andrew Nathan.

The material greatly amplifies what was already known about the internal high-level struggle in which Deng and other retired party and army veterans overruled more moderate leaders.

The reformists today are said to hope that airing the internal arguments of 1989 will 'jump-start consideration of political reform' in the lead-up to important congresses in 2002 and 2003 when Li and Jiang are due to step down.

Several hundred people died on the night of 3-4 June and on subsequent days as trigger-happy soldiers took control of Beijing.

Deng justified 'coming down hard' on the students by saying that the alternative would have been much worse. 'If the plots of the counter-revolutionaries who were pushing the riots had got anywhere,' he argued, 'we would have had civil war...Of course our side would have won, but just think of all the deaths!'

The decision to send in the troops followed weeks of disagreement over how to deal with students, with the hardline Li opposed by Zhao Zuyang, who was replaced as by Jiang as party secretary-general on 27 May. A party resolution gave Deng and his colleagues, officially retired, the right to intervene in a stalemate.

Li accused Zhao of encouraging the students. Zhao had gone to the square to apologise to the students and he opposed the decision to declare martial law.

Li was a prime target of the students and became known as the 'butcher of Beijing'. He is now in charge of China's Parliament, the National People's Congress.

The documents are said to have been brought out by a disaffected civil servant who uses the pseudonym Zhang Liang. In an interview to be broadcast today by CBS, he says he is a loyal party member and hopes to return to China.

'I saw corpses [in 1989],' he tells 60 Minutes interviewer Mike Wallace, 'I saw a depressed mood, I saw a split in the top leadership. I want, through this publication, to try to open up this question in China.'

fields.headline: On the rack
fields.standfirst: Wine tasting isn't always a pleasure, sometimes it can be torture. Tim Atkin selects 10 for Room 101
fields.trailText: Wine tasting isn't always a pleasure, sometimes it can be torture. Tim Atkin selects 10 for Room 101.
fields.body:
I don't know about you, but I've always fancied appearing on Desert Island Discs. I realise I've got more chance of managing Manchester United or performing a pas de deux with Darcey Bussell, but I can't help it. Like Nick Hornby's alter ego in High Fidelity, I'm an addictive compiler of lists. As well as my desert-island discs, I've assembled my all-time England XI (pre- and post-war), my greatest restaurants, my favourite travel destinations and, of course, my top 10 most disastrous relationships.

Given the way I earn a living, it shouldn't surprise you that I make lists with wines. Boringly. Obsessively. Over the years, I've catalogued all my favourites. On the other hand, being a glass half-full kind of guy, I've never spent much time thinking about wines that I hate. But tasting a bottle of dreadful claret last week, I came up with the following list of culprits, all of which deserve to be gnawed by rats in Room 101:

1 Cult wines
Anything that plays on the fact that it's hard to get hold of. These are invariably a rip-off and were usually not that great in the first place. Screaming Eagle (known as Screaming Ego in my household), Le Pin, Cloudy Bay and Grange are all prime suspects.

2 Deluxe cuvée Champagnes
Surely the most over-hyped wines in the world. Favoured by racing drivers, nightclub owners and people with too much chest hair. Cristal, Dom Pérignon, Clos du Mesnil, La Grande Dame, Cuvée Louise Pommery, Belle Epoque, Comtes de Champagne can be wonderful, but are they any better than 1990 Bollinger or Pol?

3 Dry German Rieslings
Wine drinkers in Germany are some of the world's great masochists. How else do you explain their penchant for wines with gum-assaulting levels of acidity? With very few exceptions, German Riesling needs sweetness for balance. If you like dry Rieslings look elsewhere.

4 Joint-venture wines
Two egos are always bigger than one. And they rarely produce superior wines. Anything involving Baron Philippe de Rothschild or Piero Antinori is usually a guarantee of a silly price tag. Opus One, Almaviva, Col Solare and Seña all deserve a berth in Room 101.

5 Almost anything from the Napa Valley
Beautiful place, but too often the wines suffer from ludicrous pretensions. There are enough idiots in America (known as 'collectors') to keep the place in business but, a few Cabernets, Pinot Noirs and Chardonnays aside, you'll find more interesting wines in Sonoma, Santa Cruz and Santa Barbara.

6 French sommeliers
Not really a wine, but they still deserve to roast in hell. There are one or two exceptions (Gérard Basset at the Htel du Vin and Joelle Marti at The Great Eastern Hotel), but they tend to be the sommeliers who have moved to Britain to get away from their compatriots. Pompous, overbearing and, more often than not, ignorant.

7 Gimmicky wines
Anything in a silver, black or frosted bottle is immediately suspect in my view. Ditto anything with a silly name - especially one that tries to disguise its region of origin with an Australian-sounding moniker. Pendulum, Marc Xero, Great with Spam, Superplonk, Scraping the Barrel, Don Coyote, Devil's Rock: away with the lot of you.

8 Cheap claret
I know there are people, some of whom call themselves my friends, who think that drinking red Bordeaux is a civilised pastime. But I'm not one of them. I've had a few great bottles in my life, but they've nearly all been expensive. Under £10, claret is invariably a clunking disappointment: thin, green, weedy, acid and dilute.

9 Over-packaged wines
Designer bottles are a modern curse. There's nothing wrong with making a wine look attractive, but I've sprained my wrist on a couple of heavyweight bottles recently. And I wouldn't mind if the wines they contained deserved the designer treatment.

10 Wine websites
With dot.coms nose-diving all around us, I can't believe there are people out there who want to invest their money in e-commerce. But wine websites are still being launched by the dozen. For every wineplanet, madaboutwine or laithwaites, there are a hundred operations run by saddoes, wideboys and has-beens.
