fields.headline: And baby makes three
fields.standfirst: Britain adopts fewer children from overseas than any other country. New laws may be about to change that, but raising a child so far from home can be an uncertain journey
fields.trailText: Britain adopts fewer children from overseas than any other country. New laws may be about to change that, but raising a child so far from home can be an uncertain journey
fields.body:
It will begin, as often as not, with a photograph. It might be no more than passport-sized and fit snugly into a wallet. But, in its own way, it will be as miraculous as any ultra-sound scan: news from overseas, the face of a child. One woman described the moment of receiving a photograph from the adoption agency as a 'conception', another as 'a birth'. One placed the photograph in every room of her house. Another carried it with her everywhere in the weeks before travelling abroad, like a talisman. She put it like this: 'It is extraordinary how you bond, the difference the photo makes. You know you are going to have a baby. You can see what she is like and start to love her.'

But what does it mean to 'have' a baby? Adoption holds up a mirror to birth families: it challenges complacent definitions, shows that no one 'owns' children. In some ways, adoption resembles birth: a blind (or almost blind) date, a lottery of genes. But for adoptive families, the genes are often unknown and the questions sharper: does nature topple nurture? Or is it the other way round?

Britain adopts fewer children from overseas than any country in the world. But this may be about to change. Tony Blair's White Paper, Adoption: a new approach, is aimed at adoption within this country but may galvanise 'intercountry' adoption too. The new laws, to be introduced this year, will cut the time taken to adopt a child from three years to 12 months; parents will no longer be turned down for being the wrong colour, sex, size or age. Children will not be left to languish in care when there is a better alternative. And there will, for the first time, be a national register for potential adoptive parents.

Intercountry adoption is even more complicated than adopting within this country. Not least because there is colossal prejudice against it. There is widespread distaste at the idea of raising children thousands of miles from home. There are concerns about child-trafficking. There have been troubling reports recently from Guatemala, Vietnam and Cambodia of corrupt lawyers forcing mothers to give up their babies.

Britain has historical reasons, too, for unease. It has a past to live down: the shipping of children from British orphanages to the colonies, which started in the Twenties and only ended in the Sixties (the last boatload of 90 children left Southampton for Australia in 1967).

And then there is xenophobia. The white mother of four Vietnamese and Chinese children remembers her feelings when a parent at her children's school asked tartly: 'Where did you buy them?' She describes living as an inter-racial, adoptive family in Britain as disagreeably conspicuous, like 'living inside a goldfish bowl'.

Sometimes prejudice is more sly, harder to define. It seems to spring out of a we're-all-right-Jack complacency. Many couples who hope to adopt healthy babies (seldom available for adoption in this country) are dismayed to encounter censorious reaction. They are judged selfish for wanting what the rest of the world so easily and thoughtlessly produces.

In a perfect world, adoption would not be necessary. But as Liv O'Hanlon of the Adoption Forum and a passionate lobbyist for reform says: 'I simply can't get past the fact that there are children out there who need families.' Hundreds and thousands of children who, for legitimate reasons, cannot find families in their own country.

And although intercountry adoption used to be a wild card, under-regulated, and open to abuse, that is about to change. The 1999 Adoption Act (intercountry aspects), is to receive its finishing touches this year when the guidelines and regulations necessary to implement it will be put before the House. It will give intercountry adoption a legal framework for the first time. Britain will ratify the Hague Convention of 1993 for the Protection of Children, which will improve its international status as an adoptive country. Peter Selman, senior lecturer in sociology at Newcastle University, whose compendious anthology on the subject has just been published, believes that intercountry adoption may be about to get the boost it needs.

In the Nineties, after the fall of the Ceausescu regime in 1989, there was a rush to adopt from Romanian orphanages. Today, China has replaced Romania (with Russia as a close second) as the main country for overseas adopters. Poverty and the (selectively enforced) one-child-per-family policy are among the reasons for the abandonment of hundreds and thousands of Chinese babies. Most are girls (it is traditionally boys who look after their parents in old age). The Chinese attitude towards intercountry adoption tends to be welcoming and flexible. It includes single women and older parents (the cut off age is 52), as long as they have been approved by a home study.

Patti Waldmeir is a 45-year-old American and single parent. She adopted her daughter, Grace Shu Min, six months ago. Grace has just celebrated her first birthday. Patti recognises that 'to take a child out of its culture is a serious matter'. She knows nothing about Grace's birth parents.

'Selfishly, it is easier for me that no one is ever going to turn up on my door step. But I hope that Grace will understand that the pressures on her mother may have been extreme, that she will never need to feel that her mother didn't want her - she probably had no choice.'

Talking to Patti is a reminder that adoption, although founded in tragedy, can also be a romance, a new version of an old story about the love between a mother and her baby. Patti was told by the adoption agency: 'You have been referred a baby' - a surreal, official phrase for such a moment. And when she saw the photo of the solemn, sweet face for the first time, a 'mugshot against a red background', she 'sobbed for a long time'. Her voice still catches now.

After the photograph, 'everything went into high gear'. Over the next six weeks, there was more paperwork and a long wait for the Chinese to send approval for travel. She thought waiting would be hard but it wasn't. There was so much to do. 'You wonder what to take. Which teats? Bottles? Pacifiers? You wonder, will it be cold or warm in the hotel at night?' She took 'baby rice cereal' - and laughs at herself, 'rice to China!' She travelled heavy: there were 10lbs of documents, a buggy, medicines 'because you don't know what shape the baby will be in'. She took nappies, wipes, prunes. She arrived in China on her forty-fifth birthday, which was 'a big milestone'.

At the Nanjing hotel where the babies were to be handed over, Patti set up a 'shrine' for the baby: bottles, kettle, Dr Spock. She was too excited to sleep. At three o'clock the following afternoon - a startling two hours earlier than expected - while she was in the bath, a woman knocked at her door holding a baby. Patti hurried into a dressing-gown and the baby (she was eight-and-a-half months old) was put into her arms.

'Shu Min, bye bye Shu Min,' the woman said and closed the door. Patti translates her baby's name delightedly: 'Shu Min means ladylike and clever.' The baby 'cried for about 10 seconds. She got very quiet. Her expression was of absolute misery. She was very watchful and closed in on herself. From behind that screen, she watched everything. She clung to me like a monkey, she looked at everything. She would not let me put her down for 48 hours. I have blonde hair. What did she think of that? She had never been out of an orphanage.'

The orphanage director summoned the adoptive parents in the hotel (there was a small group of them) and told them about the babies' routine. 'They had done a very good job with the babies,' Patti concluded. She wasn't, however, able to do a good job herself. She recalls the technical hitches: a bottle that was too hot, Chinese nappies she couldn't figure out: Grace ended up with a nappy on the wrong way round.

She and the other adoptive parents were lucky enough to visit the orphanage, the Yangzhou Social Welfare Institute. 'We pulled into the grounds. It looked like a hotel with air conditioning. It really was quite a nice place. Each baby had one special care giver. All the babies had walkers. They all made a big fuss about Grace. She is such an engaging little person. They were warm. You could see they loved these children. But, oddly enough, it was as though the babies had never seen their carers before, it was as though they had already switched over.'

Grace is flourishing, and in Patti's street in the States there are six babies, four of whom are also adopted from overseas. America adopts more children from abroad than any country in the world (the number of visas granted for orphans from overseas doubled from 8,102 in 1989 to 16,396 in 1999). The process is straightforward: a couple of sessions with a social worker and then about three months of paperwork. Peter Selman believes that Britain could learn from America: they have excellent access to information and good support networks. But he does not believe that America offers a perfect model: there are too many unregulated agencies and the vetting may not be stringent enough.

In this country, as O'Hanlon says, it is still difficult to adopt from overseas. But she insists: 'It is possible, unless you have a really bad background. You just need to be an ordinary person.' She adds, regretfully, 'with the funds'. If you adopt from this country, you do not have to pay for a home study. But if you adopt from overseas, you will (unless your local authority is exceptional) have to finance yourself. It is an expensive gamble, as you may not be passed as a parent. The home study may cost anything between £500 and £4,000 (usually six sessions of two hours each). And many adopters will already have paid for unsuccessful fertility treatment. Everyone I spoke to agreed that the cost of home studies should be streamlined. And then there is the expense of the travel. There are further costs on arrival overseas, legal and administrative fees to be paid (and, in China, the mandatory gift of $3,000 to the orphanage). At present, the overall cost of adopting a child from overseas is likely to be between £10,000 and £15,000 (with exceptions at the lower and upper end).

It is far easier to become a social worker than an adoptive parent. Social work is under-subscribed and under-funded. And the calibre of many social workers, who are, after all, playing God, is in doubt. Most parents I spoke to felt that social workers were invasive in a good cause. One adoptive father even said (and he was only half joking): 'I think all parents should be interviewed before having children.'

But parents have been turned down for being too fat, too middle class, having too many books or not enough sex, being too old, the wrong colour, or for showing insufficient grief about their infertility. One parent was upset when her social worker insisted that she and her husband use contraception throughout the adoption process to ensure that no surprise baby scupper the process. Others complained that it was farcical to be expected to answer questions about precisely how they would bring up a child before they had tried to do so.

Karen and Tony Franco from Wandsworth, London have adopted a Chinese girl, Mae (who will be three in January). The Francos were attracted to China partly because they could be sure there was nothing bogus about its need. But it took two-and-a-half years to be accepted. Karen describes it as a 'massive lottery'. Social workers are often under-informed about overseas adoption. Unless you know where to look, Karen says, there is a dearth of information. She describes the 'negative culture' of application. The first form (known as Form F) that the adopter receives will give details of how to complain when applications are turned down. Karen still remembers that 'the feeling of not having any power was awful'. The Francos were given books to study on interracial adoption and were 'tested' on them. Now they sing Mae Chinese songs, go to Chinatown for New Year, watch Chinese films. Tony is even attempting to learn Mandarin. But Karen is realistic: she does not want to overdo it, after all, Mae is growing up in this country. 'She can point to China on a globe, but to her it may be the same as Sainsbury's.'

At a conference on intercountry adoption earlier this year, held by the Overseas Adoption Helpline, speakers from adoption agencies in India, Thailand and the Philippines made it clear that intercountry adoption is always a last resort after attempts at local or inter-regional matching.

It is well understood that it may be hard for children adopted from overseas, later in life, to form a sense of identity. Some seem to arrive at a hybrid self, a marriage of two countries. But how do they decide where they belong? And what about language? The loss of a mother tongue is likely to exile them from their origins. It is hard to grow up with the past as a question mark, with no medical records, no clues to your genes.

Professionals and parents encourage adoptive parents to glean as much information as possible at the time of adoption. Even information about an orphanage and its caregivers is thought better than nothing. And perhaps adopted Chinese girls will arrive at some sense of collective identity: they are, after all, a part of their country's history.

Gill Shukla is white British, but her husband is of Indian origin. They have two children from the same Indian orphanage. She puts it like this: 'You are adopting the country as well as the child.' Adoption in India, according to Andal Damodaran, the chairperson of the Central Adoption Resource Agency in India, is a traditional practice with its principles established in the fourth century BC; it is seen as 'a gift, confirmed with a libation of water'. But even with a population of one billion, the numbers of children adopted overseas from India is tiny. Gill spent two months in the orphanage with her eldest daughter.('They massaged the babies every day,'she recalls). Each baby in the orphanage was given a shawl and Gill has kept this along with her own memories to pass on.

Julia Fleming, who edits the newsletter for the overseas adoption charity Oasis, and has adopted children of her own, points out that race is as important as culture. Children in mixed race families are often obviously 'different' and need to take 'pride in the way they look'. They need help if they are visibly different from their parents. They need protecting from racism: it is helpful to live in a multicultural area. Gill agrees with Julia Fleming, but also finds much to celebrate in difference. She loves it when she sees characteristics in her daughters that are dramatically their own. 'We are not looking for a reflection of our own personalities in our children.' Sometimes she thinks: 'Wow! That's not us. It is lovely. We can view their passions much more objectively. I am quite in awe of them. They are very strong characters.' Almost all the mothers I spoke to described their adopted children as having 'strong' characters. Make of it what you will.

Stories about adoption divide between those about disturbed children that break up their families and those that imply that 'love is all you need' (as if that were ever true). Yet love is only the beginning of the qualities needed to adopt a child. Whenever I asked what the most essential quality was, I got the same answer: openness. A reaction, I suspect, to a closed past - where adoption was a subject surrounded by guilt and shame.

Gill Shukla is clear that if her daughters ever wanted to trace their birth parents, she and her husband would support them. But it is not always possible to unlock the past. They know nothing about their daughters' parents. 'For us, this is definitely the saddest part of the adoption process.' They send regular reports back to the Indian orphanage in case the parents should ever get in touch. Karen Franco also feels sad for her daughter's unknown birth mother. And she tells a poignant story about a Chinese baby whose mother tattooed her wrist so that if they should ever be thrown together by life, she would know her again.

Adoption arises out of loss and for children adopted from overseas it is a double loss: of birth parents and their mother country (how charged that phrase seems in this context). (The first stage of the study was carried out on four- to six-year-olds; the second, testing 11-year-olds, is under way).

These can range from autism to hyperactivity and attachment problems. There are practical challenges, too. For example many children found it hard to chew: 'They had been eating thick gruel in propped up bottles and found the transition to solid food difficult.'

Rutter observes that there is 'an expectation that children will be lifted out of an orphan environment and pretty soon be OK. Regrettably, it is not quite like that'. Indeed, one of his most important findings is that the longer children spend in institutional care, the greater the likelihood of developmental, cognitive or social problems later on. My son said he felt empty

Benedict's wish to see his birth mother finally came true

Claire Andersen and her husband have three adopted children, two from El Salvador and one from Paraguay. She says: 'Adoption arises out of tragedy.' She is troubled by the inequality between 'articulate, wealthy, First World, would-be adopters and inarticulate, disenfranchised birth mothers'. She does more than pay lip-service to these views. Her openness has taken her on a remarkable journey.

She always felt it important to try to listen, but was not prepared when her son, Benedict, at six, suddenly expressed the desire to find his birth mother. She was 'staggered' by his insistence and predicted, perhaps hoped, that the intensity would pass. A year later, he was still clear about what he wanted. After careful thought, she decided it was natural and a 'good thing' that he felt able to express this wish.

With difficulty, through a friend in El Salvador and a television programme, Benedict's birth mother was traced and the family flew to meet her. Claire was 'terrified' because although Benedict had been legally adopted, she feared his birth mother might want him back. She hoped that if she acted out of love and trust, everything would turn out all right.

When Benedict found his birth mother, he was 'over the moon'. Without knowing her, he had complained of a sense of 'emptiness'. Gloria, his birth mother, may have felt something similar. She told Claire she had thought about him every day since she had given him up. She had 'heard rumours that children adopted abroad from El Salvador were being ill treated'. She expressed relief: 'I know he is happy now and I can live in peace.' And Claire met a 'real person'. She shows me a picture of Benedict and Gloria - two similar, smiling faces. 'He looks so like her,' she observes, 'he has a sunny, optimistic view of life.' Benedict thanked Claire: 'I needed to know where she was. I didn't care how long it took. It was the best thing in the world.'

They have visited the family in El Salvador three times and spent holidays together. She knows that some might think they have gone 'overboard' but believes it 'phenomenally important' that children visit their mother country and 'integrate' as far as possible. (Claire communicated in 'terrible Spanish'; Benedict's brothers took him by the hand. 'Boys don't need to talk a lot; there was a lot of grinning, punching, football.')

Many adoptive families talk about making the trip but somehow never get on the plane. Claire feels there is a lot of 'denial' and thinks parents should, ideally, explore feelings of threat towards birth families before they adopt (in the Netherlands such preparation is compulsory). Of her own children, she concludes evocatively: 'They came with some of their culture in their bones.'
fields.bodyText: It will begin, as often as not, with a photograph. It might be no more than passport-sized and fit snugly into a wallet. But, in its own way, it will be as miraculous as any ultra-sound scan: news from overseas, the face of a child. One woman described the moment of receiving a photograph from the adoption agency as a 'conception', another as 'a birth'. One placed the photograph in every room of her house. Another carried it with her everywhere in the weeks before travelling abroad, like a talisman. She put it like this: 'It is extraordinary how you bond, the difference the photo makes. You know you are going to have a baby. You can see what she is like and start to love her.' But what does it mean to 'have' a baby? Adoption holds up a mirror to birth families: it challenges complacent definitions, shows that no one 'owns' children. In some ways, adoption resembles birth: a blind (or almost blind) date, a lottery of genes. But for adoptive families, the genes are often unknown and the questions sharper: does nature topple nurture? Or is it the other way round? Britain adopts fewer children from overseas than any country in the world. But this may be about to change. Tony Blair's White Paper, Adoption: a new approach, is aimed at adoption within this country but may galvanise 'intercountry' adoption too. The new laws, to be introduced this year, will cut the time taken to adopt a child from three years to 12 months; parents will no longer be turned down for being the wrong colour, sex, size or age. Children will not be left to languish in care when there is a better alternative. And there will, for the first time, be a national register for potential adoptive parents. Intercountry adoption is even more complicated than adopting within this country. Not least because there is colossal prejudice against it. There is widespread distaste at the idea of raising children thousands of miles from home. There are concerns about child-trafficking. There have been troubling reports recently from Guatemala, Vietnam and Cambodia of corrupt lawyers forcing mothers to give up their babies. Britain has historical reasons, too, for unease. It has a past to live down: the shipping of children from British orphanages to the colonies, which started in the Twenties and only ended in the Sixties (the last boatload of 90 children left Southampton for Australia in 1967). And then there is xenophobia. The white mother of four Vietnamese and Chinese children remembers her feelings when a parent at her children's school asked tartly: 'Where did you buy them?' She describes living as an inter-racial, adoptive family in Britain as disagreeably conspicuous, like 'living inside a goldfish bowl'. Sometimes prejudice is more sly, harder to define. It seems to spring out of a we're-all-right-Jack complacency. Many couples who hope to adopt healthy babies (seldom available for adoption in this country) are dismayed to encounter censorious reaction. They are judged selfish for wanting what the rest of the world so easily and thoughtlessly produces. In a perfect world, adoption would not be necessary. But as Liv O'Hanlon of the Adoption Forum and a passionate lobbyist for reform says: 'I simply can't get past the fact that there are children out there who need families.' Hundreds and thousands of children who, for legitimate reasons, cannot find families in their own country. And although intercountry adoption used to be a wild card, under-regulated, and open to abuse, that is about to change. The 1999 Adoption Act (intercountry aspects), is to receive its finishing touches this year when the guidelines and regulations necessary to implement it will be put before the House. It will give intercountry adoption a legal framework for the first time. Britain will ratify the Hague Convention of 1993 for the Protection of Children, which will improve its international status as an adoptive country. Peter Selman, senior lecturer in sociology at Newcastle University, whose compendious anthology on the subject has just been published, believes that intercountry adoption may be about to get the boost it needs. In the Nineties, after the fall of the Ceausescu regime in 1989, there was a rush to adopt from Romanian orphanages. Today, China has replaced Romania (with Russia as a close second) as the main country for overseas adopters. Poverty and the (selectively enforced) one-child-per-family policy are among the reasons for the abandonment of hundreds and thousands of Chinese babies. Most are girls (it is traditionally boys who look after their parents in old age). The Chinese attitude towards intercountry adoption tends to be welcoming and flexible. It includes single women and older parents (the cut off age is 52), as long as they have been approved by a home study. Patti Waldmeir is a 45-year-old American and single parent. She adopted her daughter, Grace Shu Min, six months ago. Grace has just celebrated her first birthday. Patti recognises that 'to take a child out of its culture is a serious matter'. She knows nothing about Grace's birth parents. 'Selfishly, it is easier for me that no one is ever going to turn up on my door step. But I hope that Grace will understand that the pressures on her mother may have been extreme, that she will never need to feel that her mother didn't want her - she probably had no choice.' Talking to Patti is a reminder that adoption, although founded in tragedy, can also be a romance, a new version of an old story about the love between a mother and her baby. Patti was told by the adoption agency: 'You have been referred a baby' - a surreal, official phrase for such a moment. And when she saw the photo of the solemn, sweet face for the first time, a 'mugshot against a red background', she 'sobbed for a long time'. Her voice still catches now. After the photograph, 'everything went into high gear'. Over the next six weeks, there was more paperwork and a long wait for the Chinese to send approval for travel. She thought waiting would be hard but it wasn't. There was so much to do. 'You wonder what to take. Which teats? Bottles? Pacifiers? You wonder, will it be cold or warm in the hotel at night?' She took 'baby rice cereal' - and laughs at herself, 'rice to China!' She travelled heavy: there were 10lbs of documents, a buggy, medicines 'because you don't know what shape the baby will be in'. She took nappies, wipes, prunes. She arrived in China on her forty-fifth birthday, which was 'a big milestone'. At the Nanjing hotel where the babies were to be handed over, Patti set up a 'shrine' for the baby: bottles, kettle, Dr Spock. She was too excited to sleep. At three o'clock the following afternoon - a startling two hours earlier than expected - while she was in the bath, a woman knocked at her door holding a baby. Patti hurried into a dressing-gown and the baby (she was eight-and-a-half months old) was put into her arms. 'Shu Min, bye bye Shu Min,' the woman said and closed the door. Patti translates her baby's name delightedly: 'Shu Min means ladylike and clever.' The baby 'cried for about 10 seconds. She got very quiet. Her expression was of absolute misery. She was very watchful and closed in on herself. From behind that screen, she watched everything. She clung to me like a monkey, she looked at everything. The orphanage director summoned the adoptive parents in the hotel (there was a small group of them) and told them about the babies' routine. 'They had done a very good job with the babies,' Patti concluded. She wasn't, however, able to do a good job herself. She recalls the technical hitches: a bottle that was too hot, Chinese nappies she couldn't figure out: Grace ended up with a nappy on the wrong way round. The process is straightforward: a couple of sessions with a social worker and then about three months of paperwork. Peter Selman believes that Britain could learn from America: they have excellent access to information and good support networks. But he does not believe that America offers a perfect model: there are too many unregulated agencies and the vetting may not be stringent enough. In this country, as O'Hanlon says, it is still difficult to adopt from overseas. But she insists: 'It is possible, unless you have a really bad background. You just need to be an ordinary person.' She adds, regretfully, 'with the funds'. If you adopt from this country, you do not have to pay for a home study. But if you adopt from overseas, you will (unless your local authority is exceptional) have to finance yourself. It is an expensive gamble, as you may not be passed as a parent. The home study may cost anything between £500 and £4,000 (usually six sessions of two hours each). And many adopters will already have paid for unsuccessful fertility treatment. Everyone I spoke to agreed that the cost of home studies should be streamlined. And then there is the expense of the travel. There are further costs on arrival overseas, legal and administrative fees to be paid (and, in China, the mandatory gift of $3,000 to the orphanage). At present, the overall cost of adopting a child from overseas is likely to be between £10,000 and £15,000 (with exceptions at the lower and upper end). It is far easier to become a social worker than an adoptive parent. Social work is under-subscribed and under-funded. And the calibre of many social workers, who are, after all, playing God, is in doubt. Most parents I spoke to felt that social workers were invasive in a good cause. One adoptive father even said (and he was only half joking): 'I think all parents should be interviewed before having children.' But parents have been turned down for being too fat, too middle class, having too many books or not enough sex, being too old, the wrong colour, or for showing insufficient grief about their infertility. One parent was upset when her social worker insisted that she and her husband use contraception throughout the adoption process to ensure that no surprise baby scupper the process. Others complained that it was farcical to be expected to answer questions about precisely how they would bring up a child before they had tried to do so. Karen and Tony Franco from Wandsworth, London have adopted a Chinese girl, Mae (who will be three in January). The Francos were attracted to China partly because they could be sure there was nothing bogus about its need. But it took two-and-a-half years to be accepted. Karen describes it as a 'massive lottery'. Social workers are often under-informed about overseas adoption. Unless you know where to look, Karen says, there is a dearth of information. She describes the 'negative culture' of application. The first form (known as Form F) that the adopter receives will give details of how to complain when applications are turned down. Karen still remembers that 'the feeling of not having any power was awful'. The Francos were given books to study on interracial adoption and were 'tested' on them. Now they sing Mae Chinese songs, go to Chinatown for New Year, watch Chinese films. Tony is even attempting to learn Mandarin. But Karen is realistic: she does not want to overdo it, after all, Mae is growing up in this country. 'She can point to China on a globe, but to her it may be the same as Sainsbury's.' At a conference on intercountry adoption earlier this year, held by the Overseas Adoption Helpline, speakers from adoption agencies in India, Thailand and the Philippines made it clear that intercountry adoption is always a last resort after attempts at local or inter-regional matching. It is well understood that it may be hard for children adopted from overseas, later in life, to form a sense of identity. Some seem to arrive at a hybrid self, a marriage of two countries. But how do they decide where they belong? And what about language? The loss of a mother tongue is likely to exile them from their origins. It is hard to grow up with the past as a question mark, with no medical records, no clues to your genes. Professionals and parents encourage adoptive parents to glean as much information as possible at the time of adoption. Even information about an orphanage and its caregivers is thought better than nothing. And perhaps adopted Chinese girls will arrive at some sense of collective identity: they are, after all, a part of their country's history. Gill Shukla is white British, but her husband is of Indian origin. They have two children from the same Indian orphanage. She puts it like this: 'You are adopting the country as well as the child.' Adoption in India, according to Andal Damodaran, the chairperson of the Central Adoption Resource Agency in India, is a traditional practice with its principles established in the fourth century BC; it is seen as 'a gift, confirmed with a libation of water'. But even with a population of one billion, the numbers of children adopted overseas from India is tiny. Gill spent two months in the orphanage with her eldest daughter.('They massaged the babies every day,'she recalls). Each baby in the orphanage was given a shawl and Gill has kept this along with her own memories to pass on. Julia Fleming, who edits the newsletter for the overseas adoption charity Oasis, and has adopted children of her own, points out that race is as important as culture. Children in mixed race families are often obviously 'different' and need to take 'pride in the way they look'. They need help if they are visibly different from their parents. They need protecting from racism: it is helpful to live in a multicultural area. Gill agrees with Julia Fleming, but also finds much to celebrate in difference. She loves it when she sees characteristics in her daughters that are dramatically their own. 'We are not looking for a reflection of our own personalities in our children.' Sometimes she thinks: 'Wow! That's not us. It is lovely. We can view their passions much more objectively. I am quite in awe of them. They are very strong characters.' Almost all the mothers I spoke to described their adopted children as having 'strong' characters. Make of it what you will. Stories about adoption divide between those about disturbed children that break up their families and those that imply that 'love is all you need' (as if that were ever true). Yet love is only the beginning of the qualities needed to adopt a child. Whenever I asked what the most essential quality was, I got the same answer: openness. A reaction, I suspect, to a closed past - where adoption was a subject surrounded by guilt and shame. Gill Shukla is clear that if her daughters ever wanted to trace their birth parents, she and her husband would support them. But it is not always possible to unlock the past. They know nothing about their daughters' parents. 'For us, this is definitely the saddest part of the adoption process.' They send regular reports back to the Indian orphanage in case the parents should ever get in touch. Karen Franco also feels sad for her daughter's unknown birth mother. webTitle: Social workers get new image to lure recruits

fields.headline: Social workers get new image to lure recruits
fields.trailText: Social workers are to get an image makeover, portraying them as heroic carers rather than politically correct bogeymen, as new figures reveal a fresh crisis in public-sector recruitment.
fields.body:
Social workers are to get an image makeover, portraying them as heroic carers rather than politically correct bogeymen, as new figures reveal a fresh crisis in public-sector recruitment.

Research shows nearly one in six social services posts nationwide is vacant, while applications have slumped. Trade unions say that the shortages, which follow similar staffing crises in education and the NHS, may be putting vulnerable children at risk.

The Local Government Association survey, to be unveiled at the end of the month, suggests it is not low pay fuelling the exodus, but the fact that social workers feel hated by the public.

Criticism of them for interfering in family life, witch-hunts for suspected paedophiles in care homes, and controversy over murders by mental patients have eroded morale.

Now Health Minister John Hutton is planning a national advertising campaign to reverse the trend of 'social worker bashing'.

The first phase, organised by the LGA, will begin with posters on the theme that 'social workers make a difference', expected to feature emotive pictures of small children or elderly people who have been helped.

The LGA also wants to popularise the words 'social care' instead of 'social work' to soften the image of the job.

'The difficulty really is caseloads. Most people in inner London would say their caseloads are so huge, and the back-up is so small, that it is only by the grace of whoever you believe in that they haven't got a child tragedy on their hands,' said a spokeswoman for Unison, the public-sector union.

'But there is also constant carping and criticism - if you take a child away from parents you get it in the neck, if you leave them there you get it in the neck.

'Until we get over this scapegoating of social workers, we are not going to get people to stay.'

Figures from a survey in the summer compiled for the LGA by Liverpool's director of social services, Vic Citorella, show 16 per cent of posts were not filled, rising to 20 per cent in London.

Councils are increasingly hiring agency temps, many of them Australians and New Zealanders on 'gap years' in the United Kingdom.

With applications to train in social work halved between 1996 and 1999, employers have had to trawl Canada and South Africa for recruits. Children's and mental health services are the worst hit.

Labour has used advertising to attract teachers and nurses, with glowing campaigns telling how nurses have saved babies' lives, or celebrities recalling their classroom days under the slogan 'You Never Forget a Good Teacher'.

Ministers have now commissioned similar research on social workers. Junior Health Minister Lord Hunt recently admitted in the House of Lords to a problem with both recruitment and retention of social workers, blaming the 'bashings they receive'.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said that a decision would be taken later this month on the advertising campaign.

gaby.hinsliff@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Paperback of the week: The Last Place on Earth

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: The book that finally exploded the myth of Scott the polar explorer
fields.body:
The Last Place on Earth
Roland Huntford
Abacus £9.99, pp600
Buy it at BOL

When The Last Place on Earth was first published in 1979, it caused an uproar. The problem was that it once and for all debunked the myth of Scott the polar explorer who died a heroic death in his tent, unable to make the last few miles back to base. Now reissued as a hefty paperback, revised, updated, and with a cogent introduction by Paul Theroux, its arrival coincides with a rare and spectacular Shackleton exhibition at Dulwich College (go, I urge you).

Although he concentrates on Scott and Amundsen's race to the South Pole in 1912, Huntford provides an excellent guide to the extraordinary fin de siècle flurry of interest in conquering these two worldly extremes, exploration that wasn't universally welcomed: 'What on earth good accrues from going to the North and South Poles?' expostulated the First Sea Lord, Sir John Fisher, in 1904, shortly after Scott returned on Discovery. 'No one is going there when they can go to Monte Carlo.'

However, go they did in their droves. The British were spurred into action when the Norwegian, Nansen, crossed the Greenland icecap in 1888. Amundsen was 17 at the time and turned out with half the population of Norway to welcome the hero home as he sailed into Christiania fjord. 'And for the first time I heard, in my secret thoughts, the whisper clear and insistent: if you could do the North-West Passage.'

The Norwegians, natural respecters of severe weather, mounted polar expeditions with skis, sledges, dogs, Eskimo-style clothing and a high-fat diet. Most importantly, Amundsen wanted to be there. Fired by Nansen's achievements, he had a willingness to learn and adapt, went on the nearly-fatal Belgica trip in 1892, and, by the time he led his own expedition, had a clear idea of how to go about it.

Scott, primarily a naval officer, appears to have gone into polar exploration purely for advancement. He refused to go to Scandinavia to learn skiing, sledging or dog-handling, preferring to use ponies, motor sledges (he lost one unloading it from the boat on to thin ice), tinned food which led to appalling scurvy, and a team of men whom he kept largely in ignorance of his unformed plans. Captain Oates loathed him; his mother referred to Scott as the murderer of her son. Reading this book made my blood boil at the pig-headed arrogance of the man.
fields.bodyText: The Last Place on Earth Roland Huntford Abacus £9.99, pp600 Buy it at BOL When The Last Place on Earth was first published in 1979, it caused an uproar. The problem was that it once and for all debunked the myth of Scott the polar explorer who died a heroic death in his tent, unable to make the last few miles back to base. Now reissued as a hefty paperback, revised, updated, and with a cogent introduction by Paul Theroux, its arrival coincides with a rare and spectacular Shackleton exhibition at Dulwich College (go, I urge you). Although he concentrates on Scott and Amundsen's race to the South Pole in 1912, Huntford provides an excellent guide to the extraordinary fin de siècle flurry of interest in conquering these two worldly extremes, exploration that wasn't universally welcomed: 'What on earth good accrues from going to the North and South Poles?' expostulated the First Sea Lord, Sir John Fisher, in 1904, shortly after Scott returned on Discovery. 'No one is going there when they can go to Monte Carlo.' However, go they did in their droves. The British were spurred into action when the Norwegian, Nansen, crossed the Greenland icecap in 1888. Amundsen was 17 at the time and turned out with half the population of Norway to welcome the hero home as he sailed into Christiania fjord. 'And for the first time I heard, in my secret thoughts, the whisper clear and insistent: if you could do the North-West Passage.' The Norwegians, natural respecters of severe weather, mounted polar expeditions with skis, sledges, dogs, Eskimo-style clothing and a high-fat diet. Most importantly, Amundsen wanted to be there. Fired by Nansen's achievements, he had a willingness to learn and adapt, went on the nearly-fatal Belgica trip in 1892, and, by the time he led his own expedition, had a clear idea of how to go about it. webTitle: Observer review: The Peppered Moth by Margaret Drabble

fields.headline: Mother's ruin
fields.standfirst: Margaret Drabble's sadness is that her mother had wings but never flew. How does she change her mother's past in her novel, The Peppered Moth?
fields.trailText: Margaret Drabble's sadness is that her mother had wings but never flew. How does she change her mother's past in her novel, The Peppered Moth?
fields.body:
The Peppered Moth
Margaret Drabble
Viking £16.99, pp392
Buy it at BOL

'I went down into the underworld to look for my mother, but I couldn't find her. She wasn't there.' The most quietly wrenching passages in The Peppered Moth are from Margaret Drabble's Afterword rather than the novel itself. Alluding to a myth in which a woman entered hell disguised as one of the dead, she adds: 'I feel, in writing this, that I have made myself smell of dead rat, and I am not sure how to get rid of the smell.'

In autobiographical writing, the stakes are by definition higher for the writer than the reader, who may see the enterprise in terms of self-defeating exercise and iffy taste, rather than failed quest and spiritual contamination.

Drabble reconstructs her mother's early life, using family documents and research, resorting to invention only to fill gaps. Kathleen Marie Bloor (to whom the book is dedicated), born 1905, lightly disguised here as Bessie Bawtry, was on the point of escaping the restrictions of her background in a South Yorkshire mining town when she won a place at Cambridge. She seemed to have reached escape velocity, but the second-stage booster of the academic rocket did not properly ignite.

She graduated without distinction (though a reference from F.R. Leavis seems a distinction in itself) and returned home, where she married a local boy, her designated beau. Having - memorable phrase - 'suffered a good education', she becomes a dissatisfied and highly manipulative wife and mother.

From this point, the fiction is free. Drabble has replaced her own generation with a conformist son, Robert, and a rebellious daughter, Chrissie. Robert avoids entanglements, while Chrissie marries a handsome and tempestuous philanderer, by whom she has a daughter, before settling down with a calm and supportive second husband. By her own account, Drabble has used the alternate reality of fiction to explore a more hopeful set of possibilities than life actually offered. Chrissie finds first excitement and then stability; her daughter, Faro, has opportunities to combine them.

In a sense, minimising the legacy of damage you feel your mother left seems like letting her off the hook, a halfway stage towards forgiving her. Certainly, nothing said about Bessie puts her in the first rank of domestic tyrants, up there with Compton-Burnett's cold monsters or Gibbons's Aunt Ada Doom, and the violations of privacy here are almost absurdly mild by the standards of a Kureishi or a Roth. Yet Drabble rightly fears that her tone is sometimes 'harsh, dismissive, censorious'.

Her trademark manner, which leavens traditional narration with passages of direct address, can easily slide into something schoolma'amish - both informal and controlling. 'See them now...'; 'Picture them there...'; 'Cast your eye around, and see if you can discern a pattern among these descendants... can you discern the form of their common ancestor?' Sorry, Miss, I don't know, I'm not in the room. 'Do not titter. Badger is a good Yorkshire name, and not to be ridiculed.' Didn't mean to.

The most unsatisfactory part of the book is necessarily the hinge where the documentary panel is attached to the purely fictional one, after the failure of Bessie's bid for freedom. No longer is she built up, with however limited a sympathy, from inside, but viewed by others. Rather than masking the weakness of the join, Drabble emphasises it with a passage of direct address, containing the only acknowledgement within the body of the text that it is based on fact:

'If this story were merely a fiction, it would be possible to fill in these gaps with plausible incidents, but the narrator here has to admit to considerable difficulty, indeed to failure. I have tried - and I apologise for that intrusive authorial "I", which I have done my best to avoid - I have tried to understand why Joe and Bessie married, and I have tried to invent some plausible dialogue for them that might explain it.'

If the book's goal is to unearth a continuity between the young hopes-and-dreams Bessie and the soured, mature one, then rejecting the assistance of imagination seems like an act of bad faith. It's too late, having changed the names and prepared the ground, to renounce the impurity of fiction.

Margaret Forster in Hidden Lives (1995) also explored family history, the culture of unfulfilment (for women, above all) of the early twentieth century, and the martyred, masochistic matrons of the North. Her chronicle was more optimistic, showing a clear progression in women's ability to control their lives, but it also contained a larger portion of classic family shame - illegitimacy, an unacknowledged child. Forster chose to write non-fiction, and rigorously reined in speculation, however tempted by it. Fiction may abhor a vacuum, but non-fiction respects the integrity of the gap.

The 'peppered moth' of the title is Biston betularia, whose paler variations suffered in the soot-polluted environment which made them visible to predators, while the darker ones survived. This is hardly a satisfying master-image for the book; Bessie's temperamental darkening is almost the opposite of an adaptation. But it is part of Drabble's practice as a novelist to supply multiple partial frameworks of interpretation - here not only the impact of a degraded environment on individual specimens, but a project to collect DNA from locals and establish their continuity with prehistory.

Recounting the history of Bessie's granddaughter, far from the restrictions of fact, she comes up with a version of the Persephone myth, with Faro divided between the claims of a morbid and a vital lover.

The novel's suppressed core image may not be a dark moth at all, but an albino caterpillar. Throughout their marriage, Joe brought Bessie an early morning cup of tea, and she 'lay there like a white worm and took it from him'. On a transatlantic cruise, she lies in her bunk 'as in a chrysalis, a white grub in her girlish white nightdress'.

These images are shocking only because they are not assigned to any point of view but the author's. Bessie refused to metamorphose, though she had the chance - she entered the pupal stage but then regressed, to a state of venomous passivity. But Margaret Drabble too has found herself unable to work a transformation. Setting out to understand the mystery of her mother's failure, she has mysteriously reproduced it.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.standfirst: Adam Thorpe does the world of work in an array of voices, plus Seeing and Believing, Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid, Out of Me and Palimpsest
fields.trailText: Adam Thorpe does the world of work in an array of voices, plus Seeing and Believing, Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid, Out of Me and Palimpsest
fields.body:
Shifts
Adam Thorpe
Vintage £6.99, pp239
Buy it at BOL

Like Ulverton, his acclaimed debut novel, Adam Thorpe's Shifts comprises a clutch of stories surrounding a central theme, this time of work and workers. Despite this linearity, the unifying force remains his virtuoso ventriloquism: pace Eliot, he do the proles in different voices, and with convincing timbre. Achieving a pitch that rarely quavers, his first-person confessionals include a binman discovering spooky filth; a Ghanaian immigrant to 1966 Swinging London with an identity crisis; and a sodden death brought about by an old cigar butt discarded by the poet Verlaine.

Covering an array of nationalities, as well as epochs and working practices, the depressing litany of industrial injuries - hazards of occupation - guiltily stops short of celebrating the work ethic, while ruing the passage of time. Thorpe is himself a craftsman, planing away until the grain runs smooth. The results are intricate, impressively solid and yet somehow lack the thrill of splinters.

Seeing and Believing
Richard Panek
Fourth Estate £5.99, pp198
Buy it at BOL

The world may feel like it's getting smaller, yet it's still expanding. From the publishers of Longitude, Richard Panek's superbly concise history of the telescope is similarly Tardis-like, explaining the science with rare lucidity while keeping the wider metaphorical implications firmly in focus. Galileo's 1609 conversion of a sideshow novelty into the perspicillum revealed heavens containing more than met the naked eye; how, by locating the answers, one could learn what questions to ask.

Kepler, Herschel, Hale (who frequently conversed with elves) and Hoyle repeatedly pushed back the horizons to admit light - 'More light!' was Hale's cry - until by the end of the twentieth century, the end of the universe had become 'then' rather than 'there'.

Lacking illustrations or footnotes, which might have steadied the giddy, Panek's eye-opening account will nevertheless captivate the harshest Luddite with its celebration of an enlightened world.

Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid
Tibor Fischer
Vintage £6.99, pp247
Buy it at BOL

Essentially a handful of 1990s aphoristic tales sandwiched between two novellas, Tibor Fischer unleashes his caustic, Amisish hyperbole on post-laddish despondency, London marginalia and recurrent dominant female sexuality. In the final, relentlessly dark piece, 'I Like Being Killed', a ruinously sex-frenzied female comic spirals in her attempts to define comedy - and her own self - while hunting lost tweezers.

Elsewhere populated by 'failurist' artists, the demented souls of Brixton, and a man trying to read every book in the English language (two at a time), there is also a disarmingly straight account of a journalist, presumably Fischer, viewing massacred bodies in a disintegrating Romania. Among the toxic maelstrom of trailing mucus and raging dejection are discernible moments of calm, but Fischer still delivers his apocalyptic vision with a grim, despairing smile, and a compulsive articulacy that rivals Will Self at his swaggering best.

Out of Me
Fiona Shaw
Virago £6.99, pp215
Buy it at BOL

The birth of Jesse, her second child, shattered Fiona Shaw like sugar-glass. More than just baby blues, what came out of the blue was a pitch-black hell that rendered her as helpless as her newborn child. After a spell in a psychiatric unit, and the barbaric horror of ECT, Shaw began to rehabilitate herself by researching her condition, writing, and psychotherapy which liberated some of the alternative stories in her canon.

A broken home had given way to psychosomatic illness, bulimia and self-mutilation, suggesting displaced grief and a guilt that refused any palliative. Too astringent for some palates, Shaw's bleak narrative - reissued with a new preface by Adam Phillips - draws on the memories and diaries of others to fill in the shell-shocked potholes, as she gingerly explores the brittle façade we call self. The question begged, however, is whether fiction might have better interpreted these energies.

Palimpsest: A Memoir
Gore Vidal
Abacus £9.99, pp435
Buy it at BOL

Blood cousin to the defeated presidential candidate, Gore Vidal's rich memoir opens with a description of another celebrity cousin, Jackie Kennedy, hitching up her skirt to show his just-married half-sister how to douche post-sex. Famous name, earthy act: the tone is set for a description of the first 39 years of his life, viewed 29 years on.

Always a seducer, he remains so - as well as a pedantic, score-settling snob - yet what prevents his legendary froideur from wearying lesser souls is, naturally, taste: mellifluous prose, vibrant anecdotes, and a genteel brutality. Famous names dance off the pages, but the palimpsest's most indelible presence is Jimmie Trimble, a school chum and lover who died young. On the final page, Vidal opines that the memoir had turned out 'not the ghost story I feared, but a love story'. A loss story, perhaps, but for a moment, you believe him.

fields.headline: The boy done good
fields.standfirst: Tony Parsons had a huge success with Man And Boy, his 'generational love story'. He's just delivered  the manuscript of his latest book, One For My Baby. Can the punk-turned-populist do it again?
fields.trailText: Tony Parsons had a huge success with Man And Boy, his 'generational love story'. He's just delivered the manuscript of his latest book, One For My Baby. Can the punk-turned-populist do it again?
fields.body:
It's rare that the delivery of an author's manuscript to its publisher is considered newsworthy. Tom Wolfe made the front page of the New York Times when he handed in A Man In Full; the package FedExed by Thomas Harris to Random House containing Hannibal was also widely reported, as was the day in 1991 when Harold Brodkey's The Runaway Soul (27 years in the writing) finally went whoomph on his publisher's desk.

Tony Parsons might not place himself in the same league but he can now add himself to that list. The manuscript of One For My Baby, follow-up to the best-selling Man And Boy was delivered on Thursday. I should know; I shared a car with the sealed Jiffy bag as Parsons personally couriered it to HarperCollins in Hammersmith. 'Maybe you'll bring me luck,' he said, without good reason.

Tony Parsons creates his own luck, through a combination of tenacity, self-belief and a genuine eagerness to please, forged as an only child living above a greengrocer's in Essex. Thursday's historic drop-off was a far cry from his days of delivering amphetamine dispatches to aggrieved NME sub-editors in the late Seventies. He didn't have his own driver then - he drove himself. 'At the NME I got a long way on very little talent,' he happily admits.

Parsons has travelled a lot further since, from spiky punk correspondent to cream of the Eighties style press; from moneyed Fleet Street mouthpiece to chin-stroking BBC2 arts pundit, and now popular novelist. Yet he talks frequently about the limits of his own ability, describes 'holding his own' against John Grisham and Thomas Harris in the end-of-year sales charts as like 'playing in the World Cup', and states, of fiction writing, 'I'll never be so proficient at the craft that I'll be able to get it right in one go.'

To the casual observer, Tony Parsons, 45, did get it right in one go. His first novel after years of polemic, Man And Boy was an unexpected critical success and it flew off the shelves of airport and train station bookstands. Published in 16 countries, to date it has sold 700,000 copies (650,000 in paperback) and is currently being adapted by the BBC. Except of course it isn't his first novel at all: he wrote the precocious The Kids when he was 17, and three functional potboilers during his lean years in the Eighties, but to the public at large, Man And Boy is his debut, and the author is happy with the white lie of posterity.

Needless to say, there's a lot riding on One For My Baby. 'It's quite intimidating,' says Parsons, 'because you only really sell that number if people like it, and I don't know that the next one is quite as warm and cuddly. Man And Boy sold 20,000 copies last week, and it's impossible to finish a book with that kind of success hanging over you and not be influenced by it.'

In October, Parsons and his editor took the first draft of One For My Baby to a hotel near Kensington Palace and talked about it for a whole weekend. 'We kept asking ourselves, is it too much like Man And Boy, or is it not enough like Man And Boy?'

Man And Boy was what Parsons calls 'a generational love story'. Marketed as a Hornbyesque examination of how a lone dad copes with a four-year-old son, it was far more rewarding in the other direction, in describing TV producer Harry's relationship with his dying father. 'I wanted to write about my dad dying,' he says. Lung cancer took the 'old man' in 1987, aged 62. But Man And Boy is dedicated to Parsons's mother, who also died of cancer before he delivered the manuscript (she was 73). Her death is fictionalised in One For My Baby.

'You use what you've got,' he says, reminding me of the Raymond Carver poem 'Sunday Night' ('Make use of the things around you put it all in, make use'). Parsons wrote about his mother's death in the Mirror, where his weekly column earns him a reputed £100,000 a year. She died in the early hours of Friday morning, he spoke to Piers Morgan, the paper's editor, as her body was being removed by the funeral directors, wrote the copy on Saturday, filed on Sunday, and it was published on Monday. 'People said it was brave, but it wasn't at all, it made it a lot easier for me.'

Parsons has talked a lot about his father's death, how he 'butched it out' and kept the cancer to himself, to protect his family, but his mother's passing is still quite raw in him. 'My mum was this little, skinny Cockney woman, quite courageous, and the difference between her and my dad is that I was there holding her hand when the consultant said "We've had a look at your biopsy, Mrs Parsons, and as we'd expect in a woman of your age, it is malignant and I'm afraid there's nothing we can do".'

'She inspired so much affection among the neighbours and her friends and family. People would do anything for her. What a great life. So although it was terrible seeing her go through it, in some ways you come out of it thinking this world is not such a wicked place after all.'

One For My Baby concerns a man in his late twenties whose wife dies, and who decides to devote his life (or 'his nasty little knob') to meaningless relationships with women. 'It's about a man banging his head against the limits of promiscuity.' It's also 'more fathers and sons' - although this time the father is closer to Glenn in Man And Boy, a relic of the Sixties - 'refuses to relinquish his youth, shagging the au pair'. Parsons admits that as a father (his son Bobby is now a 19-year-old footballer for Brighton youth team and an NME reader) he always wanted to be like his own, 'but I fear that I'm more like the dad in the new book'.

If Parsons is a relic it's not from the Sixties, when he grew up, but the Fifties when he was born. No ponytail has ever troubled his adult collar. He is a product of post-war austerity and family values, raised in Romford, then Great Burstead, near Basildon, at a time when the suburbs meant community, not wife-swapping, golf and Valium.

It is customary to remark on the fashionable clothes Tony Parsons wears - expensive labels which confirm him as a working-class boy made good - but since this is not my area I can only tell you he was wearing a jumper, a watch, some shoes and trousers when I met him. He was remarkably well turned out though: neat, trim and polite, the epitome of old-fashioned manners mixed with the rather more exotic philosophy of kung fu, which he's learning.

He may not be able to show his future grandson the equivalent of the Distinguished Service Medal won by his father, but he retains the values handed down to him, most notably those of an honest day's work and the right to be paid for it. 'I've always taken money really seriously, and it's not the thing to do in the middle-class media. They phone you up and say, "Tony, darling, would you like to write 1,000 words for the New Statesman," and I'll say, "What's the money like?" That's why I go to work. I've got a family to support.'

Tony Parsons expected 'a kicking' when Man And Boy was published, fearing that critics would review not the book but him, the feather-ruffling bigmouth persona he'd forged in print and on the telly. He got glowing notices, all the way from the Mail to the Literary Review (Jeremy Paxman and James Brown both confessed to blubbing, and Anthea Turner wrote him a nice letter), but critics were still reviewing the man: Tony Parsons is not the hate figure he'd like to believe - he's either liked, or secretly liked, throughout the media - his ex-wife Julie Burchill being the exception. (Years after that fraught relationship ended, Parsons now lives with his second wife, Yuriko, a Japanese translator.)

Parsons stands proud, but against an opposition that isn't really there. (His dad had Hitler, he has... who? Victor Lewis-Smith?) When he took his son to school as a single parent, he vividly remembers all the other mothers looking at him disapprovingly, and this paranoia persists. Are all the middle-class people still looking at him? Well, yes, but only with admiration for his pithy putdowns. In the archaic caste system of newspapers, Parsons may still represent the tabloid underclass, while his novel-writing rival Nick Hornby is seen as broadsheet aristocracy, but because of BBC2's Late Review, which he did for six years, he occupies a unique position of 'honorary ponce'.

Parsons disappeared from the programme's line up when it transferred to a more populist Sunday teatime slot as plain old Review last year, but, he reveals, he may yet return when it's shunted back and absorbed into Newsnight. Presenter and friend Mark Lawson is delighted. 'We miss him terribly,' he says, echoing the views of many who have watched the programme struggle gamely without him.

In typical Parsons fashion, he fell out with BBC2 controller Jane Root over an unfortunate comment she made in an interview about Review's revamp in which she said that its regular critics hadn't done anything. He took umbrage, although in reality he wanted to 'do a Paul Merton' anyway and sit one series out while he wrote One For My Baby. It was telling that no effort was made to replace Parsons (his chair was filled by a revolving cartel of lesser folk who'd done something). 'He is irreplaceable,' says Lawson, 'because he's the most unpredictable critic we've ever had - he's right-wing, which most critics aren't, so he gets you away from the general liberal agenda.'

Despite Lawson's playful assertion, Parsons voted Labour in 1997 and plans to do so again this year under duress. He has made himself indispensable in the media, and controls his celebrity carefully. He turned downed OK!, but volunteered for Richard and Judy, knowing it would shift 10,000 books. A middle-aged cameraman on This Morning hugged him, saying Man And Boy had reminded him of his own father dying of cancer. 'I can't help but be moved by that. If I'd just written a book about myself, that guy would probably have never even heard of it. There's not 700,000 people who are interested in my life, and there's no reason why they should be.'

Parsons has found a new kind of fame by writing a popular novel, one that far outstrips being on BBC2. 'Somebody comes up to me every day,' he tells me. 'I'm surprised by that, because I thought that nothing was as intimate as TV, but, of course, you're in someone's living-room and they're putting the kettle on. You could appear on TV year after year and mean nothing at all, whereas a book is quite an intimate transaction. You can't read Man And Boy and not get some sense of me.'

This embrace of populism is what marks Parsons out from many of his contemporaries. Paul Morley, who was taken on by the NME as reserve 'hip young gunslinger' at the same time as Parsons and Burchill, also wrote a book about his father's death, Nothing, published last year. While at times a beautiful memoir, it was never likely to reach a wider audience. Parsons, meanwhile, turned his dad's passing into an easy-to-read bestseller, with no less sensitivity, but considerably more sales.

Likewise, the Mirror sells more than the New Statesman, and the NME used to sell more than Sounds. Parsons reckons there are two types of music journalist: those who are in it for the music and those who are in it for the writing. He was very definitely the latter ('rock'n'roll, I gave you a few years of my life,' he quips), and what's the point of writing postcards to your friends, when you've got it in you to write the fourth most popular fiction title last year?

Parsons and his publishers hope that One For My Baby, due out in May (around the same time as Hornby's follow-up to About A Boy, suicidally enough for both), will do similar business, and the Parsons literary brand will be consolidated: the king of middlebrow fiction.

'It wouldn't bother me being called that,' he says from the back of the car (the manuscript occupies the front seat). 'I don't deliberately dumb my stuff down but it's not going to win literary prizes. It's written with pure motives. I want laughter and tears, that's all I ask. Maybe I'm taking middlebrow upmarket.'

fields.bodyText: It's rare that the delivery of an author's manuscript to its publisher is considered newsworthy. Tony Parsons might not place himself in the same league but he can now add himself to that list. The manuscript of One For My Baby, follow-up to the best-selling Man And Boy was delivered on Thursday. He didn't have his own driver then - he drove himself. 'At the NME I got a long way on very little talent,' he happily admits. Yet he talks frequently about the limits of his own ability, describes 'holding his own' against John Grisham and Thomas Harris in the end-of-year sales charts as like 'playing in the World Cup', and states, of fiction writing, 'I'll never be so proficient at the craft that I'll be able to get it right in one go.' His first novel after years of polemic, Man And Boy was an unexpected critical success and it flew off the shelves of airport and train station bookstands. Marketed as a Hornbyesque examination of how a lone dad copes with a four-year-old son, it was far more rewarding in the other direction, in describing TV producer Harry's relationship with his dying father. 'I wanted to write about my dad dying,' he says. Lung cancer took the 'old man' in 1987, aged 62. 'You use what you've got,' he says, reminding me of the Raymond Carver poem 'Sunday Night' ('Make use of the things around you put it all in, make use'). She died in the early hours of Friday morning, he spoke to Piers Morgan, the paper's editor, as her body was being removed by the funeral directors, wrote the copy on Saturday, filed on Sunday, and it was published on Monday. 'People said it was brave, but it wasn't at all, it made it a lot easier for me.' Parsons has talked a lot about his father's death, how he 'butched it out' and kept the cancer to himself, to protect his family, but his mother's passing is still quite raw in him. 'My mum was this little, skinny Cockney woman, quite courageous, and the difference between her and my dad is that I was there holding her hand when the consultant said "We've had a look at your biopsy, Mrs Parsons, and as we'd expect in a woman of your age, it is malignant and I'm afraid there's nothing we can do".' webTitle: You don't have to paraglide to get your book noticed. You just have to be good

fields.headline: You don't have to paraglide to get your book noticed. You just have to be good
fields.trailText: Brett De La Mare, the Australian paraglider who dropped in on Buckingham Palace to promote a wider interest in his unpublished novel, provides another sharp reminder of the desperate lengths to which some people will go to draw attention to their work.
fields.body:
Brett De La Mare, the Australian paraglider who dropped in on Buckingham Palace to promote a wider interest in his unpublished novel, provides another sharp reminder of the desperate lengths to which some people will go to draw attention to their work.

I remember, years ago, sharing a breakfast TV sofa with the rock star Alice Cooper and a boa constrictor. Mr Cooper - we never quite got on to 'Alice' terms - was promoting an album entitled Constrictor. I recall thinking that at least, in the world of books, there were still a few limits.

That was then. De La Mare, meanwhile, appears to have been to the Alice Cooper school of publicity. Canine Dawn may or, more probably, may not, succeed in finding a publisher but its author's drastic aerial manoeuvre was simply an extreme example of a genre. To those of us in the business, it was different only in degree from more conventional book publicity measures. In the past year alone I can recall an editor who posed naked with rose petals in Waterstone's to promote a book about the film American Beauty, a children's book author who invited the press on a special train, and any number of gimmicky book launches involving fancy dress, fancy cocktails and fancy guests.

If these are some of the tricks exploited by writers who already have book publishers, it seems quite reasonable to me that an Australian who is fed up with rejection slips should break the royal 'no-fly' zone and thereby solicit an interview with the literary division of Scotland Yard. These men, according to De La Mare, have 'got a good sense of humour and [were] very courteous and professional.' He might not have had the same treatment at the hands of many literary critics. Elsewhere, in fact, the author of Canine Dawn has had a rough ride. In New York, apparently, he was verbally roughed up by shock-jock radio hosts, and who knows what scorn he's endured in his native land?

Here, too, the difference is one of degree. The life of the published author can be quite as humiliating as Howard Stern's abuse. The ill-attended signing session, the 30-second appearance on Radio 2, the down-the-line interview with Radio TK: such is the fate of many published writers in the UK - and these are the lucky ones.

More seriously, the brief, inglorious flight of Brett De La Mare offers a grim window on the plight of the unpublished writer, and the quest for a sympathetic response from within the publishing community. To those of us who work as gatekeepers to the lower steps of Parnassus, the world sometimes seems full of struggling artists yearning for that big break, the invitation to step inside the citadel.

And that's not even the half of it. Even if your book is eventually accepted for publication, you join an ever-growing herd of new titles (more than 110,000 a year, according to a recent count) jostling for attention. No wonder, then, that writers in Britain will earn, on average, less than a shop assistant at Marks and Spencer.

Yet, for all the obstacles placed in their path, I believe that really good books do get read, do get reviewed and do, ultimately, get passed from hand to hand, and will live on. In my experience, editors are only too eager to unearth a new talent, only too glad to celebrate the discovery of work they feel to be truly exceptional.

You cannot beat good writing. If it speaks to the reader, you can wrap it in brown paper, and reproduce it on a Xerox machine, and it will always find an audience. That, after all, was how samizdat worked in the last years of the Soviet empire. For every dull book by a well-connected author that gets hyped and overpraised (but doesn't sell) I can think of dozens that get virtually no publicity and which continue to find a loyal and steady audience.

Two examples from the past year spring to mind. First - and most extraordinarily - is Naomi Klein's No Logo (HarperCollins), a call to arms for the post-Seattle generation and the unofficial manifesto of the anti-corporate activist, a Zeitgeist book that's flourished with (so far as I know) barely a penny of advertising. And then there's a little book of essays, Ex Libris (Penguin) by the American writer Anne Fadiman, a delightful (and exquisitely written) volume which has flourished from reprint to reprint solely by word of mouth. As far as I know, Fadiman has no plans to take up paragliding.
