webTitle: Observer review: Tournament of Shadows by Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac

fields.headline: Great Game, set and match
fields.standfirst: Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac give a transatlantic perspective on the last 200 years of Asian history in Tournament of Shadows
fields.trailText: Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac give a transatlantic perspective on the last 200 years of Asian history in Tournament of Shadows
fields.body:
Tournament of Shadows: The Great Game and the Race for Empire in Asia
Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac
Little, Brown £25, pp644

Buy it at BOL

The Americanisation of Britain proceeds apace, hastened by all the powers of internet and TV, by English timidity and sycophancy, by American instincts for interference, by the inexorable course of history and by the mixed blessing of a common language. We have American corporation chiefs, literary editors, professors, disc jockeys and we have American writers and scholars dedicated to that most indigenous of specialities - the British Empire.

This, at least, is an innovation to be welcomed. Most Americans were fervently opposed to the Empire and did much to bring it down. As its principal successors, though, now enduring imperial disillusionments of their own, their attitudes have mellowed and they have come to recognise the good there was to it, as well as the bad. No Briton could have presided over the new Oxford History of the British Empire as fairly and as ably as Dr William Roger Louis of the University of Texas.

Certainly no British authors could have written Tournament of Shadows, a monumental new examination of the Great Game, because it recreates that protracted adventure in exploration, espionage, diplomacy, warfare and miscellaneous skulduggery from a transatlantic viewpoint. Peter Hopkirk's celebrated and more traditional accounts are unlikely to be superseded, but Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac give the subject a wider perspective and extend it beyond the geographical frontiers of Tsar and Queen-Empress into still shadier, more metaphysical realms.

The British Empire has shrunk in the memory. It used to seem, especially to Britons, a phenomenon sui generis, except perhaps as the true inheritor of the Pax Romana. Now it is taking a more incidental place in the long parade of transient dominions. Much of Tournament of Shadow is all too familiar: beheadings at Bokhara, catastrophes of Kabul, pundits with their hidden compasses, romantic shadow-boxing on the frontiers, dubious goings-on in Tibet, Lords Auckland and Curzon, Younghusband and Bailey and Roberts of Kandahar. All this is familiar stuff to adepts of Rudyard Kipling and our imperial past.

Meyer and Brysac come spectacularly into their own when the Raj more or less bows out, the Tsar is removed and the Great Game is diffused into a miasmic free-for-all among the states. Now Americans, Germans, Chinese and Soviet Russians throw themselves into the power vacuum of Central Asia, to many theorists the heartland of the world, and riddled with symbolism. Tibet, 'the Forbidden Land', 'Secret City of the Snows', was seen as the epicentre of it all, and scholarship, exploration and superstition became confused with politics. A cast of characters more remarkable even than the towering bravos of the nineteenth century strode or skulked on to the stage.

An emblematic performer was the baffling Russian Nicholas Roerich (1874-1947), one of the earliest of the persuasive gurus who have bewitched susceptible Westerners with the Timeless Wisdom of the East. Diaghilev's brilliant set-designer, Roerich was a celebrated painter, a learned ethnographer, a Himalayan explorer, probably a Soviet spy and a disciple of the mystic Madame Blavatsky, founder of the Theosophy movement. He was claimed to be a reincarnatiion of the Fifth Dalai Lama, because of seven moles on his neck, and he was a believer in the hidden paradise called Shambala, an undiscovered city in northern Tibet.

This obscure conviction made him politically significant, too, because incarnated from the legendary kings of Shambala were supposed to be the Panchen Lamas crucial to the international rivalries swirling around Lhasa. Roerich brought the bewilderments of the later Great Game to America, where he propagated the idea of Shambala, claimed healing powers for his paintings, diddled the taxman and corresponded in mystic codes with Henry Wallace, FDR's Secretary of Agriculture and later Vice-President ('I have thought of the New Country going forth, to meet the seven stars and under the sign of the three stars').

Inevitably, the Americans did go forth, sending an intelligence mission to Lhasa under the leadership of one of Tolstoy's grandsons. The Nazis had been there already. In 1938, Heinrich Himmler, who believed Tibet to be the cradle of the Aryan race, had sent an SS expedition to Lhasa, establishing a connection so suggestive that in Hitler's ruined bunker, years later, rumour said the remains of uniformed Tibetans were found among the rubble.

Of course the CIA figures in this vertiginous welter. The Great Game overlapped the Cold War, especially when Mao's China marched into Tibet. As one CIA man said, what the Gurkhas were to the British Empire, Tibetans could be to the Free World's struggle against Chinese Communism. From a lonely airfield in the American West, unfortunate Tibetan guerrillas were flown back to their homeland to harass the Chinese, who killed nearly all of them. Thus the exploits, devices and self-delusions of the Great Game's earliest players were handed down to us.

Lenin, Himmler, a CIA expedition to Tibet led by Tolstoy's grandson, the costume-designer of Stravinksy's Rite of Spring, the occult, the strategic and the archeological - through the labyrinth of the post-imperial Game Meyer and Brysac warily lead us, only occasionally tiring, or forgetting, that they have already introduced us to somebody, and finally reaching the conclusion that the Game had no prizes.

Theirs is a remarkable achievement, covering two centuries of one of history's most complex progressions. All the same, many of us on this side of the Atlantic will still most clearly see, moving dim but proudly through these murky wildernesses, the unabashed figures of our own ancestral villains and heroes, the original Great Gamers, and we shall always hear above the Morse codes and the cyber-clatter the questioning cadences of Kim - but what said he of the meaning of the stars, Friend of all the World?

This, at least, is an innovation to be welcomed. Most Americans were fervently opposed to the Empire and did much to bring it down. As its principal successors, though, now enduring imperial disillusionments of their own, their attitudes have mellowed and they have come to recognise the good there was to it, as well as the bad. webTitle: Observer review: Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory by Douglas Brinkley

fields.headline: A ticket to ride, a war to be fought
fields.standfirst: Douglas Brinkley tells the story of the life of Rosa Parks, the 'mother of the civil rights movement', in Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory
fields.trailText: Douglas Brinkley tells the story of the life of Rosa Parks, the 'mother of the civil rights movement', in Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory
fields.body:
Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory: The Life of Rosa Parks
Douglas Brinkley
Weidenfeld & Nicolson £12.99, pp248
Buy it at BOL

'How she sat there,' wrote Rita Dove, the former American poet laureate, in her collection On the Bus With Rosa Parks, 'the time right inside a place/ so wrong it was ready.' Rosa Parks, the woman who, in 1955, refused to give up her seat on a segregated bus to a white man in Montgomery, Alabama, has become known as 'the mother of the civil rights movement' and one of the key figures of the twentieth century. Nelson Mandela is quoted here as saying that Parks 'taught us to sit down for our rights'.

Despite her historical importance, however, until now no biography had been written. Parks, 87, who now lives in Detroit, wrote an autobiography intended to be read by children and a book of religious meditations. Her act of defiance, which sparked the Montgomery bus boycott, has been recorded in history books - and yet this is the first full-length work about the woman.

Curiously, and regardless of Douglas Brinkley's dedicated research, the story of her life has a certain opaqueness. Not the facts of it - that she was born in Alabama in 1913, that she had one younger brother who fought in the Second World War, that she was married to Raymond Parks in 1932 or that she worked as a seamstress and was secretary to the Montgomery chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). All of that is clear. But the problem is that, as of her streetcar activism, she became a symbol of something - of justice, civil liberty, racial equality - and she remains most powerful as that symbol. No matter what else happened in her life, the image of Parks on the Cleveland Avenue bus overshadows it all.

We learn repeatedly that she is 'dignified', 'shy', 'courageous', of unfaltering religious faith. She is, throughout the book, the heroine we want her to be. The story of her life, in this sense, is no story at all: it feels less like a narrative than an unchangeable picture - a frozen frame of that chapter in the history of human freedom.

Returning home from work on 1 December 1955, Rosa Parks boarded a bus without thinking. For the last 12 years, she had avoided buses driven by James F. Blake, with whom she had had an unpleasant encounter before. But this time she was tired and paid no attention. She sat at the back, in the section marked for coloured people, and there were plenty of white seats empty. Each of the city's buses had 36 seats, 10 at the front for whites, 10 at the back for blacks and 16 in the middle overseen by the racist whims of the pistol-toting drivers. If a white person was standing, a black person had to give up his or her seat. In fact, more than one had to stand, since blacks and whites were not allowed to sit in the same row.

Later in the journey, the bus filled up and Blake ordered four black people, including Rosa, to give up their seats so that one white man could sit down. The others moved. Rosa stayed. Blake threatened to have her arrested and, with a grace that was to go down in history, Parks replied, 'You may do that.'

Contrary to legend, Rosa Parks was far from being the first to have taken such a stand. The reason Montgomery buses were arranged as they were was because Homer Plessy had done the same in 1892, and the Supreme Court ruled against him, dictating that public conveyances should be 'separate but equal'. There had been a streetcar boycott in Montgomery in 1900, which ended segregation for 20 years, until the rise of the Ku Klux Klan enforced its return.

In 1953, the African-American community of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, staged a two-week bus boycott that cost the bus company $1,600 a day. More recently, two Montgomery teenagers had, on separate occasions, refused to give up seats. The NAACP was behind Claudette Colvin and Mary Louise Smith, but it did not think it could use their cases to argue for desegregation. Colvin was 15, unmarried and pregnant and Smith's father was a drunkard. So the NAACP and the Women's Political Council sat back and waited for 'the perfect plaintiff'.

'The bus martyr', as Rosa was later called, was precisely that. She was the angel on whom the ministers of the African-American community could hang all their hopes. And it was at this moment that a 26-year-old reverend new to the city stepped forward to spur everyone on. He delivered a speech on the evening of the first 'walking' day, exhorting the 50,000 boycotters to continue, and received a standing ovation.

It is perhaps inevitable that the great orator, Martin Luther King Jr, should emerge as the hero of Rosa Parks's story. She was proud of her association with him, and it is his words about her action that remain the most resounding. 'It was,' King wrote in Stride Toward Freedom, 'an individual expression of a timeless longing for human dignity and freedom... she was anchored to that seat by the accumulated indignities of days gone by and the boundless aspirations of generations yet unborn.'

A note at the end of Brinkley's book indicates that those aspirations should remain as embattled as ever: in the course of his research, he tried to interview the bus driver, James Blake. Blake, he reports, 'cursed me in a racist rage'.

webTitle: Observer review: Making Sense of the Troubles and Beyond the Studio

fields.headline: Troubles in mind
fields.standfirst: Making Sense of the Troubles tries to give a coherent account of the past 30 years in Northern Ireland, while Beyond the Studio offers a reminder of the 'normal' life of the region
fields.trailText: Making Sense of the Troubles tries to give a coherent account of the past 30 years in Northern Ireland, while Beyond the Studio offers a reminder of the 'normal' life of the region
fields.body:
Making Sense of the Troubles
David McKittrick and David McVea
The Blackstaff Press £20, pp353
Buy it at BOL

Beyond the Studio: A History of BBC Northern Ireland
Jonathan Bardon
The Blackstaff Press £18.99, pp230
Buy it at BOL

Buried in the text of most histories you can detect the views of the author. Making Sense of the Troubles, the first attempt to tell the whole story of the past 30 years in Northern Ireland, is an exception.

Journalist David McKittrick and teacher-turned-historian David McVea have worked as hard to efface themselves as they have to fulfil their declared commitment to writing a coherent, fair account of this incoherent and violently unfair period in their homeland. What the text does not say is that the authors, both in their fifties, both Belfast Protestants married to Catholics, have lived a commitment to making sense of the Troubles as they were happening.

McKittrick has worked throughout as a journalist in Northern Ireland, first with the Dublin-based Irish Times and latterly with the Independent. His only breaks were three years reporting in Dublin and from London for the Irish Times. David McVea spent 28 years as a teacher of history and politics in a state - and therefore Protestant - grammar school in north Belfast. His audience of sixth-formers had a political insight and maturity unrivalled anywhere in the UK.

This book grew out of Lost Lives, a massive work published last year by McKittrick and two other Belfast journalists (McVea was the unnamed fourth researcher). Lost Lives is a catalogue of all the victims of the Troubles. Making Sense is the story behind the deaths, from the confrontations between marchers and the RUC in Derry in October 1968 through to the agonising birth of the Belfast Executive in 1999. The last entry in the chronology that occupies a quarter of the 320 pages has David Trimble, the First Minister and Unionist Party leader, facing possible defeat, yet again, within his party's ruling council.

The authors have drawn on a vast wealth of knowledge, much of it gathered by McKittrick, whose job has given him extraordinary access to everyone from Loyalist paramilitaries to British Secretaries of State. He has an encyclopedic store of personal records. The tension between the two authors is in their method of using that material, with McKittrick instinctively reaching for the broad interpretative keyboard while McVea has the historian's desire for detail.

Where the book is vivid, as it often is, is in its careful use of quotes as emotional as the two authors refuse to be. John Major's strong commitment to solving the seemingly insoluble shines out of one tub-thumping challenge to Gerry Adams delivered after the Canary Wharf bomb of 1995.

The book's worst failing, made flesh in that same Major quote, is that it lacks footnotes. Some come from public platforms, others from McKittrick's notebook. It would be nice to have one's own assumption confirmed or denied. Its balancing strength is the chronology, a rich tapestry in its own right. There will be inevitable criticisms that the authors' underlying beliefs show through in their choice of events. Since Northern Ireland breeds a desire to solve and judge, others will be offended that McKittrick and McVea have sought not to. It would certainly be fascinating to read a sequel in which their own feelings were revealed.

The same criticism of lack of emotion can be levelled at Jonathan Bardon's Beyond the Studio: A History of the BBC in Northern Ireland. The first obvious criticism is that it does not unearth some of the more bitter internal rows over self-censorship that have been an inevitable part of trying to report on the Troubles (although hints are there in reports of clashes with Secretaries of State). What it does do is offer a useful reminder of everything that has continued to happen in spite of the Troubles: ordinary social and cultural life, from Seamus Heaney to Irish dancing. This makes it a vital reminder of the 'normal' life that Protestants, in particular, have been anxious to point out to incoming journalists.

webTitle: Observer review: The Oxford Companion to the Earth

fields.headline: The whole picture
fields.standfirst: The Oxford Companion to the Earth gathers together the state of geological knowledge, along with Noah's flood, the great soils of Bordeaux and the Loch Ness monster...
fields.trailText: The Oxford Companion to the Earth gathers together the state of geological knowledge, along with Noah's flood, the great soils of Bordeaux and the Loch Ness monster...
fields.body:
The Oxford Companion to the Earth
edited by Paul Hancock and Brian Skinner
OUP £39.50, pp1,174
Buy it at BOL

There are myriad ways to look at the Mona Lisa, as any art critic will tell you, though few would be expected to interpret Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece as a geological treatise. Nevertheless, the work, with its enigmatic, smiling figure and strange background of crags and rivers, reveals an unexpected fixation with rock formations, fossils and meteorology.

Da Vinci, it turns out, believed the world was a precise macrocosm of the human body. 'As man has within him a pool of blood wherein the lungs as he breathes expand and contract, so the body of the earth has its ocean, which also rises and falls with the breathing of the world,' he states in the Leicester Codex.

The idea obsessed the artist and led him to paint the Mona Lisa before a background of mountain rainfall, riverflow and ocean evaporation, the crucial components of Earth's hydrological cycle. Da Vinci was implicitly comparing her body's blood flow with movement of water round the planet, with surface details of her figure and dress being merged with the flow of streams behind her. 'Note the motion of the surface of the water which conforms to that of the hair,' he wrote. Thus the world's most famous painting was created - at least in part - as an attempt to illuminate our planet's geological correspondence to the human body.

Since the Renaissance, we have replaced such notions with ideas based on a more rigorous, scientific footing, though they are often just as fantastic. For example, we now know a single disintegrating landmass - Pangaea, 'all land' - once spawned the continents; that some rocks contain three-billion-year-old fossils; and that cataclysmic volcanic eruptions have destroyed entire cultures, such as the Minoans'. We have learnt how vulnerable we are to the forces of nature. Global warming, melted icecaps and wayward asteroids are real threats to humanity.

And as we launch more and more Earth observation satellites, laser measurement systems and exploration vessels, we risk being inundated by tidal waves of information about Mother Earth. Hence the importance of Hancock and Skinner's companion, a distillation of the vast database we have created about the third rock from the Sun, from its climate to its geology, from its fossilised inhabitants to its great oceans.

It is a timely book, though it has been long in gestation, following the death of its first editor, Bristol University geologist Paul Hancock, in 1998, with the mammoth task of completion then being taken up by geophysicist Brian Skinner of Yale University.

The end result is a marvellous, eclectic, pleasurably eccentric volume, a book that goes far beyond the mere study of the soil beneath our feet and envelops the entire dynamic planet that we share with other creatures, and whose complex processes we are now altering to their, and our, peril.

There are more than 900 entries, many of them learned essays on subjects that include the evolution of the solar system, mass extinctions, global warming; nuclear energy and the ozone layer. Intertwined with these basic themes, there are entries on the Loch Ness monster, ecclesiastical geology (the study of church masonry), mud flats, roads and pavements and the stratosphere.

There is also a section on geology's impact on music as exemplified by the blowing stone, 'a perforated block of sarsen that can be blown to produce a wailing sound'. There is a discussion on Earth myths, which include legends like Noah's flood, which was 'almost certainly based on a folk memory of localised disastrous floods in the Tigris-Euphrates valley'. There is even a delicious diversion into the geology of wine growing, in which we learn that Bordeaux's great soils, which protect the region from poor harvests, achieve their miraculous properties by being able to retain and facilitate the flow of water.

And, of course, there are the human players of this grand saga, the men and women who have transformed our ignorance of our planet into our current repository of information. Most get their proper credit, including da Vinci who is remembered, not for his mistaken views about blood and water flow, but for his pioneering work in showing that ancient marine fossils were not victims of the Deluge but had been deposited slowly and gradually aeons ago.

Less generous is the treatment accorded Alfred Weggener, the German geologist who first proposed the idea of continental drift and who was scorned and vilified for his troubles. Not until the 1960s, three decades after his death, did scientists realise their mistake and admit he had been right all along. To judge from the companion's puny entry on Weggener, this admission still hurts.

But the most important performer in this story is neither human nor igneous. It is that most wonderful of all molecules - water, 'the essence of life', which has also been the prime sculptor of landscapes, leveller of mountains and creator of valleys. Two-thirds of our planet is covered with the stuff, while living creatures are little more than bags of water with additional nutrients. Small wonder that Arthur C. Clarke once remarked: 'How inappropriate to call this planet Earth when it is quite clearly Oceania.'

Not that the name matters. Either way, it is a wonderful place.

The end result is a marvellous, eclectic, pleasurably eccentric volume, a book that goes far beyond the mere study of the soil beneath our feet and envelops the entire dynamic planet that we share with other creatures, and whose complex processes we are now altering to their, and our, peril. There are more than 900 entries, many of them learned essays on subjects that include the evolution of the solar system, mass extinctions, global warming; nuclear energy and the ozone layer. Intertwined with these basic themes, there are entries on the Loch Ness monster, ecclesiastical geology (the study of church masonry), mud flats, roads and pavements and the stratosphere. There is also a section on geology's impact on music as exemplified by the blowing stone, 'a perforated block of sarsen that can be blown to produce a wailing sound'. There is a discussion on Earth myths, which include legends like Noah's flood, which was 'almost certainly based on a folk memory of localised disastrous floods in the Tigris-Euphrates valley'. There is even a delicious diversion into the geology of wine growing, in which we learn that Bordeaux's great soils, which protect the region from poor harvests, achieve their miraculous properties by being able to retain and facilitate the flow of water. And, of course, there are the human players of this grand saga, the men and women who have transformed our ignorance of our planet into our current repository of information. Most get their proper credit, including da Vinci who is remembered, not for his mistaken views about blood and water flow, but for his pioneering work in showing that ancient marine fossils were not victims of the Deluge but had been deposited slowly and gradually aeons ago. Less generous is the treatment accorded Alfred Weggener, the German geologist who first proposed the idea of continental drift and who was scorned and vilified for his troubles. Not until the 1960s, three decades after his death, did scientists realise their mistake and admit he had been right all along. To judge from the companion's puny entry on Weggener, this admission still hurts. But the most important performer in this story is neither human nor igneous. It is that most wonderful of all molecules - water, 'the essence of life', which has also been the prime sculptor of landscapes, leveller of mountains and creator of valleys. Two-thirds of our planet is covered with the stuff, while living creatures are little more than bags of water with additional nutrients. Small wonder that Arthur C. Clarke once remarked: 'How inappropriate to call this planet Earth when it is quite clearly Oceania.' Not that the name matters. Either way, it is a wonderful place.

webTitle: Observer review: Clerical Errors by Alan Isler

fields.headline: Zion tonight
fields.standfirst: The narrator in Alan Isler's Clerical Errors is not exactly Catholic, not exactly celibate, and not exactly a believer. So what kind of a priest is he?
fields.trailText: The narrator in Alan Isler's Clerical Errors is not exactly Catholic, not exactly celibate, and not exactly a believer. So what kind of a priest is he?
fields.body:
Clerical Errors
Alan Isler
Jonathan Cape £15.99, pp279
Buy it at BOL

Alan Isler's narrators are erudite, duplicitous and horny. Holding on to secrets, fearing exposure, always ready to shuffle quotes and cop a feel, they are secular Jews with guilt on their minds. In his appealing third novel, Edmond Music is an ageing priest and director of a Catholic retreat at Beale Hall. 'Edmond is a bundle of not-exactlies,' purrs his bishop. The Paris-born child of Hungarian-Jewish parents, he converted for safety during the war and subsequently entered the priesthood. But he remains not exactly Catholic, not exactly British, not exactly celibate, not exactly believing. And, to his growing distress, not exactly Jewish either.

For Edmond, the priesthood is disguise and routine - 'a habit, in both senses of the word' - and he fends off attempts to flush out his disguise and unsettle his routine. His adversary, a pursed American priest called Fred Twombly, slavers to nudge him out of office, sneering at his Jewish origins, sniffing for peccadilloes. Beneath this narrative are remorseful memories of his parents - a mother killed by the Nazis, a father appalled by his apostasy - and his implicit betrayal of the millions who died in the Holocaust.

Edmond lards his account with Latinate innuendo and tags from the poets, Shakespeare above all (he is on the far side of bardolatry). Shakespeare provides a continual reference point, as when Edmond compares himself to an unheroic Othello, uneasy with otherness. He equally finds echoes in the guilty lovers of Dante and Milton. Although grating, these allusions are less tendentious than Twombly's, who tends to compare himself with Christ.

Faith, fraud and theatre are tight-knit confederates - Edmond remarks that the phrase 'hocus-pocus' is derived from the mass, and close relation to 'hoax'. His narrative is interleaved with researches into the eighteenth-century Jewish kabbalist Solomon Falsch, a fictional charismatic sage and alchemist hailed as the Ba'al Shem of Ludlow, and modelled on the celebrated London magus Samuel Falk.

Falsch, known to his followers as the Pish (Isler never resists a smutty pun), illuminates the story of a collection of sonnets of uncertain provenance that may just be a lost work by Shakespeare. This elusive volume, whereabouts currently unknown, was secretly sold during Edmond's early days at Beale Hall, and a reference in a bookseller's catalogue gives the embittered Twombly further ammunition against him. Clerical Errors is tugged by the transmigration of books, from reader to library, from collector to enthusiast.

Beale Hall, we learn, was designed in the late seventeenth century by Vanbrugh, playwright and architect, a perfect setting for a comedy of avarice and lost love. As in previous work, Isler uses a farcical structure of imperilled concealment and unravelling security, but with an increasingly melancholy undertow. Farce is a tired, despairing genre, hounding characters who can only lose. Edmond is weary but creaks on, plays the game, willing it to stop.

Isler is unsparing in cataloguing the crimes of the Catholic church, from persecution to paedophilia. The most widespread clerical error appears to be propagating nonsensical doctrine or, even worse, believing in it oneself. The dubious consolations of hypocrisy are such that all the central characters are mired in roles they have played too long. Bastien, Edmond's slippered servant, dwindles into senility and makes the sign of the cross over coffee-pots. His defiantly rational neighbour robustly snorts at Catholic chop-logic but yearns for the comfort of faith.

The mendacious protagonist of Isler's last novel, Kraven Images, was stripped of love, position and family, and unexpectedly welcomed an end to the masquerade. Edmond is way ahead of him, and for all its wit and spite, Clerical Errors cannot summon the robustly libidinous energy of its predecessor. Its capering narrative unfolds in what Edmond knows is a bleak, empty universe. 'Hope is the cruellest of the many cruel jokes we are born to suffer,' he muses. 'The only words in the New Testament that have the ring of authenticity, I sometimes think, are, "My God, my God, why hast Thou forsaken me?" '

In this darkly assured novel, Isler extends his focus from the fallout of twentieth-century Jewish experience to the attempt to lead a rational life amid the clutter of delusive wisdom. The Good Book may be of little help, but his faith clings to the solace of a good read.

webTitle: Observer review: Killing Time by Caleb Carr

fields.headline: H2O! What a lovely war
fields.standfirst: So the oceans are empty, the earth is barren, but must Caleb Carr make it all so exhausting in Killing Time?
fields.trailText: So the oceans are empty, the earth is barren, but must Caleb Carr make it all so exhausting in Killing Time?
fields.body:
Killing Time
Caleb Carr
Little, Brown £9.99, pp310
Buy it at BOL

It is 2023 - and blimey, how things have deteriorated in two decades! In 2006, a staphylococcus epidemic wiped out 40 million people. In 2007, there was a crash and worldwide recession. In 2021, there was an e. coli outbreak, so it is no longer possible to eat meat. Pollution is now so drastic that it is unsafe to go outside. There are water shortages, and consequently water wars are being waged between city-kingdoms. The oceans are empty; the earth is barren. Oh, it's all very bleak.

To imagine the future is to continue the line from what we know and see where it leads. Science fiction tells us more about now than the future. In his much-hyped novel, Caleb Carr has drawn dozens of lines from his present, and they all lead to a frantic dystopia. The world is violent. In the West, the population is feverishly occupied by technology, and manipulated by it. In Africa, Aids and malaria have emptied entire countries. Governments and multinationals control the minds of men and their lives. The planet hurtles towards destruction.

His heroes - a band of warriors who are all fiendishly clever in their particular fields - live on board a plane that's also a ship that can be a submarine and is protected by magnetic fields from enemy attack. They carry clever weapons and plutonium canisters. They fake their DNA identity cards. They rush around the world: Malaysia, Moscow, France, America, anywhere they want. They loathe the way that information is manipulated and truth dissolved in a flood of information, and their aim is digitally to manipulate other information themselves, thus showing people how easily they can be duped by technology.

Get it? It took me a bit of time, but Carr - through his hero-narrator, the cleverest psychologist in the world, Gideon, on a quest to find truth in an age where truth has been destroyed - manages to make all clunkingly clear.

Killing Time is an extraordinary novel. I don't think I've ever read one like it, but I have seen too many films like it. The manipulation of the information age: The Matrix. The ability to time-travel back to the past in order to improve it: The Terminator. Water wars: Total Recall and Waterworld. And then, all those snazzy spaceships and beautiful women with silver hair and bullets that travel at the speed of light and villains with cold eyes carrying nuclear devices in their pockets. There's a childish delight in the clichés of science fiction here.

Carr writes so clumsily that it's almost touching. He fills each chapter with a new, shudderingly terrible crisis, and ends on a note of emphatic apprehension ('Would I had known what lay in front of us'). He disobeys the rule Stephen King laid down in his book on writing, against the lazy use of adverbs, and instead insists at every stage on what his characters are meant to be feeling and revealing ('Tarbell laughed, quietly but with his usual fiendish delight').

He crashes through his jungle of words, frightening away all signs of life. I felt quite exhausted by the end.

webTitle: Radio sounds like a digital success

fields.headline: Radio sounds like a digital success
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Regular visitors to this column will be aware that it is not an avid cheerleader for digital television - neither its merits nor its prospects. For new readers, the problems can be summarised as follows: too many competing systems, fragmented industry, ignorant retailers, over-priced subscriptions, uninteresting software, leading to confused punters who are (mostly) unwilling to shell out large sums of money for more of the same.
fields.body:
Regular visitors to this column will be aware that it is not an avid cheerleader for digital television - neither its merits nor its prospects. For new readers, the problems can be summarised as follows: too many competing systems, fragmented industry, ignorant retailers, over-priced subscriptions, uninteresting software, leading to confused punters who are (mostly) unwilling to shell out large sums of money for more of the same.

If this is true for digital television, you may think, it must be true in spades for digital radio. You would be wrong. In traditional new year fashion, I am even prepared to make a reckless prediction which I hope will be forgotten in a year's time: 2001 will be the year in which digital radio takes over from television as the true broadcast technology of the future.

Why the optimism? First, there is the 'offer'. Late last year, BBC Director of Radio Jenny Abramsky announced that the corporation would be investing £15 million a year in five brand new digital radio stations. Their launch is subject to government approval (God forbid the BBC should take a decision on new channels on its own), but the first two could be on air within the next few months.

As well as a black music and a specialist Asian station, there will be a second speech station and a sports station dedicated to exploiting the BBC's substantial rights in sports radio: coverage of more Premiership matches, more Wimbledon courts, the whole of the Ryder Cup and - Hallelujah! - Test Match Special uninterrupted by shipping forecasts or news headlines.

Meanwhile, the commercial sector has joined forces to produce Digital One, a package of stations which includes existing services such as Virgin, Classic and TalkSPORT with added digital-only offerings such as Life, Planet Rock and Oneword, 'the first digital channel for novels, stories, comedy and discussions'.

The digital offer is not just about more stations. There is the sound quality which - unlike with television - is noticeably better. There is the uninterrupted reception, which in a car is virtually impossible with analogue signals, and no need to change frequencies after driving 30 miles. There is text information which will tell you immediately not just which station you have hit, but that the programme is Casenotes and that you are listening to a doctor's advice on the best ways to stop smoking.

You don't have to wait for the back announcement to catch the name of the singer or song title, and you can even see that the next song is by All Saints, so you can switch off immediately. For radio users, these are real benefits, rather than the superfluous add-ons of television's digital offer.

Second, there is real industry co-operation. Abramsky and Paul Brown, chief executive of the Commercial Radio Companies' Association, share conference platforms and information in a collaborative spirit which digital TV operators can only dream about. There are no damaging rifts or confusing array of subscription deals, and the big commercial battalions within a notoriously competitive industry are prepared to bury hatchets (and even sleep with the BBC) to get digital radio off the ground.

From April, a Digital Radio Development Bureau, with a chief executive and supporting staff of four, funded jointly by the BBC and major radio companies, will promote the cause to consumers, retailers and manufacturers.

Its biggest challenge will be to persuade manufacturers to make affordable, portable hardware. Digital car radios start at £350 for a very basic model, rising to £1,700. The cheapest access now is either via a £299 VideoLogic hi-fi tuner or the Psion Wavefinder, at the same price, which plugs into your PC. The latter device sits on your computer like a squashed spaceship, glowing red and green as it seeks and plays your chosen digital station while you answer your emails. They're great fun, and around 10,000 were sold in the run-up to Christmas. Dixons expects the price to fall over the coming year, but it's still a lot to pay compared with a portable tranny. Short of sticking the Wavefinder on your head and your PC under one arm, there is no easy way of wandering round the house (or the street) listening to digital radio. Manufacturers will have to produce small receivers at less than £100 a throw before it takes off.

A lad in one London store tried very hard to convince me that they were selling Sony digital radios for £39 (the bureau needs to work on retailers too). At that price, they would be queuing round the store and half-way to Manchester. Compare that with digital television, where they are literally giving equipment away, and you have some idea of the potential waiting to be unleashed. It will happen this year.

Steve Barnett is Professor of Communications at the University of Westminster.

webTitle: Novelist Francis Stuart's anti-semitic past exposed

fields.headline: Novelist's anti-semitic past exposed
fields.standfirst: Book unearths anti-Jewish views of Francis Stuart
fields.trailText: Book unearths anti-Jewish views of Francis Stuart.
fields.body:
New evidence has shown that the controversial Irish author Francis Stuart, who lived in Nazi Germany during the war, was anti-semitic.

Stuart, who died last year aged 97, angrily denied the charge and won IR£100,000 in libel damages from the Irish Times. He also sued a magazine which printed a letter accusing him of being a Nazi.

Now a new book on Stuart's writings and wartime broadcasts has shown that Stuart held anti-semitic opinions as far back as 1924.

And those on the sharp end of the late writer's litigation are bitter that had the new evidence been available even 18 months ago they would not have had to pay damages.

Stuart was the author of more than 30 novels and held the position of Saoi, the highest honour the Irish arts body, Aosdána, can bestow on an artist.

He was born in Australia but returned to Ireland following the death of his father. As a young poet in the 1920s he married Iseult MacBride, daughter of Maude Gonne and sister of Sean MacBride. He was encouraged in his early poetry by Yeats. During the Irish Civil war he fought on the Republican side with de Valera and was taken prisoner by the Free State forces.

In January 1940 he moved from his home in County Wicklow to Berlin, where he accepted a university lectureship. He stayed in Germany for the duration of the war and between 1942 and 1944 made more than 100 broadcasts to Ireland on German radio. The majority of his broadcasts were vehemently anti-Allies and called for Ireland to maintain its neutral stance in the global struggle against Nazism. As an ex-IRA member, Stuart also argued in his propaganda messages that a German victory would help bring about a united Ireland. Secretly, the author encouraged links between the Nazis and the IRA.

None of Stuart's broadcasts contained any overt anti-semitic outbursts although there were warm tributes to Hitler and his regime. Decades after the war, Stuart's friends in Ireland used this apparent absence of anti-semitism to argue that the writer was really a hopeless apolitical romantic who fled to Germany as an act of personal rebellion.

The Wartime Broadcasts of Francis Stuart, edited by Brendan Barrington, throws fresh light on the author's opinions of Jews. Barrington has discovered a 16-page IRA pamphlet Stuart wrote in March 1924 called Lecture on Nationality and Culture.

In it Stuart compares the malign influence of England on Ireland to the power the Jews allegedly exercised over post-World War I Austria, a country he visited in 1921.

'At that time Vienna was full of Jews, who controlled the banks and factories and even a large part of the government; the Austrians themselves seemed about to be driven out of their own city.'

Barrington also discovered a letter Stuart wrote to the Irish Times in 1938 - the same newspaper that 61 years later paid him IR£100,000 in costs and damages for daring to suggest he was anti-semitic - calling for Ireland to close its doors on refugees, including Jews fleeing Hitler's tyranny.

The critic and novelist Colm Toibin, long a defender of Stuart, now accepts that Stuart 're-imagined' his own role in Nazi Germany after the war. In an article for this month's London Review of Books, Toibin states: 'The following facts are clearly established: Stuart supported Hitler, he had anti-semitic feelings, he broadcast extreme anti-British sentiments in the war, and he abandoned his family. He later evaded the truth about all of this.'

But in another part of his 13,000-word article on Stuart and Barrington's book, Toibin says that the late author's 'primary interest was not politics'. 'He was a chronicler of his wounded and damaged self who also had these opinions.' Speaking from New York where he is a fellow at the Centre for Scholars and Writers, Toibin declined to elaborate on his view of Stuart's anti- semitism.

But Kevin Myers, the Irish Times columnist whose articles on Stuart led to the libel action, said he was bitterly disappointed that newspapers were forced to pay out to 'this dreadful impostor'.

He added: 'It's disgusting that we had to pay out such a sum to a man who obviously held deeply anti-semitic views and worshipped Hitler. At the time of the libel trial no one knew about the 1924 pamphlet or had discovered the 1938 letter. The award to this man was a grotesque miscarriage of justice.

'What's even more disturbing is to think about all those who defended this Jew hater and how they exalted him for so long in Ireland.'

His defenders, who included the novelist Ulick O'Connor and the historian Anthony Cronin, say that the bulk of Stuart's work was not concerned with politics. But Barrington analyses the wartime broadcasts to prove that the overwhelming content of Stuart's output was heavily political.

His propaganda talks included scathing denunciations of the last pre-war democratic Czech President Eduard Benes and a fantasy about German and Irish soldiers paying tribute to Sir Roger Casement's grave.

But despite these latest revelations of anti-semitism and Hitler worship, Francis Stuart remains a Saoi or 'wise person', according to the Irish literary establishment.
fields.bodyText: New evidence has shown that the controversial Irish author Francis Stuart, who lived in Nazi Germany during the war, was anti-semitic. Stuart, who died last year aged 97, angrily denied the charge and won IR£100,000 in libel damages from the Irish Times. He also sued a magazine which printed a letter accusing him of being a Nazi. Now a new book on Stuart's writings and wartime broadcasts has shown that Stuart held anti-semitic opinions as far back as 1924. And those on the sharp end of the late writer's litigation are bitter that had the new evidence been available even 18 months ago they would not have had to pay damages. Stuart was the author of more than 30 novels and held the position of Saoi, the highest honour the Irish arts body, Aosdána, can bestow on an artist. He was born in Australia but returned to Ireland following the death of his father. As a young poet in the 1920s he married Iseult MacBride, daughter of Maude Gonne and sister of Sean MacBride. He was encouraged in his early poetry by Yeats. During the Irish Civil war he fought on the Republican side with de Valera and was taken prisoner by the Free State forces. In January 1940 he moved from his home in County Wicklow to Berlin, where he accepted a university lectureship. He stayed in Germany for the duration of the war and between 1942 and 1944 made more than 100 broadcasts to Ireland on German radio. The majority of his broadcasts were vehemently anti-Allies and called for Ireland to maintain its neutral stance in the global struggle against Nazism. As an ex-IRA member, Stuart also argued in his propaganda messages that a German victory would help bring about a united Ireland. Secretly, the author encouraged links between the Nazis and the IRA. None of Stuart's broadcasts contained any overt anti-semitic outbursts although there were warm tributes to Hitler and his regime. Decades after the war, Stuart's friends in Ireland used this apparent absence of anti-semitism to argue that the writer was really a hopeless apolitical romantic who fled to Germany as an act of personal rebellion. The Wartime Broadcasts of Francis Stuart, edited by Brendan Barrington, throws fresh light on the author's opinions of Jews. Barrington has discovered a 16-page IRA pamphlet Stuart wrote in March 1924 called Lecture on Nationality and Culture. In it Stuart compares the malign influence of England on Ireland to the power the Jews allegedly exercised over post-World War I Austria, a country he visited in 1921. 'At that time Vienna was full of Jews, who controlled the banks and factories and even a large part of the government; the Austrians themselves seemed about to be driven out of their own city.' Barrington also discovered a letter Stuart wrote to the Irish Times in 1938 - the same newspaper that 61 years later paid him IR£100,000 in costs and damages for daring to suggest he was anti-semitic - calling for Ireland to close its doors on refugees, including Jews fleeing Hitler's tyranny. The critic and novelist Colm Toibin, long a defender of Stuart, now accepts that Stuart 're-imagined' his own role in Nazi Germany after the war. In an article for this month's London Review of Books, Toibin states: 'The following facts are clearly established: Stuart supported Hitler, he had anti-semitic feelings, he broadcast extreme anti-British sentiments in the war, and he abandoned his family. He later evaded the truth about all of this.' But in another part of his 13,000-word article on Stuart and Barrington's book, Toibin says that the late author's 'primary interest was not politics'. 'He was a chronicler of his wounded and damaged self who also had these opinions.' Speaking from New York where he is a fellow at the Centre for Scholars and Writers, Toibin declined to elaborate on his view of Stuart's anti- semitism. But Kevin Myers, the Irish Times columnist whose articles on Stuart led to the libel action, said he was bitterly disappointed that newspapers were forced to pay out to 'this dreadful impostor'. He added: 'It's disgusting that we had to pay out such a sum to a man who obviously held deeply anti-semitic views and worshipped Hitler. At the time of the libel trial no one knew about the 1924 pamphlet or had discovered the 1938 letter. The award to this man was a grotesque miscarriage of justice. 'What's even more disturbing is to think about all those who defended this Jew hater and how they exalted him for so long in Ireland.' His defenders, who included the novelist Ulick O'Connor and the historian Anthony Cronin, say that the bulk of Stuart's work was not concerned with politics. But Barrington analyses the wartime broadcasts to prove that the overwhelming content of Stuart's output was heavily political. His propaganda talks included scathing denunciations of the last pre-war democratic Czech President Eduard Benes and a fantasy about German and Irish soldiers paying tribute to Sir Roger Casement's grave. But despite these latest revelations of anti-semitism and Hitler worship, Francis Stuart remains a Saoi or 'wise person', according to the Irish literary establishment.

webTitle: Book vending machines on the underground

fields.headline: Now it's stories on the underground
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The sight of peckish commuters thumping faulty chocolate dispensers is familiar enough. But from next week the vending machine on the station platform will also cater to those hungry for literature.
fields.body:
The sight of peckish commuters thumping faulty chocolate dispensers is familiar enough. But from next week the vending machine on the station platform will also cater to those hungry for literature.

The sons of two of Britain's most aristocratic families, the Guinnesses and the Waughs, are launching a system for dispensing short stories on the London Underground.

Alexander Waugh, the grandson of the novelist Evelyn Waugh, and Ned Iveagh, the Guinness heir, will introduce their prototype dispensers to selected stations on the Tube this month before expanding the enterprise across the British rail system.

The stories, published by Travelman, are printed on one sheet of paper and fold up like a map.

Authors available in the collection include P.G. Wodehouse, Dorothy Parker, Oscar Wilde and Katherine Mansfield and the series is edited by writers including Beryl Bainbridge and Martin Amis. Their fellow editors, Dame Muriel Spark and Irish novelist William Trevor, have even written stories especially for the imprint.

The first machines were installed last month on South Kensington station in West London, each book costing £1. The scheme, backed by Lord Iveagh's Trust, will be formally launched on 15 January.

The first vending machine, a sweet dispenser, was introduced to the Underground in 1886.

'Fortunately vending technology and design has moved on!' said a spokeswoman for Lord Iveagh.

The original idea for handy travel literature can be traced back to the turn of the last century when Rudyard Kipling introduced reading sheets to Indian Railways. Iveagh and Waugh have picked their moment well. The delays on British Rail mean commuters will need to buy more than one. The stories are between 7,000 and 12,000 words and will take only around 40 minutes to read.

webTitle: Comment: A past we'd rather forget

fields.headline: A past we'd rather forget
fields.trailText: In his brilliant 1989 essay 'The Beginning and the End of Totalitarianism', Czech novelist Ivan Klima, a Jewish intellectual who survived both the Nazi and Communist regimes that dominated his country for 51 years, warns about dictatorships. 'To people trapped in the greyness of everyday life, they offered a great ideal, as well as a charismatic leader who relieved them of the burden of having to decide for themselves and, moreover, led them towards a goal that gave their lives meaning.'
fields.body:
In his brilliant 1989 essay 'The Beginning and the End of Totalitarianism', Czech novelist Ivan Klima, a Jewish intellectual who survived both the Nazi and Communist regimes that dominated his country for 51 years, warns about dictatorships. 'To people trapped in the greyness of everyday life, they offered a great ideal, as well as a charismatic leader who relieved them of the burden of having to decide for themselves and, moreover, led them towards a goal that gave their lives meaning.'

Klima's warning comes to mind in the controversy over the late Irish novelist, Francis Stuart, who shortly after the outbreak of the Second World War, moved to Berlin where he remained serving the Third Reich's propaganda arm for the duration of the war.

Stuart's defenders have always sought to portray this weird literary figure as a non-political rebel, who fled to Germany simply to annoy polite liberal society rather than out of any admiration for Hitler. This nonsense has become one of the enduring myths of Irish literature in what has been an enormous collective act of intellectual self-delusion.

The myth has finally been shattered thanks to a new book edited by Brendan Barrington. The key revelations (amplified elsewhere in this paper today) are that Stuart held anti-Semitic opinions long before he went to Germany and that he supported Hitler. Barrington has unearthed an IRA pamphlet Stuart wrote in 1924 in which he hopes that Ireland can liberate itself from Britain just as Austria must cast off the influence of money-obsessed Jews. The novelist is also found to have nursed a deep loathing of liberal democracy. No doubt for Stuart, Hitler's rule was, in contrast, 'magically effective'.

However, Stuart's twisted power-worship illuminates a wider malaise that has afflicted Irish intellectuals and rebels for the past 60 years. It is a phenomenon that has coloured the lives of writers and artists such as W.B. Yeats and his youthful flirtation with Maude Gonne's dreadful circle of anti-Semitic, mystical European nationalists. Republican radicals from the Left and the Right have worshipped regimes such as Nazi Germany, Soviet Union, East Germany and Colonel Gadaffi's Libya. For the Left, it was a case of transferred nationalism, moving from Mother Ireland to the Socialist Motherland. On the Right, it was more to do with searching for friends across the sea, any friends, who happened to hate the Brits as well.

Stuart's Berlin sojourn and his role in fostering links between the IRA and the Nazis sheds light on a dark corner of Irish history. In the1940s, the IRA was allied to one of the most evil regimes in human history. Had they succeeded in their goal of uniting Ireland on the back of a Nazi victory, every man, woman and child would have become vassals of the Nazi empire. And, as Micheal Burleigh emphasises in his outstanding book on the Third Reich, Hitler planned to eliminate the Jews of Ireland as part of his maniacal project to destroy entirely the Jewish people.

Yet this collaboration with Nazism is rarely mentioned in the traditional nationalist narratives of the twentieth century. There are plenty of rousing, red-banner ballads to the handful of IRA volunteers who fought for the Spanish Republic; there are none commemorating the exploits of the likes of Sean Russell, the Nazi-collaborating IRA leader who died on a German submarine.

My paternal grandfather drowned in the Atlantic after a U-boat torpedoed his ship in March 1943. Like thousands of other Irishmen who fought on the right side in the war, Henry McDonald left behind a young widow still in her early twenties and four small children, the youngest 10 months old.

Colm Toibin reflects on the latter years of Francis Stuart's life: 'He lived at that time in Dundrum in the suburbs of Dublin and he had settled, it seemed, into an extremely mellow and happy old age.'

Some guys, it seems, have all the luck - even when they sided with the dregs of humanity.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Who's the fittest of them all?
fields.body:
Who's the fittest of them all?

The Mirror is on a health kick. 'It's the start of another new year, and we've all made resolutions to lead healthier lives.' So it's wheeled in leading health experts such as, erm, Carol Vorderman to help us shed booze 'n' pudding-induced flab. Health tips for 2001 tell us to 'reduce alcohol intake'. But as we all know, temptation is just a drink away and to remind us - in the middle of an eight-page Health Zone supplement - is a reader offer to cross the Channel and fill your boot with beer and fags for £25. The health-conscious Mirror will throw in a case of lager and a bottle of whisky into the bargain. Now that's what we call a detox.

Nursed grievance

Well done the Journalist, in-house mag for the NUJ. Never one to miss a fat cat story, it was quick to draw attention to a heartfelt piece in one of the local London papers owned by the Dimbleby brothers. How on earth, the piece demanded, can nurses afford to live in the capital when they are paid paltry salaries - as little as £15,000 a year. This must be a particularly vexing question for hacks who work for the Dimbleby Group - starting salary for reporters is a whopping £7,000 a year.

Scots missed

Here's a rarity in Scottish newspapers. Business am, the fledgling financial and political daily launched late last year by the Swedish Bonnier group, is to up its cover price by 10p to 70p tomorrow. Although the Scottish newspaper market is one of the most cutthroat in the world, the newcomer feels no obligation to follow its rivals by slashing its price.

It says that with a circulation nearly 11,000 - ahead of its target - it feels confident that its readers will pay that bit more. Scotsman supremo Andrew Neil has pledged to blow the paper out of the water. So far it's Swedes One, Brillo Nil.

webTitle: An OK! way to Express goodbye

fields.headline: An OK! way to Express goodbye
fields.standfirst:
By yesterday afternoon, 14 letters in a five-paragraph article about the joys of free range tomatoes in the Daily Express was the talk of the media, the Cabinet and even Buckingham Palace.
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the Express takeover
fields.trailText: By yesterday afternoon, 14 letters in a five-paragraph article about the joys of free range tomatoes in the Daily Express was the talk of the media, the Cabinet and even Buckingham Palace.
fields.body:
It was only 14 letters buried in the heart of an obscure editorial about the joys of free range tomatoes. Only the most sharp-eyed readers would have spotted it. But by yesterday afternoon a five-paragraph article in the Daily Express was the talk of the media, the Cabinet and even Buckingham Palace.

'Let organic farms flourish' contained a hidden but unmistakable message. The first letter of each sentence spelt out F-u-c-k-y-o-u-D-e-s-m-o-n-d. It was the kind of message the combative Richard Desmond, new owner of the Express, would have been proud of - if it were not in his own paper.

Desmond, who also publishes OK! and top-shelf titles including Big, Black and Forty Plus, bought the Express in November prompting a wave of departures among senior staff who fear the new boss will drag the paper down market.

Yesterday's article is thought to have been penned by chief editorial writer Stephen Pollard. He quit on Friday to join the Times .

The story cheered staff. 'With the number of people rushing for the exit over the next few weeks Desmond is going to be permanently bent over the news pages checking out every story,' said one.

webTitle: The secret loves of H.G. Wells unmasked

fields.headline: The secret loves of H.G. Wells unmasked
fields.standfirst: A cache of previously suppressed material gives new details on the affairs of an unlikely Don Juan of the literary Thirties
fields.trailText: A cache of previously suppressed material gives new details on the affairs of an unlikely Don Juan of the literary Thirties.
fields.body:
The secret love life of H.G. Wells, the titan of the early 20th-century literary world who was courted by politicians and statesmen throughout the world, was more complicated and controversial than the world has dared imagine.

Thanks to a six-year investigation and the discovery of a treasure trove of previously suppressed material, a new book about to be published in the United States will prove that the writer's greatest love was a spy who relayed information revealed by his friends back to Russia with his knowledge. It will also reveal the identities of two previously unknown lovers, one of whom strenuously denied the love affair until the end of her life.

In Shadow Lovers: The Last Affairs of H.G. Wells , author Andrea Lynn reveals how Moura Budberg, the Russian baroness who captured Wells's heart in the early 1930s, pretended to be in love with Wells to gain unfettered access to his wide and politically elevated circle of friends.

Lynn also suggests that it was Budberg's influence that led to the meeting between Stalin and Wells, George Bernard Shaw, and Beatrice and Sidney Webb in 1934, after which the British visitors publicly praised the dictator and the Communist philosophy.

'Moura may also have been involved in counter-espionage,' said Lynn. 'It's impossible to tell exactly what was going on, because all her papers and files were destroyed in a convenient house fire, but from Wells's suppressed letters it's clear that something was happening and that, although he knew about it, his love for her made him powerless to leave or expose her.'

The bouncy little man whose tiny hands and squeaky voice belied his success as the Don Juan of the intelligentsia, was loved by legions of beautiful women throughout his life, one of whom credited his phenomenal pulling power to the fact that his body smelt irresistably of honey.

In an attempt to come clean about his amoratory experiences, Wells started work on his second autobiography, H.G. Wells in Love: Postscript to an Experiment in Autobiography, in 1934, immediately after the publication of his Experiment in Autobiography: Discoveries and Conclusions of a Very Ordinary Brain (Since 1866) .

While his first autobiography steered clear of Wells's lively sex life, he used the second manuscript to explore his sexual adventures in detail.

'I have done what I pleased, so that every bit of sexual impulse in me has expressed itself,' he admitted in the book. 'This is my intimate diary and the story of my amatory life.'

In accordance with his wishes that the exposé would remain unpublished until after both his death and the deaths of the women concerned, Wells's eldest son and chief editor, George Wells, held the manuscript back until 1984, 38 years after Wells's death and a year after the death of Rebecca West, the mother of Wells's illegitimate son, Anthony West.

Before the manuscript was finally published, George Wells excised large chunks of the text, including the names and details of two of Wells's last lovers, and his suspicions about Budberg's activities.

'H.G. had been extremely candid [in his second autobiography], though not X-rated,' said Lynn. 'The heirs, however, played it cautiously, their actions prompted by courtesy and concern over litigation. As well as removing pages and excising entire stories, the heirs also held back a huge cache of letters of a personal nature that H.G. received over the decades from the many women in his life '

In 1994 the Wells family sold the unexpurgated manuscript and more than 500 letters to the H.G. Wells Collection at the University of Illinois Library, but although Lynn - at the time a journalist attached to the university - publicised the sale, no Wellsian scholar came forward to investigate the contents of the collection.

'I couldn't believe that no one seemed interested,' she said. 'Then I suddenly remembered that I was a writer and researcher in my own right.

'What I have discovered blew me away. For six years I have managed to keep the things I have discovered secret. The effort was phenomenal: what I have uncovered will scandalise the literary world and change the face of Wellsian scholarship.'

Wells was 68 and married to Jane, his second wife, when he met Moura Budberg. 'I think I have really loved only three women steadfastly,' he wrote in the Postscript . 'My first wife, my second wife and Moura Budberg.'

But in letters to his close friend, Christabel McLaren, which have been suppressed for almost 70 years, Wells referred to 'the faint aroma of espionage of Moura's world in Berlin and Paris and Knightsbridge'.

'I'm tired, I'm bored by a Moura who...rambles round corners & for all I know is a spy. I'm not going to be trailed,' he complained, referring to the interest the French government had developed in Moura's activities.

'She flits away to her old familiar gossips at 88 Knightsbridge, and to Berlin and Paris and Warsaw - and maybe even Moscow,' he added.

Two years after the death of Wells's second wife in 1927, Budberg came to England and she and Wells resumed their affair. Although she refused to marry him - proving, according to her friends still alive today, that she was no spy - Lynn maintains that she refused to marry Wells because she was already in love with the British agent in Moscow, Bruce Lockhart.

'Although marriage to him would have given her the perfect protection, her relationship with Wells was work,' she said.

According to further passages removed from Wells's original draft of his Postscript, his affair with Budberg was still in full fettle when he began his affair with Constance Coolidge and, less than a year later, with the 26-year-old Martha Gellhorn, 'relationships which have been totally unknown except to a few members of the family'.

Wells met the American-born Coolidge, a French countess, in the South of France towards the end of 1934. Three of the nine pages Wells devoted to Coolidge in his Postscript were cut by his son, leaving no reference to her parents, husbands or lovers.

Coolidge, who died in 1973, was devoted to Wells; alone among his lovers, Lynn believes, she offered him a disinterested and sincere affection. But the discovery that will scandalise the literary world is that when Martha Ellis Gellhorn and the 68-year-old Wells met over a meal at the Roosevelts' residence in 1935, they began a passionate affair that could have ended in marriage.

Throughout her life, Gellhorn steadfastly denied rumours of an affair. 'I was probably the last journalist to speak to Martha before her death in 1998, and she told me again and again that there was nothing but friendship between them,' said Lynn.

In pages suppressed from the Postscript, Wells is adamant that he and Gellhorn - who later married Ernest Hemingway not only became lovers but discussed marriage. 'We had a very happy time together, making love, talking and reading,' he wrote in one suppressed passage.

'I was quite definitely in love with her at the time and she with me. We discussed our future relationship but felt the manifest incompatibility of our ages.'

The truth and extent of Budberg's espionage activities will probably never be known, but Gellhorn's letters to Wells - the missing piece of the jigsaw - were deposited at Boston University after her death. They will remain sealed until 2023, 25 years after her death.

'Until that day, we won't know for certain what the truth of their story is,' said Lynn. 'Investigating this has been like peeling back the layers of an onion: I could have gone on forever, but I had to stop somewhere.'

'H.G. had been extremely candid [in his second autobiography], though not X-rated,' said Lynn. 'The heirs, however, played it cautiously, their actions prompted by courtesy and concern over litigation. As well as removing pages and excising entire stories, the heirs also held back a huge cache of letters of a personal nature that H.G. received over the decades from the many women in his life ' In 1994 the Wells family sold the unexpurgated manuscript and more than 500 letters to the H.G. Wells Collection at the University of Illinois Library, but although Lynn - at the time a journalist attached to the university - publicised the sale, no Wellsian scholar came forward to investigate the contents of the collection. 'I couldn't believe that no one seemed interested,' she said. 'Then I suddenly remembered that I was a writer and researcher in my own right. 'What I have discovered blew me away. For six years I have managed to keep the things I have discovered secret. The effort was phenomenal: what I have uncovered will scandalise the literary world and change the face of Wellsian scholarship.' Wells was 68 and married to Jane, his second wife, when he met Moura Budberg. 'I think I have really loved only three women steadfastly,' he wrote in the Postscript . 'My first wife, my second wife and Moura Budberg.' But in letters to his close friend, Christabel McLaren, which have been suppressed for almost 70 years, Wells referred to 'the faint aroma of espionage of Moura's world in Berlin and Paris and Knightsbridge'. 'I'm tired, I'm bored by a Moura who...rambles round corners & for all I know is a spy. I'm not going to be trailed,' he complained, referring to the interest the French government had developed in Moura's activities. 'She flits away to her old familiar gossips at 88 Knightsbridge, and to Berlin and Paris and Warsaw - and maybe even Moscow,' he added. Two years after the death of Wells's second wife in 1927, Budberg came to England and she and Wells resumed their affair. Although she refused to marry him - proving, according to her friends still alive today, that she was no spy - Lynn maintains that she refused to marry Wells because she was already in love with the British agent in Moscow, Bruce Lockhart. 'Although marriage to him would have given her the perfect protection, her relationship with Wells was work,' she said. According to further passages removed from Wells's original draft of his Postscript, his affair with Budberg was still in full fettle when he began his affair with Constance Coolidge and, less than a year later, with the 26-year-old Martha Gellhorn, 'relationships which have been totally unknown except to a few members of the family'. Wells met the American-born Coolidge, a French countess, in the South of France towards the end of 1934. Three of the nine pages Wells devoted to Coolidge in his Postscript were cut by his son, leaving no reference to her parents, husbands or lovers. Coolidge, who died in 1973, was devoted to Wells; alone among his lovers, Lynn believes, she offered him a disinterested and sincere affection. But the discovery that will scandalise the literary world is that when Martha Ellis Gellhorn and the 68-year-old Wells met over a meal at the Roosevelts' residence in 1935, they began a passionate affair that could have ended in marriage. Throughout her life, Gellhorn steadfastly denied rumours of an affair. 'I was probably the last journalist to speak to Martha before her death in 1998, and she told me again and again that there was nothing but friendship between them,' said Lynn. In pages suppressed from the Postscript, Wells is adamant that he and Gellhorn - who later married Ernest Hemingway not only became lovers but discussed marriage. 'We had a very happy time together, making love, talking and reading,' he wrote in one suppressed passage. 'I was quite definitely in love with her at the time and she with me. We discussed our future relationship but felt the manifest incompatibility of our ages.' The truth and extent of Budberg's espionage activities will probably never be known, but Gellhorn's letters to Wells - the missing piece of the jigsaw - were deposited at Boston University after her death. They will remain sealed until 2023, 25 years after her death. 'Until that day, we won't know for certain what the truth of their story is,' said Lynn. 'Investigating this has been like peeling back the layers of an onion: I could have gone on forever, but I had to stop somewhere.' amelia.hill@observer.co.uk Useful links www.rdg.ac.uk The H.G. webTitle: Did mob author die for writing what she knew?

fields.headline: Did mob author die for writing what she knew?
fields.standfirst: Mystery surrounds the execution-style murder of a gangster's daughter
fields.trailText: Mystery surrounds the execution-style murder of a gangster's daughter.
fields.body:
Susan Berman - the author of Easy Street, crime novelist and screenwriter with a kindly smile - died like a character from one of her own books or movies: murdered by a single shot to the back of the head. By the time her body was found on Christmas Eve, she had been dead two days.

But the chilling twist to Berman's death is that she was probably killed because she was a character from one of her own books. Berman knew too much about her subject - the Las Vegas mafia - because she was herself a child of the mob.

Now, it seemed, she had mixed fact and fiction too much for her family's liking - or that of its rivals.

She had been killed with a small-calibre handgun and there was no sign of a break-in at her home in luxurious Benedict Canyon, in Beverly Hills. Her body was only found because neighbours spotted her dogs running loose.

Detective Brad Roberts of the LAPD said: 'It looked like the target of the murder was her.' A mob hit? 'We have to look at every angle, of course.'

Susan Berman learned how to count in casinos. Her childhood was lived among the mobsters and gangsters who turned a desert strip town into the phantasmagoria of Las Vegas.

They arranged for Elvis Presley and Liberace to sing at her birthday parties. Berman was buried beside her father, David Berman. He was a Vegas mafia kingpin in an iron triangle which also included the infamous Bugsy Siegel and Meyer Lansky.

Berman and Siegel ran the Flamingo Hotel in Vegas, the trailblazer for the gambling empire, featuring Sinatra singing at an opening night - also on Christmas Eve, in 1946. Berman took it over single-handed after Siegel was shot the following year in Beverly Hills, a short distance from Susan Berman's home.

This was the childhood Susan Berman, a former journalist, plundered in order to write her books and screenplays, and produce television documentaries about the heady and hedonistic days of the Vegas boom in the 1940s and 50s. The most celebrated books were Easy Street, in 1981 - which was about her father - and Lady Las Vegas. Her movies for television included Las Vegas: House of Cards.

Berman had cut his teeth arranging the first of the spate of kidnappings for ransom in New York during the prohibition 1920s. He was described as 'so tough he could kill a man with one hand tied behind his back'.

He, Siegel and Lansky were gangsters from a mainly Jewish syndicate which pioneered the development of a sleepy desert cow town. After turning Vegas into a goldmine, they rapidly found themselves in an uneasy alliance with the famous Bonnanno clan when the Cosa Nostra firms moved in for the pickings.

The triad had little option: Vegas became the prize in a prolonged and ferocious war between New York's mafia families and those from Chicago, led by the equally fierce Accardo clan. It was a war between the inheritors of the legacy of Al Capone and Lucky Luciano; Siegel had been connected with Luciano.

Berman died a natural death in 1957 when his daughter was 12; her mother committed suicide a year later.

But Siegel was murdered in Los Angeles because the mafia there was and still is allied to Capone and Chicago - a fact that has no doubt not escaped the investigators into Susan Berman's death.

Of her murder, an unnamed 'entertainment industry executive' told the UPI news agency: 'I heard initially that she was doing a tell-all and naming names and stuff. I think the mob got tired of hearing about her.'

Susan Berman, who was 55, lived an intensely private life - there was a brief marriage in the 1980s about which she never spoke, and she raised the two children of a boyfriend of 13 years ago; they preferred to stay with her after the couple broke up.

One of those children, Sareb Kaufman - with whom she would dine twice a week - said that she had 'complicated fears' and 'lived cautiously'. Among her worries was an acute fear of heights - she would not go above the ground level of a building without being accompanied by someone she trusted.

Kaufman last saw her when he set off for a holiday in Europe a week before Christmas. 'She was happy. She had a couple of new possibilities,' he said, among which was a memoir about high-rolling female gamblers in Vegas. 'You just ask yourself,' he said of her murder, 'why and how?'

Her manager, Nyle Brenner, said that he did not know 'if there was anything she was working on that had any relevance to the current mafia,' but confirmed that she was still mining her past for 'several other projects' when she was killed.

'She had been talking to a lot of people in Vegas recently,' added Brenner, 'People who had a past'. Among the current projects was a proposed television documentary about the Vegas underworld, focusing on women, a pitch to ABC television for a movie based on her diaries and a series being developed by Showtime called Sin City .

Brenner quickly joined a chorus of friends and relatives who deny that the writer's death at the hand of an otherwise apparently motiveless killer had any connection to the mob.

'Whoever committed this act of violence,' said the dead woman's cousin, Deni Marcus, 'maybe they did it this way to make it look suspicious. To keep people guessing at some silly notion.'
