webTitle: Radiohead: BBC has exiled adult music

fields.headline: Radiohead: BBC has exiled adult music
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Radiohead - the British rock band who have topped the album charts on both sides of the Atlantic - have attacked the BBC for keeping their music off the air.
fields.body:
Radiohead - the British rock band who have topped the album charts on both sides of the Atlantic - have attacked the BBC for keeping their music off the air.

The reclusive Oxford-based band have criticised the 'safe' music that is commercially successful in this country and called for BBC radio to take up the challenge of their work.

At best, they say, guitar music is now of 'average standard' and yet it takes up so much playtime that Radiohead are often 'excluded'.

The comments were made by Colin and Jonny Greenwood, the band's bassist and guitarist, during an interview for the BBC's own Mixing It, a contemporary music show on Radio 3. Their contentious views are unlikely to make it into the final edit of the programme which goes out on 20 January.

The Greenwood brothers' complaints echo those of other British rock stars who spoke out last autumn about their dissatisfaction with the 'phoney' world of pop music. Last October George Michael blamed the corporate takeover of youth culture for the 'rubbish' acts.

He was promptly backed by Bono of U2, who criticised Steps and said people were 'sick to the teeth of processed and hyped pop bands. It's crap'. Even Blur weighed in to call chart music 'a load of shite'.

Jonny Greenwood talks about the 'series of kickings' that Radiohead's recent album, Kid A, initially received from British critics. Despite this it sold 55,000 copies in its first day in the shops and then went in at No 1 in the US Billboard charts - the first time in three years a British act had done so.

The experimental Radiohead album, which has been branded 'difficult' even by its fans, was also nominated last week for Grammy Awards in four categories.

But, in this country, the Greenwoods argue that radio station 'demographics' are preventing serious rock music from being heard. 'I heard the controller of Radio 1 say the demographic for their station is now 14 or 15 to 25, so I think we are kind of excluded. It is getting harder for our music to be heard,' said Colin Greenwood.

'It is the nature of the times we are in,' the Cambridge-educated musician adds. 'Other artists of considerable stature launched albums in the past few months only to see them drop out of the top twenties and thirties two weeks later.'

Radio 1 says it simply has a commitment to new sounds. But Radiohead's harsh words come at a time when the BBC is facing up to a huge gap in its range of targeted audiences. The corporation now has no radio station which is aimed at rock and pop music-lovers in their late twenties and thirties.

While Radio 2 has adopted an increasingly youthward path by introducing Jonathan Ross, Jools Holland, Mark Lamarr and Steve Wright as presenters, its lower audience age profile still only reaches down to those in their late 40s. Last summer Radio 2 schedulers commissioned a series about punk rock in an effort to confound expectations. Hosted by the former Sex Pistol, Glen Matlock, and called Anarchy In the UK, it was a hit with younger listeners.

So it is Radio 3, the classical music station, that is left to make the BBC's most positive moves towards listeners in their thirties. The station was quick to pick up the world music presenter Andy Kershaw when he was edged out of Radio 1 last year.

'The difficulty is that age profiling is a fairly crude way of working out your listenership. After all, rock itself is around 50 years old now anyway,' Kershaw said.

'I know my old show on Radio 1 had a wide age range of listeners and I hope the BBC will return to the idea of surprising its audiences a little.'

Kershaw's new show on Radio 3 starts in April and is part of a concerted drive to add more jazz and world music to its schedule. The BBC's controller of Radio and Music, Jenny Abramsky, plans to launch five additional digital networks this year and one of them, which is codenamed Network Y, is to be devoted to this missing age group, the thirty-somethings or Generation Y.

'I imagine that Radiohead will be right at the core of this new digital station's playlist,' said a spokeswoman for Radio 2.

The rare Radiohead interview on Mixing It was the result of the Greenwood brothers' enthusiasm for the programme. They wanted to talk about the wider musical influences on their work. The jazz of Charlie Mingus and the sound of the harpist Alice Coltrane are both listed as providing inspiration for tracks on Kid A as well as on the next album to be released, Amnesiac, which was recorded at the same time.

A spokesman for Radio 1 argues that the band has no reason to feel excluded. 'We have actually made far more room for Radiohead than the commercial stations have, so it seems unfair that we have been picked out,' a spokesman said. 'Both Radiohead and U2 had major live performances on Radio 1 last year and Radiohead had unprecedented exposure.'

The station's attention to dance music trends merely reflects changes in musical tastes, he said.

vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

webTitle: I get a kick out of kung fu

fields.headline: I get a kick out of kung fu
fields.standfirst: The fight scenes in Ang Lee's Chinese epic are breathtaking in their beauty - even when the men join in
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...what makes it an exciting kinetic experience in the cinema is the epic sweep, the contrast between the serene beauty of the settings and the astonishing action sequences
fields.body:
There has never been a career quite like that of Ang Lee, although the chances are there will be similar ones during this coming century. Born in Taiwan of mainland Chinese parents, he studied film in the States and over the past decade has built up a coherent oeuvre while making films in a variety of genres on three continents, working as happily in English as in Chinese.

He first made his mark in 1993 with The Wedding Banquet, a comedy about a young gay New York property dealer entering into a marriage of convenience to please his traditionalist Taiwanese parents. Lee then returned to Taiwan for Eat Drink Man Woman, about a celebrity cook and his rebellious children, before coming to England to direct Emma Thompson in Sense and Sensibility, the best of all Jane Austen adaptations.

This was followed by The Ice Storm, a study in the Updike manner of middle-class New England exurban life in the morally confused early 1970s, and a superb western, Ride With the Devil, set during the American Civil War. Now he's turned to the most popular of all Oriental genres, the martial arts film, with the entrancing Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, made on location in China with leading Hong Kong actors.

Lee's films share a stylistic sophistication, a narrative flow, a feeling for the big set-piece and a concern for language. But what binds these apparently diverse works together is the consistency with which he pursues certain key themes. These include the rewards and restrictions of family life, the necessity of breaking with relations and traditions to establish your own identity, and the deceptive nature of reality, which leads us into misreading the world around us.

He brings a certain formality or reticence to the task and always locates the action in a precise society, usually one in a state of transition, whether it be Jane Austen's England or an America torn apart by the Civil War. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is set during the Qing Dynasty, a period in the early nineteenth century before the European commercial invasion that is regarded as something of a golden age. The title refers to an old Chinese proverb about people concealing their real identities - vulnerability in a strong man, assertiveness in a meek woman - and all the characters have hidden selves or suppressed desires.

A complicated (at times confusing) plot turns on two pairs of lovers. The nationally celebrated warrior Li Mu Bai (handsome Chow Yun-Fat) cannot declare his love for Yu Shu Lien (the beautiful Michelle Yeoh), his female counterpart and fellow subscriber to the ancient chivalric code laid down in the manual of Wudan. A decade or more younger than this poised couple are another charismatic pair, Jen (Zhang Ziyi) and Lo (Chang Chen). Jen is the rebellious daughter of a noble family, Lo is a bandit leader living in a cave in the desert, and they've secretly become lovers.

Jen, however, has been trained as a martial artist by Jade Fox, an evil villainess, who has taught her the Wudan system of combat, but not the ethical code that should accompany it. Jade Fox has murdered Li's spiritual master, and on her behalf Lo steals a fabulous 400-year-old sword called Green Destiny that belonged to Li and should only be wielded by an honourable warrior. This weapon, described as 'strong but supple - the way to rule', becomes a central matter of contention.

The story is not without significance and the film has considerable moral power. There are parallels with our own Arthurian legend and various other mythic echoes, though it never becomes an eclectic confection like Star Wars. But what makes it an exciting kinetic experience in the cinema is the epic sweep, the contrast between the serene beauty of the settings and the astonishing action sequences.

Preferring the marshal acts of lawmen with their feet on the ground in the West to the martial arts of athletes leaping around in the East, I've never been a devotee of kung-fu pictures. I like my karate in short, isolated bursts - Spencer Tracy taking on Ernest Borgnine in Bad Day at Black Rock, for instance, or Frank Sinatra engaging with Henry Silva in The Manchurian Candidate. Until now, the only martial arts picture I've really loved is King Hu's classic A Touch of Zen (1969), but the fights in Ang Lee's film are breathtaking in their beauty.

These action sequences are choreographed by Yuen Wo Ping, who staged the chases and battles in Jackie Chan's Hong Kong flicks, and more recently worked in America on The Matrix. Though long drawn out, they never get tedious and each is quite different in character and contributes to the dramatic development. As in dreams, the combatants defy gravity, flying through the air, running up walls, quite literally floating like butterflies and stinging like bees.

Four of these fights stand out. In the first, a masked Jen steals the Green Destiny sword and (resembling the young female cat burglar in Hitchcock's To Catch a Thief) is chased through the night over the rooftops of Beijing by the older woman, Yu. The two later have a graceful fight indoors for possession of the sword.

In the film's last big fight, Jen fights in a forest of giant bamboo trees with the mature warrior, Yi, a scene with echoes of the climactic confrontation between the good and bad brothers who conduct a moral argument as they exchange gunfire in Anthony Mann's Winchester 73. But as they bounce from the top of one tree to another swinging their lethal swords, it seems as if we're looking at Nijinsky playing a combination of Tarzan and D'Artagnan.

Jen has another scene, as cleverly staged as the others, but wonderfully comic, in which she takes on a succession of overweight braggarts in a country inn. They underestimate her martial skills as much as they overrate their own and they end up in tatters and the inn is demolished. It's a fight that would have won the admiration of John Ford. One mentions Ford, but his women stood by and watched as their men went into action. Few westerns have provided female roles like the ones so confidently played here by Michelle Yeoh and Zhang Ziyi, and it could be argued that no western has provided so persuasive a context.

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is the first foreign language picture for many years to get a sizeable release in British cinemas, and the first ever to do so in a non-European language. One wishes Lee's film well because it deserves to be popular and if successful, it might encourage distributors and audiences in the direction of greater boldness.

The title refers to an old Chinese proverb about people concealing their real identities - vulnerability in a strong man, assertiveness in a meek woman - and all the characters have hidden selves or suppressed desires. A complicated (at times confusing) plot turns on two pairs of lovers. The nationally celebrated warrior Li Mu Bai (handsome Chow Yun-Fat) cannot declare his love for Yu Shu Lien (the beautiful Michelle Yeoh), his female counterpart and fellow subscriber to the ancient chivalric code laid down in the manual of Wudan. A decade or more younger than this poised couple are another charismatic pair, Jen (Zhang Ziyi) and Lo (Chang Chen). Jen is the rebellious daughter of a noble family, Lo is a bandit leader living in a cave in the desert, and they've secretly become lovers. Jen, however, has been trained as a martial artist by Jade Fox, an evil villainess, who has taught her the Wudan system of combat, but not the ethical code that should accompany it. Jade Fox has murdered Li's spiritual master, and on her behalf Lo steals a fabulous 400-year-old sword called Green Destiny that belonged to Li and should only be wielded by an honourable warrior. This weapon, described as 'strong but supple - the way to rule', becomes a central matter of contention. The story is not without significance and the film has considerable moral power. There are parallels with our own Arthurian legend and various other mythic echoes, though it never becomes an eclectic confection like Star Wars. But what makes it an exciting kinetic experience in the cinema is the epic sweep, the contrast between the serene beauty of the settings and the astonishing action sequences. Preferring the marshal acts of lawmen with their feet on the ground in the West to the martial arts of athletes leaping around in the East, I've never been a devotee of kung-fu pictures. I like my karate in short, isolated bursts - Spencer Tracy taking on Ernest Borgnine in Bad Day at Black Rock, for instance, or Frank Sinatra engaging with Henry Silva in The Manchurian Candidate. Until now, the only martial arts picture I've really loved is King Hu's classic A Touch of Zen (1969), but the fights in Ang Lee's film are breathtaking in their beauty. These action sequences are choreographed by Yuen Wo Ping, who staged the chases and battles in Jackie Chan's Hong Kong flicks, and more recently worked in America on The Matrix. Though long drawn out, they never get tedious and each is quite different in character and contributes to the dramatic development. As in dreams, the combatants defy gravity, flying through the air, running up walls, quite literally floating like butterflies and stinging like bees. Four of these fights stand out. In the first, a masked Jen steals the Green Destiny sword and (resembling the young female cat burglar in Hitchcock's To Catch a Thief) is chased through the night over the rooftops of Beijing by the older woman, Yu. The two later have a graceful fight indoors for possession of the sword. In the film's last big fight, Jen fights in a forest of giant bamboo trees with the mature warrior, Yi, a scene with echoes of the climactic confrontation between the good and bad brothers who conduct a moral argument as they exchange gunfire in Anthony Mann's Winchester 73. But as they bounce from the top of one tree to another swinging their lethal swords, it seems as if we're looking at Nijinsky playing a combination of Tarzan and D'Artagnan. Jen has another scene, as cleverly staged as the others, but wonderfully comic, in which she takes on a succession of overweight braggarts in a country inn. They underestimate her martial skills as much as they overrate their own and they end up in tatters and the inn is demolished. It's a fight that would have won the admiration of John Ford. One mentions Ford, but his women stood by and watched as their men went into action. Few westerns have provided female roles like the ones so confidently played here by Michelle Yeoh and Zhang Ziyi, and it could be argued that no western has provided so persuasive a context. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is the first foreign language picture for many years to get a sizeable release in British cinemas, and the first ever to do so in a non-European language. One wishes Lee's film well because it deserves to be popular and if successful, it might encourage distributors and audiences in the direction of greater boldness.

fields.headline: What a lucky Soderbergh
fields.standfirst: Actors clamour to work with him and he's loved by  mainstream and arthouse. Surely an Oscar can't be far away, suggests Mark Morris. Now Hollywood's other Steven is launching his most ambitious film
fields.trailText: Actors clamour to work with him and he's loved by mainstream and arthouse. Surely an Oscar can't be far away, suggests Mark Morris. Now Hollywood's other Steven is launching his most ambitious film.
fields.body:
In the subtitle to his book, Getting Away With It, Steven Soderbergh refers to himself as the 'luckiest bastard you ever saw'. Right now, it would be hard to disagree. The stars love him. 'I want to be in all of his movies,' Julia Roberts said recently. His partner in the production company Section Eight is George Clooney. And his next film, the Rat Pack remake, Ocean's Eleven, is set to star Clooney, Roberts, Brad Pitt, Matt Damon and Ralph Fiennes.

Meanwhile, Soderbergh's biggest competition at this year's Oscars may well be himself: both Erin Brockovich and his new film, Traffic, are contenders and both have picked up Golden Globe nominations for best picture and best director. The New York Times critic A.O. Scott wrote of Traffic: 'A director who began his career with a deft chamber piece has now at last attempted a symphony. Is it a populist art film or an especially arty popular movie? Is Mr Soderbergh an independent who has infiltrated Hollywood, or was he always a mainstream director in maverick's clothing? Such questions are based on rather wobbly distinctions, the kind Mr Soderbergh, early on, seemed likely to uphold. Now, at the top of his game, he may help to abolish them, which would be good news indeed.'

'The last time a filmmaker released two films in a year this way was Steven Spielberg when he did Jurassic Park and Schindler's List,' points out Faber & Faber's Walter Donohue, who edited Getting Away With It. 'It is very rare. It has to do with the mastery Steven now has with the cinematic medium, and also his mastery of working with actors.'

Four years ago, things couldn't have been more different. Soderbergh was widely regarded as a busted flush, a prodigy who was never going to repeat the shock success of his debut, sex, lies, and videotape, having followed it with a string of interesting flops. He was struggling to get any distributor to take his micro-budgeted, bizarre and autobiographical Schizopolis, and locked in litigation over his attempt to film John Kennedy Toole's cult novel, Confederacy of Dunces. His personal life was a shambles, the split with his wife, actress Betsy Brantley, possibly accelerated by having her and their daughter appear in Schizopolis.

Since then, he has managed a miraculous return to grace, balancing a growing contacts book with an uncompromising reputation. He followed Out Of Sight, the Clooney-Jennifer Lopez romantic thriller that revived his career, with the supremely fractured revenge movie, The Limey, in which Terence Stamp talks almost entirely in rhyming slang. After Ocean's Eleven will come Son of Schizopolis ('I just thought it would be great to take a film that no one's seen and make a sequel').

And then there's Traffic. Superficially, it might seem a solid commercial venture, with a cast including Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones. But this examination of the war on drugs - loosely based on a Channel 4 mini-series - starts in the Mexican desert, with subtitled conversations and much confusion. The film is shot entirely with handheld cameras, lasts 2 hours 20 and has dozens of characters. The audience's main guide is visual: the three storylines are filmed through different coloured filters. It covers the spectrum of the drugs war, from Washington cocktail parties (featuring real politicians expounding their real positions) to big houses bought with drug profits to crack houses and informal torture chambers south of the border.

It is a massively ambitious film, a piece of fiction filled with real incidents, real statistics and real people. Gary Ross, who wrote and directed Pleasantville, which Soderbergh produced, says: 'Traffic is so good it's being drawn to the attention of a lot of people who wouldn't see that kind of movie. I think this a perfect fusion of form and content. Steven has disappeared more and more into naturalism, removing all marks of the filmmaker.'

Traffic links back to the political cinema of the Sixties and Seventies. In its combination of radical form and content, it is reminiscent of Medium Cool and, most of all, The Battle of Algiers. Like Pontecorvo's revolutionary classic, Traffic has both a broad scope and a sharp immediacy. With other filmmakers, these comparisons would be speculative, but Soderbergh is the biggest film buff among current American directors, a man who actually described The Limey as 'Alain Resnais directing Get Carter'.

There are lots of curious things about Soderbergh's biography, not least that he comes from the South - born in Atlanta (1963) and raised in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, after an early childhood in Texas, Virginia and Pennsylvania - not places you'd expect to find someone growing up to be a left-winger, let alone an atheist. He even prefers cold weather to hot. His parents, he has said, were never compatible - his father, a professor at Louisiana State University, was a fiercely practical man while his mother had New Age interests. They split when he was 16 and Steven was always closer to his father.

He is clearly something of an intellectual but didn't go to college, opting instead for an early start in Hollywood, having spent his teens making Super-8 films. It didn't work out: he hated LA and came home after 18 months. He took a job in a video arcade, making the long commute to occasional editing jobs in LA. This ultimately led him to direct a tour film for rock dinosaurs Yes.

This was also Soderbergh's admitted 'self-destructive' phase: he was drinking heavily, sleeping around and lying a lot. 'I behaved really badly,' he said later. But his immersion in deception - he was carrying on with three women at once - formed the basis for sex, lies, and videotape, the $1.2 million indie movie that won the Palme D'Or at Cannes, made $25m and briefly threatened to turn the film world upside down, leading thousands of suburban Americans to believe they too could make films.

'Whether Soderbergh likes it or not, he changed the industry landscape,' wrote John Pierson in his book Spike Mike Slackers & Dykes. 'sex, lies, and videotape showed just how far a first feature, an independent no less, could go all over the world.'

The film's continuing stylistic influence is visible in American Beauty, but its deeper impact was the sense of possibility it created. Soderbergh was still only 26. But his fall seemed equally swift. Given $11m, Soderbergh went to Prague and made Kafka, a black-and-white comedy thriller starring Jeremy Irons that conflated the author's life and work. The critics demolished it. Soderbergh now admits it was too 'cold'. Reacting against his own film, he made King of the Hill, a coming-of-age story set during the Depression. It had none of Kafka's faults, but was too low key to get noticed. Then he made The Underneath, a film noir which he admits he thought was a disaster while he was making it. 'I disconnected so far from the excitement that made me want to make movies.'

Then he started writing Getting Away With It. 'Steven wanted to do a book that was centred on a conversation between himself and Richard Lester [the veteran film director],' Walter Donohue explains. 'In the course of the year of writing the book, he went off and did Schizopolis which was done very much in what now would be called the Dogme style. And the exuberance and freedom he found in making that film very much prepared him for the films he has done subsequently.'

Gary Ross doesn't buy into the idea of Soderbergh's lost years. 'Steven never seemed dormant to any of us. He would go off and direct a play in Baton Rouge, or make Schizopolis with his own money. And when you make a movie for $5,000 or whatever, the criteria of success should be different. I wouldn't say he wandered through the wilderness; I'd say he took an interesting hike through it.'

He initially turned down the chance to direct Out of Sight, largely because he was trying to make Human Nature, based on a typically bizarre script by Being John Malkovich writer Charlie Kaufman. Eventually he relented, and the film's sizzling Clooney-Lopez partnership suddenly returned Soderbergh to the mainstream.

So what it is it that makes this geeky, self-questioning man so popular with the glossiest people on the planet? By all accounts, Soderbergh is a nice guy. And Ross adds: 'He's also very funny. I'd love to see Steven do an all-out comedy one day because he is a riot.'

'He's completely wonderful to work with,' Donohue says. 'He trusts his instincts, and the work he produces has his stamp of identity on it.'

'He's clear about his point of view,' says Ross, 'and he's in control without being overbearing. Like all people who know what they are doing, he gives everyone else around him tremendous credit for their own expertise.'

What is certain is that he brings out the best in actors. The example always cited is Andie MacDowell appearing able to act in sex, lies, and videotape. But consider also such variable talents as Jennifer Lopez in Out of Sight or Terence Stamp in The Limey.Yet Soderbergh's affinity for actors is not at the expense of other components of the director's craft: he has a great eye for colour, and on Traffic he doubled as the cinematographer.

By following the straightforward Erin Brockovich with Traffic, just as he followed Out of Sight with The Limey, Soderbergh seems to have pre-empted any accusations that he has softened up. The bigger question is whether his position at the top of the Hollywood pile is part of a larger sea change, a return to something like the Seventies, or whether he remains a one-off.

'We've got to get back to that feeling of the French and British New Wave, and the films of the Sixties and Seventies, of pushing the language a little bit,' he once declared. And according to Donohue, he spends a lot of time pondering his place in the scheme of things. 'He feels there is this polarity between mainstream Hollywood and art cinema and that there is no reason, even if you come from the arty or independent sector, why you can't work within the commercial sector. He thinks it is very important for the long-term health of the industry that the talent which emerges from the independent sector should move into the mainstream, but only on the condition that the kind of films made are films you want to make anyway.'

Right now, it is trick that the self-declared luckiest bastard in the world seems to have mastered.

 Traffic opens on 26 January

fields.headline: Blow to teacher pay deal
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Scottish teachers' leaders last night warned that an early deal on pay was unlikely amid continued disagreement between the Executive and local authorities over funding for the 21.5 per cent increase on offer.
fields.body:
Scottish teachers' leaders last night warned that an early deal on pay was unlikely amid continued disagreement between the Executive and local authorities over funding for the 21.5 per cent increase on offer.

Jack McConnell, the Education Minister, is due to chair a meeting tomorrow at which he hopes the unions and councils will sign up to the three-year pay and conditions package he announced on Friday.

But union leaders ruled out any prospect of a deal being concluded tomorrow because they have yet to see details of how the package would break down and affect the salaries of Scotland's 50,000 teachers.

Information on what the offer will mean to individuals and how the £816m package will be distributed is likely to be announced tomorrow at the final negotiating meeting.

But Ronnie Smith, general secretary of the largest teachers' union, the Educational Institute of Scotland, said there would be no deal.

'Members are predictably angry that they have been asked to take a decision on an offer about which they have no detail,' he said.

'There's no prospect of a deal. Even if the detail is on the table, we're not going to scurry about and form a view without giving it proper thought and the consideration it deserves.'

The process is being held up by a dispute between the Executive and Convention of Scottish Local Authorities, which claims there is still a £120m shortfall in McCon-nell's funding plans to cover, among other things, professional development and recruitment of classroom and administrative assistants.

The EIS' salaries committee met yesterday to discuss the offer but was unable to reach a decision because of the lack of information.

'We want to be assured that the Scottish Executive and CoSLA reach a decision that will be delivered in reality,' Smith said.

Scotland's other main union, the Scottish Secondary Teachers Association, is also angry about the delay. It had convened a meeting of its executive and local representatives from across the country for Tuesday on the assumption that all the details would be known by then, but now believes it will have to cancel the meeting.

'This means it is going to be even more of a farce than it was already,' said David Eaglesham, the union's leader. 'I can understand the arithmetic logic of having to wait for agreement between Ministers and Cosla but politically it is crazy.'

Last night, McConnell played down the criticisms. 'This is a good offer. Of course details are important but we hope we can secure agreement once these details have been discussed.'

The average rise on offer for teachers in the first year could be as much as 10 per cent, compared with the 8 per cent recommended by the McCrone review of teachers' pay and conditions last year.

A Scottish Executive spokeswoman said all the parties would be locked in discussions over the remainder weekend. 'There is a lot of number crunching going on. We're hopeful a deal can be secured tomorrow, but it's important to get the detail right. We've made it clear that we will fund McCrone and we've actually gone beyond what McCrone recommended.'

webTitle: Bullies prey on half of all children

fields.headline: Bullies prey on half of all children
fields.standfirst:
Ashamed victims attempt suicide, study reveals

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ashamed victims attempt suicide, study reveals.
fields.body:
More than half of all British schoolchildren have been bullied, a report will reveal this week. Their torment is so severe that many victims told researchers it had driven them to attempt suicide.

In one of the most detailed studies of the extent of bullying, 7,000 pupils were questioned by the charity Young Voices and Oxford University.

The evidence of the children, between 13 and 19, from rural and inner-city schools, is alarming. One in 10 reported severe bullying, including physical violence. Many felt they could not tell anyone what was happening to them as their treatment by other children had sent them into a spiral of depression and misery.

Many went on to become bullies themselves in a desperate attempt to cope with feelings of powerlessness.

'I hated myself. I felt there must be something I'd done wrong or terrible for this to happen. I felt ashamed,' said one 14-year-old girl.

Adrienne Katz, of Young Voices, told The Observer: 'It's time we listened to what kids are telling us. A glossy brochure sent to the headteacher is not going to help, nor is removing the bully from the class so that you just displace the bullying from the playground to the bus stop.

'Children are telling us that half of schools still do not have an anti-bullying policy and of those who do only half again seem to be effective.'

The study found that home life plays a vital part in determining whether a child will be a bully or a victim. 'For both the victims and the bullies, parenting was markedly less positive, colder and more controlling. Bullies were far more likely to see aggression at home,' said Katz.

Children were far less likely to be bullied if they lived with both parents. Severely bullied boys reported not having a supportive parent and were highly likely to have an absent or unsupportive father.

Of the bullied girls, 79 per cent felt anxious about one parent, and were more likely to say they planned to bring up their own children very differently from the way they were being raised.

Racism seems to be a factor. Twenty-five per cent of children from ethnic minorities reported being severely bullied, as opposed to 13 per cent of white pupils.

'There are factors which protect children: being bolder and having high self-esteem and positive, warm parenting is overwhelmingly linked to those who are not being bullied,' said Katz.

Last year Ian Rivers, of the College of Ripon and York St John, interviewed 190 lesbian and homosexual young adults who were bullied at school and discovered that in later life one in six of them suffered post-traumatic stress disorder, including nightmares and flashbacks, and used drugs to help to get through the day.

Bullying in childhood has also been linked to problems in adulthood such as alcohol abuse, violence against children, marital breakdowns and psychiatric disorders. A 12-year-old bully is three times as likely as other pupils to have a criminal conviction by the age of 24.

Bullying is taking new forms. With one in four children now owning mobile phones, harassment is conducted by phone and email. 'They send sick messages to your mobile,' one girl said.

It was a campaign of torment by text messaging and silent calls which drove Gail Jones to take an overdose at her Merseyside home last year, her father Glyn believes. She was 15.

Suicide among adolescents has risen in the past decade, and now attempts among under-14s seem to be going up too. According to Professor Keith Hawton of the Centre for Suicide Research in Oxford, girls largely account for the increase in non-fatal overdoses and self-inflicted injuries. They outnumber boys by at least six to one.

In most cases, children are sending out the simple message: 'I feel so bad I could die.'

Psychologists, who previously thought the concept of death was understood by an individual at puberty, now believe it can develop far earlier in stressed children, at around seven or eight.

Kelly Yeomans, 13, took an overdose of her mother's painkillers in 1997 to end an 18-month bullying campaign against her.

'We keep going over the same question: "Why didn't she tell somebody?"' her mother Julie said then.

Only months later 15-year-old choirboy Darren Steele's mother asked the same question when her son hanged himself just weeks away from sitting his GCSEs.

In 1996 two schoolgirls were jailed, branded by the judge 'contemptible and cowardly', after the overdose death of 16-year-old Scots schoolgirl Katherine Jane Morrison.

One of the most heart-rending cases was that of the 13-year-old Manchester schoolboy Vijay Singh whose parents found the following entries in his diary in 1997:

'Monday: My money was taken. Tuesday: Names called. Wednesday: Uniform torn. Thursday: My body pouring with blood. Friday: It's ended. Saturday: Freedom.'

Saturday was the day Vijay was found dead, hanging from the banister of his home by a silk scarf.

webTitle: Depression hits one in four adults

fields.headline: Depression hits one in four adults
fields.standfirst:
Students suffer alarming growth in mental health problems - just as support services are being cut

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Students suffer alarming growth in mental health problems - just as support services are being cut.
fields.body:
Martin is 20 but he claims he already knows what will kill him. The science student is one of those touched by the fastest growing epidemic in the UK - depression. And it is depression, he says, that will claim his life.

Mental illness has reached unprecedented levels in the UK according to research obtained by The Observer.

A survey of Britain's students shows that 46 per cent of men and 64 per cent of women show symptoms of the illness and that mental health problems are overwhelming student health services.

This compares to levels reported in 1987 where between 1 and 25 per cent of students showed significant emotional disturbance.

'It seems that poor mental health is becoming more prevalent and more severe,' said Pauline Fox of Thames Valley University who conducted the research for the Mental Health Foundation. She said the findings were cause for the deepest concern.

'Undoubtedly students are in poor mental shape and counselling services are unable to cope with the volume,' she added.

For Martin counselling was never an option. He went to his GP and was given anti-depressants. These are currently prescribed 20 million times a year - a 700 per cent increase in 10 years.

Government figures show that on any day around 33 per cent of patients who visit their GP report symptoms of depression whether they recognise them or not.

'I had money and girlfriend troubles and exam worries and I wasn't sleeping,' said Martin. 'It took a while for me to accept that what I had was actually a mental illness. It took me even longer to recognise it wasn't an embarrassment. I'm told now that I should come off the pills and try therapy,' he said.

'But although I will, and I feel a lot better than before I took the medication, I understand why people say depression kills. I know it will be the death of me sooner or later and I've got to get along with that somehow.'

Depression and related suicide, suicidal behaviours and substance misuse have all increased among people in the general population.

According to Department of Health figures, around 20 per cent of women and 14 per cent of men in England suffer from depression at any one time but the Mental Health Foundation had estimated the true figure to be higher with symptoms affecting one in four UK adults.

Now the foundation's latest research will concern experts by showing what Fox called 'an alarming overview' of an illness which is still so severely stigmatised that, as studies show, employers would rather give a job to an ex-convict than to someone who admits to having ever suffered from depression.

'It is arguable whether these figures reflect the population at large or whether the tide is rising higher and faster among students,' said Fox.

'The student population is far greater and made up of a far wider spectrum of people than ever before and the pressures are higher with people having to work very hard outside university to make money. There is evidence that their general health is poorer than non-students.'

The epidemic of depression is spreading so fast that it has been estimated it will overtake heart disease, Aids, malaria and malnutrition to become the second most common killer in the world after cancer within 20 years.

'These are alarming statistics,' said Professor Jeffrey Gray of the Institute of Psychiatry. 'What one must remember is that depression not only kills through suicide but also leads to an early death in other ways.

'It changes the structure of the brain and there is evidence now that links it to cancer, infectious diseases, premature ageing and undoubtedly dementia.

'We are designed to cope with acute stres, the kind that would see someone running from a lion. But modern stress is prolonged and evolution has not designed us to cope with that.'

According to the World Health Organisation, depression is number five in the top 10 list of disabling illness and it is expected that the WHO's latest worldwide figures, to be released in June, will show a further increase.

Recent studies in the US suggest that upwards of 40 per cent of the US population will suffer from mental illness in their lifetime.

Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, Director-General of WHO, is making mental health a priority for 2001 with political action being urged to contain the epidemic.

'What is needed in the mental health arena is less exclusion and more care,' she said. 'This will be demonstrated by dismantling common myths about mental disorders and addressing the problem of discrimination.'

An unpublished report by the Association of University and College Counselling, seen by The Observer, further exposes the crisis of mental illness among students.

It reveals that 12 per cent of students at established universities contact the counselling service at some point during their student life, a rise of 25 per cent since 1996.

Around 4.7 per cent of students in higher education receive counselling but the services are being cut due to funding problems just as the demand is rising.

webTitle: Fears for the tots sent to school

fields.headline: Fears for the tots sent to school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Children as young as three risk being sucked into schooling too early by anxious parents and the boom in nursery education, MPs will warn this week.
fields.body:
Children as young as three risk being sucked into schooling too early by anxious parents and the boom in nursery education, MPs will warn this week.

Primary school reception classes already routinely accept four-year-olds.

Now a report from the Commons education select committee will highlight the danger of age limits dropping further, with parents desperate to secure places at the 'right' schools.

Although it will praise Labour's commitment to early years education, the report will say it has to be carefully delivered.

The verdict comes amid fierce debate over whether the under-fives are being pushed too far too fast. Margaret Lochrie, chief executive of the Pre-school Learning Alliance which represents playgroups, believes they are.

'The age at which children start school has been effectively lowered to four without that being the subject of legislation and without any real public debate,' she said. 'Parents' common sense view of their children not being ready for school is mixed with a different kind of anxiety now - that if they don't accept the place they won't get it later, or that their children will go later than all their friends, that they are somehow falling behind.'

'The real core of this report is restoring five as a good age to start school,' said one select committee source.

'But it will be flagging up the real danger that now kids can go into pre-school at four and will be able to at three, there will be a danger that the reception classes will slip down to four and even to three.'

webTitle: Comment: Sir must earn his respect

fields.headline: Sir must earn his respect
fields.trailText: Tommy Sheridan, who has recently strengthened his curriculum vitae with another short spell in prison, said last year that he had been politicised at school by his course in modern studies.
fields.body:
Tommy Sheridan, who has recently strengthened his curriculum vitae with another short spell in prison, said last year that he had been politicised at school by his course in modern studies. Such anecdotes strengthen the suspicion of Conservatives that the teaching profession, when it is not actively promoting homosexuality, is filling children's heads with radical and dissident thoughts.

The Tory dislike of state schools contributed to their neglect and Chris Woodhead helped to demoralise the profession in England and Wales, not because he promoted such ideas as performance review but because of his contempt for teachers themselves.

On the railways, Mrs Thatcher's hostility to trains influenced the neglect that has now produced the rail network's near paralysis. Her administrations also drew the building of council houses to an end, and this has compounded the difficulty of recruiting teachers, nurses and policemen in London and elsewhere.

These problems were at first neglected by Labour under Gordon Brown's two-year commitment to Tory spending plans but the consequences of years of under-investment in public services are now being confronted as the next election comes on us rather more quickly than the average commuter train.

The Scottish Executive is offering a three-year salary package of 21.5 per cent, somewhat less than the teachers' demands. The episode has cast light on the deteriorating relationship between the Executive and Cosla, which suspects that 'Team McLeish' is evading the cost of the full McCrone recommendations on teachers' pay and conditions. For its part, the Executive has denied reports that it wants to keep some money back to fund the Sutherland proposals for the care of the elderly.

The details matter. As the Government loosens the purse strings across the public services, the issue, increasingly, is not how much money is spent but how wisely.

Scotland was spared the attentions of Woodhead but its own teachers are hardly less demoralised. In February, a report by academics at Paisley University found that they needed an increase of £100 per week to maintain their differentials with similar professionals. At the same time, more and more duties have been devolved upon them.

But their unhappiness has deeper roots. Since the Seventies, there have been intermittent disputes with central government, all resolved at the cost of goodwill in general and of extramural activities, like sport, in particular. Over the last decades, teachers' unhappiness became a kind of entrenched embitterment.

Their feelings are understandable. They are at the sharp of end of social alienation and exclusion and are often required to demonstrate a quiet kind of heroism in the face of disruptive or violent children.

Yet society reserves its sincerest admiration for pop stars, professional footballers and vapid celebrities famous for being famous. That respect given to ministers and priests should have been much reduced is not surprising in a secular era. But even doctors have lost something of the social admiration they once enjoyed. Only airline pilots, though now superannuated operators of automated equipment and far removed from those magnificent men in their flying machines, retain something of the awed respect once given to the heroic pioneers of aviation.

For the teachers, it will be a long road back to esteem and parity, no matter the money. McCrone made numerous recommendations about grades, professional refreshment, early retirement packages and new blood. If the teachers want to recover the respect due to professionals whose work is fundamental to social harmony and economic success, then they have to behave accordingly.

They must become more than a mulish and resentful interest group. There is no reason why trade unionism, often largely defensive in its responses, cannot also be innovative, creative and committed to the highest professional standards. New money is only the start.

webTitle: Man set to search space for new Earths

fields.headline: Man set to search space for new Earths
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: One of astronomy's greatest prizes could be within reach: scientists believe they could discover an Earth-like planet orbiting a distant star within a decade.
fields.body:
One of astronomy's greatest prizes could be within reach: scientists believe they could discover an Earth-like planet orbiting a distant star within a decade.

Dr Hans Deeg, one of the foremost planet hunters, told The Observer a new wave of space-based telescopes should quickly detect rocky planets of a similar size to mankind's home. 'I would expect to find Earth-like planets at least within a decade, perhaps sooner. They should exist around other stars, but we just have no idea how many,' he said.

About 50 planets have been found circling other stars, but until now all have been 'gas giants', like Jupiter and Saturn, incapable of supporting life. Scientists now want to find planets like Earth, which are too small for the present technology to detect. This should change with the launch in 2004 of the first satellite designed to hunt for Earth-like worlds. Corot, a French-led European Space Agency project, will have 'the time and ability to detect planets around twice the size of the Earth', said Deeg, who helped design Corot and works at the Astrophysics Institute in Tenerife.

webTitle: Sick mother speaks out over IRA beating of teenage son

fields.headline: Sick mother speaks out over IRA beating of teenage son
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland Belfast woman demands justice after punishment squad terrorised her family
fields.trailText: Belfast woman demands justice after punishment squad terrorised her family.
fields.body:
Gerard McMahon - a teenager with a mental age of eight - was visiting his mother's house on the day that she received cancer test results when the IRA came calling.

Up to 10 masked men, some carrying guns, others wielding US police-style batons, burst through the door of Mary McMahon's home on the Ballymurphy estate in west Belfast.

Their target was Gerard, a 16-year-old with an IQ of 45, who has been on powerful anti-depressants since he was raped as a child by a relative. His crimes include theft, joyriding and drug taking. The punishment was a severe beating that could have been worse but for neighbours' intervention.

Local IRA members beat Gerard in front of his cancer-stricken mother, two younger brothers and a sister. When Mary leapt on the assailants she was hit as well.

Huddled in the front room of their home in Rock Grove, a narrow lane of dilapidated postwar houses off the Whiterock Road in the heart of republican Belfast, the McMahons said they had nothing left to lose by being one of the few families to speak out about punishment beatings despite the threat of retaliation.

For them, like scores of other working-class families in loyalist and republican areas, talk of a peace process is meaningless, as paramilitary groups on both sides of the sectarian divide continue to carry out punishment beatings and shootings despite claiming to be on ceasefire.

Mary McMahon speaks for her son, who can barely string coherent sentences together and cannot write his own name. 'It was the Thursday before Christmas when they came. Gerard had just signed bail and would usually be at my daughter Elaine's house, because that's part of the bail conditions. He only came to me see because he wanted to see if I was all right. On the day of the attack I had just got back the first of my tests for cancer treatment. The doctors had told me my thyroids had collapsed and that I might need surgery.

'It must have been around 6.15pm when the door was pushed in. There were between eight and 10 of them, all masked. Some had balaclavas on, one had a Celtic scarf wrapped around his face. A few had guns, the others held these batons, like the American peelers have. They shouted to me "Who is upstairs?" One of them asked my son Stephen, who is 12, who was up there, while pointing a gun at him.

'At first I really thought it was a joke, and then I thought maybe they were looking for my other son Paul, who is in prison on drugs charges. But then they went for Gerard, who was sitting on the sofa, and I jumped up. I threw myself on top of Gerard and shouted "Roll yourself up in a ball, son." One of the gunmen shouted: "Let go, you fucking bitch." The rest of the kids were screaming and my husband came downstairs. Another of them shouted to him: "Hold her or she'll be shot."

'I kept screaming "Who are you? And what are you here for?" They said nothing. There was a hefty one who managed to drag me off Gerard. He hit me and tore my jumper during the struggle. I think I hit one of them with an ashtray. Then they dragged Gerard to the bathroom and I could hear him screaming from in there. After that they dragged him outside to the alleyway. I went into the bathroom and saw blood everywhere; after that I passed out.'

Gerard said he was beaten about the legs and heads with guns and batons. Three front teeth were knocked out. Neighbours rushed to the house and, according to Mary, their arrival forced the attackers to flee.

With his baseball cap and tracksuit trousers - the 'uniform' of petty criminals in working-class Belfast - Gerard points to the gaps in his teeth and keeps repeating: 'They just kept hitting me, they just kept hitting me.'

Mary is convinced the Provisional IRA carried out the attack. The IRA shot Paul shortly before he was convicted of possessing drugs last year. She dismissed any suggestion that republican dissidents were behind the beating. Ironically, the first person to rush to her aid was Margaret O'Connor, whose son Joe, a Real IRA member, was shot dead by the Provisionals in October last year.

'I've lived in Ballymurphy for 20 years and I know who did this - it was the Provos and everyone else on the estate knows it as well.'

She accepts that Gerard has been involved in crime but insists no one deserves to be beaten in front of their mother and younger siblings.

'My younger kids are terrified. Stephen and Gary, who's eight, sleep in their clothes every night in case the bad men come back. Gary has been wetting the bed since it happened. They're afraid to open the door. Claire won't sleep here and is staying with her aunt.

fields.headline: Saddam defies doubters on TV
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A televised speech by Saddam Hussein yesterday failed to convince doubters that he is alive and well.
fields.body:
A televised speech by Saddam Hussein yesterday failed to convince doubters that he is alive and well.

It was the third TV appearance by the Iraqi leader - or someone like him - since an Iranian-backed opposition group claimed that he had suffered a stroke last Sunday.

In his 15-minute address to mark the 80th anniversary of the Iraqi armed forces, Saddam paid tribute to the 'brave, heroic, loyal, trustworthy and great army'.

He also gave a special greeting to 'the vanguard of the striving people of Palestine' in their struggle 'to liberate Palestine from the river to the sea' - a phrase signalling Iraq's non-recognition of Israel.

Iraqi officials were unable to clarify whether the speech was delivered live or recorded in advance. There were no topical references to indicate that it had been written in the last few days.

Iraqi television showed Saddam, dressed in a dark suit and tie, standing throughout the speech and reading from a prepared text - apparently in a studio or a presidential palace.

There were no obvious signs of ill-health, although he appeared to have bags under his eyes and spoke mainly from the right side of his mouth.

Last Wednesday Iraqi television showed him entering the cabinet room and chairing a meeting. On Thursday, he was shown chatting to a group of Egyptian actors and smoking a cigar.

Many analysts now dismiss the reports of Saddam's death or illness as rubbish. Some believe the Iraqi leader occasionally starts such rumours to see if anyone will attempt to seize power.

The US-back opposition group, the Iraqi National Congress, says the reports of Saddam's illness have diverted attention from the significance of last Sunday's military parade in Baghdad, where 64 helicopters and 1,000 Russian-made tanks made a guest appearance.

An INC spokesman said the parade showed clear evidence of the Iraqi army's refurbishment. 'There were new weapons systems on display, the troops had new uniforms, and Saddam has obviously had a lot of tank parts smuggled in,' he said.

webTitle: Salmon farmers braced for clampdown on toxins

fields.headline: Salmon farmers braced for clampdown on toxins
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Scotland's beleaguered fish farming industry is facing a crisis as the European Commission considers measures to prevent contamination of farmed salmon by cancer-causing toxic chemicals.
fields.body:
Scotland's beleaguered fish farming industry is facing a crisis as the European Commission considers measures to prevent contamination of farmed salmon by cancer-causing toxic chemicals.

The Observer has learnt that Brussels is likely to act this month to slash the permissible levels of toxin contamination in fishmeal and oil pellets amid growing evidence that, potentially, they pose a threat to human health.

The development comes in the wake of a row over a BBC2 wildlife documentary to be screened tonight. It will reignite concerns about the health and environmental impact of fish farming, an industry worth £300 million to the Scottish economy, providing jobs for 6,500 people.

Last week, a BBC news story claimed the documentary had discovered research that showed farmed salmon carried up to 10 times the levels of dioxins and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBS) than their wild counterparts.

The story provoked a furious reaction from the aquaculture industry and from the scientist credited with carrying out the research, who accused the BBC of misinterpreting her findings. The Food Standards Agency, which lambasted the BBC for creating a food scare, insisted there was no evidence to suggest farmed salmon were more at risk of contamination than wild fish.

But The Observer has established that Brussels believes the problem is more serious than the British authorities would suggest. At a meeting to take place this month, the Commission will consider a proposal to cut dioxin limits in fish feed after an investigation by an EU scientific committee.

The concern focuses on the tiny feed pellets, made from the rendered-down remains of small fish, that make up 75 per cent of the diet of farmed carniverous fish such as salmon. Trace levels of dioxins, a by-product of industrial incineration, and PCBs, man-made contaminants that were banned in Britain 30 years ago, can be found throughout the food chain, including in wild fish.

But the latest EU research found fishmeal and oil carried the greatest contamination of all animal feeds, raising the possibility of toxins crossing into the human food chain.

'As farmed fish combines an important consumption of feed materials of fish origin (up to 75 per cent in the diet of carnivorous species) with a high level of contamination of these feed materials, it is the food-producing animal most exposed to dioxins,' the Scientific Committee on Animal Nutrition said in a report handed to the European Commission last November.

Another group of experts, the Scientific Committee on Food, found that fish and fish products were the main contributors to exposure to dioxin contamination, ahead of dairy and meat products. The concentration of dioxin-related compounds in fish and fish products was 10 times the level found in other foodstuffs. The EU last month lowered its weekly tolerable limit of intake of these compounds.

A Commission official said: 'This is a serious problem and I think the solution will be a cut in dioxin limits. This is a big industry...but the Commission will put public health first when it makes its decision.'

The fishmeal and fishfarming industries are bracing themselves for tough action. Stuart Barlow, chief executive of the UK-based International Fishmeal and Oil Manufacturers Association, said the $750m-a-year European meal industry would be devastated by a drastic cut in the dioxin limits. 'If it is a big cut then we will be in serious trouble and so will the fish farmers because they will have nothing to feed their fish,' he said.

The BBC2 documentary, Warnings from the Wild: The price of salmon, also contains claims that government scientists were told they would lose their jobs if they spoke out about the impact of fish farming on wild salmon stocks. The Scottish Executive has denied the claims.

webTitle: Top Tories set to quit as morale slumps

fields.headline: Top Tories set to quit as morale slumps
fields.standfirst:
Hague's Shadow Cabinet plan escape after an election they expect to lose

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Hague's Shadow Cabinet plan escape after an election they expect to lose.
fields.body:
William Hague is facing an exodus of senior Tories after the next election as dispirited Shadow Cabinet members plan a return to the backbenches.

Several are gloomy at the prospect of another five gruelling years in opposition if, as expected, Labour is returned to power.

Party chairman Michael Ancram, once spoken of as a potential leader, is thought likely to leave the Shadow Cabinet if the Tories lose again. Ancram has been repeatedly attacked by colleagues for indecision and his enemies would quickly blame him for a defeat.

Friends say the former Minister Angela Browning, once the most senior woman on Hague's team but recently reshuffled into obscurity as Shadow Leader of the Commons, is also prepared to return to the backbenches.

Colleagues believe Francis Maude, the Shadow Foreign Secretary who has trodden a difficult path sniped at by both left and right in the party, will also go if Hague stays on as leader after the election. Maude insisted last night that he was expecting the party to win, adding: 'I am not making any plans on the basis of losing the election. I expect to be in the next Tory government.'

But colleagues argue that having had a lucrative career in the City before politics, he would be in demand for directorships as a backbench MP.

Colleagues complain that Hague lacks the ability to motivate his team, demoralised by the Tories' unpopularity in the polls.

A self-reliant man himself, the Tory leader does not realise others need encouragement and praise, they complain, while Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo is described as 'aloof and distant'.

'There is likely to be something of a clearout after the next election,' said one Shadow Cabinet member. 'People are feeling a bit depressed to be honest. No man is an island, except William Hague, and we need some feedback. Too often we are not working as a team.'

The exodus could, however, make room for talent from the junior ranks. Candidates for promotion include the cerebral ex-banker Oliver Letwin, on the Treasury team; Ann Widdecombe's deputy David Lidington; and environment spokesman Damian Green, although his pro-European views may hold him back.

Any reshuffle will be studied for how it shifts the balance between so-called 'Mods and Rockers' in the party - socially liberal modernisers versus traditionalists.

The two sides are currently locking horns over the tax proposals that will form the core of the Tory manifesto.

Although Hague is committed to restoring some form of married couples' allowance, aides are stressing it will not be a simple case of replacing the universal benefit scrapped by Labour.

The Shadow Cabinet is braced for a row over the proposals drawn up by Portillo and social security spokesman David Willetts, which would only benefit couples where one stays at home to look after children or disabled relatives.

Under the plan, the non-working partner could transfer their unused tax allowance of £4,500 a year to the working spouse, letting the breadwinner earn twice as much before tax.

But the package has infuriated traditionalists. 'Some in the party want a straightforward married couple's allowance in the form it used to exist,' said another Shadow Cabinet member. 'Their argument is that marriage is a social contract in its own right regardless of whether or not you have got children and you shouldn't be reaching fine judgments between different marriages.'

A final decision on the options will not be taken until next month at the earliest.

Options for Hague to consider include restricting the perk to parents of under-fives; restricting it to parents of under-11s; or to all married couples with children.

webTitle: Snub to Branson could take lottery fight back to courts

fields.headline: Snub to Branson could take lottery fight back to courts
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The head of the National Lottery Commission, Lord Burns, has rejected a plea from Sir Richard Branson for an emergency meeting on the game's future.
fields.body:
The head of the National Lottery Commission, Lord Burns, has rejected a plea from Sir Richard Branson for an emergency meeting on the game's future, making it far more likely that the multi-millionaire will launch a legal challenge to the award of the new licence to Camelot.

The legal move, which would throw the whole future of the Lottery into doubt, is now being 'seriously considered', say close confidants of the Virgin chairman.

Sources say Branson is incensed by the way he has been treated by Burns. A letter he received from the commission on Friday, explaining why it had rejected the bid by Branson's People's Lottery, was described as 'derisory'.

The head of Virgin was particularly angry that the two-and-a-half page letter came from the commission's solicitors, Freshfields, rather than from Burns himself.

Branson had asked for a meeting tomorrow to discuss his concerns before deciding whether to launch a challenge, which would jeopardise money paid by the Lottery to good causes.

The new licence is due to start in the autumn, an almost impossible deadline if there is a legal challenge. Good causes will lose up to £4 million for every day the Lottery does not operate.

In a private phone call on Friday, Simon Burridge, the chief executive of the People' Lottery, was told by Mark Harris, a commission official, that there would be no meeting until all threats of legal challenges had been lifted.

Branson would not agree to the ultimatum, so the meeting was abandoned.

He is now considering two possible challenges. He could apply for a judicial review, which would mean asking the courts to overturn the decision, or take legal action directly against the commission to recover the £40m costs of his bid.

'If they are not going to talk to us and explain how they reached their decision, which completely overturns their previous choice, if they are going to hide behind a cloak of secrecy, they are giving us no other option but to go for legal action,' Burridge said.

Branson will meet his legal team on Tuesday to discuss his next move. Some advisers are concerned that if Branson seeks a judicial review, he might be attacked for putting the Lottery itself under threat. They prefer an action against the commission.

'We have had thousands and thousands of letters from the public supporting us,' said a Branson camp official. 'Richard has to make the choice, but it would very difficult to walk away.'

When Branson was told in December that he had lost the battle for the licence he immediately said he would take legal advice on the chances of winning a judicial review.

The Observer revealed the following weekend that the advice was that the process was 'substantially flawed' and 'unfair'.

News of Branson's anger will increase pressure on the Government to overhaul the Lottery system. Downing Street is worried that the process, which was supposed to be finalised last June, is still not complete.

The commission's original decision to award the licence to the People's Lottery in August was overturned by the courts, which said it had been 'conspicuously unfair'.

webTitle: Scientists switch to warp drive as sci-fi energy source is tapped

fields.headline: Scientists switch to warp drive as sci-fi energy source is tapped
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Warp-drive engines - Scotty's pride and joy on the Starship Enterprise - could soon be propelling spacecraft across the solar system.
fields.body:
Warp-drive engines - Scotty's pride and joy on the Starship Enterprise - could soon be propelling spacecraft across the solar system.

This extraordinary idea has been adopted by a growing group of world-ranking physicists who believe that soon spaceships could be designed to run on energy extracted from empty space - enabling them to fly for centuries without fuel.

Scientists are to hold their first international conference of the subject - supported by the British National Space Centre - in Brighton this month. Delegates will include Nobel prize winner Harry Kroto, as well as Russian, American and European space officials.

It has also been revealed that the United States Air Force and the US Navy have set up secret projects aimed at developing 'zero-point energy' engines, while the US space agency Nasa has launched its Breakthrough Propulsion Physics project to investigate similar rocket devices.

In addition, British Aerospace has confirmed it has launched a research programme - codenamed Project Greenglow - to study 'the possibility of the control of gravitational fields'.

'The last century was the atomic age, but this one could well turn out to be the zero-point age,' said conference delegate Dr Harold Puthoff, director of the Institute for Advanced Studies, in Austin, Texas. 'We are at the stage that the fathers of the atomic bomb were at when they put together their first test nuclear reactor in the early Forties - and look what happened a few years later.'

The basis for a zero-point engine rests on the recent startling discovery that a vacuum, far from being a pocket of nothingness, actually churns and seethes with unseen activity.

This cosmic unrest is caused by quantum fluctuations, tiny ripples of energy - called zero-points - in the fabric of space and time. By interfering with these fluctuations, it should be possible to tap their energy, say the physicists.

'It's almost a cosmic free lunch,' said Graham Ellis, organiser of the First International Field Propulsion Meeting at Sussex University. 'You would tap these quantum fluctuations and pick up free energy for your rocket as you flew through space.'

So far, only relatively crude demonstrations of the power of quantum fluctuations have been carried out. In one set of experiments - carried out by physicists led by the late Nobel prize winner Hendrik Casimir - two metal plates were clamped and held together by zero-point forces.

'The crucial point is that the plates were brought together with a force that heated them up very slightly,' said Puthoff. 'It's not enough to run a starship, but it did demonstrate that it is possible to tap the energy field of a vacuum and turn it into power.'

One proposal for creating a quantum fluctuation space-drive is based on the the idea that these tiny energy ripples hold objects back as they fly through space. They are responsible for the phenomenon of inertia.

'If we could counter this effect, rockets would need much less fuel to overcome their own inertia, and would fly through space with far less effort,' added Puthoff.

'We also believe electrons get the energy to whizz round the nucleus of an atom without slowing down because they are tapping quantum fluctuations of empty space. If we could fiddle with that field - we have ideas how to do it - we could destabilise atoms and get power from them.'

The crucial point of a zero-point engine is that it would run without liquid or solid fuel, or at least very little of such propellants. It would merely require some electricity from solar power, the rest would be provided by the energy of empty space.

By contrast, current space rockets use 96 per cent of their own weight in hydrogen and oxygen fuel, leaving very little room for payloads. Hence the $100 billion price tag that has been put on the construction of the International Space Station.

As Dr Marc Millis of Nasa's Breakthrough project put it: 'We have to discover a new way to eliminate or reduce dramatically the amount of propellent we take into space.' If delegates at Brighton are right, we may soon find a way.

'If we are right, we should be able to build our first small rockets and use them to keep satellites in their correct orbit in about five years,' said Graham Ellis. 'After that, there will no virtually no limit to the potential of these things.'

webTitle: How Noah could clone a new ark

fields.headline: How Noah could clone a new ark
fields.standfirst:
The recreation of a rare ox after its death marks a step towards the goal of reviving extinct species, reports Robin McKie:Candidates for cloning: the giant panda and white rhino
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The recreation of a rare ox after its death marks a step towards the goal of reviving extinct species, reports Robin McKie:Candidates for cloning: the giant panda and white rhino.
fields.body:
The death of the ageing ox in San Diego zoo in 1993 was greeted as a biological catastrophe by conservationists. The animal - a member of an endangered South-east Asian sub-species known as a gaur - had died without fathering offspring. Its precious genes, crucial to maintaining the viability of dwindling gaur herds, had been eradicated. Or so it seemed.

All had not been lost, however - a point that will be dramatically demonstrated in a few days when a clone of the long-dead gaur is born to Bessie, a regular American cow, on a farm near Sioux City, in Iowa.

The animal's resurrection is a scientific milestone: it raises hopes that potentially unlimited numbers of endangered creatures could one day be created, generating arks of threatened or extinct species, including pandas, rhinos, and wildcats. Appropriately, the baby gaur will be called Noah.

'We have shown that domestic animals can be used as surrogate mothers for clones of endangered sibling species,' said Noah's creator, Dr Phil Damiani, of the US biotech firm, Advanced Cell Technologies (ACT). 'We now have a new weapon in the fight against animal extinctions.'

According to theory, scientists need only save a few cells of an endangered animal; use one to create a cloned embryo; stick this in the womb of a similar domestic species, and in a few months, a rare wildcat or antelope will be born.

Even better, cells from the preserved corpse of an extinct animal could be use to breath life into an entire species. Scientists at ACT, in collaboration with conservationists at the Ordesa National Park in Spain, have already begun work on cells taken from the body of the last bucardo, a Spanish mountain goat. The aim is to create a clone which would be placed in the womb of an Ibex, a closely related species.

The key development in this technology is not the use of cross-species embryo implantations, however. The technique may appear dramatic but has already been used to persuade horses to give birth to zebras, and common antelopes to bear rarer sister species. What really excites scientists is the use of cloning in the gaur clone's creation, for it means that no risky operations had to be carried out to remove eggs from its mother's womb - a crucial advantage when dealing with a highly endangered species.

'We used a technique very similar to that used in the creation of Dolly the sheep,' said Damiani. 'We took an egg from a domestic cow and removed its nucleus, the bit that contains its genes. Then we fused this empty egg with a single gaur cell, creating a gaur embryo that was immunologically acceptable to its surrogate cow mother.'

As a result of this work, it should now be possible to produce endangered animals merely by collecting a few sample cells - say from saliva, hair or blood - which can then be used to generate new animals. At least, that's the theory. Several serious obstacles still have to be overcome.

For a start, Noah's conception was certainly not without difficulty. He is the only survivor of a total of 690 attempts to create embryos from the cells of its 'father'. Only 30 were sufficiently robust to transfer to surrogate cows, and from these only eight pregnancies were achieved. Noah is the only one of these that has gone to term. 'We believe he is healthy, but cannot be sure until after he has been born,' added Damiani.

Then there is the question of surrogate mothers. For a gaur, this is not a problem since the species is so genetically similar to domestic cattle. Other rare creatures are not so well-blessed, or well-connected.

Take the panda. 'It is the only member of its genus,' said Damiani. 'It has no close cousins and no obvious candidates for surrogate mothers. The closest species to it is the bear. However, we will need some major advances in immunology before we can think of persuading a bear to accept a panda embryo.'

And finally, there is the problem of sex, a vexed issue demonstrated neatly by ACT's work on the bucardo. Its last representative on Earth - killed last year when struck by a falling tree - was female. Clones from this animal will therefore be female as well. A herd made up of nothing but lady bucardos suffers an obvious reproductive problem.

'Once we have cloned bucardos we will have to look at ways of creating males,' said Damiani. 'That means finding a method of adding Y chromosomes to embryos and again that is something that will require major advances in biology.'

Nevertheless, the birth of Noah in a few days does offer some species a precious lifeline. In particular, it suggests that it should be possible to improve the genetic diversity of zoo populations merely by sending in blood samples from which new creatures can be cloned.

Already zoos such as San Diego's are stockpiling cells from African wild cats, blackfooted cats, various gazelles and other antelopes - animals fortunate enough to possess close domestic relations that could then act as surrogate hosts. 'Cloning is certainly not the answer to animal extinctions,' admitted Damiani. 'However it is a powerful new weapon.'
