webTitle: British safety claims wilt as uranium panic grips Nato

fields.headline: British safety claims wilt as uranium panic grips Nato
fields.standfirst:
New research threatens to undermine MoD denial of the dangers of Balkans Syndrome. Foreign affairs editor Peter Beaumont investigates

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: New research threatens to undermine MoD denial of the dangers of Balkans Syndrome. Foreign affairs editor Peter Beaumont investigates.
fields.body:
Commandant Frank Cop is an angry man and a formidable opponent. A soldier in the Belgian army for 30 years, his career was cut short by illness two months after returning from duty as a peace monitor with the UN and the EU during the Bosnian war.

In five years, says Cop, aged 50, he has been beset by a series of devastating ailments. He suffers headaches and muscle aches, debilitating lethargy and skin complaints so serious he finds it uncomfortable to bathe. Blood tests recorded abnormally high levels of white cells. Invalided out of the armed forces on a reduced pension, Cop embarked on a one-man campaign on behalf of Belgian veterans of the Balkans: victims, he claims, of a mysterious 'Balkans Syndrome', similar in its symptoms to the Gulf war Syndrome claimed by veterans of the war against Iraq.

Cop is convinced he knows what has made him ill. He believes he was contaminated by the highly toxic residue from the three tonnes of depleted uranium (DU) ammunition fired by US aircraft against the Serbs during the Bosnian war.

Last week Cop - one of the first peacekeepers to claim he was suffering from Balkans Syndrome - found himself at the centre of one of Nato's biggest peacetime crises, a scandal gripping the armed forces of a dozen European countries, as military chiefs across a continent ordered urgent checks on the health of soldiers allegedly exposed to depleted uranium in the Balkans.

A week after the announcement by the Italian Defence Ministry that it was investigating the deaths from leukaemia of six of its Kosovo peacekeepers for links to depleted uranium, scores of former Balkans peacekeepers - from Hull to Lisbon - are now claiming they are suffering from unexplained ailments, as the media from Rome to Berlin has daily turned up new cases of peacekeepers who died from cancers after returning from the Balkans.

In Britain two former peacekeepers have come forward, including former Royal Engineer Kevin Rudland, who believes he was contaminated servicing tank guns while based in the Bosnian Serb town of Banja Luka. His symptoms are ones that Cop would recognise immediately, most prominent among them chronic fatigue.

'After I became ill in August 1996 I was referred to the military medical services,' Cop said last week. 'My white blood cell count was three times what it should be. The military doctors said I was ill, but they did not know what from.

'That is when I began investigating for myself. I got in contact with a German doctor who had been studying the effects of depleted uranium in the Gulf and he told me American forces had used depleted uranium ammunition during the Bosnian war. The Americans denied it. Now they admit it's true.'

In seven days the safety of the depleted uranium ammunition has become an international controversy, attracting competing charges of a US cover-up over the danger the ammunition poses and dangerous claims of 'scaremongering'. After a decade of inconclusive research had mostly ruled out any link between depleted uranium ammunition and cancers - and counter-claims alleging that it had caused thousands of cancers among Iraqi children - investigations into the health implications are suddenly under way in Belgium, Italy, France and Turkey; in Finland, Sweden, Portugal and Spain.

Among those who have demanded an investigation are Italy's Prime Minister Giuliano Amato who has called for a US moratorium on the use of depleted uranium shells - rejected by the Pentagon - and EU Commission President Romano Prodi who called for the banning of the ammunition if even the slightest risk was identified.

In response, Nato's Secretary-General Lord Robertson has promised the Italians to provide information on its use of the ammunition in the Balkans. Nato too will also discuss its safety at this week's meeting of Ministers.

It is a scandal that threatens to take high profile victims.

In Portugal the strength of feeling is so strong that it threatens to overshadow the presidential elections after the media reported claims that a Portuguese peacekeeper in Kosovo had died from ammunition poisoning.

As more alleged victims emerged in Portugal, a heated emergency parliamentary debate saw MPs angrily calling for the withdrawal of Portuguese troops from the region, accusing the government of withholding information from them after the military claimed the soldier had died from septicaemia. In Kosovo, the claims have sparked a panic over fears among moderate Kosovar leaders that the scandal may lead to the withdrawal of peacekeeping contingents.

In Britain, almost alone, the Ministry of Defence remains unmoved by the sense of panic gripping its European allies.

The MoD's radiation and health experts, in step with the Pentagon, insist debris of depleted uranium poses little risk to the health of servicemen. They will read new research, they say, with interest and an open mind, but reject any calls for their own health screening of Balkan peacekeepers.

Their hopes that the row might defuse, however, were shattered on Friday with the announcement by a UN Environment Programme task force that it had found evidence of 'radioactive contamination' at eight of 11 sites tested in Kosovo that were struck by depleted uranium ammunition during the war in 1999.

It is a disclosure, however, that still does not answer a question that has become the centre of heated scientific debate - whether the reassurances of the British and American defence chiefs over the safety of depleted uranium can be sustained. Or whether they have seriously underestimated its danger.

One organisation, at least is unconvinced, by their reassurances. On Friday the UN High Commissioner for Refugees confirmed its policy was to warn all staff travelling to Kosovo - and pregnant women in particular - of the potential risks of exposure to debris from depleted uranium still in the province.

The answer to the question of whether depleted uranium ammunition is really safe may not lie in the bomb craters of Kosovo and Serbia. Instead, some experts believe, it is likely to be found in an area of barren Iraqi desert near the border with Kuwait, a place littered with remains of the last great land battle of the twentieth century - Operation Desert Storm.

It was here that depleted uranium ammunition was used for the first time - more than 30 metric tonnes - 300,000 rounds in all.

It is a landscape still dotted with the ruins of Iraqi tanks blasted with the ammunition, the rents in their armour still emitting tell-tale signs of low-level radiation.

Significantly this battlefield represents an unintentional experiment - a decade in the making - over what happens to depleted uranium debris in the environment and how it affects the health of local populations. The most serious of those effects, the Iraqi authorities have long claimed, has been a sharp rise in childhood leukaemias and birth defects.

And it was to here that British low-level radiation specialist Dr Chris Busby travelled three months ago to perform a radiological survey for an Arab television station. What Busby discovered surprised him. Soil samples - confiscated by the Iraqi authorities - showed lower levels of contamination than he expected.

But his air samples revealed levels of ionising radiation in the atmosphere around the battlefield 10 times higher than in the neighbouring city of Basra and 20 times higher than in Baghdad.

If his samples are correct, then US and British military claims that microscopic breathable particles of depleted uranium quickly disperse might not be true. It is this that is at the centre of the present controversy.

What is accepted by all sides is that when depleted uranium ammunition - used in bullets for its hardness and penetrating power - hits its target, it also explodes and burns at temperatures of up to 10,000 C forming a smoke or 'aerosol' of suspended particles composed of three toxic and radioactive compounds of uranium.

But, according to US and British defence experts, the only risk is to those in the vicinity of the battlefield in the immediate aftermath of the attack who breathe in concentrations of the aerosol of compounds.

The risk, they claim decreases, as the aerosol disperses to levels of risk below that acceptable within the civil nuclear industry. According to these calculations there should be no contamination of Iraq's air and little risk.

Busby, however, believes that the MoD's experts have got it wrong on two counts: on the way that charged, contaminated particles remain in the environment and - more seriously - over their risk models which he claims are outdated and underestimate the health impact by up to 1,000-fold, a claim he made in a paper to the Royal Society's Depleted Uranium working group last year.

Busby is not alone in believing the MoD may have got it wrong. Professor Malcolm Hooper, a member of the British Legion's Gulf War Illnesses Inter-Parliamentary group, also believes the advice given by health experts of the British and US military is dangerously out of date.

'New research suggests the risk threshold from inhaled particles is much, much lower than previously assumed,' he said.

Hooper points to research suggesting that genetic mutation to irradiated cell tissue takes place in a more pernicious way than previously assumed, with 35 per cent of cells neighbouring a single irradiated one showing evidence of damage.

The most controversial piece of research, however, has been undertaken in Newfoundland, Canada, where scientists at the International Uranium Centre tested the urine of British, US and Canadian Gulf war veterans, as well as that of Iraqi veterans and civilians, using for the first time Thermal Ionising Mass Spectrometry. 'These people have considerable amounts of depleted uranium in their bodies in the form of shrapnel, and excrete high levels of uranium in their urine,' said an MoD source. 'Significantly none of them of has shown significant problems, nor have their children.'

Frank Cop and the other victims are not going to be convinced.

fields.bodyText: Commandant Frank Cop is an angry man and a formidable opponent. A soldier in the Belgian army for 30 years, his career was cut short by illness two months after returning from duty as a peace monitor with the UN and the EU during the Bosnian war. In five years, says Cop, aged 50, he has been beset by a series of devastating ailments. He suffers headaches and muscle aches, debilitating lethargy and skin complaints so serious he finds it uncomfortable to bathe. Blood tests recorded abnormally high levels of white cells. Invalided out of the armed forces on a reduced pension, Cop embarked on a one-man campaign on behalf of Belgian veterans of the Balkans: victims, he claims, of a mysterious 'Balkans Syndrome', similar in its symptoms to the Gulf war Syndrome claimed by veterans of the war against Iraq. Cop is convinced he knows what has made him ill. He believes he was contaminated by the highly toxic residue from the three tonnes of depleted uranium (DU) ammunition fired by US aircraft against the Serbs during the Bosnian war. Last week Cop - one of the first peacekeepers to claim he was suffering from Balkans Syndrome - found himself at the centre of one of Nato's biggest peacetime crises, a scandal gripping the armed forces of a dozen European countries, as military chiefs across a continent ordered urgent checks on the health of soldiers allegedly exposed to depleted uranium in the Balkans. A week after the announcement by the Italian Defence Ministry that it was investigating the deaths from leukaemia of six of its Kosovo peacekeepers for links to depleted uranium, scores of former Balkans peacekeepers - from Hull to Lisbon - are now claiming they are suffering from unexplained ailments, as the media from Rome to Berlin has daily turned up new cases of peacekeepers who died from cancers after returning from the Balkans. In Britain two former peacekeepers have come forward, including former Royal Engineer Kevin Rudland, who believes he was contaminated servicing tank guns while based in the Bosnian Serb town of Banja Luka. His symptoms are ones that Cop would recognise immediately, most prominent among them chronic fatigue. 'After I became ill in August 1996 I was referred to the military medical services,' Cop said last week. 'My white blood cell count was three times what it should be. The military doctors said I was ill, but they did not know what from. 'That is when I began investigating for myself. I got in contact with a German doctor who had been studying the effects of depleted uranium in the Gulf and he told me American forces had used depleted uranium ammunition during the Bosnian war. The Americans denied it. Now they admit it's true.' In seven days the safety of the depleted uranium ammunition has become an international controversy, attracting competing charges of a US cover-up over the danger the ammunition poses and dangerous claims of 'scaremongering'. After a decade of inconclusive research had mostly ruled out any link between depleted uranium ammunition and cancers - and counter-claims alleging that it had caused thousands of cancers among Iraqi children - investigations into the health implications are suddenly under way in Belgium, Italy, France and Turkey; in Finland, Sweden, Portugal and Spain. Among those who have demanded an investigation are Italy's Prime Minister Giuliano Amato who has called for a US moratorium on the use of depleted uranium shells - rejected by the Pentagon - and EU Commission President Romano Prodi who called for the banning of the ammunition if even the slightest risk was identified. In response, Nato's Secretary-General Lord Robertson has promised the Italians to provide information on its use of the ammunition in the Balkans. Nato too will also discuss its safety at this week's meeting of Ministers. It is a scandal that threatens to take high profile victims. In Portugal the strength of feeling is so strong that it threatens to overshadow the presidential elections after the media reported claims that a Portuguese peacekeeper in Kosovo had died from ammunition poisoning. As more alleged victims emerged in Portugal, a heated emergency parliamentary debate saw MPs angrily calling for the withdrawal of Portuguese troops from the region, accusing the government of withholding information from them after the military claimed the soldier had died from septicaemia. In Kosovo, the claims have sparked a panic over fears among moderate Kosovar leaders that the scandal may lead to the withdrawal of peacekeeping contingents. In Britain, almost alone, the Ministry of Defence remains unmoved by the sense of panic gripping its European allies. The MoD's radiation and health experts, in step with the Pentagon, insist debris of depleted uranium poses little risk to the health of servicemen. They will read new research, they say, with interest and an open mind, but reject any calls for their own health screening of Balkan peacekeepers. Their hopes that the row might defuse, however, were shattered on Friday with the announcement by a UN Environment Programme task force that it had found evidence of 'radioactive contamination' at eight of 11 sites tested in Kosovo that were struck by depleted uranium ammunition during the war in 1999. It is a disclosure, however, that still does not answer a question that has become the centre of heated scientific debate - whether the reassurances of the British and American defence chiefs over the safety of depleted uranium can be sustained. Or whether they have seriously underestimated its danger. One organisation, at least is unconvinced, by their reassurances. On Friday the UN High Commissioner for Refugees confirmed its policy was to warn all staff travelling to Kosovo - and pregnant women in particular - of the potential risks of exposure to debris from depleted uranium still in the province. The answer to the question of whether depleted uranium ammunition is really safe may not lie in the bomb craters of Kosovo and Serbia. Instead, some experts believe, it is likely to be found in an area of barren Iraqi desert near the border with Kuwait, a place littered with remains of the last great land battle of the twentieth century - Operation Desert Storm. It was here that depleted uranium ammunition was used for the first time - more than 30 metric tonnes - 300,000 rounds in all. It is a landscape still dotted with the ruins of Iraqi tanks blasted with the ammunition, the rents in their armour still emitting tell-tale signs of low-level radiation. Significantly this battlefield represents an unintentional experiment - a decade in the making - over what happens to depleted uranium debris in the environment and how it affects the health of local populations. The most serious of those effects, the Iraqi authorities have long claimed, has been a sharp rise in childhood leukaemias and birth defects. And it was to here that British low-level radiation specialist Dr Chris Busby travelled three months ago to perform a radiological survey for an Arab television station. What Busby discovered surprised him. Soil samples - confiscated by the Iraqi authorities - showed lower levels of contamination than he expected. But his air samples revealed levels of ionising radiation in the atmosphere around the battlefield 10 times higher than in the neighbouring city of Basra and 20 times higher than in Baghdad. If his samples are correct, then US and British military claims that microscopic breathable particles of depleted uranium quickly disperse might not be true. It is this that is at the centre of the present controversy. What is accepted by all sides is that when depleted uranium ammunition - used in bullets for its hardness and penetrating power - hits its target, it also explodes and burns at temperatures of up to 10,000 C forming a smoke or 'aerosol' of suspended particles composed of three toxic and radioactive compounds of uranium. webTitle: Clinton's final acts enrage Bush team

fields.headline: Clinton's final acts enrage Bush team
fields.standfirst:
President's last-minute orders save forests from industry

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: President's last-minute orders save forests from industry.
fields.body:
As the Clinton administration enters its last days, Republicans and their allies are drawing up battle plans to defeat a 'scorched-earth policy' being pushed through in a flurry of last-minute orders.

Over the past weeks President Bill Clinton has tried to secure his legacy on labour rights, race, the regulation of industry, the security services, and the international criminal court. But the sharpest response from George Bush's Republicans, with the support of mining, drilling and logging interests, has been provoked by Clinton's executive orders on the environment. New rules will put millions of acres in national forests off limits to development.

In Washington Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said the incoming President would review 'each and every' last-minute order that Clinton issued. None can be reversed by Bush unilaterally and trying to override them in Congress would be difficult and time-consuming. Instead the Republicans are expected to use the courts to mount a legal attack on the environmental measures. Already a lawsuit has begun to challenge Clinton's unilateral designation in the past year of more than half a dozen new national monuments.

The public line in Texas and Washington remains that the passing of the baton proceeds co-operatively. But sources close to Bush, who will be inaugurated in two weeks' time, are livid at both the measures and the audacity in Clinton's deployment of the Executive Order system.

Behind the formal smiles, too, lies tension over the fact that Bush has refused to pardon Clinton as a shield from prosecution over the Lewinsky affair once he leaves office - and has appointed the leader of the impeachment drive as Attorney General.

The two men's views are particularly at odds on the environment, with Bush committed to ambitious projects for logging, road-building and oil-prospecting across hundreds of thousands of miles of American wilderness.

However, with sleight of hand on Friday, Clinton announced an almost total ban on road-building and most commercial logging across a quarter of all federally-owned land, amounting to some 60 million acres. The measure was hailed by the Natural Resources Defence Council as 'the biggest conservation achievement of any president in our history'.

The ban in effect stops all profitable oil drilling in National Forest land, and goes way beyond the 40 million acres earmarked for protection under a consultative document produced last year. In a special twist, the ban is now extended to vast tracts of Alaska's Tongrass National Forest, which had been previously exempted from draft controls, and was a particular point of contention during the election campaign.

Al Gore had pledged to add and protect the Tongrass, while Bush, who is close to the energy business and a former oilman himself, had earmarked much of the area for prospecting and drilling. Now, even if the energy giants do exercise their legal right to seek oil, they will be dogged by costly logistical problems.

A source in the Bush transition team called the move 'an irresponsible provocation', while the timber industry and Republican politicians in the West were seething with rage. The Governor of Idaho, Dirk Kepthorne, has threatened legal action, calling it 'flawed public policy that stiffs the states'.

Another gauntlet thrown down by Clinton last week was his last-minute endorsement of the permanent international criminal court for trying those charged with war crimes and crimes against humanity. For years, US equivocation, largely caused by hostility on Capitol Hill and nerves that its own military could be charged, has been the biggest obstacle to the establishment of the court. Clinton refused to authorise the American signature when most Western countries did so in Rome in 1998.

fields.headline: Toyzone struggles to survive
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Toyzone, the e-tailing toy company controlled by PR guru Matthew Freud, this weekend conceded that it will struggle to survive as an independent business.
fields.body:
Toyzone, the e-tailing toy company controlled by PR guru Matthew Freud, this weekend conceded that it will struggle to survive as an independent business.

The company, which was launched in a blaze of publicity 18 months ago, is now considered vulnerable following the defection of three key staff members before Christmas. These include Jo Hall, its former managing director, poached from Toys 'R' Us, and co-founder Peter Norris.

'A standalone internet site operating just in Britain is hard to push through,' admitted the company's chief executive, Paul Miller. He said Toyzone would have to either broaden its product range or sell out to a medium sized bricks-and-mortar retailer.

News of Toyzone's difficulties comes as its main rival, eToys, last week pulled the plug on its European operation, having run out of cash.

To cap a gloomy week in the Freud household, his future father-in-law, Rupert Murdoch, is to write off more than £10 million of his ill-fated investment in collapsed internet firm Letsbuyit.com.

This weekend, Letsbuyit's Dutch administrators are urgently investigating the firm's accounts to establish if creditors can be paid in full.

Last week, Letsbuyit's top management resigned en masse, having closed the company after Christmas in the highest-profile internet crash since Boo.com last summer. Murdoch's BSkyB invested £10m in an undisclosed stake before Letsbuyit's flotation on Germany's Neuer Markt last July. The broadcaster agreed to take over £6m more in shares in a novel 'equity-for-advertising deal'.

Letsbuyit raised £120m in its brief but colourful two- year existence. Much of that was blown on high-profile TV advertising campaigns, including one featuring cartoon ants.

fields.headline: How tosign a striker
fields.standfirst: Gordon Strachan tells all
fields.trailText: Gordon Strachan tells all.
fields.body:
It's a tricky business, particularly now that players' agents have become so prominent. I get offered so many players by these people that it's a wonder my fax machine does not blow up. Because of the importance of a striker to a team, just isolating the man you want can be wearying enough. Videos come in handy when you are assessing a foreign player, but your homework on a player has to go deeper. For example, you don't just look at his goal-per-game scoring ratio. You also look at factors such as his attitude when his team are struggling; the number of chances he misses; how many times he gets injured.

As it happens, I think that you can do too much homework on a player. The more you watch him, the more chance you have of seeing something that is going to put doubts in your mind. Coventry can less afford to take our time than a club like, say, Man United.

Not all transfer deals are the same - but generally I like to do it in the traditional way. The routine is that I telephone the manager of the player's club to ascertain whether the man I want is available and how much they want for him. If my chairman gives his approval, he finalises the financial aspects of the deal with his opposite number and we talk to the player about personal terms.

It's at that point that we meet his agent; and it's then that you can be left tearing your hair out. In one example, the agent of a player we wanted to sign told us that if we didn't give him a fee, he would advise his client not to come here.

The next hurdle is the player's medical, which can create the biggest problems of all. If that's OK, you try to help the player find the right accommodation - and cross your fingers that all the time and effort in bringing him to your club will prove worthwhile.

Gordon Strachan was talking to Jason Tomas.

webTitle: Top 10 dodgiest  haircuts in history of football

fields.headline: Top 10 dodgiest  haircuts in history of football
fields.standfirst: Plus verdicts from top stylist Nicky Clarke
fields.trailText: Plus verdicts from top stylist Nicky Clarke
fields.body:
1 Rudi Voller
Peter Shilton paid for his in champagne, Terry McDermott, Phil Thompson, Graeme Souness, Kevin Keegan and Craig Johnston greased theirs daily, but Rudi Voller was and remains queen of the perm. Peroxide with grey highlights, Voller's cut made him a German style icon and elevated him to the top of this competitive style category - landing him OSM's overall worst cut prize.

The style's greatest moment came when, during the 1990 World Cup, it collected and held, glue-like, the spit of Frank Rijkaard, leading to the Dutchman's famous red card. Voller remains one of the most popular men in Germany. He narrowly beats retired Austrian striker Toni Polster to the title - Polster wore his monster-perm with white socks and gold jewellery. He now has his own fashion label.

Nicky Clarke's verdict:
Oh god, oh god. This is just so... He's managed to combine Steve Coogan's Paul Calf with Harry Enfield's Scousers, and be German at the same time. Oh god, no, absolutely awful.

Cost of the style in Clarke's London salon: No way. I'd do all the others if pressed, but if I was asked for this in all seriousness I'd refuse. No way.

2 Alexi Lalas
If you're going to be a ginger Detroit rocker-cum-footballer, you might as well look like it - which is why Lalas only makes second in the list. It's a shocking set of facial hair devices - but whatever you think about him, Lalas is totally true to himself: bad haircut, bad musician, bad footballer. He does, though, take some credit for spending two years in Italy with Padova (after aborting a move to Coventry) without toning it down. He built a reputation in Serie A as a foul-mouthed New Age traveller, but enjoyed it. 'It was great, man, playing in Italy,' he explains. He gave up football in 1998 after meeting Pele ('Fuck, I mean, he's the man, all that sort of stuff just blows me away') to work with his band full time. His first major album, Ginger, was released in November that year. 'We just blew it out in two weeks in the studio,' he said. 'Man, it rocks.'

The Clarke verdict: I do know of this guy - I've never cut for him - but I quite like this. He breaks the rules - the top looks like he should be in an early Nineties Seattle grunge band, the bottom looks hard rock. He looks mad, I love it.

Cost: With a deft hand for the facial work, £150.

3 David Seaman
Seaman has needed a haircut from a proper, sensible £8-a-go barber for the past 19 years. Instead, the England keeper uses the likes of Belgravia's Errol Douglas - a celebrity stylist - and turns up at Highbury week in week out looking like a drug-weakened advertising executive in shorts. This season's adventure made the problem worse. In 1998, he was named most stylish sports star at the Elle Style Awards. Two years on he's just a 37-year-old with a ponytail. On leather-loving Emmanuel Petit, Roberto Baggio and even snooker's Peter Ebdon, it didn't look so bad. On Seaman, say the Helsinki press, it's a Soho porn merchant's dream.

The Clarke verdict: Ah, the infamous David Seaman. I'd like to think that no professional stylist would do this for him. It's kitsch, but surely not deliberately so.

Cost: Large tub of gel, clip and a band. £75. But, honestly, not one I'd want to see walking out of my salon.

4 Jason Lee
22 May 1996: the ultimate bad hair day. After a month of Fantasy Football's Frank Skinner and David Baddiel linking Lee's pineapple hair-do to his poor performances (Lee was depicted in then-Forest-manager Frank Clark's office failing to hit a tea cup with a sugar cube from six inches) the striker was transfer-listed, and a promising career left in ruins. Richard & Judy invited him onto This Morning for a phone-in, Nottingham nightclubs put on themed pineapple nights, the press hounded his family and, by June, the BBC were receiving more than 200 letters a week with pictures of pineapples in different settings. Lee, who had been Forest's top scorer, suffered badly. 'It was unbelievable,' he said. 'It went on and on and my family were hammered.' He left on loan, before permanent moves to Watford then Chesterfield. Now, with a freshly shaved head, he's rebuilding his career at Peterborough. The Clarke verdict: Well, it's not one of my favourites, but with afro hair, it is great to make the most of its ability to be sculpted. But not great for football, surely?

Cost: From scratch, £400.

5 George Berry
The worst/best afro of all time - big, square and in your face. Today George Berry is a bald PFA executive, but in the Seventies he was a bad haircut god, a Welsh international and considered by the rugby-playing Welsh wing of his Jamaican-Welsh family 'a big poof'. 'People think I had a square Afro because it was so big it never fitted into photo frames and the papers and magazines had to crop it that way. But there were plenty of big hairstyles around then - Remi Moses, Brendon Batson - but mine was the biggest and best.' Berry won a 1980 League Cup medal with Wolves, then moved on to Stoke, Aldershot and Stafford Rangers. Other exponents include the absurd Carlos Valderama - who ignored searing temperatures throughout his career to maintain his look - Alan Sunderland and the pre-bald Gianluca Vialli.

The Clarke verdict: I love the straight lines he's achieved. This was a popular look at the time, and apart from the practical problems, there's no arguing with it.

Cost: It would take an hour - £80

6 Peter Beardsley
There's something heroic about Peter Beardsley's hair. Any boy sporting this cut to school would be broken in minutes - but Beardsley has stood by it for over 22 years. Last year he was tipped as a great lover by the Sunday Mirror, who claimed 'research shows that women find it hard to resist the charms of ugly men like Peter Beardsley. They try harder to make their partner happy.' Beardsley though was also once named 'the only person who, when he appears on television, makes daleks hide behind the sofa'.

The Clarke verdict: Christ, he looks like a thin Ann Widdecombe. It is slightly worrying that a man should have this pre-teen Purdie arrangement.

Cost: He's actually got great hair. I'd thin the sides and contemporise the fringe. He could be cool. £50

7 Ralph Coates
A haircut so good they made a song about it. 'Grease Your Ralph', released in 1987 by Welsh band the Abs (and still available from specialist shops) was a tribute to Coates's combover - the only football combover widely considered better than Bobby Charlton's. When Coates tore down Burnley's wing, his hair travelled a second or two behind him - Charlton rarely held his with the same panache. Nobby Stiles was similarly inclined - and Bobby Mikhailov, ex-Reading and Bulgaria, once named 'cutest goalkeeper' by Bulgarian fans, wore a wig during games. Now, of course, a good bald haircut, modelled on David Beckham, will set you back £300.

The Clarke verdict: This sort of thing should never have happened. Maybe in '65 it wasn't as good to be bald as it is now, but this is absurd. However much grease or lacquer you put on, it'll not stick to the scalp - it'll just matt it all together.

Cost: We'd take this shorter, to a refined No 3. £70

8 Alan Biley
Mullet king Alan Biley comes in eighth for being a leader of this defining trend: Paul Walsh, Ron and Paul Futcher, Gerry Francis, Barry Venison, Colin Hendry, Chris Waddle, king of camp Mark Lawrenson, Bulgarian werewolf Trifon Ivanov and the whole of Eastern Europe - for whom it became the cut of choice throughout the Nineties - owe him a great debt. Today, Biley, a Seventies peroxide mullet legend for Cambridge, Derby, Everton and Portsmouth, manages Ryman League strugglers Barton Rovers after spells as a nanny, a landscape gardner and a council worker. But a mullet isn't always a bad thing. In 1996, after Spain's top sex symbol Julen 'El Guapo' (gorgeous) Guerrero was forced to cut his mullet by Athletic Bilbao's owner, female fans besieged the San Mames stadium for two days in protest. Top mullet fact: the word mullet comes from the nineteenth-century term 'mullethead', meaning 'moron' or 'fool'. Today the style is worn by those who consider themselves ironic.

The Clarke verdict: This chap's managed to do a mullet version of Joe Brown. The mullet's a Midwest American favourite - it's so ugly, and always has been.

Cost: If I really, really, had to leave the back long, £70

9 Claudio Caniggia
Caniggia wins credit for maintaining this cut, not only for 15 years, but to the detriment of his career. Told by Argentina coach Daniel Passarella in 1995 to have his 'girls hair' shortened or be thrown out of the squad, Caniggia - suspended for 13 months for cocaine use two years previously - chose the latter, and disappeared for six months. In 1998 his glam wife Marianna Nannis accused Diego Maradona of leading him astray: 'At times I believe Diego is in love with my husband,' she said. 'It must be the long hair and big muscles.' The Caniggias now live in Dundee following his unlikely move to Dens Park. In October 7,000 blond-wig wearing Scots watched him score a home debut screamer. Caniggia beats Derby's Taribo West, once master of Floella Benjamin bead chic, but now just a thinning Jason Lee wanabee.

The Clarke verdict: This again, I'm afraid, doesn't work at all. If he insists on keeping it long, he needs proper extensions to give it volume. It just doesn't work. He's a good looking guy and should do himself a few favours.

Cost: I'd rather not, but if someone insisted on having this look, with the necessary extensions, £300

10 Socrates
A fantastic player best known for chain-smoking at half-time, Brazilian legend Socrates was probably the hairiest man ever to feature in top level football (apart from Richard Keys). A star of the 1982 and 1986 World Cup finals, Socrates, also a qualified doctor, was an outspoken political dissident with grooming to match. His sense of style earns him 10th spot - Everton troll Abel Xavier, Gazza's hair extensions and the wild man of hair Terry Hurlock all just miss out.

The Clarke verdict: Oh, I like Socrates, big and butch - and he does look like a Socrates too, doesn't he? If you put this on an Englishman it would look daft, but it works here because of his deep set eyes.

Cost: A delicate cut, plus blow dry, £75.

Justifying his selection

This month's 10 were selected by Observer football writer David Hills. Here he explains his choices:

It's not trivial: footballing perms and mullets should never have hit Europe as hard as they did. But it happened, they caught on and bad taste defined at least three generations of professional athletes and their fans.

There is, of course, a reason - hairdos for footballers, dressed in uniform strips, are the only way of expressing personality through image - hence, presumably, David Beckham's close crop. And it's always been this way. During a match in the Fifties, Bobby Johnstone, a flying winger for Hibs and Man City, pulled a comb out of his pocket, put his foot on the ball and took five minutes to comb his slicked-back quiff into place.

Nicky Clarke, when we met at his London salon to talk hair, was disgusted by what he saw. 'This is awful. On the whole, I guess footballers have always tended to wear contemporary styles but with a two-year time delay. These mullets and perms were all on the streets, but footballers persisted long after the fashions had changed.

'These days, perhaps, players are getting more wary of extravagance. We have footballers in here - and golfers, boxers, racing drivers - they're all much more understated than they would have been 10 years ago. Take Beckham. I happen to think Beckham has great taste, but people with great taste don't get it right all the time. His old look was good, but this new, neutral shave does absolutely zero for him. He's still good looking, but it's such a shame he didn't stop at some of the stages in between fop and bald - I do wonder if the guy who did it tried various new styles, none of which worked, until he had nothing left to play with. He just looks like a thug now, but, I suppose, better that than a mullet.'

As for the top 10 choices: there were plenty of near misses, of course, but this is a representative set. And why so few perms? 'They're too freakish,' says Nicky. 'Voller's says it all. I haven't given anyone - man or woman - a perm since the Seventies, and even then under great duress.'

Now you have your say

Enraged by our choice? We thought so, and we want to hear why. Write and tell us who your 10 would be, justifying your selection in no more than 50 words. A selection of your 10s will be published next month.

fields.bodyText: 1 Rudi Voller Peter Shilton paid for his in champagne, Terry McDermott, Phil Thompson, Graeme Souness, Kevin Keegan and Craig Johnston greased theirs daily, but Rudi Voller was and remains queen of the perm. The style's greatest moment came when, during the 1990 World Cup, it collected and held, glue-like, the spit of Frank Rijkaard, leading to the Dutchman's famous red card. Voller remains one of the most popular men in Germany. He narrowly beats retired Austrian striker Toni Polster to the title - Polster wore his monster-perm with white socks and gold jewellery. He now has his own fashion label. Nicky Clarke's verdict: Oh god, oh god. This is just so... He's managed to combine Steve Coogan's Paul Calf with Harry Enfield's Scousers, and be German at the same time. Oh god, no, absolutely awful. Cost of the style in Clarke's London salon: No way. I'd do all the others if pressed, but if I was asked for this in all seriousness I'd refuse. No way. 2 Alexi Lalas If you're going to be a ginger Detroit rocker-cum-footballer, you might as well look like it - which is why Lalas only makes second in the list. It's a shocking set of facial hair devices - but whatever you think about him, Lalas is totally true to himself: bad haircut, bad musician, bad footballer. He does, though, take some credit for spending two years in Italy with Padova (after aborting a move to Coventry) without toning it down. He built a reputation in Serie A as a foul-mouthed New Age traveller, but enjoyed it. 'It was great, man, playing in Italy,' he explains. He gave up football in 1998 after meeting Pele ('Fuck, I mean, he's the man, all that sort of stuff just blows me away') to work with his band full time. His first major album, Ginger, was released in November that year. 'We just blew it out in two weeks in the studio,' he said. 'Man, it rocks.' He breaks the rules - the top looks like he should be in an early Nineties Seattle grunge band, the bottom looks hard rock. He looks mad, I love it. Lee, who had been Forest's top scorer, suffered badly. 'It was unbelievable,' he said. 'It went on and on and my family were hammered.' 'People think I had a square Afro because it was so big it never fitted into photo frames and the papers and magazines had to crop it that way. fields.headline: Stefan Schnoor
fields.trailText: Initially playing for Derby, Stefan was the one that got away...
fields.body:
 In early November we interviewed Stefan Schnoor. At the time the 29-year-old German defender was with Derby County. He joined the club in 1998, and when we asked him how long he would be staying in English football he said: 'I don't know. My contract is up at the end of the season, but I would be happy to stay.' In fact he had only a few more days left. On 13 November Derby swapped him for Wolfsburg's Scottish international defender Brian O'Neil. From his answers it seems unlikely that the move was his idea. At the time of going to press he had yet to play for Wolfsburg.

Age: 29
Birthplace: Neumunster
Position: Defender
Joined Derby on a free transfer under Bosman ruling in 1998
Appearances: 55 (14)

Did you get to see English football as a child, and did you support anyone?
When I was very young, not too much. It was only when there was a special game on a Sunday afternoon. As I got older, with digital TV I got to see more and more, especially European games. I always looked out for Liverpool's results, and always admired Kevin Keegan because he used to play for Hamburg.

First played professional football for?
SV Hamburg, Germany.

How did your move to England come about?
I was on a Bosman, I had played for seven or eight years at Hamburg and it was the right time to make a change. For me, I was always likely to come to England, I liked the football, so when I got the chance to join Derby I said yes straight away.

Had you heard of them before you joined?
Yes.

What were your first impressions of English football?
It's a very high-tempo game - more physical, the atmosphere in the stadiums is very noisy. I like the character and mentality of the English players. They are all honest and there is no cheating. As a foreigner that was a big surprise. There are a lot of hard tackles but you know when someone is on the floor he really is injured. It is different with the foreigners. It was something that, when I first came over, I had to get used to. I read the papers and see other foreign players moaning about playing too many matches and that the tackles are too hard. I think when you go abroad you can't do that - you have to accept the game and their style and be quiet. You shouldn't say things like Frank Lebeouf does. Who does he think he is? If he thinks France is the best, he should fuck off and go back.

Where are you living now?
I stayed in a hotel for the first six weeks, until my house was ready for me to move into.

Have you got any family over with you?
I am married to my wife Nicole and we have an 18-month-old daughter. The rest of my family is back in Germany. I go home a couple of times a year. This summer I went back for six weeks. My wife goes back more than I do because we're having a house built, which she checks up on. A lot of the time my family and friends come over to visit me and see a game or whatever.

How does the training differ to what you are used to?
There are so many games in this country, that there is a lot less training than in Germany. In Germany if you are bottom of the league you would be out training twice every day, we have the mentality that if things are not going well you have to work and try twice as hard to put things right again. Here the coaches try to relax you as much as possible to get you in the right frame of mind to concentrate on the next match.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
I watch a lot of sport, play golf. I've tried watching cricket but I don't really understand it and it doesn't really interest me. There are loads of things to do, I read the newspapers, play with my baby, or go shopping in Manchester or London. Derby is quite central so it is easy to go places. Or go out for meals, you have every type or restaurant here.

Have you learned to speak English?
I learned it at school. It is the first foreign language you are taught in Germany. Then through holidays and films you learn more and more. So it wasn't a big problem for me. I settled in very quickly, I spoke quite good English before I came here so I was able to understand everything I was being told - apart from the Scottish boys!

What do you like and dislike about living in England?
Life is more quiet and relaxed in England. On the roads people here are patient. In Germany everyone is angry, shouting or beeping their horns at each other all the time. Also people in England are much better at queuing for things, like taxis or buses. You don't get that in Germany - there it's just whoever pushes their way to the front. Things in England are much more expensive - cars, clothes, food. I don't miss Germany at the moment though because I know I'm going to be here for a certain number of years working, then I'll go back home. So I'm enjoying it.

Is the atmosphere in the dressing room different to other countries?
No, I think it largely the same throughout the world. When you lose obviously everyone is disappointed. There is a certain amount of good-natured rivalry about the German national team. When we are doing badly, like during the Euro championships, I got a bit of stick but I can always do the same about the England team, it's all just a bit of fun really.

B> How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
Here the fans are more supportive of their team, they put their hearts into it. The things I read about the big teams with the star players were all true. There is a special atmosphere in English stadiums, completely different to Germany where you slaughtered by the fans when you go on to the pitch, especially if you are doing badly.

Have you ever experienced racism by opponents or opposing fans?
No.

How long do you think you will stay in English football?
I don't know. My contract is up at the end of the season, but I would be happy to stay.

webTitle: Builders pay for trade boom with their lives

fields.headline: Builders pay for trade boom with their lives
fields.standfirst: Dozens of workers are killed on construction sites in Britain as safety standards slip in the race to cash in
fields.trailText: Dozens of workers are killed on construction sites in Britain as safety standards slip in the race to cash in.
fields.body:
The only comfort for the families was that the victims died instantly. When the derelict building in Hull collapsed around them, the three workers barely stood a chance. The construction industry had just created three new widows, and four more children would never see their fathers again.

Riding the crest of a building boom, parts of Britain's construction industry are sacrificing workers' lives in the pursuit of profit. Industry sources have told The Observer that at least 120 workers are believed to have been killed last year, the highest total for a 12-month period since 1991.

Safety campaigners say accidents are becoming increasingly common all over the country and especially in the South-East where an influx of poorly trained - but cheap - Eastern European workers has seen safety standards plummet.

It took 24 hours to recover the bodies of Shaughan Walsh, 43, Tony Laughton, 38, and Dave Jowett, 44, from beneath tons of rubble in Hull. Shaughan and Laughton had been on their first day of work. Shaughan's brother Kevin Walsh said: 'People call it an incident, or an accident, but it is not like that for me. As long as I live it will be the day somebody murdered my brother, his best mate and another close friend.'

Walsh and other relatives want someone to be prosecuted in a case that sums up many of the problems with the industry as a whole. The men were told to work on the site to demolish a burnt-out warehouse, even though safety inspectors had declared part of the building unsafe two months before.

The site's foreman, Moisi Miha, has since disappeared despite police efforts to track him down. Miha is a Kosovo Albanian who entered the country in 1998 and could still be working in the building trade.

'They should not have been working on that site at all. They should have just demolished it with machines,' said Stewart Emms, a local official with Ucatt, the largest construction union.

Latest fatality figures show that, wherever the blame might lie, accidents are on the increase. Last year alone two men died in Staffordshire after a tunnel collapsed on them, four men fell to their deaths off the Avonmouth Bridge and three died in London when a crane collapsed at Canary Wharf. Over 100 other deaths failed to make major headlines.

'The problem with construction is that the deaths come in ones, twos and occasionally threes and so don't make big waves. webTitle: Recession fear  brings New Year gloom

fields.headline: Who's for a dip in 2001?
fields.standfirst: Fears of recession are giving Britain a severe dose of New Year gloom, reports  John Arlidge
fields.trailText: Fears of recession are giving Britain a severe dose of New Year gloom, reports John Arlidge .
fields.body:
David Kanzen dragged himself out of bed at seven o'clock last Tuesday morning. The flu he caught at the office Christmas party was worse than ever and his head was fuzzy with too much cheap New Year's Eve Cava. He walked through the rain to catch the 8.05 to London Bridge but the train was delayed 'due to flooding'. On the platform hundreds of bleary-eyed commuters cursed the rotten weather, the rotten railways and the rotten New Year.

Britain struggled back to work last week with a bad case of post-holiday depression. Psychologists said all we needed was a 'duvet day' to buck us up, but in the City, Westminster and the boardrooms of Britain's biggest companies, the diagnosis was far gloomier. The year-long millennium party of high earning and high spending was over, commentators said, and the recessionary hang-over was kicking in.

Waiting on the sodden platform, Kanzen, who runs his own financial services company, needed little persuading that the bad times were around the corner. 'In 1999 I made almost £85,000 and took my wife and two children to Las Vegas to see Elton John. Last year I lost money. I think it's time to go into survival mode.'

What's worrying Kanzen and thousands like him around the country is the growing evidence that the economy is slowing down. It is too early to say whether a recession is on the way, but analysts say that, from the stock market to the high street, there is an unmistakable chill in the air. 'We will all be tightening our belts in 2001,' says Paul Edwards of the Henley Centre for Forecasting. 'The only question is how tight.' Ruth Lea, head of the Institute of Directors, agrees: 'The economy is slow.'

Over the past five years Britons have worked harder, earned more and spent more than at any time since the 'greed is good' 1980s. From dot.coms to pop stars, dirty cash and conspicuous consumption were hip. Is the party over? The tills and cash machines may be working overtime in the January sales but new figures show most retailers have had the worst year for a decade. Analysts Seymour Pierce predict one in three retailers will announce a fall in profits.

It is the same story among manufacturers. Car production is expected to drop by more than 10 per cent this year as Ford ends more than 70 years of manufacturing at its Dagenham plant in east London and Vauxhall pulls out of Luton. Overall, growth in the UK manufacturing sector is stagnant.

If the high street and traditional metal-bashing industries are hurting, the new economy is in intensive care. On average one dotcom is going under every week as consumers say 'letsbinit' to sites like Letsbuyit, Clickmango, Boxman and Breathe.

The slump in the value of internet start-ups and hi-tech shares last year dragged the FT 100 share index down to its worst performance for a decade. Even property, that traditional one-way bet, is going off the boil. House prices suffered their steepest fall in a single month for six years last month, dipping by 1.1 per cent.

Alarmed by evidence of a downturn, economists are starting to worry about spiralling consumer debt. Official figures show the amount borrowed by consumers over and above their mortgages has doubled since 1995. If the economy slows, borrowers may begin to default, prompting a round of bankruptcies and repossessions last seen more than a decade ago.

The first week of January rarely brings joy to mankind. The festive season is over, the children have not gone back to school yet and the credit card bills are falling on the mat. Is the sense of gloom just an acute case of Seasonal Affective Disorder?

Not so, says a new survey by Future Lab, social forecasters who conduct research for Britain's biggest advertisers. Britain's mood is changing. 'The evidence from the last two months is that fear, uncertainty and doubt are replacing the optimism that has characterised the past few years,' the report's author, Martin Raymond, says.

If the bubble has burst, it will be areas like Islington in north London that will be the first to feel it. With its proximity to the City, the fashionable borough rode the crest of the boom. For now it seems that the good times are over. House prices have stopped rising and at the end of last year demand tailed away. Local estate agent Colin Evans said: 'The wild rises and big spending of the last four years are over.' It is a refrain echoed by shoppers. 'Recession was a word you just didn't think about, but now you see it in the headlines and you have to be careful,' said Joanna Hall, 37.

For the moment, most economists agree, the sky is not going to fall in. While America may have spooked itself into slashing interest rates last week, Britain is still enjoying growth, inflation is low and there is pressure on wages.

But, the Future Lab study concludes, if a slowdown in America spreads beyond the world's largest economy and sparks global panic, Britain could be in for a bumpy ride. 'Enjoy 2001 while you can,' Raymond advises. 'The next change in the climate could be bracing.' Fasten your seatbelts.

webTitle: Britons flee Venezuela after 4-year jail horror

fields.headline: Britons flee Venezuela after 4-year jail horror
fields.trailText: Two young Britons, jailed for attempting to smuggle drugs out of Venezuela, have broken their parole and fled back to England after fearing they would be killed, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
Two young Britons, jailed for attempting to smuggle drugs out of Venezuela, have broken their parole and fled back to England after fearing they would be killed, The Observer can reveal.

James Miles and Paul Loseby were detained at the airport in the capital, Caracas, in November 1996. They were found to be wearing waistcoats filled with packets of cocaine and claimed they had been forced to carry the drugs by a man who had threatened them with a gun.

Speaking exclusively to The Observer from his family home in Leicester, Miles said: 'It's fantastic to be back. I am still coming to terms with it. So much has happened over the last four years, I've been through so much. The worst thing has been losing contact with all my friends and being away from my family. I feel like a stranger now. Everyone has moved on, apart from me.'

Miles was just 18 and on his first trip abroad at the time of his arrest. He and Loseby were initially held in a police detention centre in Caracas where they had to share a single toilet with 70 other prisoners. They were then moved to the notorious Yare 1 prison an hour's drive from the city which, according to Amnesty International, has been the scene of appalling human rights abuses.

'The conditions were like hell. At first we were scared because everyone had knives. So we had to get knives as well.'

At one point he and Loseby were attacked by prison guards demanding a cash bribe. They refused to pay and were dragged at gunpoint from their beds before being stripped and beaten. Miles was left with severe bruising while Loseby required medical treatment for multiple lacerations. Conditions in the prison were also extremely unhygenic. Last year Loseby contracted tuberculosis, from which he is still recovering.

Last May Miles and Loseby were released on parole. Miles said: 'Even though we had been released on parole, we still had to return to the prison every night. At weekends we would live on the streets the whole time because there was nowhere else to go.

'We had to get out of the country otherwise we would have been killed. The prisons were bad enough but it was actually more dangerous on the streets. Everyone there was a pure thief. The people were all so poor they didn't have anything, apart from a gun. The police would come along and kill them for no reason.

'We lost count of the number of times we got attacked or threatened. We knew people in the prison, we had friends there. Living on the streets, there was no one to help us but ourselves. There were shootings and killings all around us all the time.'

The pair survived on money sent by their parents. They expected to get work but soon discovered that it was not possible because they did not have the necessary permits.

'Any money we earned would have gone straight to the government anyway so in the end we didn't bother.'

Under the terms of their parole they were not allowed to leave Venezuela but after witnessing a vicious attack on street people last month, they decided to try to get back home.

Miles's family was unwilling to discuss the exact method used to get the young men out of Venezuela but both are believed to have used money sent by their parents to bribe officials in order to board an outgoing flight.

The pair arrived back in the UK shortly before Christmas but the news was kept quiet by their families. 'Jimmy's not had a proper Christmas with his family for five years. We didn't want anyone to know about it,' said his father Steven.

James Miles now hopes to find work in the building trade and attempt to rebuild his life.

Venezuela has informed the British Foreign Office that the men have failed to meet the terms of their parole but it has not asked Britain to take any action. There is no extradition agreement between the countries.

fields.headline: Cheeky chappie
fields.standfirst: The man behind dance music pioneers Faithless  talks about his new concept album... and his mother
fields.trailText: The man behind dance music pioneers Faithless talks about his new concept album... and his mother
fields.body:
Rollo Armstrong says he is a lucky man. He is a talented songwriter and producer, with a good ear for a pop hook and a knack for making it seem underground and quirky. But when I point that out he laughs and says that doesn't always mean you end up doing what you love for a living.

Eight years ago, he was working in a JobCentre. He had no musical training but samplers had begun to make it possible to make records without playing instruments or having access to expensive studios, so he teamed up with two friends and made a dance track. His old school-mate, the Radio 1 DJ Judge Jules, said it was all wrong and didn't stand a chance of success. But the record was 'Don't You Want Me?' by Felix, and it went to number six in the singles charts in the summer of 1992.

Now, Rollo says he has almost everything he wants. He gestures happily around his well-equipped recording studio near his home in Highbury, north London. Somehow, he's made a career out of producing dance music that goes against the grain. When he released Reverence, the first album by the pop/dance collective Faithless on his small independent label Cheeky in 1995, he saw it as a kind of sampler, a chance for him and his friends to showcase their varying talents. It encompassed everything from rap to techno, folk whimsy to a Tom Waits-like ballad. But the songs were unusually strong, Faithless toured endlessly to spread the word, and, although ignored at first, the album eventually sold millions, as did its equally eclectic follow-up, Sunday 8pm.

Rollo isn't interested in being famous. He did the sound on the first Faithless tour but says going on stage would have been pointless, since he couldn't play anything. As soon as he could, he returned to the studio to continue making records, including part of an album by his sister Dido, who has just broken America and looks set to replicate that success here.

He rarely agrees to be photographed, and this is a rare interview to promote Dusted, the project he has worked on with Mark Bates, a keyboard player who toured for a while with Faithless.

Their first album, When We Were Young, is a lush, ambient electronic soundscape, a warm bath of a record in which the listener can simply float, oblivious, on a surface of mellow beats and beautiful songs, or choose to explore the darker depths which lie beneath.

Although the term is now much-maligned, Rollo is happy to call it a concept album: 'There was a definite idea behind it. It's written as a sequence.'

The record is about childhood, about its joys but also its pain and frustrations. Some of the memories it documents seem to be troubled, but it's also about looking back as an adult - he is 33 now - making peace with those memories, finding forgiveness and understanding and the hope that we can do better with our own children that our parents did with us.

The album has been out since last summer but only now has Rollo agreed to release a single from it, 'Always Remember to Respect and Honour Your Mother', featuring angelic choirboy vocals and an animated video full of ambiguous demons.

When pressed to talk about his own childhood, Rollo finds it hard to go into too much detail. He has no wish to hurt anyone. His mother is a poet who he describes as 'quite eccentric'; his father is a publisher who would read him history instead of bedtime stories. They lived in a house full of books, but with no television or any awareness of what it meant to call your kids Rollo and Dido, then send them to a tough north London comprehensive with, in Rollo's case, trousers that were far too short and hair that was far too long. Luckily, he observes dryly, he was good at football.

His mother had a difficult childhood and later battled with depression. 'She was a highly intelligent woman who gave up her career to bring up kids. And though full of love, up to a point she held that against us and the world in general. We had some great times when she was happy, had lots of lovely moments, but when she was sad it could be quite a heavy experience.'

Rollo's own attitude to life seems relentlessly upbeat. After long negotiations, he recently sold Cheeky to the major label BMG. The success of Faithless enabled him to sign a roster of talented friends, but when their records were finished he was suddenly faced with the responsibility of marketing them, of organising what had become quite a large company. Realising he couldn't cope, he found a major label that could. 'Which was an enormous relief not just to me, but to all the artists.'

So now he can stay in his studio undisturbed, give or take the odd nightclub or football game. This year there will be a new Faithless album and debut albums by Cheeky artists such as Skinny and Rob D. He will also be working on a new Dusted album with Mark Bates and is thinking seriously about reworking his favourite musical, My Fair Lady. 'I think I'm a genuinely happy person,' he smiles. 'I definitely walk on the bright side of the road.'

'Always Remember to Respect and Honour Your Mother' is released tomorrow on Go Beat. When We Were Young is out now

He will also be working on a new Dusted album with Mark Bates and is thinking seriously about reworking his favourite musical, My Fair Lady. 'I think I'm a genuinely happy person,' he smiles. 'I definitely walk on the bright side of the road.' 'Always Remember to Respect and Honour Your Mother' is released tomorrow on Go Beat. When We Were Young is out now

fields.headline: I rode the perfect storm
fields.standfirst: Four years ago he answered an SOS and spectacularly saved a life. Last month, in furious seas, came his own Mayday call
fields.trailText: Four years ago he answered an SOS and spectacularly saved a life. Last month, in furious seas, came his own Mayday call.
fields.body:
In the least romantic place on Earth - a conference room of devastating soullessness inside a building in Eton High Street inhabited by management consultants - we are sitting, hardly breathing, watching the perfect storm.

Not the digitised, sanitised film of the same name - baby buckets of warm water landing gently on George Clooney while a thousand teen AppleMac wizards draw virtual designer waves - but the real thing, the Atlantic Ocean 700 miles west of Ireland in the middle of last month, as the sea moved from Force 11 storm to Force 12 hurricane.

The horizon is invisible. Waves of impossible fury climb over one other from all sides, spume flies so fast that a thick salt lace covers all: the entire sea, it seems, is trying to stand up and walk towards us. There is a terrible keening sound. Night is falling, fast, and the seas are still growing. The video ends, suddenly - and that is the last we see, possibly the last anyone will ever see, of Team Philips, the £4 million giant catamaran of luminous grace and speed which has swallowed the past five years of Pete Goss's life and which, for 10 long hours that night, prevented the worst that the bitter North Atlantic could throw at sailors from similarly swallowing Goss and his six crewmen.

'I had to stop the cameras about then,' says Goss, for whom the words 'practical' and 'understated' are simply inadequate, 'because I knew we might need the power for communications.' They did, sending out a Mayday - the first in Goss's 39 years, as Marine, yachtsman and adventurer - which led the next day to their touch-and-go rescue by a German container ship, and the sad abandonment of Team Philips to the Fates.

Goss later gave a press conference, in which he was reported as close to tears. 'Quite right, yes, I'll never be embarrassed about having emotions. It was heart-rending.'

This is the first time he has spoken face to face about that night. Meeting him this week has an added poignancy, in that the 'Race' has just begun - the French round-the-world free-for-all, devoid of classes or rules other than being first home and staying alive, which Goss and his team had spent all these years preparing for, and to whose starting line, at the stroke of the New Year, only six yachts made it.

'No, of course I'm not bitter,' he says, with a soft smile. 'I say bravo to them. The Race was always a double challenge - the first to make the start line, the second to make the finish, and we didn't make the first.'

There is no defensiveness - for, he says, he knows the boat worked. 'The concept worked brilliantly. She was a magnificent sail. I'm determined to show the videos, and tell people that it worked. If I was ever to enter another Race, it would be with the same boat and the same crew. It was just the seas, those impossible, very unusual seas. But she was magnificent, and she saved us...had we been in a 'normal' boat, I'm sure, we would not be alive today.'

Goss is no stranger to high and angry seas. Four years ago he turned around in the Southern Ocean during the Vendee Globe single-handed race after a Mayday, and sailed into the teeth of blattering seas for two solid days to rescue Frenchman Raphael Dinelli. Dinelli was an estimated 10 hours from death when Goss reached him. The first layer of his eyes, Goss tells me with a faint raising of the eyebrows, had been pebble-dashed off. 'But if you have a strong enough will to live then the body does start to feed off itself.' The pair are now best friends.

Goss had never before seen the combination of waves thrown up during his final sea-trials by December's Atlantic. 'There was a big depression off Newfoundland but I knew I'd be fine, could run back to the UK easily. But then, really unusually, the front in the depression created a new depression. You read about these phenomena, but you never really expect them.

'The pressure dropped 18 millibars in three hours, which was very, very frightening, it put the hair up on the back of your neck. This thing was generating right above us. We had this triangle of waves, all meeting, and generating rogue waves. Something would catch your eye and you'd think it was a cloud, and then suddenly realise it was a wave, twice the height of anything, travelling at a huge speed in a random direction, with a huge breaking face...it would come up and go off like a steam engine.'

Goss battened down his crew in survival suits, took the helm and got them through the night, steering desperately to avoid broaching; even with all sails down, trailing drogues and sea-anchors and every spare line out of the stern, they were still doing 32 knots. But she had taken such a battering that he feared the steering would be damaged by another storm, and a further hurricane was coming to meet them at 40 knots. He made what he admits was the hardest decision of his life and sent the Mayday.

He must have thought, often, that he was going over. 'Yeah. The rudders were coming 15 feet out of the water. You'd go into a wave and think, this is it, we've bloody had it. But she would drag us out of it. And she never really, with hindsight, took me somewhere I didn't want to go. So the concept was safe.

'I'm not a risk taker for the sake of it. I've got a family, and I want to come home. The reason I do it is because I love it. There are times I've been really frightened, but there is this thing that knowledge dispels fear, and so you minimise risk wherever you can.'

Did he think he would ever feel too much fear to carry on? And did he end up hating the sea? 'No, I love the sea. But the sea rules, there's never been any doubt about that. I feel privileged to have been able to experience that - never seen a storm like that before. It was probably the most frightening and most dangerous sail I've ever had - but it was also the most exhilarating.

'And the fear..oh, God, I'm not one for sitting around staring at my navel. But I remember there was one guy who was getting hypnosis to help him deal with the fear of death. I thought, bloody hell, if I felt like that I wouldn't go. What's the point?'

His Boy's Own stoicism may be maddening to some, for Pete Goss is not a whirling hotbed of emotion. But his character means he can bounce back and plan again, even though he's promised not to commit to anything for three months. 'I had a brilliant year last year, tremendous ups and downs, like 10 years of life condensed into a year - and it was a success, for Team Philips was about much more than just a boat. But I'm just going to enjoy life for a bit, see my family.'

And sail? 'Maybe. Although I don't have..' he smiles... 'I can't afford a boat.'

Too often, sadly, the nature of obsession can mean that, if failure follows, what once looked brave and focused can end up looking faintly ridiculous. That Pete Goss and his quiet confidence will succeed in the end is not in doubt; for I don't think I've met anyone less ridiculous in my life.
