fields.headline: Calculated to confuse
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean reveals secrets of making your tax return pain free
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean reveals secrets of making your tax return pain free.
fields.body:
If you are filling in your own tax return this month, you could be in for a shock. The calculation for the tax due has expanded from 8 pages to 28 since last year - becoming so complicated that even professionals admit to getting it wrong if they use pen and paper rather than software.

You can thank Chancellor Gordon Brown for the new complexity. Even if your affairs are fairly straightforward, you could still find yourself, for instance, calculating your tax liability at six different rates for 1999/00 - zero, 10, 20, 23, 32 and 40 per cent. 'The potential for error in the tax calculation is very high if you are doing it yourself,' says Marco Spano of accountant HLB Kidsons in Hove, East Sussex.

But there are ways of limiting the pain. 'If you get the calculation wrong, the Inland Revenue should spot it and will tell you,' says John Whiting of PricewaterhouseCoopers. But if you think you could get it wrong, you may want to err on the generous side - otherwise you will find yourself being charged interest at 8.5 per cent on any shortfall. Although the Revenue should discover all calculation errors, it could take them a couple of months to do so at this time of year.

As well as getting the tax return in by 31 January, many taxpayers - particularly those with self-employed earnings or income from letting out property - are due to pay some tax on that date. There is an automatic £100 fine for returns which come in late - although, after a legal challenge in 1999, this deadline has been pushed back to include tax returns which are on the mat when Inland Revenue offices open up for business on 2 February. Late payments of tax attract the interest charge and a 5 per cent surcharge on sums relating to the 99/00 tax year if still unpaid on 28 February.

Another way round the problem is still to ask the Inland Revenue to calculate your tax bill for you. The Revenue tries to encourage people who want the calculation done for them to get the return in by the end of September - but will do the calculations all the year round.

If you follow this route, and think you have some tax to pay, you could make a rough estimate for yourself and pay in that sum to reduce your chance of being charged interest.

The 28-page Inland Revenue calculation is designed to cover every possibility for every taxpayer, so you could produce your own tailormade procedure, if your confidence in your arithmetic is strong enough. Similarly, you could take advantage of the tax calculator on the Inland Revenue website (under Self-Assessment).

But before you reach the calculation stage, you need to gather together the basic information. 'If the worst comes to the worst, nearly every bank provides details of interest payments over the phone,' says tax adviser Richard Murphy. 'And most companies will say on their websites what their dividend is per share.'

Most employers can readily supply your income information (but make sure you write down income after payments into a company pension scheme - otherwise you can lose some of your hard-earned tax relief) and details of benefits in kind.

You also need to check that you have all the pages you need in the tax return: if you need the pages for partnership, for example, or share schemes, you can download them from the Inland Revenue website or ring up the orderline and ask for them.

Higher-rate taxpayers should get the benefit of any charitable contributions they made.

Charitable giving was made easier for the Millennium - and you can claim back your higher rate of tax on donations where you gave the charity your name and address. Murphy thinks that this is such a donor-friendly system that it is 'open to abuse'. All you need to have done was make a donation to a charity in a recorded, structured form - by cheque, for instance, rather than into a collecting tin - and given the charity your details. You only need to have given the charity your details once in the year for the subsequent payments also to qualify for the tax relief. You do not need to have a receipt for each donation: a note in your diary or on cheque stubs would do.

The charity will have claimed tax relief on your donation, assuming you paid tax at the basic rate - but you can also benefit by claiming back the difference between higher- and basic- rate on the sum.

As you go through the tax return, you should remember that some assets and income are outside the tax system - individual savings accounts and Child Benefit, for instance, and do not need even to be mentioned on the form. Similarly, if you are letting out a room in your house under the 'Rent A Room' scheme, you do not have to put down details. If your circumstances have changed from last year, or you think that some figures look odd, you run the risk of inviting difficult questions from the Inland Revenue - or even unleashing a dreaded 'inquiry' or investigation.

Jane Moore of the charity TaxAid says: 'If you are using estimates instead of actual figures, it is a good idea to disclose the reasons why on the bits of white space that are on the form.' So a short explanation - 'my freelance income dropped 50 per cent this year while I went travelling around the world' - could save you a lot of heartache later on.

Another useful move is to put your daytime telephone number down where you are given the option to do this on page seven of the return. 'It's worth doing this,' says Moore. 'If there is a query, the person inputting the information may use the telephone number. But if they can't get hold of you, they may just reject the return.'

And if you cannot pay your 31 January bill on time, you are also far better off negotiating. Moore says: 'Approach the Revenue as soon as you can. If you can set up an agreed payment arrangement before 28 February, they will probably waive the surcharge. Negotiations depend on the case - the person's compliance history, the size of the debt and what sort of proposal they have. If they think you can pay it off in two to three months, they'd probably be responsive to that. But if it's a year, they'd probably say no.'

The Inland Revenue has to work by instilling some fear into the hearts of potentially errant taxpayers. This year it has just been given a new weapon, the Fraudulent Evasion of Income Tax Act, which came into effect on 1 January. In theory, you can receive up to seven years in jail and unlimited fines for tax evasion but, in practice, it is aimed at fraudsters rather than the dopey or scatter-brained. Nevertheless, it is a reminder that the Revenue can make life very unpleasant for you if its officers discover long-standing oversights.

In projecting a tough image, the Revenue often undersells its helpful side. If you are confused about your tax return, staff in the tax inquiry offices can be extremely helpful. Also, there is much trumpeting about the £100 fines but you can only be fined £100 if you actually owe £100 or more. If you owe £43, your maximum fine is £43 for late filing of the return. If you owe nothing, your maximum fine is also nothing.

And then there is another option. 'Some people will just pay the £100 fine when there isn't any point in sending in a half-baked return,' says Sylvia Kalisch of European Media Ventures, a firm which specialises in tax issues for media clients. 'And some accountants' fees will go up for the month of January - so it may be cheaper to do it in February.'

webTitle: I'm not a sorcerer, pleads banned hypnotist

fields.headline: I'm not a sorcerer, pleads banned hypnotist
fields.trailText: France's highest court has ruled that evidence collected from witnesses while they were hypnotised by a former police officer is inadmissible.
fields.body:
France's highest court has ruled that evidence collected from witnesses while they were hypnotised by a former police officer is inadmissible.

'They think I'm a sorcerer, that I do Black Masses, incantations. It's ridiculous,' says Alban de Jong, 50, a Paris hypnotherapist who is determined his work should be taken seriously. 'But how can they say that helping a witness to remember should be illegal?'

Since 1995 more than 20 investigating magistrates have called on de Jong to help them in their cases. He has worked on three to five cases a year, often helping witnesses recover vital facts while under hypnosis and on several occasions providing crucial evidence that has helped solve puzzling cases.

But France's Cour de Cassation has decided that evidence gathered while a witness is under hypnosis cannot be used in court. If the investigating magistrate wishes 'to carry out investigations to uncover all information useful to establishing the truth,' said the court in its judgment, 'they must conform with the legal procedures for finding proofs'.

The court was ruling on the case of a policeman who witnessed an armed robbery during which a woman officer was taken hostage and one of their colleagues seriously injured. The policeman's only memory of the incident was seeing the robbers escape in an Audi 80 car. But under hypnosis by de Jong he recalled part of the registration number and, on the basis of this, the robbers were arrested and convicted.

'Hypnosis is only a means to help people to become less stressed and put their thoughts in order,' said de Jong, who insists he has the consent of witnesses before hypnotising them.

De Jong says he is not a hypnotist, but a hypnotherapist. Hypnotists, he says, are people in fairgrounds. He is also vice-president of the French Association of Legal Psychiatry and Psychology and insists the hypnotherapy he is asked to perform by criminal investigators has an important police role.

De Jong recalled that in 1998 a young man was found in a ditch 50 yards from a lane in southern Brittany. He was found to have a head wound in a helicoidal shape [the shape of a flattened coil or spiral]. But the man, reportedly of less than average intelligence and who had just passed his driving test, could not recall how he ended up in the ditch. 'Immediately the people in the area thought, because of the strange shape of the wound, his total lack of memory of what had happened, and that he had just passed his driving test, that it could have been an extra-terrestrial who attacked him,' said de Jong.

An investigating magistrate from the nearby town of Vannes called on de Jong to hypnotise the man in February 1999. Under hypnosis he recalled leaving a nightclub and setting off for home on foot, a journey of four or five miles. At one point, because he was tired, he sat on the side of the road.

Then he heard a car and stood up. The car hit the man and drove off, apparently without the driver realising what he had done. The young man described the car as 'a sky-blue Super 5', and the investigators tracked down the driver.

When interviewed the driver said he could not recall any such incident and had not been able to understand why one of his wing mirrors was broken. It turned out that a spring from the mirror was thrown from its casing in the collision, and it was the spring that gave the young man his head wound.

In another case, de Jong was employed by a lawyer whose client was suspected of murdering a child. The man could not recall what he was doing on the night in question. Under hypnosis his memory came back and he established an alibi that removed him from suspicion.

De Jong believes the information he can elicit with hypnosis is rarely conclusive proof but it can be useful in furthering an investigation. Hypnotising witnesses does not always help recall useful information. 'If people saw nothing, they will continue to see nothing.'

De Jong established a private hypnotherapy practice in Paris in 1989 and says his skills are hereditary - his grandfather possessed them. He was eight, he says, when he first put someone under hypnosis - a member of staff at his boarding school. Between 1973 and 1988 he served as a police officer, and his hypnotherapy skills were regularly called upon.

He was called on in 1986 when terrorists were foiled in an attempted murder outside Tati department store in Paris. 'They wanted me to speak to one of the terrorists under hypnosis and find out if the group had planned any more outrages,' recalled de Jong. fields.bodyText: France's highest court has ruled that evidence collected from witnesses while they were hypnotised by a former police officer is inadmissible. 'They think I'm a sorcerer, that I do Black Masses, incantations. It's ridiculous,' says Alban de Jong, 50, a Paris hypnotherapist who is determined his work should be taken seriously. 'But how can they say that helping a witness to remember should be illegal?' Since 1995 more than 20 investigating magistrates have called on de Jong to help them in their cases. He has worked on three to five cases a year, often helping witnesses recover vital facts while under hypnosis and on several occasions providing crucial evidence that has helped solve puzzling cases. But France's Cour de Cassation has decided that evidence gathered while a witness is under hypnosis cannot be used in court. If the investigating magistrate wishes 'to carry out investigations to uncover all information useful to establishing the truth,' said the court in its judgment, 'they must conform with the legal procedures for finding proofs'. The court was ruling on the case of a policeman who witnessed an armed robbery during which a woman officer was taken hostage and one of their colleagues seriously injured. The policeman's only memory of the incident was seeing the robbers escape in an Audi 80 car. But under hypnosis by de Jong he recalled part of the registration number and, on the basis of this, the robbers were arrested and convicted. 'Hypnosis is only a means to help people to become less stressed and put their thoughts in order,' said de Jong, who insists he has the consent of witnesses before hypnotising them. De Jong says he is not a hypnotist, but a hypnotherapist. Hypnotists, he says, are people in fairgrounds. He is also vice-president of the French Association of Legal Psychiatry and Psychology and insists the hypnotherapy he is asked to perform by criminal investigators has an important police role. De Jong recalled that in 1998 a young man was found in a ditch 50 yards from a lane in southern Brittany. He was found to have a head wound in a helicoidal shape [the shape of a flattened coil or spiral]. But the man, reportedly of less than average intelligence and who had just passed his driving test, could not recall how he ended up in the ditch. 'Immediately the people in the area thought, because of the strange shape of the wound, his total lack of memory of what had happened, and that he had just passed his driving test, that it could have been an extra-terrestrial who attacked him,' said de Jong. An investigating magistrate from the nearby town of Vannes called on de Jong to hypnotise the man in February 1999. Under hypnosis he recalled leaving a nightclub and setting off for home on foot, a journey of four or five miles. At one point, because he was tired, he sat on the side of the road. Then he heard a car and stood up. The car hit the man and drove off, apparently without the driver realising what he had done. The young man described the car as 'a sky-blue Super 5', and the investigators tracked down the driver. When interviewed the driver said he could not recall any such incident and had not been able to understand why one of his wing mirrors was broken. It turned out that a spring from the mirror was thrown from its casing in the collision, and it was the spring that gave the young man his head wound. Under hypnosis his memory came back and he established an alibi that removed him from suspicion. De Jong believes the information he can elicit with hypnosis is rarely conclusive proof but it can be useful in furthering an investigation. Hypnotising witnesses does not always help recall useful information. 'If people saw nothing, they will continue to see nothing.' webTitle: Fast, funny and furious. But that was before it came down the M40

fields.headline: Fast, funny and furious. But that was before it came down the M40
fields.trailText:
The Rivals Barbican, London EC2

The Glass Slipper Southwark Playhouse, London SE1

Mother Goose Hackney Empire, London E8
fields.body:
The Rivals Barbican, London EC2

The Glass Slipper Southwark Playhouse, London SE1

Mother Goose Hackney Empire, London E8

What is it that makes Lindsay Posner's production of The Rivals, now at the Barbican after a much-praised debut in Stratford, seem cosy and distant, as if tailored for a matinée audience waiting to tick off the malapropisms before launching into a symphony of coughs?

No doubt something has been lost in the move from the readily charged space of the Swan, to the big stage of the Barbican, which hoovers up intimacy. It isn't fast, funny or furious enough. Ashley Martin-Davis's smart, light-filled design makes Bath into toytown: dolls' houses are pushed time-consumingly around to form crescents or parades; a massive gilt picture frame displays a sky with merry puffed-up clouds. This is an arena made for archness and frozen moments. The play becomes a series of comic turns.

Many of these are elegantly executed. David Tennant is poised and swift as the young male lead; Ian Hughes's hyper-scrupulous wooer vibrates with anxiety - when he says the word 'electric' his fingers become wind-shaken fronds. And as Mrs Malaprop, Wendy Craig offers not a predictable giddy flutter but the humorous condition of utter, solemn self-absorption. Faced with a home truth, she begins to crack; acknowledging her rejection at the end, she stands alone, with her back to audience and actors - a female Malvolio. She shows this best-known character is ludicrous not merely because she mangles her speech but because she's not young and pretty enough to make her vanity seem charming.

But Sheridan wrote a play, not a sequence of acts. Drawing on his own romantic entanglements and on his mother's writings for some of his best moments (among them the malapropisms), he produced - at 23 - a brilliantly well-rounded and coherent satire. The events are prompted by a young woman's absorption in sentimental novels; Mrs Malaprop's blunders are caused by her wish to appear erudite, and the play's refrain is the idea that a woman's brains can be 'turned by reading'.

The Rivals shouldn't only twinkle: it should be heartfelt and savage - but move so quickly that you're hardly aware of a human feeling until it's over.

Like the ladies of The Rivals, the heroine of The Glass Slipper is disparaged for being 'a mighty reader'. Southwark Playhouse is one of the most rapidly burgeoning small theatres in London: characteristically, it has come up with a lovely anti-panto. Stephen Sharkey's version of the Cinderella story has no overweight tinselled fairy godmother, no suggestion that the heroine is pretty because she's really a toff, no remorselessly cheerful Buttons. Cinders (appealing, forthright Alison Pettitt) is a simper-free zone and a brainbox. The Ugly Sisters (played with gleaming avidity by Hannah Stokely and Melissa Collier) are not at all hideous but made gruesome by their spiteful uppitiness.

Sharkey has used elements of the melancholy, humane version of the tale, in which Cinders is rescued by the love of her mother, whose ghost glides in and out of the action. In the beautiful opening scene, the dying mother sings to her baby daughter. Soutra Gilmour's haunting design has a copper kettle gleaming on the bare hearth and the scene is washed with a restful but eerie violet light.

To the accompaniment of airs played on harp, cello and clarinet, Sharkey supplies vignettes of eighteenth- century London: the ball takes place in a lamp-lit Vauxhall Pleasure Gardens; a hot-air balloon is described rising from Moorfields; Cinderella's father arrives spluttering about transport difficulties - just as he'd finished trying to bag tigers, his ship was blown off-course. The mission to educate means his lively play is occasionally earthbound, weighed down with data. But under Erica Whyman's direction it often soars - in the manner of the balloon which lifts its bold heroine to the ball.

Hackney had a wonderful dame this Christmas in the roly-poly shape of Clive Rowe. It was worth going to the Empire just to hear that apparently effortless, rippling voice, or to catch him in the bronze wig that looked like three balls of knitting wool, in the skimpy Tina Turner lurex outfit, or in sportif mode, with tiny peaked cap and pleated skirt.

It was also worth going to sit in the gorgeous, cash-strapped Empire itself, with its bravura mixture of grandeur and hurdy-gurdy.

And Mother Goose is the ur-pantomime. Even its title has the perfect nursery combination of wholesomeness and sauce. Susie McKenna's version featured the obligatory crude set and terrible puns ('I'm taking my cat to the mews-eum'). It also had a good and a bad witch (the latter played with gothic gusto by the author) and an enormous, winsome Goose called Priscilla, knock-kneed and - confusingly - pigeon-toed, who laid her eggs as if giving birth to giant quins. The now traditional telly-interest was provided by lithe and goofy Kat from MTV, and ex-EastEnder Troy Titus-Adams, who pulled off the sort of transformation any principal boy should be proud of. In front of me, a flaxen-haired toddler punched the air as to the manner born at every rallying cry of 'Hackney Born Heroes'. Next to her, two pert little girls practised slapping their thighs.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Thai telecom mogul on course to become Prime Minister
fields.body:
Thai telecom mogul on course to become Prime Minister

Telecoms mogul Thaksin Shinawatra is set to become Thailand's Prime Minister after winning yesterday's general election, despite allegations of graft. Exit polls forecast his Thai Rak Thai (Thais Love Thais) party would win twice as many seats as the the ruling Democrat Party of veteran Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai.

Cold snap kills 68 in India

Cold weather sweeping northern and eastern India has killed at least 68 people. Poor people living on the streets have been particularly at risk. Most cannot afford to buy warm clothing.

Amnesty accuses Turkey of torturing prisoners

Turkish prisoners transferred to new small-cell jails have been tortured and kept in isolation for long periods, Amnesty International says.

Thirty people have been killed during raids on 20 jails where inmates are protesting against the transfers. Some 1,000 prisoners have been moved to smaller jails because, the authorities say, they are easier to control.

Amnesty said the prisoners had been 'beaten and some tortured before, during and after the transfers to the new prisons'. Solitary and small group isolation was being imposed and many prisoners had gone without human contact for days apart from roll calls.

Playboy arrives

Forty-seven years after it was first published, Playboy has finally gone on sale in Malta - but the authorities, while admitting 'times have changed', will continue to vet each issue.

Safety suck

A Japanese man aged 70 choking on a sticky rice cake, a hazard of the festive season, was saved by his daughter, who used a vacuum cleaner to suck out the cake.

webTitle: Mexico City cleans up its act

fields.headline: Mexico City cleans up its act
fields.standfirst: The war on pollution
fields.trailText: The war on pollution.
fields.body:
The atmosphere is infamous here. For decades it has been a danger to the millions inhaling it. But something new is in the air.

It seems to be getting fresher - or at least less foul. This would be quite a change: in 1992, the United Nations called Mexico City's air the world's worst.

'That's no longer true,' said Dr Mario Molina, a Mexico City native leading the most intensive study of the problem yet undertaken. Molina, a chemistry professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, shared the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1995 for showing 20 years earlier that chlorofluorocarbons in aerosols, refrigerators and air conditioners were depleting the ozone layer.

There has been no smog alert for 15 months. Lead, carbon dioxide and sulphur dioxide in the air are down. On many days the air is clear enough to breathe with pleasure. While fair winds and rains may take credit, so do tougher environmental rules, with cleaner fuels, catalytic converters on cars, emissions tests and rules on industry.

The air quality index runs from zero to 500, with 300 or more representing hell on earth. Below 100 is officially satisfactory, 101 to 200 is unsatisfactory, and anything higher is a potential threat to life. In the mid-1990s, it exceeded 100 about nine days out of 10; simply breathing was like smoking two packs of cigarettes a day. Once, in 1996, it peaked at 394. The pollution level still often exceeds 100, but on Wednesday in the heart of Mexico City it peaked at 69, with a low of 9. Levels of sulphur dioxode, nitrogen dioxide, carbon monoxide and particulates were all 40 or less.

Molina and his wife, Dr Luisa Molina, a research scientist at MIT, are leading the Mexico City Case Study, part of a project at MIT exploring the problems of megacities in the developing world. They have brought together scores of government scientists, engineers and economists to find how to cut the smog.

This capital of nearly 20 million people brews a miasma from three million cars, buses and trucks, thousands of dirty companies and dump sites. They fill the air with toxic chemicals and particles of everything from metals to human waste. The Institutional Revolutionary Party, which until last year enjoyed a monopoly on power, had little incentive to press for changes.

In November 1996, a five-day smog emergency sent 400,000 people to hospitals and contributed to the death of 300 or more, according to city officials.

So what has gone right?

The petrol is cleaner than it was a few years ago. Pemex, the state oil company, took the lead out, upgraded its refineries, and since 1996 has quadrupled its gasoline imports from the United States. New cars have catalytic converters, which reduce carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxide. Some industries have become cleaner or moved away from Mexico City.

People in Mexico City burn more than two million tons a year of liquefied petroleum gas or LPG for cooking and heating - 70,000 barrels a day. Leaks of LPG add to pollution. Pemex reformulated the bottled fuel, removing butylene, a harmful ingredient, but the gas still leaks from millions of poorly maintained pipes and represents perhaps 15 per cent of air pollution in Mexico City.

The left-of-centre municipal government elected in 1997 proved more amenable to stiffer environmental regulations. The Mexico City study suggests that 'new technology exists that is clean enough to solve the problem to a significant extent', Molina said. 'But it's expensive. The main one would be clean cars, buses, trucks. The next set of changes are harder: repairing leaks of LPG, replacing pilot lights, the use of solvents in small industries and homes. For industries, you need clean furnaces.'

Thirty years ago, the air in Los Angeles was worse than it is in Mexico City today, Molina says. 'Mexico City's air can improve as much as Los Angeles's did, and in a shorter time,' he said. 'That's a goal that can be achieved.'

New York Times

webTitle: Suicides in Australia soar as good life proves elusive

fields.headline: Suicides in Australia soar as good life proves elusive
fields.trailText: Australia, once dubbed the Lucky Country and still considered by many immigrants as a land of sunshine and opportunity, is suffering a suicide epidemic which saw an average of six people kill themselves each day last year.
fields.body:
Australia, once dubbed the Lucky Country and still considered by many immigrants as a land of sunshine and opportunity, is suffering a suicide epidemic which saw an average of six people kill themselves each day last year.

New government figures show a rise in the last decade of 5 per cent to 14.3 per 100,000 of the population, giving Australia the fourth highest suicide rate in the world after the Russian Federation, New Zealand and Canada.

Young men are most at risk. More Australian males have died by suicide than by road crashes each year since 1990. The majority hanged themselves.

Britain is way down the international rankings with around half the proportion of suicides per 100,000 people that Australia registers. Abundant sunshine, beautiful beaches and one of the cleanest environments in the world do little to assuage suicidal tendencies among its male youth.

In fact, these seemingly idyllic surroundings can exacerbate feelings of insecurity and inferiority among those prone to take their own lives.

One academic believes a fabulous climate, a mood of economic optimism and a glowing international reputation as a healthy and successful nation intensify depression in potentially suicidal people.

Professor Jim Barber of Flinders University in Adelaide said images of bronzed lifeguards and toned beach goddesses put pressure on troubled youngsters and make them concerned that they feel down in a great place.

'If you are surrounded by people who are having fun and getting on and you are not and you are feeling miserable then you are relatively unhappy. So a suicide risk factor is, paradoxically, a happy country,' said Barber. 'You compare yourself with others and see them as much happier, so you feel isolated and out of step with your peers.'

His research challenges long-held beliefs that suicide is more likely among those living in economically depressed countries with bleaker climates.

In research to be published in next month's Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry, Barber also blames a lingering macho attitude to life. The rugged 'Aussie battler' spirit that built the nation is now doing it no favours by placing a stigma on men who look for help.

'When boys feel down and depressed they don't talk about it among themselves,' he said.

Many suicides are of gay men often repressed in small towns by Australia's still widespread homophobia.

'We have to promote more realistic images of growing up', said Barber. And we have to be able to get depressed people, especially men, to say when they feel down and to seek help.'

webTitle: Brutal murder of family heightens Japanese fears

fields.headline: Brutal murder of family heightens Japanese fears
fields.trailText: In the latest violent crime to dent Japan's image as a safe nation, police are investigating the brutal murder of a British company's employee and his family in Tokyo.
fields.body:
In the latest violent crime to dent Japan's image as a safe nation, police are investigating the brutal murder of a British company's employee and his family in Tokyo.

Mikio Miyazawa - who worked for Interbrand, a London-based marketing consultancy - was found dead in his home last weekend with multiple knife wounds to the neck. His wife Yasuko, a teacher, and their eight-year-old daughter and six-year-old son were killed in their beds.

Police believe the assailant or assailants entered the house looking for money or documents. Two empty wallets were found at the scene and papers were strewn around the house.

Interbrand, which specialises in corporate identity and branding strategies, has many high-profile clients. The company has offices in 19 cities worldwide.

Company officials were unavailable for comment, but colleagues of Miyazawa said they thought it was unlikely his murder was job-related. 'He wasn't working on anything particularly sensitive or controversial,' said one associate, interviewed on Japanese television. 'He was a congenial man who got on well with everyone - definitely not the sort of person to make enemies.'

The murders have added to fears of a breakdown in Japan's low-crime society amid high unemployment, large-scale illegal immigration and a widespread questioning of traditional values.

Television news programmes have repeatedly played video footage of Miyazawa's children - Niina in her ballet costume and Rei at his nursery school - and newspapers have avidly followed the police hunt for the killers.

Reflecting the intense public concern, the superintendent-general of the Metropolitan Police Department made a personal inspection of the crime scene - the first time that the capital's police chief has taken such a hands-on approach.

'This is an extremely brutal crime,' Takeshi Noda told detectives. 'Do whatever you can to arrest the culprit.'

fields.headline: Credit where credit's overdue
fields.standfirst: CA's Mick McAteer tells Maria Scott why he's taking on life insurers - and east London poverty
fields.trailText: CA's Mick McAteer tells Maria Scott why he's taking on life insurers - and east London poverty.
fields.body:
If Mick McAteer had continued in a previous career he would probably be deciding what to do with another fat City bonus now.

But he lives in a shared-ownership property and in his spare time is setting up a credit union in one of the UK's most deprived areas?. His full-time job, senior policy adviser on financial services with the Consumers' Association, does not bring a salary that allows for much indulgence. 'I'm not exactly rolling in it,' says McAteer.

He worked for fund management companies for several years before changing direction. Though he admits he misses the bonuses, he says: 'I am aware that CA is a charity. I'm not in it for the money.' He enjoys the campaigning, and believes it 'makes a difference'.

McAteer, 38, from Northern Ireland, took an unorthodox route to this position. Instead of a degree, he acquired computer skills, which made him marketable to financial institutions in the Eighties. 'It was coming up to Big Bang,' he says. 'The City was taking on anyone who could count.'

He was employed by fund manager Henderson to design spread sheets for share analysis and portfolio management, and later moved to Framlington. He enjoyed the City, but remembers some aspects of it as objectionable: 'It was a reflection of the times.' So, did he wear red braces?'I might have done,' he replies, coyly.

After a spell working in Northern Ireland for an organisation advising small businesses, he responded to an advertisement for a post on Which? magazine, again using his skills in data analysis. Later he switched to policy development and has been involved in CA's struggle over the distribution of insurers' 'orphan' assets, including the test case CA lost before Christmas against Axa. McAteer has also campaigned on freedom of information.

His City background was helpful when he began dealing with financial services companies. 'They were surprised you could answer a question about derivatives.'

He identifies life insurers as a source of much consumer misery. Investors cannot understand the products or charges, so cannot wield power in the same way as they can in a supermarket.

But he does not see the industry as a source of evil. 'There has to be an industry there to provide the products.' CA's concern, he says, is that that balance of interest lies with shareholders and not with consumers.

With a four-year-old son to help support, McAteer has little left over to invest, but would dabble in the stock market if he could afford it. 'I find the whole issue of investment very interesting. It is an ever-increasing part of people's lives.' He concentrates his savings efforts on boosting his pension through an additional voluntary contribution plan.

McAteer's attempt to set up a credit union in Hackney, where he lives, was inspired by credit unions in Ireland; his parents belong to one with 30,000 members. He believes a willingness to engage in social projects is 'part of the Irish thing'.

He has also been inspired by Lord Young of Dartington, founder of the CA and the School for Social Entrepreneurs: 'If you are steeped in the traditions and values promoted by Lord Young, you would see there are other ways to value things, not just monetary terms.'

fields.headline: Soft focus, hard truths
fields.standfirst: By day, Jessica Craig-Martin photographs America's finest for Vogue. By night, she tells the truth
fields.trailText: I Am a Camera Saatchi Gallery, London NW8, to 25 March
fields.body:
I Am a Camera Saatchi Gallery, London NW8, to 25 March

New Year in New York and the ladies who lunch are dining for charity at the Guggenheim, the Plaza and the Waldorf Astoria. You see their manicured hands in the photographs perform a ritual ballet: rearranging chiffon trains, plucking champagne flutes from salvers, fluttering a curt greeting at other filed and lacquered talons. The dresses are cut deep at an ageing cleavage or gathered in frothy celebration across a bony backside. Liquid tan glistens at wrist and sternum. A young breast is exposed by a liver-spotted hand. It's pure Alexander Pope, this looking-glass world - a conceit of powders, puffs and patches.

These photographs of fundraisers, galas and benefit dinners were taken by a young artist called Jessica Craig-Martin. They are among the many highlights of I Am a Camera, the first show of the year at the Saatchi Gallery. I don't know which is the more surprising - the quality of the exhibition, after such a sequence of duds at Boundary Road, or the fact that Craig-Martin, high-society satirist, has a day job covering the same subjects for that unctuous fanzine, American Vogue.

Not that you can actually identify the people in her pictures: the faces are always excluded from each shot. I thought I glimpsed Ivana Trump's peroxide beehive, but experts put me straight - the rocks on the mystery fingers weren't nearly big enough.

Identity is wealth, inventoried here in every compact composition: the expensive logo worn like a heart on the sleeve; the bare flesh encased in Versace chainmail; the silver nails struggling to secure a canapé that will never be eaten.

Above all, Craig-Martin records the unresisting uniformity of it all - the identical handbags with their platinum clasps, the queues of gold-heeled Blahniks in the restroom. Six million years of evolution and yet no free will; in this mineral world, lucre reigns queen.

For hard contrast, compare Craig-Martin's photographs with those of Nan Goldin on the opposite wall. They both work within an enclosed milieu, but Goldin snaps the demi-monde of Manhattan's Lower East Side, the junkies, poets, transvestites and musicians who have numbered her friends for the last 30 years. Quite apart from her flair for the nocturnal, lamp-lit scene, Goldin has a particular gift for friendship - people are too busy talking to her to notice the lens.

These pictures evolve like a novel. Characters emerge - the flirty old couple who finally get hitched; the young addicts, silent with rage, who end in tears. There are tipsy weddings, candlelit wakes, tattoos, scars and black eyes, some of them dealt to Goldin herself, often present in the subplot.

Two photographs might stand as the extremes of her work: a resigned shot of a woman's thigh, aptly marked with a heart-shaped bruise; and the pristine image of breakfast in a luxury hotel. Starched linen, silver spoons, melting croissants - this is exactly what Craig-Martin's socialites probably toy with every morning. But in Goldin's memoir of wrecked and reduced lives, these objects become emblems of beauty and calm, portrayed with all the reverence of a Chardin still-life.

The 100-odd photographs in this sequence, collectively titled 'Thanksgiving', were given a solo show elsewhere in London a couple of years ago. It's the same with Duane Hanson's marvellous hyper-real figures, the cleaners, bag ladies and blue-collar workers posted about the gallery like incidental members of the public. Ditto Richard Billingham's tremendous Fuji-film snaps of Ray and Liz, his parents, which are now deservedly as famous as the family romances of Bill Douglas and Terence Davies.

It might be argued that this exhibition could hardly fail, given that it accommodates such a brilliant trio of separate shows. But I Am a Camera goes further, introducing other new artists, in addition to Craig-Martin, whose work is photo-based. Tierney Gearon usually takes fashion photographs, but her independent work isn't remotely ephemeral, taking as its theme the constrained world of adults as experienced by children.

An infant, still bandy-legged from the recent tyranny of nappies, is halted in its faltering tracks by this snapping beast on a tripod. Another waits forlornly by the pool while his grandpa jaws on the mobile. Two kids puzzle over the pompous formality of a Stars and Stripes cake, or poke at some road-kill - half fascinated, half guilty. Was it their car? Is this supposed to be their birthday cake? Why is the world so slow and intractable?

Gearon's photographs are disquieting, shrewd and not remotely sentimental. Her subjects see right through the adults around them. They give just the jolt that children can and do, whenever they ask some piercingly rational but unanswerable question.

True to form, the gallery hangs some inferior artists on the coat-tails of their betters, in this case, painters who base their work on photographs. Jason Brooks plagiarises Chuck Close, in his own fatuous words, because 'nobody else is doing it'. Kristia Calabrese's interiors are empty, banal and badly painted.

But there are some stunning images here that hover so precisely between the media that you can scarcely tell whether they are photos that mimic paintings - or vice versa.

Hiroshi Sugimoto is best known for his pictures of the floating world, mirages of air and sea that have a Zennish, all-in-nothing grace. The work in this show is also made in black and white, but it is dramatically different - seven life-sized portraits, one man and six women, so startlingly realistic they seem to be frozen in some tableau vivant.

You recognise them immediately from Holbein's paintings - Henry VIII and his half dozen wives. Seven impersonators photographed in period costume? Or perhaps the artist himself in drag (they all have the same hands)? Paradoxically, these images could also have been painted by Ingres, with their classical drawing and fulsome detail - the unnaturally bright pearls, the silk ruffs and fur collars.

What they are is never disclosed and the more you look, the more your eyes deceive you. Time swims and Henry is confronted by all six wives, suddenly and simultaneously restored to eerie life.

webTitle: Money Writes: We debit a prize from the Bank of Luck

fields.headline: We debit a prize from the Bank of Luck
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I have won a gold prize, according to a Bank of Luck scratchcard that came through my letterbox from Isomatrix UK.

To receive the prize, I had to obtain a claim code by telephoning a premium rate number, or sending a stamped addressed envelope. I wrote, as it was cheaper, but received a reply saying I had to phone, or it would be 'unfair to other prize winners who have called the line'. I think this is misleading.
HM, Crewe

It is misleading, and Icstis, the Independent Committee for the Supervision of Standards of Telephone Information Services, agrees with you. This body monitors premium-rate services, which are numbers beginning with 090. Games promoters must not say you can write in for a code and then refuse to give it.

Last year, Icstis investigated complaints about other Isomatrix scratchcards and found that they did not describe adequately the prizes available: the most frequently awarded prize was 'a trip to France', but this included only ferry tickets for foot passengers. Robert Carrington, who runs Isomatrix, was warned about his future conduct.

Icstis also criticised Isomatrix for not providing an alternative route of entry to the premium-rate telephone number and demanded that this be included. Your Bank of Luck card was distributed last September, immediately before the adjudication. Isomatrix says you were wrongly told that you have to phone because, with major changes within the company, the letter to you was sent out in error. It has shown Icstis an amended version, now used, which has a claim reference number.

Isomatrix has agreed to honour your gold prize and you will be delighted to hear that you won a trip to France.

Cover cancelled: Firm owns up

My home insurance policy with CGU has been cancelled without my knowledge. I found this out when I asked why I had not received a renewal notice. I want my policy reinstated.
YH, London

Norwich Union, as CGU now is, admits it is entirely responsible for this mistake, which arose when you switched from paying by direct debit to paying the full year's premium in advance.

Its computer interpreted this as meaning you were cancelling the policy. In fact the policy was not cancelled, even though Norwich Union told you it was, so you have been continuously insured.

On renewal, the premium rose from £363 to £364.61, but the firm is refunding £100 as compensation.

Holiday failure: Card saves fee

We paid more than £2,500 last year while on holiday in the Canaries to join a holiday club through R&S Marketing. However, when we tried to book a holiday this year we found it had ceased trading. We paid using my Barclaycard Visa. Is there any way we can recoup our money?
LA, Chinnor

Barclaycard told me last September that, before it could investigate, you must write to them explaining what happened. You did so, and the card firm replied, saying you needed to prove breach of contract for your claim to succeed. You sent in your contract, and just before Christmas Barclaycard agreed to credit your account with £2,588.

Barclaycard says it cannot be sure the company is in liquidation because it is based abroad, but is satisfied it is not delivering the service customers have paid for. It will refund money to any Barclaycard customers who have been let down by R&S.

Missing shares: Records vanish

In the Fifties, on the advice of a friend, I invested £70 (10 weeks' wages) in shares in Thomas Poole & Gladstone China. I was a miner and in 1958 was under a fall of stone, suffering multiple injuries and memory loss. I have only recently recollected that at some time I was instructed to send the shares to an address in south London. I am 81 and the return of some of that £70 would be a great help.
ER, Ormskirk

Since you bought your shares, the company has been through five different owners, and went into receivership in 1992. It was then bought by a private company that changed its name to Royal Stafford Tableware.

It has no archive recording who owned the company in 1950 or what happened to those shares. It looks most unlikely that there is anything due to you.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Include a telephone number, but not SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The paper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Strauss didn't just waltz through life

fields.headline: Strauss didn't just waltz through life
fields.trailText:
Die Fledermaus London City Opera, QEH, London SE1
Ernst Kovacic and friendsWigmore Hall, London W1
William Glock Memorial Concert St John's Smith Square, London SW1/ Radio 3
fields.body:
Die Fledermaus London City Opera, QEH, London SE1
Ernst Kovacic and friendsWigmore Hall, London W1
William Glock Memorial Concert St John's Smith Square, London SW1/ Radio 3

In the fallow unreality between Christmas and Twelfth Night, only one kind of music features on otherwise blank concert schedules: the waltzes and polkas and heel-clicking marches of Johann Strauss and his glitteringly musical family. Between them, father and sons wrote several hundred popular dances for the ballrooms of nineteenth-century Vienna. For 51 weeks of the year, their music today is virtually ignored. In the fifty-second, a curious fever takes grip. The catchy melodies and clockwork exactness of these brief works seem to embody end-of-year oblivion. Even the Viennese themselves have begun to believe their own imagined past, a time of short-lived opulence and brittle confidence before old Austria vanished in 1914. Recently, the statue of Johann Strauss the younger, the fiddler 'Waltz King', has been dressed in gold leaf in its Art Nouveau grotto, gilding his reputation and Vienna's collective memories in one artful stroke.

It was he who gave us most of the best-known 'Strauss' waltzes, including 'The Blue Danube' and 'Wiener Blut'. His masterpiece, however, was Die Fledermaus, considered by connoisseurs to be the purest of all operettas. London City Opera staged the work in English at the South Bank over New Year. A bitter-sweet study of marriage, money and class, Fledermaus may at first sight seem to bury no deeper ambition beneath its fizzing superficiality. Yet Strauss was more canny than might appear. In his handling of disguise and counter-disguise, he exposes harsh home truths about mankind's ability for self-delusion; as Alfred, the Italian tenor in love with the married Rosalinda, observes: 'Happy the person who can forget what cannot be altered.' A good performance should be like Schnitzler on wheels.

LCO's staging (by Tom Hawkes) was sturdy and unfussy. A fixed set of columns and steps represented a sunny spa town. Singing and acting were crisp, with good ensemble and none of the star indulgence which too often wrecks Fledermaus productions. As Eisenstein, Andrew Forbes Lane proved himself a master of comic timing. Constance Novis (Rosalinda) had the vocal stamina for her demanding Czardas. As Prince Orlofsky, the spirited Juliet Norman cut a dashing 'principal boy' figure, deftly maintaining her witty cod-Russian accent. Martin Handley conducted the small band with zest and diligence. Stylistically the playing had little in the way of Viennese swing, but it was accurate and rhythmic, key Strauss ingredients.

The Waltz King's 'Roses from the South' acted as the Viennese cream filling between the Creation and the End of Time in a chamber concert given by the violinist Ernst Kovacic and friends at the Wigmore Hall. Milhaud was one of the circle of composers around Cocteau nicknamed Les Six. He found inspiration for a ballet, La Création du monde, in the black jazz music of Harlem which he heard in New York in 1922. His plan was to relate the story of creation through African legend, incorporating rain birds, witches, fetishists, soothsayers and the like. His collaborator was Blaise Cendrars who, in addition to being a diamond-dealer, lorry driver, friend of Charlie Chaplin and drinking companion of Stravinsky, had compiled an influential Anthologie nègre. The version played here was for piano quintet. Without the exotic sonorities of the 17-instrument original, the work had a spikier focus.

Kovacic and his players, with the ever characterful David Owen Norris as pianist, brought lean energy to this compact and brightly explosive work. In contrast, 'Roses from the South' had precisely the right degree of smooth, central-European finesse. Kovacic, an Austrian, knows how to waltz to perfection, tripping idiomatically on the beat while second violin and viola hiccupped gracefully on (or off) their accompanying parts. Krysia Osostowicz, violin, and Judith Busbridge, viola, were expert dance partners, with the cellist Raphael Wallfisch smilingly supportive in the bass line.

His moment of glory came in the chief work of the evening, Messiaen's Quartet For The End Of Time. A song-like cello solo, here caressingly played, occupies the still heart of this visionary work, written for fellow prisoners of war and first performed (on barely adequate instruments) in 1941. Anthony Pay, too, was superb in his clarinet solo, and Kovacic scaled the ethereal heights of the last movement flawlessly, as if Messiaen's desired 'Ineffable Peace' were possible.

Sir William Glock, who died last year, was best known as BBC controller of music, 1959-73. He was also a distinguished pianist and a music critic for this newspaper. His ability to see connections between music of different styles, tastes and epochs had an influence on programme-making which is still felt, especially in the planning of the Proms. A concert to celebrate his life was held at St John's Smith Square to an invited audience conspicuous for the number of composers present (though Glock, famously, had his blind spots, and one or two may have stayed away). Oliver Knussen and Pierre Boulez conducted works by Elliott Carter, Gerhard, Stravinsky and Boulez himself.

In homage to Glock's wider musical interests, Imogen Cooper, Isabelle Faust and Natalie Clein gave an invigorating account of Haydn's Piano Trio, perhaps the most inspired music-making of the evening. An air of earnest nostalgia and warm-hearted reverence pervaded. Concerts once needed to be like this, but life has moved on. Glock's successors consider it natural to contrast music of different periods; to mix ancient and modern, oddball and mainstream. If today we are more relaxed about eclecticism, more prepared to delight in creative juxtaposition, we have William Glock to thank, as well as some mysterious force that, every now and then, delivers patronage into the right hands.

fields.headline: Calculated to confuse
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean reveals secrets of making your tax return pain free
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean reveals secrets of making your tax return pain free.
fields.body:
If you are filling in your own tax return this month, you could be in for a shock. The calculation for the tax due has expanded from 8 pages to 28 since last year - becoming so complicated that even professionals admit to getting it wrong if they use pen and paper rather than software.

You can thank Chancellor Gordon Brown for the new complexity. Even if your affairs are fairly straightforward, you could still find yourself, for instance, calculating your tax liability at six different rates for 1999/00 - zero, 10, 20, 23, 32 and 40 per cent. 'The potential for error in the tax calculation is very high if you are doing it yourself,' says Marco Spano of accountant HLB Kidsons in Hove, East Sussex.

But there are ways of limiting the pain. 'If you get the calculation wrong, the Inland Revenue should spot it and will tell you,' says John Whiting of PricewaterhouseCoopers. But if you think you could get it wrong, you may want to err on the generous side - otherwise you will find yourself being charged interest at 8.5 per cent on any shortfall. Although the Revenue should discover all calculation errors, it could take them a couple of months to do so at this time of year.

As well as getting the tax return in by 31 January, many taxpayers - particularly those with self-employed earnings or income from letting out property - are due to pay some tax on that date. There is an automatic £100 fine for returns which come in late - although, after a legal challenge in 1999, this deadline has been pushed back to include tax returns which are on the mat when Inland Revenue offices open up for business on 2 February. Late payments of tax attract the interest charge and a 5 per cent surcharge on sums relating to the 99/00 tax year if still unpaid on 28 February.

Another way round the problem is still to ask the Inland Revenue to calculate your tax bill for you. The Revenue tries to encourage people who want the calculation done for them to get the return in by the end of September - but will do the calculations all the year round.

If you follow this route, and think you have some tax to pay, you could make a rough estimate for yourself and pay in that sum to reduce your chance of being charged interest.

The 28-page Inland Revenue calculation is designed to cover every possibility for every taxpayer, so you could produce your own tailormade procedure, if your confidence in your arithmetic is strong enough. Similarly, you could take advantage of the tax calculator on the Inland Revenue website (under Self-Assessment).

But before you reach the calculation stage, you need to gather together the basic information. 'If the worst comes to the worst, nearly every bank provides details of interest payments over the phone,' says tax adviser Richard Murphy. 'And most companies will say on their websites what their dividend is per share.'

Most employers can readily supply your income information (but make sure you write down income after payments into a company pension scheme - otherwise you can lose some of your hard-earned tax relief) and details of benefits in kind.

You also need to check that you have all the pages you need in the tax return: if you need the pages for partnership, for example, or share schemes, you can download them from the Inland Revenue website or ring up the orderline and ask for them.

Higher-rate taxpayers should get the benefit of any charitable contributions they made.

Charitable giving was made easier for the Millennium - and you can claim back your higher rate of tax on donations where you gave the charity your name and address. Murphy thinks that this is such a donor-friendly system that it is 'open to abuse'. All you need to have done was make a donation to a charity in a recorded, structured form - by cheque, for instance, rather than into a collecting tin - and given the charity your details. You only need to have given the charity your details once in the year for the subsequent payments also to qualify for the tax relief. You do not need to have a receipt for each donation: a note in your diary or on cheque stubs would do.

The charity will have claimed tax relief on your donation, assuming you paid tax at the basic rate - but you can also benefit by claiming back the difference between higher- and basic- rate on the sum.

As you go through the tax return, you should remember that some assets and income are outside the tax system - individual savings accounts and Child Benefit, for instance, and do not need even to be mentioned on the form. Similarly, if you are letting out a room in your house under the 'Rent A Room' scheme, you do not have to put down details. If your circumstances have changed from last year, or you think that some figures look odd, you run the risk of inviting difficult questions from the Inland Revenue - or even unleashing a dreaded 'inquiry' or investigation.

Jane Moore of the charity TaxAid says: 'If you are using estimates instead of actual figures, it is a good idea to disclose the reasons why on the bits of white space that are on the form.' So a short explanation - 'my freelance income dropped 50 per cent this year while I went travelling around the world' - could save you a lot of heartache later on.

Another useful move is to put your daytime telephone number down where you are given the option to do this on page seven of the return. 'It's worth doing this,' says Moore. 'If there is a query, the person inputting the information may use the telephone number. But if they can't get hold of you, they may just reject the return.'

And if you cannot pay your 31 January bill on time, you are also far better off negotiating. Moore says: 'Approach the Revenue as soon as you can. If you can set up an agreed payment arrangement before 28 February, they will probably waive the surcharge. Negotiations depend on the case - the person's compliance history, the size of the debt and what sort of proposal they have. If they think you can pay it off in two to three months, they'd probably be responsive to that. But if it's a year, they'd probably say no.'

The Inland Revenue has to work by instilling some fear into the hearts of potentially errant taxpayers. This year it has just been given a new weapon, the Fraudulent Evasion of Income Tax Act, which came into effect on 1 January. In theory, you can receive up to seven years in jail and unlimited fines for tax evasion but, in practice, it is aimed at fraudsters rather than the dopey or scatter-brained. Nevertheless, it is a reminder that the Revenue can make life very unpleasant for you if its officers discover long-standing oversights.

In projecting a tough image, the Revenue often undersells its helpful side. If you are confused about your tax return, staff in the tax inquiry offices can be extremely helpful. Also, there is much trumpeting about the £100 fines but you can only be fined £100 if you actually owe £100 or more. If you owe £43, your maximum fine is £43 for late filing of the return. If you owe nothing, your maximum fine is also nothing.

And then there is another option. 'Some people will just pay the £100 fine when there isn't any point in sending in a half-baked return,' says Sylvia Kalisch of European Media Ventures, a firm which specialises in tax issues for media clients. 'And some accountants' fees will go up for the month of January - so it may be cheaper to do it in February.'

Inland Revenue orderline: 0845 9000 404, Inland Revenue helpline: 0845 9000 444.

fields.headline: The joy of stout
fields.standfirst: Comfortable with our corporation
fields.trailText: Comfortable with our corporation.
fields.body:
Arresting news from Europe's statisticians - the British are obese. We dismiss the finding that our countrywomen are the second fattest on the Continent, after the Greeks, as a mere seasonal glitch. Every detoxing female knows that a similar survey taken two weeks hence would reveal a quite different national profile.

What exercises us (no jokes that we need it, thank you) is the news that British men are the fourth fattest, after Greece, Finland and Luxembourg. That this is presented as a matter of national disgrace reveals a lamentable lack of understanding of British values.

The men of these islands are not obese, overweight or fat - ever. They are stout, or comfortable, that enviably healthy condition in which 40-year-old Prince Andrew was snapped last week aboard his holiday yacht, a far finer figure of a man than his puny, milksop brothers, we would say. Or they are well-built like John Prescott, portly like Roy Hattersley (before he forsook meat) or hearty like Ken Clarke. Westminster would be a richer place with more such stout fellows (and, indeed, stout lasses to bolster Ann Widdecombe).

The Department of Health is committed to pushing us down the obesity tables. We say, only fourth? Britons, get back up there with those Greeks.

webTitle: This means war (if you look closely)

fields.headline: This means war (if you look closely)
fields.standfirst: His Imperial War Museum of the North is taking shape. For now, just make do with Libeskind's crockery
fields.trailText: Libeskind at the Soane London WC2 (020 7405 2107), opens Thursday and runs until 10 March
fields.body:
Libeskind at the Soane London WC2 (020 7405 2107), opens Thursday and runs until 10 March

John Soane's breakfast-room, perhaps the most beautiful interior in London, still feels as if the architect has just wandered away for a moment. The walls are crowded with curios and under the spatial complexities of its domed roof the table has been laid with what looks like an exquisite if eccentric set of crockery. On closer inspection, the teapot turns out to be a brushed-steel model of Daniel Libeskind's spiral extension for the Victoria and Albert museum, the sugar bowl is the Imperial War Museum's Manchester outpost and the toast-rack is the Jewish Museum in Berlin.

It is the latest in the Soane Museum's enterprising series of exhibitions in which contemporary architects are invited to conduct a dialogue with Soane's work. In total, nine of Libeskind's projects, miniaturised to tabletop scale, float on the table. The projects are juxtaposed with a series of drawings that he made 20 years ago and which have provided the source material for everything that he has designed since.

Libeskind's drawings are highly-wrought graphic explosions that seem more like a form of musical notation than conventional architectural images. When they were published, Libeskind interleaved them with fragments of concrete poetry and Dadaist text. Since they did not look like buildings at all, people tended to assume that Libeskind was more interested in abstract theory than actually building.

But for Libeskind, the point of architecture is not how it looks, but how it feels. He always saw his drawings as a necessary preparation for building, rather than theoretical speculation. The fact that they are not immediately comprehensible as architecture is no drawback for him. 'The notion that architecture must be instantly understandable so that you can see it in plan, section and elevation is what I call the Palladio complex. I believe it is a sickness but one which is over.' He hadn't built anything before he won the competition to design Berlin's Jewish Museum in 1989, when he was well past 40. He had spent the time thinking and drawing rather than getting sidetracked by the conventional architectural stepping-stones of kitchen extensions and conversions.

The museum's opening in 1999 was a triumphant justification of Libeskind's patient preparation for a career as an architect. There was nothing to see but his architecture; the collection is only now being installed. But it was an eloquent demonstration that those mysterious drawings could produce a work of architecture that is literary in its inspiration, but also a physical and tactile experience.

The fact that an architect of Libeskind's uncompromising seriousness has managed to build anything at all in a period in which architecture is in danger of being trivialised out of existence is a heartening phenomenon. He tries to make an architecture which is about loss, memory, time and death. The death-obsessed John Soane would certainly have understood his search for the tragic in architecture. And Libeskind's way of manipulating space and light through fractured geometry also seems to echo Soane.

But it is his ability to deliver emotional content that has made him so attractive to so many museums. With museums fighting for audiences, the ability to make a museum a memorable place to visit becomes important. Berlin was a demonstration of how it could be done, and led to commissions from the V&A, the Imperial War Museum North, and the Denver Art Museum.

But to become typecast as an architect who can build emotionally manipulative museums would undermine Libeskind's work, as he himself is well aware. He was once asked if he could build another Jewish museum. 'Someone did propose that but I refused; I can't be a professional Jewish museum builder,' he replied.

In fact, since then, he has indeed been commissioned to design another Jewish museum on San Francisco's waterfront. To be fair, it is a very different project from Berlin. Rather than deliberately failing to connect with its neighbours in San Francisco, Libeskind has fused his new building with the remains of a powerful neo- classical power station.

More of an issue - given the highly personal nature of Libeskind's architectural language - is the way that the same forms are used not only for Berlin, but are also put to work to house the V&A's collection of teapots.

Libeskind has succeeded in inventing a new kind of architecture, which is difficult enough. Now he has to face up to the even more difficult task of working with that architectural language when it is no longer revolutionary, but an accepted part of the landscape.

As if to underscore the iconic quality that Libeskind's work has already acquired, he has to contend with Australia's soon-to-be opened new national museum, designed by Ashton Raggatt and McDougall. Without asking they have taken the lightning flash plan of Libeskind's Jewish Museum and reproduced it in Canberra as a kind of remix.

In Manchester, where the Imperial War Museum of the North is now rapidly taking shape, just across the canal from the spectacular Lowry Centre, Libeskind's room for manoeuvre is limited. He must tread a careful path between designing a museum that documents the grim realities of warfare and making a building that attracts enough visitors to make it a paying proposition complete with canalside cafe and shop.

'I wanted to create a building that people will find interesting and wish to visit, yet reflects the serious nature of a war museum,' says Libeskind. The conceptual idea is strong - he sees the museum as a globe, shattered into three fragments to symbolise warfare on land, sea and air. As it takes shape, we will see if he has been able to work the same magic he did in Berlin with a much more modest budget and without the skills of a German building contractor.

The projects are juxtaposed with a series of drawings that he made 20 years ago and which have provided the source material for everything that he has designed since. Libeskind's drawings are highly-wrought graphic explosions that seem more like a form of musical notation than conventional architectural images. When they were published, Libeskind interleaved them with fragments of concrete poetry and Dadaist text. Since they did not look like buildings at all, people tended to assume that Libeskind was more interested in abstract theory than actually building. But for Libeskind, the point of architecture is not how it looks, but how it feels. He always saw his drawings as a necessary preparation for building, rather than theoretical speculation. The fact that they are not immediately comprehensible as architecture is no drawback for him. 'The notion that architecture must be instantly understandable so that you can see it in plan, section and elevation is what I call the Palladio complex. I believe it is a sickness but one which is over.' He hadn't built anything before he won the competition to design Berlin's Jewish Museum in 1989, when he was well past 40. He had spent the time thinking and drawing rather than getting sidetracked by the conventional architectural stepping-stones of kitchen extensions and conversions. The museum's opening in 1999 was a triumphant justification of Libeskind's patient preparation for a career as an architect. There was nothing to see but his architecture; the collection is only now being installed. But it was an eloquent demonstration that those mysterious drawings could produce a work of architecture that is literary in its inspiration, but also a physical and tactile experience. The fact that an architect of Libeskind's uncompromising seriousness has managed to build anything at all in a period in which architecture is in danger of being trivialised out of existence is a heartening phenomenon. He tries to make an architecture which is about loss, memory, time and death. The death-obsessed John Soane would certainly have understood his search for the tragic in architecture. And Libeskind's way of manipulating space and light through fractured geometry also seems to echo Soane. But it is his ability to deliver emotional content that has made him so attractive to so many museums. With museums fighting for audiences, the ability to make a museum a memorable place to visit becomes important. Berlin was a demonstration of how it could be done, and led to commissions from the V&A, the Imperial War Museum North, and the Denver Art Museum. But to become typecast as an architect who can build emotionally manipulative museums would undermine Libeskind's work, as he himself is well aware. He was once asked if he could build another Jewish museum. 'Someone did propose that but I refused; I can't be a professional Jewish museum builder,' he replied. In fact, since then, he has indeed been commissioned to design another Jewish museum on San Francisco's waterfront. To be fair, it is a very different project from Berlin. Rather than deliberately failing to connect with its neighbours in San Francisco, Libeskind has fused his new building with the remains of a powerful neo- classical power station. More of an issue - given the highly personal nature of Libeskind's architectural language - is the way that the same forms are used not only for Berlin, but are also put to work to house the V&A's collection of teapots. Libeskind has succeeded in inventing a new kind of architecture, which is difficult enough. Now he has to face up to the even more difficult task of working with that architectural language when it is no longer revolutionary, but an accepted part of the landscape. As if to underscore the iconic quality that Libeskind's work has already acquired, he has to contend with Australia's soon-to-be opened new national museum, designed by Ashton Raggatt and McDougall. Without asking they have taken the lightning flash plan of Libeskind's Jewish Museum and reproduced it in Canberra as a kind of remix. In Manchester, where the Imperial War Museum of the North is now rapidly taking shape, just across the canal from the spectacular Lowry Centre, Libeskind's room for manoeuvre is limited. He must tread a careful path between designing a museum that documents the grim realities of warfare and making a building that attracts enough visitors to make it a paying proposition complete with canalside cafe and shop. 'I wanted to create a building that people will find interesting and wish to visit, yet reflects the serious nature of a war museum,' says Libeskind. The conceptual idea is strong - he sees the museum as a globe, shattered into three fragments to symbolise warfare on land, sea and air. As it takes shape, we will see if he has been able to work the same magic he did in Berlin with a much more modest budget and without the skills of a German building contractor.

webTitle: Property: Of Irish highs - and peaks in Wales

fields.headline: Of Irish highs - and peaks in Wales
fields.standfirst: The UK market should stay strong, writes Graham Norwood, and for once the South East is not the most lively
fields.trailText: The UK market should stay strong, writes Graham Norwood, and for once the South East is not the most lively.
fields.body:
If you are buying or selling a house in 2001, remember the old cliché that the early bird catches the worm.

Most property experts across the country say there will be a 6-10 per cent price rise in house prices this year and perhaps up to 15 per cent on larger country homes - and most of those increases will take place between now and summer.

'There is now a lot of pent-up demand, and we envisage activity developing in February and March,' says upmarket agent Knight Frank's Edward Rook. Some of the busiest areas are not the usual suspects of London and the South East.

'I have absolutely no problem in predicting that the Northern Ireland market will continue growing,' says David Cairns, of the Eric Cairns agency in Belfast. 'A lot of our market has been driven by new developments, and demand was strong right the way up to Christmas. In mid-December I sold 30 apartments, off plan, which were located by the Foyle in Derry, and which will not be complete until autumn 2001.'

In Wales it is the same. 'It's been very buoyant, mostly driven by new developments in the centre and near Cardiff Bay,' says surveyor Michael Young. The story is identical at the top end of the market - £1 million or more - where there is overseas interest as well as British.

'Because of the rise in the number of international buyers following the fall of the pound against the dollar, we can comfortably predict a further 10 per cent rise in 2001,' says Grant Alexson of Knight Frank. 'There will be no boom and bust and no sharp deviations.'

The London scene will be, as ever, aggressive. In the realistically priced part of the market the final six weeks of 2000 were unusually hectic.

'We have seen large amounts of property sold, mainly in the low to middle market, which points to a very active early part of 2001,' says Peter Rollings, managing director of London agents Foxtons. 'We are predicting a rise of between 8 per cent and 10 per cent during the first quarter of 2001. We would then expect the market to calm for a period of months before again recovering towards the autumn of 2001.'

At the top end, City bonuses may not have quite the effect they have had in past years. 'Predictions for bonuses across the board are that they will be down on last year and people won't feel as rich as they have done,' says David Forbes, of central London agency Chesterfield.

London lettings have recently been boosted by commuters who want temporary accommodation during the rail chaos, but some agents believe the rental market will suffer as the sales market picks up. 'Given an increase in rents of 7-10 per cent in 2000, we would expect letting to fall back slightly in the new year to reflect the predicted rise in sales for the next six months,' says Ian Stone of agent Bushells in south and west London.

But the north-south divide continues in housing. England's worst-hit area remains the North East, where past and future house price rises are as far away as ever. 'Bluntly, the poorer properties - of which we have a lot - have not risen in price in 2000 and don't look too promising for 2001,' says Newcastle surveyor Edward Watson. 'We have a growing number of higher-priced houses, and they may well be in more demand as the year progresses, especially in areas such as the Quays in Newcastle. It's not uncommon there to have flats for £200,000.'

If 2001 is the year you strike out with your children's inheritance or your City bonus to buy a second home overseas, you need to get in quick.

'The international second-homes market is booming and looking increasingly attractive to British buyers due to improved communications and the ability to work away from the office,' says Knight Frank's Naomi Greatbanks. 'We are anticipating small increases in Italy and France of perhaps 5 per cent, and increases of 10 per cent in Spain, where developments are still more affordable.'

But not everyone in the property industry is as upbeat. There is some concern over the effects of a possible spring general election. 'It will ruin the spring market,' claims John Hunter of property developer Northacre. 'Knowledge of the forthcoming election will leave potential buyers sitting on the fence. Only once the dust has settled will things get moving again.'

Most estate agents put on a braver, and more cynical, face. Gavin West of Hamptons says: 'The run-up to the election will give a fillip to the market, because the Government will be currying favour with the home owning democracy.'

Hot spots

Predicted by estate agents to show above-average rises in 2001

South - Bristol (particularly the docks), Newbury, Winchester

London - Kennington, Hackney, Kensal Green, Southfields, Acton

South East - St Albans, Rickmansworth, Amersham, Sunningdale

Northern Ireland - Belfast (especially new apartments)

Midlands - M40 corridor

North West - Manchester (particularly city centre), new Liverpool sites

Scotland - central Edinburgh, country areas near airports

Wales - Cardiff (especially marina developments)

Cold spots

Predicted by estate agents to show below-average rises in 2001

London - Thames Estuary and Greenwich (poor transport and Dome uncertainty)

Stoke on Trent, rural north Wales, parts of NE England
