webTitle: Comment: Pension lottery victims turn up the heat

fields.headline: Pension lottery victims turn up the heat
fields.trailText: Ex-servicemen turned up the heat last week in their campaign for a better pension scheme.
fields.body:
Ex-servicemen turned up the heat last week in their campaign for a better pension scheme.

The Officers' Pension Society estimates that about 25,000 personnel of all ranks who retired in 1977 and 1991 have lost thousands of pounds in pension income compared to colleagues of the same rank and length of service.

They lost out because, since the Fifties, their pensions have been calculated as a percentage of their salary on the day they retired, and linked to the retail price index thereafter. Servicemen retiring in 1977 suffered from well-below inflation pay rises in their final two years, while those retiring in the first three months of 1991 missed out on a substantial pay increase.

The OPS says the scheme is a lottery, based on a person's date of birth, and that many servicemen have suffered a 'gross injustice'.

It wants the Government to introduce techniques used by other funds to reduce the effect of pay freezes and changes in inflation.

Ex-servicemen are not the only ones to suffer the effects of economic fluctuations on outdated pension schemes. Anyone forced to buy a retirement annuity at the low rates of the last few years must be concerned that future increases in inflation and interest rates will erode this fixed income.

Although pensioners can defer buying a pension annuity until they reach the age of 75, drawing income directly from their pension funds instead, this is not the safety net it was. Many people now live well beyond 75, and face the prospect of falling living standards if their income diminishes in real terms.

The Government hopes to encourage more people to make their own provision for retirement by sorting out the charging structures of private pension schemes. But to really convince people that pensions are worthwhile, it must tackle the issue of annuities, either by raising the age limit or by abolishing the need to buy an annuity.

For years the main clearing banks have been able to maximise profits by charging high interest on borrowings and paying low rates on accounts that are in credit. Customers had no alternative. But the new internet-based banks are now providing real competition. So how are the big banks reacting? By cutting their charges and paying more for savings? Or by taking weeks to provide unhappy customers with the information they need to go else where?

A survey by the 'telenet' bank Intelligent Finance of 1,000 account transfers found that on average the big four banks took nearly 14 working days, and in the worst case 41 of them, to provide requested information.

It seems changes to the Banking Code, which require banks to give details of direct debits and standing orders in 10 working days, have been introduced in the nick of time. Let's hope the banks stick to it.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Surveys reveal Life is cheap | Authority figures | Insurance penalty
fields.body:
Surveys reveal Life is cheap

Standard Life offered the cheapest variable rate mortgage among leading lenders in 2000, according to two surveys. Calculations from the Research Department show that someone borrowing £50,000 would have paid £3,447 to Standard Life - £414 less than to the most expensive of the top 30 lenders, Northern Rock. MoneyFacts put Standard Life and the Chesham and Coventry building societies at the top of the list. But most borrowers should be able do better than the standard variable rate if they shop around for fixed or discount rates.

Authority figures

If you are buying a pension, mortgage or other financial product, the Financial Services Authority has produced a 'Shop Around' guide, suggesting questions you should be asking. The pages are at www.fsa.gov.uk/consumerhelp.

Insurance penalty

Watch out for mortgage lenders which offer an attractive rate but force you to buy buildings and contents insurance from them as well. The Department of Trade and Industry had planned to ban this practice - but has now decided merely to 'keep the issue under review'. Over the past year, the number of lenders offering 'compulsory insurance' deals has halved from 34 to 17, according to the DTI. Insurance is usually more expensive through a lender than separately. The practice is most common among the smaller building societies - including Newcastle, Manchester and the Leeds & Holbeck.

Calls in store

Sainsbury's has launched a mobile phone service which promises to charge the lowest price it can find each month by comparing the tariffs of the four mobile phone networks which cover the UK. Sainsbury's says some heavy users could cut their costs by up to 70 per cent. To use the service, you need a free Sainsbury's 'Reward' card . Handsets cost from £29.99, but owners of dual band mobiles can subscribe by getting a microchip card for their mobile. Leaflets in stores or call 0800 015 80 80.

Credit card tricks

If you overspent on Christmas presents and have a hefty debt left on your cards, now is the time to hunt out the cheapest balance transfer offers. You can't get much cheaper than Egg, which will charge you nothing for balance transfers in the first six months, provided you apply for your card before 31 March (apply before 31 January to benefit from the full six months' free credit on new purchases). Then the rate rises to 11.9 per cent APR, so start looking for another cheap card in the meantime. RBS Advanta (0800 077770) is charging 1.9 per cent until the start of next year.

Society pressure

Building societies are likely to come under renewed pressure from carpetbaggers to convert this year. Nationwide, the UK's biggest society, has agreed to a vote at its annual meeting in July provided it receives a valid resolution by April 4. To qualify, the resolution must be supported by 500 members of at least two year's standing. Chelsea could also face a conversion vote in April; more than 700 Portman members have supported resolutions which seek to make proposing resolutions easier, and voting procedures fair.

Waiving the rules

Investors could face increasing confusion when buying financial products, under rule changes proposed by the Financial Services Authority last week. Under the current system only independent financial advisers are allowed to advise on and sell the products of all the companies. But the FSA is to allow direct salesmen and tied agents (including many banks and building societies), who can sell the products of only one company at the moment, to sell the Cat-standard Isas and stakeholder pensions of other companies from April 6. Firms will also be able to market other companies' products through promotions which do not supply advice. The Association of Independent Financial Advisers says the FSA has ducked the key questions of how tied agents will select the most suitable product and provider, or who will be responsible if things go wrong.

Skiing can cost an arm and a leg

Skiers are increasingly likely to find themselves being sued if they injure someone else in a collision, according to TravelPlan Direct. The company has seen a steep rise in personal liability claims over the last two years. Director Andy Newman says: 'The fact is that a broken leg - yours or someone else's - could end up costing you thousands. 'Unfortunately, not all travel insurance policies include adequate personal liability cover, and most have punitive excesses - as much as £250.' For more information telephone TravelPlan: 0800 0188 747.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Teach us a lesson we won't forget

fields.headline: Teach us a lesson we won't forget
fields.standfirst: Despite reasonable salaries Sîan and Alastair always feel hard up, they tell Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Despite reasonable salaries Sîan and Alastair always feel hard up, they tell Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Sîan Harries and Alastair Veysey

Ages 27 and 30

Live in Billericay

Occupations Teachers

Earn c.£22,000 each

Mortgage £70,000

Debts Car loan £10,000, student loan £4,000

Investments Bank and building society accounts, Equity Isa

Pensions Members of Teachers' Superannuation Scheme

Aims To pay off debts, save for honeymoon and for larger property, and generally get sorted financially.

Sîan and Alastair met during teacher training. They are planning to get married in August, but now Sîan is worried less about organising their big day and more about sorting out their finances. Despite their relatively good incomes, she feels hard-up: 'We never seem to be able to make our money stretch far enough. Any savings we gather over the year are spent during the school summer holidays.'

They need to save for their honeymoon and they also want to build a nest egg with a view to moving to a bigger house in a couple of years time.

In the long run they would like to start a family, and Sîan hopes to be able to spend a few years at home. But as things stand she does not feel they could ever afford her to stop working.

The couple's main outgoings are their mortgage, which costs £475 a month and a car loan of £10,000 which they are paying back at £210 a month over the next five years. They feel the car loan in particular is a real burden and have decided not to replace their second car because they do not want another loan. Alastair also has a student loan which he is repaying.

They are not completely without savings. Sîan has an Abbey National SAYE scheme worth £1,750 which is maturing this month. She is considering using this to pay off part of the car loan. She has also been saving £150 a month for the past couple of months in a Barclays savings account towards their honeymoon. In addition, she has £600 in a Northern Rock account.

Last April Alastair invested £7,000 in a Skandia equity Isa, but they were dismayed recently to discover that it had gone down in value to £5,845. It is spread across six funds recommended by a relation - Henderson Global Technology, Jupiter UK Special Situations, Invesco European Smaller Companies, Gartmore European Selected Opportunities, Henderson UK Smaller Companies and S & P Japan Growth. In view of the losses, they wonder if this investment is worthwhile.

Both are members of the teachers' pension scheme. Being in a public-sector final salary scheme nowadays is a huge advantage, but Sîan wonders whether she could consider topping up her pension with additional voluntary contributions.

One money-saving possibility the couple are considering is selling their house and moving into Sîan's father's house while he spends a year in Spain. This would enable them to save their mortgage repayments, which they could then put towards a larger property.

Adviser 1: Gillian Cardy

There is nothing for it - Sîan and Alastair must sit down with a clean piece of paper and work out what they do with their money. They should monitor their income and outgoings over a three-month period.

The symptoms they describe often mean that too much is spent on casual and unplanned purchases. The only real way to make progress is to control the amount they spend from their current accounts, by perhaps setting a weekly limit.

For immediate savings, it is always worth taking out a cash Isa rather than a plain savings account. The interest rates on cash Isas are often higher, and the interest is tax-free. The period of saving does not matter with cash investments. Look out for best buy interest rates in the weekend papers.

As for Alastair's equity Isa, the Skandia scheme is expensive but does give access to a range of funds. The plan has fallen in value because of initial charges and because the underlying funds are inherently high-risk. The charges have now been paid and the value has fallen, so it is probably not a good idea to cash it in. I would wait until the value improves before transferring the money elsewhere or selling it.

The Teachers' Superannuation Scheme is extremely valuable and I would suggest that they get other things right first before worrying about AVCs. If they move into Sîan's father's house, I would advise them to rent out rather than sell their own home. If they sell, they may find it hard to get back into the property market.

Gillian Cardy works for financial adviser Professional Partnerships.

Adviser 2: Andrew Jones

SÎan and Alastair have one of the most common financial problems in the South East: they earn respectable salaries but feel their living expenses leave them with little in the way of disposable income and no ability to save.

Sîan's plan to repay part of the car loan with the proceeds of her Abbey National account is sensible. As a rule, all debts should be paid off before an individual begins to save or invest.

Now that Alastair has the Isa, he should hold on to it. The funds he has chosen are growth-oriented and quite aggressive in their management style. It is well positioned to benefit from any improvement in global stockmarket conditions.

I like their idea of moving into Sîan's father's house. This is an imaginative way to release some extra cash. I think they may be better off letting their home rather than selling it, as this avoids the costs of selling and repurchasing. If they do so, they will need to inform their lender and make sure they use a properly drafted assured shorthold tenancy agreement.

The rental income they receive would be taxable but they can offset their mortgage interest payments and other related expenses against it.

Finally, I suggest Sîan leaves additional pension contributions towards the bottom of her financial wish list. The Teachers' Superannuation Scheme will provide a good level of benefits to each of them, especially if they spend their whole careers in the education system.

Andrew Jones works for chartered accountant Blick Rothenberg.

 Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Let's start at the very beginning

fields.headline: Let's start at the very beginning
fields.standfirst: In the first of a series on check-ups for your finances, Margaret Dibben goes back to budgeting basics
fields.trailText: In the first of a series on check-ups for your finances, Margaret Dibben goes back to budgeting basics.
fields.body:
For those with money, there is no shortage of financial advice. Those with serious debt problems can also ask for help. But if you simply need to check that you are being sensible with money, or want tips on making ends meet, opportunities are limited.

Independent financial advisers make a living either from commission on the investments they sell or from charging fees for their time. A thorough analysis of your financial position takes two or three hours and advisers' fees start at £100 an hour. But it is not feasible to pay £200 for a check-up when you do not have that much money to spare. If you had that sort of money, you could usefully add it to your savings.

The answer is to do it yourself. You may be short of money, but you can use your time to give yourself a money makeover. You do not need qualifications to sort out your financial priorities: much of it boils down to common sense supported by a little understanding.

First you must establish where you stand today, and for that you need to draw up a budget (see opposite). You may be able to see immediately where you are wasting money or being extravagant. You may find you are paying for house insurance through your lender and also with a separate policy. Perhaps your house insurance covers your holiday needs as well.

When you have written down everything you spend money on, list all the financial products you have bought. This may take time to pull together and could include:

 Cheque account

 Savings accounts at banks and building societies

 Individual Savings Account (Isa)

 National Savings

 Shares, gilts, unit trusts, oeics or investment trusts

 Investment bonds

 Tessa

 Personal equity plan

 Life insurance, with your mortgage or separately (endowment, whole life or term insurance)

 Health insurance (income protection, loan protection, critical illness, long-term care, private medical insurance or hospital cash benefit).

 Pension, through your job or privately, and additional voluntary contributions.

Remember to include any financial protection that you do not pay for, such as life insurance or sick pay that comes with your job, and make sure you know exactly what you get. Joanne Cox, of Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers, says: 'People don't have any idea how long their employer will pay if they are off ill, or how much they will get, no idea of pension benefits or life insurance.'

She tells them to look at the booklets the company provides: 'Your employer has a duty to inform you, and most do, but it is up to you to read the booklets.'

If your pay package includes life insurance, you do not have to buy more for yourself. But do consider how long your job will last because, if you change jobs, you immediately lose this life cover. You can at that point buy your own policy but, as you will be older when you start, the premiums are higher and, if your health has deteriorated, could be out of reach. You should also check whether your employer's insurance includes cover for your spouse.

You need to plan for the future whatever your age, whether you are starting work or have already retired. The Government has made it clear that everyone who can afford to save must take care of themselves, as no future administration will be able to provide.

Anyone who has recently left university probably owes a large amount of money in student loans and overdrafts, so they need to establish a debt repayment programme before starting to think about saving.

But financial planning for 20-year-olds is not limited to coping with debt because the younger you start investing or building a pension, the less it will cost overall (see table above right). The sooner you get into the habit of putting money aside regularly, the less you will miss it.

Cox explains: 'If you are fairly young, the cumulative effect of saving over time has a snowball effect. It is better to save £20 a month for 25 years than delay and put in £50 a month for 10 years. Although the amount you pay in is the same, the amount you get out at the end is radically different because it has had time to accumulate. You do not need a fortune if you start early.'

The list of financial products is not a target but shows what is available so you can decide which you may find useful and which you can afford. Over the next few weeks, Cash will tell you more about them; but broadly you can see which are essential, which desirable and which you can do without

Once you start shopping for financial products, spend time on your research. The internet has made this easy, or you can telephone for a brochure. Get details from several different companies and go through the literature carefully.

Cox advises: 'Read the small print. It is amazing what you can find. The product may not be what you thought it was. For example, you might think you are getting life insurance but on closer examination find it is accident insurance.' Be careful not to sign up for a product that looks favourable but has penalties if you need to change or within 12 months decide it is inappropriate and therefore give it up altogether.

Here are other top tips from financial experts:

 Do not pay too much tax: non-taxpayers, including children, should sign form IR85 available from bank and building society branches and tax offices so interest is paid without tax being deducted.

 Check your tax code: you cannot assume the Inland Revenue has it right

 Index everything. When you pay in to a pension or investment, build in an automatic annual increase in contributions from the start. It will cost you only a few pennies extra each month. This way your money keeps its value. It need only be a nominal 5 per cent to outpace inflation at present.

 If you need a pension, look at stakeholder pensions, which arrive in April. Andy Agar, pensions marketing director of Legal & General, says: 'Customers buying stakeholder pensions can have confidence that the terms are benchmarked by the Government and there are no longer any hidden charges.' The minimum stakeholder contribution will be £20 a month gross, but what you actually pay will be less than that because the tax relief is added on.

 Keep your options flexible. Mortgages and pensions used to tie you down, but modern versions allow you to change your contributions and even take a payment holiday. With stakeholder pensions, you can start paying in when you are young - with spare cash and no family commitments?. When you start a family and the costs build up, you can reduce or stop your contributions without penalty and then start building them up again as money gets easier.

 Parents and grandparents can take out a stakeholder pension for the children; spouses on behalf of a non-working partner. The recipient does not have to be earning or paying tax yet can have contributions paid on their behalf up to £300 a month or £3,600 a year with no questions asked. The person contributing gets basic-rate tax relief.

 A pension is not necessarily the best choice for people on lower incomes because the money is locked away until they retire. You should still save, but an Isa may be better as you can access the money if they really need it. The downside is that the money is available and you may be tempted to use it.

 Check that you are paying the least you can for a mortgage. If your own lender has a better product, ask if you can switch. If not, remortgage to a different lender.

 Move your current account to one that pays better interest.

 Financial planning is not a one-off exercise. You need to keep reviewing your investments. Everyone plans to but, in reality, fails. Cox warns: 'Don't be lazy and leave all your money in a low-paying deposit ac-count that was good when you started.'

Bina Abel, an independent financial adviser with Bradford & Bingley, says: 'Life does move on. Every time there is any change in your circumstances, come back to look at your budget again.'

Mortgage, insurance, bills but don't forget CDs and chardonnay

You may be tempted to ignore this section if you feel you have no money, but everyone should budget. Joanne Cox of the Coop says: 'It is not a matter of how much you earn: people spend what they earn.'

You can ignore financial planning only if you always have plenty of money for all you want and need. For the rest of us, a little planning can cut costs and avoid wastage. You can do nothing until you know exactly where you stand. This means adding up all the money you have coming in: salary, overtime, bonuses, any other jobs, pension, state benefits, rental income, maintenance payments, interest from deposit accounts and dividends from investments.

You may not regard all this as spending money. You may put your Child Benefit straight into a savings scheme. Or you may reinvest dividends. Ignore those amounts: you are trying to find out exactly how much money you have available to spend.

Then calculate your outgoings. This is more difficult than it sounds because small items nibble away at your money and are easy to overlook. You can readily find the figures for mortgage or rent, council tax and utility bills. You may have a reasonable idea how much you spend on food. But you may be deceiving yourself about your booze bill or other weaknesses - be disciplined and realistic. Then add occasional items down to hairdos, makeup, birthday cards, flowers, dry cleaning, magazines and postage stamps.

Starting now, write down every penny you spend over a month. You will get a few surprises. Keep the list going for a full year, to include seasonal variations and you will get bigger shocks. There is no need to stop buying treats, but they should be a conscious decision you know you can afford.

Wise counsel for counsellor

Jan Woodhouse is 55 and has two sons in their twenties but she still has the low-income problems of youngsters just starting their working lives. For 11 years she worked as an administrator for the Kent Institute of Art and Design, but last August took voluntary redundancy and received an ex gratia payment of £5,102.

She has registered for Jobseeker's Allowance and started part-time tutoring in English and mathematics for £11 an hour. Her earning time is limited, though, because the rest of her time is spent studying for a diploma in counselling, which she is paying for herself. When she completes the course, she hopes to find part-time counselling work and start a private practice but says that, realistically, she will not be earning more than £20,000 a year.

Jan had been contributing to a company pension since 1996 but had to stop when she left her job. She has no plans to retire: 'I expect to continue working for as long as my physical and mental health allow.' She wants to know how to manage her small income to her best advantage, and provide peace of mind for later.

While Jan has the same financial worries as young people, she has far less time in which to save for her future. As her children are grown up, her priority now is her own finances.

She should follow the budget plan (page 3) to make sure she is not wasting money anywhere and establish exactly where she stands financially - whether she has insurance policies she no longer needs, an emergency fund and enough money to see her through studying.

Although she has no plans to retire, she should be saving for a time when she is no longer earning, using the £5,102 as a starting point. This could be through a stakeholder pension or an Isa - depending on whether she wants to tie up her money. She can contact the Benefits Agency or phone 0191 2187585 for a forecast of how much state pension she will receive and a valuation of the company pension from her former employer.

What bank manager?

Thw role of the traditional bank manager has disappeared. The avuncular figure who filled you with fear but doled out free financial advice of variable quality no longer exists.

If you asked Lloyds TSB, you would be offered a chat with an adviser - who would give only generic advice.

Geoff Seymour of Alliance & Leicester says: 'If a customer wanted to sort out their credit cards and investments, they could see a customer adviser at a branch for about an hour. Advisers are qualified and will advise on the best way to sort out investments within our own product range.'

Banks with an independent financial subsidiary provide a more detailed service. Seymour adds: 'If you want advice on investments not provided by Alliance & Leicester, you can make an appointment, at home or at a branch, with someone from Alliance & Leicester Independent Financial Advisers. There is no fee and, if someone does not want to buy an investment, this is not a problem. It is not out of reach and you can get good advice without it costing you.'

Bina Abel of Bradford & Bingley says her organisation has a similar service: 'I could see 10 people over a couple of days. The fact that we don't charge means I see a wide cross-section of the public. The commission we earn from larger investors enables us to help smaller ones.'

At debt's door

Repay debts as fast as you can, starting with the most expensive, but make sure with all of them that you are paying the lowest rate of interest. You do not need to stick with a mortgage or credit card if others offer cheaper rates.

Credit card companies are so competitive at the moment that you can play one off against another. Geoff Seymour, of Alliance & Leicester, suggests: 'Switch to a credit card with a very low rate of interest on the balance you transfer.'

Joanne Cox, of the Coop, says: 'Have just one credit card, with a low rate of interest, but watch for conditions. There are some very low rates for six months to attract you, but they often have steep charges if you make a late payment or want an extra statement. This is how they get their money back. Understand what you are getting into in the contract and be aware of all the charges you may be paying.'

Limit your credit cards: it is easier to control one or two. You can delude yourself if you have half a dozen cards each with a small balance.The statements arrive at different times of the month and none looks a lot of money. But it all adds up. If all your credit spending is on one bill, you can easily see what you have spent. This will help you be more disciplined. Some borrowers are better off with a personal loan than a credit card, even though the interest rate is higher. You borrow a fixed amount which you repay over a set period. This eliminates temptation because you cannot borrow any more and must keep up with repayments every month.

Avoid store cards: they are expensive. Spending £5,000 on a store card and paying it back over two years costs £6,473 at a typical 29.9 per cent. Says Seymour: 'If you owe £5,000 on a store card, and transfer the balance to an Alliance & Leicester Diamond card, with its special transfer balance rate of 6.8 per cent, you could save £1,626 paying it back over two years. On a typical credit card, you could save £787.40 in two years.' The Halifax credit card starts from 2 per cent.

What's important - and what's not

Before making any decisions, get your priorities sorted. These should be:

 protecting your income

 protecting your dependants with life insurance

 your pension

 your savings.

Bina Abel, of Bradford & Bingley, says: 'It is not easy to prioritise the financial products to buy because each individual's circumstances are different.' You need to decide what is most appropriate for your own situation.

'Pensions are important, but I might tell a young person to save although not in a pension, because there is danger that they get trapped into arrangements too young. It may be more sensible for them to save in an Isa, because the money can still be used for a pension, but they may need it for a house deposit.'

Andy Agar, of Legal and General, adds: 'The Government has tried to say that if you earn below around £10,000, you shouldn't save your hard-earned money because you are better relying on the state. If you are on the margin, you have a difficult choice. My advice would be that if you earn over that threshold you should save'

If you cannot afford everything, it is better to spread your money over two or three important areas, rather than concentrating on one and ignoring the others. If you have £50 a month to spare and two young children, you need life insurance and you need a pension.

You will be tempted to delay starting a pension, but you may find you never get round to it and, anyway, it will cost you more later on (see table, page 5. Everyone needs a pension, unless you have wealthy parents who will leave you all their money.

Joanne Cox, of the Coop, says she plays the consequences game with clients who cannot decide what to buy: 'I ask them: "What would the consequences be if you had died yesterday? How much pension would your wife have? Would the mortgage be paid off? If not, could she pay it? Does she work? If there is nothing left in the pot, could she manage on her earnings?" That shows them the choices they have to make. If the outlook is really grim, and the family would be out on the street, you need to do something.'
fields.bodyText: For those with money, there is no shortage of financial advice. Those with serious debt problems can also ask for help. But if you simply need to check that you are being sensible with money, or want tips on making ends meet, opportunities are limited. Independent financial advisers make a living either from commission on the investments they sell or from charging fees for their time. A thorough analysis of your financial position takes two or three hours and advisers' fees start at £100 an hour. But it is not feasible to pay £200 for a check-up when you do not have that much money to spare. If you had that sort of money, you could usefully add it to your savings. The answer is to do it yourself. You may be short of money, but you can use your time to give yourself a money makeover. You do not need qualifications to sort out your financial priorities: much of it boils down to common sense supported by a little understanding. First you must establish where you stand today, and for that you need to draw up a budget (see opposite). You may be able to see immediately where you are wasting money or being extravagant. You may find you are paying for house insurance through your lender and also with a separate policy. Perhaps your house insurance covers your holiday needs as well. When you have written down everything you spend money on, list all the financial products you have bought. This may take time to pull together and could include:  Cheque account  Savings accounts at banks and building societies  Individual Savings Account (Isa)  National Savings  Shares, gilts, unit trusts, oeics or investment trusts  Investment bonds  Tessa  Personal equity plan  Life insurance, with your mortgage or separately (endowment, whole life or term insurance)  Health insurance (income protection, loan protection, critical illness, long-term care, private medical insurance or hospital cash benefit).  Pension, through your job or privately, and additional voluntary contributions. Remember to include any financial protection that you do not pay for, such as life insurance or sick pay that comes with your job, and make sure you know exactly what you get. Joanne Cox, of Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers, says: 'People don't have any idea how long their employer will pay if they are off ill, or how much they will get, no idea of pension benefits or life insurance.' She tells them to look at the booklets the company provides: 'Your employer has a duty to inform you, and most do, but it is up to you to read the booklets.' If your pay package includes life insurance, you do not have to buy more for yourself. But do consider how long your job will last because, if you change jobs, you immediately lose this life cover. You can at that point buy your own policy but, as you will be older when you start, the premiums are higher and, if your health has deteriorated, could be out of reach. You should also check whether your employer's insurance includes cover for your spouse. You need to plan for the future whatever your age, whether you are starting work or have already retired. The Government has made it clear that everyone who can afford to save must take care of themselves, as no future administration will be able to provide. Anyone who has recently left university probably owes a large amount of money in student loans and overdrafts, so they need to establish a debt repayment programme before starting to think about saving. But financial planning for 20-year-olds is not limited to coping with debt because the younger you start investing or building a pension, the less it will cost overall (see table above right). The sooner you get into the habit of putting money aside regularly, the less you will miss it. Cox explains: 'If you are fairly young, the cumulative effect of saving over time has a snowball effect. It is better to save £20 a month for 25 years than delay and put in £50 a month for 10 years. Although the amount you pay in is the same, the amount you get out at the end is radically different because it has had time to accumulate. You do not need a fortune if you start early.' The list of financial products is not a target but shows what is available so you can decide which you may find useful and which you can afford. Over the next few weeks, Cash will tell you more about them; but broadly you can see which are essential, which desirable and which you can do without Once you start shopping for financial products, spend time on your research. The internet has made this easy, or you can telephone for a brochure. Get details from several different companies and go through the literature carefully. Cox advises: 'Read the small print. It is amazing what you can find. The product may not be what you thought it was. For example, you might think you are getting life insurance but on closer examination find it is accident insurance.' Be careful not to sign up for a product that looks favourable but has penalties if you need to change or within 12 months decide it is inappropriate and therefore give it up altogether. Here are other top tips from financial experts:  Do not pay too much tax: non-taxpayers, including children, should sign form IR85 available from bank and building society branches and tax offices so interest is paid without tax being deducted.  Check your tax code: you cannot assume the Inland Revenue has it right  Index everything. When you pay in to a pension or investment, build in an automatic annual increase in contributions from the start. It will cost you only a few pennies extra each month. This way your money keeps its value. It need only be a nominal 5 per cent to outpace inflation at present.  If you need a pension, look at stakeholder pensions, which arrive in April. Andy Agar, pensions marketing director of Legal & General, says: 'Customers buying stakeholder pensions can have confidence that the terms are benchmarked by the Government and there are no longer any hidden charges.' The minimum stakeholder contribution will be £20 a month gross, but what you actually pay will be less than that because the tax relief is added on.  Keep your options flexible. Mortgages and pensions used to tie you down, but modern versions allow you to change your contributions and even take a payment holiday. With stakeholder pensions, you can start paying in when you are young - with spare cash and no family commitments?. When you start a family and the costs build up, you can reduce or stop your contributions without penalty and then start building them up again as money gets easier.  Parents and grandparents can take out a stakeholder pension for the children; spouses on behalf of a non-working partner. The recipient does not have to be earning or paying tax yet can have contributions paid on their behalf up to £300 a month or £3,600 a year with no questions asked. The person contributing gets basic-rate tax relief.  A pension is not necessarily the best choice for people on lower incomes because the money is locked away until they retire. You should still save, but an Isa may be better as you can access the money if they really need it. The downside is that the money is available and you may be tempted to use it.  Check that you are paying the least you can for a mortgage. If your own lender has a better product, ask if you can switch. If not, remortgage to a different lender.  Move your current account to one that pays better interest.  Financial planning is not a one-off exercise. You need to keep reviewing your investments. Everyone plans to but, in reality, fails. Cox warns: 'Don't be lazy and leave all your money in a low-paying deposit ac-count that was good when you started.' Bina Abel, an independent financial adviser with Bradford & Bingley, says: 'Life does move on. Every time there is any change in your circumstances, come back to look at your budget again.' Mortgage, insurance, bills but don't forget CDs and chardonnay You may be tempted to ignore this section if you feel you have no money, but everyone should budget. Joanne Cox of the Coop says: 'It is not a matter of how much you earn: people spend what they earn.' You can ignore financial planning only if you always have plenty of money for all you want and need. For the rest of us, a little planning can cut costs and avoid wastage. You can do nothing until you know exactly where you stand. This means adding up all the money you have coming in: salary, overtime, bonuses, any other jobs, pension, state benefits, rental income, maintenance payments, interest from deposit accounts and dividends from investments. You may not regard all this as spending money. You may put your Child Benefit straight into a savings scheme. Or you may reinvest dividends. Ignore those amounts: you are trying to find out exactly how much money you have available to spend. Then calculate your outgoings. This is more difficult than it sounds because small items nibble away at your money and are easy to overlook. You can readily find the figures for mortgage or rent, council tax and utility bills. You may have a reasonable idea how much you spend on food. But you may be deceiving yourself about your booze bill or other weaknesses - be disciplined and realistic. Then add occasional items down to hairdos, makeup, birthday cards, flowers, dry cleaning, magazines and postage stamps. Starting now, write down every penny you spend over a month. You will get a few surprises. Keep the list going for a full year, to include seasonal variations and you will get bigger shocks. There is no need to stop buying treats, but they should be a conscious decision you know you can afford. Wise counsel for counsellor Jan Woodhouse is 55 and has two sons in their twenties but she still has the low-income problems of youngsters just starting their working lives. For 11 years she worked as an administrator for the Kent Institute of Art and Design, but last August took voluntary redundancy and received an ex gratia payment of £5,102. She has registered for Jobseeker's Allowance and started part-time tutoring in English and mathematics for £11 an hour. Her earning time is limited, though, because the rest of her time is spent studying for a diploma in counselling, which she is paying for herself. When she completes the course, she hopes to find part-time counselling work and start a private practice but says that, realistically, she will not be earning more than £20,000 a year. Jan had been contributing to a company pension since 1996 but had to stop when she left her job. She has no plans to retire: 'I expect to continue working for as long as my physical and mental health allow.' She wants to know how to manage her small income to her best advantage, and provide peace of mind for later. While Jan has the same financial worries as young people, she has far less time in which to save for her future. As her children are grown up, her priority now is her own finances. She should follow the budget plan (page 3) to make sure she is not wasting money anywhere and establish exactly where she stands financially - whether she has insurance policies she no longer needs, an emergency fund and enough money to see her through studying. Although she has no plans to retire, she should be saving for a time when she is no longer earning, using the £5,102 as a starting point. This could be through a stakeholder pension or an Isa - depending on whether she wants to tie up her money. She can contact the Benefits Agency or phone 0191 2187585 for a forecast of how much state pension she will receive and a valuation of the company pension from her former employer. What bank manager? Thw role of the traditional bank manager has disappeared. The avuncular figure who filled you with fear but doled out free financial advice of variable quality no longer exists. Geoff Seymour of Alliance & Leicester says: 'If a customer wanted to sort out their credit cards and investments, they could see a customer adviser at a branch for about an hour. Advisers are qualified and will advise on the best way to sort out investments within our own product range.' Banks with an independent financial subsidiary provide a more detailed service. Seymour adds: 'If you want advice on investments not provided by Alliance & Leicester, you can make an appointment, at home or at a branch, with someone from Alliance & Leicester Independent Financial Advisers. There is no fee and, if someone does not want to buy an investment, this is not a problem. It is not out of reach and you can get good advice without it costing you.' Bina Abel of Bradford & Bingley says her organisation has a similar service: 'I could see 10 people over a couple of days. The fact that we don't charge means I see a wide cross-section of the public. The commission we earn from larger investors enables us to help smaller ones.' You do not need to stick with a mortgage or credit card if others offer cheaper rates. Credit card companies are so competitive at the moment that you can play one off against another. Geoff Seymour, of Alliance & Leicester, suggests: 'Switch to a credit card with a very low rate of interest on the balance you transfer.' There are some very low rates for six months to attract you, but they often have steep charges if you make a late payment or want an extra statement. This is how they get their money back. Understand what you are getting into in the contract and be aware of all the charges you may be paying.' Limit your credit cards: it is easier to control one or two. You can delude yourself if you have half a dozen cards each with a small balance.The statements arrive at different times of the month and none looks a lot of money. But it all adds up. If all your credit spending is on one bill, you can easily see what you have spent. This will help you be more disciplined. Some borrowers are better off with a personal loan than a credit card, even though the interest rate is higher. You borrow a fixed amount which you repay over a set period. webTitle: What's it like to have a No 1 single?

fields.headline: What's it like to have a No 1 single?
fields.trailText:
Ray Davies, The Kinks, 'You Really Got Me'
Our first two singles had been more like Beatles pop songs and we wanted to get away from that sound. But the record company didn't. We had to pay £200 out of our own pockets to record our version of 'You Really Got Me'. Before it happened, I thought that getting to No 1 would be like winning the lottery. But I spent that day on a train, in the baggage compartment (I didn't have a seat), with an awful cold and a very runny nose. Lots of people have lots to say about the record but for me the main thing is that there is nothing to the song. It's just about teenage angst, which comes across in the energy of the song. It's about being young and wanting everything and I think that's what records are for really. I'm sure that's why it got to No 1.
fields.body:
Ray Davies, The Kinks, 'You Really Got Me'
Our first two singles had been more like Beatles pop songs and we wanted to get away from that sound. But the record company didn't. We had to pay £200 out of our own pockets to record our version of 'You Really Got Me'. Before it happened, I thought that getting to No 1 would be like winning the lottery. But I spent that day on a train, in the baggage compartment (I didn't have a seat), with an awful cold and a very runny nose. Lots of people have lots to say about the record but for me the main thing is that there is nothing to the song. It's just about teenage angst, which comes across in the energy of the song. It's about being young and wanting everything and I think that's what records are for really. I'm sure that's why it got to No 1.

Suggs, Madness, 'House of Fun'
The inspiration for the song was the film Summer of '42. The song's about a kid entering into the world of adulthood. Basically he's buying his first condom but has to buy loads of lollies and ice-creams first before he gets enough courage to ask for one. It was originally called 'The Chemist Façade' but the record label were quite worried about having a song about condoms. It was our first and only No 1 out of all our hits. We were in Japan at the time. It was about 9 o'clock in the morning when we found out, not a time for partying, but the bass player from the Jam rang us to say congratulations. When we made 'House of Fun' we were definitely at the height of our collaboration - something just came together in the studio. It's a very rare and weird thing.

Tjinder Singh, Cornershop, 'Brimful of Asha' (remix)
The song certainly wasn't written with a chart position in mind. It's a very political song and tries to express the anger a lot of people felt about how they were portrayed in Indian cinema and the issue of the Marda dam. There was also a big influence in terms of vinyl - I'd been brought up on records and the song is a kind of tribute to it.

We were really excited when Fatboy Slim approached us to do a remix of 'Brimful'. We had a really good feeling about it as soon as he played it to us. But I was very surprised when it was a hit because we really didn't think we'd get our message through. I'm really happy that people are enjoying the song and that it appeals to lots of ages.

Terry Hall, The Specials, 'Ghost Town'
Making 'Ghost Town' seemed to take months. I think it took so long because the band were rowing so much. We didn't even want to be in the same room together. In fact, I recorded part of the vocals from my living room because I couldn't stand to be in the same room as the others.

A lot of people see it as a song which encapsulates the riots and the general discontent in Britain at that time, but we didn't intend for it to reflect the frustrated state of the nation. I had mixed feelings when it got to No 1. For us the celebration of having a No 1 was pretty confusing as we always wanted to avoid the world of corporate rock. Looking back, I think it is a good record. It really sums up the period from '77 to '81.

Richard Ashcroft, The Verve, 'The Drugs Don't Work'
I was listening to the chart on the radio sitting in my flat in Chiswick when I heard it had got to No 1. I don't believe in ordering things and making lists but any one who says that charts don't mean anything is lying. I felt a kind of magic when I wrote 'The Drugs Don't Work', like I had got a hidden message through and so the public's recognition of it means a lot to me.

I worked on the song for about 18 months, me like a prize possession, tinkering with it and playing it to other people to get their opinions. I don't really know what the lyrics 'The Drugs Don't Work' mean. It was about me and my wife's life but I don't know any more than that. It doesn't feel like your tune once thousands of people have listened to it on the radio. It's a modern classic, like Noel Gallagher's 'Live Forever'. But I don't think this is the only timeless tune I've written. 'Lucky Man' and 'Bitter Sweet Symphony' both resonate this timeless message.

Interviews by Chloe Diski

fields.headline: Bohemian Rhapsody
fields.standfirst: Paul Morley, who helped choose the short list, loves its kitsch and flash but wishes Britney had beaten the old guard in the final vote
fields.trailText: Now that yet another great list exists - 100 No 1s milling around in some kind of order - do we come any closer to defining what it is that makes a great No 1 single ? Well, yes and no. The charts themselves are a history of pop as decided by a series of committees - the record industry, the media, the consumer. So chart history gives us a compromised, distorted history of pop. No 1s, a result of all sorts of accidents and intentions, hype and luck, distort this history even more. And this list - stupid, strange, dull and exhilarating - shows up the No 1 as an eccentric thing that's related to the history of pop, but sometimes only distantly.
fields.body:
Now that yet another great list exists - 100 No 1s milling around in some kind of order - do we come any closer to defining what it is that makes a great No 1 single ? Well, yes and no. The charts themselves are a history of pop as decided by a series of committees - the record industry, the media, the consumer. So chart history gives us a compromised, distorted history of pop. No 1s, a result of all sorts of accidents and intentions, hype and luck, distort this history even more. And this list - stupid, strange, dull and exhilarating - shows up the No 1 as an eccentric thing that's related to the history of pop, but sometimes only distantly.

The top 15 or so suggests that the voters were trying to straighten out a distorted history of pop by selecting certain standard heavyweights - as if the idea of putting 100 songs in any kind of proper order could ever be taken seriously. At a glance, the top 15 makes a sort of sense - the right-ish names, the right-ish songs, the right-ish mixture of the cracked, the camp, the intense, the treacly and the classic, nicely easing back and forwards through the decades. Then you notice Spiller, the one song from 2000 that was on the short list. You sense hordes of people who weren't born in the Sixties or the Seventies, or even the Eighties, voting for anything remotely recent, putting all their votes in one contemporary pot, fed up with the thick, quirky weight of the past that's in their ears and eyes and way. So in the middle of this polite grown-up overview, a jumpy little rave of protest. (In a few years time, if this exercise is repeated - although I hope we'll be post-nostalgic by then - I suppose Spiller will sink down into the low nineties like Black Box. Or Boney M.) Then you remember that after the Beatles, Stones and the Kinks, very few of the important pop phenomena ever had No 1s: no No 1s for the likes of Dylan, Sly Stone, The Who, Marley, Sex Pistols, Smiths, Stone Roses, Nirvana, REM, Eric B and Rakim, Massive Attack, Radiohead. So any list of No 1s is always going to be relatively lightweight, however hard we try to make it otherwise. Such a list can only really give a few loose clues about the lovely chaos of pop, and supply an erratic index of our weekly need for the solemn, the silly, the flashy and the kitsch. It gives us echoes of great pop, caricatures and occasionally, flukily, the real thing.

The top 15, bar the tickle of Spiller, is a little too right on and predictable, and even the possible surprises - The Verve and The Police - have a damp inevitability. The tastefulness of it all leaves a bad taste. At about 16 or 17, things go a bit haywire, and the list becomes a bundle of tracks that happen to share the bizarre feat of reaching No 1 despite all the obstacles. Order breaks down. Things get a bit livelier. You wish the chart had begun at 17 with 'I'm A Believer'. Then you could get properly upset about the Manics at No 4 rather than having to yet again muster tired outrage at 'Bohemian Rhapsody' being so high, or yet more alarm that people consider 'Everything I Do' a better song than 'Heart Of Glass' or 'Baby Love' when it is obviously as poor as 'Mull Of Kintyre'. (Lennon and McCartney top and tail the list and looking at the songs in between you get a sense of how pop succeeds and fails in trying to bust out of the Lennon and McCartney vice.) Note also the low position of the Stones' 'Satisfaction', which highlights that we live in a pro-Beatles anti-Stones era, which helps explain Blair, Westlife, Chris Evans and OK! magazine. We also live in a pro-Abba age, which helps explain Dale Winton, S Club 7 and Gail Porter. We remain as ever pro-Queen and pro-Police, which explains The Dome, Sir Paul McCartney and Sir Elton John. We appear to be anti-Elton, but I think the fact that we hate 'Candle in the Wind' is more a reflection of our embarrassment at how over the top we went at Diana's death, just as the hatred for Celine Dion reflects our embarrassment at falling for the big sinking ship. From 18 or 19 the list becomes a lovely mess, rather than a polite mess. The No 1 emerges as something somewhere between sweet novelty and grand dotty gesture. You can slice into the list and come up with some nice random runs - 'What A Wonderful World' into 'Praise You', 'I Will Survive' into 'Firestarter'. Maggie May' into 'It's Not Unusual' suggests that Rod should be knighted before Tom.

The way 'That'll Be The Day' pulls up to the bumper of 'Do You Really Want To Hurt Me ?' makes me laugh wildly, possibly at the absurdity of the whole project. That 'Back For Good' is rated better than 'Mr Tambourine Man', makes me cry, until I remember this list is voted by people who prefer 'Millennium' to 'Good Vibrations'.

In that sense, I wish the Madonna choice had been 'Music', as that might have made the top, and been even more provocative. And would people have been so embarrassed by the Spice Girls if the choice had been '2 Become 1' rather than 'Wannabe'? The lack of a Spice presence scamming away at the ankles of a Gallagher or a Garfunkel is as much a sign of the fickle fracturing of fashion as the cute Spiller anomaly.

All those who voted for her as object of hatred should be exiled to the Mull of Kintyre and made to listen to 'Imagine' for the eternity it takes to listen to 'Hey Jude'. fields.headline: Banking with brains?
fields.standfirst: Halifax's IF subsidiary is warning against trusting best-buy tables, writes Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Halifax's IF subsidiary is warning against trusting best-buy tables, writes Jill Insley.
fields.body:
The new telephone and internet bank Intelligent Finance says 'best buy' tables for mortgages and savings are giving consumers inadequate information.

The bank, known as IF, says the tables are unfair to accounts such as its own, which aim to maximise earnings and reduce costs for customers by offsetting borrowings against savings.

It claims they do not reflect the fact that 76 per cent of the UK population with two or more banking products would be better off moving their finances to IF than shopping for 'best buys'.

To back this up, it compared the top products listed in leading newspapers' best buy tables - information provided by MoneyFacts, Blays Guide and London & Country Mortgages - with its own products. The research, which considered various combinations of loans and savings, found customers could be up to £337 a year better off by switching to IF.

Chief executive Jim Spowart says: 'Best Buy tables are widely valued by consumers. However, they don't provide the full picture. Maybe it is time for regulation.'

IF, a subsidiary of the Halifax, has developed the concept of 'connectivity'. The customer can include any combination of five products an IF account: a flexible mortgage, a personal loan, a credit card, a current account and a savings account. These can be 'connected' to cut the interest paid on borrowings, or to increase the amount earned on savings.

The balances in your current and savings accounts can be added together to produce a total which earns the maximum possible interest, ranging from an annual equivalent rate (AER) of 5 per cent on deposits of up to £999, to 6.25 per cent gross on savings of £100,000 or more. Alternatively, any borrowings through a mortgage, loan or credit card can be offset against your savings, thus cutting the interest you pay. For example if you have a £60,000 mortgage and £3,000 in your current account, your savings will be 'connected' to the mortgage, so you pay interest on only £57,000.

Better still, any offsetting can be made against your most expensive form of borrowing. If you have an IF mortgage (discounted to 5.3 per cent for six months) and a personal loan (10.5 per cent APR), you can connect your savings to the personal loan and pay less interest.

The concept is not entirely new: First Active and Virgin One have offered integrated mortgage and current accounts for several years. But IF is the first to enable customers to keep their borrowings and savings in separate, identifiable 'pots' which earn, or charge, interest at different rates.

The idea has proved convincing. Since its launch in late September, 50,000 IF accounts have been opened - more than one a minute - and it has approved more than £500,000,000 in mortgages.

Spowart wants Best Buy information providers to introduce a table for integrated accounts, or to print a warning to readers that 'best buys' may not provide them with the best possible financial results.

However, John Woods, chief executive of MoneyFacts, says: 'Best Buy charts can only compare like with like. It would be totally misleading for any chart to show IF savings rates at 10.8 per cent. Customers can only get this on all their savings with IF if they have credit card borrowings of at least the same amount. How many people would ever have this?

'For people with a lump sum to save, there are better rates available. IF's savings rate at £5,000 is 5.65 per cent, while Abbey National is paying 7 per cent.'

People with low savings but large borrowings are likely to do better with a separate mortgage and a long-term discounted rate.

Although the IF account includes a flexible loan with 1.5 per cent off the standard variable rate of 6.8 per cent, this lasts only six months.

Ray Boulger of independent financial adviser John Charcol says: 'People with mortgages in six figures will find they get better value by having separate mortgage and savings accounts.

'The exception is big hitters in the City earning large bonuses which are put into their IF account and drawn on throughout the year.'

If you are not in the high bonus or high savings categories, Boulger says you may be better off with a mortgage whose discount lasts two or three years. For example, Britannia building society offers a 2.4 per cent discount from its standard variable rate of 7.64 per cent for two years on sums worth up to 75 per cent of a home's value.

 For further information on IF call 0845 609 4343 or visit its website at www.if.com.

fields.headline: Where now?
fields.trailText: Yes, Mr Rawnsley (Comment, last week), many voters will stay away from the polling booths next May or whenever the general election is to be. As a Labour supporter for 36 years and a voter for 31 of them, I experienced the height of electoral gratification on 1 May 1997 when for the first time I voted for a successful Labour candidate in any election.
fields.body:
Yes, Mr Rawnsley (Comment, last week), many voters will stay away from the polling booths next May or whenever the general election is to be. As a Labour supporter for 36 years and a voter for 31 of them, I experienced the height of electoral gratification on 1 May 1997 when for the first time I voted for a successful Labour candidate in any election.

But where can I turn to now? Can I vote for a party which advocates privatisation? Is the Post Office safe? Will the public sector be properly funded? Will wealth be redistributed fairly? New Labour has disenfranchised me.
Martyn Cresswell
Wolverhampton

webTitle: Well, you know what they say - set a thief to catch a thief

fields.headline: Well, you know what they say - set a thief to catch a thief
fields.trailText: I was 12 months into my National Service and at last I'd managed to wangle a cushy little berth in the small refreshment room, set up to supply tea, cakes and cigarettes to resting radar operatives between stints at their screens.
fields.body:
I was 12 months into my National Service and at last I'd managed to wangle a cushy little berth in the small refreshment room, set up to supply tea, cakes and cigarettes to resting radar operatives between stints at their screens.

I'd go down to the village and play the two shops off against each other to get the best deal, then sell the goods on to the boys in blue, back up at the station under the hillside. Naturally, any profits went to the camp benevolent fund.

All went extremely well until this young pilot officer arrived, straight from training school, and began to count the takings.

'There's one pound six and nine pence missing,' he said at the end of his first Friday. I knew about the pound and realised that that thieving swine Radon must have had the other six and nine.

'Are you sure, sir?' I asked all innocent like.

'If it's not back in the tin by Monday morning I'm sending for the MPs,' he barked into my left ear.

Radon had gone up to London, no doubt on strength of his ill-gotten six and nine, and I suspected that Honest Alfie Suggden would be very reluctant to refund any of the pound I'd lost on yesterday's dead cert.

So, in desperation, I went looking for Corporal Redmond in B watch; I'd heard that he had been known to lend out small amounts at 100 per cent with the option of a broken leg or two in default.

Corporal Redmond was built like the proverbial outhouse and as he dropped the greenback into my trembling mitt, I feared for the state of my government-issue underwear.

Monday came and all seemed well at first, but then the CO summoned me up to his office.

'Pilot Officer Janus says there's a thief among us. What are you going to do about it? I'll tell you what you're going to do.'

I would have liked to have said that the cash was back in the tin and as far I was concerned that was the end of the affair but Squadron Leader Slider was the sort who not only asked all the questions but insisted on answering them as well.

'What you'll do is keep these two 10 bob notes in your tin, at all times. I've put a secret mark on them.'

'It's a brilliant idea sir,' I said looking at the green spider he'd drawn on the Queen's nose.

'Charlie will never see it, will he?' he asked. 'No never!' he replied. I could have inquired how he intended tracing the missing note, if it disappeared, but I was a mere SAC and he a squadron leader. I knew my place. In any case, I'd got an idea.

A few days later, I was delighted to give Slider the news that his brilliant plan had worked and one of the notes had gone missing. Soon after that, Janus was mysteriously posted to Reykjavik on aerial rigging duty.

As I lay in the sick bay recovering from the accident with Redmond's lawn mower, I couldn't help the occasional chuckle as I imagined the scene when the unfortunate Janus tried to buy Slider a drink with the green spidered 10 bob note that I slipped into his change when he purchased his daily dose of Senior Service.

fields.headline: A rage round my father
fields.standfirst: He was strange, aloof, and even in death he cheated me
fields.trailText: My father died four years ago. It was shocking news. But it was not his death that shocked me as much as being told his burial had already taken place. It was the ultimate power play - even in death, he had got one over me.
fields.body:
My father died four years ago. It was shocking news. But it was not his death that shocked me as much as being told his burial had already taken place. It was the ultimate power play - even in death, he had got one over me.

This was a man who never hit me, never swore at me, never even shouted at me, but he did rob me. He robbed me of what I felt should have been mine - our relationship - and now, at the very end, I was being robbed again. I was not allowed to grieve, not allowed to vent my anger, not even allowed to buy him a flower. It was too late.

A soulless letter arrived 13 days after his death, announcing his demise. He had been very ill, died and then was buried. It was the way he wanted it, I was told. No other information was available; the phone line to his home in Derbyshire was disconnected.

As a child, I recall walking into Stamford Bridge football ground to the upper tiered seats and watching his beloved Newcastle United take on my team, Chelsea. It was a 1-1 draw and we both left happy and wandered back to his Hampstead flat. I was there for what is known now as a 'sleep-over'.

Except mine was with my father, rather than a school pal. He had moved out of the family home and set up on his own, and I would travel down by train for Saturday night visits. That was about as normal as it ever was, and the best of him.

Six months later, he arrived back at the family home unannounced and set up a camp-bed in the lounge. My horrified mother scooped up her brood and fled. We moved from place to place around the country for three months trying to avoid his grasp. My 11-year-old brain fought to make sense of his descending fragility.

But now I recall the time the social workers asked me whether I wanted to live with my mother or father. I lied and said it made no difference, for fear he would find out I had betrayed him. I spent the rest of the day in bed shaking, scared of the chaos my words might bring. I recall the time he blocked my mother's car in to prevent her driving me away from school and demanded to know why I wouldn't come and live with him, before I ran away screaming. I recall the time he asked my younger sister to sit in his car 'for 10 minutes' and then drove her away. For ever. I recall the time while still living in the family home, he went to live in the attic. He placed a lock and thick chain on the door to stop anyone prying and began his search for Catholicism. He was not a happy man and he found life harder than many. None of it was rational, but the accepting mind of a child absorbs and justifies it all. It was normal to me.

In my twenties, we became estranged. I felt I had tried, but failed, to attain the relationship I wanted. I had repeated the 'I've only got one father' mantra often enough to know actions are needed to back those words. And I felt a little freer. If I'm honest, I changed my surname and refused to invite him to my wedding, partly to spite him. I wanted to teach him a lesson for ignoring me, for being obsessed with his own self. What sort of father are you? I demanded to know. Not the sort I want, I boldly claimed.

Yet after his death that mantra came back to haunt me. Why else did I cry into my hands and sit transfixed by his photograph? How could he make me feel this way - for God's sake, I didn't even like him - but I think, despite myself, I loved the man he should have been, the man I wanted him to be.

A few months later, my son was born; he made me cry as well. A perfect little sod. Innocent, happy, a new start. My overwhelming sense of love for my newly born child felt at odds with my father-and-son feelings. The experience of fatherhood made it difficult to reconcile how relationships change, how the love between man and boy can become a destructive force.

Then I felt an almost irrational need to find out what happened to my father, a need to complete the circle, make sense of him and his attitude to me, to see where he lay.

So I engineered a family holiday in Derbyshire, where, one snowy day, with my son in tow I headed for Buxton cemetery to find his grave. I laboured up and down the rows pushing a buggy, trying to find what remained of his memory. There were thousands of headstones. As I walked up to the front row, his name jumped out and hit me. Proof of his existence and proof of his demise. It was real - he was dead. I don't know why I was surprised, but it was true, here was evidence that he lived. There I stood, pathetically looking at what remained of him, searching for the words that would make it all all right.

Instead, I raged, denouncing him; I still didn't have a flower to leave. Touching the gold grating at the bottom of the headstone, I reached for a fern and placed it inside. Then I manoeuvred my son in front of his grave and took a photograph. It was as close as he would get to his grandfather.

His black headstone was inscribed with just his name, date of birth and the date he died, a stark reminder of his life. And below, in lower case, were the Arabic words maata alshayikh. I had no idea what they meant. I suppose I had hoped in death there would be resolution, maybe a sign that said: 'Here lies a father that loved his son.'

I drove round to his house, where my stepmother still lived. I parked outside, walked up the drive way, and then turned back. I didn't want her to influence how I felt - I wanted whatever I had to be mine.

Nobody I asked knew what the inscription meant; even the internet failed me. So I called the local council, seeking clarification. I was told it was a chess reference. The best he could do was to make his final move a strategic and calculated one. But this time, he had been cornered. It read: 'The king is dead.' The last move of the game. Well, I guess sadly it is my move now, time to move on and time to let him go.

He was my father. I would not be who I am without him. And without him, my daughter and son would not be. And for that I am so, so grateful. I cannot pretend to understand why he did what he did, or even start to unravel his complicated mind. I doubt he knew himself. Despite his Oxford degree, his Fleet Street job, he was flawed. Well, big deal, who isn't?

Happy New Year, old fella, and may you rest in peace.
