fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Fuel protesters at the Avonmouth Docks in Bristol and the Pembroke Docks in Wales halted their demonstrations but vowed this would not be the last the Government would hear from them, although 'not in the immediate future'.
fields.body:
Fuel protesters call off demonstrations at docks after delivering 'short, sharp shock'

Fuel protesters at the Avonmouth Docks in Bristol and the Pembroke Docks in Wales halted their demonstrations but vowed this would not be the last the Government would hear from them, although 'not in the immediate future'.

John Pratt, an activist in the Pembroke demonstration, said it had been 'a short, sharp, shock treatment' to 'send the message to the Government and the oil companies that we are still around'. When they next strike they would 'be relying on an element of surprise'.

Death of rape suspect

A man awaiting trial on a rape charge was found hanged in his cell at Bristol Prison. Michael Lewis, 41, had been there on remand since last month.

Organic farms backed

Agriculture Minister Nick Brown has promised to explore better long-term ways of encouraging farmers to switch to organic methods, but has warned that plans involving tax cuts would fail.

Lesley, 81, a cut above

Lesley Baron, 81, of Dorchester, has claimed the record as the oldest working hairdresser.

Lottery numbers

The winning numbers in last night's National Lottery draw were 6 16 23 34 35 40, bonus 37. Thunderball numbers were 6 7 19 24 32, Thunderball 9. Lottery Express numbers are 11 16 20 26 31 36.

fields.headline: Life expectancy
fields.trailText: It should be made obligatory for every GP to hand over a copy of John Diamond's article on life (Review, last week) to every patient leaving the surgery. It would not surprise me if the benefit to the patient would be greater than all prescriptions put together.
fields.body:
It should be made obligatory for every GP to hand over a copy of John Diamond's article on life (Review, last week) to every patient leaving the surgery. It would not surprise me if the benefit to the patient would be greater than all prescriptions put together.

But there is more to it. We now know that the smallest particles in all our atoms contain within themselves the energy of all life forms in all their manifestations. In accordance with the second law of thermodynamics, 'energy cannot be created nor can it be destroyed', we are assured that even after our demise that energy which was responsible for our every thought and movement will remain on this planet for all eternity. Personally speaking, this thought keeps me in a confident mood and gives me some sort of security even at my age of 87.
Dr L. Horenstein
London W5

fields.headline: Please, no sir
fields.body:
It is clear from Mary Riddell's article (Comment, last week) that reform of the system of honours and titles will not come from the top down. We must reform it from the bottom up. Let us all cease to pander to the nonsense by refusing to call anyone 'Sir' or 'Lord' or 'Your Grace'. It is pointless to complain about titles and gongs if we collude in the process by sycophantically applying them according to protocol.
Tom Paterson
Whitley Bay
Tyne and Wear

fields.headline: Hunt all wrong
fields.trailText: Nice try, Countryside Alliance (News, last week), but you may have fallen at the first hedgerow and dropped your horn in the mud. The three images - child abuse, crime and drugs - are all anti-social, immoral, disgusting and fundamentally illegal. I am baffled at the inclusion of   homelessness as it is none of these, just sad and unnecessary.
fields.body:
Nice try, Countryside Alliance (News, last week), but you may have fallen at the first hedgerow and dropped your horn in the mud. The three images - child abuse, crime and drugs - are all anti-social, immoral, disgusting and fundamentally illegal. I am baffled at the inclusion of homelessness as it is none of these, just sad and unnecessary.

The missing image is that of a ruddy-faced arrogant buffoon in a pink jacket watching dogs rip a fox apart. That image has three of the above attributes but is not illegal yet. When it is, then the rest of us can use the set as a banner for activities for which we have no need in the twenty-first century.
Terry Urlwin
Werrington
Peterborough

webTitle: Observer letters: Euan Ferguson's hate list

fields.headline: What is a Royle?
fields.body:
What an eye opener was your Christmas Eve back page by Euan Ferguson with all the things he hates. I've never heard of about 90 per cent of them but they obviously send him round the twist. I wouldn't recognise a Madonna or a Royle if I saw one; I suggest he tries a little disengagement.
Joan Pennycook
Truro
Cornwall

fields.headline: Action plans
fields.body:
Your article on 'task forces' (News, last week) uses 'advisory groups', 'reviews' and 'task forces' indiscriminately. It decries some of them for not publishing reports when it was never intended that they should. The groups mentioned help us get it right in schools, colleges and universities which is surely rather more important than publishing more reports. Actions speak louder than words.
Jacqui Smith MP
Under-Secretary of State, Department for Education and Employment
London SW1

fields.headline: North exposure
fields.trailText: Tim Luckhurst writes (last week) 'North Britons and proud of it'. Is he being ironic? Even the prestigious North British Hotel (opposite the  Scotsman offices, where he was editor) found this shibboleth outdated and changed its name.
fields.body:
Tim Luckhurst writes (last week) 'North Britons and proud of it'. Is he being ironic? Even the prestigious North British Hotel (opposite the Scotsman offices, where he was editor) found this shibboleth outdated and changed its name.

Britain has failed the British people. For the English there is no solution. The Scots do have a choice. It is called independence.
Andrew Richardson
Nethy Bridge
Inverness-shire

fields.headline: Nowt so queer
fields.trailText: If Nigella Lawson were a lesbian (Comment, last week), she'd be thrilled that the hetrocentric public domain had at long last been infiltrated by Queercompany's rogue lesbian billboard - an image that dares to speak its true intent: queer existence outside of the gay ghetto.
fields.body:
If Nigella Lawson were a lesbian (Comment, last week), she'd be thrilled that the hetrocentric public domain had at long last been infiltrated by Queercompany's rogue lesbian billboard - an image that dares to speak its true intent: queer existence outside of the gay ghetto.

It might be fashionable to describe the naming of 'queer-friendly' straight bars, clubs and hotels 'retrograde' - but this suggests she is unaware of the prejudice queers still encounter when staying in hotels or stray the wrong side of 'acceptable' affection in a non-gay designated zone.
Jane Czyzselska
Queercompany
London EC2

fields.headline: The big issue
fields.standfirst: What are we without our beliefs?
fields.trailText: What are we without our beliefs?
fields.body:
Will Hutton's condescending dismissal of Christian claims (Comment, last week) invites an examination of his own assertion of a secular basis for morality. He tells us that the standard concerns of a stereotypical Observer reader - a free press, the rights of defendants, the condition of the poor - have their roots in instincts that spring from our basic humanity.

What on Earth does this mean? Most of humanity, most of the time, has organised itself into societies displaying very little evidence of liberal values - and, if good has its origins in basic humanity, presumably evil does also. Indeed, the very language of good and evil implies some system of values, derived other than from our instincts, which enables us to distinguish between them.

As our society becomes more secular, how far is it becoming more liberal? The prevailing values are those, not of The Observer, but of the Sun - authoritarian, hedonist, mean-minded and xenophobic. The dominant scientific orthodoxy, that of the evolutionists, presents an understanding of human nature which gives little comfort to either liberals or socialists.

With any pretensions to scientific basis kicked away, both liberalism and socialism seem to have their origins very much in Judaeo-Christian concepts of justice and the individual. It's odd that liberalism and secularism are still regarded as allies.
Philip Jones
Morden
Surrey

The possible evolution of human being into conscious computer being (Life, last week) is intriguing, made more so after reading Will Hutton.

Religion, whether seen as God-inspired or of human invention, gives purpose to our existence. Despite being diverse, illogical and prone to bigotry, religious belief does enable us to wrestle with the ultimate question: 'Why am I?'

Computers are, above all else, logical. A super-intelligent, conscious computer would logically grasp the futility of its own existence and, unless it could come up with a quirkily human distraction, such as shopping or football, its only logical response to the ultimate question would be to commit suicide. So the supremacy of fallible, inconsistent but endlessly interesting humans is secure!
Rev Chris Gardner
Worthing
W Sussex

fields.headline: Rough injustice
fields.trailText: In your article about the desperate situation of those sleeping rough in our streets (News, last week), you quote Louise Casey as asking: 'What more have we to do?' The first thing that lady has to do is to face the fact that she has made a mistake. To tell people not to give to beggars is an offence to our common humanity.

fields.headline: Trident tested
fields.body:
I am currently remanded in HMP Brockhill for 'taking responsibility' for Trident - a nuclear weapons system that costs £2,000 a minute to operate. As a member of the Trident Ploughshare Campaign, which has asked the British Government repeatedly to take action on Trident, I, together with Father Martin Newell, started disarming the nuclear weapons convoy in November. We are tired of waiting for the Government to clean up Trident and too terrified to wait any longer.
Susan van der Hÿden
HMP Brockhill
Redditch
Worcs

webTitle: If the US bubble is pricked can the fall be controlled? Pt 2

fields.headline: If the US bubble is pricked can the fall be controlled? Pt 2
fields.standfirst: Is recession driven by the price of oil or will it drive the price down? Oliver Morgan looks at the options for the producers' cartel
fields.trailText: The new millennium opens to an intriguing tale of two cities. Later this month, the eyes of the world will be on Washington, where a president - half of whose people do not want him - will be inaugurated. His investiture comes as his country threatens to dive into recession, possibly dragging Europe and the UK down too.
fields.body:
The new millennium opens to an intriguing tale of two cities. Later this month, the eyes of the world will be on Washington, where a president - half of whose people do not want him - will be inaugurated. His investiture comes as his country threatens to dive into recession, possibly dragging Europe and the UK down too.

Just before that, in Vienna, the leaders of the world's most important cartel, the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec), will meet to try to manipulate the price of oil.

According to some observers, the activities of the latter over the past two years - when from the spring of 1999 Opec cut oil production, triggering a surge in crude prices from $10 a barrel to $35 - have determined the inauspicious inheritance of the former.

Professor Andrew Oswald of Warwick University argues that history shows recessions following oil price hikes as night follows day. He feels vindicated. 'If you look historically, rises in the price of oil have been a very good predictor of world recessions - in the early and late Seventies, and in the early Nineties. That timing is coming true again,' he says.

It is not simply history; it is fundamentals. Despite the talk of a weightless, oil-less economy, tipped into recession by the bursting of the dotcom bubble, Oswald says: 'Oil is the largest source of energy on the globe, and you only have to look at any modern economy to see how fundamental energy is to its way of life.'

But the world moves on. Oil prices tumbled in December - from $35 to about $25 in barely more than a trading week, prompted by the delayed effects of cumulative increases in Opec production last year of 3.7 million barrels a day (mbd).

This fall is what is focusing attention on Vienna, where Opec meets in two weeks. Saudi Arabia - traditionally an Opec 'dove' - has been calling for a 1.5 mbd cut in production (5.5 per cent of Opec production and nearly 2 per cent of global consumption) to shore up the price to the mid point of its $22-$28 target range.

But traders say this is unlikely to happen. Salomon Smith Barney forecasts the 'Opec basket' benchmark to trade at an average of $20.50 this year, compared with $27.60 last year - a 25 per cent fall.

Salomon's Carlo Moccia points out that the price was sustained by worries over shortages of crude oil, gasoline and more recently winter heating oil - particularly in the US, which consumes about 20 per cent of the 76 mbd production.

He says: 'Typically there is 70-90 days' forward cover for demand for products. In September 2000 that came down to as low as 40 days. [This was when the US government took the extraordinary step of releasing its strategic oil reserve to boost supplies.]

'When we get to a level, possibly as soon as January, where forward stocks will last through the winter, we expect the oil price to come down sharply, to as low as $15. Prices may stabilise in the second and third quarters.'

These arguments are well recognised by some of the Opec states. Hawks such as Kuwait have been arguing for a 2 mbd cut.

Analysts, who do not have to make predictions, are more reticent about prices. Dr Manouchehr Takin of the Centre for Global Energy Studies points out that inventory figures are now more comfortable .

But he says: 'It is hard to judge simply by the published numbers, because they are difficult and arrive late. We do not know how much oil has been consumed, and this is more difficult to estimate because consumers did a lot of panic buying last summer.'

Add to this the question of Iraq, which at the beginning of last month cut off its 2.3 mbd supply after demands for 50 cent surcharges above prices agreed by the United Nations' oil-for-aid programme were refused.

The aims of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein - to promote an oil crisis and test President-elect George W. Bush - were frustrated as crude prices plunged. Iraq resumed some exporting last month. However, it is unclear what Saddam will do next (exports have been halted again since 31 December) or whether an Iraqi cut will be in place when and if Opec decides on one later this month.

More broadly, UK oil analyst Steven Turner points out: 'We all know it is much more difficult for Opec to manage cuts in output than rises, because individual countries do not want to cut their revenues.'

Lower prices - if they do stay low this year - will impact on the slow-down scenarios being painted in Washington and London.

Oswald expects a similar pattern to that of 1990-91, with lower prices feeding into a recovery next year. He says: 'Undoubtedly part of the reason for the $10 drop is that the market has taken a view that the world economy is slowing, and that the demand for oil will slow, therefore the price will fall. This is the next stage of the process, an automatic correction.'

Others would argue that oil prices no longer determine recessions; rather, recessions determine oil prices.

Economists do expect the oil price to provide some counterbalance if a US-led slowdown materialises later this year. In the UK, David Hillier of Barclays Capital says: 'For the first three quarters of the year, lower oil prices are going to push inflation down to closer to 2 per cent rather than the 2.5 per cent Government target.'

Hillier has adjusted his oil-price forecast for 2001 from $28 to $22, which delivers a 0.2 per cent drop in inflation. This, he believes, will help offset the inflationary impact of what appears to be stubborn consumer demand on the high street - evidenced by strong Christmas trading. In this scenario, if recession comes, oil will not be a contributory factor, as it was during the 'stagflation' of the Seventies.

The outlook is anything but clear. Paul Horsnell of the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies says: 'The price will be difficult to predict over the coming year: I expect more volatility. The key problem is creaking infrastructure - when you are running refineries at 95 to 97 per cent capacity, there is little margin for error.'

Further off, Oswald believes oil will continue to maintain its influence over the global economy. 'This is the first time in history that we have seen a doubling of the oil price without a war. That is a signal of long-term oil demand.'

And for those who say the US and Western economies are no longer as oil-reliant as they were in the Seventies he says: 'You have to think about China. It has five times the population of the US, and at the moment has one-twenty-fifth of the vehicles. You don't need a PhD in economics to see that demand is going to soar.'

Despite the talk of a weightless, oil-less economy, tipped into recession by the bursting of the dotcom bubble, Oswald says: 'Oil is the largest source of energy on the globe, and you only have to look at any modern economy to see how fundamental energy is to its way of life.' But the world moves on. Oil prices tumbled in December - from $35 to about $25 in barely more than a trading week, prompted by the delayed effects of cumulative increases in Opec production last year of 3.7 million barrels a day (mbd). This fall is what is focusing attention on Vienna, where Opec meets in two weeks. Saudi Arabia - traditionally an Opec 'dove' - has been calling for a 1.5 mbd cut in production (5.5 per cent of Opec production and nearly 2 per cent of global consumption) to shore up the price to the mid point of its $22-$28 target range. But traders say this is unlikely to happen. Salomon Smith Barney forecasts the 'Opec basket' benchmark to trade at an average of $20.50 this year, compared with $27.60 last year - a 25 per cent fall. Salomon's Carlo Moccia points out that the price was sustained by worries over shortages of crude oil, gasoline and more recently winter heating oil - particularly in the US, which consumes about 20 per cent of the 76 mbd production. He says: 'Typically there is 70-90 days' forward cover for demand for products. In September 2000 that came down to as low as 40 days. [This was when the US government took the extraordinary step of releasing its strategic oil reserve to boost supplies.] 'When we get to a level, possibly as soon as January, where forward stocks will last through the winter, we expect the oil price to come down sharply, to as low as $15. Prices may stabilise in the second and third quarters.' These arguments are well recognised by some of the Opec states. Hawks such as Kuwait have been arguing for a 2 mbd cut. Analysts, who do not have to make predictions, are more reticent about prices. Dr Manouchehr Takin of the Centre for Global Energy Studies points out that inventory figures are now more comfortable . But he says: 'It is hard to judge simply by the published numbers, because they are difficult and arrive late. We do not know how much oil has been consumed, and this is more difficult to estimate because consumers did a lot of panic buying last summer.' Add to this the question of Iraq, which at the beginning of last month cut off its 2.3 mbd supply after demands for 50 cent surcharges above prices agreed by the United Nations' oil-for-aid programme were refused. The aims of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein - to promote an oil crisis and test President-elect George W. Bush - were frustrated as crude prices plunged. Iraq resumed some exporting last month. However, it is unclear what Saddam will do next (exports have been halted again since 31 December) or whether an Iraqi cut will be in place when and if Opec decides on one later this month. More broadly, UK oil analyst Steven Turner points out: 'We all know it is much more difficult for Opec to manage cuts in output than rises, because individual countries do not want to cut their revenues.' Lower prices - if they do stay low this year - will impact on the slow-down scenarios being painted in Washington and London. Oswald expects a similar pattern to that of 1990-91, with lower prices feeding into a recovery next year. He says: 'Undoubtedly part of the reason for the $10 drop is that the market has taken a view that the world economy is slowing, and that the demand for oil will slow, therefore the price will fall. This is the next stage of the process, an automatic correction.' Others would argue that oil prices no longer determine recessions; rather, recessions determine oil prices. Economists do expect the oil price to provide some counterbalance if a US-led slowdown materialises later this year. In the UK, David Hillier of Barclays Capital says: 'For the first three quarters of the year, lower oil prices are going to push inflation down to closer to 2 per cent rather than the 2.5 per cent Government target.' Hillier has adjusted his oil-price forecast for 2001 from $28 to $22, which delivers a 0.2 per cent drop in inflation. This, he believes, will help offset the inflationary impact of what appears to be stubborn consumer demand on the high street - evidenced by strong Christmas trading. In this scenario, if recession comes, oil will not be a contributory factor, as it was during the 'stagflation' of the Seventies. The outlook is anything but clear. Paul Horsnell of the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies says: 'The price will be difficult to predict over the coming year: I expect more volatility. The key problem is creaking infrastructure - when you are running refineries at 95 to 97 per cent capacity, there is little margin for error.' Further off, Oswald believes oil will continue to maintain its influence over the global economy. 'This is the first time in history that we have seen a doubling of the oil price without a war. That is a signal of long-term oil demand.' And for those who say the US and Western economies are no longer as oil-reliant as they were in the Seventies he says: 'You have to think about China. It has five times the population of the US, and at the moment has one-twenty-fifth of the vehicles. You don't need a PhD in economics to see that demand is going to soar.'

fields.headline: Squashed by a hard landing
fields.standfirst: Stephen King, global chief economist at HSBC,  on which countries will suffer the most
fields.trailText: US interest rates may have fallen, but there is no guarantee that the Federal Reserve will be able to prevent a hard landing for the economy. We are now seeing signs of distress that may reduce the effectiveness of interest-rate cuts.
fields.body:
US interest rates may have fallen, but there is no guarantee that the Federal Reserve will be able to prevent a hard landing for the economy. We are now seeing signs of distress that may reduce the effectiveness of interest-rate cuts.

Banks are less prepared to lend. In parts of the corporate bond market, liquidity has dried up. The collapse in the Nasdaq implies a significant deterioration in the cost and availability of funds going into the 'new economy'. On top of all this, there's been a substantial decline in household wealth. That's an event that has occurred only ahead of major recessions.

What does all this mean? Our distress signals effectively imply blockages within the system, which prevent interest rate cuts from performing their usual magic. As a result, even with lower rates, the US economy may still end up in recession.

So how will the rest of the world react? There is some good news. Over the past 35 years, US recessions have come and gone, but they have never been associated with a truly global recession. When some countries are doing badly, there are always one or two that are doing a lot better. The oil shocks, for example, may have been terrible news for the western industrialised world but, for Opec, they represented a sudden surge in spending power.

Rather than worrying about the global economy as a whole, it may be more useful to work out who suffers most from an American hard landing. How can we do this?

The easiest approach is to focus on the share of a country's GDP being exported to the US. On that basis, Canada and Mexico face the biggest risks, whereas the central European countries and - more surprisingly - Brazil and Argentina are among the least exposed. The UK and Europe also appear to have only modest vulnerability.

But this approach, has limited usefulness. There are a number of other important factors to consider. Falling global demand will hit countries that produce raw materials but benefit those which import raw materials - as commodity prices fall.

Those countries that have built up large investments in the US in recent years will find themselves having to pay a significant price in terms of lower investment income from America. Countries that have pegged their currencies against the dollar may benefit from general dollar depreciation, an inevitable consequence of a US hard landing. Those that haven't - including the UK and Europe - may find themselves on the wrong end of a competitive adjustment.

Meanwhile, the fall in the value of global technology shares may create problems which spread beyond America's shores. Our estimates, for example, suggest that Japan's apparent recovery in the first half of 2000 was being fuelled by a heavy dose of technology mania. With the bubble now having burst, the danger is of a renewed collapse in Japanese capital spending, sending the economy into a tailspin once again.

HSBC has a US recession-exposure scoring system, designed to capture all of the varying effects outlined above. It provides a score for exposure to US recession in each of six different categories. The aggregate number at the end gives an overall 'vulnerability to US recession' rating. On our analysis, the UK is more vulnerable than virtually any other area of the world, other than the North American Free Trade Area (Nafta) countries. Why?

Trade exposure is clearly not the answer: the UK is no more exposed on the export front than euroland, for example. The real dangers lie elsewhere. In particular, the UK's heavy investments in the US economy leave it vulnerable to a severe weakening in investment income.

Meanwhile, the UK remains a country of choice for US investors looking to put their money abroad - and there will be a lot less of that sort of thing if the US really does go into recession. Does this mean that the UK will be dragged into recession as well? Not necessarily. The good news is that the UK has plenty of room on the policy front. Fiscal policy is already being loosened and there are likely to be more giveaways in the next Budget. Meanwhile, some members of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee are already signalling that rates should come down. In other words, although the British economy is heavily exposed to the US, there is a lot that policy makers can potentially do to avoid a UK version of an American hard landing.

Do British policymakers need to act right away? Perhaps not. Although the Federal Reserve has made its intentions clear, the UK is, to date, nowhere near as weak as the US. Indeed, recent data on the domestic economy and on exports have suggested a far higher level of resilience than might be expected given developments across the Atlantic.

UK base rates will almost certainly come down this year. But the continued strength of the domestic economy suggests that hopes of a rate cut as early as this week may prove premature.

webTitle: If the US bubble is pricked can the fall be controlled?

fields.headline: If the US bubble is pricked can the fall be controlled?
fields.standfirst: The Fed chief's rate cut was a big surprise. Faisal Islam considers whether it will do more harm than good and what it conceals
fields.trailText: If the cold chill of a US recession is felt by any group of people in Britain, it will be the blue blazer brigade flogging £1 million yachts in champagne bars at the London Boat Show this weekend.
fields.body:
If the cold chill of a US recession is felt by any group of people in Britain, it will be the blue blazer brigade flogging £1 million yachts in champagne bars at the London Boat Show this weekend.

Costly luxury items, such as the Princess 20M motorboat, priced at that magic £1m, are normally the first to suffer when booms turns to bust. But manufacturers at the Earls Court show, which export a third of their boats to the US, were cheerful.

'Our order books are full, we have not seen any slowdown, and following Alan Greenspan's interest rate cut, we are cautiously optimistic,' said Clive Brooks, sales manager at Marine Projects, maker of the Princess range.

Howard Pridding of the British Marine Industries Federation agreed: 'With a change in president, this sort of speculation is natural, but confidence remains high.' For this bunch, whose businesses can collapse at the merest whiff of a slowdown, the response seems to be: 'What recession?' And the Fed chief's action only reinforced their confidence.

Cross the Atlantic and the mood is more fragile. Some 40 million US consumers receive monthly pension statements showing the value of their funds. Overall, about half of US households hold shares directly, or indirectly through mutual funds and pension plans.

So after a year in which the Nasdaq lost more than half of its peak value and other markets ended significantly down, it is not surprising that Americans are buying fewer cars, spent less at Christmas and are worrying about the size of their debts. After four years' growth in real household net worth of between 5 and 12 per cent, last year's share slide will see a fall of around 5 per cent,according to HSBC projections.

Business confidence is no better. Poor sales, the impact of last year's interest rate and oil price rises, and less cheap investment finance have taken their toll on profits.

Federal Reserve surveys show credit conditions at their tightest since the last recession, a decade ago. Most importantly, people - specifically, important members of George W Bush's new administration - are talking, repeatedly, about recession. And if anyone had any doubts about the US economy, Greenspan's astonishing move seems to have sounded a final warning siren.

Economists are split over the wisdom of the cut: was it too late, was it panic, or was it another stunning manoeuvre by the sage of global macroeconomics?

'This is a very precipitous and almost desperate action on the part of the Fed,' said Stanley Nabi of Credit Suisse Asset Management in New York. 'What information do they have that you and I don't? Do they know any financial institutions that are in trouble? The Fed rarely acts between formal meetings. If it did, it would be a sign that it thought things were worse than we did - that they were acting to prevent a disaster.'

In this view the talk of recession is overblown, but Greenspan's action may add to the panic-ridden downward spiral. Indeed, market euphoria after the surprise cut on Wednesday had been replaced by Friday with neurosis about liquidity problems in the financial sector.

A more optimistic interpretation is that the cut was a skillful, timely vaccination against the virus of poor consumer and business confidence before the entire economy was infected. 'The Fed is always right,' Lawrence Lindsey, President-elect Bush's chief economic adviser, said last week. Other veins of thought say Greenspan has done too little, too late, especially after the oil price volatility that began last September, or that he is doing little more than propping up the Nasdaq, increasing the extent of any slowdown that finally arrives.

Certainly the Fed's move seems to have raised more questions than it answered. Why, for instance, didn't Greenspan lower rates at last month's meeting, or earlier?

Does the move mark the Fed chairman's tacit support for Bush's $1.3 trillion tax cut plan? Some analysts believe the move marks Greenspan's efforts to lay down the law to the incoming President. He met Bill Clinton in 1992 to instruct the then starry-eyed arrival on which parts of his election manifesto were economically feasible.

Conversely, others note that Greenspan, a Republican appointee, owes a political debt to the Bush clan for 'losing' George Bush Senior the 1991 election through interest rate rises. The 180-degree turnaround in the Fed's attitude and policy has coincided exactly with the younger Bush's preparations to assume the presidency, and sits nicely with his tax cuts.

But was the dampening of irrational exuberance in stock markets and consumer spending not what he wanted anyway? By rights we are now seeing the effect of the 50-basis-point rise made by Greenspan in May, a move undertaken two months after the initial dotcom stock market bubble had burst. If he's having to take fairly drastic action now, perhaps that move was misplaced.

The textbook rule of monetary policy is that it acts with lags that are long and variable. Greenspan's action was intended to have a much more immediate impact.

'It was an exercise in applied psychology,' as John Llewellyn, global chief economist at Lehman Brothers puts it. Never before under Greenspan has the Fed marked a change in monetary policy stance with a 50-point move nor, bar the 1987 stock market crash, has it done so between meetings. But Greenspan's game is a tactical one: surprise markets, media and consumers for maximum effect.

In the past, the Fed didn't even announce such shifts; now they are trumpeted loudly, sending a clear message that the Fed is there for the rescue. Otherwise, there is the very real risk that US consumers will start saving at precisely the wrong time in the economic cycle, and rein in spending even more.

But such action also injects fragility into market expectations. Ideally, monetary policy should be boring, predictable and directly dis- cernible from the data. One surprise invites the markets to speculate on further surprises, and so on.

Of course it could be that this is the bell tolling to show that the decade-long party is officially over, and there is little the Fed can do. The direct effects of monetary policy changes will be felt by companies only in seven or eight months. Meanwhile, the outlook for corporate earnings remains bleak throughout the first half of the year. And with interest-rate cuts and general economic weakness bringing down the dollar, inflation cannot be forgotten..

After all, the causes of the longest postwar US boom are manifold, but low interest rates were not principal among them. Positive market sentiment, cheap finance, and a bias towards entrepreneurial risk-taking were all interrelated factors sustaining it - and now they are absent. Llewellyn, formerly an economist at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, recalls the lament of Governor Mieno of the Bank of Japan, who tried in the early Nineties to bring a bubble economy based on property prices slowly down to earth. 'Pricking the bubble is the easy part; controlling the fall is the problem.'

Is a US recession looming?

Factors for
1. Consumer confidence is low
2. Household net worth is falling - a sure predictor of recession
3. Credit conditions for companies of all sizes are tightening
4. Jobless figures are inching up
5. There is a threat from the low savings rate and a huge current account deficit financed by uncertain foreign capital flows

Factors against
1. Growth, though down, is nowhere near the two quarters of negative growth required
2. Unemployment is still close to record lows of 4.9 per cent
3. Greenspan's interest rate cut will do the trick
4. Bush's tax cuts will provide the required boost to consumers
5. Talk of recession is a political game designed to win backing for tax cuts

fields.headline: Airbus's giant wings of desire
fields.standfirst: The superjumbo is good news for British workers, as long as German hopes are checked, writes Joanna Walters
fields.trailText: Airbus's new idea is to get into shipping. Don't be puzzled. The European jetmaker has no plans to start welding tankers together for a life on the ocean wave.
fields.body:
Airbus's new idea is to get into shipping. Don't be puzzled. The European jetmaker has no plans to start welding tankers together for a life on the ocean wave.

This is a watery solution to an air-transport problem. The wings for the new, double-deck A3XX aircraft are so enormous that the only way they could be delivered from its North Wales factory to the final assembly line in southern France is by sea and then river barge.

Airbus has just passed two of the most important milestones in its 30-year existence. First, the Anglo-German-French-Spanish Airbus partners have decided to go-ahead with building A3XX at a cost of £7 billion, after years of brandishing giant models, computer graphics and fables about the giant's potential to house flying squash courts and swimming pools.

Now renamed the A380, the giant craft will, when it takes to the skies in 2006, leapfrog the Boeing 747 as the world's largest passenger aircraft, capable of seating between 550 and 900 people.

The second milestone was the partners agreeing to abandon their loose consortium arrangement and turn Airbus into a single company, in which the UK's BAE Systems (formerly British Aerospace) will have a 20 per cent stake.

The other 80 per cent will be held by European Aerospace, Defence and Space (EADS), the giant new company formed by the merger of the Continental partners, France's Aerospatiale Matra, Germany's DaimlerChrysler Aerospace and Spain's Casa.

The birth of the single company should herald a new era of huge potential growth, efficiency and profitability - and frighten the life out of Airbus's US rival Boeing. But it has also raised the disturbing question of the long-term security of around 9,000 Airbus jobs in Britain.

BAE Systems has the option from 2004 to sell its stake in Airbus to EADS. Some observers are asking whether, if it does so, Germany will snatch away Britain's world-class wingmaking capability, with the loss to the UK of highly skilled Airbus jobs at its Filton and Broughton factories in Bristol and North Wales and tens of thousands of additional subcontractor jobs. One UK aerospace source said: 'BAE Systems currently has a veto over all sorts of Airbus matters, such as the location of wing manufacturing. If it sells its stake in the new, single Airbus company, what are the obligations of the Germans and French to maintain employment and plants in the UK?'

DaimlerChrysler Aerospace has always coveted Britain's high-technology wing design and manufacturing over its own less glamorous and lower-value role of making the fuselage. The source said: 'They have hankered after BAE's wing-making capability for years and years. With each new Airbus product range and each variant of an existing aircraft, the Germans have been very keen to get their foot in the door on wing-making contracts, and they submit bids.' These bids always lose to the UK, but they are a dramatic indicator of German desires. DaimlerChrysler has strong military aircraft capability and a history of involvement in plane making - with defunct Fokker of the Netherlands and German regional jet brand Dornier - all of which give it aspirations towards Airbus way beyond bashing fuselages into shape.

'If they could win some wing work, it would be the thin end of the wedge and they would try and get on a par with BAE product by product,' said the source.

When Airbus developed the A320, Germany grasped the right to final assembly of this family of smaller jet from Aerospatiale of France and built its own facilities in Hamburg, desperate to be on a par with Toulouse. Said the source: 'It could be like a Trojan horse for Germany's ambition to dominate Airbus.'

It is understood that DaimlerChrysler fought particularly hard to win rights to develop wings for the 'superjumbo' A380. This would have been a massive blow to Airbus UK and a bridgehead to assault Britain's wing-making domain.

The threat was instrumental in persuading the Government to commit to £530 million in repayable launch aid for the A380 - even before the jet was given the official manufacturing go-ahead at Airbus and before the other partners' governments made their contributions. If BAE sold its stake in Airbus, and EADS tried to transfer wing work to Germany, the Department of Trade and Industry and its Secretary of State, Stephen Byers, would undoubtedly demand the instant return of the £530m.

Mike Turner, chief operating officer at BAE Systems, told The Observer: 'There are safeguards to the British jobs. But City analysts are not convinced. Nick Cunningham of Salomon Smith Barney, and Sandy Morris of ABN Amro, agreed that BAE was likely to sell out.

Cunningham said: 'It is a good thing that Airbus is restructuring, but it is also a step on the way to disposal [of its Airbus interest] by BAE. Over the next few years there should be good profits from Airbus, but BAE is a defence company. Realising capital from its Airbus holding and putting it into the core defence business at the right time would be good.'

However, the Government's position and strong industrial logic would see Britain continue to dominate wing-making for Airbus. Cunningham said: 'The UK would be very embarrassed if the jobs and the knowledge moved overseas.'

So it seems certain that the vision of 45 metre-long wings sailing majestically from Wales to France will be realised - heralding supremacy in the skies.

1971: Spain's national aerospace company CASA joins Airbus as 4.2 per cent partner.

1974: First Airbus aircraft, the 250-seat A300, goes into service with Air France.

1979: British Aerospace, formed in 1977 from merger of Hawker Siddeley and British Aircraft Corp, joins Airbus as full member with 20 per cent stake.

1983: Airbus A310 goes into service with new digital flight systems.

1988: 150-seater A320 launched with fly-by-wire controls, proving controversial after some early crashes.

webTitle: Can child's play pay? Yes it can

fields.headline: Can child's play pay? Yes it can
fields.standfirst: Kids'  TV is now big business,  with merchandising spin-offs worth millions,  reports Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Karl Woolley, managing director of Tell-Tale Productions - which makes the Tweenies for the BBC - has been asked so many times to explain the success of the TV characters that he has a theory finely honed: 'They're just kids. The kids are just watching themselves. Some programmes feature a talking dog or something, but the kids love watching themselves.'
fields.body:
Karl Woolley, managing director of Tell-Tale Productions - which makes the Tweenies for the BBC - has been asked so many times to explain the success of the TV characters that he has a theory finely honed: 'They're just kids. The kids are just watching themselves. Some programmes feature a talking dog or something, but the kids love watching themselves.'

But Georgia, 3, knows exactly why she and millions of other children her age like Tweenies Bella, Milo, Jake and Fizz. 'They're nice,' she says. 'What do you mean, nice?' her father asks. 'They're puddy,' comes Georgia's earnest reply.

This may not seem a revealing answer, but it is. Georgia's mysterious faith in the merits of the fab four is a force to be reckoned with. Broadcasters love pre-school children more than any other demographic group, simply because these kids know what they want, and aren't fazed by peer-group pressure.

'Pre-schoolers tend to be very honest,' says Katie Foster, director of consumer products at Hit Entertainment, the company behind the phenomenally successful Bob the Builder series on the BBC. 'They like things because they like them, rather than because friends tell them to like them. They're a lot less faddish, a lot more faithful. Playground currency is very dangerous. Look at Pokémon. Hot one minute, then out of the window.'

Children's television is now big news. So much so that the BBC is to launch two new digital television channels dedicated to children's programming later this year. It will spend £100 million (double its current budget) on new commissions.

The seemingly inexorable rise of the industry is to some extent the result of an injection of talent. 'Only 10 years ago children's television was seen as the bottom of the business,' says Rupert Gavin, chief executive of BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the corporation. 'But now it's attracting the most creative producers in the country.'

But it is also down to the fact that the companies behind the likes of Bella and Bob are now aware that successful kids TV characters are capable of generating multimillion-pound merchandising deals, some of which bring in more money than the firms would expect to make from broadcasting fees.

Tweenies, for example, sold more than £100m worth of merchandise last year - beating the record set by the Teletubbies in its first year. In addition to notching up a number one single, Tweenies also swelled Auntie's coffers with a Christmas video and an educational CD-rom. Now the show's characters are on tour around the UK, playing to sell-out audiences.

So delighted is the BBC with Tweenies that it has commissioned another 130 half-hour programmes to add to the 260 screened since March 1999. This is all good news for Aunty, which last year earned revenues of around £80m from its children's division, of which 25 per cent came from merchandising sales.

So seriously does the BBC take the potential of merchandising that it has built a factory in China dedicated to making toys based around its programmes. This means the BBC can ensure its products meet a certain standard and, at the same time, keep the entire merchandising cake to itself without having to sign-up costly third parties.

But Tweenies' success is dwarfed by that of Thomas the Tank Engine - with around $500m worth of merchandise a year across 2,500 product ranges. The company that owns the Thomas name, Gullane Entertainment, has licensed the character to more than 500 companies, including toymakers Bandai and Hornby and food giant Heinz. Thomas even has his own theme park in Japan and last year hit the big screen in a feature film. More than 60 per cent of the revenues Thomas generates for Gullane come from merchandising deals.

Hit Entertainment has already licensed the Bob the Builder brand for more than 500 products and, given the success of its Christmas number one single, more deals must be likely. Already more than 40 per cent of the revenues Bob generates for Hit come from licensing deals.

'We'd like to claim we always knew it was going to be fantastic,' says Foster, 'but you can never expect it to be as fantastic as it turned out.'

Bob is the most visible success of the UK licensing industry, which rough estimates suggest is worth nearly £5 billion. About a third of this currently comes from character and entertainment merchandising - by far the biggest segment of the market.

Parents may moan that they are condemned to years of pester power but the companies that own the rights to the characters argue that without licensing the programmes wouldn't get made.

A half-hour of quality children's television costs £120,000-£350,000. In recent years the major broadcasters have started to agree to pay for part of the programmes up front to help offset swingeing start-up costs, but the producers argue that an increasingly discerning audience means they still have to find other income streams.

'The shows are so bloody expensive to make that an alliance between the commercial and creative sides is a necessity,' says Angus Fletcher, head of UK TV for the Jim Henson Company, behind the Muppets, Fraggle Rock and, later this month on Channel 4, The Hoobs, a series about friendly aliens who land on Earth.

Significantly, as broadcasters and production companies have woken up to the need to create credible, durable characters, capable of sustaining a plethora of licensing deals, they have moved to commission longer- running series to allow the programmes to become more established. Channel 4, for example, has commissioned more than 250 episodes of The Hoobs, the largest-ever pre-school commission to date.

'You have to move away from short runs of programmes. There's much more potential if the characters are credible and believable, and this only comes over time,' Fletcher says. Several companies are prepared to trade fat broadcasting fees if their series get prime-time slots. 'The crucial thing is getting the best possible TV exposure for the character, says William Harris, chief executive of Gullane. We would accept a lower fee in return for better exposure. There are instances where people will give it away free.'

But having the conviction to commission a large number of programmes is risky. 'No one has the patent on the magic formula,' says Gordon Welsh, spokesman for the Just Group, the company behind the revival of Pinky and Perky (coming soon to a channel near you) and the irreverent 3D animated series Butt-ugly Martians.

For this reason commissioners increasingly want to be convinced that the series will have merchandising potential. But there is a fine line between maximising revenue and tarnishing the brand.

'You need to keep the integrity of the character,' said Leysa Kay, a consultant for Brand Licensing London. 'It's not about being a prostitute to everyone who wants to sign a licence.' Hit, for instance, which has signed up around 60 licensees to make Bob the Builder products, turned down a similar number of interested firms because it didn't feel they were suitable for the brand.

Hit's Foster says: 'The industry is a lot more sophisticated. In the past it was all about mugs and T-shirts. People thought they could just stick an image on something, whack it out to a retailer and make shedloads, but that's all changed. What you could get away with then you couldn't get away with now.'

The quality of merchandising will become ever more pertinent with the release of the first Harry Potter films. Now that really could be a licence to print money.

Thomas the wealth engine

Thomas the Tank Engine is more than 50 years old, but the character created by the Reverend Wilbert Awdry for his books has found global fame only in the past decade or so.

The Thomas television series wasn't an immediate success when it was exported from Britain to the US in 1989. US audiences didn't warm to the five-and-a-half minute episodes so Britt Allcroft, the company which owned the Thomas name, turned the show into half-hour formats.

The company, which later changed its name to Gullane Entertainment and is currently valued at around £160 million, invested $16m in building the character's name and subsequently reaped the benefits when Thomas developed truly worldwide appeal. Today 75 per cent of revenues generated by Thomas come from outside the UK. In addition to Thomas, Gullane also owns the Captain Pugwash and Sooty characters.

The show is currently seen in 120 countries around the world and the Thomas books have been translated into 19 languages. The Thomas the Tank Engine feature film was seen by more than 4 million cinema-goers while it is estimated that the character has sold more than £2 billion worth of merchandising in the UK alone.

Thomas is hugely popular in Japan, where he has his own theme park - Thomas Land. Consumers can even buy Thomas toilet paper and home furnishings.

Tweenie dreams

Created for the BBC by Tell-Tale productions, whose team have in the past worked on the likes of Playschool and Playdays, the Tweenies are hailed as the new Teletubbies.

The adventures of Bella, Milo, Jake and Fizz are now seen in 40 countries and have spawned numerous merchandising deals. The Tweenies became the first pre-school children's characters to release a pop album, Friends Forever, which brought in producers and songwriters who had worked with pop bands such as Steps.

The album spawned a single which went to number one and spent eight weeks in the British Top 10.

The programme is the fastest-selling property in the history of BBC Worldwide. In its first year, The Tweenies sold more than £110 million worth of products - outpacing even the Teletubbies, which has grossed more than £1 billion in merchandising sales.

A Christmas video and an educational CD-Rom were big sellers last year.

Nearly 2 million Tweenies videos and books were sold by the end of October last year and the show's format has now been converted into a pop concert.

Currently in the middle of a whirlwind 30-day tour, the Tweenies have sold more than 250,000 tickets - equal to Robbie Williams during his last tour.

Bob the empire builder

Owned by Hit Entertainment, which is valued on the stock market at more than £380 million, broadcasting rights to Bob the Builder have been sold in more than 100 countries. Hit has spent more than £5m developing the Bob character.

The show launches in the US next week - a crucial test if the character is to develop a global appeal.

Around 500 Bob products are made under licence - including dolls, videos, cassette tapes, board games, puzzles and computer games. Big-name toy manufacturers signed up to make Bob products include Lego, Hasbro and Mattel.

In addition, Bob's debut single, voiced by Men Behaving Badly star Neil Morrissey, knocked rap star Eminem off the festive number one slot and was the UK's best-selling single of last year. Not bad for a character who was launched only in April 1999.

The show has made a millionaire of Bob's creator, Keith Chapman, a former advertising executive and cartoonist. In addition to Bob, Hit also owns other children's favourites such as Kipper, Percy the Park Keeper and Angelina Ballerina.

webTitle: Big Four  breach banking code on moving accounts

fields.headline: Big Four  breach banking code on moving accounts
fields.trailText: The big four banks are under attack for dragging their heels in providing information vital to customers who want to switch accounts.
fields.body:
The big four banks are under attack for dragging their heels in providing information vital to customers who want to switch accounts.

Just a week after the introduction of an agreement to ensure speedy, problem-free transfers, two newer banks have broken ranks to criticise their mainstream counterparts for failing to respond to requests for details of customers' direct debits and standing orders within 10 working days.

Intelligent Finance, Halifax's new internet and telephone subsidiary, surveyed the progress of 1,000 account transfers randomly selected from the 50,000 that have switched since the bank opened in September. It found that HSBC failed to meet the 10-day limit in 63 per cent of cases, NatWest in 57 per cent of cases, Barclays in 37 per cent and LloydsTSB in 33 per cent. NatWest took more than 28 working days to transfer accounts on several occasions, while Lloyds TSB took 41 working days simply to respond to a request for information on one account.

Jim Spowart, chief executive of Intelligent Finance, estimates that the clearing banks make about £2.25 billion a year in unearned interest from current accounts by paying only 0.1 per cent on credit balances. 'You don't have to be a genius to work out why the big banks are dragging their heels.'

webTitle: Hamlyn books £100m profit on old Mirror

fields.headline: Hamlyn books £100m profit on old Mirror
fields.trailText: Lord Hamlyn, last week revealed as a £2 million Labour Party donor, is poised to make a cool £100m through the sale of a prestigious London office block, writes Nick Mathiason.
fields.body:
Lord Hamlyn, last week revealed as a £2 million Labour Party donor, is poised to make a cool £100m through the sale of a prestigious London office block, writes Nick Mathiason.

Hamlyn Ventures, the 75-year-old peer's trading company, is in negotiations to sell Holborn Place, the former home of the Mirror group of newspapers, for close to £230m. In March 1999 Hamlyn, who made his fortune in publishing, bought what was a flattened site on the edge of the City of London for £40m and has spent around £70m constructing a glass-fronted cylindrical building which will soon be Sainsbury's corporate headquarters. Sainsbury, which beat off competition from Goldman Sachs, is paying £16.8m in rent to Hamlyn. A source working on the sale said it should be concluded within two months.

fields.headline: Beware the summer cold
fields.trailText: The similarity between the state of the Conservatives early in the new millennium and the state of the Labour Party in the early Eighties is remarkable; but so is the difference. Labour was considered unelectable then because of its extreme left-wing policies; the Tories are now considered unelectable not so much because they have moved to the extreme Right as because they don't know where they are moving.
fields.body:
The similarity between the state of the Conservatives early in the new millennium and the state of the Labour Party in the early Eighties is remarkable; but so is the difference. Labour was considered unelectable then because of its extreme left-wing policies; the Tories are now considered unelectable not so much because they have moved to the extreme Right as because they don't know where they are moving.

One reason for the confusion among the Tories is that Tony Blair and his colleagues have stolen most of the Conservatives' clothes. True, Labour is pursuing dozens of 'social' and so-called 'redistributive' initiatives that the Conservatives would eschew. But 'New' Labour has accepted much of the Thatcher settlement - something it could never have been accused of in the Eighties.

Despite the fact that it has performed poorly in almost every election since May 1997, Labour is widely expected to walk the next election. Indeed, Labour insiders boast that they are within sight of a historic record: the first Labour Government to serve two full terms.

This very boast is a classic example of the debasement of the language, because if Tony Blair goes to the country, as widely expected, in May, he will only have served four-fifths of a 'full' term. The transport system may be in chaos, the health service overstretched, manufacturing and agriculture suffering acute problems because of the overvalued pound, but Labour in general, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer in particular, are considered to be doing a good job - or, rather, a better job than the present Conservative Party would make of it.

Yet there is great dissatisfaction and disappointment with this Government. What Blair and his colleagues have going for them is what Margaret Thatcher had going for her in the Eighties, the cliché: there is no alternative.

Recently, as then, there has been an alternative; it is just that there has been little political pressure on the government of the time to change its ways. Certainly this Government wisely relented a little on pensions and fuel; but it accepted Tory privatisation policies - even some Mrs Thatcher herself would not touch - and made the mistake of many a previous Labour government in acquiescing in events which temporarily gave them a seriously overvalued pound.

Michael Heseltine recently said this Government had 'lost its nerve'. It was news that it ever had one. In its desperate desire to appear 'responsible' the Government has been responsible for much of what now ails a British public that has a sense of resignation as it tries to go about its daily business.

Make no mistake: Britain is one of the most advanced economies in the world, and we have a very high standard of living. But there is a distinction between 'standard of living' as measured by the economic statistics, and the 'quality of life' of daily experience. It is here that most people experience the frustrations of the excessive pursuit of profit and productivity at the expense of common sense standards of service, whether they are trying to travel by rail or to see a hospital doctor.

Never, we are told, has a Labour government been in such a strong financial position at this stage of office. Now that the Government has established a reputation for sound economic competence, says the Prime Minister, it has laid the foundations for investment in public services.

Yes, in order to achieve something in its second term, a Labour government has spent most of its first term cultivating a reputation for 'responsibility'; this has been at the expense of being responsible for widespread inefficiency in the public sector and in what should, as with transport, be regarded as within the public sector's domain.

Everyday life is a continuum, but the Government's approach has been sequential: let things run down while you establish a reputation, then try to repair the neglect, then make the improvements you were elected to effect in the first place. One of the great ironies is that the civil servant Labour seems to have relied on most to persist with its labyrinthine 'public-private' partnerships is Sir Steve Robson, who pushed forward the Great Railway Privatisation. Perhaps they should now employ the newly retired Sir Steve as a consultant to sort out the mess. As the Dome episode has shown, certain things are, in the end, the public sector's responsibility, even if it is appropriate that the private sector should carry out the work. 'Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's '

An area of policy which fuses the 'sequential' and the 'responsible' is the euro. The Chancellor's approach has been, 'trust me with the economy, and then trust me to make the decision on the euro'. This is all very well, and with good growth figures, very high employment and a sound fiscal position, the Chancellor is very popular. But huge damage has been wrought on British industry and agriculture by the strong pound; and industrial operations that have closed down in the wait for a lower pound will probably never reopen. The damage has been disguised by the unsustainable US boom and its beneficial impact on world trade.

The Governor of the Bank of England, Sir Edward George, has warned that the UK is in danger of catching an economic cold from the US sneeze, but he put this in the context of the need for a private sector slowdown in order to make room for Labour's public spending increases. That, I think, is what lay behind his point that 'I honestly couldn't predict, at this stage, whether that [achieving a sustainable growth rate] will require lower interest rates. It may even require higher interest rates still.'

The Chancellor has not abolished 'boom and bust' in the US, but he has staked a lot on abolishing it here. Although the Government is confident of sweeping the country at election time, it is slightly nervous of being infected by the US sneeze. But these things take time. Labour's economic policies will probably look 'sound' and 'responsible' until the election is out of the way. Then the fun will start.

webTitle: Strong sales and output stall rate cut

fields.headline: Strong sales and output stall rate cut
fields.trailText: Economic data out this week will fuel optimism that the UK is avoiding the fallout from the US slowdown. This will lessen pressure on the Bank of England to follow the US with an interest rate cut.
fields.body:
Economic data out this week will fuel optimism that the UK is avoiding the fallout from the US slowdown. This will lessen pressure on the Bank of England to follow the US with an interest rate cut.

The FTSE was static in Friday's trading, indicating that the previous day's euphoria over the Federal Reserve's rate cut was short lived.

A series of eagerly awaited Christmas trading statements are expected to indicate buoyant high street demand, while an Engineering Employers' Federation survey, due on Tuesday, shows healthy performance in some manufacturing sectors. Figures tomorrow from the Confederation of British Industry and PricewaterhouseCoopers will paint a similar picture in financial services. The slew of data will provide ammunition for those in the 'wait and see' camp on the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee, which meets on Wednesday and Thursday.

Selfridges, Dixons, Next, GUS and House of Fraser will give an indication of Christmas trading figures this week. They are set to show healthy sales, particularly in the final week; expectations for growth this month are moderate, after poor weather and transport problems dampened the start of the New Year sales.

Meanwhile, the John Lewis Partnership recorded Christmas week sales that 'far-exceeded expectations', and Whitbread said its performance was 'satisfactory'.

The EEF data will show output for all engineering sectors except vehicle-making rising for the second quarter running in the last three months of 2000.

Higher-value sectors such as electronics, electrical equipment and aerospace showed the strongest performance, leading the EEF to call for rates to stay on hold. However, weak investment figures are provoking longer-term concerns: the employers are hoping for a 50 basis-point cut by the summer.

The CBI/PWC data will show sales and profitability at the 123 financial services firms polled improving over the last quarter, although some slowing is expected in the first quarter of this year.

A poll of 36 City economists put the average likelihood of a cut in interest rates at only 25 per cent. 'No change' was considered the most likely outcome of the MPC meeting, with a 74 per cent probability. Only Barclays Capital ranked a cut more likely than no change. The consensus pointed to a 50 basis-point drop by the end of 2001.

fields.headline: Now Diageo stalks Fosters
fields.standfirst: Spirits giant considers £4bn bid for Aussie brewer to boost global operations of Guinness
fields.trailText: Spirits giant Diageo has been considering a £4 billion bid for Foster's to bolster its worldwide Guinness brewing operations.
fields.body:
Spirits giant Diageo has been considering a £4 billion bid for Foster's to bolster its worldwide Guinness brewing operations.

Foster's, based in south Australia, also has major wine operations, which interest new Diageo new chief executive Paul Walsh following its $8.2bn acquisition - with Pernod - of Seagram's spirits and wine business before Christmas.

The revelation of a potential further shake-up in the world brewing industry follows the Government's dramatic blocking of a £2.3bn takeover of Bass Brewers by Belgium's Interbrew last week.

This weekend a stunned Interbrew - best known for its Stella Artois lager - is locked in meetings with its City lawyers over the controversial decision by Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers. Plans for a judicial review are expected to focus on the alternative option of selling the Whitbread Beer Company, which Interbrew also bought last year.

'By the middle of next week we will have a clearer view of the grounds for a legal challenge,' one Interbrew source said.

Foster's is the UK's number two beer brand, with over £1bn sales and 8.2 per cent of the market, behind Bass's Carling Black Label. In the UK and continental Europe it is brewed under licence by Scottish and Newcastle, the UK's number two brewer. The arrangement followed S&N's £425 million takeover of Courage from Foster's Brewing in 1995.

Foster's is valued at A$9bn (£3.5bn). According to industry sources, Diageo held talks with S&N last summer to buy the Foster's licence following S&N's £1.7bn acquisition of France's Kronenbourg.

This weekend, however, S&N said it had no intention of selling. 'We've invested a vast amount of time and money in creating Fosters' position,' one S&N source said. 'If Guinness bought Fosters, they would have to deal with us in Europe and with Miller and Molson in North America. They would have difficulty reuniting the brand.'

Diageo declined to comment on the discussions. However, industry sources said the spirits giant was likely to revive its interest after integrating Seagram.

Walsh is reluctant to dispose of Guinness, but is interested only in global beer brands: he has ruled Diageo out of the race for Bass.

Heineken and South African Breweries are now leading the pack to buy Bass, while venture capitalists including Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst have also previously submitted bids.

Byers blocked the takeover because Interbrew and S&N would have a powerful duopoly, with 63 per cent of the market, leading to higher prices and less competition.

The decision has already led to complaints from the Belgian government. But a Guinness bid for Foster's would not be expected to lead to a diplomatic row. The Australian brewer has sales of £1.1bn, half of which is wine, and 'down under' the Foster's brand is nowhere near as strong as in the UK.

European sales of Foster's account for two-thirds of the brand's worldwide turnover.

Guinness's last attempt to expand its brewing interest ended in failure - with the purchase and disposal of Spain's Cruz Campo.

webTitle: Blair steps in as Tube privatisation fears escalate

fields.headline: Blair steps in as Tube privatisation fears escalate
fields.trailText: Prime Minister Tony Blair will tomorrow wade into the crisis surrounding the controversial partial privatisation of the London Underground, writes Nick Mathiason.
fields.body:
Prime Minister Tony Blair will tomorrow wade into the crisis surrounding the controversial partial privatisation of the London Underground, writes Nick Mathiason.

Blair will hold a top-level meeting with transport supremo John Prescott and Tube chiefs as consortia bidding to 'own' the tube for 30 years under public private partnership (PPP) are beginning to buckle.

'Clearly we're nervous,' said one chief executive involved in the bidding. 'We're close to a general election and the timescale is now uncertain. There are concerns about rising costs and that the whole nature of the deal is changing, which will make the PPP as envisaged difficult to work.' Another consortium member said he was 'unsettled' by moves towards a compromise between Prescott and London Mayor Ken Livingstone. Consortia vying to run the tube resubmitted bids after their first effort was deemed too expensive by Prescott.

Bob Kiley, the American Livingstone appointed to run London's transport system, said companies bidding on PPP would still be involved in rebuilding the tube if his bond scheme won government approval.

webTitle: Kathryn Flett: The rest was history

fields.headline: The rest was history
fields.standfirst: At least one family watched no TV this week. Didn't they know there was a Waugh on?
fields.trailText: At least one family watched no TV this week says Kathryn Flett. Didn't they know there was a Waugh on?
fields.body:
Castaway BBC1
Gentlemen's Relish BBC1
Scandalous Women BBC2
The 1940s House C4
Sword of Honour C4
Frasier C4

The first few days of the purist's new millennium turned out to be a very good week for corsets: as we broached the new frontier, TV boldly went backwards. Indeed, if the casual viewer zapped cleverly enough and managed to avoid all those weeping members of Castaway, it was as if drip-dry fabrics had yet to be invented. Even the Castaways, when asked what they were most looking forward to on their return to civilisation, failed to mention logging onto the internet or popping out to Starbucks for a double-double decaff skinny latte - no, they just wanted a bath. Edited highlights of these (including 'Ben Fogle's First Nice Long Candlelit Soak Back Home in Notting Hill. PG: Includes stiff upper lip, occasional tears and black labrador'), will soon be available on BBC Video priced at £9.99.

The tightly-laced tone was set by Gentlemen's Relish, which had looked like a potentially feisty piece of drama in the trailers, but somehow contrived to make a little light pornography even duller than almost anything to be viewed late night on Channel 5.

Billy Connolly as Swann, an unfashionable painter of classical nudes who turns to photography to kick-start his career, was quite improperly squandered thanks to a lumberingly unfunny script (not even Connolly can be expected to charm and twinkle his way through 90 minutes of alleged comedy without being given a character to play with); Sarah Lancashire, as his devoted housekeeper, fell back on a campy combination of wide eyes and pursed lips, as if Julie Andrews was playing Widow Twankey; while Douglas Henshall, as Swann's sleazy assistant whose dark-room manipulations turned the boss's works of art into under-the-counter sauce, was caught inexplicably impersonating Alfie-era Michael Caine.

I suppose it was meant to be panto-farcical, but I had a bit of a humour bypass - all wide-eyes and pursed lips - because there was something slightly suspect about the amount of corpulent female flesh captured in close-up; a kind of retrograde humour that relied on the viewer colluding with the premise that skinny women's naked bodies are intrinsically, dangerously erotic (so we weren't allowed too many of those in close-up, thank you very much), while goosing fat women's wobbly bits is just so much prime-time snigger-worthy sauce for the ganders - 'Ooh! sir! What a great big BBC budget you've got!' 'Come and sit on m'knee, m'dear, and be sure to get your ratings out for the chaps...'

Meanwhile BBC2's Scandalous Women, part of the channel's Victorian Week, had a more edifying angle on old-fashioned sexual mores, reminding us that sex wasn't invented in the naughty 1990s by Loaded magazine. As a Victorian married woman and therefore 'a legal non-person', Caroline Norton endured her husband (Tory MP) George Norton's regular beatings (perfectly legal to beat your wife, of course - as long as the stick was no thicker than your thumb) and bore him three sons, before sensibly embarking on an affair with the jolly nice (Whig Home Secretary) Lord Melbourne.

After a messy courtroom battle, Caroline was denied access to her children for six years (George handed them over to the care of his mistress) and even when the youngest was fatally injured in a riding accident, Caroline was informed too late to make it to his bedside. However, her fight for custody ensured a change in the law, thus allowing divorced or separated women rights to both property and children for the first time. And aside from the fact that this legislation subsequently resulted in Sarah Lancashire's playing a simpering suffragette in Gentlemen's Relish, clearly more 'scandalous women' should make it on to the National Curriculum, while Caroline Norton should be at the very least a household name and ideally a national holiday, on 2 January.

I was gripped by Channel 4's The 1900 House but revisiting the experiment, in The 1940s House, looked like a less engaging prospect. With electricity, a radio, plenty of lipstick and no Heath Robinsonesque underwear to grapple with every morning, how hard could life really get for the Hymers family, even with a bit of rationing? Happily, however, the Hymers turned out to be made of less robust stuff than their time-travelling predecessors, straightaway admitting to having eaten only convenience foods all their lives ('Our diet is appalling. Nutritionally we're at the bottom end of poor... we're Mr and Mrs Blobby, we're greedy, we drink...'), so now that the rationing has kicked in, their misery is palpable - and it's still only 1940.

On hand to welcome them to their home, Marguerite Patten's expression of wide-eyed, yet politely restrained horror as Lynne Hymers admitted to never having baked a cake, was a treat. And despite Geoffrey Palmer's voiceover informing us that 'beauty will be expected as part of their wartime duty', Lynne and her daughter Kirsty are already looking a bit tonsorially lackadaisical, despite having arrived in the house with spiffy Trevor Sorbie marcel waves and a 'sixpenny singe'. In the real, twenty-first century world it is practically impossible to get an appointment with Trevor so, frankly, they should work harder at keeping up appearances while mincing their rissoles.

Kirsty's two sons are sweet. 'Compared to what we have at home, the rizzles [sic] were really nice... and the blancmange was creamy and light - perfect! I like home-made meals' said 10-year-old Ben, wistfully. Still, that was before rationing, at which point the family resorted to a staple diet of jam sandwiches. 'War is really not a good game,' Ben conceded several days later, after a night in the Anderson shelter and a week without 'rizzles'. They'll regret giving those rabbits to the pet shop, mark my words.

Not a Marceled hair out of place in Sword of Honour, Channel 4's delicious adaptation of the Waugh trilogy, effectively condensed into a two-parter by William Boyd. It would be a fine challenge to write a review of a televised Waugh without invoking Brideshead, but I'm not too proud to fail. Just as beautifully art-directed, sun-dappled and costumed as it's forerunner, but far more dramatically paced (if you've watched Brideshead recently, you'll have noted how it now looks languid to the point of comatose), Sword of Honour wore its predictable comparisons well.

As our hero, Guy Crouchback, a man of boundless decency and infinite idealism, forced to fight his way through a cynical World Waugh 2, craggy Daniel Craig initially looked a little too lived-in to play quite such an emotional naif, though by the end Crouchback's character was perhaps sufficiently disillusioned to suit Craig's face. Around the central character, as every apparently noble action had comically dreadful repercussions, a wonderful cast (including Leslie Phillips, refreshingly cad-free and bounderless as Crouchback Sr and Megan Dodds as the wicked and wilful Virginia) made the potentially cartoonish actions of the blimpish, wimpish and vampish successfully navigate the line between black comedy and pathos. Sword of Honour will, I guess, have had far fewer viewers than Gentlemen's Relish, but deserved far more.

Incidentally, last Thursday I found myself in the rather unlikely but entirely delightful position of being seated for supper between the RAF and the Navy on board HMS Illustrious, and can (I hope) safely report, on the record and without having signed the Official Secrets Act, that some very top brass from those Forces, not to mention the Army on the other side of the table, had all loved Sword of Honour - even though the Captain of Illustrious had opted to watch ITV's repeat of A Touch of Frost instead. I hope Channel 4 won't mind me sending my review tapes to save the Captain's wife the trouble of buying it on video - both of them, will, I'm sure, enjoy the numerous references to 'the bloody, bloody Navy...'
