At the end of the last we left Daphne and Niles in a recreational vehicle escaping both Daphne's impending nuptials to the hapless Donny and Niles's three-day-old marriage to the ghastly Mel. But five minutes later, Jane Leeves's Daphne is suddenly wearing baggy tops and attempting to hide what looks - unless she nervously OD'd on pre-wedding canapes - suspiciously like a pregnancy. This presumably unscheduled bump of a plot development should make the series worth watching even if, for the first time in the show's history, the writing felt a little bit flabby around its midriff, too.

webTitle: Film of the week: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

fields.headline: I get a kick out of kung fu
fields.standfirst: The fight scenes in Ang Lee's Chinese epic are breathtaking in their beauty - even when the men join in
fields.trailText: Film of the week: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
fields.body:
Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (120 mins, 12) Directed by Ang Lee; starring Chow Yun-Fat, Michelle Yeoh, Zhang Ziyi, Chang Chen

There has never been a career quite like that of Ang Lee, although the chances are there will be similar ones during this coming century. Born in Taiwan of mainland Chinese parents, he studied film in the States and over the past decade has built up a coherent oeuvre while making films in a variety of genres on three continents, working as happily in English as in Chinese.

He first made his mark in 1993 with The Wedding Banquet, a comedy about a young gay New York property dealer entering into a marriage of convenience to please his traditionalist Taiwanese parents. Lee then returned to Taiwan for Eat Drink Man Woman, about a celebrity cook and his rebellious children, before coming to England to direct Emma Thompson in Sense and Sensibility, the best of all Jane Austen adaptations.

This was followed by The Ice Storm, a study in the Updike manner of middle-class New England exurban life in the morally confused early 1970s, and a superb western, Ride With the Devil, set during the American Civil War. Now he's turned to the most popular of all Oriental genres, the martial arts film, with the entrancing Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, made on location in China with leading Hong Kong actors.

Lee's films share a stylistic sophistication, a narrative flow, a feeling for the big set-piece and a concern for language. But what binds these apparently diverse works together is the consistency with which he pursues certain key themes. These include the rewards and restrictions of family life, the necessity of breaking with relations and traditions to establish your own identity, and the deceptive nature of reality, which leads us into misreading the world around us.

He brings a certain formality or reticence to the task and always locates the action in a precise society, usually one in a state of transition, whether it be Jane Austen's England or an America torn apart by the Civil War. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is set during the Qing Dynasty, a period in the early nineteenth century before the European commercial invasion that is regarded as something of a golden age. The title refers to an old Chinese proverb about people concealing their real identities - vulnerability in a strong man, assertiveness in a meek woman - and all the characters have hidden selves or suppressed desires.

A complicated (at times confusing) plot turns on two pairs of lovers. The nationally celebrated warrior Li Mu Bai (handsome Chow Yun-Fat) cannot declare his love for Yu Shu Lien (the beautiful Michelle Yeoh), his female counterpart and fellow subscriber to the ancient chivalric code laid down in the manual of Wudan. A decade or more younger than this poised couple are another charismatic pair, Jen (Zhang Ziyi) and Lo (Chang Chen). Jen is the rebellious daughter of a noble family, Lo is a bandit leader living in a cave in the desert, and they've secretly become lovers.

Jen, however, has been trained as a martial artist by Jade Fox, an evil villainess, who has taught her the Wudan system of combat, but not the ethical code that should accompany it. Jade Fox has murdered Li's spiritual master, and on her behalf Lo steals a fabulous 400-year-old sword called Green Destiny that belonged to Li and should only be wielded by an honourable warrior. This weapon, described as 'strong but supple - the way to rule', becomes a central matter of contention.

The story is not without significance and the film has considerable moral power. There are parallels with our own Arthurian legend and various other mythic echoes, though it never becomes an eclectic confection like Star Wars. But what makes it an exciting kinetic experience in the cinema is the epic sweep, the contrast between the serene beauty of the settings and the astonishing action sequences.

Preferring the marshal acts of lawmen with their feet on the ground in the West to the martial arts of athletes leaping around in the East, I've never been a devotee of kung-fu pictures. I like my karate in short, isolated bursts - Spencer Tracy taking on Ernest Borgnine in Bad Day at Black Rock, for instance, or Frank Sinatra engaging with Henry Silva in The Manchurian Candidate. Until now, the only martial arts picture I've really loved is King Hu's classic A Touch of Zen (1969), but the fights in Ang Lee's film are breathtaking in their beauty.

These action sequences are choreographed by Yuen Wo Ping, who staged the chases and battles in Jackie Chan's Hong Kong flicks, and more recently worked in America on The Matrix. Though long drawn out, they never get tedious and each is quite different in character and contributes to the dramatic development. As in dreams, the combatants defy gravity, flying through the air, running up walls, quite literally floating like butterflies and stinging like bees.

Four of these fights stand out. In the first, a masked Jen steals the Green Destiny sword and (resembling the young female cat burglar in Hitchcock's To Catch a Thief) is chased through the night over the rooftops of Beijing by the older woman, Yu. The two later have a graceful fight indoors for possession of the sword.

In the film's last big fight, Jen fights in a forest of giant bamboo trees with the mature warrior, Yi, a scene with echoes of the climactic confrontation between the good and bad brothers who conduct a moral argument as they exchange gunfire in Anthony Mann's Winchester 73. But as they bounce from the top of one tree to another swinging their lethal swords, it seems as if we're looking at Nijinsky playing a combination of Tarzan and D'Artagnan.

Jen has another scene, as cleverly staged as the others, but wonderfully comic, in which she takes on a succession of overweight braggarts in a country inn. They underestimate her martial skills as much as they overrate their own and they end up in tatters and the inn is demolished. It's a fight that would have won the admiration of John Ford. One mentions Ford, but his women stood by and watched as their men went into action. Few westerns have provided female roles like the ones so confidently played here by Michelle Yeoh and Zhang Ziyi, and it could be argued that no western has provided so persuasive a context.

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is the first foreign language picture for many years to get a sizeable release in British cinemas, and the first ever to do so in a non-European language. One wishes Lee's film well because it deserves to be popular and if successful, it might encourage distributors and audiences in the direction of greater boldness.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Bright blue rubber breasts first brought writer Lynda La Plante and actress Lynda Bellingham together on stage at the Oxford Playhouse. Now, 30 years later and the best of friends, they're still laughing
fields.trailText: Bright blue rubber breasts first brought writer Lynda La Plante and actress Lynda Bellingham together on stage at the Oxford Playhouse. Now, 30 years later and the best of friends, they're still laughing.
fields.body:
Lynda La Plante: Before I started writing professionally, I was an actress and I met Lynda in the early 70s when we were both in Lysistrata at the Oxford Playhouse. It was the most peculiar production in the history of Greek theatre. Lynda and I were part of the spectacularly exotic chorus and our costumes were beyond belief. We wore huge, bright blue rubber breasts, a massive rubber bottom and were swathed in blue parachute silk. We looked totally idiotic.

The reviews were dreadful and when we went on tour we were booed off the stage in Cambridge. However, limping around the country in a terrible production and looking ridiculous is a very bonding experience and we have been great friends ever since.

Lynda is a terrific person to have around because she's a very good leader - she's a bit like a form prefect - and great at galvanising people into doing things. She has a generous nature but finds it difficult to receive, and I think she's been used by some people because of her generosity.

We've both gone down some bizarre emotional tracks in our life and although we've sometimes taken different routes there is a great bond between us. There was a period when her children were very tiny when I didn't see her much and I really missed her, but as soon as the boys were up and running, Lynda was back.

She was always there for me during my divorce. I'd been married many years and was devastated by the break-up of my marriage, but Lynda and I are both very similar in that however difficult our circumstances, we usually roll up our sleeves and get on with things. Lynda has cloaked some of the traumas she's had in her life with great humour.

We haven't worked together since the Oxford Playhouse. It wouldn't have been inappropriate when she was doing the Oxo ads but now she doesn't have to be anybody's mum, I can think about writing for her. I don't think her major talent has been recognised. She is a great tragedy actress and has enormous gravitas - a rare quality. Having said that, she often makes me weep with laughter at her antics. Especially when I think about those great big rubber breasts.

Lynda Bellingham: I left drama school in 1969 and I'd done quite a bit of rep and telly but I was desperate to do some 'serious drama', so I couldn't believe my luck when I was cast in Lysistrata. Although the play was a catastrophe, the cast was great.

At first, I was rather cowed by Lynda. She was so glamorous, but we hit it off and she's been a good friend to me over the years. I was married very briefly to Greg Smith, the producer, and when the marriage fell apart and I was anxious the press didn't find out, I laid low for a while in Lynda's flat in west London. It was in an old mansion block and if it had been anyone else's it might have been dull, but Lynda has exquisite taste and her home was full of beautiful things.

We used to have jumble-sale nights. Everyone would turn up with clothes they didn't want and there would be about 20 minutes of frantic clothes buying, then we'd have lots to drink. People bought things two sizes too small because they were drunk enough to think they really were that size.

At this point Lynda was working at the RSC. She was given a hard time because she wore fur coats and was very flamboyant at a time when to be taken seriously as an actress you had to have a flat chest and a dirty T-shirt. No one ever took us seriously, which made Lynda even more outrageous.

Lynda was a talented actress but she's a phenomenally successful writer - of series such as Prime Suspect and Trial and Retribution. Two years ago, I spent New Year's Eve at her house in the Hamptons and she was constantly on the phone to people like Steven Spielberg and Barbra Streisand - I was terribly impressed!

This trip was also cathartic for me in sorting myself out after the difficult breakdown of my second marriage [to Nunzio Peluso who pleaded guilty last year to harrassment]. I'd rather talk to friends than have therapy. Lynda and I have had to deal with many of the same issues over the years and there's a lot of shared history. She's a great friend and I trust her completely. She's utterly unique.

I was married very briefly to Greg Smith, the producer, and when the marriage fell apart and I was anxious the press didn't find out, I laid low for a while in Lynda's flat in west London. It was in an old mansion block and if it had been anyone else's it might have been dull, but Lynda has exquisite taste and her home was full of beautiful things. We used to have jumble-sale nights. Everyone would turn up with clothes they didn't want and there would be about 20 minutes of frantic clothes buying, then we'd have lots to drink. People bought things two sizes too small because they were drunk enough to think they really were that size. At this point Lynda was working at the RSC. She was given a hard time because she wore fur coats and was very flamboyant at a time when to be taken seriously as an actress you had to have a flat chest and a dirty T-shirt. No one ever took us seriously, which made Lynda even more outrageous. Lynda was a talented actress but she's a phenomenally successful writer - of series such as Prime Suspect and Trial and Retribution. Two years ago, I spent New Year's Eve at her house in the Hamptons and she was constantly on the phone to people like Steven Spielberg and Barbra Streisand - I was terribly impressed! This trip was also cathartic for me in sorting myself out after the difficult breakdown of my second marriage [to Nunzio Peluso who pleaded guilty last year to harrassment]. I'd rather talk to friends than have therapy. Lynda and I have had to deal with many of the same issues over the years and there's a lot of shared history. She's a great friend and I trust her completely. She's utterly unique.

webTitle: Other films: Cheerleaders, mystic voyeurs obviously, it's Dostoyevsky

fields.headline: Cheerleaders, mystic voyeurs obviously, it's Dostoyevsky
fields.standfirst: Crime and Punishment's hero has a sex change and Kim Basinger does the Lord's work in a topsy-turvy week
fields.trailText: Crime & Punishment in Suburbia | Saltwater | Bless the Child
fields.body:
Crime & Punishment in Suburbia (98 Mins, 15) Directed by Rob Schmidt; starring Ellen Barkin, Monica Keena, Michael Ironside, Jeffrey Wright

Saltwater (97 mins, 15) Directed by Conor McPherson; starring Brian Cox, Brendan Gleeson, Peter McDonald, Conor Mullen

Bless the Child (110 mins, 15) Directed by Chuck Russell; starring Kim Basinger, Jimmy Smits, Rufus Sewell, Ian Holm

The cinema has had a dozen shots at Dostoyevsky's Crime and Punishment, ranging from Von Sternberg's 1935 version starring Peter Lorre as Raskolnikov to Aki Kaurismaki's transposition of the story to modern Helsinki and a Latin American treatment a couple of years ago that reworked the story in Colombia. All missed the target. But none was as odd as Rob Schmidt's low-budget American independent production, Crime & Punishment in Suburbia.

Without that title and an epigraph by Dostoyevsky (from one of his prison letters) one might not have guessed the film's source, and thus not noticed the significance of the teenage heroine's name - Rosanne Skolnik. Yes, Raskolnikov has changed sex to become a pretty high school cheerleader who lives in an anonymous suburb of Los Angeles with her drunken, abusive stepfather (Michael Ironside) and her sluttish mother (Ellen Barkin). When Mom leaves home to move in with a good-looking black bartender (Jeffrey Wright), a deranged Dad rapes Rosanne who then gets her football star boyfriend to help her murder Dad. She butchers him with an electric carving knife, but Mom gets arrested and charged with Murder One.

This is a curious affair that plays around with themes from the book, turns Sonia into a sad, mystic Christian voyeur called Vincent, but has no equivalent to Inspector Porfiry. Like a novel, it's divided into eight chapters, each given a sort of explanatory Brechtian title. But this is less Dostoyevsky Lite than Crime and Punishment re-written in the lowdown pulp style of Jim Thompson, and as such not without a certain interest.

The screenwriter Larry Gross - best known for his collaborations with Walter Hill (on 48 Hrs and Geronimo) and for some trenchant articles on Hitchcock and Kubrick in Sight and Sound - wrote the script a couple of years ago for This World, Then the Fireworks, one of the best screen adaptations of a Thompson fiction, and also dealing with murder and incest. Unsatisfactory as the picture is, one senses a serious mind behind it.

Saltwater, the cinematic debut as writer-director of Conor McPherson, author of the long-running play The Weir, might well have been called 'Crime Without Punishment by the Seaside'. Set out of season in a small coastal resort north of Dublin, the movie (based on an earlier play by McPherson called This Lime Tree Bower) is an account of a hectic week in the lives of three Irish lads living under the roof of the widowed George Beneventi (Brian Cox), a chip-shop owner in hock to the local loan shark (Brendan Gleeson). Two are his sons, Frank (Peter MacDonald) who works in the shop, and the 15-year-old schoolboy Joe (Laurence Kinlan); the third, Ray (Conor Mullen) is a cocksure philosophy lecturer living with George's daughter.

Joe gets involved with a seductive delinquent newcomer at his school which leads to him being accused of rape. Frank fakes an armed robbery at the loan shark's betting shop to pay Dad's debts. Ray, who's having an affair with a student and is threatened with losing his job, gets horrendously drunk the night before an important university occasion.

As with most Irish drama, the men are weak, feckless, drawn to the bottle, and the women are sensible, wry and long-suffering, most especially the local representative of the Garda, an attractive female police sergeant. The plotting is not entirely plausible, the college scenes are unconvincing and the pace is evenly slow. But there's a nice sense of place in the empty seaside town, some good turns of phrase and several excellent performances, especially Laurence Kinlan's as sad, serious, likeable Joe, who unlike the others faces up to the consequences of his actions.

Producer Mace Neufeld made his name in 1976 with The Omen, a derivative contribution to the diabolical possession movie that had included such notable pictures as Rosemary's Baby and The Exorcist. His latest film, Bless the Child, turns up at the end of a similar cycle of sanctimonious horror flicks in which the forces of good and evil do battle for the future of the world on the eve of the third millennium.

The dispute this time is over Cody, a six-year-old girl with special powers, born under the same star as Christ, and kidnapped like other children born that day by a sinister band of diabolists called New Dawn and headed by Satan's agent Eric Stark (Rufus Sewell).

Opposing them with bell, book and Magnum are the girl's aunt (Kim Basinger), an ex-seminarian now doing God's work as an FBI specialist in 'ritual homicide and the occult' (Jimmy Smits), and the usual renegade priest, a grizzled, crazy old-timer, who knows things the Vatican won't acknowledge, played in this case by Ian Holm. The cross-cutting between a chapel full of nuns praying for Cody's soul at Easter 1999 and Sewell conducting a black mass with the Devil himself in attendance is hilarious.

fields.headline: Living history
fields.standfirst: Peter Gillies always dreamed of living in a castle. So when he found a ruin called Ballencrief, he thought nothing of giving up his job or plunging into debt
fields.trailText: Peter Gillies always dreamed of living in a castle. So when he found a ruin called Ballencrief, he thought nothing of giving up his job or plunging into debt.
fields.body:
When Peter Gillies and his partner Lin Dalgleish first considered living in a castle, they were thinking of a 'wee tower'. Most people, Peter explains, begin with this vision. The problem is, there aren't that many wee towers around. The idea of living in a castle had always seemed like a dream to Peter, even as a boy growing up in Berwickshire, where his father used to take him round old ruins.

'I always wanted to restore a castle,' he says. 'I just never thought it would happen.' Of course not - it's what rich people do, people who have the estimated £1.5m it takes to restore a castle ruin. But one Sunday afternoon 11 years ago, Peter and Lin visited the ruin of Ballencrieff Castle. They were on the east coast of Scotland, near Aberlady, and they had heard that the building, or what was left of it, was due to be demolished. Pictures taken at the time by Historic Scotland show piles of rubble lying within the crumbling ruin walls.

Today, Ballencrieff is a gem, unexpected in its sheer scale as you pull up in the drive expecting a home of more humble proportions. One could easily get lost in its winding stone stairwells, snatching glimpses of the surrounding landscape from the windows inset within the deep stone walls, and wandering into rooms of an imposing grandeur we're quite unused to. Yet it's also a family home, with recipe books in the kitchen and photos scattered in the drawing room where Peter and Lin settle with the Sunday papers - informal signs of everyday life.

As a civil engineer who has spent his life restoring properties, Peter saw the potential below the grime. 'The logistics of restoring the castle weren't huge,' he says, sounding surprisingly matter-of-fact. But the scale of the renovation was daunting, particularly when it came to financing the project. Although he received a grant from Historic Scotland, he settled the bulk of the bill on his own.

'I had to fight the costs all the time,' Peter admits. 'We more or less stuck to the budget, which in itself was miraculous, but if you want a way to get rid of your money, buy a ruined castle.' It can, he says, feel like you're pouring money down the drain. Although Peter won't divulge the exact sums, he admits going £50,000 over budget. Peter knows of people who've simply gone bankrupt, overwhelmed by the costs. He himself gave up his job for the final two years to oversee the restoration, living off Lin's salary as a schoolteacher, purely because they could then save on a contract manager's fee.

Still, there were rewards, particularly when it came to piecing together the puzzle of a building that had lain empty since 1868, when fire ripped through the castle leaving only its walls standing. Although no one can precisely pinpoint its age, history shows Ballencrieff suffering its first baptism of fire in 1547 before being rebuilt in 1586, with changing fashions seeing the five-storey castle encased within a Georgian mansion in 1730, a style obliterated by the second fire 138 years later. For Peter, the challenge was to restore the 16th-century design without becoming sidetracked by clues unearthed from the 'jerry-built' Georgian version.

'When they made this into a Georgian building, they removed all the medieval architecture. It simply went out of fashion,' he explains, and it's funny to consider that this would be the equivalent of us moving into a new pad and ripping out the Anaglypta wallpaper and 70s Hygena kitchen units. The Great Hall - a cavernous space at the top of the main sweeping stone staircase designed to strike awe into any humble peasant arriving to pay their rent - was oak panelled at one point, while the flagstones had been replaced by timber, all easy to deconstruct.

But the real clues lay in the rubble, which Peter sifted through like a giant jigsaw. In the Great Hall, Peter reconstructed the intricate plasterwork ceiling with its heraldic symbols from fragments buried within 8ft of rubble. Some of the shattered symbols displayed the initials of Sir Gideon Murray, a previous owner who was also the deputy treasurer for Scotland between 1612 and 1621, while high on the wall he discovered a minstrel's gallery, once in stone and now recreated in timber.

A section of ceiling found intact from where it had fallen during the fire prompted Peter to research the records of ceilings in Scotland, where he discovered an identical example in Kellie Castle in Fife. The moulds were later taken to Edinburgh Castle. Recently, when that castle was restored, Ballencrief in turn supplied samples for it.

'We were constantly surprised by what we were finding. We know who lived here and what they looked like because their paintings hang in some of the national galleries. The domestic history was wonderful,' Peter says. 'Imagine all the tragedies that went on in this house. Sir Gideon Murray was the Baron in 1617. He could hang people on the gallows two fields away. In 1617 he declared three local men outlaws for stealing his apples. They could be shot on sight.'

Clearly, it is details such as this that kept the project alive for Peter. It took seven years before they could leave their home in nearby Gullane and move into the top floor, while work continued on the levels below. While most people move into a space and then decipher what's needed and what will suit before splurging out on the Visa card, Peter and Lin spent years buying pieces from auctions and other castles, holding them in storage until the time was right. Larger items had to be lifted in through the roof.

Peter recalls that first Christmas, which was far from the roasting-chestnuts-over-the-fire scenario the family might have wished for. Instead, it was spent huddling in the upper reaches of the castle without central heating or hot water. This Christmas, things were looking markedly different, with the family gathering in the Great Hall, coming and going as the day unfolded. Peter admits turning down a significant sum of money from a party from Hong Kong who had proposed hiring Ballencrieff for their New Year celebrations. Most people would have jumped at the chance, but, as Peter says, it's not a case of money being no object. It's just that family comes first, and if Christmas was to turn into nothing more than a money-making process, well, what's the point?

The Hong Kong party would not have been disappointed. There are great touches: the four-poster in the master bedroom (an ideal honeymoon suite) was made using an old church-organ frame, while the pewter goblets in the dining room were found among the rubble. The doors throughout are traditionally made, just planks of wood roughly nailed together. There's a Hepplewhite chair which belonged to the late author Nigel Tranter, who visited Ballencrieff with the couple on that first Sunday and invited Peter to pick a piece from his own home as a house-warming gift. Peter chose the Hepplewhite because it came from Greystoke Castle in Cumberland. It seemed fitting. And in the top-floor living room, an easy, informal space, you'll find original graffiti on the plasterwork, proof that 16th-century kids could become bored little vandals, too.

Would he do it again? Well, yes. Peter now sources castles for other people, and is currently restoring one in Fife for a client. He also lectures on castle restoration at Aberdeen University. Tranter calculated there were more than 7,000 castles in Scotland and Peter can see six ruins from his many windows. All you need is a spare million or so and one could be yours. In the meantime, as Peter says, 'We won't be leaving until we're too old to climb up and down these stairs!'

fields.headline: Force field
fields.standfirst: Nothing soothes the soul like rhubarb, says Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: Nothing soothes the soul like rhubarb, says Sybil Kapoor.
fields.body:
Suffering from post-Christmas stress? Considering Ayurvedic massage, acupuncture or flotation-tank therapy? No need - grab a pair of wellies and visit the dark rhubarb sheds of West Yorkshire. Philippa Ventom, tourism manager for Wakefield District Council, found one visit sufficient to wipe away the cares of the world. Admittedly, she is somewhat biased, given that she organises such tours, but even tourist officers need to relax.

Every year, from January until March, rhubarb grower Janet Oldroyd Hulme guides visitors around her warm forcing sheds. 'It's like entering a beautiful, secret world,' she says. 'It's very peaceful, the rhubarb is lit by candles and if you enter the shed alone, you can hear an eerie popping as the yellow leaves unfurl from their buds.'

Her affection for the humble rhubarb is understandable, given that forcing it requires as much skill as nurturing asparagus. The roots can only be lifted into the sheds after three years of outdoor growth, when they have accumulated enough cold units (frost). The Yorkshire Rhubarb Triangle - between Leeds, Bradford and Wakefield - is a frost pocket that hastens the chilling of the plants early in the autumn and allows them to be lifted into the forcing sheds ready for picking in January. The root crowns are carefully rinsed clean and spun into close-knit soil-less beds. Just a few grains of grit can scar a fragile, sprouting pink rhubarb stem.

Once, much of the country depended upon this small area for their first taste of rhubarb. Today, southern growers have entered the fray, chilling their rhubarb roots artificially in cold stores to allow them to produce a crop as early as November. 'We give our ladies [the pickers] miner's headlamps instead of candles,' explains Jill Mycock, sales director of Mockbeggar Farm in Rochester, Kent. The rhubarb crowns grow in stacked wooden crates to facilitate picking. Clearly such sheds are not as ethereal as those in Yorkshire. The rhubarb, however, is equally delicious.

Justin Gellatly, head pastry chef at St John in London is in no doubt as to the charms of both. 'Forced English rhubarb is very sexy,' he enthuses. 'After cooking endlessly with apples and pears, I get quite excited about being able to use it again. Its just so versatile with its balance of sweetness and sourness.'

Gellatly starts with 'Timperley Early' before moving on to the later varieties such as 'Stockbridge Arrow' and the brighter red-stemmed 'Stockbridge Harbinger'. All have a refined flavour that lingers on the palate as a refreshing aftertaste. 'I bake it in the oven (200 C) with a good sprinkling of caster sugar and covered with foil for about 10 minutes,' says Gellatly. He also uses the juice in granitas, sorbets and jellies and the flesh in crumbles, brlées and on mini-pavlovas. 'Best of all, I like it in a fool, folded into cream with some vanilla sugar and eaten with some home-made shortbread.' Such a dish might prove a good alternative to restore one's inner calm.

'After cooking endlessly with apples and pears, I get quite excited about being able to use it again. Its just so versatile with its balance of sweetness and sourness.' Gellatly starts with 'Timperley Early' before moving on to the later varieties such as 'Stockbridge Arrow' and the brighter red-stemmed 'Stockbridge Harbinger'. All have a refined flavour that lingers on the palate as a refreshing aftertaste. 'I bake it in the oven (200 C) with a good sprinkling of caster sugar and covered with foil for about 10 minutes,' says Gellatly. He also uses the juice in granitas, sorbets and jellies and the flesh in crumbles, brlées and on mini-pavlovas. 'Best of all, I like it in a fool, folded into cream with some vanilla sugar and eaten with some home-made shortbread.' Such a dish might prove a good alternative to restore one's inner calm.

webTitle: The cost of... buying a pub

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... buying a pub
fields.trailText: ... buying a pub.
fields.body:
Overindulgence during the Christmas holidays, especially in the local, encourages all sorts of foolish New Year vows such as giving up alcohol, or dieting. Instead, this year, resolve not to endure stale beer, grimy decor and a landlord with the charm and odour of an overflowing ashtray any longer: buy your own pub.

The advantages are obvious, but it is hard work. What you are looking for is a freehold; if you rent or lease a pub, you may be tied to particular suppliers who may not only overcharge you but also penalise you if you don't sell certain quantities.

There are a couple of specialist pub estate agents, and at any one time 500 of Britain's 61,000 pubs may be for sale. Prices vary according to region, so while the asking price for a freehouse in Fitzrovia is currently £875,000 and a pub in Hoxton is on the market at £550,000, another in Sunderland is a snip at £75,000.

Next, apply to your local magistrates for a liquor licence at £30 (it will need renewal after three years). You should convince the magistrates that you will be an exemplary publican. The British Institute of Innkeeping accredits several courses covering the basics of food hygiene, employment law and the correct technique for ejecting drunk students, and also issues the useful National Licencees Certificate.

Licence granted, it is time to realise your vision of the Utopian pub. A new solid-oak bar costs about £800 per metre. Ditch the fruit machine and invest in a jukebox (both similarly priced at around £3,000). No pub is complete without a table-football game, which will set you back at least £200, although you can draw the line at a pool table. All in all, a complete refurbishment, including the kitchen, may cost £20,000. On the bright side, a successful city pub can turn over £350,000 annually.

Finally, you'll need beer and someone to serve it. Giant multinational brewers have an unpleasant habit of buying up regional brewers and closing them, so buy from a smaller producer for about £40 to £50 per barrel (36 gallons or 288 pints) - although the price is dependent on your negotiating skills.

Pub up to £875,000
Liquor licence £30
Innkeeping course and certificate £130
Bar £800 per metre
Jukebox £3,000
Table football £200
Beer £40 per barrel
Bar staff from £4 per hour

fields.headline: 99 ways to change your life
fields.standfirst: One week down and the resolutions are beginning to slip. You're already stressed out at work and you're back on 20 a day. But worry not. Our panel of experts have divided your life into nine basic categories: from work, rest and play to sex and relationships. Get ready for a whole new you...
fields.trailText: One week down and the resolutions are beginning to slip. You're already stressed out at work and you're back on 20 a day. But worry not. Our panel of experts have divided your life into nine basic categories: from work, rest and play to sex and relationships. Get ready for a whole new you...
fields.body:
The panel

Maureen Freely writes about relationships. She says her main qualification is that she's a veteran of many bad ones. 'I know what other people should avoid doing.'

Euan Ferguson is an Observer interviewer and commentator.

Neasa Macerlean is a personal finance expert and reporter for the Cash section of The Observer.

Eileen Mulligan is one of the UK's most successful and sought after life coaches. She is also the author of Life Coaching For Work (£9.99, Piatkus).

Pat Kane is a social commentator and devised The Play Ethic, which he introduced in Life magazine and outlined during a series of lectures at the ICA.

Wendy Moore is an award-winning medical journalist, regular contributor to Life and editor of Channel 4's stress site (www.channel4.com/stress).

Jane Clarke is a state registered dietician and has a regular column in Life. She is also the author of the Bodyfood series of books (from £12.99, Orion).

Helen Foster is a health and fitness journalist as well as the author of the forthcoming self-help book Dejunk Your Life (£12.99, Time Life Books).

Barefoot Doctor teaches Taoism, meditation, Chinese medicine and t'ai chi and has a regular column in Life. He is also the author of several books including The Barefoot Doctor's Handbook for the Urban Warrior (£8.99, Piatkus).

Relationships
Maureen Freely

1 Follow the example of Rabbi Shmuley Boteach, author of The Jewish Book of Adultery, who says that the best way to keep a stable relationship passionate is to build in periods of abstinence. Let both parties ache for it before they allow themselves to have it.

2 Try using what's called 'paradoxical problem solving'. For example, instead of going into counselling to express your sexual boredom, first try changing the position of your bed. This is not as silly as it sounds. With paradoxical problem solving, instead of seeking a logical or rational resolution to a domestic drama, all you do is rearrange the props and, without a single earnest discussion, break the deadlock.

3 Find out if someone is as interested in you as you are in them by doing the following: next time you meet for a drink, calculate the distance between your drink and theirs and then push your drink forward so it is twice as close. If the person flinches or moves the glass, you still have a lot of work to do. If he/she does not seem to mind, try pushing it a little closer, then a little closer still. If your glass meets with no resistance whatsoever, the chances are you won't either.

4 If pressed for time, try what relationship guru Laura Corn calls 'quickies'. If, for example, you like someone, just say so. If you want to meet for a coffee, or equally have sex on the kitchen floor, go for it, now. And don't worry if it's over almost before it begins. Ten minutes of intense pleasure are about all anyone can take in a 24-hour day.

5 Be warned by John Gottman - the world's most accurate expert on marital relations. In one study he was able to predict with 94 per cent accuracy which couples in his studies would divorce within three years. The earliest warning sign is frequent harsh personal criticism and it can be non-verbal as well as verbal. In Gottman's lab studies, wherever wives' faces registered disgust at their husbands' words four or five times in a 15-minute period, the couple were likely to separate within four years.

6 Avoid 'flooding'. This is when you're so upset you can't think, or when he/she seems not to hear a word you've said. This is not just in your head. It's an unpleasant physical state in which your heartbeat is about 10 beats a minute above your normal level, and adrenaline is racing through your bloodstream. Our friend Gottman has trained some couples to stop and count their pulse mid-argument. If they detect flooding, they then call a 20-minute time-out and retire to their separate corners to practise their favourite relaxation techniques.

7 Stick to the point. If you want to keep your rows from turning into plate-smashing ceremonies, Daniel Goleman, author of Emotional Intelligence, advises that you avoid throwing in the other thousand things that are driving you mad about a person. Thus, if the argument started out being about the red socks that got in with the whites by mistake and turned everything pink, it should still be about red socks and pink sheets when it comes to a close. When you are making a complaint, be specific - not just about the thing you don't like, but how you feel about it, and what you'd like to happen instead.

8 Try 'mirroring' - another technique relationship that experts recommend. What this means is that when your loved one complains about something you do, you throw away your standard defensive responses, eg: 'Yes, but', 'You can talk', and 'Have you ever heard the one about people who live in glass houses?' and instead listen carefully to the complaint, and then repeat it back to him/her, in his/her own words and ask if you have understood correctly. This technique keeps the temperature cool and the level of communication high.

9 Remember that ratios count. According to Gottman, if the amount of time you spend arguing with your partner is only a seventh of the amount you spend together happily, your relationship is doing very well. If 60 per cent of your problems are unresolvable, you're normal, so don't worry. Instead, try building up goodwill by practising what the experts call validation. This means praising people for work well done, or generous gestures appreciated.

10 Don't underestimate the importance of time spent alone together and bear in mind that the harder it is to arrange, the more important it is to arrange it. How you spend that time is also crucial. Leave behind mundane domestic matters on these occasions and talk instead about the big things: your hopes, your dreams and your fears. And how about this? Instead of drawing up a list of personal New Year's resolutions, sit down together and think of three things you've never done, or never done together, that you'd like to do before the year is out.

11 Finally, if you feel you're putting a lot more into a relationship than the other person is, or if you're upset because you're ready to settle down into something more permanent and he/she very clearly isn't or you find yourself waking up in the middle of the night with worst-case scenario jealous fantasies, you could do worse than try the Anaïs Nin Cure. That is, you take the same worst-case scenario but this time make yourself its main player; perfect happiness, according to Nin, means having not one, not two, but three lovers on the go. That way you're never bored, always busy, and have at least one person waiting in the wings who is just dying to give you a good time.

Culture
Euan Ferguson

12 Throw away your telly. A little drastic, certainly, but if you're going to spend one year of your life wholly freed from spoonfed dumbo cretin-babble it might as well be this one. Britons are rushing back to the cinema and you should join them, for there will be nothing good on television in the coming year.

13 Subscribe to McSweeney's, a quarterly American magazine of new writing due to be distributed in Britain next year, and one of the most savagely cool things to appear between hard covers. Edited as a labour of love by Dave Eggers, author of A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, it switches format and price from issue to issue (the most recent was individual pamphlets presented in a box), is typographically stunning and is printed, naturally, in Iceland.

14 Log on to either www.tvgohome.com or www.theonion.com, two of the few genuinely funny things on the interwebnet. The first, a set of spoof TV listings, is more creative and entertaining than 99 per cent of the medium it parodies.

15 Buy five jazz albums and spend some time falling in love with smart music. You could do far worse, for a starter kit, than the following: Kind of Blue by Miles Davis, naturally, still the classic post-war jazz recording; A Love Supreme , the best collection around of John Coltrane; Elegiac Cycle by Brad Mehldau and Soul on Soul by Dave Douglas, the improvisers of the moment on, respectively, piano and trumpet; and Promenade with Duke by the late Michel Petrucciani, the world's formost Ellington interpreter.

16 Brush up on your Tolkien, even if you hate it. When the film comes out, no party will be safe from a Lord of the Rings conversation, so make sure you have something to say, even if it's simply, 'I never read it; and nor, happily, did I spent my entire teenage years making horrid cracking sounds with my knuckles and picking my sweaty feet and masturbating.' If you want to say something else, remember that the Elf language was based on Finnish, the Orc vernacular based on Turkish, that Tolkien (John Ronald Reuel) wrote half of it sitting in a tree and that the filming was interrupted last year when the New Zealand army, acting as paid extras, had to take off their goblin outfits to go and fight with the UN in East Timor.

17 Go to Colombia. Cartagena, on the Caribbean coast, features both a lovely old cobbled city and a new hedonistic overflow of clubs, casinos and beaches, and will be the destination of choice for those in the know.

18 Turn Japanese. Japan 2001, a year-long celebration of the country and its culture and trends and gadgets and wars, really kicks off in May with a spectacular Matsuri jamboree in Hyde Park - but you should try to get with the programme before tout London is dressing and dancing like Tokyo. If you want to escape all this, take a quick trip to Rotterdam, the year's joint European City of Culture with Oporto - a fine Breughel the Elder show begins at the renovated Boijmans Van Beuningen Museum on 27 May.

19 Become a Friend of Tate Modern, and win cultured access to the grooviest bar in London, the private riverside terrace on the fifth floor. But don't stay in the capital all the time: Walsall's New Art Gallery has already attracted more than 210,000 visitors in less than a year and features, along with the Picassos and Chagalls, lift announcements by Noddy Holder.

20 Join a poetry workshop. Key fact: make sure it's a good one, such as that run by Michael Donaghy at London City University, not a pony one attended by Lord of the Ring's aficionados and wet-lipped, recently divorced, failed marketing managers called Malcolm feeling sorry for themselves. Donaghy's, however, is not for the faint-hearted or emotionally dishonest; his deconstruction of your own work will help, but it will scare.

21 Go to Dulwich College in south London, before the end of February, to see the James Caird, the wooden boat in which Ernest Shackleton and an exhausted crew crossed 800 miles of open sea to South Georgia to secure rescue for the marooned men on his failed 1916 expedition, and the marvellous accompanying photographs of hell on ice.

22 Fly to New York to visit the stunning Rose Space Center and new Planetarium. Take in, on the way, a ruinously expensive but delightful cocktail at the Campbell Apartment, a splendidly restored chic hideaway beside Grand Central Station.

Money
Neasa MacErlean

23 Don't see your parents as financial gurus. Even the big City regulator the Financial Services Authority is concerned that up to 40 per cent of people consult their parents, which is OK if you want views and recommendations from 20 years back, but not OK for now.

24 Start being entrepreneurial. A degree and a profession will pay the mortgage but won't give you the financial freedom that comes from running clever businesses, renting out property or owning other well-picked income-generating assets.

25 Get yourself computer-literate for free. The first one million people who apply can get a £150 subsidy for a training course through the government's Individual Learning Account scheme (0800 072 5678).

26 Work out what you will do with the money you save from switching mortgages. Cutting your costs by 2 per cent a month - quite possible if you are currently on the standard variable rate - could save you £50,000 over the lifetime of the loan on a £100,000 property. Lenders are making huge sums from the lazy borrowers sitting on the standard variable rate (of 7.74 per cent in many banks and building societies) - while more alert borrowers are getting fixed and discount deals, bringing their rate below 6 per cent.

27 Beware of independent financial advisers urging you to take out (expensive) critical-illness plans. With charges coming down on pension plans, they need to make their money elsewhere - and this is where many will focus.

28 Get your baby a stakeholder pension. The new scheme, starting in April, sets no minimum age for taking out a plan. If you build up funds for your children - taking advantage of the automatic tax relief of 22 per cent given to all plan-holders, regardless of earnings level - they might never need to make pension contributions at all.

29 See financial advisers or salespeople as a couple if you are in a partnership. Women are far more likely to ask those basic (and crucial) questions that many men are embarrassed to ask.

30 Think of investing up to 10 per cent of your savings in emerging markets funds - but only if you can afford to lose the money. See this as a long-term investment of 15 to 40 years. The developing economies now have the biggest potential for growth and financial return. South East Asian funds shot up by 80 per cent and 17 per cent in the past two years - whereas you would be lucky to get 10 per cent a year in more mature Western markets. But be aware that volatility is inherent in new market investments: as well as reaping big rewards, you could also lose everything if there is a coup in the country you invest in, widespread fraud or some other disaster.

31 Put some savings into an Individual Savings Account where growth and income are tax-free. When you open up a standard building society account, you are taxed on the interest - but with ISA accounts you don't have to pay tax. You could double the amount of interest you receive by going this route.

32 Choose your career with care. The reason that women earn just 75 per cent of what men earn is not just to do with career breaks or sexism: women tend to go into low-paying careers such as nursing in greater numbers. If you are going to university, choose your degree subject with an eye to the returns. Law and politics graduates earn 50 per cent more than agriculture graduates, according to Warwick University.

33 Recognise that keeping fit saves you money and gives you freedom. Thousands of old women live in old people's homes now because they lack the upper body strength to draw a curtain or get out of a chair. Even in your 80s, a few gentle aerobics classes will tone those muscles again.

Work
Eileen Mulligan

34 Select a job that is in line with your values so that your career choice is based on 'suitability' as well as 'capability'. List your top 10 values, ideally in order of priority, to remind yourself of what's important to you. Common values include security, challenge, recognition, job satisfaction, family life and health.

35 Bear in mind that you're in the best possible position to negotiate a salary increase when you (a) know what the market will bear in your job/profession, (b) have had positive feedback on your performance and (c) can demonstrate that you are meeting the objectives of your job and, if necessary, are exceeding them.

36 Avoid unnecessary confrontation by using effective communication. Here are some guidelines: clarify information by asking questions such as, 'Would I be right in thinking you mean_?' When a difference of opinion arises, emphasise the points both parties agree on rather than just focusing on the areas of disagreement. Be prepared to offer solutions; simply identifying the problem will keep you blocked.

37 Stay motivated and maintain a sense of purpose by always having goals. Goals should always be positive and about what you want to get out of a job and not about a job you want to get out of.

38 Achieve a better work/life balance by setting goals that include all areas of your life, such as family, health, finances, personal relationships and social life.

39 Be warned - the 'flexible worker' is the most sought after in today's workplace. If you want to stay in demand, you should be a multi-skilled worker who is prepared to work flexible hours, prepared to expand your job demarcation and willing to relocate.

40 Be a smart worker. Smart workers get recognition for the work they do because they know that it's not how hard they work in the office, but how they work the office that counts. Here are a few tips: listen to the grapevine and understand how office politics work; be aware that although your immediate boss may hold the power, you also need to impress the people who have influence.

41 Don't resist change. Change requires an incubation period before you can determine if it offers a better way of working. So, before you react negatively, remember that in the new world of work, 'change' rather than 'stability' is the norm.

42 Use the web to search for a new job, using internet recruitment firms that cover information on what a company has to offer in terms of training, pension schemes, health-care insurance and profit-share options. Advice on preparing your CV, writing a covering letter and how to handle an interview is also available.

43 Remember that technology is only useful when it is combined with effective time management. If you're allocating time to access information, make sure that you are also allocating time to act on that information.

44 Keep on top of your hardcore skills - qualifications and ability to perform a task - as well as your interpersonal skills. Both skills are equally important in today's workplace and will help you keep your job.

Read the second part of 99 ways to change your life here

Key fact: make sure it's a good one, such as that run by Michael Donaghy at London City University, not a pony one attended by Lord of the Ring's aficionados and wet-lipped, recently divorced, failed marketing managers called Malcolm feeling sorry for themselves. Donaghy's, however, is not for the faint-hearted or emotionally dishonest; his deconstruction of your own work will help, but it will scare. 21 Go to Dulwich College in south London, before the end of February, to see the James Caird, the wooden boat in which Ernest Shackleton and an exhausted crew crossed 800 miles of open sea to South Georgia to secure rescue for the marooned men on his failed 1916 expedition, and the marvellous accompanying photographs of hell on ice. 22 Fly to New York to visit the stunning Rose Space Center and new Planetarium. Take in, on the way, a ruinously expensive but delightful cocktail at the Campbell Apartment, a splendidly restored chic hideaway beside Grand Central Station. Money Neasa MacErlean 23 Don't see your parents as financial gurus. Even the big City regulator the Financial Services Authority is concerned that up to 40 per cent of people consult their parents, which is OK if you want views and recommendations from 20 years back, but not OK for now. 24 Start being entrepreneurial. A degree and a profession will pay the mortgage but won't give you the financial freedom that comes from running clever businesses, renting out property or owning other well-picked income-generating assets. 25 Get yourself computer-literate for free. The first one million people who apply can get a £150 subsidy for a training course through the government's Individual Learning Account scheme (0800 072 5678). 26 Work out what you will do with the money you save from switching mortgages. Cutting your costs by 2 per cent a month - quite possible if you are currently on the standard variable rate - could save you £50,000 over the lifetime of the loan on a £100,000 property. Lenders are making huge sums from the lazy borrowers sitting on the standard variable rate (of 7.74 per cent in many banks and building societies) - while more alert borrowers are getting fixed and discount deals, bringing their rate below 6 per cent. 27 Beware of independent financial advisers urging you to take out (expensive) critical-illness plans. With charges coming down on pension plans, they need to make their money elsewhere - and this is where many will focus. 28 Get your baby a stakeholder pension. The new scheme, starting in April, sets no minimum age for taking out a plan. If you build up funds for your children - taking advantage of the automatic tax relief of 22 per cent given to all plan-holders, regardless of earnings level - they might never need to make pension contributions at all. 29 See financial advisers or salespeople as a couple if you are in a partnership. Women are far more likely to ask those basic (and crucial) questions that many men are embarrassed to ask. 30 Think of investing up to 10 per cent of your savings in emerging markets funds - but only if you can afford to lose the money. See this as a long-term investment of 15 to 40 years. The developing economies now have the biggest potential for growth and financial return. South East Asian funds shot up by 80 per cent and 17 per cent in the past two years - whereas you would be lucky to get 10 per cent a year in more mature Western markets. But be aware that volatility is inherent in new market investments: as well as reaping big rewards, you could also lose everything if there is a coup in the country you invest in, widespread fraud or some other disaster. 31 Put some savings into an Individual Savings Account where growth and income are tax-free. When you open up a standard building society account, you are taxed on the interest - but with ISA accounts you don't have to pay tax. You could double the amount of interest you receive by going this route. 32 Choose your career with care. The reason that women earn just 75 per cent of what men earn is not just to do with career breaks or sexism: women tend to go into low-paying careers such as nursing in greater numbers. If you are going to university, choose your degree subject with an eye to the returns. Law and politics graduates earn 50 per cent more than agriculture graduates, according to Warwick University. 33 Recognise that keeping fit saves you money and gives you freedom. Thousands of old women live in old people's homes now because they lack the upper body strength to draw a curtain or get out of a chair. Even in your 80s, a few gentle aerobics classes will tone those muscles again. Work Eileen Mulligan 34 Select a job that is in line with your values so that your career choice is based on 'suitability' as well as 'capability'. List your top 10 values, ideally in order of priority, to remind yourself of what's important to you. Common values include security, challenge, recognition, job satisfaction, family life and health. 35 Bear in mind that you're in the best possible position to negotiate a salary increase when you (a) know what the market will bear in your job/profession, (b) have had positive feedback on your performance and (c) can demonstrate that you are meeting the objectives of your job and, if necessary, are exceeding them. 36 Avoid unnecessary confrontation by using effective communication. Here are some guidelines: clarify information by asking questions such as, 'Would I be right in thinking you mean_?' When a difference of opinion arises, emphasise the points both parties agree on rather than just focusing on the areas of disagreement. Be prepared to offer solutions; simply identifying the problem will keep you blocked. 37 Stay motivated and maintain a sense of purpose by always having goals. Goals should always be positive and about what you want to get out of a job and not about a job you want to get out of. 38 Achieve a better work/life balance by setting goals that include all areas of your life, such as family, health, finances, personal relationships and social life. 39 Be warned - the 'flexible worker' is the most sought after in today's workplace. If you want to stay in demand, you should be a multi-skilled worker who is prepared to work flexible hours, prepared to expand your job demarcation and willing to relocate. 40 Be a smart worker. Smart workers get recognition for the work they do because they know that it's not how hard they work in the office, but how they work the office that counts. Here are a few tips: listen to the grapevine and understand how office politics work; be aware that although your immediate boss may hold the power, you also need to impress the people who have influence. 41 Don't resist change. Change requires an incubation period before you can determine if it offers a better way of working. So, before you react negatively, remember that in the new world of work, 'change' rather than 'stability' is the norm. 42 Use the web to search for a new job, using internet recruitment firms that cover information on what a company has to offer in terms of training, pension schemes, health-care insurance and profit-share options. Advice on preparing your CV, writing a covering letter and how to handle an interview is also available. 43 Remember that technology is only useful when it is combined with effective time management. If you're allocating time to access information, make sure that you are also allocating time to act on that information. 44 Keep on top of your hardcore skills - qualifications and ability to perform a task - as well as your interpersonal skills. Both skills are equally important in today's workplace and will help you keep your job. Read the second part of 99 ways to change your life here

fields.headline: Mvondo
fields.trailText: Born in Cameroon, now playing for Dundee United.
fields.body:
Birthplace: Yaounde, Cameroon
Now playing for Dundee United in the Scottish Premier League
Age: 21
Position: Striker
Joined Dundee United from Tonnerre Kalara (Cameroon)
Appearances: 12 (4 as a substitute)

Did you see British football as a child, and did you support an English team?
Only a little bit. In Cameroon we used to get a highlights programme every Sunday which showed the old English First Division. They didn't really show much of the matches, just the goals really.

How did your move to Dundee United come about?
My agent handled the move. I have played for Cameroon's national team and was spotted by Dundee United. So I came over to have a look, and was impressed by the club and the amount of young players here. So I signed for them for three years. I didn't go to the Olympics with Cameroon because I wanted to start my club career as soon as possible.

Had you heard of Dundee United before you joined them?
Only after my agent told me about them.

What were your first impressions of Scottish football, and how have they changed?
I like it. The game is faster and more physical, you don't get much time to recover during a match. You have to do a lot more running over here. In my first few matches I had run out of energy and was tired before the end. It took about two months to get used to it but I think I have adjusted now. Sometimes when I finish a match I am not that tired any more. I am looking forward to scoring my first goal because the fans have been very good to me. I hope to repay them for their support.

Where are you living?
I have my own house. I stayed in a hotel for my first two months here while I was looking for somewhere of my own. Living in a hotel sounds good but after a while it gets boring. I am happier now I have my own place. I have made a lot of good friends since I have been here.

Have you any family over with you?
Not at the moment. I am hoping that my girlfriend will be able to come over soon. She is waiting for a visa. I am hoping other members of my family will be able to come and stay as well.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
I just relax. Dundee is a nice place to live. It is not too big. I occasionally get recognised when I go down the shops. People come up to me and say things like 'Mvondo, when are you going to score your first goal for us?' I try to explain to them that we are all trying to score for the team and that I am doing my best.

Have you learnt to speak English?
I am learning all the time. I learnt some at school, so it's not too bad.

How does training differ from what you are used to?
There is a lot more pressure, because of the size of the club, its supporters and the fact that we are not doing so well at the moment.

What do you like most about living in Scotland?
I like the relaxed lifestyle. I am here to earn a living playing football so it's great to play somewhere like Dundee. It is very peaceful and enjoyable.

What do you like least about it?
Obviously I miss my family. It is a long way to be away from home on your own.

How do Scottish fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
The fans over here are brilliant. I love them. The atmosphere is so good in the stadiums. I love the way the fans chant and sing while we play. They are all so passionate.

How long do you think you will stay in Scottish football?
I've only just joined and am enjoying it at the moment so I'm not thinking about leaving.

fields.headline: Silvinho
fields.trailText: Born in Brazil, now playing for Arsenal.
fields.body:
full name: Sylvio Mendes Campos Junior

Birthplace: Sao Paulo, Brazil
Now playing for Arsenal in the Premiership

Age: 26
Position: Left-back
Joined Arsenal in June 1999, from the Brazlian club Corinthians for about £4m Appearances: 55 (10)

Describe the place you grew up
I was born in Sao Paulo and came from a poor family. I was always playing football from when I was a toddler.

Did you get to see English football as a child, and did you support an English team?
I didn't know anything about English football. It's too far away. And anyway, there is enough football in Brazil keep us occupied.

When did you first play professional football?
In 1995 for my old club Corinthians. I was 20 years old.

How did your move to England come about?
I played professionally for five years but I had been in Corinthinas all my life, from when I was an amateur - maybe 12 years in total. When I received an invitation from Arsenal I was very happy. It is one of the best teams in England at the moment.

Had you heard of your current team before you joined them?
Some things, but only because there are so many great players here: Dennis Bergkamp, Emmanuel Petit, Patrick Vieira, Tony Adams.

What were your first impressions of English football, and how have they changed?
It was very difficult at the beginning because the style of play is so different. I was also pleased because everything about the game was very competitive but also fun. With time I have come to think the British way is the best way in the world.

Where are you living?
When I first arrived I stayed in a hotel for three and a half months, and since then I live in a house in New Barnet. It's North London, close to the training ground, and I like it. It's very different from Sao Paulo - much better in some ways. I can walk on the street and everyone shows respect. Sometimes in Sao Paulo after you have lost a game you can't venture out, can't go to a restaurant, can't go anywhere. It's a religion.

Have you got any family with you?
No parents, sisters, brothers; just me and my wife. My parents came to visit two months ago and they stayed for about a month. My wife's parents came last season.

Do you send any money home?
No, my family is ok.

What do you like and dislike most about living in England?
I wanted to learn English because it is the universal language. It's a country where they offer you very good conditions to live and work. I don't like it when it's raining a lot, just because I play football. If you stay at home you don't need to worry about it but when you are going out to play and you see it is rainy it's terrible. When you are used to playing in 20-25 degrees you need to motivate yourself to go out when it's like that. I had never played in the rain before I came here.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
I like to watch movies. Sometimes I go to the cinema or theatre.

Have you learned to speak English?
It's not easy for me. How can I explain? I needed to understand how to get by in training, games, hotel but I didn't have any time to have lessons three or four hours a day so I learned as I went along, listening to my team-mates at Arsenal. I can communicate much better now than when I arrived, it took about six months until I felt comfortable. Once I have completed two years here I am sure I will be better.

Is English football better or worse than you expected?
I didn't know about English football but it is very impressive to me. A hard game, physical game, difficult game. It's a good football battle. Arsene Wenger was very good to me because he gave me about six months to adapt to the game, and he kept encouraging me to go forward even thought I play in defence.

Is the atmosphere in the dressing room different that to in other countries?
Completely different, and not just compared to Brazil. I was in the national team and my team-mates were telling me in Italy you cannot speak on the bus, other places you can't talk to the boss or make a joke. I told them you can do all that in England. I like having the stereo as well. The atmosphere is more relaxed and it motivates us. In Brazil it is quieter and each player gets on with their own routine.

How does training differ from what you are used to?
Basically it's the same balance between working with the ball and physical work. In Brazil because of the temparatures we normally did two sessions a day, and also because the game is not so physical it's easier to train more - and play the games - without it taking too much out of you.

What do you like most about English football?
Every stadium is a full house! It's not like that in Brazil. My old club Corinthians had a lot of fans - it's a big club like Arsenal - but if you go through a bad patch they desert you. Sometimes 100,000, sometimes not.

What do you like least about it?
Sometimes the referees. Because it's a physical game I understand it makes the referee's job a hard one, but so many people go over the top.

How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
I like the way the British fans are so polite when they approach a player to ask for an autograph. They wait, one by one, whereas sometimes in Brazil you are just mobbed by a crowd. It is more civilised here, people give you more space.

Have you experienced racism by opponents or opposing fans?
Nothing.

How long do you think you will stay in English football?
You never know with football. I have a contract here that I intend to fulfil. I am happier with my professional life here. It's wonderful.

fields.headline: Christian Karembeu
fields.trailText: Born in New Caledonia, now playing for Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Birthplace: New Caledonia
Now playing for Middlesbrough in the Premiership
Age: 30
Position: Midfielder
Joined Middlesbrough for £2.1m in July 2000
Appearances: 12 (2)
First played professional football for: FC Nantes
Clubs since: Sampdoria, Real Madrid

Did you see English football as a child, and did you support an English team?
I didn't see much. I lived in New Caledonia until I was 17 and because it is a French colony I watched mainly French football on our old Black and White TV. I also saw a lot of South American football, so I was more familiar with players from Brazil and Argentina. I still knew about British players like Kenny Dalgleish and Bobby Charlton though - everyone has heard of them.

How did your move to England come about?
I am a competitor and saw coming to Middlesbrough as a great challenge and a continuation of my football education. I had learned so much already from my years in France, Italy and Spain, I won several trophies in that time and I wanted to come to England and try to achieve something for the people of Middlesbrough. This is a club that is really trying to achieve success and I hope to be a part of it.

Had you heard of Middlesbrough before you joined them?
Yes of course. Macca (Steve McManaman) told me all about them at Madrid last season. I also played with Platty (David Platt) at Sampdoria so I have always had an interest in English football.

What were your first impressions of English Football, and how have they changed?
Coming from Madrid, I was used to a more patient, controlled style of play, so English football was totally different. I knew it was going to be difficult, but I am really enjoying it. I love the fighting spirit in English football, so much passion. It is another way of playing the game, although it is more direct and harder work, there is still a lot of passing. I am trying to become as knowledgeable about all styles of football as possible.

Where are you living?
I am still living in a hotel. I am out most of the time at the moment so I don't mind. It's a nice hotel.

Have you got any family over with you?
My wife Adriana is here with me. She works all over Europe, but when she isn't working she is here.

Do you send any money home?
Yes of course. My father died five years ago and I need to take care of the rest of my family back home. I have 15 brothers and sisters back in New Caledonia so we are a massive family. I'm not doing it because I am here, more because it comes natural to me. I would help out no matter what job I had. It's no big deal to me. I go home whenever I can although football seasons are so long nowadays that it is difficult.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
At the moment I am spending most of my time looking for a house. We found a couple of places that we liked but were beaten to them. I know what everyone says about me living in Middlesbrough, but when you come here you find the training ground is nowhere near the City Centre, it's actually out in the countryside, very quiet and peaceful. I am also shopping quite a lot, buying clothes especially. I had hardly any clothes when I arrived. They were all left in my house in Madrid. I have been to York as well. It's a beautiful city, so much history.

Have you learned to speak English?
I learned English at school. I always used to study very hard and wanted to have a good career. I believe that education is very important. I wasn't sure that I even wanted to be a footballer, I was also into tennis and handball but when I got the chance to play for Nantes in France I took it. It was a great opportunity.


How does training differ from what you are used to?
The facilities here are the best I've seen. Madrid are a contradiction, they are a big club yet they only have two pitches to train on. Here at Middlesbrough we have 15 pitches and a whole new training complex with everything you can imagine. It is amazing and a credit to the chairman and the Gaffer that the club is in such a healthy condition. We are not doing so well on the pitch at the moment, but with more self-belief I know we can turn it around. We have some very good players here.

What do you like most about living in England?
I love it. English life always surprises me. Everyday something different happens. I love the countryside in North Yorkshire. It is beautiful, I am a big admirer of art and I have seen many painting of the landscapes around here. London is a great city also, it has all the restaurants, shopping and the theatres you could want. It is a great place to visit.

What do you like least about it?
My family has to get visas if they want to come over here to stay, which is difficult. The other thing that bothers me is the way people seem to be against the French beef at the moment!

How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
Fans are the same all over the world. They are all passionate about their team. Wherever I play I always respect the identity of the fans. They are all so proud of their club. They wear the colours of the team, and the shirts to matches. I know how much the team means to them. All players should be proud of the fans they are representing.

Have you experienced any racism by opponents or opposing fans?
No.

How long do you think you will stay in English football?
I like to try and respect my contracts. I have a four-year contract and I hope to stay here.
