Where are you living? I am still living in a hotel. I am out most of the time at the moment so I don't mind. It's a nice hotel. Have you got any family over with you? My wife Adriana is here with me. She works all over Europe, but when she isn't working she is here. Do you send any money home? Yes of course. My father died five years ago and I need to take care of the rest of my family back home. I have 15 brothers and sisters back in New Caledonia so we are a massive family. I'm not doing it because I am here, more because it comes natural to me. I would help out no matter what job I had. It's no big deal to me. I go home whenever I can although football seasons are so long nowadays that it is difficult. What do you do in the afternoons and evenings? At the moment I am spending most of my time looking for a house. We found a couple of places that we liked but were beaten to them. I know what everyone says about me living in Middlesbrough, but when you come here you find the training ground is nowhere near the City Centre, it's actually out in the countryside, very quiet and peaceful. I am also shopping quite a lot, buying clothes especially. I had hardly any clothes when I arrived. They were all left in my house in Madrid. I have been to York as well. It's a beautiful city, so much history. Have you learned to speak English? I learned English at school. I always used to study very hard and wanted to have a good career. I believe that education is very important. I wasn't sure that I even wanted to be a footballer, I was also into tennis and handball but when I got the chance to play for Nantes in France I took it. It was a great opportunity. How does training differ from what you are used to? The facilities here are the best I've seen. Madrid are a contradiction, they are a big club yet they only have two pitches to train on. Here at Middlesbrough we have 15 pitches and a whole new training complex with everything you can imagine. It is amazing and a credit to the chairman and the Gaffer that the club is in such a healthy condition. We are not doing so well on the pitch at the moment, but with more self-belief I know we can turn it around. We have some very good players here. What do you like most about living in England? I love it. English life always surprises me. Everyday something different happens. I love the countryside in North Yorkshire. It is beautiful, I am a big admirer of art and I have seen many painting of the landscapes around here. London is a great city also, it has all the restaurants, shopping and the theatres you could want. It is a great place to visit. What do you like least about it? My family has to get visas if they want to come over here to stay, which is difficult. The other thing that bothers me is the way people seem to be against the French beef at the moment! How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in? Fans are the same all over the world. They are all passionate about their team. Wherever I play I always respect the identity of the fans. They are all so proud of their club. They wear the colours of the team, and the shirts to matches. I know how much the team means to them. All players should be proud of the fans they are representing. Have you experienced any racism by opponents or opposing fans? No. How long do you think you will stay in English football? I like to try and respect my contracts. I have a four-year contract and I hope to stay here.

fields.headline: Davide Xausa
fields.trailText: Born in Canada, now playing for Inverness in the Scottish First Division.
fields.body:
Birthplace: Vancouver, Canada
Now playing for Inverness in the Scottish First Division
Age: 24
Position: Forward
Joined Inverness on free transfer from Dutch club Dordrecht 90 in Sept 1999
Appearances: 32 (6)
First played professional football for? Sporting Lisbon
(Other clubs: University of Portland, Stoke City, St.Johnstone, Dordrecht 90)

Did you get to see English/Scottish football as a child, and did you support anyone?
Not much, my father is from Italy so growing up I was always into Italian football, I was a big Juventus fan. I first heard about the English Premier league when I was 15 or 16, you can watch it in bars in Canada at 10am over breakfast or a beer - that turns into long drinking session for some people! I did see Peter Beardsley play, he was at Vancouver for a while and was the first English player I ever saw in person. As for Scottish football, everybody knows about Celtic and Rangers but that's about it.

How did your move to Britain come about?
My Canadian national team coach Bruce Twamley who worked with Bobby Robson at Ipswich, suggested to Bobby to take me on trial at Sporting Lisbon to get me some experience and Bobby agreed. I was quite close to him while I was out there, I still see him occasionally. He comes on holiday to Canada quite often, the last time he came over we played golf together. I left Lisbon after six months, I was 17 at the time and didn't feel ready for such a big change in lifestyle so I came back to Canada and went through university majoring in finance. There were no professional clubs in Canada for me to join, the CSL (Canadian Soccer League) had just folded, so I just played college football. My move over here came up through my agent, it was kind of a friend of a friend thing, and was a great opportunity for me.

Had you heard of Inverness before you joined?
Yes I had, we have another Canadian International Richard Hastings who plays here, so I had heard of them through him.

What were your first impressions of British football?
Not good! In my first game for Inverness I dislocated my shoulder and was out for eight weeks! Seriously though, it was a steep learning curve to come from playing college football in Canada to professional football in the UK. The pace of the game is so fast, and the games are so physical, even compared to Holland, where things are more skilful and tactical and you get more time on the ball. The game here is more direct, and although there are hard tackles in football all over the world, because of the pace of the game here, they are flying in so much more often that it takes some getting used to. When you have a 200-pound, six-foot three Scotsman running into you, believe me, you know about it. I have a much harder match playing for Inverness than I do for Canada.

Where are you living now?
I have a house in Inverness with a fantastic view that I moved into six months ago. When I was at St Johnstone I lived in a hotel for over five months, it was great for the first month, but after that you get bored of eating there and only having your room to go back to. You really need your own place to stay sane.

Have you got any family over with you?
No, my girlfriend Jacquie lived with me for the past two years, she has gone back over to Canada to finish her degree, we are getting engaged over Christmas and hopefully she will be back here soon. I only really get to go home to see everyone once a year over the summer for a few weeks. When I go home to play internationals it's not like here where everywhere is so close, no-one gets a chance to visit family or friends. It's very much - go home, play the game, come back again.

What do you like and dislike about living in Scotland?
I don't like being so far away from home. It gets a little chilly in the winter here too, so my friends and family back home would rather be in Mexico or Hawaii than coming over to see me. There is a slow pace of life here which although I really like, it's very much for families, not exactly what you'd call a single person's paradise. Even though I have a girlfriend, I still like a night out with the lads, and there's only a handful of bars to go to. The television here is terrible - its sucks, although some friends of mine gave me some Roy Chubby Brown videos which were funny. Food wise, I do like Bangers and Mash and have tried Haggis a couple times - never again!

How does the training differ to what you are used to?
The training varies depending on if we have a game coming up, usually I'm finished by one. Over here before the game they name the team and give a little pep talk then send you out to play. In Holland and Portugal it is a lot more technical and tactical, they sit you down they put four or five different charts on the board, with your name on, what you should be doing and runs you should be making. Here it's just a case of 'go get 'em' or 'get stuck in'.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
Occasionally golf depending on the weather. I have a lot of time on my hands so I tried to take up fishing but it didn't really do it for me, the rods are at the back of the cupboard already. I am still studying finance, it kills a couple of hours and also means that when I finish playing I'll have some credentials to be able to get a decent job. I have become a bit of a computer nerd as well - always on the Internet checking emails. I am into stocks and shares and do day trading on the Internet. The market back home in Toronto or New York opens a 9am which is 2pm over here so it works out perfectly for me. I have my own trading account, so I can check things out, see what the rumours are and make a couple of trades before the market opens. I've been getting killed the past couple of months, but if you buy into quality companies and sell at the right time it can make money. It's like a hobby now.

Is the atmosphere in the dressing room different to other countries?
It varies from club to club, what people forget is that when you join a new club people can be quite cold towards you, because you are effectively coming in and trying to take their job. You have to prove yourself, when I first came over I was young and when you're sharing a dressing room with men that are 32 and 33 it can be quite intimidating, especially if you're not from around there. I get stick for being a Canadian everyday - people taking the piss, trying to do their Canadian accents, most of them are terrible. Its good banter really.

How do the fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
The people in Inverness are fine, you do get recognized occasionally but nothing near the scale of player's who play for a big club like Celtic or Rangers, people just sort of smile at you and wonder where they know you from. Back home, I got recognized for the first time this summer, this guy came up to me and wanted my autograph, I couldn't believe it, I was so shocked that I asked for his autograph back.

How long do you think you will stay in British football?
I don't know. I'm not one of those guys who will try and prolong his career in his thirties, by the time I'm 30 I will be out of football completely. There are other things I want to do in my life. When I retire I won't stay in the game, I might coach a kid's team or something but that will be it.

fields.headline: Davor Suker
fields.trailText: Born in Croatia, now playing for West Ham.
fields.body:
Birthplace: Osijek, Croatia
Now playing for West Ham in the Premiership
Age: 33
Position: Striker
Joined West Ham in June 2000 on a free transer
Appearances: 6 (3)

Describe the place you grew up
Osijek is a nice, small, family town. It's very green, a city of agriculture, and it also has a good reputation nurturing sports - all sports do well there.

Did you get to see English football as a child, and did you support an English team?
I always watched the best games in Wembley, teams like Arsenal, Man U, Chelsea. Inspired by what I saw on television all my childhood I dreamed about two things - playing for Real Madrid, and playing at Wembley. The history, the pitch, atmosphere, it's my dream. I didn't support an English team, I always supported Real Madrid as a team and Maradona as a player. This was my life.

First played professional football for?
Osijek, in Croatia. I was 16 when I made my debut, the youngest player to be a professional in Croatia's history.

Clubs since?
Dynamo Zagreb, Sevilla, Real Madrid, Arsenal, West Ham.

How did your move to England come about?
I had played eight years in Spain and it was time to look to the future. English clubs are very strong in Europe, and many Croatian players told me it was an excellent league. I had other opportunities in many other countries but I wanted to come here. I enjoy playing at the birthplace of football - real football is here. I savour the old culture. Outside of football there was one other main reason to come: to learn English. It's very important, a big profit for football players. It's a hard profession for 16 years but you have some privileges: learning a language, making many friends abroad. These friendships stay with you after football.

Had you heard of West Ham before you joined them?
Yes.

What were your first impressions of English football, and how have they changed?
My first impression was that it is honest football. People run, people fight, but it's always honest. Referees make mistakes but they too are honest.

More honest than Spain?
100%.

More honest than Croatia?
100%. It's more professional here. Even if you are having a good or bad day, you have to fight for the shirt.

Where are you living?
I am renting a flat in Knightsbridge.

Have you got any family with you?
I live alone but a couple of times a year my family come to visit me in London, and my friends come too.

Do you send any money home?
Of course. I am proud, I am a football player who has played for 16 years thank God, and I am lucky that I can help all my family. I feel that I have fulfilled something and I feel good about that. I also want to give something to football in my country. I would like to open a soccer academy in Zagreb and I have prepared all the plans for next year. I want to employ some coaches to teach groups from 8-10 years, 10-12, etc. Most of all I want to teach them how to score goals. I would like to talk to the youngsters to explain what qualities you need - how you need to control the ball, how you need to feel when you are one on one with the goalkeeper. The best word is cold. We are a small country and I hope everyone will help to promote Croatia, to make the country stronger and happier, more than just the beautiful Adriatic Sea.

What do you like and dislike most about living in England?
I like organisation and England is a very organised country. I lived eight years in Spain and two years in England and I would like to live in Croatia with the same kind of respect for rules I have seen on my travels. Sometimes we are stifled by too many restrictions. I like the fact everybody here has a chance, and there are so many opportunities. I would like to have the same in my country, where kids finish school and they don't have jobs. The percentage of unemployment is much worse than England. I hope we will be in the European Community soon. It's vital. What do I dislike about England? Come on, the weather! But having said that we footballers have privileges, we have five airports in London and in two hours you are on the coast.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
Sit in a café and enjoy a cappuccino or a cup of tea with my friends. I like a cup of tea. I have many friends here from different nationalities and it's beautiful to enjoy that cosmopolitan variety in London. After tea I have a Spanish siesta, one hour minimum, where I can go into my world, my totally private sanctuary.

Have you learned to speak English?
I have some books, and my friends correct me when I make a mistake. Sometimes it's funny but I'm not scared of language. I'm not perfect but I'm not an English man. I'm Croatian and I'm learning.

Is English football better or worse than you expected?
Champions League is one test of a club's quality. Manchester United won recently, and although last year Spanish teams were very dominant now we have many teams who play very well, which reflects well on the Premier League. The standard is how I expected.

Is the atmosphere in the dressing room different to that in other countries?
One hundred per cent. I've learned something new here. Before I didn't used to smile before the game, never experienced loud music and a hot atmosphere. In the past in Europe I have come across some coaches who didn't speak, didn't like joking, didn't like music. It's democratic here. The philosophy is for the players to go on the pitch and give everything and after the game it's history, victory or defeat. You get over things quicker here than in other countries. Harry Redknapp is my first English coach and we have a good relationship. He is so honest. I caught something positive from my first impressions of him and I like to fight for this man.

How does training differ from what you are used to?
It was better with Arsenal! But it's a lovely atmosphere at the training ground. It's a smaller club than Arsenal but I really enjoy it. Because we don't have European competition we have a couple more days free, which is maybe good for the league. That could be important if we want to make the top six.

What do you like most about English football?
The chanting. Things like "You're not singing anymore!" We listen to it out on the pitch and it pushes you.

What do you like least about English football?
Losing, but that's the same in any country.

How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
I like the fact the fans stay behind you even when you lose. I haven't experienced this loyalty before, where they never turn on the players. It's not like that in Spain or Italy, where there is more negaitvity and people saying bad things.

Have you experienced racism by opponents or opposing fans?
No, and if I heard such stuff I would leave. I support the Kick the Racism out of Football campaign. You need to open people's minds. Football has given me my life and I have to respect it for that.

How long do you think you will stay in English football?
Er... 10 years! I wait for an English passport! Honestly, you never know. I am 32 (he was 33 on 1 January) and I want to keep playing as long as possible. At the moment I would like to finish my career here, but in football you never know.

fields.headline: Fan Zhiyi
fields.trailText: Born in China, now playing for Crystal Palace
fields.body:
Birthplace: Shanghai, China
Now playing for Crystal Palace in the First Division
Age: 30
Position: Central defender/striker
Joined Crystal Palace for £700,000 from Shanghai Shenhua in September 1998
Appearances: 85 (1)

Did you get to see English football as a child, and did you support anyone?
As a young footballer in Shanghai, I watched the old English Division One whenever I could. Today's Premiership is on Chinese TV all the time, but even ten years ago we saw a lot of the old Division One. And, yes, I watched Crystal Palace a lot. They finished third in 1991 behind Arsenal and Liverpool, with Ian Wright scoring constantly. But in the years before that I most enjoyed watching Liverpool pass and move the ball, with people like Ray Houghton who coaches here now, and watching players like Glenn Hoddle. They were my favourites, but the pace and passion of the whole game here has always attracted me.

First played professional football for?
Shanghai.

How did your move to England come about?
Terry Venables spotted me during England's tour of China in 1996, and Ted Buxton, China's former coach and then a coach at Crystal Palace, knew about Sun Jihai. They signed both of us after we came over here on tour in 1998.

Had you heard of Crystal Palace before you joined them?
Well, as I said, Ian Wright was an inspiration for me. Palace had a great time in the early 90s, and now I want to help us do it again.

What were your first impressions of English football?

I was shocked by the speed and aggression, even though I was expecting a very different style to that at Shanghai. The game moves so quickly - defence turns to attack in an instant - but my coaches and colleagues helped me adjust and cope with the pace. The concentration needed to play successfully here is high, but I think now IÕm playing better this season than last.

Where are you living now?
I have bought a house in Purley, which is a nice place to live. All the neighbours are very generous, and my wife and our little girl Fan Si Jing are very happy - my daughter even knows a few words of English. But when I first arrived I was living in the Selsdon Park Hotel in Croydon: a very nice hotel for golfers but I don't play I golf. I did feel very isolated. But Jihai and I gave each other moral support, and everyone at the club helped us settle down, everyone looked after us. We soon overcame the initial fears and loneliness.

Have you got any family over with you?
Besides my wife and daughter, my parents come to watch when it is possible. They are both sportspeople - my father played for Shanghai too, long before football in China became professional in 1994, while my mother was an international athlete. They are very pleased to see what I am doing now, and enjoy their visits to London and to Selhurst Park.

Do you send any money home?
No - we are comfortable.

What do you like and dislike about living in England?
The food, when I arrived, was a problem - perhaps the biggest apart from language, but I have grown used to it now. But culturally, England hasn't presented us with many problems as it is a more relaxed society. I particularly like the people here. Being famous in China can be overwhelming, but here there is more space and friendship.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
Apart from spending time with my family, I love to watch football on the television. Everyday I think. Spanish football is the best in the world at the moment, but the Premiership and First Division here is also very enjoyable and very educative.

Is English football better or worse than you expected?
It is much as I expected - very strong, powerful, passionate, and at the top level is beautiful. Beckham is a lovely player.

Have you learned to speak English?
My English is developing. Some of my teammates pretend they can speak Chinese to me.

Is the atmosphere in the dressing room different to other countries?
Because Chinese professional football is still in its infancy, there is a difference, yes. Everyone here is more sure of themselves, and more focused.

How does training differ from what you are used to at home?
In China, training is very strict, fitness based and regimented. Here there is more technique and tactical coaching, plus more individual advice.

How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
Crystal Palace fans are very loud - even when we're very bad, they continue to shout. It is wonderful for all of us when we are playing towards the Holmesdale Road end of the ground, as the noise when we attack is astonishing. In China, if you score or win the crowd will be pleased, if you concede they will go home. They are very enthusiastic - 100 million watched when I first played for Palace on television - but they are not yet so committed to clubs. Here, when we score at Selhurst Park the players, crowd and coaches become one. Now I feel hugely welcomed by the supporters: at first I think they weren't sure about me, but now everyone sees me and calls me Fan. I am very happy.

Have you ever experienced racism by opponents or opposing fans?
No, nothing. Everyone I deal with is very good towards me - they don't say 'there's that Chinese man', they say 'there's that footballer', and come and talk to me about football. It is a nice place to live.

How long do you think you will stay in English football?
I have a great passion for England, and for Crystal Palace. I hope to recommend younger Chinese players to the gaffer, and I hope we will continue to bring Chinese players to England, as it helps the club and the players' quality. China is very keen to qualify for the World Cup, so the management have encouraged players to seek European experience. Personally, I want to become a coach eventually, and hope to learn how to coach in England with the FA qualifications, then maybe use that knowledge here or to teach younger Chinese players. But I have a lot of playing time left, I hope.

fields.headline: Alex Calvo-Garcia
fields.trailText: Born in Spain, now playing for Scunthorpe
fields.body:
Birthplace: Ordizia, Spain
Now playing for Scunthorpe in the Third Division
Age: 28
Position: Midfielder
Joined Scunthorpe on a free transfer in October 1996
Appearances:
145 (12)

Did you get to see English football as a child, and did you support anyone?
Football was invented in England, so naturally I took an interest in it. I thought it looked fantastic from the outside, fast and exciting, more so than in Spain. I didn't support any one team though.

First played professional football for?
Beasin, a small team based in the Basque country.

How did your move to England come about?
My career wasn't going brilliantly in Spain, with Eiber, and I wanted a new challenge in a new country. My agent told me that Scunthorpe were having a trial and I flew over to try out. They offered me a contract and that was that.

Had you heard of Scunthorpe before you joined them?
No. I had to look it up on the map!

What were your first impressions of English football?
Everyone at the club and in the town were very friendly to me. I knew I was coming to a small club, but I didn't realise how small a city Scunthorpe was. But the atmosphere! The atmosphere more than made up for any misgivings I had about the status of the club. It shocked me how well organized everything was.

Where are you living now?
I started off, like most foreign players, staying in a hotel, which was a little cold and lonely. Now I have a nice house in Scunthorpe.

Have you got any family over with you?
My wife Leira, who is Spanish, came over with me from the beginning, which was a great help.

Do you send any money home?
No. My family in Spain are comfortable so I don't have to.

What do you like and dislike about living in England?
I love the privacy. The Spanish media are always in your face, but over here I can walk down the street and people, even if they know who you are, give you respect. I miss the obvious things, like family and friends. I go back to Spain as much as I can though, especially in the summer, so it's not too bad.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
I usually relax at home, just spending time with my wife, or maybe I'll go and play golf or tennis. I've also learnt to play snooker since I've been in England - we don't really play it in Spain, but all the Scunthorpe lads play it, so I've gradually picked it up.

Is English football better or worse than you expected?
Probably better. The games are always exciting, played at a fast pace and with lots of goals.

Have you learned to speak English?
I had lessons with a tutor, but mostly I pick up stuff from the rest of the players, not always repeatable though!

Is the atmosphere in the dressing room different to other countries?
Not so different from Spain. I think dressing rooms are the same the world over. You get nervous wherever you play, and you also get that dressing room humour which calms the nerves.

How does training differ from what you are used to at home?
We train for shorter periods in Spain and it's more technical. Over here the emphasis is on fitness. We train long hours, but you have to, it's the nature of the game over here.

How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
Supporters in Spain can turn against you after a couple of bad results. In England the fans are very loyal, they support you through thick and thin.

Have you ever experienced racism by opponents or opposing fans?
No I haven't - if I have, I haven't noticed! When youÍre on the pitch you don't really notice because the action is so frantic. I can't recall any bad experiences.

How long do you think you will stay in English football?
I'll go back when I've finished my career or when I start missing my family too much - whichever happens first. I have two years left on my contract so my wife and I will talk it through and come to the right decision. I'm very happy at Scunthorpe though. It's an education.

fields.headline: Baichung Bhutia
fields.trailText: Born in India, now playing for Bury.
fields.body:
Birthplace: Tinkitam, Sikkim, India
Now playing for Bury in the Second Division
Age: 23
Position: Forward
Joined Bury on a free transfer in August 1999
Appearances: 17 (19)

Did you get to see English football as a child, and did you support anyone?
Not as a child. Satellite channels only became available in India about three years ago, so I was already playing when I first started to watch it. I never supported anyone, I just enjoyed watching a good game and liked teams that played good football. Growing up, I watched a lot of local football and like everyone else in India, had local heroes. I always used to watch the World Cup on TV, and I really admired Maradona.

First played professional football for?
East Bengal, who I joined as a semi-professional when I left school. No one in India is a full-time professional, even the well known players. I also played for a team called JCT but only for one season.

How did your move to England come about?
When I first came over I had a trial at Aston Villa, but I ended up at Bury because my agent knew someone who was good friends with their manager Neil Warnock. He gave me a trial and it went from there.

Had you heard of Bury before you joined them?
No.

What were your first impressions of English football?
I found it very difficult to start with, I was used to playing in India where obviously the temperature is very high, so the style of play is totally different - a lot slower. As well as the fast pace of the game, I had to get used to the physical aspect of English football, which is a lot tougher than I what I was used to back home.

Where are you living now?
As soon as I joined Bury, they helped me find my own place, where I am still living now.

Have you got any family over with you?
No. I went to see them all this summer and while I continue playing, I'm going to try and go home to see them at least once a year.

Do you send any money home?
No I don't, not at the moment anyway.

What do you like and dislike about living in England?
Obviously I miss my family and my friends, so it can get lonely sometimes. I knew when I joined, that coming from a different culture, speaking a different language I was going to have a difficult time to start with. Back home, I am surrounded by friends, so coming here to live on my own was a big challenge. But I was prepared and very determined to make a success of it. It took me a couple of months to settle in and get used to things.

What do you do in the afternoons and evenings?
I usually leave the training ground after lunch, and either relax at home, go out to get some food or go to the cinema - whatever I feel like really. Manchester is close by so I occasionally go there. Some evenings I go out with the other players and friends for a meal or for a few drinks, although I'm not a big drinker.

Is English football better or worse than you expected?
I always knew the standard of football was very high in England, so I expected it to be difficult. The facilities over here are very good. In India training grounds are unheard of and even the big clubs don't have them.

Have you learned to speak English?
In India, you learn English in grammar school. You are told it is very important to learn to speak English, so when I came over there wasn't really a problem.

Is the atmosphere in the dressing room different to other countries?
It is very different. At home there is a lot more tension, because the crowds are very big, and their expectations are so high. It puts a lot of pressure on the players to do well, especially in the home games. Here, everyone is very focused and relaxed before the game, which I think is the best way to be. If you win it is great because you get a big reaction from all the players, which is a lot of fun.

How does training differ from what you are used to at home?
Here the training is more technical than back in India and you get to learn a lot of things. Also you get assigned specific jobs to do in matches. At home there are less tactics. The training here is very hard and professional and I know that I will benefit from that.

How do English fans compare to those in other countries you have played in?
At home I used to regularly play in front of crowds of over 30,000. The Salt Lake Stadium where I played for East Bengal can hold well over a 100,000 and if it was a derby match it would be full. However, in the regular matches, because the stadium is so big the atmosphere could sometimes get lost. Here, even if you are playing in front of 4,000 people, because the grounds are very compact and the fans are so close to the pitch you can hear everything, so they make just as much noise as the crowds at home.

Have you ever experienced racism by opponents or opposing fans?
No I haven't. So far all of the fans have been very supportive of me.

How long do you think you will stay in English football?
As long as I have a club, I'm playing well and enjoying it.

fields.headline: Overrated/underrated
fields.trailText: The World footballer of the year award and Ken Bates.
fields.body:
Overrated
The world footballer of the year award

Zinedine Zidane's coronation as world player of the year was a bit like a film getting an Oscar for a couple of good scenes (or, in the case of Titanic, one good scene). Zidane is not overrated, but the award certainly is. What Zidane was (as Luis Figo observed) was world player of June - his brilliance leading France to triumph in Euro 2000. But that apart the Frenchman played reasonably but not brilliantly for a Juventus side pipped by Lazio for the Italian title and humiliated in successive European competitions - the latter of which saw him sent off twice.

Figo was a worthier winner, so was David Beckham, who Zidane himself thought should have finished higher than sixth. So how did Zidane win? Well the Fifa award is based on the votes of 150 national coaches, who nominate their top three but are not allowed to vote for compatriots. It seems a fair systemuntil you look at the list. Then you can't helping detecting a regional, if not national, bias. How else can you explain Kanu's joint 21st placing (ahead of Roy Keane and every Englishmen except Beckham) after a year in which his form stagnated at Arsenal? Not that Kanu's is the most ludicrous placing. That honour goes to Paolo Wanchope, also joint 21st, thanks to the first-place vote of the Costa Rican coach, whose rule-breaking Fifa chose to ignore. Thus was an already questionable poll reduced to farce.

Underrated
Ken Bates

Ken Bates is not a popular man. He is, however, a terrific football club chairman. When he bought Chelsea in 1982 they were a second-rate, Second Division club with little except a stack of debts, a crumbling ground and a reputation for having some of the nastiest fans in the country. They were managed by John Neal and fielded players like Gary Locke, Mike Fillery and the aptly named John Bumstead (though Yugoslav keeper Peter Borotra did offer the faintest whiff of what was to come). Teams who would naturally consider themselves Chelsea's superior not only included the obvious ones (Spurs and Everton) but also Nottingham Forest and West Brom - and arguably all 40 teams that finished above Chelsea in Bates's first season at Stamford Bridge.

And now? Now Chelsea fans take for granted watching the likes of Marcel Desailly and Gianfranco Zola every week in a rebuilt stadium. For all their recent wobbles, only a handful of clubs can consider themselves bigger. Along the way Chelsea have won two FA Cups, the League Cup, the Cup-Winners' and even the Zenith Data Systems. What's more, Bates has been a relentless opponent of the Chelsea racists (thankfully a declining minority) and for all his recent problems about the Wembley redevelopment did at least get one thing right. The idea that the new stadium should have an athletics track around the pitch is absurd. And he said so.

When he bought Chelsea in 1982 they were a second-rate, Second Division club with little except a stack of debts, a crumbling ground and a reputation for having some of the nastiest fans in the country. They were managed by John Neal and fielded players like Gary Locke, Mike Fillery and the aptly named John Bumstead (though Yugoslav keeper Peter Borotra did offer the faintest whiff of what was to come). Teams who would naturally consider themselves Chelsea's superior not only included the obvious ones (Spurs and Everton) but also Nottingham Forest and West Brom - and arguably all 40 teams that finished above Chelsea in Bates's first season at Stamford Bridge. And now? Now Chelsea fans take for granted watching the likes of Marcel Desailly and Gianfranco Zola every week in a rebuilt stadium. For all their recent wobbles, only a handful of clubs can consider themselves bigger. Along the way Chelsea have won two FA Cups, the League Cup, the Cup-Winners' and even the Zenith Data Systems. What's more, Bates has been a relentless opponent of the Chelsea racists (thankfully a declining minority) and for all his recent problems about the Wembley redevelopment did at least get one thing right. The idea that the new stadium should have an athletics track around the pitch is absurd. And he said so.

fields.headline: My teamChelsea
fields.standfirst: David Baddiel
fields.trailText: David Baddiel
fields.body:
When Chelsea won the FA Cup in 1970, I was six - too young to know what it meant. My older brother Ivor was really excited about it and I just fell in with him. Chelsea seemed very glamorous. I remember collecting stickers of players like Charlie Cooke, Alan Hudson and Peter Osgood. But when I was old enough to be allowed to go, they'd all gone. Going to Chelsea then was horrible. The Shed was very violent - Chelsea fans fought each other as well as opposing fans - and I was constantly frightened.

Until recently it's been pretty much all lean times. We won things like the Second Division Championship and Zenith Data Trophy and had disgusting yellow shirts. I stopped going for a bit in the Eighties when I became a total nonce for a while. I was very politically correct then and elements of Chelsea were racist and horrible. There's still a hardcore of unpleasant fans at Chelsea. Three of them were behind my seat for a while, so I moved.

The renaissance began with Glenn Hoddle. He gave us ambition - and brought in Ruud Gullit. He's probably the best Chelsea player I've seen. He was still a great player when he came. Even when they're getting on, great players like Gullit and Hoddle are still fantastic because of their confidence on the ball.

I have a season ticket in the East Stand Upper Tier. It's less atmospheric than The Shed, but you don't get the complete morons. My season ticket costs £870, which is ridiculous, I know. I can afford it, but I know people who used to sit with me in the West Stand, lifelong supporters, who don't go any more because they can't afford it.

I don't mention this to Ken Bates. I've had problems with him in the past mainly because I was a friend of Matthew Harding's and he's a little suspicious of any friend of Matthew's. Matthew and I became friends because he was a big fan of Fantasy Football and we went to some away games together. I don't want to comment on Ken Bates because he's the chairman and I don't want to be banned! He could make my life very difficult.

After the drudgery of the Seventies and Eighties, the best times have been winning the Cup in 1997 and the Cup Winners Cup the year after. That was brilliant but I had a terrible day in Stockholm. My plane over was full of Combat 18 types, there was fighting everywhere. Then I couldn't get home again because they sealed off Stockholm Airport to Chelsea fans, so by the time I got in all the planes had gone and the place looked like a refugee camp.

This team can be very successful. But they need a midfield player of vision, someone like Beckham. They should have a backbone of English players and have our best foreigners play around them. At the moment we have all foreigners, who feel a bit disparate. But Chelsea have always been slightly exotic. We're not like Leicester; we'll never do well through solidity and organisation. It's always going to be a side of glamorous individuals. But to be really successful, we need that one player: either Zidane or the Paul Gascoigne of 10 years ago. Or was he already fucked by then?'

 'Baddiel Syndrome' starts on Sky One on 14 January.

David Baddiel was talking to Denis Campbell.

fields.headline: Want a job, old thing?
fields.standfirst: An ageist bias  against staff is to be illegal, writes Neasa MacErlean. Victims will be eligible for big payouts
fields.trailText: Most people aged 25 and over are nervous about their job prospects in an ageist culture. But in five years' time ageism in the workforce is due to be outlawed, and employment experts believe there will be major improvements in the lot of older workers.
fields.body:
Most people aged 25 and over are nervous about their job prospects in an ageist culture. But in five years' time ageism in the workforce is due to be outlawed, and employment experts believe there will be major improvements in the lot of older workers.

A European Union directive agreed last October bans discrimination at work on the grounds of sexual orientation and religion by 2002, and bias due to disability and age by 2006. Solicitor James Davies of Lewis Silkin says the move against ageism will have a big impact: 'Prejudices about older workers not fitting into a young, thrusting executive style will be difficult to sustain. Employers who recruit young people all the time or get rid of older people who don't fit the clichéd image will be facing claims in employment tribunals.'

Britain's agreement to go forward with this EU directive came as something of a surprise. The Government, which had favoured anti-ageism legislation before being elected in 1997, had dragged its feet. In 1999, it issued a 'voluntary code of practice' against ageism for employers - but research from the Employers' Forum on Age lobbying group suggests that, currently, only a third of employers are aware of this code, let alone adhere to it.

The Government, under pressure from employers, slowed down the European negotiations until last October, when the other nations agreed to some of the UK demands (exempting the armed forces from anti-ageism laws, for instance) and plans for the directive were finally put in motion. This spring, the Forum will start to campaign and lobby on the final form of the UK law, which will be needed to implement the directive. The directive sets out a bare minimum: all sorts of discussions will need to take place to define 'older workers' and what counts as discrimination against them.

The law will also protect 'younger workers' who could, for example, allege that ageism is working against them in job advertisements which require a considerable amount of experience. In the summer, there will be another opportunity to publicise the issue: the Government is due to report back on its own evaluation of the voluntary code.

Although details of the UK law have still to be agreed, it is widely expected that victims of ageism will be able to claim unlimited damages in employment tribunals. Since claims for race, sex, disability and whistleblowing discrimination are uncapped, it is difficult to imagine that a limit could be justified on claims in the new areas of religion, sexual orientation and age.

This will mean that the practices of employers will have to change dramatically. In the huge downsizing programmes of the Nineties, many employers routinely kicked out their older workers first. Only 5 per cent of the banking workforce, for example, is estimated by banking union Unifi to be over 50.

When they selected people for redundancy, many employers specifically cited age as a selection criterion. In many instances, businesses benefited financially from getting rid of older workers - because they were paid more and many were in 'final salary' pension schemes, where the employer's costs are high for staff in their fifties and sixties.

The new regime will outlaw this approach, and employers who flout the law will pay heavily in compensation.

David Whincup, employment law specialist at solicitor Hammond Suddards Edge, says: 'Until now, the traditional victim of ageism - the middle-aged white man - didn't have any rights to speak of.'

From 2006, however, he can claim unfair dismissal on grounds of age. Since it will be so easy for anyone middle-aged to make a claim, Whincup believes employers will have to become far better at management in general: 'This will force employers to do proper appraisals and to take action if, for example, they are dealing with employees who are genuinely slowing down, resistant to change or resentful of young Turks in management. These issues are all extremely difficult to prove.'

So, if your bosses are worried about your ability to do the job, for example, they should make their concerns clear to you, document the steps taken and follow disciplinary procedures to the letter. These moves will reduce your chance of success if you later make a claim on grounds of ageism.

But this begs the question of why ageism exists at all. Since we are all getting older, ageist practices are an example of turkeys voting for Christmas. 'The media is still very focused on the young,' says Charlotte Thorne of the Industrial Society, citing research which shows that the over-sixties appear in only 9 per cent of advertisements and TV coverage, even though they represent more than 20 per cent of the population.

'The directive is a good signal to employers,' Thorne says, 'but the biggest changes need to come from people's minds.'

Ageism seems to come in waves, reaching peaks at times of greatest change, when older people are seen as lacking skills which children are learning at school. This is why the Government is concentrating so hard on 'lifelong learning' and spreading access to the internet to us all.

But if even the 2006 legislation is not enough, commercial factors will play a huge role in strengthening the hand of the older worker. Nick Burkitt of the Institute for Public Policy Research says: 'In a tightening labour market such as we now have, employers are going to get increasingly desperate and will have to take on older people, whether they like it or not. They will then realise how stupid they were not to do so before.'

As the Employers' Forum on Age frequently says, there are many business arguments for retaining older staff. Barry Chambers, of Family Assurance in Brighton, values older salespeople: 'You need people who can talk to customers. People like to deal with people they can trust, which tends to be older people because they have the experience.'

How Nationwide wised up

In the past decade, the Nationwide building society has pushed up the proportion of staff aged over 50 in its workforce from 1 to 10 per cent - a move that is now paying dividends in a tightening labour market.

It realised it faced big future manpower problems, and a high staff turnover was reducing productivity. So, as a starting point, it introduced age into its equal opportunities policy. But to help ensure that this happened it began interviewing applicants for branch jobs by telephone to reduce the possibility of prejudice based on age and appearance. 'We are measuring the person's talent rather than their previous job history,' says Denise Walker, head of corporate personnel. 'This is about the person's contribution, not about their shape, size, colour or age.'

Backing up this approach was a flexible benefits system which catered for individuals, rather than the stereotypical family. So the society's 13,000 employees can, for example, choose to have time off to look after elderly parents if they wish - flexibility which makes life easier for older workers.

More controversial was abolishing age-related pay increments. Pay is now linked to a staff member's 'contribution' (measured through achievements, personal development and approach to work) rather than length of service. After 10, 20, 30 or 40 years, staff do get a one-off gift or financial reward for their loyalty, but these are one-offs, and not built into basic pay.

Nationwide is cited as a model of anti-ageism and recently won a Personnel Today award for this. The changes have brought great benefits for the organisation, says Walker: 'We had a huge turnover and we needed stability. People often want to learn from other people, but it's harder for young people to learn from others in the same age group. They wanted the wisdom of older people.'

webTitle: How to cope with after-work drink

fields.headline: How to cope with after-work drink
fields.trailText: 1 Recognise that this subject is only usually a big problem for two groups of people - those who don't like this kind of fraternising and those who like it too much. In many offices you will be viewed as disloyal and suspect if you never visit the pub. Colleagues whose whole lives are bound up in the workplace are likely to feel slighted if you don't want to spend some of your unpaid hours with them. Some occupations - particularly journalism and the army - used to see heavy drinking as part of the job description, but this situation started to improve in the health and efficiency-conscious late Nineties. Force yourself down the boozer with good grace occasionally, and make up a good long-term excuse why you can't go regularly - children are useful. On no account reveal that you are actually a dipsomaniac.
fields.body:
1 Recognise that this subject is only usually a big problem for two groups of people - those who don't like this kind of fraternising and those who like it too much. In many offices you will be viewed as disloyal and suspect if you never visit the pub. Colleagues whose whole lives are bound up in the workplace are likely to feel slighted if you don't want to spend some of your unpaid hours with them. Some occupations - particularly journalism and the army - used to see heavy drinking as part of the job description, but this situation started to improve in the health and efficiency-conscious late Nineties. Force yourself down the boozer with good grace occasionally, and make up a good long-term excuse why you can't go regularly - children are useful. On no account reveal that you are actually a dipsomaniac.

2 Appreciate the dangers of always being in the pub. Although you won't further your career by avoiding the pub completely, you won't help it by being there all the time. However popular you are with drinking buddies, you will ultimately be regarded as a soak by the powers that be. Take your cue from your bosses: the more time they spend in the pub or wine bar, the more they will be happy for you to spend time there.

Watch for the obvious traps. 'Getting plastered can lead to sexual encounters if you are not careful,' warns Gladys, an office politician who used to spend most Friday evenings with colleagues in the pub. The aftermath can be particularly grim if you linked up with someone married, or embarrassed about the liaison, or eager to get involved when you are not.

3 Understand that after-work drinks are good fun and worthwhile for most. 'You can get some good work ideas,' says psychologist Sandi Mann. Gladys agrees: 'The bonding side is important. Even if you don't feel at home, remember that every group needs listeners. If you nod and laugh at everyone's jokes, they'll think you're wonderful.' An hour in a pub can forge more camaraderie than a year at your desk.

4 Buy your round. 'If you are the boss, buy more than your share,' says former boss Ian. If you're poor, buy your own drinks and don't join in rounds - but explain why in a jolly and open fashion.

5 Set up a slightly erratic pattern to your pub visits. If you go every Tuesday, colleagues may feel neglected if you start going less often. 'If people say "We don't see Fred as often as we used to," they could be offended,' says Ian.

webTitle: People who live in grass houses

fields.headline: People who live in grass houses
fields.standfirst: A design revolution is saving money - and the planet, reports Terry Slavin
fields.trailText: At Gap Inc's office complex in San Bruno, California, planes fly low overhead, on their final descent into San Francisco's international airport. But for the 600 employees who work there the polluting crates are but a distant rumble, drowned by birdsong from the more natural winged creatures living in the building's grass roof.
fields.body:
At Gap Inc's office complex in San Bruno, California, planes fly low overhead, on their final descent into San Francisco's international airport. But for the 600 employees who work there the polluting crates are but a distant rumble, drowned by birdsong from the more natural winged creatures living in the building's grass roof.

The complex, built in 1997, is constructed along industrial ecology lines, a revolution in industrial design and architecture that is not confined to ageing San Francisco flower children, but gathering pace across the world. Even manufacturing behemoth the Ford Motor Company is planning a major overhaul of its largest plant which will revolutionise the way it makes cars, all under a grass roof.

The roofs of the Gap complex, which uses 30 per cent less energy than the maximum permitted by law, are planted with native grasses and wild flowers atop six inches of soil. They act as a thermal and acoustic insulator, almost obviating the need for air conditioning - and they absorb the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide.

High ceilings, huge atriums and interior courtyards bring natural light deep into the buildings.

Architect William McDonough says this is the next industrial revolution: design that works with, not against, nature. For him eco-efficiency, under the mantra 'reduce, reuse, recycle', does not go far enough. He and Michael Braungart argue in their book The Next Industrial Revolution: 'It works within the system that caused the problem in the first place. Relying on eco-efficiency to save the environment will in fact achieve the opposite. It will let industry finish off everything quietly, persistently, and completely.'

When Rohner Textil, a struggling Swiss textile factory, went looking for an environmentally safe upholstery fabric, it thought it had hit on an ideal combination: cotton and Pet [Polyethylene Terephthalate] fibres from recycled beverage bottles. But when McDonough and Braungart looked at the proposal they realised that Pet would prevent the fabric from composting safely, while the cotton would prevent it from being reused in an industrial cycle - meaning the product would end its life in landfill.

The team decided on a mixture of organically grown ramie - a plant fibre - and wool from free-range sheep. The tricky bit was finding biodegradable dyes. Of 8,000 chemicals tested, only 38 came up clean, yet they were sufficient to make an entire garment line in every colour but black. In fact the manufacturing process was so clean that when regulators tested the plant's effluent they thought their instruments were broken: the water going out was as clean as that going in.

'The new design not only bypassed traditional three-R responses to environmental problems but also eliminated the need for regulations,' say the authors. 'In our next industrial revolution, regulations can be seen as signals of design failure.'

Amory Lovins, of the Rocky Mountain Institute in Denver, another leading thinker in industrial ecology, jokes that it makes sense to learn the lessons of 3.8 billion years of evolution: 'Whatever didn't work had already been recalled by the manufacturer.' In Natural Capitalism, he, Paul Hawken, and L Hunter Lovins, argue that environment-friendly technologies are less important than a design approach that emulates nature by looking at the entire system, rather than bits of it.

They point to Interface, the international flooring company, which, in designing its new Shanghai carpet factory, realised that two simple changes to conventional factory design would cut power requirements by 92 per cent. The Interface engineer, Jan Schilham, chose fatter-than-usual pipes, which create much less friction than thin pipes and thus need less pumping energy. Conventional design theory is that the extra cost of fatter pipes isn't justified by savings in pumping energy, but Schilham also took into account the lower capital cost of smaller pumps. This justified the fatter pipes without considering future energy saving.

His second innovation was to locate equipment so that connecting pipes were short and straight rather than long and crooked - an inversion of standard practice.

Since pumping is the commonest application of motors, and motors use three-quarters of all industrial electricity, the energy savings if all companies followed Interface's lead would be staggering.

'This isn't rocket science,' say the authors. 'Often it's just a rediscovery of good Victorian engineering principles that have been lost because of specialisation.'

Bill Ford, chairman of Ford Motor Company, regularly invokes his great-grandfather Henry's name when outlining his vision for a $2 billion overhaul of the company's Rouge plant in Detroit, the first mass-manufacturing plant in the world. Ford wants to make it an icon of lean, green manufacturing.

Environmental improvements include the 454,000 sq ft grass roof - punctuated by skylights - which will reduce stormwater runoff, absorb carbon dioxide, and moderate temperatures by 10 F in summer and winter, and an experiment in using plants to clean contaminated soil. Fuel cells will power computer systems, while wind power may also be introduced.

The new assembly plant will build three vehicle platforms at a time instead of one, and reduce the number of workstations by 40 per cent. It will also halve storage for finished vehicles.

Ford has already invested $1bn in cleaning up its paint processes, typically responsible for up to three-quarters of an auto plant's toxic waste.

The Rouge overhaul is a first step towards Ford's greater vision of 'cradle-to cradle' manufacturing, the Holy Grail of the industrial ecology movement - manufacturing that produces no waste.

Ford has already talked about 'renting' rather than selling its cars in the future; US elevator company Schindler prefers to lease rather than sell its products so it can capture the savings from its elevators' lower energy costs. Dow Chemical prefers to lease its dissolving services rather than sell solvents because it can reuse the same solvent many times, reducing costs as well as emissions.

fields.bodyText: At Gap Inc's office complex in San Bruno, California, planes fly low overhead, on their final descent into San Francisco's international airport. But for the 600 employees who work there the polluting crates are but a distant rumble, drowned by birdsong from the more natural winged creatures living in the building's grass roof. The complex, built in 1997, is constructed along industrial ecology lines, a revolution in industrial design and architecture that is not confined to ageing San Francisco flower children, but gathering pace across the world. Even manufacturing behemoth the Ford Motor Company is planning a major overhaul of its largest plant which will revolutionise the way it makes cars, all under a grass roof. The roofs of the Gap complex, which uses 30 per cent less energy than the maximum permitted by law, are planted with native grasses and wild flowers atop six inches of soil. They act as a thermal and acoustic insulator, almost obviating the need for air conditioning - and they absorb the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide. High ceilings, huge atriums and interior courtyards bring natural light deep into the buildings. Architect William McDonough says this is the next industrial revolution: design that works with, not against, nature. For him eco-efficiency, under the mantra 'reduce, reuse, recycle', does not go far enough. He and Michael Braungart argue in their book The Next Industrial Revolution: 'It works within the system that caused the problem in the first place. Relying on eco-efficiency to save the environment will in fact achieve the opposite. It will let industry finish off everything quietly, persistently, and completely.' When Rohner Textil, a struggling Swiss textile factory, went looking for an environmentally safe upholstery fabric, it thought it had hit on an ideal combination: cotton and Pet [Polyethylene Terephthalate] fibres from recycled beverage bottles. But when McDonough and Braungart looked at the proposal they realised that Pet would prevent the fabric from composting safely, while the cotton would prevent it from being reused in an industrial cycle - meaning the product would end its life in landfill. The team decided on a mixture of organically grown ramie - a plant fibre - and wool from free-range sheep. The tricky bit was finding biodegradable dyes. Of 8,000 chemicals tested, only 38 came up clean, yet they were sufficient to make an entire garment line in every colour but black. In fact the manufacturing process was so clean that when regulators tested the plant's effluent they thought their instruments were broken: the water going out was as clean as that going in. 'The new design not only bypassed traditional three-R responses to environmental problems but also eliminated the need for regulations,' say the authors. 'In our next industrial revolution, regulations can be seen as signals of design failure.' Amory Lovins, of the Rocky Mountain Institute in Denver, another leading thinker in industrial ecology, jokes that it makes sense to learn the lessons of 3.8 billion years of evolution: 'Whatever didn't work had already been recalled by the manufacturer.' In Natural Capitalism, he, Paul Hawken, and L Hunter Lovins, argue that environment-friendly technologies are less important than a design approach that emulates nature by looking at the entire system, rather than bits of it. They point to Interface, the international flooring company, which, in designing its new Shanghai carpet factory, realised that two simple changes to conventional factory design would cut power requirements by 92 per cent. The Interface engineer, Jan Schilham, chose fatter-than-usual pipes, which create much less friction than thin pipes and thus need less pumping energy. Conventional design theory is that the extra cost of fatter pipes isn't justified by savings in pumping energy, but Schilham also took into account the lower capital cost of smaller pumps. This justified the fatter pipes without considering future energy saving. His second innovation was to locate equipment so that connecting pipes were short and straight rather than long and crooked - an inversion of standard practice. Since pumping is the commonest application of motors, and motors use three-quarters of all industrial electricity, the energy savings if all companies followed Interface's lead would be staggering. 'This isn't rocket science,' say the authors. 'Often it's just a rediscovery of good Victorian engineering principles that have been lost because of specialisation.' Bill Ford, chairman of Ford Motor Company, regularly invokes his great-grandfather Henry's name when outlining his vision for a $2 billion overhaul of the company's Rouge plant in Detroit, the first mass-manufacturing plant in the world. Ford wants to make it an icon of lean, green manufacturing. Environmental improvements include the 454,000 sq ft grass roof - punctuated by skylights - which will reduce stormwater runoff, absorb carbon dioxide, and moderate temperatures by 10 F in summer and winter, and an experiment in using plants to clean contaminated soil. Fuel cells will power computer systems, while wind power may also be introduced. The new assembly plant will build three vehicle platforms at a time instead of one, and reduce the number of workstations by 40 per cent. It will also halve storage for finished vehicles. Ford has already invested $1bn in cleaning up its paint processes, typically responsible for up to three-quarters of an auto plant's toxic waste.
